Author: ALDANOV, A. D.
Title: 25 years work of Saratov Central Station of plant-breeding and genetics.
Abstract Note: Among the achievements of the station in wheat breeding one of the most outstanding referred to is the production of the spring wheat Lutescens 062 by individual plant selection. This variety has yielded an average of 14.3 c. per ha. over a period of nineteen years and on account of its drought resistance has outyielded the local " Poltavka " in the seven worst drought years by 34.2 per cent. Various other varieties both of T. vulgare and T. durum have been produced by the same method, e.g.-Erythrospermum 0341 and T. durum hordeiforme 0432. By interspecific crossing the famous varieties Sarrubra and Sarrosa have been obtained from crosses of T. vulgare (Poltavka) and T. durum (Beloturka). These varieties are distinguished by their high drought resistance; in yield they have surpassed the two parents by 25.4 and 32.1 per cent respectively and are more or less equal to Lutescens 062, which they distinctly excel in milling and baking quality. Sarrubra is free from shedding when standing in the field and is suitable for combine harvesting; the area under this variety is constantly increasing. Other promising hybrids have been produced from later crosses of the same combination of species. Among these is an awnless T. durum equal to the standards in yield and earlier in maturity. Promising results have also been obtained from interracial crosses in T. vulgare and certain varieties resistant to smut and leaf rust have been produced. In winter wheat equally successful results have been obtained. The variety Lutescens 0329 is characterized by exceptional cold resistance, and is closely followed by Lutescens 1060/10; these two varieties have made possible a considerable extension of wheat cultivation in the lower Volga basin. Various newer hybrids are equally, if not more, promising. Many of the hybrids with rye are highly promising in respect of cold and drought resistance, yield and grain quality. The main characteristics of the forms that have proved most popular in cultivation are described. Some of them are equal to rye in earliness of maturity and exceed the standard wheat varieties in yield. They are being further crossed among themselves and with winter wheat and the amphidiploids obtained are also being used in crossing. Perennial rye is also being crossed with winter wheats in the attempt to produce perennial wheats. The same object is pursued in the crosses between Agropyrum and wheat. Some of these hybrids are at the same time possessed of great winter-hardiness and resistance both to drought and to many fungous diseases, and are also tolerant of very unfavourable growth conditions. The hybrids of A. elongaium contain the highest proportion of perennial plants in the later generations. Valuable hardy lines of both annual and perennial type have been isolated and some of these are now in the stage of variety testing. Sunflowers resistant to Orobanche and also to moth and drought have been produced by selection. A valuable new form, No. 169, possesses in addition to these characters, high yielding ability and ripens in 95-104 days, giving also a satisfactory oil content. An early variety ripening in 78 days, also resistant to Orobanche and moth has been selected, and various interesting lines have been obtained by inbreeding. One of these, No. 137 is superior both in yield and oil content and is at the same time rust-resistant. Sunflower crosses have been made, including one between the variety No. 169 and the perennial wild species Helianthus divaricatus; the hybrids are resistant to drought, rust and other fungous diseases, and include a perennial oil form which is receiving attention. Improved strains of rye have been selected and constant lines have been obtained by inbreeding which exceed the standard in yield by 6 to 60 per cent. Crosses have been effected also between rye and Agropyrum Cristatum. Millet has been subjected to selection and improved lines produced, including one No. 853, which is drought-resistant, uniform in ripening, free from shedding, good in grain quality, and unusually high in yield.
Manual Tags: search.rye; search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 ("rye" OR secale) NOT "rye$grass"); TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); WOS

Author: Laidlaw, R.A.; Reid, S.G.
Title: 400. Studies on fructosans. Part III. A fructosan from Lolium perenne
Abstract Note: A fructosan from early perennial rye-grass (Lolium perenne), on hydrolysis, gave D-fructose (98%) and D-glucose (2%). Acetylation, methylation, and hydrolysis yielded 1:3:4:6-tetramethyl D-fructose (4%), 1:3:4-trimethyl D-fructose (93%), and 3:4-dimethyl D-fructose (2.8%), along with small amounts of aldose derivatives and a trace of fructose. It is concluded that the methylated fructosan has a unit chain length of ca. 25-30 residues.

Author: Poppenborg, Patrick; Koellner, Thomas
Title: A Bayesian network approach to model farmers' crop choice using socio-psychological measurements of expected benefits of ecosystem services
Abstract Note: Abstract Models of ecosystem management typically measure the benefits of ecosystem services in terms of ecological or biophysical variables, which are influenced by management decisions and biophysical/ecological conditions. This study uses farmers' expected benefits of ecosystem services as input variables to model their decision between planting rice, annual crops or perennial crops. Based on the theory of planned behavior, a Bayesian network is constructed to model crop choice depending on attitudes toward the ecosystem services of biomass production, reduction of soil erosion, and water quality improvement. The relative importance of these decision-making criteria is quantified using the Analytical Hierarchy Process. Results indicate that Bayesian networks can use socio-psychological measurements to model decision-making. Especially as an extension to biophysical or economic models, they can serve as a powerful tool for grasping the more abstract socio-psychological dimensions of benefits of ecosystem services, and how they translate into the decisions of ecosystem managers.
Manual Tags: Analytical Hierarchy Process; Bayesian network; Decision-making support; Ecosystem services; perennial W/1 (oryza OR rice); ScienceDirect; search.rice; SPV; Theory of planned behavior

Author: Neilson, Roy; Robinson, David; Marriott, Carol A.; Scrimgeour, Charlie M.; Hamilton, David; Wishart, Jane; Boag, Brian; Handley, Linda L.
Title: Above-ground grazing affects floristic composition and modifies soil trophic interactions
Abstract Note: There are few data on the functional inter-relationships between above- and below-ground components of soil ecosystems. Here, we report changes in below-ground soil invertebrate trophic relationships (manifested as alterations in stable isotope natural abundances, δ13C and δ15N) that arose in association with the removal of sheep grazing and from the resulting changes in above-ground floristic composition. Consequent to grazing removal, Lolium perenne L. (perennial rye-grass) was replaced as the dominant plant species in ungrazed treatments by Ranunculus repens L. (creeping buttercup), a species with more 13C-enriched foliage. Consequently, all invertebrate functional groups studied, but not whole soil, were more 13C-enriched in ungrazed treatments. Earthworms (detritivore) from grazed treatments were significantly 15N-enriched compared with earthworms from ungrazed treatments. In contrast, slug (herbivore) δ15N exhibited no treatment effect. Reasons for this are unclear but may be related to the effects of above-ground grazing on the composition of below-ground microbial/microfaunal communities. Omnivores/carnivores (beetles and spiders), were more 15N-enriched than primary producers in the grazed than in the ungrazed treatments (6 vs. 4‰) suggesting a longer below-ground foodchain in the grazed plots. The cessation of fertilizer application had no comparable effects on below-ground trophic relationships.
Manual Tags: AGRICOLA; Ecosystem function; grazing; perennial W/1 ("rye" OR secale) AND NOT ("rye?grass" OR "ryegrass"); ScienceDirect; Scopus; search.rye; Soil ecosystems; SPV; Stable isotopes; TITLE-ABS-KEY (perennial W/1 ("rye" OR secale) AND NOT ("rye?grass" OR ryegrass)) AND DOCTYPE (ar); Trophic interactions; TX (perennial N1 ("rye" OR secale) NOT "rye#grass")

Author: RJAZAXOV, JA I.
Title: A brief summary of the results and problems in the research work of the Institute of Grain Husbandry in the South-East of the U.S.S.R.
Abstract Note: The overriding consideration in plant breeding for the South-Eastern regions of the U.S.S.R. is drought. Comparative analyses have been made of the meteorological conditions over a period of years and of the yields of winter rye and spring wheat, and it has been possible to define those conditions which lead to the best yields in each. The influence of various cultural measures, rotations and other operations on moisture conservation has been studied by the Saratov institute. A number of new and improved varieties suitable for these conditions have been produced and are described The spring wheat Lutescens 15/12 is a product of complex hybridization, characterized by rapid development of the root system and rapid gain in dry weight in the developing grain; it is free from shedding, high in grain quality and exceeds Sarrubra in yield by up to 5 c. per ha. The spring wheat Albidum 43, the most drought resistant yet produced, is also a product of complex hybridization, and has a high rate of development of the primary and secondary roots, rapid filling of the grain and very uniform grain; it is free from shedding and has exceeded the standard by 2-2.5 c. per ha. in yield New spring wheats for irrigated land are Lutescens 605 and 758, and the best winter wheat yet produced is the rye-wheat hybrid Lutescens 230, distinguished by its winter hardiness, standing capacity, and large vitreous grains of high baking quality. Good results have been obtained with new varieties of other crops, such as Volzanka No. 7 winter rye; sunflowers with improved oil content such as Saratov No. 19, P-10, P4 and P-27, the last being a very early variety maturing in 77 days; and the millet Saratov Cream 311, characterized by a high extraction rate of 85%. Five perennial wheat selections from Triticum * Agropyron hybrids are under observation.
Manual Tags: search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); WOS

Author: Hanks, Gordon R.
Title: Abscisic acid levels and daylength in perennial rye-grass
Abstract Note: Summary Endogenous concentrations of abscisic acid were studied in Lolium perenne S. 24 growing under long and short days. Attention was paid to other variables such as diurnal effects and water supply. Under these conditions, there was no clear effect of daylength on abscisic acid levels. This result is related to some contradictory reports in the literature.
Manual Tags: abscisic acid; daylength (photo-period); Lolium perenne; perennial W/1 ("rye" OR secale) AND NOT ("rye?grass" OR "ryegrass"); ScienceDirect; search.rye; SPV

Author: BRAMLEY, W.
Title: A bumper crop on five inches of summer rain. Argentine perennial Sorghum introduced by " The Farmer's Weekly" succeeds on marginal farm in Central Free State. Three cuttings of prussic-acid-free hay in one season.
Abstract Note: Argentine or Columbus grass ( Sorghum almum) was planted on a farm lying in the transition grass-veld area of the central Orange Free State where the average annual rainfall was 18 in. A description of its establishment on a 5-morgen field [1 morgen = 2-1165 ac.] and its subsequent utilization is given. After 3 years, it is claimed that the grass is a true perennial, is relished by sheep and would give a hay yield comparable to that of Sudan grass [ Sorghum sudanense]. Columbus grass survived 3 summers from 1950-3, in which the rainfall was 14 in., 5 in. and 28 in., respectively.-M.A.
Manual Tags: search.sorghum; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 sorghum); WOS

Author: Afsana, Nadira; Islam, Zahirul
Title: Abundance of ladybird beetles in irrigated rice environment in Bangladesh, diurnal activity pattern of Micraspis discolor (Fab.) and its influence on rice grain sterility.
Abstract Note: Five species of ladybird beetles viz., Micraspis discolor (Fab.), M. crocea Mulsant, Coccinella transversalis Fab., C. septempunctata Linn. and Brumoides suturalts (Fab.) (Coccinellidae: Coleoptera) were found in irrigated rice fields at Gazipur in Bangladesh. Among them Micraspis discolor was the most dominant species comprising about 92.9% of the total ladybird beetle populations. Their relative abundance was highest in the rice fields with ponding water (37.73 %), followed by rice fields without ponding water (22.05%), rice seedbed (12.50%), grassy fallow fields (10.23%), fields with rice ratoons (7.95%), grassy road-sides (6.59%), and the least on rice bunds with grasses (2.95%). Micraspis discolor appeared to prefer rice than grasses, and rice fields with water than without water. At the flowering stage, adult M. discolor remained active on the rice panicle throughout the day but its abundance was influenced by some physical factors. It appeared that temperature and sunlight had positive influence, and rainfall and relative humidity had negative influence on the abundance of adult M. discolor on rice panicles. Observations indicated that sampling of M. discolor on emerging rice panicles can be done at any time of the day except during rain. At the flowering stage they fed on rice pollen, but their feeding even by high populations (20 adults/hill) did not cause grain sterility.
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: Lin, S.-C.; Chang, T.-K.; Huang, W.-D.; Lur, H.-S.; Shyu, G.-S.
Title: Accumulation of arsenic in rice plant: a study of an arsenic-contaminated site in Taiwan
Abstract Note: A study conducted in 2006 showed that over 100 ha of rice paddies in Beitou, Taiwan, irrigated over the years using water mixed with hot spring, was heavily polluted by arsenic. Thus, the objective of the present study is to measure arsenic content in different parts of rice and paddy soils, and eventually explain the arsenic distribution in ratoon rice, including its relationship to the soil. Arsenic levels of rice in grains, straws, roots, and soils were obtained from 15 rice paddies, selected based on different arsenic soil concentrations ranging from 67 to 438 mg kg(-1) (n = 15). The mean arsenic content in grains was measured at 0.20 mg kg(-1) (n = 60) and the highest grain arsenic of the survey was at 1.183 mg kg(-1). Meanwhile, the mean total arsenic levels were 244 mg kg(-1) (n = 28) in root and 4.4 mg kg(-1) (n = 28) in straw. In comparison, regression of topsoil arsenic levels with rice grains (r (2) = 0.00) and straws (r (2) = 0.56) were less significant compared to that with rice roots (r (2) = 0.93), and the mean arsenic level in rice from root to grain was also shown to have a decreasing trend. Though concentrations of arsenic in compositive rice grain each field did not exceed food hygiene concentration limit, arsenic level in root strongly depended on arsenic concentrations of soil suggesting that the high arsenic concentration may have the potential for translocation from root to grain which ultimately effects on the human health.
Manual Tags: Arsenic; FPXRF; Rice; Scopus; search.rice; Soil contamination; SPV; TITLE-ABS-KEY (ratoon* W/5 (oryza OR rice)) AND DOCTYPE (ar); TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: Young, R. R.; Wilson, B.; Harden, S.; Bernardi, A.
Title: Accumulation of soil carbon under zero tillage cropping and perennial vegetation on the Liverpool Plains, eastern Australia
Abstract Note: Australian agriculture contributes an estimated 16% of all national greenhouse gas emissions, and considerable attention is now focused on management approaches that reduce net emissions. One area of potential is the modi. cation of cropping practices to increase soil carbon storage. Here, we report short-medium term changes in soil carbon under zero tillage cropping systems and perennial vegetation, both in a replicated field experiment and on nearby farmers' paddocks, on carbon-depleted Black Vertosols in the upper Liverpool Plains catchment. Soil organic carbon stocks (C(S)) remained unchanged under both zero tillage long fallow wheat-sorghum rotations and zero tillage continuous winter cereal in a replicated field experiment from 1994 to 2000. There was some evidence of accumulation of C(S) under intensive (>1 crop/year) zero tillage response cropping. There was significant accumulation of C(S) (similar to 0.35 Mg/ha.year) under 3 types of perennial pasture, despite removal of aerial biomass with each harvest. Significant accumulation was detected in the 0-0.1, 0.1-0.2, and 0.2-0.4 m depth increments under lucerne and the top 2 increments under mixed pastures of lucerne and phalaris and of C3 and C4 perennial grasses. Average annual rainfall for the period of observations was 772 mm, greater than the 40-year average of 680 mm. A comparison of major attributes of cropping systems and perennial pastures showed no association between aerial biomass production and accumulation rates of C(S) but a positive correlation between the residence times of established plants and accumulation rates of C(S). C(S) also remained unchanged (1998/2000-07) under zero tillage cropping on nearby farms, irrespective of paddock history before 1998/2000 (zero tillage cropping, traditional cropping, or similar to 10 years of sown perennial pasture). These results are consistent with previous work in Queensland and central western New South Wales suggesting that the climate (warm, semi-arid temperate, semi-arid subtropical) of much of the inland cropping country in eastern Australia is not conducive to accumulation of soil carbon under continuous cropping, although they do suggest that C(S) may accumulate under several years of healthy perennial pastures in rotation with zero tillage cropping.
Manual Tags: search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); WOS

Author: Acharya, S. N.; Mir, Z.; Moyer, J. R.
Title: ACE-1 perennial cereal rye
Abstract Note: ACE-1 perennial cereal rye (PC rye) (Secale cereale) was developed by the Agriculture and Agri-Food Canada Research Centre, Lethbridge, Alberta. This cultivar, tested as LRC 96-1 in western Canada, was developed for silage and greenfeed. ACE-1 is easy to establish, competes well with weeds, grows early in spring, produces more biomass than barley and fall rye under dryland and irrigated conditions, but produces less seed than high yielding fall rye cultivars. Forage quality of ACE-1 was found to be similar to barley.
Manual Tags: Cultivar description; Perennial; Rye; Scopus; search.rye; Secale cereale; SPV; TITLE-ABS-KEY (perennial W/1 ("rye" OR secale) AND NOT ("rye?grass" OR ryegrass)) AND DOCTYPE (ar); TS=(perennial NEAR/1 ("rye" OR secale) NOT "rye$grass"); WOS

Author: CICIN, N. V.
Title: Achievements and tasks of Soviet plant breeding.
Abstract Note: In 1966, there were 225 approved cultivars of wheat, the most outstanding of which are described. Other achievements are sunflowers with high oil content and immunity to a number of diseases and pests, resulting from interspecific crosses. Of the 30 promising maize hybrids, a number are derived from male-sterile parents and corresponding wheat hybrids show yield increases of 30-40%; all the Triticum-Agropyron hybrids excel the standards in standing capacity and recent ones such as PPG391 and PPG56 yield over 40 c. per ha. without lodging; PPG172 is also resistant to drought, shedding and brown and yellow rust, yielding up to 55.4 c. per ha. under irrigation. The advantages of polyploidy are exemplified by triploid sugar beets, tetraploid rye and rye-wheat amphidiploids; three perennial Triticum-Agropyron hybrids give 2-3 yields without resowing and are resistant to frost and disease, though yielding less grain than the common wheat cultivars; a description is given of 1345, which, when sown in autumn, gives three crops of hay with a protein content of 12-14%, the total yield of which is 90-100 c., after which it can be grazed; other Triticum-Agropyron hybrids, with branching ears, contain over 100 grains per ear. A perennial rye, Pervenec [Firstborn], gives a crop in three successive years almost equal to that from normal rye. Incompatibility has been overcome in interspecific tobacco crosses by polyploidy, in crosses of cabbage with radish by grafting, which also induces flowering in the first year; an interspecific potato hybrid contains 23-5% starch and 3% protein; successful cultivars of pea and French bean have been produced by interspecific hybridization and others by crossing between ecotypes.
Manual Tags: search.rye; search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 ("rye" OR secale) NOT "rye$grass"); TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); WOS

Author: HyungSuk, Lee; InDuk, Lee
Title: A comparative study of dry matter yield and nutritive value of tall type and turf type mixtures.
Publication Title: Journal of the Korean Society of Grassland Science
Abstract Note: A study was conducted to determine the effect of tall type and turf type mixtures on dry matter yield, botanical composition and quality. The tall type mixture included orchardgrass [ Dactylis glomerata] 50% + tall fescue [ Festuca arundinacea] 20% + Kentucky bluegrass [ Poa pratensis] 10% + red clover [ Trifolium pratense] 20%. The turf type mixture included Kentucky bluegrass (Newport) 60% + tall fescue (rebell Jr.) 20% + perennial ryegrass [ Secale montanum] (palmer II) 20%. Higher dry matter yield was obtained from the tall type mixture than from the turf type mixture. In terms of chemical composition, the turf type mixture had higher crude protein and dry matter digestibility, but lower fibrous compound (neutral detergent fibre, acid detergent fibre, cellulose and lignin) than the tall type mixture. The crude protein dry matter and digestible dry matter yield was higher in tall type mixture than the turf type mixture. The nutritive value of the turf type mixture was higher than that of tall type mixture, but crude protein dry matter and digestible dry matter yield of turf type mixture were lower than that of the turf type mixture due to low dry matter yield. On the other hand, high feed value was obtained from the turf type mixture, and maintaining the various botanical compositions on the 13th cutting frequency condition, therefore, turf type mixture can be used for grazing by livestock (e.g. sheep and milk goats).
Manual Tags: search.rye; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 ("rye" OR secale) NOT "rye$grass"); WOS

Author: Meharg, A.A.; Killham, K.
Title: A comparison of carbon flow from pre-labelled and pulse-labelled plants
Abstract Note: Perennial rye-grass was subjected to two different14C labelling regimes to enable a partitioning of the carbon sources contributing to rhizosphere carbon-flow. Plant/soil microcosms were designed which enabled rye-grass plants to either receive a single pulse of14C-CO2 or to be pre-labelled using a series of14C-CO2 pulses, allowing the fate of newly photoassimilated carbon and carbon lost by root decomposition to be followed into the soil. For young rye-grass plants grown over a short period, rhizosphere carbon flow was found to be dominated by newly photoassimilated carbon. Evidence for this came from the observed percentage of the total14C budget (i.e. total14C-CO2 fixed by the plants) lost from the root/soil system, which was 30 times greater for the pulse labelled compared to pre-labelled plants. Root decomposition was found to be less at 10°C compared to 20-25°C, though input of14C into the soil was the same at both temperatures.
Manual Tags: carbon-flow; Lolium perenne; rhizosphere; roots; Scopus; search.rye; SPV; TITLE-ABS-KEY (perennial W/1 ("rye" OR secale) AND NOT ("rye?grass" OR ryegrass)) AND DOCTYPE (ar)

Author: Fitzsimons, R.; Grammer, L.C.; Shaughnessy, M.A.; Patterson, R.
Title: A comparison of the immune response to immunotherapy with polymerized grass allergen and monomeric grass allergen
Abstract Note: This study compares the immune response of ten patients treated with polymerized grass (PG) immunotherapy with that of 12 patients treated with conventional monomer grass (MG) immunotherapy. The patients treated with PG immunotherapy received a mean cumulative dose of 44,840 protein nitrogen units (PNU), and those treated with MG immunotherapy received a mean cumulative dose of 46,083 PNU. Total antibody binding of perennial rye grass groups I, II, and III (RGGI, RGGII, and RGGIII) was measured in the serum of each individual. In addition, IgG titers to partially purified extracts of Bermuda, timothy, and orchard grass were also determined. A significant increase in the total antibody binding of RGGI, as well as an increase in the mean IgG titer to Bermuda, timothy, and orchard grass was demonstrated after treatment in the patients who had received PG immunotherapy. The mean total anibody binding of RGII and RGIII also increased in these patients, although not significantly. No significant difference in the mean total antibody binding of RGGI, RGGII, or RGGIII nor in the mean IgG titer to the three grass extracts was found in the sera of the two groups of patients. This study demonstrates a comparable immune response between immunotherapy with PG and MG, and retention of antigenic determinants during the polymerization process.
Manual Tags: Scopus; search.rye; SPV; TITLE-ABS-KEY (perennial W/1 ("rye" OR secale) AND NOT ("rye?grass" OR ryegrass)) AND DOCTYPE (ar)

Author: SULJE; Ja, SOULIER] E.
Title: A composite perennial Elymus-wheat-Agropyron hybrid.
Abstract Note: From a F 4 perennial sterile wheat * Agropyron hybrid pollinated by Ely mus gigante-us, grains were germinated yielding seedlings which are described. These seedlings have inherited from E. giganteus the general habit, rhythm of development, creeping habit of the root system, and other peculiarities of the leaf and stem structure.-M.H.
Manual Tags: search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); WOS

Author: SOULIER, E. J.
Title: A composite perennial Elymus-wheat-Agropyrum hybrid.
Abstract Note: Descriptions are given of two hybrid plants obtained by pollinating a sterile F 4 perennial Triticum x Agropyron hybrid with pollen from Elymus giganteus. The two hybrids resembled E. giganteus. in general plant habit, rhythm of development, the creeping habit of the root system, and in leaf and stem structure. The chromosome number of the maternal hybrid was 2n = 48, while that of the hybrid was 2n = 52. Since 2n = 28 in Elymus giganteus, it is inferred that an unreduced gamete of this species took part in the fertilization.
Manual Tags: search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); WOS

Author: HIZNJAK, V. A.
Title: A cyto-genetical study of Triticum X Agropyron hybrids and the trend in breeding perennial wheat. Preliminary communication.
Abstract Note: Sterility of the F 1 hybrids between Triticum and Agropyron is due to (1) frequent anomalies in pre-meiotic and mitotic divisions of the pollen mother-cells, (2) incomplete and casual conjugation of chromosomes, the number of bivalents varying from 0 to 2 ( T. durum X 28 chromo- some A. intermedium) to 19 to 23 ( T. vulgare x A. elongatum) and (3) irregular pollen-grain division. The degree of self-fertility varies however with parental forms; all hybrids between Triticum and A. intermedium are self-sterile, as are the hybrids between hard wheat and A.-elongatum, but a part of the hybrids between soft wheat and A. elongatum are self-fertile. The triple hybrids are relatively easily obtained by crossing F 1 to one of the parents. The data on the second generation concern chiefly the hybrids between wheat and A. intermedium, the majority of which were obtained by fusion of the male gametes with unreduced gametes of the F 1. Among sesquidiploids a forty-two chromosome plant was obtained, and among triple hybrids (F 1 X T. vulgare) forty-six and fifty-four chromosome plants were found; these plants resemble wheat, but they are perennial, Among F 2 plants (chiefly the triple hybrids) some lethal specimens with deficient chlorophyll were found. Both wheat sesquidiploids and those of couch grass are perennial and partly fertile. In reduction division of triple hybrids between T. dumm x 48 chromosome A. intermedium and A. vulgare, fourteen to twenty-one bivalents were counted and in the triple hybrid between T. durum X 48 chromosome A. intermedium and A. elongatum the number of bivalents was twenty-one. This suggests that the genomes A, B and D of wheats are homologous, though modified, with the respective Agropyron genomes. The Agropyron genomes X 1 and X 2 are not found in wheat; their relation to those of Aegilops has not yet been shown. The main trend of obtaining perennial wheat is thought to be through producing sesquidiploids which contain a haploid set of wheat and some Agropyron chromosomes. Fusion of these gametes will give plants with a diploid set of Triticum and Agropyron and a haploid set of Agropyron chromosomes; in these plants some of the Agropyron chromosomes will be univalents; selection of forms without univalents will give constant fertile forms. Triple hybrids might also give valuable forms, and finally obtaining amphidiploids by crossing wheat sesquidi-ploids with those of Agropyron should produce valuable forage plants.-M.A.O.
Manual Tags: search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); WOS

Author: CAUDERON, M. Y.
Title: A cyto-genetic study of a trigeneric hybrid involving T. dicoccum Schrank, A., intermedium Host. P.B. and S. cereale L.
Abstract Note: Attempts were made to cross the two amphi-diploids, T. timopheevi x A. intermedium, and T. dicoccum x A. intermedium with diploid S. secale used as the pollen parent. In the former case, six seeds were obtained from the 104 flowers pollinated but no progeny was raised. Five seeds were gained from 288 pollinations in the second case; five hybrids were raised. These plants had chromosome numbers of 2n = 42, 14 chromosomes having been obtained from Triticum, 21 from Agropyron and seven from Secale. Root-tip nuclei at interphase showed the chromocentric structure characteristic of Secale. Meiotic behaviour was studied in one hybrid; the average metaphase configurations of 100 cells were 34.26 I + (2.95 IId + 0.08 IIa) + 0.56 III. There were 0.56 chiasmata per conjugated chromosome. These results were compared with those of the F 1 of T. dicoccum x A. intermedium; in this case the average configurations were 24.37 r + (3.87 IId + 0.25 IIa) + 77 III + 0.02 iv. There was no apparent pairing between the chromosomes of Secale and those of the other two species; most of the chromosome associations arose from auto-syndesis of the Agropyron chromosomes. It was often possible to distinguish the Secale chromosomes amongst the univalents. Other aberrations typical of intergeneric hybrids were also observed.The hybrids were completely sterile even under conditions of open pollination. They showed great vigour; in their habit the hybrids resembled Agropyron from which they also inherited certain characteristics of the glume and the property of being perennial. From Secale the hybrids had inherited the hairy collar of the ear. In their late ripening, they resembled both Triticum and Agropyron. In other ear characters the hybrids were intermediate between the parent forms.
Manual Tags: search.rye; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 ("rye" OR secale) NOT "rye$grass"); WOS

Author: Sumawinata, B.
Title: Adaptive agricultural practices and land use cycles on pyritic sediments in South Kalimantan.
Abstract Note: The reclamation of potential acid sulfate soils for agriculture invoves the risk that pyritic minerals present in the soil will be oxidized and produce unfavourable conditions for plant growth. Pyritic minerals are oxidized when swamps are reclaimed by forest cutting, canal excavation, and by the destruction of the covering peat layer. In South Kalimantan, Indonesia, Banjarese people use an adaptive agricultural technique to cultivate rice and perennial crops on potential acid sulfate soils. Its characteristic features are: drainage is kept to the minimum needed for reclamation, so as to depress the oxidation of pyritic sediments; the traditional method for swamp-land rice cultivation is employed; and the secondary Melaleuca forest is conserved by the shifting cultivation of rice with long-term planting and fallowing periods. This paper discusses land use in South Kalimantan.
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: King, J.; Thomas, A.; James, C.; King, I.; Armstead, I.
Title: A DArT marker genetic map of perennial ryegrass (Lolium perenne L.) integrated with detailed comparative mapping information; comparison with existing DArT marker genetic maps of Lolium perenne, L. multiflorum and Festuca pratensis
Abstract Note: Background: Ryegrasses and fescues (genera, Lolium and Festuca) are species of forage and turf grasses which are used widely in agricultural and amenity situations. They are classified within the sub-family Pooideae and so are closely related to Brachypodium distachyon, wheat, barley, rye and oats. Recently, a DArT array has been developed which can be used in generating marker and mapping information for ryegrasses and fescues. This represents a potential common marker set for ryegrass and fescue researchers which can be linked through to comparative genomic information for the grasses.Results: A F2 perennial ryegrass genetic map was developed consisting of 7 linkage groups defined by 1316 markers and deriving a total map length of 683 cM. The marker set included 866 DArT and 315 gene sequence-based markers. Comparison with previous DArT mapping studies in perennial and Italian ryegrass (L. multiflorum) identified 87 and 105 DArT markers in common, respectively, of which 94% and 87% mapped to homoeologous linkage groups. A similar comparison with meadow fescue (F. pratensis) identified only 28 DArT markers in common, of which c. 50% mapped to non-homoelogous linkage groups. In L. perenne, the genetic distance spanned by the DArT markers encompassed the majority of the regions that could be described in terms of comparative genomic relationships with rice, Brachypodium distachyon, and Sorghum bicolor.Conclusions: DArT markers are likely to be a useful common marker resource for ryegrasses and fescues, though the success in aligning different populations through the mapping of common markers will be influenced by degrees of population interrelatedness. The detailed mapping of DArT and gene-based markers in this study potentially allows comparative relationships to be derived in future mapping populations characterised using solely DArT markers.
Manual Tags: Comparative genomics; DArT Markers; Festuca; Genetic Maps; Lolium; Scopus; search.rice; SPV; TITLE-ABS-KEY (perennial W/1 (oryza OR rice)) AND DOCTYPE (ar)

Author: Sampson, Kathleen
Title: Additional notes on the systemic infection of Lolium
Publication Title: Transactions of the British Mycological Society
Abstract Note: Summary Some plants of the natural hybrid Festulolium loliaceum (Huds.) C. E. Hubbard carry mycelia like those present in Lolium perenne. A number of new isolations from this hybrid and from perennial rye-grass have been compared with those previously described as endophytes 1 and 2. Some isolates possess the mycelial characteristics of endophyte 1 while their growth in culture resembles endophyte 2. The mycelium in L. multiflorum failed to grow on artificial media, agreeing in this and other respects with that present in L. temulentum and L. remotum.
Journal Abbreviation: Transactions of the British Mycological Society
Manual Tags: perennial W/1 ("rye" OR secale) AND NOT ("rye?grass" OR "ryegrass"); ScienceDirect; search.rye; SPV

Author: Fujisaka, Sam; Moody, Keith; Ingram, Keith
Title: A descriptive study of farming practices for dry seeded rainfed lowland rice in India, Indonesia, and Myanmar
Abstract Note: Farmers' traditional dry seeded rice systems were examined: practices were matched to field environments and included ways to address not only weeds, but also poor soil physical properties, water deficit and excess, and poor plant stand. Among others, farmers used pigmented rice cultivars to be able to rogue wild rice and rotated or switched from dry seeded to transplanted rice because of weeds or a too rapid onset of rains. Redistribution of seedlings and manual weeding were used to improve plant stand and soil physical properties in addition to reducing weeds. Farmers' dry-seeding systems did not necessarily reduce labor, but could increase cropping intensity, result in stable yields using low material inputs, or distribute labor demands where some fields are dry seeded and others transplanted. Because of difficult and uncertain environmental conditions, research on direct seeding must build upon farmer practices and knowledge.
Manual Tags: perennial W/1 (oryza OR rice); ScienceDirect; search.rice; SPV

Author: CICIN, N.
Title: Advancement of winter forms in the eastern regions of the U.S.S.R, and breeding of new varieties of winter crops.
Abstract Note: The history of cultivation of winter cereals in Siberia and the present and ultimate participation of winter forms in grain production are discussed in relation to the need for extending the acreage under cereals to 17, 865, 000 ha. in 1941 and 18, 830, 000 ha. in 1942. Heavy depletion of winter sowings occurring yearly is the chief limiting factor in extension of the acreage sown with winter forms. With good management, the existing varieties will ensure a good crop; among agronomical measures, protection of sowings with snow is particularly important; it has been shown that under 50 cm. deep snow, temperatures at the depth of the tillering node do not fall below-2.4degreesC. when the surface temperature is about-22.6degreesC. Another important aspect is manuring which tends to increase carbohydrate content and thus the resistance of the plants, as well as regeneration of the parts damaged during winter. There is need for production of special Siberian varieties, in the breeding of which the vast resources in local peasant strains must be utilized; the method of training must also be used. The most promising trend, however, is distant hybridization. Extensive work has been done to this end at the Siberian Research Institute of Grain Husbandry, Omsk: large numbers of hybrids are now available; among them
Manual Tags: search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); WOS

Author: Mel'nik, I.
Title: Advantages of perennial rye.
Abstract Note: The perennial rye [Secale kuprijanovii] cv. Odesskaya gave fresh fodder yields of 25-45 t/ha in the W. Ukraine, contained 28-30% CP and 4.5% lysine in the DM and was palatable to animals. It starts regrowth in early spring, gives 2-3 cuts/year and gives fresh fodder up to the onset of frosts. Notes on its cultivation are given.
Manual Tags: search.rye; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 ("rye" OR secale) NOT "rye$grass"); WOS

Author: Jin, G.; Englande Jr., A.J.
Title: A field study on cost-effectiveness of five erosion control measures
Abstract Note: Purpose: The purpose of this study is to quantitatively evaluate five erosion control measures at a residential development area in Louisiana, USA in order to provide Best Management Practices (BMPs) that have been tested in the field with demonstrated cost-effectiveness. Design/methodology/approach: A total of six testing sites at a nine-degree slope were used in parallel to study five erosion control measures with one being the control site (no protection). Soil erosion rate was quantified using the erosion bridge method. Soil underlying the study area was analyzed for surface runoff potential. Precipitation was monitored using a Sigma rain gauge. Analysis of variance (ANOVA) and Student Newman-Keuls Post-Hoc ANOVA analysis were conducted to evaluate statistical significance of erosion control effectiveness. Ratio of soil erosion rate reduction to cost of each control measure is also analyzed. Findings: All erosion control measures studied were very effective in reducing soil erosion for soils with high runoff potential, ranging from 75 percent to about 100 percent reduction in soil erosion rate. The most effective soil erosion protection was observed by Geojute fabric and Curlex blanket with greater than 90 percent reduction in soil erosion rate. However, after factoring-in cost, straw bedding was observed to be five times as cost-effective as Geojute fabric and Curlex blanket. The most cost-effective measure is temporary seeding using perennial rye grass. For each dollar spent, about 12 tons of soil per acre per year will be prevented from eroding. Originality/value: The study evaluated erosion control measures in the field with quantitative cost-effectiveness analyzed. Besides enforcement, providing practical and cost-effectiveness control measures that have been tested in the field is critical for actual implementation of erosion control measures.
Manual Tags: Environmental management; Scopus; search.rye; Soil erosion; SPV; TITLE-ABS-KEY (perennial W/1 ("rye" OR secale) AND NOT ("rye?grass" OR ryegrass)) AND DOCTYPE (ar); United States of America; Water pollution; Water treatment

Author: ZuDe, Zhang; NengPu, Shi
Title: A fixed-site study on a multiple cropping model for tobacco-producing fields in a red soil area.
Publication Title: Journal of Fujian Academy of Agricultural Sciences
Abstract Note: A fixed-site experiment was conducted in Yongding county, the main tobacco-producing area in Fujian Province, China to study 9 multiple cropping systems. The best systems were spring tobacco-rice-early autumn maize-vegetables and spring tobacco-rice-ratooned rice. The effects of these systems on yield and quality of tobacco and soil properties and resource utilization were also considered.

Title: AFRICAN YAM BEAN AS A CROP IN NIGERIA

Author: Anonymous
Title: Again about distant hybridization and the wheat- Agropyron hybrids.
Abstract Note: The minutes are published of a conference of the Scientific Council of the Institute of Grain Farming of the Non-Black-Earth Belt held on 8 March 1948. The meeting was held as a protest against an article on N. V. Cicin's work by G. Andreev (cf. Abst, 1518). The editorial commentary on the dispute lends its support to Andreev. The resolution, which is signed by 20 members of the Scientific Council, may be summarized as follows. (1) The article by G. Andreev should be declared as libellous and misleading. (2) Accusations of Cicin and his colleagues of an anti-Micurinite direction in biology is due to misrepresentation. (3) Hybridization between cultivated and wild plants at the Institute has given new forms and varieties during a shorter period of time than ordinary breeding methods would have done. (4) Cicin and his colleagues have obtained by distant hybrid-ization, for the first time in history, a perennial wheat and several useful annual spring and winter wheat- Agropyron hybrids. These have either been released commercially or are undergoing State commercial tests. (5) The first form of perennial wheat, No. 34085, was obtained by Cicin in. 1935. Commercial tests in Kazahstan and Kirgizia have shown that the wheat can yield 2-3 harvests in succession without resowing. At the Kirgiz State Breeding Station, for instance, during the two growth periods, 1942 and 1943, four harvests were collected totalling 55.2 c.per ha. The wheat was discarded because of certain uneconomic characters. It has been replaced by new perennial wheats lacking the disadvantages of the original form. Among the best of these is wheat No. 2, which has been bred in the Moscow province. (6) A spring wheat-Agropyron hybrid, variety Flora -5, and a winter variety No. 599 are undergoing state tests. The winter variety No. 599 is superior in yields to standard varieties of the Novgorod, Leningrad, Tula and Kaluga provinces. (7) The Agropyron-wheat varieties 22850 and 23021 have been highly productive in commercial fanning. The promising spring Agropyron-wheat varieties Flora 6 and 7 and the winter hybrid varieties Nos 186, 4871, 64/45 and the squarehead No. 1/P have been submitted for testing. (8) The winter hybrids No. 599 and E-2493 are resistant to lodging and smut and their grain has good baking properties. (9) In the course of developing distant hybridization, the institute has made advances in the problems of polyploids, in rapprochment by grafting of intergeneric and other plants, and in methods of artificial preservation of hybrid embryos resulting from difficult distant crosses. It discovered the presence of gluten in the grain of barley, rye and other cereals and the application of the fact to breeding cereals. (10) The research institute has obtained new wheat, rye and barley hybrids with Elymus, Agropyron-rye hybrids, and the trigeneric hybrids, wheat x Agropyron x Elymus, wheat x Agropyron x rye, and wheat x rye x Elymus. (11) Some shortcomings of the work at the institute, mostly of an administrative nature, are pointed out. The attention is drawn of the Minister of Agriculture of the USSR, I. A. Benediktov, to Andreev's article. This has nothing in common with Soviet self criticism, but instead runs down outstanding discoveries of Soviet breeding and misleads the Soviet public. The main points of the editorial criticisms of Cicin and his colleagues are lack of practical results during 20 years of activity, due to formalism, Morganism and metaphysical conceptions; the absence of a perennial wheat in commercial production; misinterpretation of Micurin to suit formalist theories; and the use of colchicine methods and other "chance" methods of orthodox geneticists.
Manual Tags: search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); WOS

Author: GORGIDZE, A. D.
Title: A genetic study of wheat-rye hybrids.
Abstract Note: A wheat-rye amphidiploid (2 n = 42) was obtained which is highly fertile and combines the features and properties of Triticum palaeocolchicum (2 n = 28) and perennial rye (2 n = 14). This hybrid is biennial, self fertile, high yielding and resistant to fungal diseases.
Manual Tags: search.rye; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 ("rye" OR secale) NOT "rye$grass"); WOS

Author: Lanoiselet, V.M.; Cother, E.J.; Ash, G.J.
Title: Aggregate sheath spot and sheath spot of rice
Abstract Note: Aggregate sheath spot and sheath spot of rice are caused by Rhizoctonia oryzae-sativae (Sawada) Mordue and R. oryzae Ryker & Gooch, respectively. Although sheath spot is usually considered as a minor disease, it can be a very aggressive disease of rice. Aggregate sheath spot was also regarded as minor until the disease became increasingly important in temperate rice-growing regions such as California and south eastern Australia. The potential yield loss caused by both diseases was unknown until recent research clearly demonstrated the potential threat aggregate sheath spot and sheath spot represent to temperate rice industries. Worldwide, aggregate sheath spot and sheath spot have received little attention compared with the disease sheath blight, caused by Rhizoctonia solani. This article reviews the information available on both R. oryzae-sativae and R. oryzae relating to distribution, host range, biology, symptoms, disease cycle, epidemiology, pathogenicity, identification and control methods, yield losses and resistance. This paper is the first comprehensive review of sheath spot and aggregate sheath spot of rice.
Manual Tags: Diseases of rice; perennial W/1 (oryza OR rice); Rhizoctonia oryzae; Rhizoctonia oryzae-sativae; ScienceDirect; search.rice; SPV

Author: Akgun, I.; Tosun, M.
Title: Agricultural and cytological characteristics of M 1 perennial rye ( Secale montanum Guss.) as effected by the application of different doses of gamma rays.
Abstract Note: Perennial rye seeds were exposed to different doses of gamma rays (cobalt-60), i.e. 0, 2, 4, 6, 8, 10, 12, 14, 16, 20, 25 and 30 krad, and grown under field and greenhouse conditions in Turkey. The higher gamma ray doses decreased seed emerging rate, seedling height, spike length, spikelet number and seed set. The lethal dose (LD 50) was 18-20 krad and growth reduction dose (GR 50) was 12 krad. In the M 1 generation, as doses of gamma rays increased, the frequency of metaphase I with univalent and the frequency of irregular anaphase I cells increased. In the M 1 plants, anaphase I irregularities were especially seen as chromatin bridge. However, the frequency of anaphase I cells with laggards was higher than anaphase I cells with bridge at 20 and 25 krad doses of gamma rays.
Manual Tags: search.rye; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 ("rye" OR secale) NOT "rye$grass"); WOS

Title: Agriculture - In search of perennial solutions

Author: Karthikeyan, Alagarsamy; Pandian, Shunmugiah Karutha; Ramesh, Manikandan
Title: Agrobacterium-mediated transformation of leaf base derived callus tissues of popular indica rice (Oryza sativa L. sub sp. indica cv. ADT 43)
Abstract Note: A simple and efficient protocol for the Agrobacterium-mediated transformation of an agronomically useful abiotic sensitive popular indica rice cv. ADT 43 has been developed. Initiation of calli were best achieved from the leaf bases of 4 days old rice seedlings on LS medium supplemented with 2.5 mg/L 2,4-D and 1.0 mg/L thiamine–HCl. Rice calli immersed in Agrobacterium suspension (strain EHA 105, OD600 = 0.8) were co-cultured on LS30-AsPC medium for 2 days at 25 ± 2 °C in the dark. Based on GUS expression analysis, 10 min co-cultivation time with 100 μM acetosyringone was found optimum for the delivery of gus gene. Calli were proved to be very sensitive to Agrobacterium infection and we found that the level of necrotic response can be minimized after co-cultivation with 30% LS, 10 g/L PVP, 10% coconut water and 250 mg/L timentin which improved the final transformation efficiency to 9.33%. Molecular and genetic analysis of transgenic plants reveals the integration, expression and inheritance of transgene in the progeny (T1) of these plants. The copy number of transgenes has been found to vary from 1 to 2 in transgenic plants (T0 and T1).
Manual Tags: Abiotic factors; Acetosyringone; Coconut water; GUS (β-glucuronidase); HPT (hygromycin phosphotransferase); perennial W/1 (oryza OR rice); Polyvinyl pyrrolidone (PVP); ScienceDirect; search.rice; SPV

Author: Altieri, Miguel A.
Title: Agroecological foundations of alternative agriculture in California
Abstract Note: Most agricultural regions of California enjoy long growing seasons, fertile soils and irrigantion, all conditions that favor a highly diversified cropping. In addition, the wide variety of vegetables, field and tree crops determined a high diversity and flexibility of agricultural enterprises. Despite these factors, Californian agroecosystems are dominated by monocultural cropping systems. Although productive, these systems lack the ecological features to ensure efficient nutrient cycling, water and soil conservation, and biotic regulation. Productivity is subsidized with chemical inputs such as pesticides and fertilizers, some of which caue undesirable environmental and public health hazards. Large-scale monocultures are also highly susceptible to wind erosion and are dependent on ground water for irrigation, leading in some areas to a considerable ‘ leading in some areas to a considerable ‘overdraft’. In other regions, poor field drainage and rising water are leading to unacceptable soil salinity levels. In summary, Californian agriculture is very productive, but the environmental costs of such productivity is threatening the sustainability of agriculture. The search for self-sustaining, low-input, diversified and energy-efficient agricultural systems is now a major concern of researchers, farmers, policy makers and the public in California. The long tradition in biological pest control in California, as well as the experience of a number of organic farmers who developed low-input systems through ‘trial and error’, provide the building blocks for the search for a more sustainable agriculture. A key strategy is sustainable agriculture is to restore the agricultural diversity of the agricultural landscape. Diversity can be enhanced in lime through crop rotations and sequences, and in space in the form of cover crops, intercropping, agroforestry crop/livestock,mixturee, etc. Vegetation diversification not only results in pest regulation through restoration of natural controls, but also produces optimal nutrient recycling, energy conservation and less dependence on cultural inputs. In California although this new approach to agriculture is actively researched. realistically it will work only if it is economicically sensible and can be carried out within the constraints of a fairty normal agricultural system. Therefore, adoption of recommended diversification designs will procesd as these reduce costs and increase the efficiency and viability of farmers.
Manual Tags: perennial W/1 (oryza OR rice); ScienceDirect; search.rice; SPV

Author: Jaikumar, N. S.; Snapp, S. S.; Murphy, K.; Jones, S. S.
Title: Agronomic Assessment of Perennial Wheat and Perennial Rye as Cereal Crops
Abstract Note: Perennial wheat (Triticum aestivum L. X Thinopyrum spp.) and perennial rye (Secale cereale L. x S. montanum) are novel hybrid species under development as alternatives to annual cereal crops. We conducted a 2-yr field study with a split plot design to evaluate agronomic performance, including yield, phenology, and biomass production, of perennial accessions of wheat and rye, along with annual analogs. This is one of the first studies to rigorously compare agronomic performance of 2-yr-old plants to 1-yr-old plants in perennial cereals. Perennial wheat produced 1.0 to 1.6 Mg ha(-1) grain yield, 50% of annual wheat (2.7 Mg ha(-1)), while perennial rye produced 1.3 Mg ha(-1), 73% of annual rye (1.8 Mg ha(-1)). Modest yields from perennials relative to annuals reflected lower harvest index, lower yield per tiller, and less kernel mass. One-year-old and 2-yr-old perennial plants had similar seed yields, yield components, and biomass production, indicating that plant age had little effect on these parameters and older plants maintained yield potential. In contrast, phenology did vary with plant age, and showed a shift toward earlier spring growth and later flowering dates in older perennial plants. This illustrates an expanded vegetative period for regrowing plants of these perennial cereals. There appears to be potential for producing an early season forage crop from these cereals, although biomass yields were not high at this site and regrowth was not always reliable. Overall, performance of perennial rye was consistent with a viable new cereal crop. On the other hand, perennial wheat requires further selection for allocation of biomass to grain and vigorous regrowth.

Author: Bilski, J.; Jacob, D.; Soumaila, F.; Kraft, C.; Farnsworth, A.
Title: Agronomic biofortification of cereal crop plants with Fe, Zn, and Se, by the utilization of coal fly ash as plant growth media.
Abstract Note: The implementation of agronomic biofortification of cereal crops with Fe, Zn, and Se appears to be a rapid and simple solution to the deficiency of these elements in soils and plants. These deficiencies are a reason for serious public health concerns. Low levels of Fe, Zn, and Se are important soil constraints to crop production, especially in the developing world. In our study we planted six cereal crops on soil control and different coal combustion residues, naturally rich in these micronutrients. Plants were harvested AND chemically analyzed for Fe, Zn, and Se concentration using ICP. Six plant species have been tested including barley ( Hordeum vulgare), Jerry oats ( Avena sativa), rye ( Secale cereale), wheat ( Triticum aestivum), perennial ryegrass ( Lolium multiflorum), and ReGreen (wheat * wheatgrass hybrid) ( Triticum aestivum * Thinopyrum intermedium). All tested plants were able to establish growth on coal ash based growth media, and accumulated significant amounts of Fe, Zn, and Se. It supported our hypothesis, that phytoremediation of coal ash piles may serve also as agronomicbiofortificationof plants, especially cereal crops cultivated on coal fly ash.
Manual Tags: search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); WOS

Author: Costa, E. G. de C.; Santos, A. B. dos; Zimmermann, F. J. P.
Title: Agronomic characteristics of irrigated rice in the main crop and in the ratoon.
Abstract Note: A field experiment was conducted during 1995-96 in Goias, Brazil to evaluate the agronomic characteristics correlated to rice grain yield in both main and ratoon crops and to establish criteria for genotype selection in irrigated rice. The number of panicles/m 2 was the main component in the determination of grain yield in the ratoon crop. The growth duration periods and the number of grains per panicle were greater in the main crop. The average 100-grain weight was approximately 2.5 g in both crops. Plant height and harvest index were highly correlated to grain yield of the main crop, whereas number of panicles/m 2 and number of tillers/m 2 were highly correlated on yield of the ratoon crop. Milling ability, evaluated by total head rice recovery and percentage of whole kernels, was similar on both ratoon and main crops. The agronomic characters of the main crop were correlated to grain yield, but these correlations were not significant for the ratoon crop.
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: Lansigan, F.P; de los Santos, W.L; Coladilla, J.O
Title: Agronomic impacts of climate variability on rice production in the Philippines
Abstract Note: Climate variability is a threat to food production. Typhoons, floods, and droughts caused 82.4% of the total Philippine rice losses from 1970 to 1990. In 1990 alone, domestic losses due to climatic constraints amounted to US$ 39.2 million. Weather aberrations, climatic fluctuations such as El Niño, and the growing concern for their effects on agriculture have stimulated academic, public and policy-level interests on the analysis of the impacts of climate variability on agricultural production systems. This paper is presented to discuss the agronomic impacts of climate variability on rice production in the Philippines. Long-term climate variability influences sowing date, crop duration, crop yield, and the management practices adapted in rice production. Short-term weather episodes can also affect yield by inducing changes in temperature, potential evapotranspiration, and moisture availability. The degree of vulnerability of crops to climate variability depends mainly on the development stage of the crops at the time of weather aberration. The vulnerability and risk of crop production due to weather fluctuations and climate variability can be minimized if future weather variation can be adequately predicted and a suitable process-based ecophysiological crop yield forecasting model can be identified to produce real-time yield forecasts. Scientists and farmers must join efforts to further understand crop–climate relationships and formulate viable, locally adapted production technologies that will address critical issues such as climate variability.
Manual Tags: Climate variability; El Niño; Philippines; ratoon* W/5 (oryza OR rice); Rice production; ScienceDirect; search.rice; SPV

Author: Ahmed, N. U.
Title: Agronomic measurement and comparative performance of short duration post-rainy season pigeonpea in rice-based cropping patterns.
Publication Title: Dissertation Abstracts International, B (Sciences and Engineering)
Abstract Note: In field trials in the Philippines with Cajanus cajan (preceding crop rice), highest main crop seed yields were obtained with 50 plants/m in rows 30 cm apart, but ratoon crop yields were unaffected by plant density or spatial arrangement. Vigna radiata was poor for intercropping with C. cajan in upland soil; V. unguiculata performed better but suppressed growth of C. cajan. Ratooning C. cajan delayed flowering because of vegetative regrowth and it reduced seed yields compared with those of plants not ratooned. In studies with rice, recommended management gave higher or equal grain yields and better profitability but lower net return per dollar of weeding and transplanting costs than farmers' normal management. Transplanting in rows was unacceptable because of the high labour requirement. In the better environments C. cajan was recommended grown alone or intercropped with V. unguiculata or V. radiata and in poorer environments C. cajan was of use when grown for fodder or firewood.
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: Wade, L. J.; Douglas, A. C. L.; Foreman, J. W.
Title: Agronomic measures to minimise limitations to grain yield of irrigated and ratooned grain sorghum.
Abstract Note: In several field trials at 9 locations in central Queensland, up to 12 sorghum cultivars were ratooned, and irrigation was applied 8 times to the plant crop and 3 times to the ratoon according to cumulative pan evaporation (full irrigation), 5 times to the plant crop and twice to the ratoon at chosen growth stages (optimum irrigation) or 3 times to the plant crop and once to the ratoon at critical growth stages (supplementary irrigation). Fertilizer was applied in various combinations, with N at 0-300 kg/ha and P at 0-60 kg/ha. Plant density was 50 000-250 000 plants/ha with row spacings of 40-100 cm. At 4 sites at Dawson and Callide, the average plant crop grain yields for Goldrush II, Texas 610SR, Pride, Hylan 4X8, DK55+ and E57+ were 6.69, 7.13, 6.51, 6.59, 6.82 and 6.37 t/ha, respectively, with corresponding ratoon crop yields of 4.24, 3.48, 4.08, 4.75, 4.19 and 3.60 t/ha for row spacings of 90-100 cm. At Emerald, where 12 cultivars were grown, yields obtained with double rows spaced 40 cm apart, in 1-m beds were 40% higher than obtained with single rows 1 m apart. Yields declined with delay in optimum sowing time in early Sep. In the irrigation trial, the optimum irrigation strategy yielded 6.35 t/ha, whereas full irrigation and supplementary irrigation yielded 4.93 and 4.11 t/ha, respectively. N application of 100 kg/ha increased yield of the ratoon crop at one site from 1.50 t/ha (no fertilizer) to 1.76 t/ha. The trials showed that grain yields varied widely; the highest obtained was 9.58 t/ha. It is concluded that higher sorghum yields in central Queensland are commercially achievable with good management practices.
Manual Tags: search.sorghum; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 sorghum); WOS

Author: Usenya, A. A.
Title: Agrophysical properties of the soil under cultivation of fodder and cereals crops in crop rotation.
Publication Title: Vestsi Akademii Agrarnykh Navuk Respubliki Belarus'
Abstract Note: Results are presented of research on the condition of the soil structure under crops (barley, winter rye, potatoes, root crops, maize), fodder crops (clover [ Trifolium], timothy [ Phleum], grasses, lucerne [ Medicago sativa]), and ploughing in a rotation in Zhodino, Belarus, in 1989-91. Perennial grass, grain crops and cultivated crops influenced structural formation and also the quantity of water-stable aggregates in the plough layer.
Manual Tags: search.grain; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 grain); WOS

Author: SUDNOV, P.
Title: Agrotechnique of cultivation of perennial wheats.
Abstract Note: In the number of tillers, growth rate, time of flowering and aftermath formation, early autumn sowings were superior to late autumn sowings, particularly in a dry season. The yield in the first year of growth increased with increasing seeding rate; however, too great rates of seeding (120 kg. per ha. and higher) depressed the plants. In dense sowings the length of stems was increased, but the length of leaves and ear was curtailed. At the same rate of seeding, sowings in furrows were superior to broadcast sowings. Among the methods of additional nutrition, fractional application of fertilizers during tillering, at the jointing phase and in the beginning of flowering, proved to be most effective. Wild NPK, potassium increased the 1, 000-grain weight as compared with other variants, but decreased total seed yield, the highest seed yield being obtained with NP. Chemical analyses showed that the straw of the first cut of perennial rye-wheat hybrids contained 5.19 per cent proteins, 1.60 per cent fat, and 39.48 per cent fibre; still better chemical composition was found in the hay of the second cut, containing 10.25 per cent proteins, 2.31 per cent fat and 27.28 per cent fibre.-M.A.O.

Author: Sutherland, William J.; Aveling, Ros; Bennun, Leon; Chapman, Eleanor; Clout, Mick; Côté, Isabelle M.; Depledge, Michael H.; Dicks, Lynn V.; Dobson, Andrew P.; Fellman, Liz; Fleishman, Erica; Gibbons, David W.; Keim, Brandon; Lickorish, Fiona; Lindenmayer, David B.; Monk, Kathryn A.; Norris, Kenneth; Peck, Lloyd S.; Prior, Stephanie V.; Scharlemann, Jörn P.W.; Spalding, Mark; Watkinson, Andrew R.
Title: A horizon scan of global conservation issues for 2012
Abstract Note: Our aim in conducting annual horizon scans is to identify issues that, although currently receiving little attention, may be of increasing importance to the conservation of biological diversity in the future. The 15 issues presented here were identified by a diverse team of 22 experts in horizon scanning, and conservation science and its application. Methods for identifying and refining issues were the same as in two previous annual scans and are widely transferable to other disciplines. The issues highlight potential changes in climate, technology and human behaviour. Examples include warming of the deep sea, increased cultivation of perennial grains, burning of Arctic tundra, and the development of nuclear batteries and hydrokinetic in-stream turbines.
Manual Tags: AGRICOLA; perennial W/1 grain; ScienceDirect; search.grain; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 grain); TX (perennial N1 grain); WOS

Title: A. I. Derzavin's sorghum-Johnson grass hybrids as initial material for perennial sorghum.

Author: ZABOLOTNAYA, Mme E. S.
Title: Alkaloid content of ergot parasitizing various wild cereals and hybrid forms of Eye and Wheat.
Abstract Note: Determination in 1948-51 of the alkaloid content in Claviceps purpurea [cf. above] collected mainly in the Moscow region from various wild and cultivated cereals showed it to be very high in ergot from perennial rye and wheat vars. in the Stavropol' perennial test field in 1949, especially no. 35 hybrid (hard wheat * perennial rye, total alkaloids, determined micrometrically, 0.31%), no. 36 hybrid (wheat Hostianum 237 * perennial rye, 0.448%), and Alabazskaya soft wheat * perennial rye (0.315%). The higher alkaloid from these hybrids than from rye in a number of other areas must probably be attributed to different races of the fungus, disseminated mainly in the E., SE., and S. of the country. There was considerable variation in the alkaloid content of ergots from wild grasses, e.g. from Alopecurus pratensis (0.55%), Dactylis glomerata (0.59%), Festuca rubra (0.418%), and Elymus aren-arius (0.29%). There was also considerable variation in specimens from the same host, but from different sites.

Author: Pilipavičius, V.; Romaneckas, K.; Česna, J.
Title: Allelopathic effect of Sonchus arvensis L. On germination and early growth of spring wheat
Publication Title: Journal of Food, Agriculture and Environment
Abstract Note: In laboratory bioassay the allelopathic influence of ground perennial sow thistle Sonchus arvensis over-ground and rootstock biomass water extracts on spring wheat Triticum aestivum L. variety SW Estrad C2 grain germination and early growth was investigated. Grinded 50 g of air-dried plant part (over-ground or rootstock) was stirred into 500 ml of distilled water and left for 24 hours at a room temperature. Filtered water extract was taken as a stock solution. Stock solution was applied in 2-, 5-and 10-fold dilution, distilled water application served as control treatment. The spring wheat grain germination was checked after 5 and 11 days of sprouting using 5, 10 and 15 grains per Petri dish as different concentration of recipient plant. Spring wheat grain germination was more inhibited by Sonchus arvensis over-ground part than by rootstock water extracts. Spring wheat grain germination in Sonchus arvensis root water extract of stock solution was higher by 20-45% and by 5-30% than in Sonchus arvensis over-ground part water extract of stock solution, sprouting grains 5 and 11 days, respectively. During longer germination period of 11 days, negative effect of Sonchus arvensis over-ground part and root stock solution on spring wheat grain germination was moderated. Sonchus arvensis over-ground part and rootstock water extracts inhibited more spring wheat radicle growth than its seedling growth. Low concentration water extracts of Sonchus arvensis over-ground part showed tendency to increase spring wheat grain germination. The highest allelopathic inhibitory effect of Sonchus arvensis over-ground part and rootstock water extracts on spring wheat grain germination and early growth of seedlings and radicles was established in stock solution. Increase of recipient plant spring wheat grain number per Petri dish had no essential influence on its germination initiation, seedling and radicle growth in Sonchus arvensis over-ground part and rootstock water extracts.
Manual Tags: Allelopathy; Early growth; Germination; Grain; Perennial sow thistle; Radicle; Scopus; search.grain; search.wheat; Seedling; Sonchus arvensis L.; Spring wheat; SPV; TITLE-ABS-KEY (perennial W/1 grain) AND DOCTYPE (ar); Triticum aestivum L.; Water extract

Author: Putnam, A.r.; Barnes, J.p.; Nair, M.g.
Title: Allelopathy: a viable weed control strategy
Publication Title: UCLA symposia on molecular and cellular biology
Abstract Note: Allelopathy is the interference plants impose upon one another through release of chemicals. It has been implicated most frequently with aggressive weeds in their interference with crops and less frequently with crops against weeds. Work in our laboratory has focused on the use of allelopathic crops or their residues for weed control. Screening of crop germplasm indicates that differential allelopathic potential exists within these collections. The most successful approach we have employed is to use allelopathic cereal grains in rotation with annual crops or in companion planting with perennial crops. Rye (Secale cereale L.) is an example of a plant which provides excellent weed suppression through both allelopathic and competitive mechanisms. Rye residues maintained on the soil surface release 2,4-dihydroxy-1,4(2H)-benzoxazin-3-one (DIBOA) and a breakdown product 2(3H)-benzoxazalinone (BOA) both of which are strongly inhibitory to germination and seedling growth of dicoytylenous annual weeds. In addition, soil fungi convert BOA to 2,2'-oxo-1,1'-azo-benzene which is ten-fold more phytotoxic than BOA. Hence a variety of natural products contribute to the herbicidal activity of rye residues.
Journal Abbreviation: UCLA symposia on molecular and cellular biology
Manual Tags: AGRICOLA; search.rye; SPV; TX (perennial N1 ("rye" OR secale) NOT "rye#grass")
