Author: Quakernack, R.; Pacholski, A.; Techow, A.; Herrmann, A.; Taube, F.; Kage, H.
Title: Ammonia volatilization and yield response of energy crops after fertilization with biogas residues in a coastal marsh of Northern Germany
Publication Title: Recycling of organic resudues to agriculture
Abstract Note: Anaerobic co-fermentation of animal slurries and crop silages leads to new types of biogas residues with an uncertain fertilizer value. Ammonia volatilization losses and crop productivity after supplying co-fermented biogas residues were investigated at a marshland site in Northern Germany. Due to the ecological risks of monocultures, maize (Zea mays) in monoculture as the dominant biogas crop in the marsh was tested against a crop rotation (maize, wheat (Triticum aestivum), Italian ryegrass (Lolium multiflorum)) and perennial ryegrass (Lolium perenne). Biogas residues, applied by trail hoses, and CAN (mineral fertilizer) were used as nitrogen fertilizers. Ammonia losses at all application dates were investigated by an approach including passive flux samplers and a calibrated dynamic chamber method. Simultaneously a micrometeorological technique was used as a reference. A comparison of methods showed a close correlation (r2 = 0.92) between micromet and passive flux sampler techniques. Ammonia volatilization losses (on average 15% NH4+-N applied) occurred mainly within the first 10 h. Concomitant with high ammonia losses, a significant yield depression of 5 t DM ha−1 for ryegrass fertilized by biogas residues compared to CAN was observed. Little or no affect of biogas was observed for maize and wheat. The crop rotation had yields (34 t DM ha−1 2 year−1) that were comparable with the maize monoculture (31 t DM ha−1 2 year−1).
Manual Tags: Ammonia; Co-fermentation; Crop rotation; Energy crops; perennial W/1 (triticum OR wheat); ScienceDirect; search.wheat; SPV; Trail hoses

Author: Ramburan, S.
Title: A multivariate illustration and interpretation of non-repeatable genotype × environment interactions in sugarcane
Abstract Note: Abstract Non-repeatable genotype × ratoon (G × R) and genotype × site × ratoon (G × S × R) interactions in sugarcane (Saccharum sp.) restricts the evaluation of repeatable genotype × site (G × S) interactions, which is important for test site evaluation in breeding programs. Non-repeatable genotype × environment (G × E) interactions are rarely analysed and interpreted further in sugarcane. The aim of this study was to use environmental characterisation and multivariate methods when non-repeatable interactions dominate to (i) illustrate and interpret the confounding crop-year effects in sugarcane and its contribution to non-repeatable G × E, (ii) investigate the nature and magnitude of G × E interactions, and (iii) gain insights into test site similarities in the coastal region of South Africa to improve the efficiencies of the testing network. Variation in estimated recoverable crystal yield was larger for non-repeatable components compared to repeatable components in eight out of ten planting series. Additive main effects and multiplicative interaction (AMMI) biplots illustrated the differential genotype interactions with crop-years of the same trial. Principal components analysis (PCA) illustrated how crop-years clustered together on biplots in response to key environmental covariates derived from climatic data and crop growth models. Based on interpretations using integrated multivariate methods, it is hypothesised that non-repeatable G × E interactions may be larger in autumn compared to spring harvests. AMMI biplots for individual crop-years showed that site T2 is redundant, and should be removed from the trial network without loss of information. Integrated environmental characterisation and multivariate visual appraisals are proposed as alternatives to understanding non-repeatable G × E when crop and year effects cannot be separated experimentally. Hypotheses generated through visual appraisals should be subsequently tested quantitatively.
Manual Tags: Environmental covariate; Genotype × environment; Multivariate analyses; Non-repeatable G × E; ratoon* W/5 (oryza OR rice); ScienceDirect; search.rice; SPV; Sugarcane

Author: Paul, Asosii; Kumar, Sanjay
Title: An A20/AN1-zinc-finger domain containing protein gene in tea is differentially expressed during winter dormancy and in response to abiotic stress and plant growth regulators
Abstract Note: Abstract The present manuscript describes cloning and expression characterization of A20/AN1-zinc-finger domain containing protein (CsZfp) gene in an evergreen tree tea [Camellia sinensis (L.) O. Kuntze] in response to winter dormancy (WD), abiotic stresses (polyethylene glycol, hydrogen peroxide, and sodium chloride) and plant growth regulators [abscisic acid (ABA), and gibberellic acid (GA3)]. CsZfp encoded a putative protein of 173 amino acids with a calculated molecular weight of 18.44 kDa, an isoelectric point (pI) of 6.50 and grand average of hydropathicity (GRAVY) value of − 0.334. The gene did not have an intron, and belonged to a multi-gene family. During the period of active growth (PAG), CsZfp showed maximum expression in root and fruit as compared to leaf, floral bud and stem. Interaction studies between temperature and plant growth regulators on the expression of CsZfp showed that ABA upregulated CsZfp expression at growth temperature (GT; 25 °C) but had no effect at low temperature (LT; 4 °C). In response to GA3, upregulation was observed at LT but not at GT. Further, the expression was not modulated by LT either in the tissue harvested during PAG or during WD. It was interesting to record that the expression of CsZfp was upregulated by hydrogen peroxide and sodium chloride, whereas it was non-responsive to polyethylene glycol. The possible role of CsZfp in playing key but differential roles in tea to various abiotic stresses is discussed.
Manual Tags: A20/AN1 zinc-finger protein; Camellia sinensis; CsZfp; Gene expression; perennial W/1 (oryza OR rice); ScienceDirect; search.rice; SPV; Winter dormancy

Author: GRIGOR'EVA, N. M.; KUZ'MIN, Z. E.; LANINA, A. V.
Title: An All-Union meeting on distant hybridization in plants and animals.
Abstract Note: At a recent meeting in Moscow, N. V. Cicin named some of the successful cultivars that have arisen from crosses of wheat with rye, with Agropyron and with other Triticum species, discussed methods of overcoming sterility and explained the value of aneuploids. D. D. Breznev described the world collections and the use that had been made of them, leading to the production of over 500 new cultivars of various crop plants. Ja. S. Nesterov outlined the wide crosses that have been made in fruits and some of the problems associated with them. A. S. Jablokov stressed the importance of distant crosses in inducing heterosis in forest trees. A. F. Sulyndin reviewed work on wide crosses in cereals, and mentioned winter forms of Triticum durum and valuable segregates from crosses between different amphidiploid wheat hybrids, some of which have large ears, short straw, high tillering capacity and resistance to lodging and diseases. I. D. Mustafaev discussed the interrelationships between species of Triticum, Aegilops and SEcale and the natural hybrids frequently found in Azerbaijan. Several speakers referred to the Triticum-Agropyron hybrids of N. V. Cicin and described the most successful, some of which give three crops of green matter and excelled all other forage plants in hay yields, while others show a wide range in gluten contents and other factors determining baking quality and in resistance to frost and diseases; some are hardier than standard wheat cultivars such as Ul'janovka or Lutescens 329; P. P. Bereznoj reported on mutations induced in the amphidiploids, the proportion, which varied from 0.90 to 10.82%, being greatest after treatment of the octoploids; monosomics produced in back crosses with wheat were described by G. L. Jacevskij and meiotic irregularities in the hybrids by F. M. Skutina and I. N. Golubov-skaja. Forms resembling T. durum arising in crosses between octoploid and hexaploid Trificale, and described by M. A. Mahalin and E. D. Gruzdeva, proved resistant to frost and fungal diseases, bore 70-90 large grains per ear and had a protein content of 17-18%; hybrids of rye with A. glaucum were also described. V. V. Hvostova stated that none of the 56-chromosome Triticum-Agropyron or Triticale hybrids is fertile enough to be approved as a cultivar. Several speakers referred to Triticum-Agropyron hybrids that persist for 2-4 years and others to a successful perennial rye. Promising new wheats with high yields arising from back crosses of T. aestivum x T. durum to T. aestivum were described by A. M. Gabbasov. M. A. Ali-Zade and R. T. Alieva reported that interspecific wheat hybrids were intermediate between the parents in RNA content but did not differ from them in DNA. A spontaneous pea x vetch hybrid described by N. A. Sobolev and V. P. Bugrij was said to cross with both parents. B. S. Moskov and G. A. Makarova produced Raphanobrassica hybrids from cabbage grafts on radish; the F 1 displayed heterosis and various meiotic irregularities, the F 2 contained triploids, aneuploids and amphidiploids, the last being vigourous, frost resistant and high in vitamin C [ascorbic acid]; the diploids contained some forms that bred true and contained up to 130 mg. % vitamin C [ascorbic acid] in the leaves while having a root like a radish. S. M. Bukasov mentioned several hundred potato cultivars bred by interspecific crossing and analysed compatibility relationships between different series of section TUberarium in the genus Solanum. A. Ja. Kameraz outlined the use made in the Soviet Union of the primitive and wild potato species of Latin America, which contain resistance to Phytophthora, the aggressive races of Synchytrium endobioticum, nematodes and other diseases and to frost. E. I. Mamedov and others discussed interspecific crosses in cotton and the successful use of gibberellin and vitamin B 1K. A. Vysockij described a trispecific hybrid involving Hibiscus esculentus[Abelmoschus esculentus]; it combined the long lint of Gossypium barbadense with bolls weighing 8.5 g., earliness and high yield derived from 108F; other hybrids had double flowers, wilt resistance, glabrous seed and other properties from the Hibiscus, mallow and other plants participating as pollinators; a constant hybrid with marked heterosis has been obtained from crosses of Hibiscus species with n = 36 and n = 16. G. I. Belova described meiotic irregularities leading to sterility in distant hybrids in cotton. G. V. Pustovojt gave details of the resistance to diseases and pests in 24 wild sunflower species. M. F. Ternovskij referred to a large collection of Nicotiana species, various methods of overcoming their incompatibility with N. tabacum and N. rustica and the production from them of cultivars resistant to Peronospora tabacina and Erysiphe cichoracearum and to tobacco mosaic; N. didebia, resistant also to Thielaviopsis basicola, was also described. Various other speakers gave reports on interspecific hybrids of tobacco, one of those from N. rustica being resistant to tip chlorosis. G. S. Voskresenskaja referred to an amphidiploid Brassica juncea exceeding the control by 2.75 c. in seed yield and by 108 kg. in oil yield per ha. ; crossing B. juncea with winter rape gave a new crop, winter mustard, equal to winter rape in hardiness but higher in yield and described by V. I. Spota. Several speakers referred to interspecific hybrids of mint, lavender and tomato, some of the last being resistant to virus diseases. Several speakers mentioned a number of fruit cultivars bred by interspecific or intergeneric crossing, which included vines with high yields and quality derived from Vitis amurensis; others referred to wide crosses in nuts and in forest trees. T. S. Kantor reported the use of chemical mutagens on interspecific Fragaria hybrids and V. I. Ostapenko the application of high-frequency radioactive rays in overcoming incompatibility in fruit crosses.
Manual Tags: search.rye; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 ("rye" OR secale) NOT "rye$grass"); WOS

Author: MAHALIN, M. A.
Title: An All-Union meeting on distant hybridization in plants and animals.
Abstract Note: At a meeting on 27 February-2 March, 1968, at which 152 papers were presented, it was reported that some 20 field-crop cultivars derived from wide crosses have been approved. The various methods employed were described by N. V. Cicin, who in a joint contribution with V. F. Ljubimova gave a report on perennial wheats, some of which grow for up to four years. Several speakers referred to promising hybrids of Triticum with Secale, Elymus and Agropyron, of perennial rye and of winter T. durum, others to the results of cytological, embryological and physiological studies on wide crosses and to methods of overcoming sterility. In fruit trees, reference was made to hybrids of apple with pear and quince, to new hardy cultivars of apple and pear and to interspecific hybrids of currants, vines and strawberries, some of which are being introduced into cultivation. Interspecific hybrids in potatoes, sunflowers and tobacco were referred to as having disease resistance, Raphanobrassica as having smooth leaves with a high content of vitamin C [ascorbic acid] as well as roots resembling a radish. A winter mustard has been produced by crossing mustard with rape.
Manual Tags: search.rye; search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 ("rye" OR secale) NOT "rye$grass"); TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); WOS

Author: OGANOVA, E. A.
Title: An All-Union meeting on distant hybridization in plants and animals.
Publication Title: Izvestiya Akademii Nauk Belorusskoi SSR. Seriya Biologicheskikh Nauk
Abstract Note: At a meeting on 27 February to 2 March, 1968, in Moscow, N. V. Cicin stressed the contributions of N. I. Vavilov and his colleagues and the need to combine wide crossing with other modern methods such as the use of polyploidy, male sterility and mutagenesis. D. D. Breznev explained the value of the world collections as a source of material. Ja. S. Nesterov reported on some achievements in breeding fruit cultivars and A. S. Jablokov on the use of heterosis in breeding forest trees. In the section devoted to cereals there were reports on new methods of overcoming sterility in hybrids and on new winter forms of Triticum durum, perennial forms of rye and wheat, Triticale with complex disease resistance and Triticum x Agropyron hybrids that withstand 30-35C. of frost. In the section on perennial crops, reports were given of new winter-hardy cultivars of apple and pear and in that on technological crops, on interspecific hybrids of potato with complex disease resistance and new forms of sunflower, tobacco and other crops. [Cf. 169].
Manual Tags: search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); WOS

Author: Johnson, R. S.
Title: Analysis of a grain reserve plan.
Publication Title: [Publication] Economic Research Service, US Department of Agriculture
Abstract Note: This paper develops a specific proposal for grain reserves. By examining past experiences and the evolving role of the US in world grain markets, it identifies four purposes of reserves. First, grain reserves should function like shock absorbers - rising and falling as needed - rather than as a perennial grain inventory insulating the US from events in world markets. Second, reserves should be carefully insulated from the market to avoid premature release on the one hand and distortions of market forces on the other. Third, reserves should be held to meet needs arising from inevitable but unforeseeable fluctuations in supply and demand. Finally, governmental actions should be limited to eliminate needless uncertainties. A reserves proposal meeting these standards would include the following provisions: agreement on specific total carryover objectives; acreage adjustments to bring actual carryover levels to these objectives; government ownership of a specific proportion of total carryover objectives; governmental acquisition and release of stocks at specific, known prices separated by a wide band.
Manual Tags: search.grain; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 grain); WOS

Author: Zhang, Xing-Hai; Moloney, Maurice M.; Chinnappa, C.C.
Title: Analysis of an ABA- and osmotic stress-inducible dehydrin from Stellaria longipes
Abstract Note: Summary A complementary DNA (cDNA) clone encoding an ABA or osmotic-stress-inducible protein of Stellaria longipes was isolated and sequenced. Northern blot analysis showed that the expression of the corresponding gene was induced by treatments of ABA, PEG or drought but not by flooding. The deduced amino acid sequence exhibited overall structural similarity to the ABA- or osmotic stress-inducible proteins, especially dehydrins, from other plants. Sequence analysis indicated that the deduced protein may belong to a group of plant dehydrins. The S. longipes dehydrin shared some similarity in structural features with dehydrins of other plants and also exhibited certain unique characteristics.
Manual Tags: ABA; cDNA sequence; dehydrin; osmotic stress; perennial W/1 (oryza OR rice); ScienceDirect; search.rice; SPV; Stellaria longipes

Author: TianJu, Ren; JingYong, Li; XiaoChun, Zhang; PeiHua, Wang; GuangPing, Yu; Yao, Lu
Title: Analysis of combining ability and heritability of ratooning qualities in hybrid rice F 1.
Publication Title: Southwest China Journal of Agricultural Sciences
Abstract Note: To accelerate the breeding procedure of strong ratooning quality combinations, the combining ability and heritability of ratooning quality of hybrid F 1 rice were analysed by NC II design using 6 cytoplasmic male sterile (CMS) lines and 6 restorer lines for 3 times. The results showed that the general (GCA) and specific combining ability (SCA) of ratooning quality of hybrid rice F 1 were all significant, which were controlled by the additive and non-additive gene effects. The additive effect was predominant with higher narrow-sense heritability, which was affected by the environment and planting technique. The contribution rate of CMS lines and restorer lines to GCA depended on mean squares size. The relation between SCA and phenotypic value was positively significant. If SCA of cross was higher, GCA of one parent at least was also higher, showing that the parents with higher GCA could be used to breed hybrid combination with higher SCA. The CMS lines Fu 76A, G46A, 182A and II-32A, which had significant GCA, and the restorer lines 130, Minghui 63 and Duoxi 1 could be used as parents to breed combinations with strong ratooning quality.
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: TianJu, Ren; XiaoChun, Zhang; PeiHua, Wang; JingYong, Li
Title: Analysis of combining ability effect and the dominant characteristics of crosses with high yields in twice of hybrid mid-season and ratooning rice.
Publication Title: Southwest China Journal of Agricultural Sciences
Abstract Note: Using 6 CMS lines and 6 restorer lines for 3 times, a NC II model was designed to form 108 hybrid crosses. Among them, 12 hybrid crosses were selected whose yields in one season or total yield in two seasons were significantly higher that of the control Shanyou 63. Compared with Shanyou 63, these crosses showed earlier maturity, larger green canopy, more efficient transfer of photosynthetic production, higher grain-to-straw ratio, plant height and bearing rate, stronger resistance to lodging, and longer ratooning duration. Both general (GCA) and specific combining ability (SCA) effects significantly influenced the yields of the main crop and ratooning rice, and its total yields in two seasons, but GCA effect was dominant. There was significantly positive relationship among the value of GCA, SCA and total combining ability (TCA) to grain weight per plant. Therefore, the crosses with higher total yields in two seasons had larger value of TCA. The results showed that TCA value can be used as one of the indexes to select high yielding crosses in both mid-season and ratooning rice.
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: Zhang, Ting; Li, Lijuan; Hu, Fengyi; Zhao, Xiuqin; Fu, Binying; Yang, Daichang
Title: Analysis of ESTs from a Normalized cDNA Library of the Rhizome Tip of Oryza longistaminata
Abstract Note: Oryza longistaminata, a perennial wild rice species with an AA genome, is characterized by the presence of rhizomatous stems. The rhizomatous trait in rice was previously shown to be quantitatively controlled by many genes, but the molecular mechanism related to rhizome development is still unknown. In the present study, expressed sequence tags (ESTs) generated from rhizome tips of O. longistaminata were collected and analyzed. A total of 10,283 complimentary deoxyribunucleic acid clones were randomly sequenced, which generated 10,136 raw sequences, and finally, 4,419 unisequences with diverse functional categories were generated. These unisequences were mapped onto the Oryza sativa genome, which revealed that 4,285 (96.97%) and 4,151 (93.94%) of the unisequences were alignable to the japonica and indica genomic sequences, respectively, with > 80% sequence identity. Additionally, 41 unisequences showed four typical types of alternative splicing patterns. More than 600 simple sequence repeats were identified in these unisequences. A subset of unisequences were physically colocalized onto rhizome-related quantitative trait locus intervals in rice and sorghum, and one gene, OLRR1, was further confirmed to be enriched in the rhizome tip and young leaf by real-time polymerase chain reaction and in situ hybridization. Unisequences reported in this study provide valuable data for molecular dissection of the rhizomatous growth habit in O. longistaminata.
Manual Tags: Expressed sequence tags; Oryza longistaminata; Rhizome; Scopus; search.rice; SPV; TITLE-ABS-KEY (perennial W/1 (oryza OR rice)) AND DOCTYPE (ar); TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (oryza OR rice)); Unisequence; WOS

Author: Hou, Y.; Hou, G.; Qi, H.; Chen, C.; Li, X.; Zhao, M.; Dong, S.
Title: Analysis of photothermic resource use efficiency and potential increases in crop yields in high-yielding regions of eastern Asia
Abstract Note: In agronomic management, photothermic resources will play an increasingly important role in boosting crop yields to meet growing demands. This study explored photothermic resource use efficiency and predicted the highest theoretical yield of four crop types (maize, rice, ratoon rice and wheat) in the high-yielding regions of the Northeast plain, Huai Hai Lyrics valley and Yangtze River valley of China spanning a latitudinal range from N25.48° to N45.32°. The radiation production potential (RPP) and thermal production potential (TPP) of the four crop types were analyzed, using indexes of radiation production potential equivalence (RPPE) and thermal production potential equivalence (TPPE). The results showed that RPPE and TPPE varied with crop type, harvest zone and high-yielding areas. For the different crop types, the RPPE and TPPE of ratoon rice (0.7406, 0.7848) were the highest, while the RPPE of winter wheat (0.3041) and TPPE of rice (0.4955) were the lowest. The theoretical yield of maize (15,408.2kg hm"2) was the highest while that of winter wheat (10,273.4kg hm"2) was the lowest, and the theoretical yield of ratoon rice (12,245.2kg hm"2) was higher than that of rice (11,117.7kg hm"2). By harvest zone, the RPPE of the double harvest zone (0.5105) and TPPE of the single harvest zone (0.7015) were the highest, while the RPPE and TPPE of the triple harvest zone (0.4688, 0.5607) were the lowest. By area, the RPPE of Youxi (0.7406) and TPPE of Huadian (0.9089) were the highest, while the RPPE of Lianyungang (0.3607) and TPPE of Changsha (0.4702) were the lowest. Environmental parameters also impacted crop yield, where fewer hours of solar radiation caused a decline in RPP, while higher air temperatures increased TPP. Radiation was the limiting factor for summer maize, late rice and ratoon rice, while temperature was the limiting factor for winter wheat, spring maize and early rice; radiation was the limiting factor for the triple harvest zone, while temperature was the limiting factor for single and double harvest zones; finally, radiation was the limiting factor for Youxi, Changsha, Jiangsu, Wuxue and Haicheng, while temperature was the limiting factor for Harbin, Huadian, Laizhou, Xinxiang, Wuqiao and Lianyungang. Agricultural techniques also affected yield, where the optimum cultivation models were found to be high density double-planting for summer maize, cultivation in earth furrows for winter wheat, simultaneous optimization of the use of radiation and heat by ratoon rice and boosting of sink capacity and source capacity for rice. In conclusion, latitudinal differences in photothermic resources are poorly utilized, even in high-yielding regions, meaning that all regions including those that already meet their annual targets have the potential to further improve yields. Therefore, crops should be sown early to improve heat use efficiency in areas of low latitude while suitable sowing and harvesting dates should be chosen for high latitudes to improve radiation use efficiency. At the same time, the highest-yielding cultivation mode should be matched to the latitude, such as spring maize planting in Huadian, winter-wheat planting in Laizhou and ratoon rice planting in Youxi.
Manual Tags: Agriculture; China; Crop; Photothermic resource use efficiency; Radiation production potential; Radiation production potential equivalence; Scopus; search.rice; SPV; Thermal production potential; Thermal production potential equivalence; TITLE-ABS-KEY (ratoon* W/5 (oryza OR rice)) AND DOCTYPE (ar); Yield

Author: YuHong, Hou; GuoFeng, Hou; Hua, Qi; ChuanYong, Chen; XiangLing, Li; Ming, Zhao; ShuTing, Dong

Author: Bassani, Tiago Packer; Breda, Luciani
Title: Analysis of production costs, productivity and profitability on three technologies of cultivation of irrigated rice on the farm Sao Sebastiao, Querencia do Norte, PR
Abstract Note: This study aims to verify and analyze the technical and economic viability of irrigated rice in face of three technology models of cultivation: a) first planting, b) second planting c) ratoon, describing and distinguishing the technology models and analyzing and comparing production costs. The study was conduct in the farm "Sao Sebastiao", municipality of "Querencia do Norte". First, were described the technologies and later the production costs per hectare (ha) for each technology adopted. Among the three technological models, which the highest cost of production is the first planting, along with the most revenue. But as the study seeks to determine which of the two other technologies (second planting and ratoon) is the more viable, it's observed that the ratoon technology has the lowest cost of production and most profitability, moreover, is the ratoon cultivation there is lower wear and tear of machinery and equipment. So, conclude that the more viable technology both in production conditions, financial and procedural, is the ratoon technology. In the conditions presented this technology is the most appropriate and profitable to be adopted after the crop of the first planting technology.
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: Roberto, Z. E.; Viglizzo, E. F.
Title: Analysis of the impact of forage resources on agroecosystems of the semiarid pampas.
Abstract Note: A group of 55 farms in the semiarid pampas regions was divided by cluster analysis into a cattle production ecosystem and a cattle-crop production ecosystem. For these the relation of the amounts of natural, cultivated perennial, Eragrostis curvula, small grain and annual summer pastures to productivity, profitability and stability of farms was investigated. There were correlations between pasture areas and cattle production but not between pasture areas and the stability of ecosystems. Close correlations with total farm production were only found in the cattle production ecosystem. The cattle ecosystem showed close correlations between costs and relative areas of perennial, E. curvula and small grain pastures. The impact of the introduction of perennial pastures was greater in the cattle than in the cattle-crop system. The importance of the introduction of different pastures decreased in the order perennial, small grain, E. curvula and annual summer pastures.
Manual Tags: search.grain; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 grain); WOS

Author: Pereira, Antonio Roberto; Villa Nova, Nilson Augusto
Title: Analysis of the Priestley-Taylor parameter
Abstract Note: Using three independent data sets, one representative of an upland rice crop grown in Campinas, Brazil, and the other two obtained in Davis, CA, for a perennial rye grass, it was shown that the variations of the Priestley-Taylor parameter α reported in the literature is well described by the fluctuations of the sensible heat flux (H). The results obtained show that α was linearly related to H in a positive way, either on an hourly basis or on a daily scale. The relationships found indicate that the original proposition of α = 1.26, for the potential conditions, does not represent a situation of advection.
Manual Tags: perennial W/1 ("rye" OR secale) AND NOT ("rye?grass" OR "ryegrass"); ScienceDirect; Scopus; search.rye; SPV; TITLE-ABS-KEY (perennial W/1 ("rye" OR secale) AND NOT ("rye?grass" OR ryegrass)) AND DOCTYPE (ar)

Author: Jian-fu, Zhang; Yong-sheng, Zhu; Qiu-hua, Cai; Chuan-ying, Zhuo; Shang-shou, Zhang; Rong-he, Zheng; Hua-an, Xie
Title: Analysis on Correlationship of Net Photosynthetic Rate with Yield and Its Components of Ratooning Rice
Abstract Note: The net photosynthetic rate of flag leaf was measured at the filling stage and maturity stage of ratooning rice with thirteen hybrid rice combinations as materials. The net photosynthetic rate at the filling stage of ratooning rice was significantly higher than that at the maturity stage, and the difference in the photosynthetic rate at the filling stage was more than that at the maturity stage among all the combinations, and the net photosynthetic rate was significantly different at the same stage among different combinations. The net photoynthetic rate at the filling stage was positively correlated with the yield of ratooning rice, and that at the maturity stage was significantly and negatively correlated with the yield of ratooning rice. In addition, the net photosynthetic rate at the filling stage was significantly and positively correlated with the seed setting rate.
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: RuiYu, Lin; HongFei, Chen; JiaYao, Deng; YiYuan, Liang; KangJing, Liang; WenXiong, Lin
Title: Analysis on energy accumulation and calorific value of early-season rice and its ratooning rice under different cultivation models.
Abstract Note: A new rice hybrid, Youhang I, was used to analyse accumulated dry weight, energy fixation and calorific value in early-season rice and its ratooning rice under super high-yield cultivation (SHC) and conventional cultivation (CC) models. The results showed that accumulated dry weight in the plants at mature stage under SHC was 2220.04 and 1697.62 g/m 2 for early-season and ratooning rice, respectively, being 1.26- and 1.29-fold higher than that under CC. Calorific value in leaves, grains, sheaths and culms of the plants were 14 848.7-18 494.9, 15 810.3-17 438.0, 14 029.1-17 039.6 and 14 405.4-17 576.5 J/g under SHC, respectively. The calorific values in leaves and grains were significantly higher than those in culm and sheath, but no significant difference was found under the 2 cultivation models. The accumulated energy in the plants at mature stage was 35.71 and 26.24 MJ/m 2 under SHC for early season and ratooning rice, respectively, being 27.4 and 29.6% higher than that under CC. The ratio of accumulated energy partitioned into grains was 52.7% for early-season rice under SHC, which was 1.2% higher than that under CC, and for ratooning rice (51.5%), there was no significant difference between the 2 models. During grain filling, the ratio of energy remobilized from leaves, culms and sheaths was 39.7% for early-season rice under SHC, being significantly higher than that under CC (23.1%), and the value was 16.9% for ratooning rice, which was also higher than that under CC (14.7%). It implied that the energy flow in rice under SHC was much more smooth than that under CC. In addition, at yellow mature stage, the energy exportation ratio of the root was 7.9% under SHC, being obviously lower than that of CC, it was ensured for grain filling and regeneration of ratooning rice, and the energy of grains remobilized from the stubble of ratooning rice was 25.9%, indicating that the grain yield under SHC relied less on the photosynthate in the period of grain filling, which was beneficial to steady and high yield of ratooning rice.
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: Chavez, M.D.; Berentsen, P.B.M.; Oude Lansink, A.G.J.M.
Title: Analyzing diversification possibilities on specialized tobacco farms in Argentina using a bio-economic farm model
Abstract Note: Abstract Tobacco (Nicotiana tabacum L.) is the non-food crop with the largest acreage in the world. Tobacco is criticized because it causes health problems to its consumers and because production causes environmental damage such as soil degradation, deforestation and water pollution. Diversification has been indicated as the strategy for a sustainable economic development for farmers. In the specific case of Valle de Lerma, many years of continuous tobacco mono-cropping, excessive ploughing and poor irrigation control have caused soil degradation of the land used for tobacco. Tobacco farming in Salta also entails a production and a price risk which is increasing because of uncertainty surrounding governmental subsidies. The objective of this article is to assess the impact of diversification on expected farm income, income risk and soil organic matter (as an indicator of soil degradation) on specialized tobacco farms. To reach this objective, a quadratic programming model of a typical specialized tobacco farm is developed. Soil organic matter is included in the model by means of the concept of the carbon balance. The carbon balance is the difference between carbon supply and carbon decline in a year. Two different situations with respect to soil degradation are evaluated using the model. The current situation includes no restriction on carbon balance while the desired situation includes the restriction that the carbon balance cannot be negative. So farmers’ choices are valuated with and without carbon balance constraints. The model results for the current situation show that, no matter which risk attitude is used, the maximum area of land given irrigation possibilities is devoted to tobacco, while the rest of the land is assigned to the non-irrigated crop soybean. The carbon balance is negative and soil continues to degrade. In the desired situation, tobacco and soybean are partly replaced by bull beef production (including the production of alfalfa and maize for silage) to fulfill the requirement of a no negative carbon balance. As the risk aversion coefficient in this situation increases, the low risk crop chickpea enters the solution and bull beef decreases. The requirement of no further soil degradation comes at a high cost since gross margin of the farm is decreased by some 35% compared to the current situation. Finally, the model is used to explore the effects of an abolishment of governmental subsidies on tobacco. In this situation the production plan consists of soybean, bull beef and tobacco in such a proportion that the carbon balance is positive. Income effects of an abolishment of governmental subsidies on tobacco would be large as the gross margin of the farm decreases by some 60%.
Manual Tags: Income risk; perennial W/1 (oryza OR rice); Quadratic risk programming; Risk aversion; ScienceDirect; search.rice; Soil degradation; SPV; Tobacco diversification

Author: Li, J.X.; Yu, S.B.; Xu, C.G.; Tan, Y.F.; Gao, Y.J.; Li, X.H.; Zhang, Q.
Title: Analyzing quantitative trait loci for yield using a vegetatively replicated F2 population from a cross between the parents of an elite rice hybrid
Abstract Note: Although F2s are the most informative populations for genetic analysis, it has been difficult to use F2 populations directly for QTL analysis because it is usually difficult to assess the reliability of the data, due to an inability to estimate the experimental errors. In this study, we performed a QTL analysis for yield and yield-component traits of an F2 population based on data from replicated field trials over 2 years using vegetative shoots of ratooned plants, making use of the ratooning habit of rice. The objective of this study was to explore the possibility of conducting QTL analyses directly based on an F2 population by means of ratooning plants. The experimental population was from a cross between 'Zhenshan 97' and 'Minghui 63', the parents of 'Shanyou 63', an elite rice hybrid widely grown in China. A genetic linkage map containing 151 molecular markers was constructed for QTL mapping. A total of 20 distinct QTLs were detected; eight of these were detected in both years and remaining 12 in only 1 year. Compared with the results of our previous analysis of the F(2:3) families from the same cross, it was shown that most of the QTLs detected in the ratooned F2 population were also detected in the F(2:3) population. However, the estimates of both additive and dominant types of genetic effects for many of the QTLs based on F2 ratoons were substantially larger than those based on F(2:3) families. The results indicate that vegetatively ratooned F2 populations may have considerable utility in the mapping of QTLs, especially if dominant types of gene actions are of concern, although there were certain technical limitations in making use of such populations in the experiments.
Manual Tags: Molecular marker; Oryza sativa L.; QTL; Ratoon; Scopus; search.rice; SPV; TITLE-ABS-KEY (ratoon* W/5 (oryza OR rice)) AND DOCTYPE (ar)

Author: Li, J. X.; Yu, S. B.; Xu, C. G.; Tan, Y. F.; Gao, Y. J.; Li, X. H.; Zhang, Q.
Title: Analyzing quantitative trait loci for yield using a vegetatively replicated F-2 population from a cross between the parents of an elite rice hybrid
Abstract Note: Although F(2)s are the most informative populations for genetic analysis, it has been difficult to use F-2 populations directly for QTL analysis because it is usually difficult to assess the reliability of the data, due to an inability to estimate the experimental errors. In this study, we performed a QTL analysis for yield and yield-component traits of an F-2 population based on data from replicated field trials over 2 years using vegetative shoots of ratooned plants, making use of the ratooning habit of rice. The objective of this study was to explore the possibility of conducting QTL analyses directly based on an F-2 population by means of ratooning plants. The experimental population was from a cross between 'Zhenshan 97' and 'Minghui 63', the parents of 'Shanyou 63', an elite rice hybrid widely grown in China. Agenetic linkage map containing 151 molecular markers was constructed for QTL I napping. A total of 20 distinct QTLs were detected. eight of these were detected in both years and remaining 12 in only 1 year. Compared with the results of our previous analysis of the F-2:3 families from the same cross, it was shown that most of the QTLs detected in the ratooned F-2 population were also detected in the F-2:3 population. However, the estimates of both additive and dominant types of genetic effects for many of the QTLs based on F-2 ratoons were substantially larger than those based on F-2:3 families. The results indicate that vegetatively ratooned F-2 populations may have considerable utility in the mapping of QTLs, especially if dominant types of gene actions are of concern, although there were certain technical limitations in making use of such populations in the experiments.
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: Rao, J. V. D. K. K.; Johansen, C.; Chauhan, Y. S.; Chauhan, Y. S.; Jain, V. K.; Jain, K. C.; Talwar, H. S.
Title: An analysis of yield variation among long-duration pigeonpea genotypes in relation to season, irrigation and plant population.
Abstract Note: The response of eight long-duration pigeonpea ( Cajanus cajan) genotypes to irrigation was studied at Gwalior, Madhya Pradesh, India during the 1990/91, 1991/92 and 1992/93 growing seasons on an Inceptisol. The crop was grown at two spacings as it was expected that crop density could interact with the crop's ability to extract soil moisture. The irrigation treatment received furrow irrigation four times during the 1990/91 and 1992/93 seasons and twice during the 1991/92 season. Grain yields of all genotypes were 11% higher when planted at higher density than at low density. There was a differential variation in yield and harvest index among genotypes due to season but not due to spacing and irrigation suggesting the validity of the present approach of testing genotypes under optimum conditions. Grain yield declined by 21% from the 1990 to 1992 season. The decline was >1 t/ha in some cultivars (ICPL 366, GW3), and between 0.5 and 1.0 t/ha in others (NP (WR) 15, ICP 87143 and ICPL 84072). In others (Bahar, ICP 9174, ICP 8860) the yield fluctuation was <0.5 t/ha. The genotypes' mean yields were as high as 2.7 t/ha for ICPL 87143, ICPL 84072 and ICPL 366. There was a significant reduction in both grain yield (16%), and also aboveground plant dry mass (18%) due to soil moisture limitation in the unirrigated treatment. Both the aboveground plant dry mass and grain yields were significantly more at high plant density than at lower plant density especially with irrigation. The genotypes were found to differ in their response to production environment (irrigation, spacing and to the undefined differences of the 3 years). Genotypic variation in yield within a production environment was found to vary in relation to changes in harvest index and across environment (irrigation, seasons) due to variation in total dry matter production. A lack of negative relationship between the total dry matter and harvest index suggests the possibility of optimizing both for obtaining higher yield from long-duration genotypes.
Manual Tags: AGRICOLA; Scopus; search.grain; search.pigeonpea; SPV; TITLE-ABS-KEY ("long duration" W/1 (cajanus OR "pigeon?pea" OR pigeonpea)) AND DOCTYPE (ar); TS=(perennial NEAR/1 grain); TX ("long duration" N1 (cajanus OR "pigeon#pea")); WOS
Automatic Tags: Cajanus cajan; crop production; crop yield; genetic variation; genotype; India; irrigation; seasonal variation; soil chemistry

Author: M, SHINOHARA; T, KANEHIRA
Title: ANATOMICAL OBSERVATIONS OF THE FUNGUS GALLS OF PERENNIAL WILD RICE ZIZANIA-LATIFOLIA CAUSED BY USTILAGO-ESCULENTA AND INOCULATION EXPERIMENTS OF THE FUNGUS TO THE PLANT
Publication Title: Bulletin of the College of Agriculture and Veterinary Medicine Nihon   University
Abstract Note: It is known that there are two type galls, makomotake type (cultivated type) and makomozumi type (wild type), induced by Ustilago esculenta in the stem tissue of Zizania latifolia. The former is widely used as a vegetable in the Southern Far East and the spores abundantly produced in the latter wild type gall are used in the wood carving craft (Kamakura carving) in Japan. Three cultivated strains and two wild strains of Z. latifolia, both of which had been infected with U. esculenta, were used in the histopathological observations. Artificial inoculation experiments were carried out to the healthy plants grown from the seeds of wild Z. latifolia with spores and monosporidial culture from the makomozumi type galls and isolate strain culture from the tissue of makomotake type gall, by partial vacuum and injection methods, together with some tests on storage conditions influencing longevity of the spores. From the results the following are suggested that the different symptoms or the two gall types of Z. latifolia may be due to the reactions of the host plants, the cultivated and the wild, to the pathogen, as stated previously by KANEHIRA et al.
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: JOHNSON, L. P. V.; MCLENNAN, H. A.
Title: An attempt to hybridize annual and perennial Avena species.
Abstract Note: Success in hybridizing annual Triticum and perennial Agropyron species, and the interest in the production of new perennial forage crops prompted attempts to hybridize annual and perennial Avena species. Results were negative.-R.O.W.
Manual Tags: search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); WOS

Author: Wani, Shabir H.; Sanghera, Gulzar S.; Gosal, Satbir S.
Title: An efficient and reproducible method for regeneration of whole plants from mature seeds of a high yielding Indica rice (Oryza sativa L.) variety PAU 201
Abstract Note: Tissue culture is one of the tools necessary for genetic engineering and many other breeding programs. Moreover, selection of high regenerating rice varieties is a pre-requisite for success in rice biotechnology. In this report we established a reproducible plant regeneration system through somatic embryogenesis. The explants used for regeneration were embryogenic calli derived from mature seeds cultured on callus induction media. For callus induction mature seeds were cultured on MS medium containing 30 g/l sucrose combined with 560 mg/l proline and 1.5–3.5 mg/l 2,4-D and 0.5–1.5 mg/l Kin. For plant regeneration, embryogenic calli were transferred to MS medium containing 30 g/l sucrose, supplemented with 1.0–3.0 mg/l BAP, 0.5–1.5 mg/l Kin and 0.5–1.5 mg/l NAA. The highest frequency of callus induction (44.4%) was observed on the MS medium supplemented with 2.5 mg/l 2,4-D, 0.5 mg/l Kin, 560 mg/l proline and 30 g/l sucrose. The highest frequency of shoot regeneration (42.5%) was observed on the MS medium supplemented with 2.0 mg/l BAP, 0.5 mg/l NAA and 0.5 mg/l Kin. The plantlets were hardened and transferred to soil in earthen pots. The developed method was highly reproducible. The in vitro developed plants showed normal growth and flowering under glasshouse conditions.
Manual Tags: perennial W/1 (oryza OR rice); ScienceDirect; search.rice; SPV

Author: MALYGIN, JU N.
Title: An enthusiast for distant hybridization.
Abstract Note: An outline of the work of N. V. Cicin mentions his Triticum-Agropyron hybrids, which include successful winter and spring cultivars and some perennial wheats giving crops for two to four successive years; various other cereal hybrids, including Triticum * Elymus, Secale * Agropyron and Triticale; and interspecific Nicotiana hybrids resistant to tip chlorosis.
Manual Tags: search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); WOS

Author: Keady, T.W.J.; O'Kiely, P.
Title: An evaluation of the effects of rate of nitrogen fertilization of grassland on silage fermentation, in-silo losses, effluent production and aerobic stability
Abstract Note: A factorial experiment was carried out to evaluate the effects of level of nitrogen (N) application to grassland and subsequent treatment of the herbage at ensiling with formic acid on the rate of silage fermentation, dry-matter (DM) recovery, aerobic stability and effluent production. Herbage from the primary regrowth of predominantly perennial rye-grass swards received either 72 (LN), 126 (MN) or 180 (HN) kg N ha-1. The herbages were harvested and yield estimated after a 50-day regrowth interval. After storage for 24 h in polythene bags, the herbages were ensiled, unwilted, in laboratory silos (6 kg capacity) either untreated (UT) or treated with formic acid (F) at 3 ml (kg herbage)-1 . Three silos per treatment were opened and sampled on days 1. 3, 6, 15, 50 and 105 after ensiling. The mean herbage yields for the LN, MN and HN swards were 5.2, 6.3 and 6.2 (s.e. = 0.27) t DM ha-1 and there was no carryover effect of nitrogen treatment on the yield of a subsequent 22-day regrowth harvested on 2 September. As level of fertilizer N application increased, concentrations in the herbage at mowing of crude protein, nitrate and ash increased, DM decreased and water-soluble carbohydrate and in vitro DM digestibility remained unchanged. Increasing the rate of N fertilizer to the sward resulted in higher silage pH (P<0.001) and ammonia N concentrations (P < 0.001) at each time of sampling. Increasing the rate of fertilizer N increased effluent output (P < 0.001) and DM recovery (P<0.001). Aerobic stability was improved (P < 0.001) by use of high rates of N fertilizer application. Formic acid treatment restricted fermentation and increased effluent output (P<0.001) but had no effect (P>0.05) on DM recovery. It is concluded that the rate and extent of pH decline was reduced with increasing N application, associated with increased buffering capacity and decreased DM concentrations of the herbage at ensiling. However, increasing the level of N fertilizer applied increased DM recovery and effluent output, and improved aerobic stability of the resulting silages.
Manual Tags: Scopus; search.rye; SPV; TITLE-ABS-KEY (perennial W/1 ("rye" OR secale) AND NOT ("rye?grass" OR ryegrass)) AND DOCTYPE (ar)

Author: MIHAILOVSKII, V.
Title: A new cultivated plant, perennial sorghum.
Abstract Note: Hybridization of Sorghum halepense (L.) Pers. has been carried out since 1936 with a large number of cultivated varieties of S. technicum (Koern.) Roshev., S. vulgare (L.) Pers., S. saccharatum (L.), Pers., S. japonicum (Hack) Roshev., S. durra Stapf and S. Caffrorum Beauv. Only combinations involving S annual and f S. halepense were successful. The hybrid origin was definitely established only in the combination S. halepense * S. saccharatum (two varieties). The F 2 generation developed slowly, but in growth vigour the hybrids exceeded the parent plant. In F 2, forms with cultivated panicles were found. In the height of plants and forage yield, 40-chromosome hybrids (a part of No. 110 * S. halepense) were inferior to 30-chromosome hybrids (all " Orange " * S. halepense and some of the other combinations), but they produced larger amounts of seeds. Vigorous halepense roots dominated in F 2, but several forms with shorter and less vigourous roots could be selected; only the latter could be regarded as desirable.-M.A.O.
Manual Tags: search.sorghum; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 sorghum); WOS

Author: MIKHAILOVSKII, V.
Title: A new cultivated plant-perennial sorghum.
Abstract Note: Crosses of various cultivated annual sorghums with S. halepense were successful when the former were used as maternal parent; crosses with sweet sorghum were the most successful. Segregation occurred in the F 2 for time of flowering, some plants giving no seed at all before the onset of frosts. Only a small proportion of the plants had a non-shattering rachis. Most of the hybrids had rhizomes and those with short ones are being selected. The grain was intermediate in size and type. The somatic chromosome number was 30 in most plants, some however had 2 n = 40.
Manual Tags: search.sorghum; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 sorghum); WOS

Author: EDWARDS, D. C.
Title: A new fodder crop : perennial Kavirondo sorghum.
Abstract Note: The species, grown experimentally during the last 5 years, results from a natural hybrid between a native cultivated grain sorghum and Sorghum verticilliflorum, a widely distributed wild sorghum of Kenya. Trials have shown that the plant is a perennial of considerable duration, that a heavy seed crop is produced and establishment from seed is exceptionally easy. Information is supplied on yields and chemical composition and use of the crop in drier, mixed farming areas, as a highly productive fodder and in a temporary ley, is notable. The species does not seem prone to develop cyanogenetic properties.-M.H.
Manual Tags: search.sorghum; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 sorghum); WOS

Author: GORGIDZE, A. D.; NAZAROVA, E. A.
Title: A new original form of wheat-rye hybrid.
Publication Title: Rec. Georg. bot. Soc. Acad. Sci. Georg. SSR
Abstract Note: On crossing the Colchis wheat Triticum palaeo-colchicum var. chvamlicum with Derzavin's perennial rye, a self-fertile, stable hybrid was obtained which combines the morphological characters of both parents. It has a two-year developmental cycle and is amphidiploid (2n = 42).

Author: D'HERDE, J.
Title: A new root-knot nematode. parasite of beet culture [Dutch, French, and Engl. summ.]
Abstract Note: In June 1964 a new Meloidogyne species was found on sugar beet at Doel in the Antwerp Polder. Two large patches of poor growth occurred in the field where the roots of the young plants showed small and oblong thickenings. The same year this nematode was also found on sugar beet in Melsele and Vrasene and on mangold in Melsele. Larvae of this nematode have been found several times in soil samples taken in fields where only agricultural crops were grown. In pot trials the following plants also were infected: wheat, barley, oats, rye, perennial ryegrass, Italian ryegrass, and weeds Poa anmia, Polvgonum persicaria. and Mercurialis sp. No? infected were: tomato, scorzonera, carrot, lettuce, chicory, bean, flax, white clover, red clover, corn, potato, and the weeds Agropyron repens and Matricaria chamomilla. This is undoubtedly a typical root-knot nematode of the Gramineae. As many as 16 swollen females were found in one small gall on sugar beet, and over 400 eggs were counted in one single egg mass. Eggs were deposed in the roots of wheat and of perennial and Italian ryegrass on the 23rd day after sowing in the green-house at 22[degree]C. However up to now it is not known to what extent Gramineae can be damaged by this nematode. || ABSTRACT AUTHORS: Author

Author: JAKOVLEV, A. V.
Title: An experiment on growing perennial wheat in southern Kazahstan.
Abstract Note: The perennial wheat variety 2, obtained by crossing the winter wheat Lutescens 329 with Agropyron glaucum[Elymus hispidus], proved productive when grown for forage on irrigated land at Alma-Ata. It yielded up to 141 c. forage per ha. and was hardy, notably in the first year. It showed resistance to lodging, rusts, bunt and smut.
Manual Tags: search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); WOS

Author: GUREEV, I. G.
Title: An experiment with the introduction of crop rotations in the collective farms of the ckalov territory.
Abstract Note: An account of work conducted between 1939-41, in the drought-susceptible territory in S.E. U.S.S.R., with a view to obtaining stable yields of grain and forage crops. In the majority of collective farms, 9-course rotations have been introduced on ordinary black-earth soils: (1) fallow; (2) winter rye; (3) spring wheat + perennials (lucerne + Agropyvon sp.); (4) and (5) perennial herbage crops; (6) and (7) spring wheat; (8) sunflower + millet; and (9) oats + barley. On southern black-earth and chestnut soils, poorer in humus, 10-course rotations have been in use, differing from the 9-course rotation in that 3, instead of 2, fields were allotted to perennial herbage crops. The area under forage crops varied according to the" total arable land in cultivation, being proportionately smaller in the larger than in the lesser farming units. Thus, in the three collective farms with 2, 223, 1, 431 and 916 ha. of land, the herbage crops constituted 11.7, 15.7 and 21.8 per cent respectively of the total cultivated area. The pro-duction of seeds of forage crops must be organized according to the 6-year plan, in each collective farm where 40-60 per cent of the grass yield should be ear-marked for the seed reserve fund. There are given 8 standard 8-, 9-and 10-course rotations to illustrate the gradual transition from the ordinary to complex rotations with the inclusion of perennial herbage crops. Administrative details and premium payments to the technical personnel for the successful carrying out of the plan are discussed.-H.F.
Manual Tags: search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); WOS

Author: LiYun, Chen; YingHui, Xiao; WenBang, Tang; DaiMiao, Liu
Title: An ideal planting pattern for the adjustment of grain yield structure - middle season rice and its ratoon rice.
Abstract Note: Two-line rice hybrid Peiliangyou 500 was ratooned after growing as a middle-season crop. Total yield of the main and ratoon crop was 12.08 t/ha, which was 37.5% higher than yield of the control cultivar Shanyou 63. Grain quality was also better in the hybrid rice.

Author: Liu, B. G.; Zhang, X. Q.; Wang, G. M.; Wan, Z. L.; Huang, Y. Q.; Ren, C. F.
Title: An investigation of the distribution of photosynthates during the ripening stage of the main crop and the ratooning period of rice cultivar Shanyou 63.
Abstract Note: In a experiment with rice cv. Shanyou 63 using 14C tracer techniques, it was shown that more than half of the photosynthates produced during the ripening stage of the main crop were transported to the panicles while the rest (39-49%) remained in the vegetative organs, chiefly in the stems and leaves. 8.2-10.6% was eventually transferred to the panicles of the ratoon crop, mostly to those from the 2nd and 3rd nodes. The photosynthetic products formed by the ratoon crop were largely delivered to the panicles, with those from the 2nd, 3rd and 4th nodes from the bottom as the major recipients.
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: Pimentel, David; Cerasale, David; Stanley, Rose C.; Perlman, Rachel; Newman, Elise M.; Brent, Lincoln C.; Mullan, Amanda; Chang, Debbie Tai-I
Title: Annual vs. perennial grain production
Abstract Note: Annual grain crops are planted on about 70% of the world's cropland and provide 80% of the world's food. Currently annual grains dominate grain production. Perennial grains offer many important opportunities to produce grains in a more environmentally, economically, and energetically sound manner. Thus, major research efforts are needed to develop perennial grains to help feed the growing and malnourished world population. These grains would also aid in diversifying agriculture.

Author: A, AGUIAR P. A.
Title: ANNUAL YIELD POTENTIAL OF GRAIN SORGHUM SORGHUM-BICOLOR UNDER IRRIGATED CONDITIONS
Abstract Note: The annual sorthum (S. bicolor L. Moench) grain production potential of 8 commercial hybrids and 2 varieties was evaluated under irrigated conditions in the Sao Francisco Valley [Brazil]. A double row system spaced 40 cm apart in beds of 70 cm width, with approximately 15 plants/m in each row. The hybrids tested were more productive than the varieties. A gradual decrease in the average yield was obtained from the 1st harvest to the 1st and 2nd ratoon cropping, with 9313, 6476 and 3602 kg/ha, respectively. The total average yield from the 3 harvests reached 19,391 kg/ha, indicating the technical viability of exploring grain sorghum under irrigated conditions.

Author: PAL, M.; KAUSHIK, S. K.
Title: A note on ratoon-ing of sorghum in Northern India.
Abstract Note: Sorghum cv. CSH-1 and Swarna sown in early May and harvested 74-80 days later, yielded approximately 500hkg fresh fodder/ha. The ratoon crops of CSH-1 and Swarna yielded 61 and 60 hkg grain/ha, respectively, compared with 43.2 and 22.2 hkg when sown as late crops. The increased yields in ratoon crops were attributed to an increase in tillers/plant.-M.S.M.

Author: Palchamy, A.
Title: A note on the yield and duration of ratooned rice varieties.
Abstract Note: Rice cv. Bhavani and Vaigai sown in end June matured in 133 and 107 days and gave paddy yields of 8.00 and 6.54 t/ha, resp. their ratoon crops matured in 76 and 70 days and gave yields of 4.85 and 3.29 t, resp.

Author: Babaev, A. G.; Ovezliev, A. O.; Muradov, B. K.
Title: Antideflation fodder crop rotations on sands.
Abstract Note: The productivity of two 6-course fodder crop rotations designed to reduce soil erosion by wind blow was compared in 1986-90 on fine-grained sand at the central Karakum field station. 10 t FYM, 100 kg P and 50 kg K/ha were applied at seedbed preparation, 150 kg N/ha was top dressed in the 1st year and mineral fertilizers and FYM were applied as appropriate to Medicago sativa, millet [ Panicum miliaceum], perennial sorghum and swedes. Soil erosion was most prevalent in spring in the period from sowing to tillering and in the initial year of the study, when the natural vegetation was ploughed up. Soil erosion was greater with fodder beet, Medicago sativa and millet than with Sorghum sudanense, and was lowest with sunflowers and maize. By the tillering stage, the risk of erosion was reduced by a well-developed root system and thinning and weeding were worthwhile. The increase in the occurrence of weeds after the 1st year is discussed; weeds were most prevalent in sorghum and fodder beet. The yields and nutritive value of the rotations are discussed. The recommended rotations were late sorghum cv. Guinea/ M. sativa/Sudan grass/perennial sorghum/annual sorghum + Lablab purpureus/ M. sativa + Sudan grass and silage maize followed by swedes/perennial sorghum/silage sunflowers followed by swedes/ M. sativa + Sudan grass/fodder beet followed by swedes or winter oats/ M. sativa.
Manual Tags: search.sorghum; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 sorghum); WOS

Author: Signorelli, Santiago; Casaretto, Esteban; Sainz, Martha; Díaz, Pedro; Monza, Jorge; Borsani, Omar
Title: Antioxidant and photosystem II responses contribute to explain the drought–heat contrasting tolerance of two forage legumes
Abstract Note: Abstract Identification of metabolic targets of environmental stress factors is critical to improve the stress tolerance of plants. Studying the biochemical and physiological responses of plants with different capacities to deal with stress is a valid approach to reach this objective. Lotus corniculatus (lotus) and Trifolium pratense (clover) are legumes with contrasting summer stress tolerances. In stress conditions, which are defined as drought, heat or a combination of both, we found that differential biochemical responses of leaves explain these behaviours. Lotus and clover showed differences in water loss control, proline accumulation and antioxidant enzymatic capacity. Drought and/or heat stress induced a large accumulation of proline in the tolerant species (lotus), whereas heat stress did not cause proline accumulation in the sensitive species (clover). In lotus, Mn-SOD and Fe-SOD were induced by drought, but in clover, the SOD-isoform profile was not affected by stress. Moreover, lotus has more SOD-isoforms and a higher total SOD activity than clover. The functionality and electrophoretic profile of photosystem II (PSII) proteins under stress also exhibited differences between the two species. In lotus, PSII activity was drastically affected by combined stress and, interestingly, was correlated with D2 protein degradation. Possible implications of this event as an adaption mechanism in tolerant species are discussed. We conclude that the stress-tolerant capability of lotus is related to its ability to respond to oxidative damage and adaption of the photosynthetic machinery. This reveals that these two aspects should be included in the evaluation of the tolerance of species to stress conditions.
Manual Tags: Heat stress; Lotus corniculatus; perennial W/1 (oryza OR rice); Photoinhibition; Proline; PSII proteins; ScienceDirect; search.rice; SPV; Trifolium pratense; Water stress

Author: Yadav, R. P.; Prasad, Ram; Aggarwal, R. K.; Agnihotri, Y.; Samra, J. S.
Title: Aonla ( Emblica officinalis) based silvi-pastoral systems for soil and water conservation in degraded lands of Shivalik foothills.
Abstract Note: Two grass species, viz., Chrysopogon fulvus, Pennisetum purpureum (Hybrid napier, var.NB-21) and a pulse Cajanus cajan (perennial pigeon pea, var.ICP-8094) were planted in 1992 with aonla ( Emblica officinalis [ Phyllanthus emblica]), planted in 1991, to evolve a suitable silvopastoral system to conserve and rejuvenate the degraded lands and provide good economic returns in the Shivalik foothills in India. The study was conducted at the Research farm of the Central Soil and Water Conservation and Training Institute in Chandigarh, Haryana, India. Studies on soil loss, runoff and nutrient losses for a decade showed that Emblica officinalis+ Chrysopogon fulvus was the best silvopastoral system for soil conservation in the region and resulted in 65 and 81% reduction in runoff and soil loss, respectively. The corresponding values were 43 and 56, and 19 and 25% for aonla+hybrid napier and aonla+pigeon pea systems, respectively. Aonla+ Chrysopogon also proved to be the most effective system in reducing nutrient losses and led to 68, 66 and 68% reduction in nitrogen, phosphorus and potassium losses, respectively, over pure aonla plantation. These systems saved rain water, soil, N, P 2O 5 and K 2O in the range of 4.88 to 30.66 cm, 862-2818 kg ha -1, 3.8-11.0 kg ha -1, 0.005-0.024 kg ha -1 and 0.57-1.98 kg ha -1, respectively, over sole aonla plantation. Effectiveness of aonla+hybrid napier and aonla+pigeon pea in conserving the resources decreased in the post-bearing stage while that of aonla+ Chrysopogon showed reverse (increasing) trend. The combination of Emblica officinalis+ Chrysopogon fulvus proved to be the most effective silvopastoral system for reclamation of degraded land in the Shivalik foot hills.

Author: TUMANJAN, M. G.
Title: A perennial seed-cultivated rye in Armenia.
Abstract Note: A new form was found at an elevation of 1700-1800 m. which differed in several, chiefly cultivated, characters from the usual forms of Secale montanum. It may have arisen either through natural hybridization, but is more probably a remnant of the perennial rye cultivated in Armenia before the war. This form is described by the author as S. Daralagesi sp. n.-M.A.O.

Author: SOPRANIS Y PENASCO, F. S. de
Title: A perennial wheat appears to have been obtained in Russia.
Abstract Note: An account is given of a hybrid of Agropyron elongatum[Elymus elongatus] and wheat, produced by N. V. Cicin at Omsk, Siberia. The new form of wheat thus produced is said to persist for 5 years in the same field, to be resistant to drought and rust although as yet insufficiently resistant to frost, and to give extremely satisfactory yields. Information is quoted from N. E. Hansen, North Dakota Agric. Exp. Sta. (reference not given).-G.M.R.

Author: Aguiero, V. M.; Cabauatan, P. Q.; Hibino, H.
Title: A possible source of resistance to rice grassy stunt virus (GSV).
Abstract Note: Infection studies with the perennial rice Guang-Keng A/ Oryza rufipogon/ O. longistaminata (IRRI accession number 104315) using strains GSV1 and GSV2 and the vector Nilaparvata lugens revealed that no tillers became infected with GSV1 when 20 or 50 vectors/tiller were used and that 1 out of 4 tillers became infected when the vector number was increased to 130; with GSV2, 1 out of 21 tillers became infected with 50 vectors/tiller. Seedlings of the rice segregated into tall and dwarf types; only talls showed resistance. Since (1) vectors survived on tall plants and (2) it was difficult to recover the viruses from infected material, using aviruliferous vectors, it is concluded that the resistance shown by the tall type is not likely to be due to resistance to the vector.
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: Collina, M.
Title: A post-emergence herbicide.
Abstract Note: Information on a herbicide, already registered in 40 countries of the world, which is currently being registered in the EU for use on industrial crops and some vegetable crops, designated quizalofop-P-tefuryl, was presented at a meeting on Phytopathology held in Italy in 2004. The effect of quizalofop-P-tefuryl, characterized by a high systemic activity against annual and perennial Poaceae weeds is outlined. It is stated that the effect is increased at weather conditions favourable to weed development, i.e. medium-high temperature and good levels of soil humidity. A slight increase in the standard dose is recommended for conditions unfavourable to weed development, i.e. drought and low RH. Weeds sensitive to medium-low doses included Echinochloa crus-galli, Alopecurus myosuroides, Avena spp., Lolium spp. and Phalaris spp. Perennial Sorghum halepense, Cynodon dactylon and Agropyron, and annual weeds Digitaria sanguinalis, Setaria viridis, S. glauca [ S. pumila] and Poa spp. are sensitive to higher doses. Quizalofop-P-tefuryl shows high selectivity to a wide range of industrial and vegetable crops with wide leaves, non-Poaceae ornamentals, and forest tree seedlings and fruit trees. Optimal results obtained in field trials conducted during 2002-03 were obtained with 40-72 g/ha a.i.
Manual Tags: search.sorghum; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 sorghum); WOS

Title: Application of "3S" technology in climatic feasibility study of ratooning paddy growing in Jiangxi Province.
Abstract Note: Remote sensing, geographic information system and global positioning system were used to study the climatic feasibility of ratooning paddy in Jiangxi Province, China. This paper presents a synthetic climatic division of ratooning rice production and provides scientific bases for the extension and development of ratooning rice.

Author: Dijkstra, J.; Kebreab, E.; Bannink, A.; France, J.; López, S.
Title: Application of the gas production technique to feed evaluation systems for ruminants
Publication Title: The in vitro Gas Production Technique: Limitations and Opportunities
Abstract Note: A range of feed evaluation techniques is available to predict the nutritional value of ruminant feedstuffs. The aim of this paper was to critically evaluate use of gas production (GP) data as inputs to current feed evaluation systems, as well as to mechanistic rumen models. Topics discussed include prediction of rumen degradation of feed, efficiency of microbial synthesis, and the profile of volatile fatty acids (VFA) produced. Derivation of GP models to permit calculation of extent of degradation of organic matter (OM) has been of great value, as well as to reveal assumptions underlying models to analyse GP data. Gas production techniques (GPT) have good potential to predict rumen OM degradation, in particular through provision of kinetic information, but the potential to provide parameters of degradation of OM components seems limited. Optimal use of GP data to predict microbial efficiency and VFA formed is best achieved when the possibilities, and limitations, of batch culture GPT are recognised. The mechanisms governing microbial efficiency and VFA molar proportions in the GPT are not necessarily applicable to in vivo situations. A simple model based on classic microbial growth and substrate utilisation equations for batch cultures is used to illustrate the need to carefully interpret microbial efficiency in batch culture for use in in vivo situations. The profile of VFA in GPTs is only a reflection of the dynamic VFA profile in vivo. Of crucial importance for estimation of OM degradation, microbial efficiency and amount and type of VFA formed is knowledge of the fractional passage rate of ingesta from the rumen. The value of the GPT is greatly enhanced in combination with mechanistic modelling. However, the role of the technique is not in giving direct predictions of nutrient supply.
Manual Tags: Gas production; Mathematical modelling; Microbial efficiency; perennial W/1 (oryza OR rice); Rumen; ScienceDirect; search.rice; SPV; Substrate degradation

Author: ChangMin, Zheng
Title: A preliminary study of growth and development of ratooned rice and its yield components.
Abstract Note: The growth characteristics of ratooned rice in Fushun County, Sichuan, show that its development period is very short with rapid production of panicles after ratooning. In the ratoon crop in Fushun panicle production took as little as 25-30 days. Yield was related to the number of tillers produced, the grain number/panicle, the proportion of effective panicles and the 1000-grain weight. Yields were lower than from the main rice crop.

Author: Feng, R. Z.
Title: A preliminary study on the distribution, occurrence and fluctuation of rice root nematodes.
Abstract Note: Hirshmanniella spp. was distributed in all rice growing regions of Guangxi, China. Nematode numbers found in late season rice roots were higher than those in early season rice and the maximum number were found from tillering stage to booting stage. Nematodes overwinter in undecayed roots of rice stubble, ratooning rice roots, as well as in grass roots. There were more females than males or juveniles.

Author: Bell, Lindsay W.; Byrne (nee Flugge), Felicity; Ewing, Mike A.; Wade, Len J.
Title: A preliminary whole-farm economic analysis of perennial wheat in an Australian dryland farming system
Abstract Note: The development of perennial wheat could have a number of advantages for improving the sustainability of Australian dryland agricultural systems. The profitability that might be expected from perennial wheat of different types was investigated using MIDAS (Model of an Integrated Dryland Agricultural System), a bioeconomic model of a mixed crop/livestock farming system. Although perennial wheat may produce a lower grain yield and quality than annual wheat, it is expected inputs of fertiliser, herbicide and sowing costs will be lower. Perennial wheat used solely for grain production was not selected as part of an optimal farm plan under the standard assumptions. In contrast, dual-purpose perennial wheat that produces grain and additional forage during summer and autumn than annual wheat can increase farm profitability substantially (AU$20/ha over the whole farm) and 20% of farm area was selected on the optimal farm plan under standard assumptions. Forage from perennial wheat replaced stubble over summer and grain supplement at the break of season and increased farm stock numbers. The additional value added by grazing also reduced the relative yield required for perennial wheat to be profitable. This analysis suggests perennial wheat used for the dual purposes of grain and forage production could be developed as a profitable option for mixed crop/livestock producers.
Manual Tags: AGRICOLA; Benefit–cost; Benefit-cost; Dual-purpose; MIDAS; Perennial crop; perennial W/1 (triticum OR wheat); Profitability; ScienceDirect; Scopus; search.wheat; SPV; Sustainability; TITLE-ABS-KEY (perennial W/1 (triticum OR wheat)) AND DOCTYPE (ar); TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); TX (perennial N1 (triticum OR wheat)); WOS

Title: Arable forage.
Abstract Note: In a comparative fodder-production trial, Velvet sorghum was harvested in the first flush at the silage stage and during subsequent growth at the grazing stage. At the silage cut, yields of Velvet sorghum and maize were 71 and 67 cwt/ac, respectively, both of which were significantly higher than perennial Kavirondo sorghum and oats (49 and 48 cwt respectively), while yields of both of these were significantly higher than those of Columbus grass ( Sorghum almum) and Sudan grass [ Sorghum sudanense] at 31 and 26 cwt. The mean crude-protein content of the silage material, on a dry-matter basis, was: oats 15.5%, Sudan grass 15.3%, Columbus grass 14.5%, perennial Kavirondo sorghum 12.7%, Velvet sorghum 12.3% and maize 10.7%. The yield/ac of crude protein from Velvet sorghum (971 Ib) was significantly higher than that from other varieties. Oats and maize yielded 830 and 802 Ib crude protein/ac respectively. Sudan grass gave a low silage yield but a high green-matter yield for aftermath grazing. -S.M.J.
Manual Tags: search.sorghum; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 sorghum); WOS

Author: Medappa, C. K.; Mahadevappa, M.
Title: A ratoon crop of Intan paddy in Coorg is possible.
Abstract Note: In Coorg district, Karnataka, a ratoon crop of rice cv. Intan harvested on 30 Jan. gave paddy yields of 1.67 t/ha in 109 days.
