Author: Renne, Ian J.; Tracy, Benjamin F.
Title: Disturbance persistence in managed grasslands: shifts in aboveground community structure and the weed seed bank
Abstract Note: The length of time and form in which disturbances persist in systems depends on the intensity and frequency of disturbance and on the abilities of resident species to recover from such events. In grazed grasslands, trampling by large mammalian herbivores can periodically facilitate weed establishment by exposing patches of bare ground but whether an intense soil disturbance event results in a temporary increase in weed abundance or a persistent weed problem remains unclear. In May 2002, cattle trampling following heavy rain caused severe damage to nine-month old, rotationally grazed, cool-season pastures (Midwest USA). In September 2002, we compared the aboveground composition of paddocks (i.e., fenced pasture sections) that were heavily disturbed to those that received no damage. Relative to undisturbed paddocks, forage species relative cover was 17% lower in disturbed paddocks, and weed species and bare ground relative cover was 61% and 100% higher, respectively. By September 2004, paddock types did not differ in all aboveground community components. However, the abundance and species richness of weed seeds in the soil seed bank averaged respectively 82% and 30% higher in disturbed paddocks between 2003 and 2004. These findings indicate that a spatially extensive, intense soil disturbance event may soon become undetectable in components of aboveground pasture structure but can persist as an augmented weed seed bank. Because of high weed seed bank longevity, disturbances to formerly disturbed pastures would likely result in higher weed recruitment, with more species represented, than in those which lack previous disturbance. Disturbance history may thus be a useful predictor of weed community composition following subsequent disturbance. Based on empirical data supporting this proposition, we recommend that grassland managers explicitly incorporate disturbance history into dynamic management planning and do not rely exclusively on aboveground characters to evaluate the invasion status or colonization potential of an area by undesirable plants. We emphasize that the ecological legacies of past soil disturbance events cannot only influence the contemporary patterns and processes of grasslands, but importantly, affect their compositional trajectories following subsequent perturbation.
Manual Tags: search.rye; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 ("rye" OR secale) NOT "rye$grass"); WOS

Author: Vaughan, Duncan A; Morishima, H; Kadowaki, K
Title: Diversity in the Oryza genus
Abstract Note: The pan-tropical wild relatives of rice grow in a wide variety of habitats: forests, savanna, mountainsides, rivers and lakes. The completion of the sequencing of the rice nuclear and cytoplasmic genomes affords an opportunity to widen our understanding of the genomes of the genus Oryza. Research on the Oryza genus has begun to help to answer questions related to domestication, speciation, polyploidy and ecological adaptation that cannot be answered by studying rice alone. The wild relatives of rice have furnished genes for the hybrid rice revolution, and other genes from Oryza species with major impact on rice yields and sustainable rice production are likely to be found. Care is needed, however, when using wild relatives of rice in experiments and in interpreting the results of these experiments. Careful checking of species identity, maintenance of herbarium specimens and recording of genebank accession numbers of material used in experiments should be standard procedure when studying wild relatives of rice.
Manual Tags: perennial W/1 (oryza OR rice); ScienceDirect; search.rice; SPV

Author: Poppenborg, Patrick; Koellner, Thomas
Title: Do attitudes toward ecosystem services determine agricultural land use practices? An analysis of farmers' decision-making in a South Korean watershed
Abstract Note: Land use practices directly influence the provision of ecosystem services from agrarian landscapes, and are thus key factors for the development of environmental policy programs. This study analyzes farmers' decision-making processes with respect to land use in a South Korean watershed, based on the theory of planned behavior. Decisions between cultivation of rice, annual or perennial crops, and between organic and conventional farming were compared among farmers as a function of their attitudes toward the following ecosystem services: biomass production, prevention of soil erosion, improvement of water quality, and conservation of plants and animals. Results show that decisions to plant perennial crops are most often accompanied by positive attitudes toward ecosystem services, whereas no differences were found between organic and conventional farming. In addition, latent class analysis reveals that positive attitudes toward ecosystem services are most likely held by farmers with high income, showing that financial means are key determinants of farmers' environmental attitudes.
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: Barker, A.M.; Reynolds, C.J.M.
Title: Do host-plant interactions and susceptibility to soil cultivation determine the abundance of graminivorous sawflies on British farmland?
Publication Title: Journal of Agricultural and Urban Entomology
Abstract Note: Larvae of the sawfly genera Dolerus and Pachynematus feed on cereals and grasses in farmland habitats and can cause crop damage. In Britain they are not economic pests, but they have a role in the wider ecology of agricultural ecosystems as important sources of food for birds. They have a patchy distribution across the landscape and are particularly associated with areas of cereals undersown with grass. In a survey of British farmland, larvae of these two genera were significantly more abundant in fields of sown perennial rye-grass, Lolium perenne L., than in crops of winter wheat, Triticum aestivum L., and spring barley, Hordeum vulgare L. Host-plant relationships and the effect of soil cultivation on overwintering survival were considered as factors underlying this distribution. In oviposition trials, perennial rye-grass was the preferred host of most species tested, and winter wheat was avoided. Growth rates and survival of larvae in performance trials were significantly higher on rye-grass than on cereals. Soil cultivation during the overwintering period caused up to 50% additional winter mortality of pupae in some years. However, in other years there was no additional mortality, indicating that another factor must be involved following the soil disturbance, such as winter frosts. The observed differences in host-suitability could strongly influence larval distribution on farms, depressing abundance in cereal habitats. Post-cultivation mortality may reinforce this effect. Varying cultivation regimes and availability of undisturbed grassland could be used to manipulate the abundance of these sawflies on farms.
Manual Tags: Cereals; Cultivation; Dolerus; Grasses; Host-plant interactions; Hymenoptera; Pachynematus; Perennial rye-grass; Sawflies; Scopus; search.rye; SPV; Tenthredinidae; TITLE-ABS-KEY (perennial W/1 ("rye" OR secale) AND NOT ("rye?grass" OR ryegrass)) AND DOCTYPE (ar)

Author: Barker, A.M.; Brown, N.J.; Reynolds, C.J.M.
Title: Do host-plant requirements and mortality from soil cultivation determine the distribution of graminivorous sawflies on farmland?
Abstract Note: 1. There are many arthropod species on farmland that are not economic pests but which have an important role in the wider ecology of agricultural ecosystems. Few of these have been studied in detail. This study investigated the factors underlying the distribution of one such group, graminivorous sawflies (Hymenoptera: Tenthredinidae). 2. In a farm survey, sawfly larvae of the genera Dolerus and Pachynematus were over six times more abundant in fields of sown perennial rye-grass Lolium perenne L. than in fields of spring barley, winter wheat or long-established grazing pastures. 3. In rearing trials the growth rates and survival of larvae of the two genera were high on L. perenne and low on two cereals, spring barley and winter wheat. Differences were sufficiently marked to have had a strong influence on the distribution of larvae between crops in the field. 4. In an experimental study, nearly twice as many adults emerged from uncultivated as from cultivated ground, suggesting that disturbance of the overwintering prepupae and pupae in the soil caused about 50% extra mortality. This mortality will have reinforced the effects of host-plant requirements, suppressing sawfly numbers in annually cultivated cereal fields whilst numbers built up in less-frequently cultivated grass fields. 5. Sawfly abundance is known to have declined on farmland. Our results suggest that changes in patterns of crop rotation have been the main cause of this decline. Farming practice in Britain has moved away from mixed rotations alternating cereals with undersown grass fields. Modern intensive farms grow monocultures of cereal crops or of heavily grazed grass, both poor habitats for sawflies. 6. Increasing insecticide use in cereals has probably been only a minor influence on population abundance of sawflies as wheat and barley fields are not high-quality habitats. 7. Provision of undisturbed grassy habitats would promote the conservation of graminivorous sawflies on farmland.
Manual Tags: Cereals; Dolerus; Farming practices; Pachynematus; Sawfly distribution; Scopus; search.rye; SPV; TITLE-ABS-KEY (perennial W/1 ("rye" OR secale) AND NOT ("rye?grass" OR ryegrass)) AND DOCTYPE (ar)

Author: Munné-Bosch, Sergi
Title: Do perennials really senesce?
Abstract Note: Although senescence remains less studied in perennials than in monocarpic plants, major advances in understanding senescence in perennials have been achieved recently. This success is due not only to the use of genetic tools in woody plants but also to a renaissance of research on how perennials can live for centuries or even millennia. The particularities of perennial life are considered here, with an emphasis on how these affect senescence at different levels of organization. I conclude that although cellular and leaf senescence do share common features in monocarpic and perennial plants, the indeterminacy of meristems found in perennials begs the question of whether senescence really occurs in these organisms at the whole-plant level.
Manual Tags: perennial W/1 (oryza OR rice); ScienceDirect; search.rice; SPV

Author: LE ROUX, P. M.
Title: Downy mildew in Kaffircorn and Maize.
Abstract Note: Severe outbreaks of downy mildew ( Sclerospora sorghi[Peronosclerospora sorghi]) [33, 657] on kaffir corn [ Sorghum caffrorum] and maize in the Springbok Flats, Central Transvaal, are reported from Univ. Pretoria. All kaffir corn, maize, and sorghum plants with signs of infection should be removed, and severely infected plants burnt after harvesting, the rest of the plant remains being ploughed in deeply and thoroughly. Sweet Sudan and other perennial Sorghum spp., from which the disease may spread, should not be left on the laud in winter. Early planting is recommended to protect the crops from secondary infection. The maize strs. T35, Mex. 155-86, and Mex. 155-152 showed resistance, as did A17.
Manual Tags: search.sorghum; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 sorghum); WOS

Author: McCauley, G.N; Way, M.O
Title: Drain and harvest timing affects on rice grain drying and whole-milled grain
Abstract Note: The economic value of a rice (Oryza sativa) crop depends mainly on percent whole-milled grain (milling quality) production. Whole-milled grain depends on preharvest drying conditions, harvest grain moisture (GM), postharvest management, and mill management. Research was conducted at the Texas A&M University Agricultural Research and Extension Center near Beaumont, TX from 1989 to 1992 to evaluate the effect of drain and harvest timing on grain drying patterns of rice and whole-milled grain. The study was laid out in a split plot design with drain date as main plot and harvest date as subplots. ‘Lemont’ rice was drill-planted in (12–18.2) m×36.5 m plots on 0.2 m centers at 112 kg ha−1 and received uniform management from planting to 7 days after heading (DAH). Main plots were drained at 4-day intervals from 7 to 27 DAH (draining 24–27 DAH traditional). Subplots were harvested at 2-day intervals from 350 to 150 g kg−1 GM. Drain date did not significantly affect yield or whole-milled grain. Field drying patterns for rice were influenced by year and harvest sequence. There was no apparent relationship between key weather conditions and drying pattern. Drain time influenced drying patterns mainly for drains at 7 and 11 DAH. Drying patterns for drains of 15 and 19 DAH were similar to the more traditional 23 and 27 DAH (7–12 days before harvest) drains. GM converged for all drain dates at lower GM levels. GM declined about 22 g kg−1 per day above 230 g kg−1, but declined only about 0.6 g kg−1 per day from 23 to 15 g kg−1. Draining at 7 DAH reduced whole-milled grain at least 5%. Whole-milled grain fluctuated among years but the impact of key climatic conditions was complex. Late rainfall, after 123 days after planting (DAP), appeared to influence the maximum whole-milled grain. The influence of rainfall prior to 123 DAP was not apparent. Averaged over years, whole-milled grain increased until 133 DAP. Under the conditions of this study, whole-milled grain was similar between 170 and 200 g kg−1 GM. Rice should be harvested from 127 to 130 DAP (210–170 g kg−1 GM) to optimize whole-milled grain. These factors may have a more dramatic impact on small plot studies where treatments resulted in large GM differences than in field conditions.
Manual Tags: Drain time; Grain moisture; Oryza sativa; ratoon* W/5 (oryza OR rice); Rice; ScienceDirect; search.rice; SPV; Whole-milled grain

Author: Pandey, Dev Mani; Wu, Rong Zhe; Hahn, Eun-Joo; Paek, Kee-Yoeup
Title: Drought effect on electrophoretic protein pattern of Anoectochilus formosanus
Abstract Note: Drought effect on two dimensional iso-electric focusing/sodium dodecyl sulfate-poly acrylamide gel electrophoretic (2-D IEF/SDS-PAGE) protein pattern was studied in Anoectochilus formosanus leaves under ex vitro condition. Spectrophotometery analysis revealed that under drought condition protein content decreased significantly. Similarly, 2-D IEF/SDS-PAGE and PDQuest software analysis indicated that out of 17 protein spots, expression of 15 protein spots were quantitatively down-regulated and 2 spots were up-regulated. Moreover, 11 protein spots were qualitatively up-regulated while 6 were down-regulated.
Manual Tags: 2-D IEF/SDS-PAGE; Anoectochilus formosanus; Drought; perennial W/1 (oryza OR rice); ScienceDirect; search.rice; SPV

Author: KREYGER, J.
Title: Drying and storage of seed.
Abstract Note: The following work in connexion with the drying and conservation of seed is described: (a) determination of the equilibrium moisture-contents of seeds corresponding with relative humidities of the atmosphere varying from 10 to 95%, (b) determination of loss of viability in seeds of varying moisture-content hermetically stored for 6 months at various temperatures, (c) measurement of the effect of temperature used in the drying process on the viability of seed, (d) determination of moisture-content of seeds after exposure to slow air-drying with air of a given relative humidity. The seeds used were rape, sugar-beet, perennial ryegrass, rye, maize, oats, wheat, peas, beans [ Vicia faba], and lupins. The results of (a) are tabulated. The equilibrium moisture-contents of seeds of the crops mentioned, at temperatures of 12-25degrees C. (20degrees C. for wheat), corresponding to a relative humidity of 70%, were 8, 13.3, 14.3, 15.1, 14.6, 14.0, 14.8, I5.0, 14.8 and 13.4%. respectively. Before storage, seeds should be dried to a point where their moisture content is in equilibrium with an atmospheric R.H. of 70-75% (R.H. greater than 70-75% encourages mould and bacterial development). In experiment (b) lupin, rape, bean and pea seeds with moisture-contents in equilibrium with R.H. of 63-75% were stored for 6 months at 2, 12, 18 and 25degrees C. without loss of germinative capacity; at 25degrees the germinative capacity of these seeds was slightly reduced. Oat seeds were also unaffected at the 3 lower-temperatures, but at 25degrees C. lost germinative capacity to a greater extent than the seeds of the 4 crops already mentioned. In the case of maize, perennial ryegrass, sugar-beet and rye, deterioration of germinative capacity was observed in seeds having moisture-contents in equilibrium with R.H. 65-75% stored at 18degrees C. Seeds of the last 4 crops named, with moisture-contents in equilibrium with R.H. 75-80%, showed deterioration of germinative capacity when stored at 12degrees C. Maize, ryegrass and sugar-beet seed with moisture-contents in equilibrium with R.H. 80-90% showed reduced germinative capacities when stored at 2degrees C. Thus too high a storage temperature and too high a moisture content in seeds both affected adversely the viability of hermetically stored seed. In experiment (c) seeds with moisture contents in equilibrium with R.H. 50, 70 and 90 were dried at 30, 40, 50, 60 and 70degrees C. for periods (adjusted to temperature and seed moisture-content) of 1-4 hr. Seed heated to 30degrees C. for 4 hr. (3 hr. in the case of the abnormally damp seed) did not lose germinative capacity. At 40degrees C. beans showed a slight loss of germinative capacity at all moisture-contents but no other seeds were affected. At 50degrees C. (heat applied for 2 hr.) only lupins, rape and peas showed no loss of germinative capacity. At 60 and 70degrees C. all seeds tested showed some loss of viability. The results are tabulated. In experiment (d) seeds were exposed to slow drying with air of varying R.H. until a constant moisture-content in the seed was obtained. The moisture-contents obtained were in accordance with the data obtained in (a). Thus, provided that the R.H. of the air used and the corresponding equilibrium moisture-content of the seed are known, the minimum moisture-content in seed attainable by the slow-drying process can be calculated.
Manual Tags: search.rye; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 ("rye" OR secale) NOT "rye$grass"); WOS

Author: HongFei, Chen; RuiYu, Lin; YiYuan, Liang; LuDuan, Zheng; KangJing, Liang; WenXiong, Lin
Title: Dry-matter accumulation and transportation in first-rice crop of early rice-ratoon rice under different cultivation patterns.
Publication Title: Zhongguo Shengtai Nongye Xuebao / Chinese Journal of Eco-Agriculture
Abstract Note: The effect of different cultivation patterns (Super High-yield Cultivation Pattern, SHCP; and Tradition Cultivation Pattern, TCP) on chlorophyll content, Leaf Area Index (LAI), dry matter accumulation and transportation and yield component of the first-rice crop of ratoon rice were studied. Results indicate that chlorophyll content and LAI of the first-rice crop under super high-yield cultivation pattern are higher than those under the tradition pattern from tillering to ripening stage, especially during the middle and latter periods, by 10.77% and 63.29%, respectively. Compared with the tradition cultivation pattern, accumulation of population dry-matter under super high-yield cultivation is 24.83%-38.17% higher; transportation of stem-sheet matter is 10.60% and transformation of stem-sheet matter is 13.88% higher; productive tillers per hectare increase by 21.43%; and yields increase by 24.22%.
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: SKRIPCHINSKY, A. V.
Title: Duration of the life and function of the roots in various forms of perennial rye and wheat grass ; Referat. Zhur., Biol., 1956, No. 13630. (Translation.)
Abstract Note: Experiments in culture vessels with cultivated and wild perennial rye and with broad-leaved wheat grass showed that roots of reproductive shoots do not die off after these shoots have fruited and dried but function until the start of winter providing for the formation and subsequent growth of the sprouting shoots. The sprouting shoots may live owing to the previously formed roots, the active parts of which at the time of shoot formation in the middle of the summer are at a considerable depth; and, therefore, drying of the upper soil layers does not cause death of the newly formed shoots which are incapable of developing roots until the autumn rains. This character, acquired by natural selection, is the cause of perennial nature of the cereals which form new organs of vegetative reproduction during the dry summer period on old reproductive stalks, and it is especially important for cereals of the steppe, semidesert, and desert zones. Consequently, in cultivation of perennial cereals in arid conditions moisture must be conserved in the deep layers of the soil even if it cannot be preserved in the upper layers.
Manual Tags: search.rye; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 ("rye" OR secale) NOT "rye$grass"); WOS

Author: BYALYI, A. M.
Title: Durum wheat on the east bank of the Volga [English, German and French summ.]
Abstract Note: Data on the cultivation of durum wheat after different precursors are presented. The best precursors were a bed of perennial grasses, winter crops after autumn fallow, and maize. The principal devices for increasing the yielding capacity of durum wheat are increasing the seeding norm (180-220 kg ha), vernalization, early sowing after early fall ploughing, introduction of mineral fertilizers, especially N fertilizers (Naa 1-1.5 metric cntr ha), under presowing treatment, and a divided harvest at a grain moisture of 30-36% (beginning of wax ripeness). Of the new varieties of durum wheat, those recommended for the Saratov and Stalingrad areas are Gordenforme 5695 and Melyanopus 26, distinguished by their good yielding capacity in high-humus chernozem and their resistance to brown leaf rust and common bunt; for the Ul'yanovsk and Penza areas, Leukurm 33 and Narodnaya (Gordeiforme 9923) are recommended.
Manual Tags: search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); WOS

Author: DEWEY, WADE G.; TYLER, L. J.
Title: Dwarf bunt on ryegrass in New York
Abstract Note: Dwarf bund (Tilletia brevifaciens) was observed in 1955 on perennial ryegrass (Lolium perenne) and Italian ryegrass (L. multiflorum). This appears to be the 1st published record of the dwarf bunt fungus on Lolium spp. The diseased ryegrass plants were growing among winter wheat in an exptl. nursery. || ABSTRACT AUTHORS: G. K. Parris
Manual Tags: search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); WOS

Author: Dong, Chen Fei; Liu, Xin Bao; Qu, Hui; Shen, Yi Xin
Title: Dynamical partition of photosynthates in tillers of rice (Oryza sativa L.) during late growth period and its correlation with feeding value of rice straw at harvest
Abstract Note: This study was to investigate the dynamical partition of photosynthates in panicle-removed tillers of rice (Oryza sativa L.) during late growth period and its correlation with the feeding value of rice straw at harvest. Four rice cultivars (Liangyou 108, Huaidao 6, Nanjing 43, Nanjing 44) were cultivated in Nanjing under the same management of Jiangsu area, and were sampled from weeks 1 to 5 after anthesis and at harvest in 2008, 2009 and 2010. Then, the content of nonstructural carbohydrates (NSC), hemicellulose, and acid detergent fiber (exclusive of residual ash, ADFom) in tillers were determined. The crude protein (CP) content in tillers at harvest was assayed in 2009 and 2010. Freehand sections of the fourth internode of main culm were made to visualize the starch particles in parenchyma cells in week 1, 3 and 5 after anthesis in 2010. The results showed that the content of NSC decreased sharply from week 1 to 3 and then increased to week 5 after anthesis; hemicellulose in week 5 remained at an approximate level with that of week 1; ADFom increased slightly from week 1 to 3, and then stayed constant till week 5 after anthesis. The starch particles in parenchyma cells of stems decreased from week 1 to 3 and increased slightly till week 5 after anthesis again. The rebounding rate of NSC (NSCRR) was positively correlated with the content of NSC and CP at harvest while negatively correlated with the content of hemicellulose and ADFom at harvest.
Manual Tags: Acid detergent fiber; Correlation; Crude protein; Freehand section; Hemicellulose; Nonstructural carbohydrates; ratoon* W/5 (oryza OR rice); Rebounding rate; Rice straw; ScienceDirect; search.rice; SPV

Author: I, BELKOVSKII V.; P, RESHETNIK A.
Title: DYNAMICS OF CARBON DI OXIDE LIBERATION FROM PEATY SOIL UNDER VARIOUS CROPS
Abstract Note: The seasonal dynamics of CO2 emanation from the peaty soil in relation to soil temperature, humidity and cultivated crops [perennial grasses, winter rye and potatoes] is discussed. The lowest biological activity of peaty soil was observed in April, the highest in July. CO2 emanation from the soil surface under black fallow was low; under perennial grasses and cereal crops it was 1.9 times higher.

Author: Ovezov, M. A.
Title: Dynamics of hydrophysical properties of aeolian sands of the central Karakum.
Abstract Note: Soil physical properties of aeolian sands in the Turkmen SSR as affected by cultivation of irrigated silage maize, lucerne and perennial sorghum were studied. In 26-28 irrigation cycles the application rate varied from 250 to 300 m/ha totalling 6100-9000 m/ha. Cultivation did not affect particle density, which averaged 2.66-2.68 g/cm, but the bulk density of the top soil (0-30 cm) decreased from 1.51 to 1.46 g/cm under lucerne. Root biomass and plant residues increased soil organic matter and consequently increased soil porosity from 43.2 to 45.5%, 42.7 to 44% and 43.5 to 44% for lucerne, maize and sorghum, resp. Water holding capacity also increased with cultivation.
Manual Tags: search.sorghum; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 sorghum); WOS

Author: A, OVEZOV M.
Title: DYNAMICS OF WATER AND PHYSICAL PROPERTIES OF EOLIAN SANDS IN THE CENTRAL KARA KUM UNDER THE INFLUENCE OF PLANT PRODUCTION TURKMEN SSR USSR
Abstract Note: Water and physical parameters of eolian sands in Central Karakum (specific gravity, volume weight, porousness, maximum hygroscopity, moisture of fading, the least water-capacity, full water-capacity) were identified. Influence of different forage crops (lucerne, maize, sorghum perennial) on dynamics of water and physical properties of eolian sands in Central Karakum was studied.

Title: Earing and maturation of some spring-sown and autumn-sown forms of perennial and grain-fodder wheats.
Abstract Note: Winter hardiness of the seven wheat-Agropyron hybrids varied with variety and autumnal sowing date. Four hybrids eared when sown in the spring.

Author: FEDOROV, A. K.
Title: Earing of winter plants under conditions of relatively high temperature
Abstract Note: Translated from Fiziol. Rastenii 7(6): 686-694. 1960. One of the differences of summer plants, alternatives, and winter plants is the different reaction to light conditions. After the continued action of decreased temperatures there takes place a change in the reaction to light conditions, and differences in the reaction of plants differing in type of development to a significant degree are smoothed out (for example, by sowing vernalized seeds). This makes it possible to approach an explanation of a number of insufficiently clear facts in biological literature connected with the nature of winter plants, alternatives, perennial grasses, with the propagation of fairly long day plants in Abyssinia where the natural length of the day does not exceed 12 hours,

Author: Chandrasekhar, A.; Sudheer, M. J.; Reddy, P. R.; Reddy, A. G. V. R.
Title: Early arhar varieties are best for intercropping with groundnut.
Abstract Note: In a field trial in the monsoon season of 1985-86 in Andhra Pradesh, 5 short and 2 long duration Cajanus cajan cultivars were compared. The short duration cultivars ICPL-151 (842 kg/ha), ICPL-186 (622 kg/ha) and ICPL-161 (566 kg/ha) yielded well in comparison with the long duration cultivars PDM-1 (583 kg/ha) and LRG-30 (208 kg/ha). In another trial in the monsoon season of 1986-87, cv. ICPL-161 and ICPL-151 performed better than PDM-1 when intercropped with groundnuts. Groundnut yields were also greater when intercropped with ICPL-161 and ICPL-151 than with PDM-1.
Manual Tags: search.grain; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 grain); WOS

Author: H, XIONG; W, FANG
Title: ECOLOGICAL CONDITIONS FOR AXILLARY BUD SPROUTING OF RATOONING RICE

Author: Y, WATANABE
Title: ECOLOGICAL STUDIES ON KRESEK PHASE OF BACTERIAL LEAF BLIGHT OF RICE
Publication Title: Bulletin of the Tokai Kinki National Agricultural Experiment Station
Abstract Note: Ecological studies on bacterial leaf blight of rice caused by Xanthomonas oryzae were conducted in Sri Lanka [Ceylon] with special reference to the Kresek phase of the disease. The primary infection source for Kresek occurrence was suggested as the neighboring fields. The minimum concentration of bacterium for causing Kresek symptoms was estimated at 102 cells/ml for both inoculation methods of root dipping and whole plant immersion. The infection stage of rice plant for the Kresek development was limited to the nursery stage under field conditions. Histological investigations revealed that the causal bacterium invaded the leaf blade through wounds or hydathodes and spread over the plant body through the vascular system until resulting Kresek occurrence. All the bacterial isolates collected from various localities of Sri Lanka were capable of causing Kresek. A wide range in the grade of pathogenicity existed among them. Several chemicals developed in Japan were effective for control of the Kresek phase. Recommended control measures are to select resistant varieties, to avoid excess application of nitrogenous fertilizers, to select the position of nursery bed so as to irrigate with water non-infested with the causal bacterium, to separate the irrigation system from the drainage system, to remove diseased stubble before preparing a nursery bed, to prevent the nursery bed from being submerged under irrigation water and to adopt direct sowing instead of transplanting, if possible.
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: LEPINIS, A. K.
Title: Ecology of Protozoa in eroding soil of north-eastern Lithuania From: REF
Publication Title: Tr Akad Nauk Lit Ssr B
Abstract Note: The number of protozoa and their species distribution depends on the erosion, humidity and temperature of the soil, and also on the crop under cultivation. Three groups of soil protozoa occur in eroding, soddy-podzolic, gravelly loam soils: flagellates, amoeba and Infusoria. Flagellates are the most abundant in 1 g of soil, with amoeba second. The greatest amount of flagellates were observed in spring in soil prepared for a barley crop than on plots under rye with an admixture of perennial grasses. By autumn the number of Infusoria increased. All 3 protozoan groups occur in the least numbers in summer. Considerable porosity and the presence in the soil of a large amount of nitrates bring about a greater abundance of protozoa.
Manual Tags: search.rye; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 ("rye" OR secale) NOT "rye$grass"); WOS

Author: Noy-Meir, I.
Title: Ecology of wild emmer wheat in Mediterranean grasslands in Galilee
Abstract Note: Aaronsohn in 1909 noted that Triticum dicoccoides was found mainly in rocky habitats. Recent research in Mediterranean grasslands in Galilee supports the hypothesis that rocks served as refuges from intensive grazing. Although proximity of rocks enhances early germination of Triticum, cattle grazing intensity is the major factor determining its abundance. At high grazing intensity, it is absent or survives only among rocks. At moderate grazing intensity it is common not only near rocks. In ungrazed sites it sometimes becomes dominant, but in the long term is often suppressed by perennial grasses. Fitness of Triticum plants in intensively grazed populations was only half that of plants in ungrazed populations, mainly because of damage to maturing ears. After grass fires, Triticum cover increased in ungrazed grasslands, as the cover of perennials was reduced. In ungrazed or lightly grazed grasslands, severe reductions of Triticum populations were observed during population eruptions of the Levant vole, followed by slow recovery. The dynamics of T. dicoccoides in grasslands of Galilee results from an interaction of rock microrelief, seasonal rainfall pattern, livestock grazing regime, perennial grass cover, fires, and vole eruptions. The least risky management strategy recommended for in situ conservation of Triticum populations is cattle grazing at moderate intensity, avoiding intensive grazing in the reproductive stage but also avoiding long periods without any grazing. The sensitivity of wild emmer to grazing has implications for the history of domestication and the beginnings of agriculture.
Manual Tags: search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); WOS

Author: OKA, HI
Title: ECOLOGY OF WILD-RICE PLANTED IN TAIWAN .3. DIFFERENCES IN REGENERATING STRATEGIES AMONG GENETIC STOCKS
Abstract Note: Variation in the mode of regeneration in a perennial (W120), an annual (W630), and an intermediate perennial-annual type (W593) of common wild rice was tested in lowland fields in semi-natural conditions. The perennial type continued vegetative growth vigorously and increased its population size in a few years. This type also produced a few seedlings. In contrast, the annual type was unsuccessful. Seeds were dispersed and buried in soil, but they did not germinate in the next season. Furthermore, the mother plants died out. Seed germination of this type was sensitive to soil substrates and seemed to be suppressed, at least partly, by an allelopathic effect of field weeds. The intermediate type after maturity covered the field with a thick layer of litter preventing weed growth. In the next season, the seeds germinated to form a new population which included a few mother plants that remained alive vegetatively. Thus, the three genotypes showed markedly different regenerating strategies. Soil-buried seeds of all types survived for years in spite of high moisture content and high temperatures.
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: Thri Murty, V. S.; Devadath, S.; Rao, C. S.
Title: Ecology of Xanthomonas campestris pv. oryzae, the incitant of bacterial blight of rice.
Abstract Note: The pathogen survived on diseased stubble and leaves on the soil surface for 190 and 130 days, and buried in the soil for 110 and 60 days, respectively. Flooding of infected material reduced survival. In double cropped areas infected stubble was a source of inoculum for the new crop. Typical symptoms were observed on perennial wild rice (Oryza perennis) in Dec.-Aug. Although the leaves died during summer, blight symptoms appeared on new leaves long before the onset of the disease on newly transplanted rice seedlings in adjacent fields.
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: Santhi, P.; Ponnuswamy, K.; Shanmugasundaram, V. S.
Title: Economic evaluation of ratoon paddy in low lying old ayacut areas of Tamil Nadu.
Abstract Note: Field trials were conducted in Tamil Nadu in 1991-92 to assess the effects of treating rice cv. IR 20, Bhavani and ADT 38 sown in Sep. 1991 with 150-225 kg N/ha applied 50% basally, 25% at tillering and 25% at panicle initiation, with or without Azospirillum applied basally; the crop was harvested in Jan. and the ratoon crop in Apr. 1992. IR 20 gave the highest ratoon grain yield of 846.7 kg/ha, while ADT 38 gave the highest straw yield (858 kg/ha). Of N treatments, highest ratoon grain yields were recorded for 225 kg N and 150 kg N + Azospirillum (1016.7 and 869.4 kg, respectively). The highest net income for the ratoon crop was achieved by IR 20 at Rs. 2346.20/ha, followed by ADT 38 and Bhavani with Rs. 1888.80 and Rs. 1883.30, respectively.
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: Alvarez, J.; Snyder, G.H.; Anderson, D.L.; Jones, D.B.
Title: Economics of calcium silicate slag application in a rice-sugarcane rotation in the Everglades
Abstract Note: Rice and sugarcane are grown in rotation on organic soils in some areas of the Everglades. Both crops have shown positive agronomic responses to pre-plant applications of calcium silicate slag. The magnitude of the response, however, depends on the time at which the material is applied. Data from previous experiments were used to perform an economic analysis. Two timing applications of slag in the three production systems were analyzed: before rice, before cane, and before rice-cane rotation. Results indicate that, under the costs and prices assumed, it is more profitable to apply the slag prior to the rice planting when this crop is grown in rotation with sugarcane. The variables in the profit maximizing equations were translated into general terms to provide agronomists with the means for performing economic analyses of fertilizer responses in production systems involving a rotation. The resulting equations apply to cases where the application is done before the first crop to take advantage of residual effects and for which quadratic response functions are known.
Manual Tags: ratoon* W/5 (oryza OR rice); ScienceDirect; search.rice; SPV

Author: Mohan, R.; Balasubramaniam, N.; Aruna, L.; Narayanan, A.
Title: Economic viability of ratooning rice.
Abstract Note: A study was conducted during 1993/94, in Coimbatore, Tamil Nadu, India, to assess the effect of ratooning on the yield, yield parameters and income of medium-duration cultivars, i.e. IR 20, Co 43, ADT 38 and PONNI, under the lock-lodge (by braiding the stubbles) and conventional methods of ratooning. Although there were no significant differences in the regeneration of stubbles between these methods, lock-lodging was found to be superior over the conventional method in favourably influencing all yield parameters, i.e. filled grains per panicle, green grains per panicle and test weight, except number of productive tillers per hill. All cultivars produced significantly higher grain yield under lock-lodge (2443-3106 kg/ha), compared with the conventional method of ratooning (1285-1704 kg/ha). Consequently, the lock-lodge method recorded significantly higher net income (Rs. 7489/ha) than the conventional method (Rs. 1934/ha). The lock-lodge method also recorded significantly higher benefit:cost ratio (2.39) compared with conventional ratooning (1.40) and the main crop (1.93).
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: Germaine, K.J.; Byrne, J.; Liu, X.; Keohane, J.; Culhane, J.; Lally, R.D.; Kiwanuka, S.; Ryan, D.; Dowling, D.N.
Title: Ecopiling: A combined phytoremediation and passive biopiling system for remediating hydrocarbon impacted soils at field scale
Abstract Note: Biopiling is an ex situ bioremediation technology that has been extensively used for remediating a wide range of petrochemical contaminants in soils. Biopiling involves the assembling of contaminated soils into piles and stimulating the biodegrading activity of microbial populations by creating near optimum growth conditions. Phytoremediation is another very successful bioremediation technique and involves the use of plants and their associated microbiomes to degrade, sequester or bio-accumulate pollutants from contaminated soil and water. The objective of this study was to investigate the effectiveness of a combined phytoremediation/biopiling system, termed Ecopiling, to remediate hydrocarbon impacted industrial soil.The large scale project was carried out on a sandy loam, petroleum impacted soil [1613 mg total petroleum hydrocarbons (TPHs) kg-1soil]. The contaminated soil was amended with chemical fertilizers, inoculated with TPH degrading bacterial consortia and then used to construct passive biopiles. Finally, a phytocap of perennial rye grass (Lolium perenne) and white clover (Trifolium repens) was sown on the soil surface to complete the Ecopile. Monitoring of important physico-chemical parameters was carried out at regular intervals throughout the trial. Two years after construction the TPH levels in the petroleum impacted Ecopiles were below detectable limits in all but one subsample (152 mgTPH kg-1soil).The Ecopile system is a multi-factorial bioremediation process involving bio-stimulation, bio-augmentation and phytoremediation. One of the key advantages to this system is the reduced costs of the remediation process, as once constructed, there is little additional cost in terms of labor and maintenance (although the longer process time may incur additional monitoring costs). The other major advantage is that many ecological functions are rapidly restored to the site and the process is esthetically pleasing.
Manual Tags: Biopiling; Bioremediation; Field trials; Phytoremediation; Scopus; search.rye; SPV; TITLE-ABS-KEY (perennial W/1 ("rye" OR secale) AND NOT ("rye?grass" OR ryegrass)) AND DOCTYPE (ar); TPH

Author: KUZNETSOV, P. I.
Title: Effectiveness of a new system of cultivation of the soil in crop rotation on a Trans-Ural collective farm Referat. Zhur., Biol., 1961, No. 5G284. (Translation).
Abstract Note: On chernozems of the Shadrinskii Raion of the Kurgan Oblast the use of subsurface tillage of fallow soil to a depth of 35-40 cm produced an increase in the harvest of spring wheat averaging 7 cntr,/ha in comparison with the usual plowing to a depth of 20-22 cm. Under a 2d crop after fallow the soil was shallow-plowed to a depth of 10-12 cm. This method, in comparison with the usual fall plowing guaranteed an increase in the grain harvest of 1-4.5 cntr, and in the hay harvest of perennial grasses of 1.1-7.1 metric cntr/ha.
Manual Tags: search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); WOS

Author: Nebol'sin, A. N.; Egorova, L. I.
Title: Effectiveness of different rates of lime in a fibre flax rotation on heavy soils.
Abstract Note: In crop rotation trials with fallow/wheat + perennial herbage species/perennial herbage species for hay for 2 years/fibre flax on derno-podzolic acid soil in Novgorod region N.W. Russia, application of lime to the full neutralizing value before sowing wheat increased yields of all crops in the rotation.
Manual Tags: search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); WOS

Author: SHILENKO, B.
Title: Effectiveness of fertilization systems in crop rotation
Abstract Note: The paper is based on the results of tests, carried out during several years on the test field in Ufimsk and also on the registration of production experiences of collective and state farms. The Bashkhirian State Institute of Rural Economy recommends for collective and state farms with transitional forest-steppes a model fertilization system with an 11-fold crop rotation, which has provided a high standard of nourishment in the crop rotation: bare fallow, grain, perennial grasses. It also provides an application of bacterial fertilizers: nitrogen-bacteria under winter rye and phosphorus-bacteria under spring wheat. Under these conditions, 25 tons of manure and 5.7 centners of mineral fertilizers have been used/ha. || ABSTRACT AUTHORS: Transl. from Referat. Zhur. Biol. 91429, 1958, courtesy OTS-JPRS

Title: EFFECTIVENESS OF POTASSIUM FERTILIZERS IN LONG-TERM FIELD EXPERIMENTS ON SODDY-PODZOLIC SOILS
Publication Title: Doklady Vsesoyuznoi Ordena Lenina i Ordena Trudovogo Krasnogo Znameni   Akademii Sel'skokhozyaistvennykh Nauk Imeni V I Lenina

Author: Mineikiene, V.
Title: Effectiveness of rates of liming on yield of agricultural crops in a rotation on weakly acid light loam soil.
Abstract Note: The effects of liming at 0.25, 0.5, 1.0 or 2.0 times soil hydrolytic acidity on FU yields of 3 cycles of a 7-year rotation including winter wheat, perennial grasses, fodder beet, barley and vetch/oats fodder mixture were studied in 1967-87 on a light loam soil of pH 5.5. Liming did not significantly increase yields; this was attributed to the weak acidity of the soil, its relatively low Al content and its base saturation, with carbonaceous deposits at 45 cm depth.
Manual Tags: search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); WOS

Author: BOGDANOVA, V. B.; IOSELEV, L. G.
Title: Effect of agricultural improvement of dernovo-podzolic loamy soil on the yield and quality of some rotation crops.
Abstract Note: Trials during 1957-67 were carried out to determine the residual effects of lime, f.y.m. and fertilizers on yield of the following sequence of crops: wheat (1958)/perennial grasses (2 years)/maize 4 years/vetch and oats mixture/winter wheat/[red] clover grown on dernovopodzolic soil. Lime at 0-40 tons/ha was applied in the beginning of the sequence. F.y.m. at 0-40 tons/ha was applied initially and also to the maize on some plots in its 1st and 3rd years. N, P 2O 5 and K 2O at 270, 180 and 270 kg/ha, respectively, were applied annually until 1964 to each crop on plots given lime and/or f.y.m. and at 330, 240 and 330 kg to each crop given no lime and/or no f.y.m. On the previously treated plots, grain yields of winter wheat in 1966 were 29.4-32.3 hkg/ha, compared with 23.6 hkg/ ha for untreated controls; lime + f.y.m. (applied 3 times) + NPK gave the highest increases. All treatments markedly increased grain protein and gluten content.-M.S.M.
Manual Tags: search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); WOS

Author: Dan, Jianguo; Krüger, Martin; Frenzel, Peter; Conrad, Ralf
Title: Effect of a late season urea fertilization on methane emission from a rice field in Italy
Abstract Note: The application of NH4+-based fertilizers is a common practice in rice production. The immediate effect of a late season urea application on the processes involved in CH4 emission from a rice field was investigated on sandy loam located in the valley of River Po at Vercelli, northern Italy, and planted with rice (Oryza sativa, type japonica, variety Koral). Urea, applied at a rate of 50 kg N ha−1 on the 75th day after flooding, significantly stimulated both CH4 production and CH4 oxidation. During the following 9 days, the rates of CH4 production and CH4 oxidation in the 0–3 cm soil layer increased by 24–52 and 18–41%, respectively, of the fertilized plot compared to the unfertilized control plot. Methane oxidation on roots was also stimulated by urea, indicated by shorter lag times. Porewater concentrations of CH4 in the 0–6 cm soil layer increased with time and soil depth, but were not affected by fertilization with urea. Urea application also exhibited little impact on CH4 emission. During the 7 days following fertilization, urea only slightly reduced the CH4 flux. Ammonium originating from urea hydrolysis was completely depleted from the porewater within 3 days, mainly due to plant uptake. Fertilizer application did also not affect the contribution of CH4 oxidation to the net flux of CH4, determined by measuring δ13CH4 and by inhibition of CH4 oxidation. The absence of any effect of urea on net CH4 emission in this study was presumably caused by the rapid depletion of urea, the counterbalance between the increase of CH4 production and the increase of CH4 oxidation after fertilization, and methanogenesis in deeper soil layers.
Manual Tags: Ammonium; CH4 oxidation; CH4 production; Methane; Northern Italy; Paddy field; ratoon* W/5 (oryza OR rice); Rice; ScienceDirect; search.rice; SPV

Author: Guinee, T.P.; Mulholland, E.O.; Mullins, C.; Corcoran, M.O.; Connolly, J.F.; Beresford, T.; Mehra, R.; O'Brien, B.J.; Murphy, J.J.; Stakelum, G.; Harrington, D.
Title: Effect of altering the daily herbage allowance to cows in mid lactation on the composition, ripening and functionality of low-moisture, part-skim Mozzarella cheese
Abstract Note: Milk was collected from three spring-calving herds, on different daily herbage allowances (DHA) of perennial rye-grass (16, 20 or 24 kg dry matter (DM)/cow for a 17 week period. On five occasions, at weekly intervals in the middle of the period, the three different milks were converted into low-moisture part-skim Mozzarella cheese. Increasing the DHA resulted in significant increases in the concentrations of protein in the cheesemilk (P < 0.05) and cheese whey (P < 0.02). The moisture-adjusted cheese yield increased significantly (P < 0.01) on raising the DHA from 16 to 24 kg grass DM/cow. DHA had no significant effects on any of the gross compositional values of the cheese (although moisture and fat-in-DM levels tended to decrease and increase respectively with increasing DHA). The hardness of the uncooked cheese and functionality of cooked cheese (i.e. melt time, flowability, stretch and viscosity) were not significantly influenced by DHA over the 115 d ripening period at 4 °C.
Manual Tags: AGRICOLA; Scopus; search.rye; SPV; TITLE-ABS-KEY (perennial W/1 ("rye" OR secale) AND NOT ("rye?grass" OR ryegrass)) AND DOCTYPE (ar); TX (perennial N1 ("rye" OR secale) NOT "rye#grass")
Automatic Tags: casein; cheese milk; chemical composition; dairy cows; feeding level; flow; forage; hardness; lactose; melting; milk protein percentage; moisture content; mozzarella cheese; nitrogen content; rheological properties; viscosity; yields

Author: Padmavathiamma, P.K.; Li, L.Y.
Title: Effect of amendments on phytoavailability and fractionation of copper and zinc in a contaminated soil
Abstract Note: The ability of amendments to modify the soil properties and influence plants to immobilise Cu and Zn was studied in a naturally contaminated, additionally spiked podzolic soil. Lolium perenne L (perennial rye grass), Festuca rubra L (creeping red fescue) and Poa pratensis L (Kentucky blue grass) were tested in a pot study in the presence of soil amendments (lime, phosphate, and compost, individually and in combination) to assess the effect of soil-plantamendment interaction on phytostabilisation. The ability of treatments to stabilize metals was assessed on the basis of metal fractionation in soil, partitioning of metals in plants, and metal uptake by the plants. Significant partitioning of Cu into immobile forms occurred as a result of the growth of Festuca rubra, and of Zn by the growth of Poa pratensis. Application of lime significantly reduced the exchangeable fraction of Zn, whereas phosphate application had an accelerating effect on exchangeable Cu. With combined application of amendments, the plant metal concentration decreased by more than 40% for Cu and 70% for Zn, compared to soils receiving no amendments. Combined application of amendments, in conjunction with growth of Festuca and Poa, can be recommended for phytostabilising of Cu and Zn in moderately contaminated acid soils of southwest British Columbia.
Manual Tags: Bioconcentration factor; Phenotypical trait; Phytostabilisation; Scopus; search.rye; Sequential extraction; SPV; TITLE-ABS-KEY (perennial W/1 ("rye" OR secale) AND NOT ("rye?grass" OR ryegrass)) AND DOCTYPE (ar); Translocation factor

Author: Prasad, S. M.; Kudada, N.
Title: Effect of barrier and inter crops on natural incidence of Papaya ringspot virus disease and fruit yield of papaya.
Abstract Note: Field trials were conducted during the 1994/95 and 1995/96 cropping seasons in Bihar, India, to study the effect of barrier and intercrops (i.e. pigeon pea, sorghum and castor) on the natural incidence of Papaya ringspot virus (PRSV) disease and on the yield of pawpaw (cv. Farm Selection-1) fruits. Perennial pigeon pea used as a barrier or border crop (2 rows) and intercropped with pawpaw significantly reduced the PRSV disease incidence. Pawpaw with pigeon pea as the barrier or border crop recorded the minimum disease incidence with high fruit number and yield per plant. However, the maximum fruit weight, fruit length and fruit circumference were obtained in pawpaw intercropped with pigeon pea. These parameters showed positive and significant association with fruit yield per plant and together accounted for 97.45% (R 2=0.9745) variation in fruit yield. The highest direct effect on fruit yield per plant was obtained by fruit length.
Manual Tags: search.pigeonpea; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (cajanus OR "pigeon$pea")); WOS

Author: Srinivasa Rao, M.; Dharma Reddy, K.; Srivatsava, N.N.; Singh, T.V.K.; Subba Reddy, G.; Ramakrishna, Y.S.
Title: Effect of change in microclimate on insect pests and their predators in pigeonpea (Cajanus cajan)
Abstract Note: A field experiment was conducted during the rainy seasons of 1999 and 2000 to observe the change in microclimate and its effect on insect pests and predators of pigeonpea [Cajanus cajan (L.) Millsp.]. The intercropping was followed with 3 intercrops to monitor the modification of microclimate. The microclimate variables, viz canopy temperature (Tc), canopy air temperature differential (CATD) and relative humidity in crop canopy (CRH), varied with duration of pigeonpea and intercropping systems. Medium-and long-duration pigeonpea recorded higher Tc and CRH and were more with sorghum [Sorghum bicolor (L.) Moench] and castor (Ricinus communis L.) as intercrops. Canopy air temperature defferential was in consistent. Insect pests (leaf hopper, Empoasca kerri Pruthi, spotted pod borer, Maruca vitrata Geyer and gram pod borer, Helicoverpa armigera Hubner) and predators (coccinellids and spiders) were highly correlated with relative humidity in crop canopy.
Manual Tags: Cajanus cajan; Entomology; Insect pests; Microclimate; Pigeonea-based cropping; Scopus; search.pigeonpea; SPV; TITLE-ABS-KEY ("long duration" W/1 (cajanus OR "pigeon?pea" OR pigeonpea)) AND DOCTYPE (ar)

Author: Pandey, N.; Ojha, C. B.; Jha, V. B.; Singh, N. B.
Title: Effect of chemical mutagens on the rate of germination, seedling mortality, and induced sterility in pigeonpea.
Abstract Note: To induce male sterility in long-duration pigeon pea [ Cajanus cajan] by chemical mutation, the varieties Bahar, DA11 and Pusa 9 were treated with streptomycin sulfate (SS) for 24 h and sodium azide (SA) for 48 h. Four concentrations (0.1, 0.5, 1.0 and 1.5 M) of SS and SA (0.025, 0.05, 0.10 and 0.125%) were used for seed treatment, before sowing in the field in September 1994. Seeds treated with SS germinated earlier than seeds treated with SA. For both chemicals, germination percentage decreased with an increase in mutagenic dose. DA11 was the most sensitive to SA, showing no germination at all except for the lowest concentration. Bahar showed the highest seed germination percentage and seedling survival following treatment with both mutagens. Seed from each treatment was sown in August 1995 and 4 male sterile plants were isolated from 2 different treatments of Pusa 9 (0.025% SA and 0.5 M SS).
Manual Tags: search.grain; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 grain); WOS

Author: Kavino, M.; Harish, S.; Kumar, N.; Saravanakumar, D.; Samiyappan, R.
Title: Effect of chitinolytic PGPR on growth, yield and physiological attributes of banana (Musa spp.) under field conditions
Abstract Note: Plant growth promoting effects of two Pseudomonas fluorescens strains, CHA0 and Pf1 were tested alone or in combinations with chitin on banana cv.Virupakshi (Musa spp. AAB) in terms of growth, yield, leaf nutrient contents and physiology in lower Pulney hills, Western Ghats, India under rainfed field conditions. The P. fluorescens strains, CHA0 and Pf1 were tested for their efficiency to produce chitinases in the presence of chitin molecules. Bio-formulations containing PGPR strains and chitin molecules were further developed to improve the chitinolytic activity of the rhizobacteria. The bio-formulations amended with chitin, viz., CHA0 + chitin significantly increased the height and girth of pseudostem, bunch yield, number of hands per bunch, fingers per hand and quality attributes compared to other treatments both in plant as well as ratoon crops. Further, the application of CHA0 + chitin significantly improved the N, P and K contents of banana leaves when compared to untreated control. These results revealed that P. fluorescens strain, CHA0 in combination with chitin has the potential to increase growth, leaf nutrient contents and yield of banana plants under perennial cropping systems. In view of environmental pollution, due to excessive use and high production costs of fertilizers, PGPR strains tested in our study have a potential to be used for sustainable and environmentally friendly horticultural production.
Manual Tags: Growth; Musa spp.; Physiology and yield; Plant growth promoting rhizobacteria (PGPR); ratoon* W/5 (oryza OR rice); ScienceDirect; search.rice; SPV

Author: Nzokou, P.; Wilson, A. R.; Lin, Y.
Title: Effect of cover crop management on organic matter production and soil fertility in an Abies fraseri plantation.
Abstract Note: Fraser fir ( Abies fraseri) is traditionally produced in a high input intensively managed cropping system for Christmas tree production in the Midwest and Eastern United States of America. The goal of the project is to investigate the effect of three ground covers (alfafa [ Medicago sativa], Dutch white clover [ Trifolium repens] and perennial rye [ Lolium perenne]) on the sustainability of Fraser fir Christmas tree production system. This paper reports on the effect of ground cover species and management practices on organic matter production, soil organic matter, and soil mineral nitrogen. Intercropped ground covers were mowed every 21 days, and the cut vegetation returned to the ground as green mulch. The effect of cover crop species and management practices were evaluated by quantifying the cover crop above-ground biomass production. The total amount of mineral nutrients including nitrogen, phosphorus, potassium, calcium, and magnesium were determined by chemical analyses of subsamples of materials from the cover crop biomass. The effect of cover crop on soil fertility was evaluated by monitoring changes in soil organic carbon and soil mineral nitrogen. The results indicate that cover crop species affected the amount of green manure produced and its total nitrogen and macronutrients content. Soil organic matter content was stable in the upper soil profile due to the relatively small quantities of organic matter added with the cropping system compared with the total stock of soil C. Mineral nitrogen decreased over the season due to the synchrony of cover crop decomposition, mineralization and nutrient uptake by trees in the upper profile. These results indicate that intercropping cover crops can improve soil nitrogen fertility and organic matter; however, there is strong competition for other nutrients that need to be carefully considered.
Manual Tags: search.rye; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 ("rye" OR secale) NOT "rye$grass"); WOS
Editor: Biala, J.; Prange, R.; Raviv, M.

Author: Perez Polanco, R.; Sanzo Mancebo, R.; Reyes Llorente, H.; Hernandez Alfonso, F.
Title: Effect of cultivar and cutting height on yield of ratoon crops of rice.
Abstract Note: In field trials in 1991-92 in Sancti Spiritus, Cuba, 5 rice cultivars were cut to a height of 15, 30 or 45 cm. Yields of ratoon crops were highest when the main crop was cut to a height of 15 cm. The highest grain yields were obtained with cv. IA Cuba-15 with 8.87 t/ha from the main crop and 3.20 t/ha from the ratoon crop. Yields of ratoon crops ranged from 37.7% to 56.8% of those of main crops.
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: FuXian, Xu; QingHua, Fan; YingPing, Chen; ChangRong, Chen; DingSu, Chen; JingCheng, Zeng; ZuJun, Chen; Lin, Zhang; Mao, Liu; XingBing, Zhou; XiaoYi, Guo; Hong, Xiong; YongChuan, Zhu
Title: Effect of cultural density and model on main crop and ratooning rice of mid-season hybrid rice in winter paddy field.
Publication Title: Southwest China Journal of Agricultural Sciences
Abstract Note: The experiment was conducted with Chuan-Jiang You 527, a mid-season rice combinations grown under the condition of 6 cultural densities and 2 cultural models of equal-distance between rows (EDBR) and triangle. By using variance, correlation and path analysis, the results indicated that the grain yield of EDBR were highly significantly higher than ones of triangle in equal cultural density, and there were significantly negative correlations between the amount of grain yield increased and cultural densities. The best high yield cultural treatment was density about 15.16*10 4 hill/hm 2 with EDBR for main crop, rationing rice and total yield. The reason of EDBR helping to increase grain yield was that the seedlings of EDBR were fairly well-distributed, so that sun light was well-distributed in field, and the single seedling strongly grew.
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: Thakar, M. W.; Shah, N. L.; Mahmood, Tariq; Gill, M. A.
Title: Effect of cultural practices on green fodder yield of ratoon sorghum.
Abstract Note: In field trials at Faisalabad in 1987, green fodder yield of ratoon sorghum was highest when cut to 2.5 cm above ground level and given 50 kg N/ha at first irrigation.
Manual Tags: search.sorghum; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 sorghum); WOS

Author: Akgun, I.; Tosun, M.; Sagsoz, S.; Taspinar, M.
Title: Effect of cutting frequency and height on the yield and some chemical characteristics of dry matter of diploid and tetraploid perennial rye ( Secale montanum Guss.).
Abstract Note: In a greenhouse trial, diploid and tetraploid S. montanum was cut every 4, 6 or 8 weeks to heights of 0, 5 or 10 cm. In diploids, tiller numbers per plant were higher than in tetraploids, whereas green and dry matter yields, and the percentage and yield of crude protein were lower than in tetraploids. There were no significant differences between diploids and tetraploids for the percentages of Ca, Mg, K or P. Cutting to ground level (0 cm) and cutting every 4 weeks significantly decreased tiller numbers per plant, plant growth rate, green and dry matter yields and crude protein yield. As cutting height increased, the percentages of Ca, Mg, K and P also increased. The longer cutting intervals increased the percentages of Ca and Mg, and but decreased the percentages of K and P.
Manual Tags: search.rye; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 ("rye" OR secale) NOT "rye$grass"); WOS

Author: Daliri, M. S.; Eftekari, A.; Mobasser, H. R.; Tari, D. B.; Porkalhor, H.
Title: Effect of cutting time and cutting height on yield and yield components of ratoon rice (Tarom Langrodi Variety)
Abstract Note: In order to study the effect of cutting time and cutting height on yield and yield components of ratoon rice (Oryza sativa L.) Tarom langrody variety a field experiment was carried out in the field of Ghaemshahr Azad University in 2007. Experimental design was arranged in spilt plot in basis of Randomized Completely Block Design with four replications. Some agronomical traits such as numbers of effective tiller hill(-1), panicle number m(-2), total spikelet panicle(-1), filled spikelets percentage, 1000 grains weight, grain and biological yield and harvest index were measured. Results showed that the effect of cutting time on number of effective tiller hill(-1), panicle m(-2), percent filled spikelet panicle(-)1, grain yield and harvest index were found statistically significant. Cutting height had a significant effect on number of tiller in hill, number of effective tiller in hill, number of panicle m(-2), filled spikelet panicle(-1) percentage, grain yield and harvest index. Interaction among cutting time and cutting height on number of tiller hill(-1), number of effective tillers hill(-1), number of panicle m(-2) percent filled spikelet panicle(-1) were significant. According to results cutting time at physiological maturity and also cutting in 40 cm cutting height from soil surface for the best grain yield of ratoon rice were recommended.
Manual Tags: Cutting time; Ratoon; Rice; Scopus; search.rice; SPV; TITLE-ABS-KEY (ratoon* W/5 (oryza OR rice)) AND DOCTYPE (ar); TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); WOS; Yield

Author: Quddus, M. A.; Pendleton, J. W.
Title: Effect of deep placement of nitrogen fertilizer on ratoon rice.
Abstract Note: Rice cv. IR9784-52-2-3-2 was grown in pots containing Maahas clay soil mixed with 75 mg N, 44 mg P and 83 mg K/kg soil. N as urea was broadcast on the soil surface 4 days after harvest of the main crop, or injected
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: HongFei, Chen; YiYuan, Liang; RuiYu, Lin; LuDuan, Zheng; KangJing, Liang; WenXiong, Lin
Title: Effect of different cultivation patterns on tiller development and physio-biochemical characteristics of first ratoon rice crop.
Publication Title: Zhongguo Shengtai Nongye Xuebao / Chinese Journal of Eco-Agriculture
Abstract Note: The effect of different cultivation patterns, Super High-Yield Cultivation Pattern (SHCP) and Tradition Cultivation Pattern (TCP), on tiller development and physio-biochemical characteristics of first ratoon rice were studied. The result indicates that root activity, chlorophyll content, LAI, nitrate reductase activity, NO 3--N content, Ca 2+-ATPase activity and Mg 2+-ATPase activity of the first rice crop under SHCP are respectively 20.60%-38.65%, 5.16%-23.26%, 18.91%-63.29%, 18.22%-76.76%, 34.88%-48.35%, 1.25%-17.94% and 4.09%-17.87% higher than TCP from tillering to ripening stage. Productive tillering period shortens by 5 d and lower node tillers increases by 51.61%. Accumulation of N and P at different growth stages and K during grain filling under SHCP are respectively 1.43-2.44, 1.21-1.48, 1.55-2.21 times those of TCP. These traits can optimize population quality, improve the photosynthesis efficiency in later growth period, and lay the foundation for high yield attainment.
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: van Niekerk, W.A.; Hassen, A.; Casey, N.H.; Coertze, R.J.
Title: Effect of different grazing pressure by lambs grazing Lolium perenne and Dactylis glomerata pastures during spring on: 1. Diet quality
Publication Title: South African Journal of Animal Sciences
Abstract Note: This study was undertaken to determine the influence of three grazing pressures [high (HGP), medium (MGP) and low (LGP), corresponding to 30, 50 and 75 g available DM/kg BW/day, respectively] on the quality of herbage consumed by lambs grazing Lolium perenne and Dactylis glomerata pastures in spring. Feed samples collected via oesophageal fistulae at the start and end of a six-week grazing period were analyzed for nitrogen (N), ash, neutral detergent fibre (NDF), acid detergent fibre (ADF), acid detergent lignin (ADL) concentrations, and in vitro digestibility of organic matter (IVDOM). In general, the quality of diets selected by lambs grazing both L. perenne and D. glomerata pastures was lower at the end than at the start of the grazing period. For both pastures the N concentration of herbage consumed by lambs in the HGP treatment was lower than for that in the LGP treatment. For L. perenne HGP resulted in the selection of a diet with higher fibre (NDF and ADF) concentrations and consequently lower IVDOM than in the LGP treatment. In the D. glomerata pasture, higher ADF and lower IVDOM were recorded in the MGP treatment compared to the other treatments. On the D. glomerata pasture the ADL concentration of the selected forage was lower in the HGP than in the MGP or LGP treatments. Forage selected on the L. perenne pasture had generally lower N, ash, ADF and ADL concentrations than those selected from the D. glomerata pasture. However, the IVDOM of the selected L. perenne was higher than that of selected D. glomerata.
Manual Tags: Chemical composition; Cocksfoot; Diet selection; Pasture availability; perennial rye grass; Scopus; search.rye; SPV; TITLE-ABS-KEY (perennial W/1 ("rye" OR secale) AND NOT ("rye?grass" OR ryegrass)) AND DOCTYPE (ar)

Author: van Niekerk, W.A.; Hassen, A.; Casey, N.H.; Coertze, R.J.
Title: Effect of different grazing pressures by lambs grazing Lolium perenne and Dactylis glomerata pastures during spring on: 2. Intake and growth
Publication Title: South African Journal of Animal Sciences
Abstract Note: This study was undertaken to determine the influence of three grazing pressures [high (HGP), medium (MGP) and low (LGP), corresponding to 30, 50 and 75 g available DM/kg BW/day, respectively] on the performance of lambs grazing Lolium perenne and Dactylis glomerata pastures in spring. Feed intakes and average daily live weight gains (ADG in g/day) were determined for each group. In general intakes of both L. perenne and D. glomerata pastures were higher at the end of the study than at the onset. Grazing pressure had no effect on the intake of L. perenne, but on the D. glomerata pasture, HGP resulted in a decreased intake by the lambs compared to the LGP treatment. For both pasture species the ADG of the lambs were lower on the HGP compared to the MGP treatment, though intake and ADG of the lambs were higher when grazing L. perenne compared to D. glomerata.
Manual Tags: Cocksfoot; Diet selection; Pasture availability; perennial rye grass; Performance; Scopus; search.rye; SPV; TITLE-ABS-KEY (perennial W/1 ("rye" OR secale) AND NOT ("rye?grass" OR ryegrass)) AND DOCTYPE (ar)

Author: Farrokh, A. R.; Razavipour, T.; Lomer, A. M.
Title: Effect of different levels of nitrogen and potassium on yield and yield components of rice ratoon of Hashemi cultivar in Astaneh Ashrafiyeh (Guilan province).
Abstract Note: An experiment was conducted in Iran to investigate the effects of N (at 0, 50, 100 and 150 kg/ha) and K (at 0 and 100 kg/ha) fertilizers on the yield and yield components of rice cv. Hashemi ratoon. The effect of N on the number of panicles/m 2 was significant at 5%. K had significant effect on yield, number of grains per panicle and 1000-grain weight at 1%. The highest yield and number of grains per panicle were obtained from N 100K 100 treatment. The highest number of panicles/m 2 was recorded from N 150K 100 treatment.
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: Dong, Yang; HongFei, Chen; ChuanYing, Zhuo; WenXiong, Lin
Title: Effect of different N application modes in the first cropping rice on the physiobiochemistry of the first cropping rice and its ratoon rice.
Publication Title: Zhongguo Shengtai Nongye Xuebao / Chinese Journal of Eco-Agriculture
Abstract Note: In order to determine the physiobiochemical mechanisms of the first cropping rice and its ratoon rice under different N application modes in the first cropping rice, the different ratios of nitrogen (N) fertilizer supply for basal-tillering to that for spike application in the first cropping rice were designed under total N supply of 225 kg/hm 2, which were N 1 (8:2), N 2 (7:3), N 3 (6:4), and the zero N supply (N 0) was the control. Changes in nitrate reductase activity, chlorophyll content, net photosynthetic rate and root activity were analysed and their effects on dry matter accumulation and grain yield formation were determined. The results showed that the changing tendency in nitrate reductase activity, chlorophyll content and net photosynthetic rate in different treatments was similar under different N application modes in different developmental stages of the first cropping rice and its ratoon rice, showing an increase at the early stage, peaking at the booting stage and then gradually declining in the first cropping rice. It rapidly increased again at full-heading stage and then rapidly declined at the ripening stage of the ratoon rice. It was also found that bleeding rate continuously declined after the booting stage of the first cropping rice. However, during the ratooning cropping, it gradually increased at the budding and tillering stages, reached a peak at full-heading stage and then gradually declined at maturity. The result indicated that N supply enhanced nitrate reductase activity, chlorophyll content, net photosynthetic rate and root activity. This therefore suggests that the proportion of N supply should be increased to enhance these parameters during the middle and late growth stages of the first cropping rice. The good pratoce in N fertilizer application can also enhance root activity, especially at the booting stage of the first cropping rice. This, in turn, can result in increased dry matter accumulation of the first cropping rice and, consequently, high grain output of the ratoon rice.
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: Jeyabaskaran, K. J.; Pandey, S. D.; Mustaffa, M. M.; Sathiamoorthy, S.
Title: Effect of different organic manures with graded levels of inorganic fertilizers on ratoon of Poovan banana.
Abstract Note: In a field experiment conducted during 1999-2000, in Trichy, Tamil Nadu, India, the effect of different organic manures (all at 15 kg/plant) with levels of inorganic fertilizers (40, 60, 80, 100 and 120% of recommended dose of NPK) on ratoon of banana cv. Poovan was investigated. The recommended dose of NPK was 200 : 50 : 400 g/plant. The performance of different organic manures in terms of yield was in the order of poultry manure = rice husk ash > pressmud > farmyard manure (FYM) > control. It was found that nearly 20% of NPK could be saved by adding either poultry manure or rice husk ash to produce 18.5% more yield than at 100% NPK + no organic manure, and this would lead to an additional profit of either Rs 9500/acre or Rs 13 700/acre, respectively. Application of pressmud, poultry manure or rice husk ash can save 40% of NPK and produce similar yield to 100% NPK + no organic manure.
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: Ri, Yang; GuiFen, Yang; ZhiHong, Gong; QianQi, Li; FengWu, Wei
Title: Effect of different sowing dates on characteristics of first and ratoon super rice crops.
Abstract Note: Objective: The present experiment was conducted to investigate suitable sowing dates for super rice in order to regulate the growth duration of first and ratoon croppings of rice and rape. Method: The super rice variety Zhongzheyou 1 was used to compare the morphological and economical characteristics of first and ratoon crops for super rice sown on different sowing dates (19th, 24th and 29th March and 3rd and 8th April) in Rongshui and Sanjiang counties. Result: The results showed that the leaf-age, basal seedlings, max seedlings and effective panicles of first cropping increased with the delay of sowing dates for 5 days, while the panicle setting rate, grains per panicle, full grains per panicle and yield were decreased. The initial heading stage, full heading stage and maturity stage of first cropping also delayed for 1-4 days and the whole growth period shortened by 1-4 days. The growth duration was also delayed in ratoon cropping and most of the characteristics worsened. Under suitable climatic conditions, the stubble of ratoon rice should be kept higher to elongate growth period for getting high yield. Conclusion: The suitable sowing date for super rice planting areas with 140-250 m elevation ranged from 19-24 March and may be delayed, and the stubble height of ratoon cropping kept higher to get higher yield.
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: Yang, Shang-Shyng; Chang, Hsiu-Lan
Title: Effect of environmental conditions on methane production and emission from paddy soil
Abstract Note: Methane production and emission from paddy soil in laboratory experiments were affected by sterilization, temperature, organic matter supplementation, urea application, oxygen concentration, water content, soil pH and light intensity. Methane production was negligible in sterilized soil, whereas each gram of natural soil produced a daily maximum of 344 μg methane. There were two methane production peaks, one at 37°C, the other at 60°C. There was a positive linear correlation between methane production and incubation temperature from 15 to 37°C, and a negative linear correlation between 37 and 50°C. Methane production increased with the amount of rice straw supplementation. Green manure, corncob, xylan, avicel and compost application had a stimulating effect on methane production, whereas glucose, sucrose and urea supplements were inhibitory. Anaerobic conditions and water flooding on the surface of soil favoured methane emission.
Manual Tags: Methane emission; Methane production; Oxygen; Paddy soil; ratoon* W/5 (oryza OR rice); Rice straw; ScienceDirect; search.rice; SPV; Temperature

Author: Birrell, H.A.; Thompson, R.L.
Title: Effect of environmental factors on the growth of grazed pasture in south-western Victoria
Abstract Note: This paper presents work from several studies on pasture production that were conducted in south-west Victoria at the Pastoral Research Institute, Hamilton. The frequency with which pasture growth commenced for each week of autumn in the years from 1965 to 1991 was assessed. The median period for the commencement of growth was in the third week of March (although the average date was March 27). Autumn data from several trials conducted over 3 decades were collated and analysed. A relationship between the grazed pasture yield (average of stocking rates plots) at the end of autumn and the rainfall showed that 200 mm of rainfall in the 3 months to the end of May was optimal while higher rainfall depressed the growth. The average daily growth rates of introduced pasture (perennial rye grass, Lolium perenne L. cv. Victorian, phalaris, Phalaris aquatica L. cv. Australian, subterranean clover Trifollum subterranneum L. and volunteer species) were measured in 2- and 4-week growth periods (G 2 and G 4, kg DM/ha.day) for the seasonal growth cycles over 4 years (1980-84 except 1983) when grazed by Merino wether sheep at stocking rates of 10, 13 or 18 sheep/ha. The rainfall throughout the study was lower than normal. Although differences in the animal performance between the stocking rates were only small, at the low stocking rate capeweed (Arctotheca calendula L.) in patches became the major component of the sward. Greater variation in G 2 than in G 4 indicated that growth responded quickly to current environmental conditions. A nonlinear regression accounted for 74% of the variance in G 2 when related to the 3 climatic factors of daylength, soil temperature at 10 cm depth and the soil moisture to a depth of 10 cm, and a plant factor of green herbage yield. The 26 % of unaccounted variance appears to be associated with an effect of stocking rate, possibly botanical composition. The botanical composition was not continuously monitored hence the only sward character included in the investigation was herbage yield. Comparison of the patterns of pasture growth from different latitudes indicated that while the growth pattern in south-western Victoria is erratic, it is intermediary between Mediterranean and temperate pasture types. Understanding this aspect has implications for improving the efficiency of animal production in this environment.
Manual Tags: Grazed pasture; Pasture growth; Pasture production; Scopus; search.rye; SPV; TITLE-ABS-KEY (perennial W/1 ("rye" OR secale) AND NOT ("rye?grass" OR ryegrass)) AND DOCTYPE (ar)

Title: Effect of fertilisation of the main crop on tillering in ratoon rice.
