Author: SHVEDOV, A. P.; ALEKSANDROV, A. A.
Title: Effect of fertilizers on the yield of winter rye, spring wheat & perennial herbage.
Abstract Note: On dark gray forest soils the effectiveness of dung or peat (20-40 ton/ha) for rye increased with simultaneous application of rock P or lime. NH 4NO 3 gave greater yield increases of grain (up to 5 q/ha per q of NH 4NO 3) than super did. P & particularly N were effective on spring wheat. K had little effect. Yield increases were greatest (7.0-7.8 q/ha) with 2 q/ha NH 4NO 3, 2 q/ha super & 0.3 q/ha K before sowing, 0.5 q/ha super at sowing & 0.5 q/ha NH 4NO 3 subsequently. Dung, lime & P had a residual effect on yields of perennial herbage.
Manual Tags: search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); WOS

Title: EFFECT OF FOOD RESERVES ON THE RATOON GROWTH OF RICE PLANT

Author: Mousa, S. M.; Soliman, I. A.; Spoelstra, S. F.; El-Hafiz, G. A. A.; Salem, I. A.
Title: Effect of forage maturity on: 1. Chemical composition, in vitro digestibility and in sacco degradability.
Publication Title: Egyptian Journal of Nutrition and Feeds
Abstract Note: Effect of forage maturity on DM yield (DMY), organic matter yield (OMY), chemical composition, in vitro organic matter digestibility (IVOMD) and in sacco degradability were studied. Perennial rye grasses ( Lolium perenne L.) were collected at different stages of maturity, sampled and analysed. The in vitro digestibility was carried out using all samples. In sacco degradability was carried out by incubating samples of grasses in 4 lactating Holstein Friesian cows fitted with rumen cannulae. Incubation times were 0, 3, 6, 12, 24, 48 and 72 h. Cows were fed one of two feed mixtures based on either young grass-silage (D1) or old grass-silage (D2). DMY and OMY increased ( P<0.01) with increasing number of growth days (R=0.89, 0.92, respectively). The digestible organic matter yield (DOMY) increased with a decreasing rate particularly after 6 weeks of growth. The cell wall contents (NDF) increased ( P<0.001) with increasing maturity of grasses. Within the cell wall, the highest correlation was found between growing days (GD) and ADL (R=0.95). The CP content of grasses decreased ( P<0.001) as the

Author: VOROB'EV, V. F.
Title: Effect of foreign pollen on fertility of intervarietal spring wheat hybrids.
Publication Title: Trud. Orenburg, obi. sel'skohoz. opyt. Sta. (Trans. Orenburg reg. agric.   exp. Sta.)
Abstract Note: When intervarietal crosses were made without emasculation, supplementary pollination with foreign pollen of winter perennial rye had no effect on the viability of the F 1 hybrids or on the segregation of the F 2 into awned (maternal) and awnless (paternal) forms.

Author: CHAUHAN, JS; LOPEZ, FSS; VERGARA, BS
Title: EFFECT OF GIBBERELLIC-ACID AND KINETIN APPLICATION BEFORE AND AFTER MAIN CROP CUTTING ON RATOON GRAIN-YIELD OF IR-44 RICE
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: Somasundaram, E.; Srinivasan, G.; Manoharan, M. L.
Title: Effect of green manuring Sesbania rostrata and fertilizers application on chemical properties of soil and grain yield in rice-rice crop sequences.
Abstract Note: In a field experiment during the kuruvai (June-September) season of 1990 in Tamil Nadu, rice cv. IR 50 produced the highest grain yield of 5.34 t/ha when the crop was green manured with 12.5 t/ha Sesbania rostrata 7 days before transplanting, compared with manuring at transplanting (5.20 t) or at dates after transplanting. During the thaladi (October - January) season in 1990/91, rice cv. IR 60 was grown on the same plots and given 0, 50 or 100 kg N/ha. Growing rice on plots where S. rostrata intercropped with rice in the first season and ratooned at 45 days after transplanting and incorporated at harvest with 50 or 100 kg N produced the highest yields of 6.10 and 6.43 t/ha, respectively.
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: Manjappa, K.; Prabhakar, A. S.
Title: Effect of growth regulators and nutrients spray on performance of ratoon crop of hybrid rice under different irrigation levels.
Abstract Note: An experiment was conducted during 1997-98 and 1998-99 at Agricultural Research Station (Paddy), Sirsi, Karnataka, India, to determine the effect of growth regulators and nutrients spray on ratooning ability of hybrid rice (cv. KRH-2) under different irrigation levels. The plant growth regulator and nutrient sprays consisted of benzyladenine at 100 ppm, kinetin at 50 ppm, gibberellic acid (GA 3) at 25 ppm, urea spray at 2%, potassium nitrate at 0.5% and zinc sulfate at 1%. Irrigation treatments consisted of residual moisture (RM; no irrigation), irrigation at critical stages (ICS), irrigation at hair cracking stage (IHCS) and irrigation at saturation point (ISP). On an average of over 2 years, ISP recorded the highest grain yield (2767 kg/ha), followed by IHCS (2297 kg/ha), ICS (1602 kg/ha) and RM (1123 kg/ha). Spraying of GA 3 to main crop resulted in significantly higher ratoon grain yield (2251 kg ha -1) over other treatments. The grain yields of plants supplied with kinetin kg (2088 kg ha -1), benzyladenine (2063 kg ha -1) and urea spray (2058 kg ha -1) were similar. Spraying of KNO 3 and ZnSO 4 resulted in 15.6 and 10.5% increase in grain yield over no spray, respectively. Net returns obtained with ISP (Rs. 14210 ha -1) were significantly higher over those obtained with IHCS, ICS and RM. Among the different plant growth regulators and nutrients spray, net returns were significantly higher with GA 3 (Rs. 11190 ha -1) than the others. Urea spray, (Rs. 8948 ha -1) and kinetin (Rs. 10390 ha -1) recorded similar net returns. The lowest net returns was recorded in the control treatment (Rs. 7096 ha -1).
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: Liu, Feihu; Liang, Xueni; Zhang, Naigen; Huang, Yousheng; Zhang, Shouwen
Title: Effect of growth regulators on yield and fiber quality in ramie (Boemheria nivea (L.) Gaud.), China grass
Abstract Note: The effects of two mixtures of four plant growth regulators (choline chloride, gibberellin (GA3), benzyladenine (6-BA) and NaHSO3) at 20:9:5:800 mg kg−1 (H1) and 20:42:43:2350 mg kg−1 (H3) (active ingredients), respectively, were investigated on yield and fiber quality in ramie (Boehmeria nivea (L.) Gaud.). The mixtures were sprayed over the canopy at two growth stages (10 and 20 days after the previous cut) of field-grown ramie. The treatments increased raw fiber yield by 13–18%, and improved fiber fineness by 57–349 m g−1, increased number of leaves per plant, and also improved all yield components. Treatment H1 resulted in a denser distribution, smaller diameters and greater quantity of fiber cells in stem cross-section. Physiological responses included improving leaf water status, increasing net photosynthetic rate, and decreasing electrolyte exosmosis rate.
Manual Tags: Boehmeria nivea (L.) Gaud.; Fiber fineness; Fiber yield; Microstructure of fiber; perennial W/1 (oryza OR rice); Plant growth regulators; Ramie; ScienceDirect; search.rice; SPV

Author: Santos, A. B. dos; Prabhu, A. S.
Title: Effect of harvesting systems and fungicide application on the performance of irrigated ratoon rice.
Publication Title: Revista Brasileira de Engenharia Agricola e Ambiental
Abstract Note: The cultivation of ratoon rice ( Oryza sativa) may constitute a source of additional income. However, to make it economically viable, an adequate harvesting system of the main crop is necessary. With the objective of evaluating the response of irrigated ratoon rice to the harvesting equipment, cutting height, management of stubble after harvest and fungicides, experiments were conducted during two consecutive years. In the first year, harvesters with three types of equipment (straw chopper, straw spreader, without chopper and spreader); two heights of cutting and four fungicide treatments were evaluated. In the second year, besides harvesting equipments, three stubble management practices (compactor roll, straw chaffer and without management) and five fungicide treatments were assessed. The straw chopper was superior in increasing the grain yield and quality, in comparison with normal harvest without utilizing this equipment. The fungicide applications increased grain yield and reduced incidence of grain discoloration and consequent improvement in the quality of the product. The roll compactor did not contribute to growth and yield of irrigated ratoon rice crop. The straw spreader increased yield only when the cutting height was low.

Title: Effect of harvesting time and plant residual on agronomic traits of rice ratoon.
Publication Title: American-Eurasian Journal of Agricultural & Environmental Sciences
Abstract Note: A field experiment was carried out in 2010 to investigate the effect of harvesting time and main plant residual on yield and yield components of rice. A split-split plot arrangement fitted into a Randomized Completely Block Design with three replications was used. Main factor was 3 harvesting time (T 1: harvesting plant crop at physiological maturity T 2: harvesting at 7 days after physiological maturity T 3: harvesting at

Author: Chauhan, J. S.; Lopez, F. S. S.; Vergara, B. S.
Title: Effect of harvest time on IR44 ratoon grain yield.
Abstract Note: The effect of time of harvest of an IR44 rice ratoon crop on grain yield was studied between Dec. 1983 and July 1984. The ratoon crop was harvested at 75, 80, 85 and 90 days after main crop harvest. Main crop grain yield was 516 g/m. Ratoon crop harvest time significantly affected spikelet fertility, number of filled grains and ratoon grain yield. Ratoon grain yield varied from 126 g/m for 75 days after main crop harvest (DAH) to 168 g for 85 DAH. Lowest grain yield (136 g) was at 75 DAH and the highest was at 85 DAH. Differences in grain yield were not fully explained by differences in spikelet fertility. Opt. time for harvest of ratoon crop was 80-85 days after main crop.

Author: Maharaj, K.; Brathwaite, R. A. I.
Title: Effect of herbicide treatments on the main rice (Oryza sativa L.) crop and its subsequent influence on the ratoon crop in Trinidad
Abstract Note: A field experiment was conducted in 1993-94 to study the effect of five post-emergence herbicide combinations on weed control and yield of wet seeded (WS) and transplanted (TP) main rice (Oryza sativa L.) crop (MC) and its ratoon (RC). Common weeds which occurred in this study were Fimbristylis littoralis Gaudich, Ischaemum rogusum Salisb., Sphenoclea zeylanica Geartn., and Ludwigia hyssopifolia (G. Don) Excell. Combinations of propanil (3.0 kg a.i. ha(-1)) with oxadiazon (3.0 kg a.i. ha(-1)), pendimenthalin (1.5 kg a.i. ha(-1)), and butachlor (2.0 kg a.i. ha(-1)) were applied 14 days after seeding (DAS) and 7 days after transplanting (DAT) and a split application of propanil (3.0 kg a.i. ha(-1) + 3.0 kg a.i. ha(-1)) was applied 14 DAS, 28 DAT, and 7 DAT. Author: MASLOV, A. B.
Title: Effect of high-energy protons on mitotic division in roots of perennial wheat.
Abstract Note: The number of disrupted anaphases increased with dose. The efficiency of protons as a muta-genic agent equalled that of any other form of ionizing radiation.

Author: van Eekeren, N.; Bos, M.; de Wit, J.; Keidel, H.; Bloem, J.
Title: Effect of individual grass species and grass species mixtures on soil quality as related to root biomass and grass yield
Abstract Note: For the purpose of feeding value, drought resistance and nitrogen utilization, other grasses (e.g. Festuca arundinacea and Dactylis glomerata) than the currently widely used perennial rye grass (Lolium perenne) are introduced in dairy farming, either as a monoculture or in a mixture. To study the effect of these grasses on yield and soil chemical and biological quality, the three species were sown in a field experiment in monoculture and in two mixtures. Within two growing seasons, the grass species tested under high soil fertility conditions did not show significant effects on most of the tested soil biological parameters. Only for the mixture of L. perenne and D. glomerata a higher soil NO3 - and mineral N content were most probably related to a higher bacterial activity, possibly induced by dying roots of L. perenne. This was the likely cause of the high aboveground dry matter yield of this mixture. The N-efficiencies of the monocultures of L. perenne, F. arundinacea and D. glomerata were not different when only considering the aboveground biomass. In L. perenne and F. arundinacea the total N in root biomass was higher while under D. glomerata the NO3 - in the soil was higher. The lower fraction of mineral N to total N for L. perenne, F. arundinacea and the mixture of the two suggests that their organic matter build-up/mineralization ratio was higher than for D. glomerata. Furthermore, the mixture of L. perenne and F. arundinacea showed significantly lower soil mineral N levels than the monocultures of each. We conclude that grassland systems with a mixture of L. perenne and F. arundinacea are more sustainable than the monocultures of each, in terms of reduction of nitrogen losses and the build-up of soil organic matter. D. glomerata should only be used in a mixture in which the companion grass(es) are maintained.

Author: SUBBIAN, P.; PALANIAPPAN, S.
Title: EFFECT OF INTEGRATED MANAGEMENT-PRACTICES ON THE YIELD AND ECONOMICS OF CROPS UNDER HIGH-INTENSITY MULTIPLE CROPPING SYSTEMS
Abstract Note: A field investigation was carried out at Coimbatore during June 1986-May 1988 to study the yield potential of different high-intensity multiple cropping systems with varied N levels and biofertilizers under garden land. Among the N-management practices, combined application of 100% recommended N and biofertilizer gave higher economic yields in cereals, whereas pulses and other vegetable and oilseed crops performed well at 75% recommended N level and biofertilizer application. Both these practices were found superior to application of 100% recommended N alone.
Manual Tags: search.sorghum; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 sorghum); WOS

Author: Singh, T.; Singh, P. N.
Title: Effect of integrated nutrient management on soil fertility status and productivity of sugarcane grown under sugarcane based cropping sequence.
Abstract Note: A field experiment was conducted from 1992-2000 at the Indian Institute of Sugarcane Research, Lucknow, Uttar Pradesh, India to investigate the effect of integrated use of nitrogen (N) fertilizer and different organic manures (green manure (GM; Sesbania aculeata), farmyard manure (FYM), sulfitation pressmud cake (SPMC) and sugarcane trash mulch (TM)) on the change in fertility status of sandy loam soil (Typic Ustochrept) and productivity of sugarcane (plant and ratoon) grown under sorghum-mustard-plant cane-ratoon I-ratoon II-wheat cropping sequence. Eleven treatments on integrated use of N fertilizer and different organic manures were given to sugarcane (plant and ratoons) grown under the sequence. Nitrogen fertilizer (urea) was given at 75 and 150 kg/ha and P and K fertilizers were applied as basal dose at 60 kg/ha each. FYM and SPMC at 20 t/ha each as fresh weight were ploughed-mixed uniformly into the soil 10 days before planting the sugarcane variety CoLk 8102. Trash mulching was practised only in ratoons. Results showed that application of N in plant and subsequent ratoon crops significantly increased the cane yield over control. Both doses of N fertilizer varied significantly for the effects on the yield. The integrated use of N and organic manures resulted in further increase in enhanced yield over N application. No significant effect was observed on green manuring on the yield of plant cane, similarly with the residual effect on the yield of subsequent ratoon crops. The inclusion of FYM and SPMC with N fertilizer resulted in a significant increase in yield of plant crop with residual effect on ratoon yield. After 8 years of continuous cropping and manuring, significant increase of available N and K 2O was observed in most of the treatments, except control in which the available nutrients (Fe, Mn, Zn and Cu) decreased. On comparing the final soil fertility status with the initial status, no change was recorded after 8 years of continuous cropping and manuring.
Manual Tags: search.sorghum; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 sorghum); WOS

Author: Ramalinga Swamy, K.; Raju, D.V.N.; Mallikarjuna Rao, T.K.V.V.; Padma Raju, A.
Title: Effect of integrated use of fertilizers and organic manures on soil and crop productivity under sugarcane (Saccharum officinarum) based cropping system
Abstract Note: The effect of integrated use of fertilizers (100, 50 and 0%N and full dose of P and K recommended for each crop in cycle) and organic manures [farmyard manure, sunnhemp (Crotalaria juncea L.), pressmud cake and cane trash applied to sugarcane plant crop and their' residual effect on subsequent crops] on soil fertility, physical properties besides productivity of crops grown in crop cycle, sugarcane (Saccharum officinarum L.) plant - sugarcane ratoon - gingelly (Sesamum indicum)- rice (Oryza sativa) was studied. Available nitrogen and phosphorus improved due to integrated use of fertilizers and manures at 100 and 50% nitrogen but depleted when no fertilizers and manures were applied. Though the soil available potash depleted at all levels of fertilization, the extent of depletion was lower under integrated use of fertilizers and manures. The bulk density lowered and infiltration rate, water-holding capacity improved under integrated nutrient management system. Integrated use of fertilizers (100% NPK) and organic manures (cane trash+pressmud cake) resulted in highest cane and sugar production of sugarcane plant and ratoon crop and grain yield of gingelly. However, the residual effect of farmyard manure and 100% NPK resulted in maximum production of rice. Application of 50 N+ 100% P and K. and direct and residual effects of organic manures resulted in sustainable crop production which is nearer to 100% fertilizers alone.

Author: Katti, V. S.; Sheelavantar, M. N.; Malipatil, T. B.; Bellakki, M. A.
Title: Effect of intercropping of short, medium and long duration pigeonpea ( Cajanus cajan L.) with groundnut ( Arachis hypogaea L.) on dry matter production and its accumulation in different parts.
Abstract Note: A field experiment was conducted during kharif [monsoon] 1990-91 to study the effect of intercropping of short, medium and long duration pigeonpea with groundnuts on dry matter production and distribution in both legumes. The total dry matter production per plant in groundnuts was higher with sole cropping at all growth stages. In pigeonpeas, the dry matter production in the initial stage of growth (up to 120 days) was higher under sole cropping, but after the harvest of intercropped groundnut there was a rapid increase in dry matter production of the pigeonpeas until maturity. Among different row proportions, a 5:1 row groundnut:pigeonpea ratio gave higher dry-matter production (g/plant) and accumulation in reproductive parts. Intercropping of groundnuts with short duration pigeonpea resulted in higher dry matter production.
Manual Tags: search.grain; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 grain); WOS

Author: Arunachalam, L.; Kulandaivelu, R.; Palaniappan, S.; Devashhayam, M. M.
Title: Effect of intercrops on yield attributes of sorghum ratoon.
Abstract Note: In a field experiment, plant sorghum crop was intercropped with cowpeas and in the following 2 years, a ratoon sorghum crop was intercropped with safflower, Bengal gram [ Cicer arietinum], horse gram [ Macrotyloma uniflorum], coriander or wheat or not intercropped. Intercropping decreased ratoon sorghum DM production and grain yields. The lowest reduction in grain yield was with horse gram (18.6%) and and highest with wheat (29.9%).

Author: PATEL, LK; PATEL, JC; CHANIARA, NJ; BALDHA, NM
Title: EFFECT OF IRRIGATION, NITROGEN AND PHOSPHORUS ON THE PRODUCTIVITY OF RABI RATOON SORGHUM
Abstract Note: In a field investigation at the Instructional Farm, Gujarat Agricultural University, Junagadh, during 1982-83 and 1984-85 on rabi ratoon sorghum, a significant increase in grain and straw yield was observed with increasing levels of IW/PAN-E ratio from 0.5 to 0.9. Response to N and P2O5 was recorded up to 150 and 75 kg/ha, respectively. Highest grain yield was obtained when irrigation was scheduled at 0.9 IW/PAN-E ratio in combination with 150 kg N/ha.

Author: WEHRLE, VALERIC N.; OGILVIE, L.
Title: Effect of ley grasses on the carry-over of take-all
Abstract Note: From 1950-54 a field expt. was conducted on land heavily infected with Ophiobolus graminis to test the effects on its carry-over with timothy, meadow fescue, perennial rye grass and cocksfoot. It was discovered that there was a marked increase in the amount of root infection, and a corresponding decline in yield, according to the number of years that the block had been sown to wheat. There was no difference in the amount of root infection, or in yield, due to the grasses used in the leys. || ABSTRACT AUTHORS: K. W. Loucks

Author: Chauhan, J. S.; Lopez, F. S. S.; Vergara, B. S.
Title: Effect of light intensity before and after main crop cutting on ratooning ability of rice.
Abstract Note: In pot trials, effects of reduced light intensity during the ripening period of the main rice crop and after cutting the main crop on the regeneration of ratoon plants, their yield components and grain yield were studied. The regeneration of ratoon plants was only 19 and 44% with reductions of 60 and 40% in the light intensity, resp., during main crop ripening compared with 81% regeneration of ratoon plants in the untreated control. Regeneration was decreased to 63% by a 60% reduction in the light intensity after cutting the main crop but was not adversely affected by a 40% reduction in light intensity. The low light intensity treatments had no adverse effect on yield components of the ratoon plants, but decreased grain yields by increasing the number of missing ratoon plants.

Title: EFFECT OF LIME AND FERTILIZER ON THE FERTILITY OF PEAT SOILS IN THE KARELIAN-ASSR

Author: S, CHAUHAN J.; S, LOPEZ F. S.; S, VERGARA B.
Title: EFFECT OF LOW LIGHT INTENSITY BEFORE AND AFTER MAIN CROP CUTTING ON RATOONING ABILITY OF RICE
Abstract Note: Reduced light intensity before cutting appreciably reduced regeneration of ratooned rice. Only 19% of the plants regenerated under 60% shading during ripening phase of the main crop. The regeneration was also slightly reduced under 60% shading after main crop cutting. Low light intensity before and after main crop cutting decreased ratoon grain yield through increased missing hills in the ratoon crop.

Title: Effect of main crop harvesting time on rice-ratoon and berseem clover ( Trifolium alexanderinum L.) yield as intercropping system.
Publication Title: Technical Journal of Engineering and Applied Sciences
Abstract Note: To determine the effect of main crop harvesting time on rice ratoon and berseem clover yield as intercropping system, the experiment was conducted out as split plot in randomized complete block design with three replications in Northern Iran at 2010. Main crop harvesting time of rice has been chosen as main plot at four levels; 19 and 26 August, and 2 and 9 September. The kind of cultivation has been also chosen as sub-plot at three levels; berseem clover cultivation, ratooning, and intercropping berseem clover with rice ratoon. The results showed that the total number of tillers and effective tillers per hill, the total number of spikelet per panicle and percentage of filled spikelet were significantly decreased by delaying harvesting time. The maximum grain yield and harvesting index were attained by earlier harvesting time at

Author: Rao, P. Srinivasa; Kumar, C. Ganesh; Malapaka, Jayalakshmi; Kamal, Ahmed; Reddy, Belum V. S.
Title: Effect of Micronutrient Treatments in Main and Ratoon Crops of Sweet Sorghum Cultivar ICSV 93046 Under Tropical Conditions
Abstract Note: The sweet sorghum variety, ICSV 93046 is commercially cultivated in large areas in India and the Philippines. The response of ICSV 93046 to six fertilizer treatments viz., T1 (control: 80 kg N ha(-1) and 40 kg P2O5 ha(-1)); T2 (designed fertilizer from a commercial source); T3 (N + P with Zn and B soil application); T4 (N + P with Zn and B soil application); T5 (N + P with foliar application of 0.1 % sodium borate and T6 (N + P with foliar application of 0.5 % ZnSO4 and 0.1 % sodium borate) was evaluated during the post-rainy season (December-March, 2009-2010) as main (plant) crop and during summer season (April-July, 2010) as ratoon crop. The combined ANOVA showed that there were no significant differences observed between main and ratoon crops and the treatment interactions for the qualitative and quantitative component traits of sugar yield measured and also no significant differences observed for main and ratoon crop except for non-significant numerical differences giving a trend. The stalk yield was highest for treatments

Author: Sharma, Pramod; Duveiller, Etienne; Sharma, Ram C.
Title: Effect of mineral nutrients on spot blotch severity in wheat, and associated increases in grain yield
Abstract Note: Spot blotch, caused by Cochliobolus sativus, is a serious disease of wheat (Triticum aestivum L.) in the warm lowlands of South Asia. A field study was conducted using two wheat varieties (Bhrikuti and Sonalika) during the 2001 and 2002 wheat seasons in Rampur, Nepal, to determine the effect of nitrogen, phosphorus, potassium, and chlorine fertilization on reducing spot blotch severity in wheat, and its associated increase in grain yield. Application of N alone reduced spot blotch severity by 8% in 2002. Phosphorus fertilization had no effect on spot blotch development. The balanced application of N, P, and K reduced disease severity by 15 and 22% in 2001 and 2002, respectively. Application of KCl as well as CaCl2 reduced spot blotch severity, but the former caused 11% greater reduction than the latter. The two varieties responded differently to the mineral nutrients’ effect on spot blotch severity, suggesting the nutrients’ importance in cultivar selection when considering the effect of soil fertility on susceptibility to foliar diseases. The lower disease severity and higher grain yield observed after the application of KCl compared to CaCl2 showed that KCl should be used on K-deficient soils in the warmer wheat growing regions of South Asia where spot blotch is a serious perennial wheat disease in intensive rice–wheat cropping systems.
Manual Tags: Bipolaris sorokiniana; Chlorine; Cochliobolus sativus; Foliar blight; Nitrogen; perennial W/1 (triticum OR wheat); Phosphorus; Potash; ScienceDirect; Scopus; search.wheat; Spot blotch; SPV; TITLE-ABS-KEY (perennial W/1 (triticum OR wheat)) AND DOCTYPE (ar); TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); Wheat; WOS

Author: Deka, K. C.; Bhagowati, A. K.; Baruah, U. K.
Title: Effect of monocrotophos application in rice-fish farming.
Publication Title: Journal of the Agricultural Science Society of North East India
Abstract Note: Field studies in Assam, India, in 1990-91 showed that a perennial system of integration of fish culture (5 species of carp) with rice cultivation resulted in good control of stem borers [? Scirpophaga incertulas] and case worms [ Parapoynx stagnalis] but not of rice hispa [ Dicladispa armigera] and leaf folders [ Cnaphalocrocis medinalis]. Foliar sprays of monocrotophos (Nuvacron 40 EC) applied at the rate of 1.25 kg/ha effectively controlled the pests without any apparent toxic effects on fish. No residues of monocrotophos were detected in brain, gill, liver, muscle and kidney tissues taken from fish 223 and 228 days after application. This suggested that monocrotophos at 1.25 kg/ha was safe for use in perennial rice-fish farming systems.
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: Stryczula, P.; Mozdzer, E.
Title: Effect of multi-component mineral fertilisers and organic fertilisation on the npk content and uptake by perennial rye-grass biomass
Abstract Note: A pot vegetation experiment was carried out in 2007-2008. This study aimed at determination of the interaction of organic fertilisation with selected multi-component mineral fertilisers (SuproFoska 20, Suprofos 25 and Inmarc 4 with urea addition) in the formation of some qualitative traits of perennial rye-grass. Increase in the N, P and K contents in the test plant in the control object with compost did not exceed the values which were obtained in the experimental series with mineral fertilisers without compost. The obtained results are connected with the amount of nutrients being introduced into the soil material in the form of municipal sewage sludge compost and mineral fertilisers. Municipal sewage sludge compost being introduced into the soil material ignificantly increased the uptake of nitrogen, phosphorus and potassium by the test plant when compared with the experimental series where it had not been applied. The findings show that the largest correlation occurred between the crop yield of the test plant and the N, P and K uptake. This proves that the uptake of nutrients fully depends on the crop yield.

Author: HongFei, Chen; Dong, Yang; YiYuan, Liang; ZhiXing, Zhang; KangJing, Liang; WenXiong, Lin
Title: Effect of nitrogen application strategy in the first cropping rice on dry matter accumulation, grain yield and nitrogen utilization efficiency of the first cropping rice and its ratoon rice crop.
Publication Title: Zhongguo Shengtai Nongye Xuebao / Chinese Journal of Eco-Agriculture
Abstract Note: The effect of fertilizer application strategy on nitrogen (N) and dry-matter accumulation, grain yield and N utilization efficiency (NUE) of the ratoon rice crop and its first cropping rice was determined in China by designing 3 N applied proportion between basal-tiller dressing and panicle dressing [8:2(N 1), 7:3(N 2), 6:4(N 3)] in the first cropping rice season with a constant N supply at 225.00 kg/hm 2. The results indicated that N accumulation under the N 3 treatment was 9.26 and 3.54% higher at ripening stage of the first cropping rice than that under N 1 and N 2 treatments. Transportation of N from vegetative parts to panicle during the grain-filling stage of the first cropping rice under N 3 were 21.47 and 6.76% higher than under N 1 and N 2 treatments. For the entire growth period, the net dry matter accumulation in rice under N 3 treatment increased by 5.10 and 4.78% compared to the N 1 and N 2 treatments. For grain yield of the first cropping rice, the N 3 treatment produced the highest yield (12 431 kg/hm 2), which was significantly higher than that produced by the N 1 and N 2 treatments. The N utilization efficiency of N 3 treatment was as high 46.4%, 14.81 and 5.43% higher than that under N 1 and N 2. N agronomic efficiency in the N 3 treatment was 20.66 kg/kg, 14.97 and 12.34% higher than in N 1 and N 2. Furthermore, the results showed that different N proportion between basal-tiller dressing and panicle dressing with a constant N supply (225.00 kg/hm 2) in the first cropping rice had no significant influence on the ratoon rice crop.
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: Prakash, K. S.; Prakash, B. G.
Title: Effect of nitrogen source and insect control on growth of a ratoon crop.
Abstract Note: In field experiments in 1985-86, 0 or 50 kg N/ha, 2.5 t Azolla applied 3-4 times, or Azolla + 25 kg N were applied to a rice cv. Sona Mahsuri ratoon crop in combination with 0.5 kg monocrotophos or 0.3 kg chlorpyrifos/ha. Combinations with 50 kg N/ha or Azolla + 25 kg N increased plant height, number of regenerated tillers, number of tillers per plant and number of panicles per plant. Yield ranged from 0.7 t/ha with Azolla + chlorpyrifos to 2.2 t with 50 kg N. Highest harvest index was 0.50 with 2.5 t Azolla/ha.

Author: Singh, R. S.
Title: Effect of organic and inorganic sources of nutrition on productivity of long duration pigeonpea ( Cajanus cajan (L.) Millsp).
Abstract Note: Field experiments were conducted in Uttar Pradesh, India, during the 2002-03 and 2003-04 rainy seasons, to study the effect of organic (5 t FYM, 10 t FYM, 1.0 t vermicompost and 2.0 t vermicompost/ha) and inorganic sources (50% RDF, 100% RDF, 50% RDF + 5 t FYM and 50% RDF + 1.0 t vermicompost/ha) of nutrition on growth, yield attributes, yield and nutrient uptake of pigeon pea. The results showed that the application of 50% RDF+5 t FYM/ha remained at par with 10 t FYM/ha, 100% RDF and recorded significantly taller plants (211.4 cm), maximum number of branches (38.7), dry matter/plant (167.5 g), grain yield (26.5 q/ha), stalk yield (98.4 q/ha) and uptake of N (150.8 kg/ha), P (31.9 kg/ha), K (98.7 kg/ha). Net return (Rs 32 190) was also higher with 50% RDF + 5 t FYM/ha.
Manual Tags: search.grain; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 grain); WOS

Author: N, TRIPOL'SKAYA L.
Title: EFFECT OF ORGANIC AND MINERAL FERTILIZER SYSTEMS ON THE PRODUCTIVITY OF FIELD AND GRAIN CROP ROTATIONS
Publication Title: Doklady Vsesoyuznoi Ordena Lenina i Ordena Trudovogo Krasnogo Znameni   Akademii Sel'skokhozyaistvennykh Nauk Imeni V I Lenina
Abstract Note: The effectiveness of organic, organic-mineral and mineral systems of fertilization was studied in a steady-state multiple-factor experiment with various crop rotations including potatoes, barley, annual grasses, winter wheat and perennial grasses. Advantages of the field crop rotation were elucidated on the basis of data on experiments carried out in 1980-1982. The productivity of field and grain crop rotations differed depending on fertilizers used. The effect of the precursors of crop rotation on the productivity of cereal crops was evaluated.
Manual Tags: search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); WOS

Author: Skuodiene, R.; Nekrosiene, R.
Title: Effect of perennial grasses ploughed in as green manure on the occurence of net blotch in spring barley
Abstract Note: Experiments were carried out in the Vezaiciai Branch of the Lithuanian Institute of Agriculture (West Lithuania) in 2005-2007. The aim of this research was to assess the impact of using perennial legumes (red and white clover, lucerne) and timothy as green manure in crop rotation on the occurence of net blotch disease (causal agent Drechslera teres (Sacc.) Shoem.) in spring barley. Preceding crops of spring barley were winter triticale and winter rye (perennial grasses were preceding crops of these winter cereals). The yearly occurence of net blotch disease was high: incidence was about 70.00-100.00% severity; at the spring barley booting stage (BBCH 37-39) - from 4.45 to 12.25%, at milk maturity stage (BBCH 73-75) - 43.75-70.95%. The variously-managed perennial grasses in the crop rotation had a significant effect on the occurence of net blotch: the spring barley grown after timothy was 1.1-1.5 times less affected in 2005 and 2007, compared to the spring barley grown after red and white clovers, and about 1.2 times less affected grown after lucerne, compared with spring barley grown after other grasses in 2006.
Manual Tags: search.rye; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 ("rye" OR secale) NOT "rye$grass"); WOS

Author: Singh, R. S.; Yadav, M. K.
Title: Effect of phosphorus and biofertilizers on growth, yield and nutrient uptake of long duration pigeonpea under rainfed condition.
Abstract Note: Field experiments were conducted in Varanasi, Uttar Pradesh, India, during the 2004-05 and 2005-06 rainy seasons, to study the effect of phosphorus (P) fertilizer levels (0, 15, 30, 45 and 60 kg P 2O 5/ha) and biofertilizers (untreated control, Rhizobium, PSB and Rhizobium + PSB) on growth, yield and nutrient uptake of long duration pigeon pea. Author: Singh, A.K.; Singh, R.S.
Title: Effect of phosphorus and bioinoculants on yield, nutrient uptake and economics of long duration pigeonpea (Cajanus cajan)
Abstract Note: A field experiment was conducted during kharif season of 2008-09 and 2009-10 to study the response of phos-phorus (0, 25, 50 and 75 kg P2O5/ha) and bioinoculants (control, PSB, PGPR and PSB + PGPR) on yield and yield attributes, nutrient uptake and economics of pigeonpea (Cajanus cajan L.). Application of 75 kg P2O5/ha recorded the highest grain yield (2.19 t/ha) and yield attributes, nutrient uptake, gross returns (1, 19, 858/ha), net returns (90, 500/ha) and B:C ratio (3.09), which was significantly superior over 25 kg P2O5/ha. Agronomic (AEp), recovery (REp) and physiological (PEp) efficiency was the highest with 25 kg P2O5/ha, followed by 50 and 75 kg P2O5/ha. REp was the highest with 50 kg P2O5/ha. Dual seed inoculation with PSB + PGPR produced the highest yield (2.24 t/ha) and yield attributes, nutrient uptake, gross returns (1, 22, 377/ha), net return (93, 498/ha) and B: C ratio (3.23), being significantly superior over PGPR, PSB and control. AEp and REp was the highest with PSB followed by PSB + PGPR and PGPR, while PEp was the maximum with PGPR. The available phosphorus in soil after har-vest of the crop was the highest (22.2 kg/ha) with application of 75 kg P2O5/ha.
Manual Tags: Agronomic efficiency; Bioinoculents; P balance; Phosphorus; Physiological efficiency; Recovery efficiency; Scopus; search.grain; search.pigeonpea; SPV; TITLE-ABS-KEY ("long duration" W/1 (cajanus OR "pigeon?pea" OR pigeonpea)) AND DOCTYPE (ar); TS=(perennial NEAR/1 grain); WOS

Author: LIU, Yang; DING, Yan-Feng; WANG, Qiang-Sheng; LI, Gang-Hua; XU, Jun-Xu; LIU, Zheng-Hui; WANG, Shao-Hua
Title: Effect of Plant Growth Regulators on Growth of Rice Tiller Bud and Changes of Endogenous Hormones
Abstract Note: The objectives of this study were to investigate the changes in plant hormones during tiller bud growing in rice (Oryza sativa L.) and the mechanism that underlies the effect of hormonal regulation on tiller bud growth. Rice cultivars Yangdao 6 (indica) and Nanjing 44 (japonica) were used to investigate the effects of exogenous abscisic acid (ABA, 50 mg L−1), gibberellic acid 3 (GA3, 50 mg L−1), and α-naphthalene acetic acid (NAA, 50 mg L−1) on tiller bud outgrowth and the changes of endogenous hormones. After foliar spray of the exogenous hormones, the tiller bud growth was completely inhibited in treatments of GA3 and NAA applies; but exogenous ABA application slowed down the growth rate of tiller bud. Both exogenous GA3 and NAA increased the ABA contents in tiller node and tiller bud and decreased the zeatin + zeatin riboside (Z+ZR) contents. Exogenous GA3 increased the IAA content in tiller node; besides, the variation of IAA and Z+ZR occurred earlier than that of ABA. Suggestively, these 3 endogenous hormones are closely associated with tiller bud growth, of which only IAA and Z+ZR play key roles, although ABA can affect the growth velocity of tiller bud. Exogenous hormones regulate tiller bud growth through changing the contents of endogenous ABA, IAA, and Z+ZR in rice plant.
Manual Tags: hormone; outgrowth; ratoon* W/5 (oryza OR rice); Rice; ScienceDirect; search.rice; SPV; tiller bud

Author: M, AKRAM; A, CHEEMA A.; A, AWAN M.; M, AHMAD
Title: EFFECT OF PLANTING DATE AND FERTILIZER LEVEL ON GRAIN YIELD AND PROTEIN CONTENT OF RICE
Abstract Note: The effects of planting date and fertilizer level on grain yield and protein content were studied in a double cropping (by ratooning) experiment using a rice cultivar, 'Kashmir Basmati'. Four fertilizer levels with 4 planting dates were used in these studies. A considerable variability in protein content and grain yield was observed with different fertilizer doses and date of transplanting combinations. Planting on June 8 with 45:90 (P2 O5 : N2) fertilizer gave highest grain yield (4.48 t/ha) while maximum protein content (9.7 percent) was observed in the crop planted on June 24 with same fertilizer doses.
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: Espino, L.; Way, M. O.; Pearson, R.; Nunez, M.
Title: Effect of Planting Date on Lissorhoptrus oryzophilus (Coleoptera: Curculionidae) Density-Yield Relationship on Rice in Southeastern Texas
Abstract Note: Results of planting date and insecticide efficacy experiments targeting Lissorhoptrus oryzophilus Kuschel (Coleoptera: Curculionidae) on rice, Oryza sativa L., in Southeastern Texas between 2002 and 2007 were used to determine density-yield relationships as a function of planting date. Soil core samples were collected on two dates during main crop development to estimate immature L. oryzophilus populations followed by main and ratoon crop harvests. Analysis of covariance (ANCOVA) revealed that planting date did not affect the density-main crop yield relationship during most years and that these relationships varied substantially among years. For ratoon crop yield, an effect of main crop L. oryzophilus immature infestation was detected during some years, but the real effect of these populations on ratoon crop yield remains unclear. Using estimates of yield reduction per L. oryzophilus immature, economic injury levels were calculated. Main crop yields from treated plots and first soil core sample L. oryzophilus immature populations from untreated plots were significantly higher in plots planted at recommended dates than in plots planted earlier or later. This suggests that the presence of high populations of reproductive L. oryzophilus coincides with the period when rice fields planted at optimum dates are flooded. Results from this study reinforce the importance of managing L. oryzophilus populations when planting rice at recommended dates in southeastern Texas.
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: MuYing, Li; QingHua, Shi; ZhongMing, Wang; XiaoHua, Pan; XueMing, Tan
Title: Effect of planting density on the population development and yield of II Youming 86 as Mid-season rice plus ratooning rice.
Abstract Note: The effect of transplanting density on the population development and yield on II Youming 86 as mid-season and ratooning rice in the region of double season rice was studied. The highest yield was obtained under the density of 244 300 holl/ha. As a dominant population in the main season, it was advantageous to coordinating the conflicts between the individuals and the population, and between the main season and the ratooning. The effective rate of tiller was negatively correlated with the planting density and the maximum tiller number. The maximum number and effective number of tillers increased with the planting density. The leaf area index and the planting density were positively correlated before full heading but not after full heading. The lower density was propitious to bud growth. The bud growth and xylem sap amount were positively correlated. The number of ratooning was positively correlated with the dry weight of stalk of main season subsistence. The nitrogen content of individual plant, total nitrogen amount in the population, nitrogen amount in each organ, and nitrogen consumption of 100 kg grain increased with the decrease in density in the main season.
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: Ashiono, G.B.; Ouda, J.O.; Akuja, T.E.; Kitilit, J.K.; Irungu, R.G.; Gatwiku, S.
Title: Effect of potato vines and sorghum silage on cattle milk productivity
Abstract Note: The study was conducted to evaluate the nutritive value and productivity of Sweet Potato Vines (SPV) and Sorghum Silage (SS) as feeds for dairy production in the dry highlands of Kenya during the years 2002 and 2003. Data on yield parameters of SPV and SS were collected. Both On-centre and on-farm work involved evaluation of milk production by dairy cattle fed on varying proportions of SPV with SS while demonstration and popularization of SPV and SS utilization technologies were conducted on farms. Mean grain and dry matter (DM) yields of sorghum were 5.5 and 23 t ha -1, respectively. The Dry Matter (DM), Crude Protein (CP), Neutral Detergent Fibre (NDF) and Acid Detergent Lignin (ADL) contents of SS were 308, 60.3, 622 and 61.6 g kg -1, respectively. Corresponding values of SPV were 160, 131, 341 and 64.5 g kg -1. Average daily milk yield was 3.44 l day -1 when SS alone was fed dairy cows and the yield was 26 l day -1 when a combination of SPV, SS and home made dairy meal was supplied. Improved and sustained milk production in most of the farms was observed when sorghum ratoon was fed as green chop alongside SS especially during the dry season. This showed that sorghum fed together with SPV had great potential in enhancing milk production.
Manual Tags: Dairy farms; Scopus; search.sorghum; Sorghum silage; SPV; Sweet potato vines; TITLE-ABS-KEY (ratoon* W/5 sorghum) AND DOCTYPE (ar); TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 sorghum); WOS

Author: Shevchenko, A. I.; Stepanenko, A. Ya
Title: Effect of preceding crops on N nutrition, yields and protein content in winter wheat grain under long-term application of fertilizers in sugar-beet rotations in the forest-steppe zone of the Ukrainian SSR.
Abstract Note: In long-term (40-year) trials with winter wheat given annual applications of moderate amounts of fertilizers, the highest yields (3.4-3.6 t grain/ha) resulted from application either of f.y.m. or of NPK. The best preceding crops for winter wheat were perennial grass/legume mixtures and peas; bare fallow gave slightly lower yields because of frequent lodging. The contents of protein and gluten in wheat grain were not particularly high.
Manual Tags: search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); WOS

Author: Channabasavanna, A. S.; Setty, R. A.
Title: Effect of pressmud and rice husk on growth and yield of main and ratoon crops of sugarcane (Saccharum officinarum)
Abstract Note: An experiment was conducted during 1991 and 1992 to study the effect of pressmud and rice husk on the growth and yield of main and ratoon crops of sugarcane (Saccharum officinarum L.) Increase in fertilizer dose from 250, 75 and 75 to 375, 112.5 and 112.5 kg N, P and K kg/ha respectively did nor increase the cane yield of main and ratoon crops. Incorporation of pressmud in combination with chemical fertilizers did not increase the seed yield of main crop, but its effect was seen on the succeeding ratoon crop. Cane yield with ratoon crop with application of 125% NPK (312.5, 93.7, 93.7 kg N, P and K/ha) through fertilizer + 25% NPK through rice husk was at par with 150% (375, 112.5 and 112.5 kg N, P and K/ha) through fertilizer, thus indicating the saving of chemical fertilizer by 25% in ratoon crop.
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: Rabochev, G. I.; Korobkova, O. I.
Title: Effect of quality of irrigation water on amino-acid composition of fodders.
Abstract Note: In studies at S. Karakum field station near Ashkhabad maize cv. Uzbek 100, perennial fodder sorghum [ Sorghum sudanense] and creeping lucerne [ Medicago falcata] were grown on slightly saline, not very fertile sand and irrigated with drainage water (3.5-4.0 g minerals/litre) or fresh water (0.5-1.0 g/litre). Leaves of S. sudanense irrigated with drainage water had the highest lysine content of all treatments (4.75 g/kg DM). Use of drainage water increased the CP and amino acid contents of S. sudanense leaves, stems and grain. In maize, use of drainage water for irrigation increased the CP and amino acid contents of ears, stover and leaves and particularly the content of glutamic acid in grain compared with fresh water. Maize leaves from plants irrigated with drainage water had a lysine content of 3.48% compared with 2.25% with fresh water. Irrigation with drainage water reduced the amino acid content of M. falcata.
Manual Tags: search.sorghum; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 sorghum); WOS

Author: Lindau, C.W.; Bollich, P.K.; DeLaune, R.D.
Title: Effect of rice variety on methane emission from Louisiana rice
Abstract Note: A field experiment was conducted to determine the effect local cultivars of Oryza sativa L. (rice) had on methane evolution from flooded plots. Semidwarf and tall varieties were drill-seeded into a Crowley silt loam (Typic Albaqualf) and methane fluxes were measured twice a week over the first and ratoon cropping seasons. Semidwarf varieties evolved significantly less methane over both growing seasons. Over the main cropping season, semidwarfs emitted an average 185 kg CH4 ha−1 to the atmosphere compared with 300 kg CH4 ha−1 for the tall varieties. During the ratoon sampling season, semidwarf and tall varieties evolved 540 and 830 kg CH4 ha−1, respectively. Compared with tall cultivars, semidwarfs evolved 36% less methane over both seasons.
Manual Tags: Greenhouse gas; Methane; Mitigation; Oryza sativa; ratoon* W/5 (oryza OR rice); ScienceDirect; search.rice; SPV

Author: Acharya, S.N.; Mir, Z.; Moyer, J.R.; Orshinsky, B.R.; Thomas, J.E.
Title: Effect of row spacing and seeding rate on forage yield and quality of perennial cereal rye (Secale cereale L.)
Abstract Note: Perennial cereal rye (PC rye) is being developed at Lethbridge Research Centre as a new forage crop. The first Canadian cultivar of this crop (ACE-1), tested as LRC 96-1, will have the distinction of being the first North American cultivar of PC rye and the only perennial cereal crop specifically developed for forage production. PC rye was originally developed in Germany by crossing rye (Secale cereale L.) with a perennial wild rye (Secale montanum L.) and then backcrossing the F, with Secale cereale L. while selecting for a perennial nature. In field trials, ACE-1 PC rye has produced economically viable biomass yields for 3 yr under southern Alberta growing conditions. It has similar yield and quality to barley, which is grown extensively for silage in the Canadian prairies. For proper land management and adequate forage production, ACE-1 PC rye should be seeded from mid-September to mid-October in narrow (17.5 cm) rows at a seeding rate of 80 kg ha(-1). When harvested at the soft dough stage for silage it contained less crude protein (CP) and more fibre than barley; however, in vitro gas production indicates that its dry matter (DM) digestibility will be similar to that of barley. PC rye is a valuable forage crop, but it needs to be harvested earlier than the soft dough stage to obtain comparable silage quality to barley.
Manual Tags: Acid detergent fibre; Crude protein; Digestibility; Forage yield; Neutral detergent fibre; Perennial cereal rye; Scopus; search.rye; Seed yield; SPV; TITLE-ABS-KEY (perennial W/1 ("rye" OR secale) AND NOT ("rye?grass" OR ryegrass)) AND DOCTYPE (ar); TS=(perennial NEAR/1 ("rye" OR secale) NOT "rye$grass"); WOS

Author: Singh, L. N.; Devi, K. N.
Title: Effect of seedling age, cutting height and nitrogen levels on yield and economics of ratoon paddy.
Publication Title: Journal of the Agricultural Science Society of North-East India
Abstract Note: A field experiment was conducted in Imphal, Manipur, India during April-November 1996 and 1997 to study the effects of seedling age, cutting height and nitrogen levels on the yield and economics of ratoon rice. Transplanting of 27-day-old seedlings, harvested at 30 cm height and with the application of 60 kg N/ha in ratoon rice gave the highest grain yield and it was economically sound and viable for the small-scale farmers of Manipur.

Author: Azandehi, S. M. M.; Fallah, A.; Taghizadeh, R.
Title: Effect of spraying potassium silicate and nitrogen on the physicochemical characteristics of Ratoon rice (Tarom's local variety).
Publication Title: International Journal of Agronomy and Plant Production
Abstract Note: The quality of rice is the most important issue to be considered after yield. Amylose is an important determinant of the quality and one of starch component and its linear components. To evaluate the effect of spraying potassium silicate and nitrogen on the physicochemical properties of chemical Local Tarom Ratoon, an experiment was done in 2011 at the Institute of Rice Research of Iran based on a factorial and completely randomized block design with three replications and nine combined treatments. The treatments were spraying potassium silicate and nitrogen at the levels of zero (control), three and six per thousand and in two steps away after 20 and 40 days from the harvest of main crop. Analysis of the variance showed that the effects of potassium silicate and nitrogen treatments and their interactions are not statistically significant at any level. But means comparison of treatments showed significant difference between the control and other treatment combinations; so that the increased rate of 2-3 percent for all attributes of quality properties and conversion efficiency were measured.
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: TingJie, Jiang; ZhenXie, Yi; NaiMei, Tu
Title: Effect of stubble height on ratooning properties of Pei'ai64S/E32.
Abstract Note: The effects of stubble height (10-40 cm) on the ratooning properties of rice cv. Pei'ai64S/E32 were investigated. The regeneration speed of axillary buds, total ratooning rate and yield of ratooning rice increased with increasing stubble height. Increasing stubble height resulted in an increase in plant height, but reduced the total leaf number. Under the same stubble height, the plant height, leaf number and grain number/panicle increased when the position of node descended, but the seed setting rate and 1000-grain weight of the upper node's ratooning rice were higher than those of the lower node. The highest stubble height should be reserved for ratooning cultivation of this particular genotype.
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: Larsen, K.J.; Madden, L.V.; Nault, L.R.
Title: Effect of temperature and host plant on the development of the blackfaced leafhopper
Abstract Note: Population dynamics of the blackfaced leafhopper, Graminella nigrifrons (Forbes) (Homoptera: Cicadellidae), was studied at five temperatures (18, 21, 24, 27, & 30°C) in the laboratory on seedling maize (Zea mays L.), oats (Avena sativa L.), and the perennial johnsongrass (Sorghum halepense (L.) Pers.). Effects of temperature and host plant on egg to adult mean development time, adult size and weight, and fecundity were determined. Leafhoppers on all three hosts developed fastest at the highest temperature tested (21.3 days), and slowest at the lowest temperature tested (73.2 days). The duration from first to last adult eclosion was shortest at 30°C, (11.5 days) and longest at 18°C (43 days). The sex ratio of males to females did not differ from 1:1, but males developed an average of 1.2 days faster than females on all three hosts. Mean percent development/day ranged from 1.4% at 18°C to 4.7% at 30°C. The relationship of this development rate and temperature was determined using both a linear model and a variable parameter biophysical model. Based on these models, the developmental threshold is estimated at 12-15°C. The lowest temperature yielded larger and heavier adults (312 μg, dry weight) than did the highest temperature (225 μg). Fewer leafhoppers developed on the perennial than the annuals at 30°C and fewer on the annuals than the perennial at 18°C. Our results suggest that early in the season johnsongrass and perhaps other perennials are the superior developmental hosts for this leafhopper, whereas in midsummer when temperatures are highest, annuals are the better hosts.
Manual Tags: development; fecundity; Graminella nigrifrons; host suitability; johnsongrass; Maize; Oats; Scopus; search.sorghum; SPV; TITLE-ABS-KEY (perennial W/1 sorghum) AND DOCTYPE (ar); TS=(perennial NEAR/1 sorghum); WOS

Author: FuXian, Xu; Hong, Xiong; YongChuan, Zhu; Lin, Zhang
Title: Effect of the amount of N application for bud development on the ratooning ability and in association with ratio of source to sink in mid-season hybrid rice.
Publication Title: Southwest China Journal of Agricultural Sciences
Abstract Note: Field studies were conducted in China to determine the difference of the amount of nitrogen (N) fertilizer application for bud development (NABD) among genes of mid-season hybrid rice. The effect of the amount of NABD on the ratooning ability under the amount of NABD and cut leaves and spikelet treatments was investigated using 25 mid-season hybrid rice combinations. At full heading of the main crop, there existed highly significant positive correlations between the spikelets per panicle and dry weight of leaves and stem sheath per stem, and highly significant negative correlations between the spikelets per panicle and ratio of leaves to grain and stem to grain, respectively. The more spikelets were set on per panicle, the less photosynthetic matter remained in the basic stems for ratooning rice growth at harvest of main crop. Therefore, when ratooning rice is to be cultivated with cultivars having many spikelets per panicle of the main crop, more amount of NAHD will be needed. But the effect of NABD on increasing grain yield of ratooning rice were slight when photosynthetic matter that remained in the basic stems were very high or low. The cultivars of 130-160 s,170-200 spikelets and 210-250 s were set on per panicle, their best amount of NABD were 150, 300 and 300 kg urea/hm 2. There were highly significant positive correlations between the amount of NABD for high yield of rationing rice and the spikelets per panicle of the main crop.
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: Sétamou, Mamoudou; Jiang, Nanqing; Schulthess, Fritz
Title: Effect of the host plant on the survivorship of parasitized Chilo partellus Swinhoe (Lepidoptera: Crambidae) larvae and performance of its larval parasitoid Cotesia flavipes Cameron (Hymenoptera: Braconidae)
Abstract Note: The effect of wild and cultivated gramineous hosts on the survivorship and weight of parasitized Chilo partellus larvae and on the performance of its larval parasitoid Cotesia flavipes were studied under laboratory conditions, in two experiments. In Experiment A, weight of Ch. partellus larvae offered to Co. flavipes was allowed to vary with host plant species in order to assess both the effect of weight and quality of larvae, as affected by the host plant, on the performance of the parasitoid. In Experiment B, larvae of similar weight across host plant species were selected to enable to separate the effect of weight from that of quality of the larvae. In Experiment A, the mean weight of larvae that produced cocoons varied significantly with plant species. In both experiments, the percentage of larvae producing cocoons and mean progeny size were lower and larvae died faster on wild than cultivated host plants. Immature development time of Co. flavipes tended to be higher on wild than cultivated grasses. The proportion of female progeny was highest on maize and lowest on the two sorghum species, in Experiment A, whereas in Experiment B, the sex ratio was similar between the host plant species. Similarly, egg-load of Co. flavipes offspring was highest on maize and lowest on Napier grass in Experiment A, but it did not vary significantly between host plants in Experiment B. It is suggested that in the coastal region of Kenya, perennial wild sorghum species are vital for the survival of Co. flavipes during the dry season, when superior plant hosts such as cultivated sorghum and maize are scarce.

Author: YAKHINA, R.
Title: Effect of the layer of perennial grain-leguminous grass mixtures on the subsequent crop yields
Abstract Note: Experiments conducted by the Institute of the Alma-Ata Oblast over a period of 3 years (1948-1951) have shown an increase in the yield of each of the 3 crops (hard wheat, soft wheat and corn) following the sowing of grass and grass mixtures, The best ratio of grass was 40-50% alfalfa and 60-50% grain. The highest disintegration of the root mass in lucerne and in the roots of the grass mixture is observed during the second year, during which the largest amount of nutritive matter is also found to be accumulating in the roots. In sierozem earth, when properly irrigated, and in the presence of proper agricultural methods, the restoration of fertility takes place very rapidly during the first 2 years of life of the grass. In the third year, the accumulation of the humus proceeds very slowly. || ABSTRACT AUTHORS: Transl. from Referat. Zhur. Biol. 34561, 1958, courtesy OTS-JPRS

Author: Srinivasan, K.; Purushothaman, S.
Title: Effect of time of N application of ratoon rice.
Abstract Note: In field experiments, the greatest grain and straw yield of rice cv. Bhavani and Ponni came from N given as a basal application.

Author: Nenaidenko, G. N.; Korchagin, A. A.; Sibiryakova, T. V.
Title: Effect of using malt for top-dressing on the yield of winter rye and perennial grasses
Abstract Note: The effects of fresh alcohol malt on soil and the yield of winter rye and perennial grasses were studied. On the average, during the 8 years of experiments, the use of ordinary (acid) and neutralized malt made it possible to obtain additionally 12.1-12.5 and 15.018.3 kg of grains per one ton, respectively. In experiments with perennial grasses, acid and neutralized malt increased grain yield by 72 and 78%, respectively, (ammonium nitrate - by 100%). When used for post-harvest treatment the effect of malt exceeded that of ammonium nitrate.

Author: KUDELYA, P. G.
Title: Effect of varios methods of soil cultivation on yield of annual and prennial crops.
Publication Title: Doklady Moskovskoi sel'sko-khozyaistvennoi Akademii im K. A. Timiryazeva
Abstract Note: On sod-podzolic soil, yields of spring wheat and perennial herbage were higher after moidboard plowing to 25-3o cm than after deep loosening to 25-30 cm or disking to 8-10 cm. Moldboard plowing did not decrease microbial activity.

Author: Chiduza, C.
Title: Effect of various management strategies on the ratooning ability of sorghum cultivars SV1 and SV2
Abstract Note: Experiments were carried out both in the green-house and field to assess the ratooning potential of newly released short cycle sorghum cultivars SV1 and SV2. Imposing water stress on the plant crop had no significant effect on shoot number development in the subsequent ratoon crop in the green-house experiment. However, a longer dry duration in a field experiment resulted in few tillers being produced by the ratoon crop implying that SV1 and SV2 ratoon crops could suffer from low tiller number under farmer ratooning strategy where there was a six-month dry period between plant and ratoon crops. There were no significant differences in grain yield between a direct seeded and a ratooned crop in both the green-house and field experiments indicating the potential of ratooning as a cropping system practice. Stalkorer control did not produce significantly higher yield compared to non-control in a field experiment indicating that stalk borer only became a problem with increased cycles of ratooning. Application of inorganic nitrogen to the ratoon crop produced significantly higher yield (P<0.05) compared to non-application indicating the need for improving fertility management in ratoon crops. The research concluded that inspite of potential limitations of tiller survival with SV1 and SV2 ratoon crops, farmers could ratoon these to advantage in cropping systems similar to semi-arid areas of Zimbabwe.

Author: Quddus, M. A.; Pendleton, J. W.
Title: Effect on ratoon rice of cutting height and time of nitrogen application on the main crop.
Abstract Note: The effect of main crop management practices on the performance of ratoon rice was studied during 1980-81. The crop was harvested by cutting 5 cm and 15 cm above soil surface. 2 days after harvest 40 kg N/ha was applied and fields were flooded with 2-3 cm water. Cutting ht. and N application at different main crop growth stages did not affect grain yield. Plants cut at 5 cm ht. had more healthy ratoon tillers, heavier grains and more even maturity; they matured in 74 days compared with 65 days for those cut at 15 cm.

Author: AVDONIN, N. S.; STESHKINA, V. I.
Title: Effect & residual effect of different rates of lime on alteration of soil properties, yield & quality of agricultural plants.
Abstract Note: Dolomitic dust at rates equivalent to 100%, 50% & 6% of the hydrolytic acidity was applied to derno-strongly podzolic soil in 1951, & NH 4NO 3+ super + KC1 was applied annually to all plots in the rotation. In 1960 the two higher rates decreased the actual, exchangeable & hydrolytic acidities, increased the content of absorbed bases & the percentage base saturation, increased the available-P content somewhat & decreased the contents of available Al & Mn sharply. These changes occurred in the arable & sub-arable layers to extents permitting normal growth of most agricultural crops. The lowest rate improved soil conditions only slightly in the arable layer & had very little effect on the sub-arable layer. In 1960 the two higher rates increased nitrification. All the rates still had a residual effect on crop yield in 1961. The residual effect of the intermediate rate was similar to that of the highest rate for potatoes, spring wheat, oats & turnips, but that of the highest rate was greater for winter wheat & perennial herbage, particularly clover. In 1959 the two higher rates increased clover yield in the herbage mixture 7 times & the lowest rate doubled it, whereas in 1960 the two higher rates doubled yield & the lowest rate had little effect. Liming increased the protein & carotene contents of clover hay & the sugar content of cabbage. The two higher rates decreased the vitamin-C content (dry-weight basis) of cabbage, but increased the absolute amount of vitamin C [ascorbic acid] in the plant.
Manual Tags: search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); WOS

Author: Bhattacharyya, R.; Yi, Zheng; Yongmei, Li; Li, Tang; Panomtaranichagul, M.; Peukrai, S.; Thu, Dao Chau; Cuong, Tran Huu; Toan, Truong Thi; Jankauskas, B.; Jankauskiene, G.; Fullen, M. A.; Subedi, M.; Booth, C. A.
Title: Effects of biological geotextiles on aboveground biomass production in selected agro-ecosystems
Abstract Note: Biological geotextiles have considerable potential for soil erosion control, but few studies have been completed on their effects on aboveground biomass production. Hence, field experiments were conducted to investigate the hypothesis that the use of geotextile mats would increase aboveground biomass. We investigated the crop and weed aboveground biomass at four international sites (in China, Thailand, Vietnam and Lithuania). These sites were selected due to the severity of soil erosion problems and feasibility of using biological geotextiles in highlands. In Lithuania, imported Borassus and Buriti mats and indigenous wheat straw mats were used on roadside slopes. In China, Thailand and Vietnam, both Borassus mats and other biological geotextiles were constructed using indigenous local materials (bamboo, rice straw, wheat straw and maize stalks). Results show that biomass production was similar to 6 to 53% higher in plots with biological geotextiles compared with the plots with no geotextile treatment. In Lithuania, cover of Borassus and Buriti mats during 2006-2007 increased perennial grass productivity by similar to 50 and 18%, respectively, compared with plots with no cover (5.29 Mg ha(-1)). In China, plots with contour planting covered by rice straw mats had similar to 29% higher wheat yield than the plots with no geotextile treatment (1.98 Mg ha(-1)). Likewise, rice straw, Borassus and maize stalk mat-cover on the plots with no geotextile treatment had significant effects in increasing yields of faber bristle grass (by similar to 52%) and maize by 18% and 14% in two separate experiments in China. In Thailand, results (May 2007-June 2008) showed that plots under contour planting mulched with bamboo mats had similar to 40 and 26% higher (P< 0.05) sweet corn (Zea mays) and lablab bean (La blab purpureous) yields, respectively, than plots under contour planting only. Plots under contour planting (without a geotextile cover) had 2.5 and 0.61 Mg ha(-1) of sweet corn and lablab bean grain yield production, respectively. In Vietnam, Borassus, maize stalk and bamboo mat cover on bare plots had similar to 53,47 and 35% higher soybean yields, respectively, than the plots with no geotextile treatment (6.6 Mg ha(-1)). Increased biomass in plots under biological geotextiles was due to soil and moisture conservation. Erosion rates significantly decreased by 15-20% in Lithuania and 67-98% in South-East Asia, compared with the plots with no geotextile cover. Thus, biological geotextiles significantly increased aboveground biomass production and generally contributed to decreased soil loss under diverse soil and climatic conditions.
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: Borkhataria, R.R.; Nuessly, G.S.; Pearlstine, E.; Cherry, R.H.
Title: Effects of blackbirds (Agelaius phoenicius) on stink bug (Hemiptera: Pentatomidae) populations, damage, and yield in Florida rice
Abstract Note: Blackbirds are important agricultural pests that can cause major economic losses in a variety of crops. Although birds in other agro-ecosystems may perform biological control services by controlling insect pests, the potential of blackbirds to provide these services in rice had not been evaluated. We used bird exclosures to evaluate the effects of blackbirds on stink bugs in rice and on crop damage and yields in the Everglades Agricultural Area in southern Florida. Experiments were conducted in both the main rice crop and the ratoon crop. We found no difference in the abundance of rice stink bugs (Oebalus spp.) in exclosures vs. controls, indicating that predation by birds did not reduce stink bug populations. Damage to rice by stink bugs (pecky rice) was similar between exclosures and controls, as well. However, bird damage, quantified as the percentage of panicles damaged, differed by as much as an order of magnitude in exclosures vs. controls. Mean damage estimates were 3.5% in the bird exclosures vs. 35.3% in the control for the main crop and 4.5% and 20.5%, respectively, in the exclosures and controls for the ratoon crop. Nonetheless, mean yields did not differ between exclosures and controls. Our results suggest that despite their conspicuous presence, blackbirds have little effect on stink bug populations or rice yield in Florida rice fields.
Manual Tags: Biological control; exclosures; pecky rice; Scopus; search.rice; SPV; TITLE-ABS-KEY (ratoon* W/5 (oryza OR rice)) AND DOCTYPE (ar); TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); wildlife damage control; WOS

Author: Zhang, Xingxu; Li, Chunjie; Nan, Zhibiao
Title: Effects of cadmium stress on growth and anti-oxidative systems in Achnatherum inebrians symbiotic with Neotyphodium gansuense
Abstract Note: The effects of cadmium on biomass production and growth parameters of drunken horse grass (Achnatherum inebrians) over an 8-week period were determined in a controlled-environment experiment. Changes were determined for relative water content, anti-oxidative enzymes (i.e., catalase (CAT), superoxide dismutase (SOD), peroxidase (POD), and ascorbate peroxidase (APX)) and for H2O2 content, as well as levels of proline, malondialdehyde (MDA), and chlorophylls “a” and “b” present within leaves infected with Neotyphodium gansuense vs. non-infected controls. Observations began 4 weeks after addition of CdCl2 (0, 50, 100 and 200 μM) to the nutrient solution. Under high concentrations (100 and 200 μM) of CdCl2, endophyte-infected plants produced more biomass and had higher values for plant height and tiller number compared to non-infected controls, but there was no significant difference (P > 0.05) under 0 and 50 μM CdCl2. Anti-oxidative enzyme activities, H2O2 concentration, and chlorophylls “a” and “b” levels increased, but proline and malondialdehyde content declined in the infected plants vs. non-infected plants under high (100 and 200 μM) concentrations of CdCl2. There was no significant difference (P > 0.05) under 0 and 50 μM CdCl2. Endophyte infection was concluded to be of benefit to the growth and anti-oxidative mechanisms within A. inebrians under high concentrations exposures to CdCl2.
Manual Tags: Achnatherum inebrians; Anti-oxidative enzyme; Cadmium; Endophyte; Growth; perennial W/1 (oryza OR rice); ScienceDirect; search.rice; SPV

Author: Wu, H. Q.
Title: Effects of different cultivation ways on root growth of ratooning rice.
Abstract Note: Trials on ratooning rice cv. Shanyou 63 compared planting on ridges, planting on raised beds, flat planting with alternating wide and narrow row spacing, and conventional flat planting in submerged paddy fields. Ridge planting produced a yield 21.1-36.64 kg/mu higher than in the other 3 treatments. The total yield of two crops in a year was in the order ridge planting > flat planting with wide and narrow rows > bed planting > flat planting. The transplanted plants had a survival rate of old roots and a germination rate of new roots in the order of ridge planting > bed planting > flat planting with wide and narrow rows > conventional flat planting for first crop rice and ratoon rice. At the heading stage of first crop rice, redox potential (Eh value) in the 0.220 cm soil layer was in the order ridge planting > bed planting > flat planting with wide and narrow rows > conventional flat planting. [1 mu = 0.067 ha].

Author: YouGuang, Liu; Ri, Yang; FengWu, Wei; ChangZhi, Wu; ShuHua, Wei; HanZhou, Zhang; YunQu, Wei
Title: Effects of different seeding dates on the first cropping and ratoon of super rice.
Abstract Note: In order to make full use of light resources, temperature and field in one-cropping middle rice zone, super rice variety Zhongzheyou 1 was used to study the effects of different seeding dates on the yields of the first cropping and ratoon rice. The results showed that the first cropping of rice variety Zhongzheyou 1 (sown during March, 19 to April, 8 in one cropping middle zone) could be harvested before August, 20 and ratoon could be harvested in the first ten-day of November. But the yield of super rice was the highest as sowing around March, 19 and the total yield of two cropping rice reached 14197.5 kg/ha. Therefore, it could be extended in one-cropping middle rice zone.
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: Akgün I; Tosun, M.; Taşpinar, M.; Saǧsöz, S.
Title: Effects of different seeding rates and cutting times on the forage yield and forage quality of Autotetraploid perennial rye (Secale montanum guss.)
Publication Title: Turkish Journal of Agriculture and Forestry
Abstract Note: This research was carried out in 1995-97, in Erzurum ecological conditions, in order to study the effects of different seeding rates (100, 200, 300, 400 and 500 seeds/m2) and cutting times (at shooting, boot, heading and flowering stages) on hay yield and quality. The effects of seeding rates on fresh and dry hay yields, crude protein content and crude protein yield were significant while P, Ca, Mg, K, and ash contents and tetany value were not significant, based on the research. According to cutting times, all characteristics examined showed significant differences. Delayed cuttings applied at the flowering stage reduced fresh and hay yields (compared with boot stage and heading) and quality (compared with shooting, boot stage and heading). It was concluded that autotetraploid perennial rye should be cut at the heading stage to obtain high quality hay yield, when sown in 30 cm spaced rows and 400 seeds/m2 (6.4 kg/da) under Erzurum and similar ecological conditions.
Short Title: Autotetraploid Çokyillik Çavdar (Secale montanum Guss.)'da Farkli Ekim Sikliǧi ve Bii̧m Zamaninin ot Verimi ve Kalitesi üzerine Etkisi

Author: Nakano, Hiroshi; Hattori, Ikuo; Sato, Kenzi; Morita, Satoshi
Title: Effects of double harvesting on estimated total digestible nutrient yield of forage rice
Abstract Note: We examined the effects of cultivar (Taporuri, Mohretsu, Tachiaoba, and Hinohikari) on estimated total digestible nutrient (TDN) yield of forage rice in double harvesting. The total estimated whole-plant TDN yield (i.e., of the first crop plus second crop) of Taporuri was the highest in double harvesting. In the first crop, the estimated whole-plant TDN yield of Taporuri was the highest. In the second crop, the estimated whole-plant TDN yield of Taporuri was almost the same as those of Mohretsu and Tachiaoba but higher than that of Hinohikari. We also examined the effects of cultivation method (double harvesting or single harvesting) on estimated TDN yield of forage rice. In Taporuri and Mohretsu, the total estimated whole-plant TDN yield was similar in double harvesting and single harvesting. However, in Tachiaoba and Hinohikari, it was lower in double harvesting than in single harvesting. It is important to maximize the amount of nutrition in leaf and stem rather than panicle because the grain is not digested well by cattle. In the double harvesting, the total estimated leaf blade (leaf) TDN yield of Taporuri was higher than that of Hinohikari and almost the same as those of Tachiaoba and Mohretsu. The total estimated leaf sheath plus stem (stem) TDN yield of Taporuri was the highest. In comparison of the total TDN yield of double harvesting with that of single harvesting, the total estimated leaf and stem TDN yields were higher in double harvesting than in single harvesting in all cultivars except for Hinohikari. Thus, double harvesting of Taporuri is an effective way of reducing the overall loss of nutrition from the crop.
Manual Tags: Double harvesting; Forage rice; Oryza sativa; Ratoon cropping; ratoon* W/5 (oryza OR rice); ScienceDirect; Scopus; search.rice; SPV; TITLE-ABS-KEY (ratoon* W/5 (oryza OR rice)) AND DOCTYPE (ar); Total digestible nutrients; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: GuangMing, Wang; BaoGuo, Liu; Jing, Chen; ChangFu, Ren
Title: Effects of endogenous ABA on the germination of ratooning buds in paddy rice.
Abstract Note: In a pot experiment with rice cv. Shanyou 63, the plants were fed with urea at 3 g/pot on the 25th day after heading of the main crop (25 DAH), and the changes in dry weight, peroxidase (POD) activity and endogenous abscisic acid (ABA) content in the vegetative parts, ratooning buds and spikes from heading (0 DAH) to harvest (30 DAH) were investigated using ELISA. From 0 to 20 DAH of the main crop, ABA in the plants rose steadily while POD activity and straw dry weight dropped gradually, and a sharp increase was observed in spike dry weight. Starting from 20 DAH, ABA content in the main crop and the ratooning buds drastically decreased, POD activity and straw dry weight showed a slight increase, the growth in spike dry weight slowed and the ratooning buds began to germinate. The death of ratooning buds occurred mainly during their growth after germination. N application changed ABA content and POD activity and raised the content of soluble protein in the plants, thus improving the germination and growth of the ratooning buds and promoting their survival.
