Author: Thampan, P. K.; Gopalakrishnan, Remany
Title: Nitrogen fixing trees in coconut based mixed cropping system.
Abstract Note: This paper focuses on the role of N fixing trees in coconut-based mixed cropping system in India. Some compatible N fixing trees under coconut are described, i.e. gliricidia ( Gliricidia maculata), coral tree ( Erythrina indica [ E. variegata]), agati ( Sesbania grandiflora), mangium ( Acacia mangium), subalbul ( Leucaena leucocephala), perennial pigeon pea ( Cajanus cajan) and casuarina ( Casuarina equisetifolia). By integrating N fixing trees in the coconut-based mixed cropping system, the use of chemical fertilizers could be minimized. Reduction in the use of nitrogenous fertilizers controls the emission of nitrous oxide which has ~300 times the warming capacity of carbon dioxide, the major greenhouse gas. The tree species introduced in the system will also assimilate carbon dioxide from the atmosphere and store it in the tree biomass and soil. In this way, the N fixing tree population in the system contributes to climate change mitigation besides supporting important ecosystem services. Although N fixation is impeded in fertile soils, the trees could still perform protective functions benefiting the system as a whole.
Manual Tags: search.pigeonpea; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (cajanus OR "pigeon$pea")); WOS

Author: Demidov, V. V.; Nikitishina, I. A.; Lichko, V. I.
Title: Nitrogen losses on eroded grey forest soils during snowmelt.
Abstract Note: Studies were made of the spring runoff and N losses from grey forest soils under long-term intensive agriculture on a SE facing slope of a small catchment in the Moscow region of Russia since 1985. The runoff plots were 100 * 18 m, on areas under different rotations involving grain crops and annual or perennial grain crops and annual or perennial grasses. Results showed that application of N fertilizer in the autumn increases the concentration of N-NO 3 in the spring snowmelt water by 2- to 2.5-fold. However, good husbandry with appropriate soil-protection measures can significantly reduce the N losses to insignificant levels.
Manual Tags: search.grain; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 grain); WOS

Author: SOKOLOVA, S. M.
Title: Nitrogen metabolism in ripening of perennial wheat
Publication Title: Byull Moskov Obshch Ispytat Prirody Otdel Biol
Abstract Note: Total nitrogen content, and protein, amine and amino acid N were studied. In the ripening process the total N content in the leaves decreased toward the end of vegetative growth. The maximum occurred in the tillering stage (4.25% absolute dry weight). The amount of free amine N decreased (from 5.8 mg/g dry weight to 2.15 mg at the milk stage). Free amino acid content of the leaves decreased in proportion to ripeness. In the ripe grain there was an increase in protein substances with a high molecular weight and a decrease of amino acids and peptides of low molecular weight. The maximum amount of amino acids was observed in the milk ripe stage. When the plants were fully ripe the amount decreased and arginine, glycine, glutamine, amino butyric acid, valine, proline and phenylalanine disappeared completely. With ripening the protein content decreased, and the gliadin content increased. || ABSTRACT AUTHORS: M. J. Hall
Manual Tags: search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); WOS

Author: Chu, T. M.; King, W. W.
Title: Nitrogen metabolism of sorghum plant. III. Nitrogen accumulation and remobilization of ratoon crop.
Abstract Note: Ratoon or sown crops of sorghum cv. Taichung 5 were given 0 or 200 kg N/ha. The ratoon crop grew vigorously, but after the flowering stage, its metabolic activities declined faster than those of the sown crop. This resulted in reduced N uptake. At 200 kg N, TRN [total recoverable N?] in the sown crop was 1994.46 mg/plant compared with 1819.29 mg for the ratoon crop. However, the grain yields were similar (5.18-5.39 t/ha), even though the sown crop remobilized more N from vegetative organs to the grain. With no applied N, TRN was similar in both crops, but the sown crop yielded 4.75 t grain/ha compared with 4.64 t from the ratoon crop.
Manual Tags: search.sorghum; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 sorghum); WOS

Author: Wivstad, M.
Title: Nitrogen mineralization and crop uptake of N from decomposing N-15 labelled red clover and yellow sweetclover plant fractions of different age
Abstract Note: Nitrogen mineralization from N-15 labelled red clover (Trifolium pratense L.) and yellow sweetclover (Melilotus officinalis Lam.) plant fractions of three different ages (8-, 14- and 20-week old) was studied in an out-door pot experiment during 8.5 months. Individual plant fractions (leaves/stems/roots/flowers), 23 g dry matter pot(-1) (corresponding to 7300 kg ha(-1)), were incorporated into a sandy soil. The net mineralization of N was measured as N-15 recovery in spring wheat (Triticum aestivum L.), perennial ryegrass (Lolium perenne L.) following the wheat and in the soil mineral N pool. Dry matter and N yields of the wheat crop were largest in pots receiving the legume leaf materials and the oldest root fractions. The largest amount of net N mineralized was obtained after application of sweetclover leaves, 381 mg N pot(-1) (38% of added N), and a smaller amount was measured from red clover leaves, 215 mg N pot(-1) (26% of added N). The N release was much smaller from the stems, being on average 63 mg N pot(-1) (15% of added N), with intermediate values obtained from roots, 152 mg N pot(-1) (26% of added N). The effects of age of the legume fractions on net N mineralization were more pronounced for sweetclover than for red clover materials. Greater net N release was obtained from sweetclover leaves and roots with inceasing age, but the opposite was valid for stems. At final harvest of the ryegrass, an additional 2.8% of added legume N was mineralized, compared with at wheat harvest. The net N mineralized proportion of added N was significantly related to concentrations of N and cell wall constituents in the plant material. Differences in net N mineralization estimates were generally larger between plant fractions than between materials of different age, implying that leaf proportion of the above-ground biomass is of great importance when predicting net N mineralization from green-manure plant materials. In addition, the contribution from roots to net mineralized legume N could be substantial.
Manual Tags: search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); WOS

Author: CICCARONE, ANTONIO; MALAGUTI, GINO
Title: Notas sobre la biologia y control del carbon del sorgo (Sphacelotheca sorghi (Lk.) Clinton) en Venezuela
Abstract Note: Laboratory and field tests with S. sorghi at Maracay and at Chirgua in Venezuela are reported. The plots were occasionally irrigated. Infections by S. sorghi seemed to be more serious during the dry season (spring) than during and immediately after the rainy season. Chlamydospores remained viable for almost a yr. when kept dry in the laboratory. When smutted inflorescences and stalks were left in a heap in the field the chlamydospores showed fair viability after more than 7 mos. and induced infections amounting to 25-40 % of the control. When chlamydospores were mixed with soil and left in the field, with a light cover (a wire net), they were dead after 7 mos.; without protection they died within 40 days. The presence of glumes did not affect the results; and broken seed had no influence on infection. No effect from different fertilizers was detected. At harvest the parasite was still present in the stubble; heavily infected plants did not sprout again. Infection increased in the ratoon crop and spread from a smutted plot to an originally unaffected one. 26 vars. were tested for reaction S. sorghi and also, to Cercospora sorghi, Gloeocercospora sorghi, and Helmin-thosporium turcicum. Seed produced in Venezuela was often badly infected. Various fungicides were tested for seed disinfection and gave good control of the disease. Some fungicides were tested both in laboratory cultures and in the field at concns. lower and higher than ordinary, and the effect on germination and emergence were noted. The authors stress the importance of good seed protectants to counteract the abundant microflora of tropical soils. A list is given of the principal fungi isolated from sorghum roots. || ABSTRACT AUTHORS: From auth. summ
Manual Tags: search.sorghum; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 sorghum); WOS

Author: KOVALEVA, P. G.
Title: Notes on work on the crossing of Agropyron species with wheat.
Abstract Note: The following species of Agropyron were crossed at the Bezencuk breeding station with Triticum durum, T. persicum, T. Timopheevi and T. polonicum and the soft wheats: A. intermedium, A. trichophorum, A. obtusiuscum [sic] and A. elongatum. The soft wheats were autumn forms and the hard, mainly spring forms. With all the species of Agropyron the highest percentage set was obtained from the crosses with the soft varieties and the lowest percentage in the crosses involving T. persicum. Of the Agropyron species, A. glaucum gave the lowest set when crossed with the wheats, and A. elongatum the highest. On back-crossing the hybrids from soft and hard wheats crossed with A. intermedium, to counteract the F 1sterility, the best set was obtained with soft wheat pollen, i.e. from 1.5 to 6.1%, while the corresponding figures for the hard wheats were 0.2 to 0.9%. Under the conditions at the station all Agropyron species (except the local ones) comprised winter, semi-winter and spring forms. The local types and A. elongatum were very winter-hardy and the latter species had the longest vernalization stage. The Agropyron species varied in the length of the second stage. The F 1 intergeneric hybrids were perennial forms of marked vigour. The F 1 from the crosses between autumn wheats and the local Agropyron were the most winter hardy, while the F 1 hybrids from the combination of autumn wheats with A. glaucum were the least so, the percentage that survived the winter being 65.8% for the former and 29.2% for the latter. Figures for the F 3 and F 4 generations show that, with few exceptions, crosses between spring wheats and the various Agropyron species used did not produce winter hardy forms. In 1940, 57 of the best F 4 strains superior to the standard Lutescens 1060/10 in various economic features were sown in the nursery. Some of them were perennial and showed high tillering capacity and a cultivated type of ear and grain and good threshing qualities, as well as being resistant to fungous diseases. In addition, 158 superior clones were chosen for their potential value in the breeding of perennial wheats. Hybrids between wheats and local Agropyron forms deserve attention for their drought resistance.
Manual Tags: search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); WOS

Author: Iyengar, G.A.S.; Sen, S.K.
Title: Nuclear DNA content of several wild and cultivated Oryza species
Abstract Note: Nuclear DNA content was determined for 11 wild and three cultivated Oryza species. All investigated species were diploid (2n = 24) except three, which were tetraploid (2x = 48). Measurement of nuclear DNA was done microspectrophotometrically using prophase nuclei in Feulgen stained root tip squashes. There were highly significant differences among the diploid species although the differences formed a continuous series. Three tetraploid species included in this study did not differ significantly in their DNA content. The trend in evolution of this genus seems towards increase in DNA content since the cultivated species, presumable being more advanced than the wild species, contained more DNA per nucleus than the wild species.
Manual Tags: perennial W/1 (oryza OR rice); ScienceDirect; search.rice; SPV

Author: Luo, Na; Yu, Xiaoqing; Liu, Jianxiu; Jiang, Yiwei
Title: Nucleotide diversity and linkage disequilibrium in antioxidant genes of Brachypodium distachyon
Abstract Note: Brachypodium distachyon (Brachypodium) is a powerful model system for studying cereal, bioenergy, forage, and turf grasses. Nucleotide diversity (π) and linkage disequilibrium (LD) in candidate genes involved in the antioxidative pathways in this species are not known. The average π for CAT encoding catalase, GPX encoding glutathione peroxidase, DHAR encoding dehydroascorbate reductase, MDHAR encoding monodehydroascorbate reductase, and APX ecoding ascorbate peroxidase was 0.0027 among 19 accessions contrasting for drought tolerance. The highest value of π was found in APX (0.0046) and the lowest π was in MDHAR (0.0006). The average single nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) frequency across these five genes was one SNP per 131 bp between two randomly sampled sequences for the five genes in the sequence length ranging from 1447 bp to 1701 bp. The LD decay was slow and extended to a distance of more than 1.2 kb for all genes. The neighbor-joining tree analyses of DHAR, MDHAR, and CAT generally separated accessions differing in drought tolerance. The results indicate a putative role of these candidate genes in increasing general fitness of Brachypodium.
Manual Tags: Antioxidant gene; Brachypodium distachyon; Drought stress; Linkage disequilibrium; Nucleotide diversity; perennial W/1 (oryza OR rice); ScienceDirect; search.rice; SPV

Author: Fiil, Alice; Lenk, Ingo; Petersen, Klaus; Jensen, Christian S.; Nielsen, Klaus K.; Schejbel, Britt; Andersen, Jeppe Reitan; Lübberstedt, Thomas
Title: Nucleotide diversity and linkage disequilibrium of nine genes with putative effects on flowering time in perennial ryegrass (Lolium perenne L.)
Abstract Note: Optimization of flowering is an important breeding goal in forage and turf grasses, such as perennial ryegrass (Lolium perenne L.). Nine floral control genes including Lolium perenne CONSTANS (LpCO), SISTER OF FLOWERING LOCUS T (LpSFT), TERMINAL FLOWER1 (LpTFL1), VERNALIZATION1 (LpVRN1, identical to LpMADS1) and five additional MADS-box genes, were analyzed for nucleotide diversity and linkage disequilibrium (LD). For each gene, about 1 kb genomic fragments were isolated from 10 to 20 genotypes of perennial ryegrass of diverse origin. Four to twelve haplotypes per gene were observed. On average, one single nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) was present per 127 bp between two randomly sampled sequences for the nine genes (π = 0.00790). Two MADS-box genes, LpMADS1 and LpMADS10, involved in timing of flowering showed high nucleotide diversity and rapid LD decay, whereas MADS-box genes involved in floral organ identity were found to be highly conserved and showed extended LD. For LpMADS4, LpMADS5, LpCO, LpSFT and LpTFL1, LD extended over the entire region analyzed. The results are compared to previously published results on resistance genes within the same collection of genotypes and the prospects for association mapping of floral control in perennial ryegrass are discussed.
Manual Tags: Flowering time; Linkage disequilibrium; Lolium perenne; MADS-box; Nucleotide diversity; Perennial ryegrass; perennial W/1 (oryza OR rice); ScienceDirect; search.rice; search.rye; SPV

Author: S, CHAUHAN J.; S, LOPEZ F. S.; S, VERGARA B.
Title: NUMBER OF SEEDLINGS PER HILL AND RATOONING ABILITY OF RICE ORYZA-SATIVA
Abstract Note: In a study of the effects of varying the number of seedlings in a main crop, on the plant stand and tiller regeneration of the ratoon crop, 20-day old seedlings of rice variety IR44 were transplanted at 1, 2, 4, 6 and 8 seedlings/hill. Plant stand of the ratoon crop was better, and tiller regenerated earlier in the treatments with more seedlings per hill. Four seedlings/hill resulted in the highest ratoon grain yield. Number of seedlings/hill affected mainly the number of missing hills in the ratoon crop. This effect may account for the high ratoon grain yields in the treatments with higher numbers of seedlings/hill.
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: IRVING, DW; PEAKE, JL; BREDA, VA
Title: NUTRIENT DISTRIBUTION IN 5 PERENNIAL GRAIN SPECIES EXHIBITED BY LIGHT AND SCANNING ELECTRON-MICROSCOPY
Abstract Note: The anatomy and histochemistry of mature caryopses of five perennial grains (Agropyron intermedium, A. trichophorum, Secale montanum, Hordeum bulbosum, and Tripsacum dactyloides) were studied by fluorescence and scanning electron microscopy. All five grains contain starch granules and protein in the starchy endosperm. Protein bodies, which often contain phytin inclusions, are abundant in the aleurone and embryo. Lipid deposits are primarily located in the embryo and aleurone. Caryopses of A. intermedium, A. trichophorum, S. montanum, and H. bulbosum are similar morphologically, having two populations of starch granules as well as continuous protein matrix in starchy endosperm tissue. The aleurone of Agropyron spp., T dactyloides, and S. montanum are single celled in thickness. H. bulbosum has a multiple-layered aleurone (usually three cells thick). The caryopsis of T. dactyloides is nearly spherical, and the starchy endosperm contains spherical starch granules embedded in a matrix of small protein bodies. The embryo of T. dactyloides contains starch granules.
Manual Tags: search.grain; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 grain); WOS

Author: Balasubramaniam, A.; Manickasundram, P.
Title: Nutrient management for sorghum-sorghum ratoon system.
Abstract Note: In a field experiment during the summer season at Coimbatore, Tamil Nadu, irrigated sorghum cv. Co.23 was supplied with 0 or 10 t FYM or dried biodigested slurry/ha to the sown crop and given no fertilizer; recommended NPK fertilizer to the sown and ratoon crops; 75% N + 100% P and K at the recommended fertilizer rate to both crops plus seed and soil inoculation with Azospirillum to the sown crop and only soil inoculation for the ratoon crop; and recommended N rates to both crops and P and K to sown crop only. In both crops, grain yields were over 2 t/ha more with FYM or biodigested slurry than without manure and over 3 t more in the treatments given NPK fertilizer treatments than in those given no fertilizer. Grain yields of the ratoon crops were about 300 to 600 kg higher than the sown crop in treatments given organic or mineral fertilizers.

Author: Kumaresan, M.
Title: Nutrient uptake as influenced by residual effect of green manuring and growth regulators in ratoon rice.
Abstract Note: A field experiment was conducted in Coimbatore, Tamil Nadu, India, during 1990-91 to study the nutrient (N, P and K) uptake in ratoon rice as influenced by residual effect of green manure and growth regulators. The main plot treatments consisted of rice cv. Bhavani (solid stand) without green manure ( Sesbania rostrata), rice with S. rostrata at 12.5 t/ha as basal and applied 7 days before transplanting, S. rostrata intercropped with rice and incorporated at 30, 45, and 60 days after planting (DAP). The subplot treatments (for ratoon crop) comprised no spray (control), 2% glucose spray on the 5th day after harvest of the main crop (DAHMC)+2% diammonium phosphate (DAP) spray at 30 DAP, 2% glucose spray on the 5th DAHMC+Cytozyme spray (1 ml/litre water) at 30 DAP, 2% Jaggery solution spray on the 5th DAHMC+2% DAP spray at 30 DAHMC, and 2% Jaggery solution spray on the 5th DAHMC+Cytozyme spray at

Author: Radotra, S.; Katoch, B.S.
Title: Nutritive value and utilization of perennial grasses intercropped with soybean fodder by crossbred heifers in humid-subtropics of Himachal Pradesh
Abstract Note: A study was carried out to investigate the nutritive value and utilization of hybrid sorghum and perennial grass species viz. setaria (Setaria anceps) and hybrid napier when intercropped with soybean by growing Jersey crossbred heifers. Fifteen growing crossbred heifers (JerseyxRed Sindhi) of between 7-10 months age and pre-trial average body weight of 49-50 kg were divided on the basis of weight in to three treatment groups viz. T-1-hybrid sorghum+soybean, T-2-setaria+soybean and T-3-hybrid napier+soybean in a completely randomized block design. Intercropped forages were harvested fresh, chaffed and mixed before they were offered to the heifers. Chemical composition of the herbage, dry matter intake (DMI), body weight gain and nutrient digestibility co-efficients were estimated. The herbage mixtures had crude protein (CP) content in the range of 11.87 to 13.86% and ether extract (EE) contents were 2.91 to 3.11%, respectively. The herbage mixtures were rich in minerals (ash). The gross energy (kcal/g DM) was higher in hybrid napier+soybean, while hybrid sorghum+soybean and setaria+soybean herbage mixtures had lower value for gross energy. The hybrid sorghum+soybean and setaria+soybean herbage mixtures had higher contents of NDF, ADF, cellulose, lignin and silica as compared to that of hybrid napier+soybean herbage mixture. The heifers fed hybrid napier+soybean herbage mixture had significantly (p<0.05) higher DMI g/kg W-0.75 (97.41 +/- 4.34) as compared to hybrid sorghum+soybean (88.31 +/- 2.66) and setaria+soybean (79.29 +/- 1.06) herbage mixtures. Nutrients digestibility, DCP percent, DCP intake and nitrogen balance were significantly (p<0.05) higher in the heifers fed on hybrid napier+soybean herbage mixture. There was a significant (p<0.05) difference among different herbage mixtures in TDN. The heifers on setaria+soybean herbage mixture had lower average body weight gain (g/day) than those on hybrid sorghum+soybean and hybrid napier+soybean herbage mixtures. Data obtained in this experiment demonstrated that herbage mixture of hybrid napier+soybean was better than hybrid sorghum+soybean and setaria+soybean herbage mixtures in the nutrition of growing heifers. It had highest nutritive value, batter digestibility co-efficients which showed better growth rate and higher feed efficiency. In ranking, hybrid napier+soybean herbage mixture was better followed by hybrid sorghum+soybean and setaria+soybean in nutritive value in the parameters studied. For future wasteland development program in humid-sub tropics of Himachal Pradesh hybrid napier and its intercropping with soybean is recommended for general adoption because of its better adaptability and higher nutritive value.
Manual Tags: Cattle; Chemical composition; Digestibility; DMI; Feed Efficiency; Growth Rate; Intercropping; Perennial Grasses; Scopus; search.sorghum; SPV; TITLE-ABS-KEY (perennial W/1 sorghum) AND DOCTYPE (ar); TS=(perennial NEAR/1 sorghum); WOS

Author: Myer, R.o.; Combs, G.e.; Gorbet, D.w.
Title: Nutritive value of early-planted, ratoon (regrowth), and late-planted grain sorghums for young, growing swine
Abstract Note: Grain sorghum [Sorghum bicolor (L.) Moench] is a versatile feed grain crop which can be grown in multiple-cropping systems employed in the Southeastern USA. Two trials were conducted to compare the feeding value of either high- (Ht; bird-resistant) or low-tannin (Lt; non-bird-resistant) grain sorghum from early, ratoon (regrowth), or late crops when used as the primary energy source in diets for young swine. Each trial was a 2 X 3 factorial design and each involved 144 young pigs (Sus scrota domesticus) (17 lb average initial weight). Both trials were similar but each used grain from a different cropping year. For each year, the early crops (Lt and Ht) were planted in April and harvested in August. The early crop plants were then cut back after harvest with the ratoon (regrowth) crops harvested in December. The late crops were planted in July and harvested in December. The level of grain sorghum in the diet was constant across treatments and pigs were fed the diets (0.97% lysine) for 30-d. Rate of gain, daily feed intake, and feed-to-gain ratio were measured as a means to assess comparative feed value of the grain sorghums. An indigestible marker (chromic oxide) procedure was used to determine apparent dry matter (DM) and N digestibilities of the diets. In general, crude protein and crude fiber contents and content of most amino acids, including lysine, tended to be higher and grain test weight lower for the four ratoon crops (2 hybrids, 2 yr) than for the four early- or four late-planted crops. Nutrient composition, test weight, and tannin concentration tended to vary more among the ratoon crops. Pig average daily gain was not affected (P > 0.05) by dietary grain sorghum crop type (early, ratoon, or late) or grain hybrid (Lt or Ht). Ht grain diets resulted in poorer (P < 0.01) feed-to-gain ratio and N and DM digestibilities than Lt diets. Significant interactions included hybrid X crop type X crop year (trial) (P < 0.5) for feed-to-gain ratio and DM and N digestibilities; crop type X crop year (P < 0.01) for DM digestibility; and hybrid X crop type (P < 0.05) for N digestibility. Ratoon crops, in particular Ht ratoon crops, of grain sorghum showed more evidence of year-to-year variation in feeding value for young swine than early-planted or late-planted crops.
Manual Tags: AGRICOLA; search.sorghum; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 sorghum); TX (ratoon* N5 sorghum); WOS
Automatic Tags: hybrids; nutrient content; nutritive value; regrowth; Sorghum bicolor; sowing date; swine; tannins

Author: Peña-Barragán, José M.; Ngugi, Moffatt K.; Plant, Richard E.; Six, Johan
Title: Object-based crop identification using multiple vegetation indices, textural features and crop phenology
Abstract Note: Crop identification on specific parcels and the assessment of soil management practices are important for agro-ecological studies, greenhouse gas modeling, and agrarian policy development. Traditional pixel-based analysis of remotely sensed data results in inaccurate identification of some crops due to pixel heterogeneity, mixed pixels, spectral similarity, and crop pattern variability. These problems can be overcome using object-based image analysis (OBIA) techniques, which incorporate new spectral, textural and hierarchical features after segmentation of imagery. We combined OBIA and decision tree (DT) algorithms to develop a methodology, named Object-based Crop Identification and Mapping (OCIM), for a multi-seasonal assessment of a large number of crop types and field status. In our approach, we explored several vegetation indices (VIs) and textural features derived from visible, near-infrared and short-wave infrared (SWIR) bands of ASTER satellite scenes collected during three distinct growing-season periods (mid-spring, early-summer and late-summer). OCIM was developed for 13 major crops cultivated in the agricultural area of Yolo County in California, USA. The model design was built in four different scenarios (combinations of three or two periods) by using two independent training and validation datasets and the best DTs resulted in an error rate of 9% for the three-period model and between 12 and 16% for the two-period models. Next, the selected DT was used for the thematic classification of the entire cropland area and mapping was then evaluated applying the confusion matrix method to the independent testing dataset that reported 79% overall accuracy. OCIM detected intra-class variations in most crops attributed to variability from local crop calendars, tree-orchard structures and land management operations. Spectral variables (based on VIs) contributed around 90% to the models, although textural variables were necessary to discriminate between most of the permanent crop-fields (orchards, vineyard, alfalfa and meadow). Features extracted from late-summer imagery contributed around 60% in classification model development, whereas mid-spring and early-summer imagery contributed around 30 and 10%, respectively. The Normalized Difference Vegetation Index (NDVI) was used to identify the main groups of crops based on the presence and vigor of green vegetation within the fields, contributing around 50% to the models. In addition, other VIs based on SWIR bands were also crucial to crop identification because of their potential to detect field properties like moisture, vegetation vigor, non-photosynthetic vegetation and bare soil. The OCIM method was built using interpretable rules based on physical properties of the crops studied and it was successful for object-based feature selection and crop identification.
Manual Tags: Agriculture; ASTER; Decision tree; Field-scale; OBIA; perennial W/1 (oryza OR rice); ScienceDirect; search.rice; Spectral and textural features; SPV

Author: LEEUWANGH, J.; LEUAMSANG, P.
Title: Observations on the ecology of Thaia oryzivora, a leafhopper found on rice in Thailand.
Abstract Note: Extensive damage to the leaves of rice, found in late November and early December 1965 at Bangkhen in the south of the Central Plain of Thailand, proved to be caused by Thaia oryzivora Ghauri, which had previously been recorded only as a minor pest of rice seedlings [ RAE A 51 42-43]. The injuries superficially resembled those caused by thrips but resulted only in discoloration and not in complete removal of the affected leaf tissue. Field-collected adults survived in the laboratory for up to 30 days on rice and for more than two weeks on Brachiaria mutica. The size of field populations at Bangkhen and at three localities in the north of the Central Plain, as shown by light-trap catches, varied greatly according to region, but population peaks appeared to occur between November and March in 1965-66 and between October and February in 1966-67. The greatest densities of the Cicadellid on transplanted rice (40-63 adults per sq. m.) occurred in November-December 1965 and on ratoon rice (25-49) in February-March 1966, both in Bangkhen. Density was not normally high in seedbeds, except at Chiengmai in August 1966 (10 adults per sq. m.). In observations on weeds growing in or round rice-fields, the largest numbers of adults were found on Panicum repens and Digitada corymbosa, but the characteristic damage was observed only on B. mutica and one other species. T. oryzivora has not so far proved to be of economic importance but could cause considerable damage, especially to seedlings, if present in large numbers.
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: Aslim, Belma
Title: Obtaining tetraploid perennial rye from diploid perennial rye (Secale montanum Guss.) and comparing their meiosis chromosomes
Abstract Note: Perennial rye, which has its origin in Turkey is an important plant which is used as green fodder, hay, green manure and performs a function of protection against erosion. In this study, we aimed to obtain more yielding tetraploid perennial rye from diploid perennial rye (Secale montanum Guss.) by the effects of colchicine. The analysis of meiotic chromosomes were done in both tetraploid and diploid material. In diploid perennial rye, at diakinesis and metaphase I, chromosomes were determined in the shape of 7 bivalents. At anaphase, chromosomes showed a normal segregation of 7 chromosomes to each pole in 87.61% of the cells. At the end of regular meiotic division, normal pollen grains had been produced and the fertility was found to be high. In tetraploid material at diakinesis and metaphase I, in addition to quadrivalents were found bivalents and univalent and trivalents were observed in metaphase cells. In the tetraoloid material, 39.6% of anaphase cells were found to be divided into 14 chromosomes to each pole. Because of the irregularities of the meiotic division of tetraploid plants, in comparison with the diploid plants, their fertility is lowered.
Manual Tags: search.rye; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 ("rye" OR secale) NOT "rye$grass"); WOS

Author: Sevimay, C.S.
Title: Obtaining tetraploid perennial rye from diploid perennial rye (Secale montanum Guss.) by colchicine treatment
Publication Title: Turkish Journal of Agriculture and Forestry
Abstract Note: In this study, we have examined the mitotis and meiosis chromosomes of the diploid (2n=14) perennial rye (Secale montanum Guss.) and tetraploid (2n=28) perennial rye obtained artifically by the treatment of colchicine, and some morphological characteristics of both materials have been compared by each other. at the end of the examinations, chromosome number in diploid perennial rye was determined as 2n=14. Satellites were determined on two chromosomes in each genom. the chromosome lengths have changed between 7.00 μm- 8.86 μm. Chromosome number was determined as 2n=28 in tetraploid perennial rye. in each cell. 4 chromosomes with satellite were observed. Chromosome lenghts have changed between 7.70 μm- 9.15 μm. Tetraploid perennial rye was compared as for the morphological characters. According to the measurements, tetraploid plant has reached to higher values than the diploid plants.
Short Title: Diploid çok yillik çavdardan (Secale montanum Guss.) kolkisin uygulamasiyla tetraploid çok yillik çavdarin eide edilmesi

Author: SunGye, Lee; EuySeog, Yang; JaeChoul, Lee; ChongTae, Chung; ChoulWoo, Shin; InShik, Woo; JongYeong, Pyon
Title: Occurrence of sulfonylurea-herbicide-resistant- Monochoria vaginalis Presl and its control in Chungnam region.
Abstract Note: The occurrence of a biotype of M. vaginalis resistant to sulfonylurea herbicides was confirmed in rice fields in 15 cities and counties in Chungnam region, Korea Republic. The efficacy of sulfonylurea herbicides, such as azimsulfuron, imazosulfuron and cyclosulfamuron to resistant Monochoria vaginalis, was generally poor. The resistant biotype of M. vaginalis was controlled by acetolactate synthase (ALS)-inhibiting herbicides oxadiazon, oxadiargyl, pyrazosulfuron-ethyl [pyrazosulfuron] + pyrazolate [pyrazolynate] + simetryn, and fentrazamide, followed by MCPA + bentazon [bentazone]. Oxadiazon or oxadiargyl followed by any sulfonylurea herbicide controlled M. vaginalis and perennial rice weeds. All sequential application treatments except pyriftalid + cinosulfuron followed by bentazon controlled M. vaginalis at 60 days after treatment. Pyrazosulfuron-ethyl + pyrazolate + simetryn followed by cyclosulfamuron + fentrazamide and oxadiazon followed by pyrazosulfuron-ethyl + fentrazamide were the most effective against annual and perennial weeds. Rice yield was 5.19-5.29 t/ha under pyrazosulfuron-ethyl + fentrazamide and 5.35-5.62 t/ha under all sequential application treatments except pyriftalid + cinosulfuron followed by bentazon.
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: Wale, Melaku; Jembere, Bekele; Seyoum, Emiru
Title: Occurrence of the pea aphid, Acyrthosiphon pisum (Harris) (Homoptera: Aphididae) on wild leguminous plants in West Gojam, Ethiopia.
Abstract Note: The occurrence of the pea aphid ( A. pisum) on wild annual and perennial leguminous plants was studied at 2 locations (Adet and Wondata) in West Gojam, Ethiopia in 1999/2000. Annual and perennial leguminous wild or volunteer plants were closely monitored for the presence of the pea aphid. Annual legumes, such as wild clover ( Trifolium rueppellianum) and vetch ( Vicia spp.), carried more aphid load than clover. The aphid attacked more vetch in September and clover in October. Among the perennial legumes, pigeon pea ( Cajanus cajan) was the most susceptible to attack by pea aphids and it was heavily infested and damaged in September and October. High plant density of vetch carried more aphid load than low plant density; sole stand of vetch plants suffered more damage than when mixed up with other crops or weeds suggesting the advantage of intercropping to reduce pea aphids.
Manual Tags: search.pigeonpea; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (cajanus OR "pigeon$pea")); WOS

Author: Murphy, Kevin M.; Hoagland, Lori A.; Reeves, Philip G.; Baik, Byung-Kee; Jones, Stephen S.
Title: of the annual cultivars (mu = 0.97). The significant genotype x location interaction found for TI suggests that the variation in annual precipitation positively influenced some perennial lines to express greater threshability. In addition to transferring traits important to the perennial growth habit in wheat, the wild wheatgrass species also introduced beneficial characteristics (i.e. increased protein and mineral concentration) and deleterious traits (poor threshing grain and inferior baking qualities). This research gives researchers a platform from which to direct further research and selection in the development of perennial wheat.
Abstract Note: Soil erosion due to annual cropping on highly erodible farmland is a major ecological concern in the wheat growing regions of Washington State. In response to requests from farmers, the winter wheat breeding program at Washington State University has been developing perennial wheat selected from crosses between wild wheatgrass species and commonly grown annual wheat cultivars. In 2005/06, we conducted field trials of the most promising perennial wheat breeding lines derived from interspecific crosses between tall wheatgrass (Thinopyrum elongatum) and bread wheat (Triticum aestivum). Thirty-one perennial breeding lines and two annual winter wheat cultivars; were evaluated for nutritional value in the form of grain mineral concentration, multiple baking and milling quality traits, and ease of grain threshability. The objective of this study was to identify the strengths and weaknesses of these post-harvest traits in the perennial wheat lines derived from these interspecific crosses. Mineral nutrient concentrations in the perennial lines were 44, 40, 24, 23, 32, 30 and 33% higher than the annual control cultivars for calcium, copper, iron, magnesium, manganese, phosphorus and zinc, respectively. The annual cultivars had a higher grain mineral content per unit area of land than the perennial lines, due primarily to the higher grain yields of the annual cultivars. Compared to the annual wheat cultivars, the perennial lines produced grain with smaller seed size, lower test weight and reduced flour yield, mix time and loaf volume. Protein content was 3.5-4.5% higher in the perennial lines than in the annual cultivars. The threshability index (TI) ranged from 0.63 to 0.89 in the perennials (mu = 0.75); significantly lower than the mean
Manual Tags: Agroecology; Mineral concentration; Perennial grains; Protein; Scopus; search.grain; search.wheat; Specialty crops; SPV; Threshability; TITLE-ABS-KEY (perennial W/1 grain) AND DOCTYPE (ar); TITLE-ABS-KEY (perennial W/1 (triticum OR wheat)) AND DOCTYPE (ar); TS=(perennial NEAR/1 grain); TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); Wheat; WOS; Yield

Author: OLIVA, A.
Title: Old and new varieties of wheat for the mountains for the 1951-52 season.
Abstract Note: The old mountain wheats were very resistant to the rigours of the alpine and Apennine climate but low in yield. Attempts to replace them by wheats from northern climates, or even by the Russian perennial wheats, have invariably failed. A certain number of new varieties which are perfectly adapted to the conditions in question have however now been bred, namely Est and Mont Calme, closely followed by Rieti 11, 201, Catria and Niccoli. Some of the hybrids of Est with Mont Calme, Florence, Vilmorin and Poilu are promising in particular respects such as rust resistance, earliness or hardiness.
Manual Tags: search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); WOS

Author: Anonymous
Title: Once more about distant hybridization and the wheat- Agropyron hybrids.
Abstract Note: The Scientific Council of the Institute of Grain Farming of the Non-Blackearth Belt has passed a resolution in which Cicin's distant hybridization work with cereals is defended against criticisms voiced (cf. Abst. 1518). In a commentary the editorial views are identified with those of Andreev. The resolution contains references to several new plants obtained by Cicin and his colleagues by hybridizing cultivated forms with distant wild forms. These include new perennial wheat forms, which have replaced the perennial wheat variety 34085 lacking certain economic characters; the spring wheat- Agropyron hybrid variety Flora-5 and the winter wheat- Agropyron variety 599. The latter variety is superior in yielding capacity to the Standards of the Novgorod, Leningrad, Tula and Kaluga provinces. The Agropyron-wheat hybrid varieties 22850 and 23021 have been grown commercially and given good account of themselves. Several other promising wheat- Agropyron hybrids are listed, of which the winter varieties 599 and E-2493 are resistant to lodging and smut. The hybridization work has given hybrids between Elymus and wheat, rye and barley, Agropyron x rye hybrids and the trigeneric hybrids: wheat x Agropyron x Elymus; wheat x Agropyron x rye; and wheat x rye x Elymus.
Manual Tags: search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); WOS

Author: Qiang, He; LiYun, Chen; GuoHua, Liu; Feng, Luo
Title: On correlation between physiological function of root system and ratooning ability of hybrid rice.
Abstract Note: Changes in TTC deoxidizing ability, superoxide dismutase (SOD) activity, and exudate intensity in the root systems of 10 hybrid rice combinations at the late growth stage were studied, and the relationship between these parameters and ratooning ability was investigated. Peaks of TTC deoxidizing ability and exudate intensity were observed at the booting stage. The peak activity of SOD occurred between the full heading stage and milk ripening stage. The TTC deoxidizing ability of the root system at the full heading and yellow ripening stages was highly correlated with ratooning ability. The SOD activity of the root system at the onset of heading had a highly significant negative effect on the growth of axillary buds, but the SOD activity at the full heading stage had a highly significant positive effect on the growth of axillary buds. The exudate level at the booting and heading stages showed a significant or highly significant negative correlation with ratooning ability.
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: Singh, R. A.; Rathi, P. K.; Singh, Dhananjai; Haider, Ekhlaq; Singh, S. K.
Title: On farm activities for enhancing productivity through rain water in ravines affected area of Bundelkhand, Uttar Pradesh
Abstract Note: On farm activities to manage the rain water were followed for water resources development on watershed basis in Bundelkhand. The main objective of the study was to enhance the crop productivity on ravinous land with different on farm activities based on rain water management. Twenty five check dams were constructed earlier in the entire project area on down stream of nalas. The catchment area of these nalas bunds is about 200 ha and 20 hectometer surface water is arrested in these check dams every year, which was exploited for irrigation on 190 ha land. The mini earthen store reservoir in the form of contour bunds, submergence bunds, water harvesting bundhies, land levelling & smoothening and vegetative barrier, which were earlier formed also help in harvesting the maximum rain water under dry environment. The arrested rain water and run off control have helped in improvement of ground water table, which has risen to the extent of 3.85 m over the base year. The cropping systems followed in catchments area of check dams gave system productivity as 47.94 q/ha in sesamum-pea, 42.00 q/ha in sesamum-gram, 37.52 q/ha in sesamum-mustard and 72.48 q/ha in black gram-wheat, which was higher over the farmers practices. The cultivation on contour alignment gave system productivity of sesamum-pea by 37.41 q/ha, sesamum-gram by 34.86 q/ha, sesamum-mustard by 32.89 q/ha and black gram-wheat by 54.28 q/ha. The long duration pigeon pea raised in submergence bunding gave yield of 22.00 q/ha, which was higher over farmers practices (19.50 q/ha). The cabbage and tomato yielded 255.00 q/ha and 242.00 q/ha, respectively, irrigated with recycled water in well from the water harvesting demonstration, conducted under 'Farmers Participatory Action Research programme on Water/Rain Water Harvesting'. The grain yield of pigeon pea harvested was 21.00 q/ha from the leveled field, which was higher by a margin of 1.50 q/ha or 7.70 % over farmers practices. The black gram and wheat yielded 8.50 q/ha and 47.85 q/ha, respectively, from the cropping system of black gram - wheat followed under this soil and water conservation measures.
Manual Tags: search.grain; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 grain); WOS

Author: YOLKOVA, N. P.; SMETANIN, A. P.
Title: On ratooning characters of rice cv. adapted to the Kuban' region.
Publication Title: Byulleten' Nauchno-Tekhnicheskoi Informatsii. Vsesoyuznyi   NauchnoIssledovatel'skii Institut Risa.
Abstract Note: The ratooning ability of rice plants depended on cv. and cutting height at harvest. Plants of cv. Kuban' 3 formed tillers from all nodes on stem stubbles and those of cv. Krasnodarskii 424 formed tillers from the lower nodes including tillering nodes. Plants of cv. Dubovskii 129 formed tillers mainly from the 3rd nodes on stem stubbles. In general, all tillers from the 3rd nodes produced ears. It was concluded that ratoon crops would give high yields if stubbles of the main crop were left with 2-3 stem nodes. MSM.
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: SKOSYREVA, A.
Title: On the biology of perennial wheat
Publication Title: Trudy Zonal Inst Zernovovo Khoziaistva Necherozemnoi Polosy Sssr
Abstract Note: Fertilizer expts. on plots of 200 sq. meters, replicated 3 times, gave the following dry weights for 100 two-month-old plants of perennial wheat no. 34085: unfertilized 22.06 g.; NPK 28.49 g,; peat -manure, 33.97 g.; peat-manure-NPK, 44.63g. Perennial wheat responds much more strongly to organic fertilizer than annual spring wheat because of its greater ability to form roots under these conditions. Size of mature plant and yield of grain were likewise highest with peat-manure-NPK. Growth was strongly depressed on soil made acid with H2SO4, and was best on soil made alkaline to pH 7.17 with Ca(0H)2. Plants grown in Helregel's culture solution grew slightly better with the addition of 0.04% NaCl, and were able to reach maturity and form seeds when 0.35% NaCl was added. At this concn., seedlings of the spring wheat Caesium 0111 grew very poorly and died before reaching the stage of flowering. Perennial wheat thus has potentialities as a crop adapted to saline soils. || ABSTRACT AUTHORS: G.L. Stebbins, Jr
Manual Tags: search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); WOS

Author: RADZEVENCHUK, I. F.
Title: On the carotene and xanthophyll contents in perennial rye
Abstract Note: Contents of carotene and xanthophyll in a whole plant[long dash]according to a modified method of D. I. Sapozhnikov (Experimental Botany, 1951, No. 3)[long dash]were ascertained. Before taking a test sample, a vegetative cone was prepared and examined under binocular magnifying glass. A choice of test samples was made from Septempber 23 to November 11 and from April 29 to July 11. The content of pigments and relationship of carotene to xanthophyll in Derzhavin s perennial rye was intermittently changing according to the degree of growth. Content of xanthophyll dropped sharply in the spring, while that of carotene sharply increased. From the moment of forming of tetrads of female pollen cells, a reverse picture was observed. A hypothesis is made as to the active participation of carotenoids in the metabolism. || ABSTRACT AUTHORS: Transl. from Referat. Zhur. Biol. 34226, 1958, courtesy OTS-JPRS
Manual Tags: search.rye; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 ("rye" OR secale) NOT "rye$grass"); WOS

Author: ARENS, L. E.
Title: On the history of the discovery of wild perennial rye in the North Caucasus.
Abstract Note: The species now known as Secale kuprijanovii was first reported by N. G. Petrusevic in 1870. Subsequent finds are briefly surveyed.
Manual Tags: search.rye; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 ("rye" OR secale) NOT "rye$grass"); WOS

Author: KOSHY, P. K.; SWARUP, G.
Title: On the number of generations of Heteroderacajani, the pigeon-pea cyst nematode in a year.
Abstract Note: In the laboratory, more than 9 generations of Heterodera cajani on Cajanus cajan are recorded. The pigeon-pea crop is normally of 10 months duration followed by ratooning with the result that the nematode is always provided with fresh host roots for feeding and multiplication. There is continuous emergence of larvae from egg masses as well as occurence of white and brown cysts on the roots. M.S.J.
Manual Tags: search.pigeonpea; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (cajanus OR "pigeon$pea")); WOS

Author: Hisamune, T.
Title: On the numerical relations of the sterile grains in the perennial sterile rice strains of the sterile tillers in the subsequent generations.
Abstract Note: The tillers with the fertile and sterile panicles described by Hondo were allowed to grow on into perennial plants and it was found that both continued to produce fertile and sterile panicles respectively although a few sterile grains were occasionally found in the fertile panicles and vice versa.
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: KANDELAKI, G. V.
Title: On the origin of Triticum macha Dek. et Men.
Abstract Note: The relationships between T. macha (2 n = 42), the species T. tubalicum and T. imereticum into which it has been. subdivided, and other species are discussed; their origin remains uncertain. In T. tubalicum, 5-21% of the ovules are defective and apomixis is frequent, which suggests it may be an amphidiploid. Pollination of T. palaeocolchicum (2 n = 28) by a perennial rye derived from winter rye x Secale montanum gave a set of 367 grains from 858 florets pollinated. The hybrids varied in fertility and their grains differed in size; some gave rise to segregating hybrids whereas others, mostly large and well developed grains formed on plants with low fertility, produced fertile, true-breeding plants assumed to be amphidiploids arising by pseudogamy; these resembled T. tubalicum in ear characters. Tabular data on content of trifructosan in 11 Triticum species, the amphidiploid, two rye species and Aegilops squarrosa show much higher values in rye and T. tubalicum than in other wheat species; relatively high values were found also in T. spelta, T. palaeocolchicum and the amphidiploid. It is thought probable that T. tubalicum arose from crosses of T. palaeocolchicum with a weed rye and is the earliest known Triticale; it would therefore have the genome structure AABBRR whereas T. imereticum has AABBCC [cf. XXXVI, 5991], being more closely related to the bread wheats.
Manual Tags: search.rye; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 ("rye" OR secale) NOT "rye$grass"); WOS

Author: Dolgov, B. S.
Title: On the place of fibre flax in crop rotations.
Abstract Note: In field trials in Kalinin province, in which fibre flax was grown in rotations with pea, potato, winter rye, perennial grass/legume mixtures and oat/vetch mixtures, the highest yields of fibre, 760 kg/ha, were obtained after potato. When grown after perennial mixtures, fibre flax was invaded by Agropyron repens. Disease-resistant fibre flax cultivars were not affected by diseases when grown in 2 or more consecutive years, but gave lower yields of fibre compared with those obtained after potato or pea.
Manual Tags: search.rye; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 ("rye" OR secale) NOT "rye$grass"); WOS

Author: VERUSHKINE, S. M.
Title: On the ways towards perennial wheat.
Abstract Note: Reference is made to the numerous useful qualities in the three species of Agropyrum that cross with wheat and which it would be desirable to introduce into wheat, for instance resistance to drought, cold, salty soil and various diseases, vigourous growth and lastly the perennial habit. The success of crossing depends very largely on the choice of parental strains, the success in different combinations varying from 7-10 to 90 or more per cent. The fertility of the F 1 hybrids also varies, being highest in some combinations of Triticum vulgare x A. elongatum. Thus as many as 3000 grains were obtained from seven plants of the wheat Sarrosa x A. elongatum, whilst from another T. vulgare with the same species of Agropyrum only 14, 000 grains were obtained from 2000 plants. Even different plants in the same F 1 vary in fertility. Great variations in fertility, as well as in all other characters, occur in the later generations. These, mainly obtained by back-crossing with wheat in the crosses with A. trichophorum and A. intermedium, contain less and less perennial forms, though the expression of this character varies with growth conditions, being more pronounced in the greenhouse than in the field. The later generations of the cross with A, elongatum, being largely obtained by selfing, contain many more perennial forms, sometimes up to 90 per cent, and in other ways more nearly resemble the Agropyrum parent. One constant perennial line was isolated from this cross in 1934 and is described and illustrated. It has an ear intermediate in type and small grain of the wheat type. Thus the possibility of obtaining true-breeding perennial lines from the cross has been demonstrated and it only remains now to isolate a form of higher quality. Many of the annual forms are also of exceptional interest for breeding, being distinguished by productivity, good vitreous grain, and complete resistance to rust and smut and this part of the problem can definitely be said to have been achieved. The high degree of pairing in the hybrids, where up to 21 bivalents have been observed, indicates the close relationship between the two genera. This supports the hope that the desired combinations will be attained, and suggests that the genus Agropyrum may contain the ancestors of the genus Triticum, in which case such crosses as these gain enormously in importance.
Manual Tags: search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); WOS

Author: MEISTER, G. K.
Title: On what we are working.
Abstract Note: Also Izvestija 1936: 23rd April. Reference is made to the achievements of the Saratov Breeding Station on the lines of earlier articles (Cf. "Plant Breeding Abstracts", Vol. VII, p. 116). Constant perennial rye-wheat hybrids with excellent grain quality have now been obtained, as well as crosses of Agropyrum cristatum with both wheat and rye.

Author: Cassman, K.G.; Peng, S.; Olk, D.C.; Ladha, J.K.; Reichardt, W.; Dobermann, A.; Singh, U.
Title: Opportunities for increased nitrogen-use efficiency from improved resource management in irrigated rice systems
Publication Title: Nutrient Use Efficiency in Rice Cropping Systems
Abstract Note: Research and extension work to improve nitrogen (N) management of irrigated rice has received considerable investment because yield levels presently achieved by Asian farmers depend on large amounts of N fertilizer. Most work has focused on placement, form, and timing of applied N to reduce losses from volatilization and denitrification. In contrast, less emphasis has been given to development of methods to adjust N rates in relation to the amount of N supplied by indigenous soil resources. As a result, N fertilizer recommendations are typically made for districts or regions with the implicit assumption that soil N supply is relatively uniform within these domains. Recent studies, however, document tremendous variation in soil N supply among lowland rice fields with similar soil types or in the same field over time. Despite these differences, rice farmers do not adjust applied N rates to account for the wide range in soil N supply, and the resulting imbalance contributes to low N-use efficiency. A model for calculating N-use efficiency is proposed that explicitly accounts for contributions from both indigenous and applied N to plant uptake and yield. We argue that increased N-use efficiency will depend on field-specific N management tactics that are responsive to soil N supply and plant N status. N fertilizer losses are thus considered a symptom of incongruence between N supply and crop demand rather than a driving force of N efficiency. Recent knowledge of process controls on N cycling, microbial populations, and soil organic matter (SOM) formation and decomposition in flooded soils are discussed in relation to N-use efficiency. We conclude that the intrinsic capacity of wetland rice systems to conserve N and the rapid N uptake potential of the rice plant provide opportunities for significant increases in N efficiency by improved management and monitoring of indigenous N resources, straw residues, plant N status, and N fertilizer.
Manual Tags: Cropping systems; Fertilizer management; Nitrogen accumulation; Nitrogen-use efficiency; Nutrient-use efficiency; ratoon* W/5 (oryza OR rice); Rice; ScienceDirect; search.rice; Soil organic matter; SPV

Author: Kobayashi, R.; Sato, K.; Hattori, I.
Title: Optimizing fertilizer application rate, planting density, and cutting time to maximize dry matter yield by ratoon cropping in forage rice ( Oryza sativa L.).
Abstract Note: The effects of fertilizer application rate, plant density and cutting time on the dry matter yield of forage rice cv. Sprice in double cutting cultivation were studied. Various conditions maximized the total dry matter yield and improved the yield balance between the first and second crop. These conditions are: (i) total N application rate was more than 1.8 times of that in the conventional cultivation for grain rice; (ii) planting density was 55 per m 2; and (iii) the first and second harvesting dates were a few days after heading and yellow ripening stage, respectively. Under these conditions, the risk of lodging became lower and the dry matter yield was higher than those under single cutting.
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: Kobayashi, R.; Sato, K.; Hattori, I.; Konishi, T.
Title: Optimum planting density and fertilizer application rate of forage rice under ratoon cropping in the Central Kyushu Region.
Abstract Note: Field studies were conducted in Japan to investigate the dry matter yield and nitrogen budget of ratoon-cropped forage rice on farm fields receiving 300 kg/a manure, under various combinations of planting densities (18-80 plants/m 2) and chemical fertilizer rates (conventional=1.7 kg N/a, 1.1 or 1.3 kg P 2O 5/a, 1.1 or 1.3 kg K 2O/a; high=2.6 kg N/a, 1.3 kg P 2O 5/a, 1.3 kg K 2O/a). Rice plants were transplanted using a conventional rice planter (18-27 plants/m 2), a zigzag planter (40 plants/m 2) or a zigzag planter plus manual planting (80 plants/m 2). The annual dry matter yield over two harvests was the highest at a density of 40 plants/m 2, and increased as the chemical fertilizer rate increased, exceeding 200 kg/a when climatic conditions during the cultivation period favored plant growth. This high yield (200 kg/a) was achieved by allowing plants to absorb more than 2.4 kg N/a, which required application of chemical fertilizer N equivalent to more than 2.9 times that used in conventional cultivation for grain rice, in addition to 300 kg/a manure.
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: VARENICA, E. T.; IL'CENKO, I. K.
Title: Organization of breeding and seed production in the USA.
Abstract Note: Breeding work with wheat, barley, perennial forage plants and pulses is described from a recent scientific tour of the USA.

Author: CHAUBET, N.; PHILIPPS, G.; GIGOT, C.
Title: ORGANIZATION OF THE HISTONE-H3 AND HISTONE-H4 MULTIGENIC FAMILIES IN MAIZE AND IN RELATED GENOMES

Author: Vishnu-Mittre
Title: Origins and history of agriculture in the Indian sub-continent
Abstract Note: The origin of agriculture in India is obscure. The belated Neolithic opens up with extralocal crops domesticated elsewhere. Evidence is now forthcoming of the antiquity of the Neolithic with the local crop rice but its origin remains unknown. Evidence from the Mesolithic reveals that, as elsewhere, the animal domestication had preceded the plant domestication. Howsoever uncertain the evidence is, it does indicate the possibility of the occurrence of such wild grasses which are today the forgotten cereals and are cultivated by the tribals. The extralocal crops which entered the extreme northwest of the sub-continent were diffused among diverse and contemporaneous cultures from the west to the east and subsequently from the north to Maharashtra. Rice entered the wheat-barley and/or millet-based economy from the north (Ganga Plains) to the south subsequent to the diffusion of wheat and barley, and entered the deep south during the Iron Age, during which its cultivation had expanded into the rest of the sub-continent. Both cultivation and exploitation of wild plant life went on side by side. Dolichos biflorus and Paspalum scrobiculatum appear to have been domesticated in Neolithic and post-Neolithic times.
Manual Tags: cultivated plants; history; Indian sub-continent; perennial W/1 (oryza OR rice); ScienceDirect; search.rice; SPV

Author: M, IWASAKI; I, MAEJIMA; A, SHINKAI
Title: OVER WINTERING OF RICE WAIKA VIRUS IN RICE STUBBLES
Publication Title: Annals of the Phytopathological Society of Japan
