Author: ShuangDa, Xie; XiaoMao, Zhou; Hao, Yu; ShuGuang, Zhang; HuoGen, Xiao; HuaiZhong, Fan; HanXiong, Cai; XiuHua, Xu; GuangLai, Huang
Title: Overwintering of the rice orange leaf MLO in Guangdong Province.
Abstract Note: In the epidemic region of Maoming in Guangdong, ratoon and volunteer rice plants were the most important overwintering hosts for this phytoplasma disease, with incidences of 2.37-17.78% and 1.95-16.67%, respectively. In greenhouse tests, the rice orange leaf MLO was successfully inoculated to Alopecurus aequalis by means of the leafhopper Recilia dorsalis, and back to rice again, but no diseased A. aequalis plants were found in the field. R. dorsalis was the only insect vector of this phytoplasma. Infective adults and nymphs were found during the winter. In Maoming the leafhoppers multiplied in the winter and both nymphs and adults readily acquired and transmitted the MLO. Infected rice plants survived in the field during the winter, but some died quickly at low temp. Lab. tests showed that infective adult leafhoppers survived for 105-125 d. It is suggested that infective R. dorsalis surviving the winter may provide primary inoculum of the orange leaf MLO in the following season.
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: Sukhani, T. R.; Dotwani, M. G.
Title: Ovipositional preference and damage of sorghum shootfly in different stages of tillers of ratoon crop.
Manual Tags: search.sorghum; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 sorghum); WOS

Author: Beuzelin, J.M.; Wilson, L.T.; Showler, A.T.; Mészáros, A.; Wilson, B.E.; Way, M.O.; Reagan, T.E.
Title: Oviposition and larval development of a stem borer, Eoreuma loftini, On rice and non-crop grass hosts
Abstract Note: A greenhouse study compared oviposition preference and larval development duration of a stem borer, Eoreuma loftini (Dyar) (Lepidoptera: Crambidae), on rice, Oryza sativa L. cv Cocodrie (Poaceae), and four primary non-crop hosts of Texas Gulf Coast rice agroecosystems. Rice and two perennials, johnsongrass, Sorghum halepense (L.) Pers., and vaseygrass, Paspalum urvillei Steud. (both Poaceae), were assessed at three phenological stages. Two spring annuals, brome, Bromus spec., and ryegrass, Lolium spec. (both Poaceae), were assessed at two phenological stages. Phenological stages represented the diversity of plant development stages E. loftini may encounter. Plant fresh biomass, dry biomass, and sum of tiller heights were used as measures of plant availability. Accounting for plant availability, rice was preferred over non-crop hosts, and intermediate and older plants were preferred over young plants. Johnsongrass and vaseygrass were 32-60% as preferred as rice when considering the most preferred phenological stages of each host. Brome and ryegrass received few or no eggs, respectively. Eoreuma loftini larval development (in degree days above developmental threshold temperatures) was fastest on rice and slowest on johnsongrass and vaseygrass. Development duration was only retarded by plant stage on young rice plants. Foliar and stem free amino acid concentrations were determined to help provide insights on the mechanisms of E. loftini oviposition preference and developmental performance.
Manual Tags: Crambidae; Free amino acids; Larval developmental performance; Lepidoptera; Oryza sativa; Oviposition preference; Poaceae; Scopus; search.rice; search.sorghum; SPV; TITLE-ABS-KEY (perennial W/1 sorghum) AND DOCTYPE (ar); TS=(perennial NEAR/1 sorghum); WOS

Author: Liu, Xiang; Chen, Meiqian; Yu, Dong
Title: Oxygen enriched co-combustion characteristics of herbaceous biomass and bituminous coal
Abstract Note: Abstract The oxy-fuel co-combustion behavior of two different herbaceous biomass species (beetroot and switchgrass) with bituminous coal was investigated by thermal gravimetric analysis (40 °C/min). The effects of sample kinds, oxygen concentrations and blend ratios on the co-combustion characteristics were obtained. The results showed that the incorporation of the beetroot or switchgrass could improve the combustion characteristics of the bituminous coal. The ignition temperatures (Ti) of the blends were very close to the pure beetroot and switchgrass. The Ti values of the pure beetroot and beetroot/coal blends were lower than those of the pure switchgrass and switchgrass/coal blends. The Ti values and Tb values of blends and their parent samples decreased with increasing the oxygen concentration. The comprehensive performance indices of blends and their parent samples increased with increasing the oxygen concentration. A significant interaction was detected between the bituminous coal and the beetroot or switchgrass during the oxy-fuel co-combustion.
Manual Tags: Biomass; Blending ratio; Chinese bituminous coal; Co-combustion; Oxygen concentration; perennial W/1 (oryza OR rice); ScienceDirect; search.rice; SPV

Author: Q, CHU; Z, ZHANG
Title: PACHYTENE ANALYSIS ON CHINESE DONG-XIANG WILD RICE AND ITS AFFINITY WITH CULTIVATED RICE
Abstract Note: Chinese Dong Xiang wild rice is perennial, rhizomatous and its growth habits are either erect or spreading. Genetic differentiation was found in the wild population. The morphological characters of Dong Xiang wild rice suggest that it is an ecogeographic race of Oryza sativa var. spontanea. Cytological observation on the root tips confirms that the chromosome number is 2n = 24. Chromosomal behavior of the pollen mother cells [PMC] at meiosis is normal. Pachytene analysis revealed that this wild rice has 3 median, 8 submedian and 1 subtelocentric chromosomes. Chromosome VIII is attached to the nuclear body. The absolute length of chromosome complement ranges 64.4-18.7 .mu.. Pollen fertility and chromosome pairing are normal when it is crossed with cultivated varieties. The genome may be designated AA.
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: PRASHAR, C. R. K.
Title: Paddy ratoons.
Abstract Note: In both the rice varieties IR5 and IR8, ratoon yield increased as cutting height of the main crop decreased. When both were cut at ground level, IR8 significantly outyielded IR5 owing to more profuse tillering. (Inst. Agric. Res., Addis Ababa, Ethiopia).
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: Mathew, G.; Alexander, D.; Dev, V. P. S.
Title: Paddy - some promising ratooners.
Abstract Note: In a field study in 1989-90 at Pattambi, 15 rice cultivars were tested for ratooning ability. Of these, 8 showed potential for ratooning, producing ratoon grain yields in the range 621 to 1523 kg/ha. The longest duration (151 d) cultivars IET9862, IET9215, IET9573 and IET9190 produced the highest yields of >1000 kg.
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: Nikitin, V. V.; Voskoboeva, P. I.
Title: Panicum antidotale, a promising fodder plant for southern Middle Asia.
Publication Title: Byulleten' Vsesoyuznogo Ordena Lenina i Ordena Druzhby Narodov   Nauchno-Issledovatel'skogo Instituta Rastenievodstva imeni N.I. Vavilova
Abstract Note: In field trials in 1959-63 in Turkmen SSR, irrigated P. antidotale yielded 46.73 t fresh fodder/ha year. In another trial it yielded 12.68, 20.18, 20.22 and 7.43 t in the 1st-4th cuts, respectively, or 60.51 t/year, although lower and higher yields ranging from 37 to 75 t/ha were also recorded; it was usually outyielded by perennial sorghums. In Turkmen SSR, P. antidotale showed high tolerance to summer heat and reasonable tolerance to soil salinity, and survived heavy frosts of -20 to -25 deg C. Germination and early growth were slow but the plants grew fast at later stages, attained a height of 90-180 cm, and flowered 31-61 days after emergence or the beginning of spring growth.
Manual Tags: search.sorghum; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 sorghum); WOS

Author: Asokaraja, N.; Ramiah, S.
Title: Parallel and relay intercropping in rainfed redgram on growth and yield.
Abstract Note: The effects of intercropping and relay intercropping (reintercropping after harvesting the first intercrops) of several crops in redgram [ Cajanus cajan] on total seed/grain production and net returns were studied. C. cajan intercropped with sorghum and then with ratoon sorghum gave the highest net returns, followed by C. cajan intercropped with green gram [ Vigna radiata] and relay intercropped with wheat. C. cajan in pure stands gave the lowest net returns. Data on yields of different intercropping systems are given.
Manual Tags: search.sorghum; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 sorghum); WOS

Author: SAMONTE, Stanley Omar PB.; TABIEN, Rodante E.; WILSON, Lloyd T.
Title: Parental Selection in Rice Cultivar Improvement
Abstract Note: The evaluation of rice (Oryza sativa L.) cultivars assists breeders in identifying useful trait relationships and in selecting parents as donors of specific traits. This study was conducted to compare long-grain rice cultivars using genotype × trait (GT) biplot analysis and determine potential donors of traits related to grain yield and quality. Seventeen cultivars in the 2005 and 2006 Uniform Regional Rice Nursery in Beaumont, Texas, USA were analyzed for 20 traits using GT biplot analysis. The GT biplots showed the diversity among cultivars with regards to yield-related traits. Cultivars recommended as donor parents were: Trenasse, Spring, Presidio, and Cocodrie for high grain yield and head rice rate; Trenasse and Presidio for semi-dwarfness; Banks for tall plant height; Wells for high flag leaf area, panicle weight, and number and mass of filled grains per panicle; Hidalgo for high tiller density; Francis for high number of spikelets per panicle; Spring and Trenasse for short flowering duration; Cheniere for more days to heading and maturity and Spring for less days; and Spring and Hidalgo for high grain weight. Breeders can use these cultivars with specific traits to increase grain yield and quality.
Manual Tags: Diversity; genotype × trait biplot analysis; grain quality; Grain yield; parental selection; ratoon* W/5 (oryza OR rice); Rice; ScienceDirect; search.rice; SPV

Author: Newaj, R.; Roy, R. D.; Bisaria, A. K.
Title: Partial of alley cropping systems with perennial pigeonpea (Cajanus cajan) under rainfed condition
Abstract Note: Four varieties of perennial pigeonpea [Cajanus cajan (L.) Millsp.] were tested in a field experiment under sole and alley cropping systems at Jhansi, during 1991-93. Growth performance of pigeonpea was better with groundnut (Arachis hypogaea L.) than in association with sorghum [Sorghum bicolor (L.) Moench]. The fast and profuse growth of pigeonpea was observed after first cropping. Pigeonpea in association with groundnut gave 33.9 and 64.9% higher yield in pigeonpea equivalent from perennial pigeonpea + sorghum combinations during 1991-92 and 1992-93 respectively. Sole crop of sorghum produced highest dry matter (11.94 and 11.93 tonnes/ha during 1991-92 and 1992-93 respectively), Followed by perennial pigeonpea + sorghum systems. The yield advantages due to alley systems increased during the second year compared with first year and maximum yield advantages were (LER 1.42 to 1.84) recorded in perennial pigeonpea + groundnut systems compared with perennial pigeonpea + sorghum (LER 1.20 to 1.42) systems. The yield of sorghum and groundnut was poorer in adjacent nt to pigeonpea hedge row than in the centre of alleys.
Manual Tags: search.pigeonpea; search.sorghum; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (cajanus OR "pigeon$pea")); TS=(perennial NEAR/1 sorghum); WOS

Author: EDWARDS, D. C.
Title: Pasture and fodder grasses of Kenya.
Abstract Note: The merits of the following grasses for use in various parts of the country are recorded: Pennisetum clandestinum, Chloris gayana, Bothriochloa insculpta, Cynodon spp., Cenchrus ciliaris, Brachiaria spp., Melinis minutiflora and Paspalum dilatatum. Study has also been made of legumes suitable for sowing in mixture with grasses. The best results have been obtained from lucerne varieties in mixture with Rhodes grass and Bothriochloa insculpta. Grazing experiments have demonstrated that the proportion of the indigenous clover ( Trifolium Johnstonii) of the Kikuyu-grass areas is controlled by the grazing practised. Work on breeding a pasture type of lucerne has been in progress for some years. Grasses which supply green fodder and silage are Pennisetum purpureum, Hyparrhenia rufa, Echinochloa sp. and perennial Kavirondo Sorghum sp.-M.H.
Manual Tags: search.sorghum; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 sorghum); WOS

Author: RENSBURG, H. J. VAN
Title: Pasture research.
Abstract Note: Feeding values, p. 24. Values of crude-protein content, ether extract, crude-fibre content, N-free extract and ash were obtained for the following fodder-crops and weeds: velvet beans [ Stizolobium sp.] dry leaves, seeds and green regrowth; maize cob-covers, leaves and stalks; sorghum leaves, stalks and ratoon shoots; Rhodes grass [ Chloris gayana], 3rd cut; star grass [ Cynodon sp], young growth (6 in.) and 3rd cut (8 in.); elephant grass [Pennisetum purpureum]at 18 in. and 8 ft. high; Russian comfrey [ Symphytum peregrinum]; lucerne, flowering; Astrochlaena sp. at seeding stage; Ipomoea sp. at seeding stage; Setaria splendida at 15 in. and 4 ft. high; S. sphacelata, 3rd cut; Panicum maximum, 3rd cut. Grass silage was also analysed.-A.M.H.
Manual Tags: search.sorghum; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 sorghum); WOS

Author: SWYNNERTON, R. J. M.
Title: Pasture research at Kitale.
Publication Title: Report of the Department of Agriculture
Abstract Note: In a comparison of grass species under both clipping and grazing treatments, molasses grass [ Melinis minutiflora], the Chepararia, Mbarara, Mpwapwa and Endebess strains of Rhodes grass [ Chloris gayana], and Panicum coloratum were the best yielders. In a dry season, Glycine javanica sown with grasses such as Panicum maximum gave good, dry-season (late) pastures. Rows between Guinea grass varieties [ P. maximum] could be up to 8 ft apart without loss of yield. The elephant grass [ Pennisetum purpureum] var. Gold Coast and French Cameroons were the best for dry-season grazing under Kitale conditions. In a comparison of the silage yield from the first cut of 6 forage spp., maize and velvet sorghum significantly outyielded perennial Kavirondo sorghum, Sudan grass [ S. sudanense], Columbus grass [ S. almum] and oats. The yield of grain in a maize test-crop following mixed grass/clover leys was significantly increased by the residuum of the gypsum applied to the leys.-S.M.J.
Manual Tags: search.sorghum; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 sorghum); WOS

Author: BISHOP, A. H.
Title: Pasture utilization and wool production.
Abstract Note: This experiment, which is continuing, examines the extent to which wool production can be increased by raising stocking rate, and the influence of grazing management and fodder conservation on wool production per animal and per acre. Fifty-two groups of 12 wethers are confined year round on pastures of perennial rye and subterranean clover. Stocking rates used were 4, 6, 8, 10 sheep per acre; the levels of hay consumption are nil, 1 1/2 per cent., 3 per cent. and 4 1/2 per cent. of the area for each sheep per acre, which equals 0.015, 0.030, and 0.045 acres per sheep. Provisional conclusions are: (1) stocking rate has a potent influence on the output of animal production from improved pastures. The efficient utilization by sheep of this increased pasture material offers the opportunity of increasing the quantity of saleable products; (2) wool production per sheep declines as stocking rate rises, at 4 sheep per acre, average wool per sheep was 11.3 Ibs., and at 12 sheep per acre, 7.8 Ibs. ; (3) there is strong response to fodder conservation at all rates and management systems, and this is almost invariably greatest at the medium level of fodder conservation, C.H.C.
Manual Tags: search.rye; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 ("rye" OR secale) NOT "rye$grass"); WOS

Author: Prakash, K. S.; Prakash, B. G.
Title: Path analysis in ratoon rice.
Abstract Note: Analysis of data on several yield components from 23 diverse genotypes grown as main and ratoon crops identified main crop grain yield, number of regenerated tillers and number of panicles/ratooned plant as suitable criteria for selecting genotypes with good ratoon yield.
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: MARYUSHKINA, VY
Title: PECULIARITIES OF COMMON RAGWEED (AMBROSIA-ARTEMISIIFOLIA L) STRATEGY
Abstract Note: The strategy of common ragweed (Ambrosia artemisiifolia L.) has been analysed by comparing its position in five phytocenoses of the steppe zone of the Ukraine: weedy-fallow, agrocenoses of sunflower (Helianthus annuus L.), wheat (Triticum aestivum L.), perennial grass mixture (Bromus inermis Medicago sativa + Onobrychis viciifolia) and a pasture community. Data were processed by direct gradient analysis along the axis of the foliar cover of common ragweed. An experiment was conducted in a freshly ploughed abandoned field with and without the manual removal of the common ragweed seedlings. Such removal imitated seedling extermination by the ragweed leaf beetle (Zygogramma suturalis F., Coleoptera, Chryzomelidae). The influence of common ragweed on the rate of progressive abandoned field succession was studied. If the foliar cover of common ragweed is high (greater-than-or-equal-to 30%), then it suppresses the local weed species in annual crop and weedy-fallow communities. Common ragweed is suppressed by perennial grasses in a perennial grass mixture and in pasture communities. Common ragweed strongly inhibits progressive succession by suppressing both annual and perennial species, and thus decreasing the species diversity of communities. Thus, during spontaneous introduction under the break of consortive relations, a peculiar 'drift' of common ragweed from the R-strategy towards the K-strategy occurs. Adventization of communities under anthropogenic action may be decreased by limiting introduction from other regions. Conversely, phytocenotic control of ragweed numbers by creating artificial phytocenoses of perennial grasses is appropriate for areas of adventitious species distribution. Reintroduction of local natural species, as well as increasing the number of reserves for the preservation of groups of these plants, are also expedient for increasing the buffer properties of anthropogenically controlled landscapes.
Manual Tags: search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); WOS

Author: Pospelova, L. S.; Komarov, N. M.; Polovyanova, L. V.
Title: Perennial and annual rye - valuable fodder crops.
Abstract Note: Information is reviewed on the development since 1965 of perennial rye ( Secale * derzhavinii) cultivars in the Stavropol' region, southern Russia. Data (1984-86) are tabulated on protein, lysine and 5-alkylresorcinols contents in perennial rye cultivars Derzhavinskaya 29, P-1D, P-2D, P-5 and P-9. Data (1996-98) are also tabulated on yield of annual fodder rye cultivars Ramira 98 and Zarechenskaya zelenoukosnaya.
Manual Tags: search.rye; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 ("rye" OR secale) NOT "rye$grass"); WOS

Author: Hayes, R.C.; Newell, M.T.; DeHaan, L.R.; Murphy, K.M.; Crane, S.; Norton, M.R.; Wade, L.J.; Newberry, M.; Fahim, M.; Jones, S.S.; Cox, T.S.; Larkin, P.J.
Title: Perennial cereal crops: An initial evaluation of wheat derivatives
Abstract Note: This study evaluated over 150 wheat × wheatgrass derivatives in a series of field experiments. The objective was to assess their capacity to regrow post-harvest and yield grain over successive years, and thereby identify characteristics common to the surviving breeding lines. Over the 3-year experimental period 61% of the 176 experimental entries demonstrated some capacity for post-harvest regrowth. Of 125 entries planted in the first two years of experimentation, 34% persisted to produce a second grain harvest in year 2. Three entries from 73 planted in 2008 persisted to produce grain in 3 successive years. In a subset of 87 entries that underwent cytogenetic analysis there was an association between regrowth ability and the presence of at least one whole genome equivalent (14 chromosomes) from the perennial donor species. If the wheat parent was a hexaploid (2n = 42), an entry required at least 56 chromosomes to achieve any substantial post-harvest regrowth. However, the presence of 56 chromosomes was no guarantee of a capacity to survive post-harvest. The morphology of the hybrid germplasm was highly variable for every trait assessed including grain yield, grain size, grain quality, harvest index, tiller height and head morphology; reflective of the diversity of pedigrees. Narrower kernels appeared to be associated with higher grain protein concentrations. Unextractable polymeric protein (UPP) correlates with rheological properties of the doughs; some of the experimental entries had very low UPP; the majority had high UPP suggesting useful flour, dough and baking properties. A high level of disease resistance was observed in the subset of entries tested for leaf, stem and stripe rust as well as wheat streak mosaic virus, indicating that further development of hybrid germplasm would be unlikely to pose an unacceptable disease threat to conventional cereal crops, particularly where amphiploids were deployed. The variability of the cohort and the presence of entries with desirable agronomic and grain quality attributes suggested a potential to breed and select for perennial wheat derivatives with commercially desirable characteristics.
Manual Tags: AGRICOLA; Intermediate wheatgrass; perennial W/1 (triticum OR wheat); Perennial wheat; ScienceDirect; Scopus; search.wheat; SPV; Tall wheatgrass; Thinopyrum elongatum; Thinopyrum intermedium; Thinopyrum ponticum; TITLE-ABS-KEY (perennial W/1 (triticum OR wheat)) AND DOCTYPE (ar); TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); TX (perennial N1 (triticum OR wheat)); WOS

Author: Acharya, S. N.
Title: Perennial cereal rye: a profile of traditional research in developing a new crop.
Abstract Note: Perennial Cereal Rye (PC Rye) is being developed at Lethbridge Research Centre (L.R.C.), Alberta, Canada as a new forage crop. The first Canadian cultivar of this crop (AC E-1), tested as LRC 96-1, was released in 2001 to a seed company for multiplication and distribution. Seed for commercial forage production is expected to be available in 2003. AC E-1 will have the distinction of being the first North American cultivar of PC Rye and the only perennial cereal crop specifically developed for forage production. PC Rye was originally developed in Germany by crossing Rye ( Secale cereale) with a Perennial Wild Rye ( Secale montanum). AC E-1 PC Rye has survived and produced economic amounts of biomass for four years under southern Alberta growing conditions. It has the ability to produce an amount and quality of silage similar to barley, which is grown extensively in the Canadian prairies for the purpose. Grazing studies with AC E-1 have shown that the crop can be used for grazing during its early stages of growth with good results. However, it produces less seed than the fall rye cultivars grown in the area and the seed heads are susceptible to ergot infection. Its poor seed yield and susceptibility to ergot may be due to a high proportion of sterile seed heads, the main drawback of this cultivar. Although ergot susceptibility is not a major concern for a silage crop, research at Lethbridge is directed towards improving seed head fertility of this crop, which will have a positive impact on its seed yield. This review deals with the historical background of this crop, present status, and our efforts to improve it.

Author: DeHaan, L. R.; Van Tassel, D. L.; Cox, T. S.
Title: Perennial grain crops: A synthesis of ecology and plant breeding
Abstract Note: Perennial grain crops would address many agricultural problems, including soil erosion, nutrient loss and pesticide contamination. Doubts about the possibility of perennial grain crops rest upon two assumptions: (1) that the relationship between yield and longevity is a fixed function that cannot be influenced by selection, mutation or environmental changes; and (2) that yield and longevity trade off in a bivariate manner to the exclusion of all other traits. These assumptions are consistent with the phenotypic trade-off model, but recent research suggests that a quantitative genetic model is a more appropriate approach to trade-offs. In the quantitative genetic model, environmental and genetic changes can result in increases in two traits simultaneously even when a trade-off, or negative correlation, exists between the two traits. Empirical evidence that the trade-off between perenniality and reproductive allocation is not fixed comes from wild, herbaceous perennials that can produce more than 2000 kg seed ha(-1) in the temperate zone, and herbaceous perennial crops that produce on average 8900 kg fruit ha(-1) in the tropics. Ecological literature suggests that most perennials produce small amounts of seed relative to their vegetative growth not as a physiological absolute, but rather as a result of natural selection in a stable, competitive environment favoring longevity. By selecting strongly for seed yield in a population of perennial plants, the plant breeder can likely achieve that which is rare in nature-a high seed-yielding perennial plant. The same general methodologies that have allowed annual grain breeders to increase grain yield and push many combinations of negatively correlated traits to levels of expression not seen in nature are available to the perennial grain breeder. Perennial,rain breeders are integrating ecological principles and traditional plant breeding methods in their efforts to develop perennial grain wheat (Triticum spp.), sorghum (Sorghum spp.), sunflower (Helianthus spp.), Illinois bundleflower (Desmanthus illinoensis) and rice (Oryza spp.).
Manual Tags: search.grain; search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 grain); TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); WOS

Author: Weik, L.; Pacan, J.; Aufhammer, W.; Kaul, H.-P.; Nalborczyk, E.
Title: Perennial grain crops in pure and mixed stands on marginal sites
Abstract Note: The use of marginal arable sites is becoming less profitable. If those sites are to be protected against succession, new ways for preserving an open landscape and for an extensive use should be found. Perennial grain crops might be advantageous in comparison to annuals because of lower crop management costs. This study was conducted to examine the yield potential and the persistence of perennial species of rye, lupine and linseed in pure and mixed stands. Factorial field experiments were conducted at two sites with marginal environmental conditions. The above ground biomass production was up to 110 dt ha-1 but seed yields were comparatively low. The species' ability for competition differed very much depending on the site. The aboveground biomass was often higher in mixed stands than in monoculture, but the seed yield of the mixed stands did not reach the yield of the pure rye crops. Re-growth of all species after winter was given, but in the second year a general decline in seed yield was observed.
Short Title: Perennierende Körnerfruchtarten in Rein- und Mischbeständen auf marginalen Standorten
Manual Tags: Competition; Dry matter yield; Mixed stands; Perennial grains; Scopus; search.grain; SPV; TITLE-ABS-KEY (perennial W/1 grain) AND DOCTYPE (ar); TS=(perennial NEAR/1 grain); WOS

Author: WAGONER, P.
Title: PERENNIAL GRAIN DEVELOPMENT - PAST EFFORTS AND POTENTIAL FOR THE FUTURE
Abstract Note: The development of perennial grains has the potential to provide environmentally sound, economically viable alternatives for use on erodible land where annual crop production is not sustainable. The concept of perennial grain production is not new. Historically, seeds of perennial grasses have been used as grain by various human cultures. In this paper, efforts to develop perennial grain crops which were initiated during the 20th century are discussed. These include attempts by the Soviets and Europeans to perennialize annual grains such as wheat and rye. More recently, efforts in the U.S. inspired by the publication of Dr. Wes Jackson's book, New Roots for Agriculture,1,2 have focused upon the domestication of perennial grass species. The advantages and disadvantages of these two approaches to perennial grain development are discussed. Specific examples are given with the hope that future efforts can benefit from experiences of the past and present.
Manual Tags: search.grain; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 grain); WOS

Author: Glover, J.D.; Reganold, J.P.
Title: Perennial grains food security for the future
Abstract Note: The development of the perennial versions of the crops such as wheat, sunflowers, and legumes through breeding in the US would enable the country to meet the growing demands of the food. The development of perennial crops through breeding would deal with the multiple issues involving environmental conservation and food security. The crops also increases 50 to 100% soil carbon and could significantly reduce water and nitrate losses and require less pesticide and fertilizer inputs thus resulting in lower costs. The use of perennial crops reduces global warming and the increases the reserves protected in the soil and increases the access to more soil moisture. The farmers could use available management practices, such as no-till or organic approaches, which gives them more options to have long rotations of perennial crops or rotations in which annuals are grown for several years followed by several years of perennials. The suitability of perennial crops requires the support from federal programs for farmers to encourage the initial adoption of new crops and practices.
Manual Tags: Scopus; search.grain; SPV; TITLE-ABS-KEY (perennial W/1 grain) AND DOCTYPE (ar); TS=(perennial NEAR/1 grain); WOS

Author: ORAM, R. N.; HOEN, K.
Title: Perennial grass cultivars for long leys in the wheat belt of southern New South Wales [Lolium rigidum, Hordeum leporinum, Phalaris tuberosa, Dactylis glomerata]
Publication Title: Aust J Exp Agr Anim Husb
Abstract Note: Forty-six cultivars in 11 perennial grass species were assessed in association with subterranean clover in 5 trials extending over 2 to 4 growing seasons. Established stands of several phalaris and cocksfoot cultivars yielded more sown grass herbage and total herbage than 'Wimmera' ryegrass, 'Australia commercial phalaris and "Currie" cocksfoot The highest yields were from C.P.I.19331 phalaris and Gl 35 cocksfoot. Gl 35 was also more resistant than 'Wimmera" ryegrass to the invasion of older stands by barley grass. The herbage yield of the perennial grasses was more stable between years and trials than that of 'Wimmera' ryegrass. The probable utility of these cultivars in the wheat belt and in the adjacent higher-rainfall pastoral zones is discussed. || ABSTRACT AUTHORS: Author
Manual Tags: search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); WOS

Author: MUZYCHKIN, YE T.
Title: Perennial grasses for restoring fertility of Ciscaucasian irrigated chernozems
Abstract Note: By irrigating high and consistent yields are obtainable from perennial grass crops. For 3 years of cropping with irrigation, alfalfa yielded 305 cntr/ha of hay, alfalfa + ryegrass yielded 290 cntr/ha, and ryegrass, 140 cntr/ha. Under the same conditions without irrigation, crop yields were 3-4 times less. With irrigation, accumulations of alfalfa roots in the soil layer at 0-60 cm attain 90 cntr/ha, those of grass mixtures, 117 cntr/ha. Irrigation increases the percentage of large roots of perennial grasses and reduces that of medium and small roots. Mixed grass crops and pure grain crops have no advantages over pure legume crops in formation of soil structure in irrigated soils. A certain compaction of the plowed layer under perennial grasses has been observed with irrigation, especially in the case of alfalfa. N accumulated in root residues during 2 years of perennial grasses. During subsequent cropping years, N accum-ulated at considerably lower rates. Amounts of N fixed from the air by perennial legumes can be expressed by the following values; with irrigation, pure alfalfa stand, 561 kg/ha; mixed grasses, 284 kg/ha; without irrigation, pure alfalfa stand, 171 kg/ha; mixed grasses; 151 kg/ha. Half the N fixed from the air goes to root and stubble) while the other half can return to the soil in the form of manure. Although perennial grasses have not substantially increased the humus and N content in the soil, they have improved the nutrient regime for sub-sequent crops considerably. Alfalfa contained more nitrates after plowing than predecessor crops. Winter wheat crops after alfalfa yielded 32 cntr/ha, and 16 cntr/ha on the preceding grain crops. Perennial legumes enhance the biological cycle of phosphates in soils. It can be assumed that irrigated alfalfa uses 3 times as much soil phosphates as perennial grain crops (ryegrass) or annual grain crops. || ABSTRACT AUTHORS: Author
Manual Tags: search.grain; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 grain); WOS

Author: Zhao, Ming; Acuña, Tina L. Botwright; Lafitte, H.R.; Dimayuga, Glenn; Sacks, Eric
Title: Perennial hybrids of Oryza sativa × Oryza rufipogon: Part II. Carbon exchange and assimilate partitioning
Abstract Note: Oryza species differ in their degree of perenniality, which has implications for patterns of carbon distribution in the plant. Interspecific F1 hybrids of Oryza sativa × Oryza rufipogon were compared with their parental lines to assess whether they differed in assimilate storage and distribution at flowering and after maturity of the first cohort of panicles. The F1 hybrids varied widely in plant type, but on average they had small plant size and low main tiller weights at anthesis, similar to O. rufipogon, and had intermediate tiller numbers and final single plant weights similar to cultivated rice. O. rufipogon had higher concentrations of starch in stems at anthesis, while interspecific hybrids exhibited comparatively low leaf, stem + sheath, and root sugar concentrations. Near anthesis, substantial 14C label remained in the source (flag) leaf in O. sativa and F1 hybrids, while in O. rufipogon more label was exported to sink tissues. The hybrids partitioned more 14C label to panicles than did cultivated rice and less to leaf sheaths than either parent. Hybrids that had previously been identified as having above-average carbon exchange rates (CER) did not differ consistently from the low-CER hybrids in carbohydrate dynamics. The cultivated species itself maintains some perennial features, and changes in these traits might increase productivity.
Manual Tags: 14C; Non-structural carbohydrate; O. rufipogon; Oryza; O. sativa; Perenniality; perennial W/1 (oryza OR rice); Photosynthesis; Rice; ScienceDirect; search.rice; Source-sink; SPV

Author: S, MUSIIKO A.
Title: PERENNIAL ODESSA RYE A VALUABLE FODDER CULTURE
Publication Title: Doklady Vsesoyuznoi Ordena Lenina i Ordena Trudovogo Krasnogo Znameni   Akademii Sel'skokhozyaistvennykh Nauk Imeni V I Lenina

Author: Zhao, Ming; Lafitte, H.R.; Sacks, Eric; Dimayuga, Glenn; Acuña, Tina L. Botwright
Title: Perennial O. sativa × O. rufipogon interspecific hybrids: I. Photosynthetic characteristics and their inheritance
Abstract Note: A survey of 24 wild Oryza accessions identified Oryza australiensis and Oryza rufipogon as potential sources of enhanced photosynthetic rate for introgression into cultivated rice. Photosynthetic capacity per unit leaf area (CER) was associated with leaf N content but not with leaf chlorophyll concentration, flag leaf area, or specific leaf area. Eight fertile, perennial F1 hybrids between O. sativa and O. rufipogon were grown in non-flooded soil, and CER was measured at flowering under saturating light. Two F1 hybrids had greater CER than the average of 26.1 μmol m2 s−1. The F2 progeny from these hybrids were screened for CER in the field, and segregants with even greater rates of photosynthesis were selected. The basis of high photosynthetic rate in the F2 populations was not leaf thickness or leaf chlorophyll content. One F2 line had exceptionally high CER and stomatal conductance. Broad-sense heritability on an individual plant basis for CER in two F2 populations was 0.44 and 0.37. A highly significant offspring-parent regression of 0.89 for CER was observed in a replicated field evaluation (four blocks, five plants per plot) of 20 vegetatively propagated F2 selections and their F3 seedling progeny. Broad-sense heritability for CER on a plot-mean basis was estimated as 0.74 for both selected F2:3 families and for the selected F2 clones. Genetic resources in the genus Oryza may represent a source of alleles to increase leaf photosynthetic rate in the cultivated species, which we have demonstrated to be a heritable, though environmentally variable, trait in an O. sativa/O. rufipogon population.
Manual Tags: O. rufipogon; Oryza; O. sativa; perennial W/1 (oryza OR rice); Photosynthesis; Rice; ScienceDirect; search.rice; SPV

Author: Daniel, J.N.; Ong, C.K.
Title: Perennial pigeonpea: a multi-purpose species for agroforestry systems
Abstract Note: Perennial pigeonpea is receiving considerable attention in India as a multi-purpose species for agroforestry systems. Its multiple uses include food, fodder, manure and firewood. Data on perennial pigeonpea, together with relevant information on shorter-duration genotypes, are reviewed in this paper. Growth of perennial pigeonpea, like that of medium-duration grain types (150 to 190 days) in intercropping systems with cereals, is slow during the first 3 to 4 months. Therefore, it requires minimum sacrifice in terms of yield of annual crops in the system during the first year and offers many of the benefits of tree species in subsequent years. Total dry matter production potential of perennial pigeonpea in peninsular India is more than 15 t ha-1 year-1 consisting of about 2.0 t of grain, 3.0 t of leaf litter, 9.0 t of stems and 1.0 t of residue made up of podwalls and twigs. In addition, pigeonpea improves soil fertility by nutrient cycling and biological nitrogen fixation. Susceptibility of pigeonpea to diseases and negative effects on growth of annual crops are the potential constraints in the semi-arid tropics. Some pertinent areas for further research are proposed.
Manual Tags: Agroforestry; fodder; genotype; Grain yield; Perennial pigeonpea; Scopus; search.grain; search.pigeonpea; Soil fertility; SPV; TITLE-ABS-KEY (perennial W/1 (cajanus OR "pigeon?pea" OR pigeonpea)) AND DOCTYPE (ar); TITLE-ABS-KEY (perennial W/1 grain) AND DOCTYPE (ar); TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (cajanus OR "pigeon$pea")); WOS

Author: Tyagi, P.C.; Joshi, B.P.; Sharma, N.K.; Khullar, A.K.
Title: Perennial Pigeonpea as a vegetative barrier for protection and production in millet-lentil cropping systems
Abstract Note: To evolve a promising cropping system which reduced run-off, soil loss, and increases total production under marginal rainfed lands of Doon Valley and lower Himalayan region, ragilentil and kodomillet-lentil systems with and without vegetative barriers were constructed and tested at 2% sloping experimental field. The treatments were monitored for run-off, soil loss and production parameters. It was observed that incorporation of perennial Pigeonpea hedge rows in the cropping systems reduced the run-off and soil loss but significantly increased total production and net returns.
Manual Tags: Scopus; search.pigeonpea; SPV; TITLE-ABS-KEY (perennial W/1 (cajanus OR "pigeon?pea" OR pigeonpea)) AND DOCTYPE (ar); TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (cajanus OR "pigeon$pea")); WOS

Author: CICIN, TSYTSYN\N V.; MAHALIN, MAKHALIN\M A.; CICIN, TSYTSYN
Title: Perennial polyploid rye.
Abstract Note: A perennial rye bred by A. I. Derzavin was selected for winter hardiness, perennial habit and grain size; the final selection, with a 1000-grain weight of 20 g., was treated with 0.1% colchicine. The resulting polyploid had larger ears, thicker and taller straw and produced 20 ears per plant, where annual polyploids had only 12-15. The maximum number of grains per ear was 44, from 66 florets. Its grain yield corresponded to 12.4 c. per ha. in the first year and 10.7 c. in the second; with wider spacing its yield was 13.7 c. per ha. Maturity was 10-12 days later than that of di-ploid rye. Thousand-grain weight was 32 g. compared with 21 g. in the original diploid and 32.6 g. in Vjatka; selection raised it to 36-38 g. ; protein content was 16-17% compared with 13-15% in annual ryes. After the grain was harvested, a crop of 25-30 c. per ha. of hay was obtained, with a protein content of 14-15%. The polyploid was resistant to mildew and brown rust.
Manual Tags: search.rye; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 ("rye" OR secale) NOT "rye$grass"); WOS

Author: V, TSITSIN N.; A, MAKHALIN M.
Title: PERENNIAL POLY PLOID RYE-M

Author: JunghYun, Shim
Title: Perennial rice: improving rice productivity for a sustainable upland ecosystem.
Publication Title: SABRAO Journal of Breeding and Genetics
Abstract Note: The world population will reach a staggering 9 billion by 2050. Recent statistics show that an additional 40 million hectares of rice paddy is needed to increase rice production to 118 million tons by 2035, a figure that is more than double the current rice production. Every year, rice is planted in approximately 14 million hectares of upland areas. Current benchmark yields of annual upland rice are lower than 1 t/ha. If upland rice yield can be increased to 3-4 t/ha, a reasonable yield under barren and infertile soil conditions, 40 Mt of rice can easily be secured. Traditionally, the uplands suffer from drought, infertile soils, weed infestation and plant diseases. Compounding these problems is the continuous erosion and degradation of upland soils due to agricultural use. A practical solution to these problems would be to breed and cultivate perennial upland rice that would not have to be planted annually. Not only would perennial upland rice reduce soil erosion by providing permanent groundcover. It would also improve the sustainability of the uplands for agricultural use and lower the annual inputs related to field operations, thus increasing the income of farmers.
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: PORTERES, ROLAND
Title: Perennial rice in Africa
Abstract Note: The number of perennial spp. of rice is comparatively limited. In Africa, the most important is Oryzae barthii. which comprises several vars. This sp. is widely distributed over the Egyptian Sudan, Tanganyika, the Belgian Congo, French Equatorial Africa, and French Guinea. It multiplies by seed, rhizomes, and short pieces of culms. Its persistence in nature is due mainly to reproduction by rhizomes, which are drought-resistant and resume growth with the first rain after the 7-mo's. dry season; 4 or 5 generations of tillers may come from one rhizome. The distribution of the species is controlled largely by the duration of soil inundation; it is absent from areas continuously under water. It is somewhat salt-tolerant, being found in soils with a content of NaCl up to 840 ppm. The potential economic uses of O. barthii are varied; the foliage is excellent for green forage, and suitable as hay for cattle and sheep. The straw can be used in the manufacture of paper. The grain is excellent for human consumption and has the desirable feature of a white pericarp. The main obstacles ot its domestication are its irregularity in date of ripening and low yield. || ABSTRACT AUTHORS: R. W. Shuel
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: Ciferri, R.
Title: Perennial rice of the Dominican Republic
Publication Title: Atti Ist Bot Giovanni Briosi" E Lab Crittogamico Ital Univ Pavia Ser V
Abstract Note: There are 3 spp. of rice present in the Dominican Republic, Oryza sativa, O. perennis, and 0. latifolia. The 2 perennial types are compared and their vars. and habitat discussed. Comments are made regarding the classification proposed by Roschevitz (Bull. Appl. Bot. PL. Breed. 27: 1-33. 1931). A map shows the distribution of the genus Oryza in S. and Central America. || ABSTRACT AUTHORS: Charles Chupp
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: Nosov, V. S.; Kopytin, I. P.
Title: Perennial rye.
Abstract Note: In the dry steppe zone of Kazakh SSR perennial rye [Secale kuprijanovii] was established by sowing in autumn at 110-120 kg seed or 5-5.5 million seeds/ha. In the first 3 yr of growth its av. yields were 1.64 t hay/ha, compared with 1.29 t for Agropyron desertorum used as a control crop and 0.38 t for local natural steppe vegetation. CP yields of the 2 sown grasses were 205 and 172 kg/ha, resp., and they were equally palatable. A. desertorum lasted longer than S. kuprijanovii in which 22%, 41% and 63% plants died out after the 1st, 2nd and 3rd utilization yr, resp. Attempts to grow S. kuprijanovii in the drier semi-desert zone were not successful.
Manual Tags: search.rye; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 ("rye" OR secale) NOT "rye$grass"); WOS

Author: Ossent, H. P.
Title: Perennial rye.
Abstract Note: A perennial rye would have great cultural advantages. Wild forms, however, are deficient in quality and the ears shatter at harvest. In 1927, crosses were made of Secale cereals with S. montanum and S. anatolicum. The F 1 was of intermediate type, but with brittle rachis; very few plants remained alive after the third harvest. In F 2 75% of the plants had perennial habit and brittle rachis, only 1% had perennial habit and tough rachis. The remaining plants were intermediate. Segregation occurred also for habit, type of ear, size and-quality of grain. The F 3 contained many more plants with the desired ear type and it is hoped that valuable types may be secured by rigorous selection among the mass of different types which appeared.
Manual Tags: search.rye; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 ("rye" OR secale) NOT "rye$grass"); WOS

Author: MOKROV, S. V.
Title: Perennial rye and the possibilities for its cultivation under the conditions prevailing in the southern Ukrainian SSR Referat. Zhur., 1961, No. 5G518. (Translation)
Abstract Note: The rates and methods of seeding of annual and perennial rye were investigated. Data are presented regarding the growth and development and aftergrowth and fodder yield of annual and perennial rye. The fodder yield of a single cutting of perennial rye amounted to 362 metric cntr/ha when it had been planted on bare fallow and to 260 metric cntr/ha when it had been planted in fields used the preceding year for corn. The yield in the 2nd year was 50% lower. It is concluded that perennial rye is suitable for cultivation in the southern Ukraine as a green fodder crop.
Manual Tags: search.rye; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 ("rye" OR secale) NOT "rye$grass"); WOS

Author: NARLAMOV, A. A.; ZNAMENSKII, A. A.
Title: Perennial rye as a fodder crop in Rostov province.
Abstract Note: The effectiveness of perennial rye ( Secale cereale) as a fodder crop indicates that it can be included with success as a grass component in herbage mixtures. According to data from the Rostov Selection Station, the yield of hay of perennial rye from two cuts in 1950, the first harvest year, was 42.2 centners per ha., while the yield of Agropyron cristatum was 25 centners per ha., and that of Bromus inermis 18.8 centners per ha.-R.P.J.
Manual Tags: search.rye; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 ("rye" OR secale) NOT "rye$grass"); WOS

Author: VARLAMOV, A. A.; ZNAMENSKII, A. A.
Title: Perennial rye as a forage crop in Rostov province.
Abstract Note: A variable population of perennial rye has been produced at the Stavropoljsk experimental station. Plants differing in morphology and growth habit and reacting variously to their environment occurred. After seed was sown in the autumn of 1948, a large proportion of plants died during the ensuing seasons, but by the end of 1951 the plants which survived had vigourous foliage and roots. It is therefore suggested that the proportion of perennial plants with numerous tillers could be increased if seed were collected-during the second and third cropping season, the plants persisting beyond this period being persistent and vegetatively vigourous, and therefore most suitable for grazing and hay.
Manual Tags: search.rye; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 ("rye" OR secale) NOT "rye$grass"); WOS

Author: KAPLUNOVSKII, S.
Title: Perennial rye-a valuable forage plant.
Abstract Note: A productive and hardy perennial rye grown for forage has been bred by Micurinite methods at the Stavropolj Experimental Field Station. The crosses made involved Eliseevskaja, Bezencukskaja [Bezencuk], Vjatka and Tarascanskaja as the female varieties and two wild perennial rye species originating from the northern Caucasus and Armenia as the male parents. Variety 133, which was selected from the hybrid material and has the perennial habit, gave a good account of itself in the trials.
Manual Tags: search.rye; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 ("rye" OR secale) NOT "rye$grass"); WOS

Author: Garkushin, V. I.; Galkin, A.
Title: Perennial rye cv. Odesskaya.
Abstract Note: The cultivation of perennial rye [Secale kuprijanovii] cv. Odesskaya on a farm in Rostov region is described. Perennial rye gives lower fresh fodder yields in the 1st cut than winter rye but its fodder is more succulent and is more palatable to animals. The sowing rate for perennial rye is 30-40 kg seed/ha for fodder production and 30 kg/ha for grain production compared with 180-200 and 200-220 kg/ha, resp., for winter rye. The stems of perennial rye remain green up to the wax-ripeness stage and therefore can be fed to cattle during a period of 1-1.5 months. A month after cutting before the heading stage, the regrowth of perennial rye attains a ht. of 125-130 cm.
Manual Tags: search.rye; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 ("rye" OR secale) NOT "rye$grass"); WOS

Author: Anonymous
Title: Perennial rye for fodder.
Abstract Note: In trials in 1977-8 in the Astrakhan' semi-desert zone, perennial rye [Secale kuprijanovii] cv. Odesskaya Mnogoletnayaya gave fresh fodder yields of 7.48 t/ha in the 1st yr and 9.12 t in the 2nd yr; these yields were 5- to 6-fold higher than in natural grasslands. Its yields were 2.14-2.46 t/ha when used for grazing.
Manual Tags: search.rye; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 ("rye" OR secale) NOT "rye$grass"); WOS

Author: CERKEZISVILI, G.
Title: Perennial rye in Georgia.
Abstract Note: Form 133 of Derzavin's perennial rye proved drought and frost resistant and tolerant of poor soil, producing 150 c. of green matter, 8.5 c. of grain and 60 c. of aftermath per ha. where other cereals and sown grasses failed entirely.
Manual Tags: search.rye; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 ("rye" OR secale) NOT "rye$grass"); WOS

Author: REZNICUK, S. P.
Title: Perennial rye. Preliminary communication.
Abstract Note: The first hybridization attempts date back to 1935 when Hordeum bulbosum was crossed with cultivated barley and Elymus, and Secale montanum with Petkus rye; only the latter hybridization was successful. Among fourteen hybrids obtained from 568 crosses, only two proved to be truly perennial. From 1, 200 P 1 seeds normally obtained, 1, 000 plants survived in the second generation, forty-one of which gave two seed yields in the season. Perennial forms could be propagated vegetatively. Among the plants of the second generation there were segregates endowed with vigourous tillering (sixty tillers) and high 1, 000-grain weight (41.5 grm.); some segregates attained a height of 2 metres. In the second year the hybrids eared earlier than the annual forms. Less fragile stems and a better quality forage are among the objectives of further research.-M.A.O.
Manual Tags: search.rye; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 ("rye" OR secale) NOT "rye$grass"); WOS

Author: Stchebarskova, Z. S.
Title: Perennial rye - the new forage crop in irrigated agriculture of Volga delta.

Author: MOREISON, S. H.
Title: Perennial sorghum, a new forage crop for farms in southern U.S.
Abstract Note: Sorghum almum, a natural hybrid of Johnson grass and Sudan grass developed by selection in Argentina (cf. PBA, Vol. XIV, Abst. 896), has shown promise as a forage crop at Athens, Ga., since 1949. It has inherited the perennial habit of Johnson grass, without undue spreading by underground rhizomes, and grows as vigorously as Sudan grass, producing tall, luxuriant foliage with no higher HCN content than annual types.
Manual Tags: search.sorghum; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 sorghum); WOS

Author: MIKHAILOVSKII, V.
Title: Perennial sorghum[long dash]a new cultivated plant
Publication Title: Selektsiia I Semenovodstvo [plant Breeding and Seed Growing]
Abstract Note: In 1936, the production of a perennial form of sorghum was undertaken at Voroshilovsk. The wild form of Sorghum halepense (Gumai) was crossed with 36 vars. of annual sorghums and 6 strains of Sudan grass {S. sudanense). Among the annual sorghums the following were used: S. technicum, S. vulgare, S. saccharatum, S. japonicum, S. durra, and S. caffrorum. The crossing was successful only when the maternal parent was the annual sorghum. Reciprocal crosses did not yield any progeny. The work was continued in 1937 and 1938. The best results were obtained from crossing of A. halepense with S. saccharatum. From this combination 163 plants were obtained in 1938, and from S. halepense X Orange sorgo, 157 plants were obtained. The hybrid plants bloomed and ripened later and some did not mature before frost. Seeds in many of the heads shattered easily[long dash]a halepense characteristic. Out of 93 hybrids of halepense X saccharatum only 5 had heads which did not shatter. Of S. halepense X Orange sorgo, 24 out of 225 did not shatter. Cultivated forms segregated out in the F2. The former hybrid had 40 chromosomes, the latter 30. The 40-chromosome forms had lower, weaker growth, but a higher maturity of seeds at frost time than in 30-chromosome plants. || ABSTRACT AUTHORS: /. W. Pincus
Manual Tags: search.sorghum; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 sorghum); WOS

Author: M, ATAEV A.
Title: PERENNIAL SORGHUM ON JUNGLE LANDS OF THE MIDDLE AMU-DARYA FLOODPLAIN
Publication Title: Izvestiya Akademii Nauk Turkmenskoi SSR Seriya Biologicheskikh Nauk
Abstract Note: Perennial sorghum [Sorghum almum cultivar Parodi] is a new tropical grass for Turkmenistan USSR. Besides producing high fodder yields, this grass is heat and drought resistant. It may be harvested many times during the summer.
Manual Tags: search.sorghum; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 sorghum); WOS

Author: DERZAVIN, A. I.
Title: Perennial varieties of cultivated plants.
Abstract Note: The advantages of the perennial types which are found in related species of so many of the main crop plants are enumerated, these being largely associated with their greater vigour and yield, hardiness, disease and drought resistance and their considerably earlier maturity in the second and later years of vegetation; it is thus often possible to get more than one crop per year. In crossing wheat with perennial rye the best results have been obtained with ryes from Armenia-the hybrids from these forms were more fertile and gave a more fertile back-cross progeny than any others; this is ascribed to the fact that these forms have for thousands of years been growing in similar climatic conditions to the wheats, as a result of which "their chromatin has become more similar", owing to natural selection of a similar ecological type. Wheat is also being crossed extensively with Agropyrum and with perennial rye. Of the latter over 200 different parental combinations have been made, in which an average success of 70 per cent was observed. The most successful of all the combinations was leucurum 1364/1 x Secale moniamtm (Kat. 8) from Armenia which cross was made in 1933 and has now produced a fertile perennial T. durum, in which the yield and grain weight were superior to those of the standard varieties but the ear is unfortunately brittle. Hybrids of this form with standard wheat varieties have a tough rachis and it is thought probable that perennial tough forms will be obtained in the second or third generation. The hybrids are resistant to brown rust and quite immune to stem and yellow rust. New stems are formed after harvest and in 1936 these attained a height of 40-50 cm. and were cut for hay, and in 10-15 of the hybrids they produced a second crop of grain 50-60 per cent the size of the first, 15 to 24 grains being produced per ear, with a. 1, 000-corn weight of 35 grm. By suitable cultural treatments this second yield could be brought up to that of the first. Similar crosses are being made between perennial and cultivated rye, sunflower with Helianthus maximiliani and H. rigidus and cultivated sorghum with S. halepense and several perennial leguminous species are being crossed with the allied cultivated forms.
Manual Tags: search.rye; search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 ("rye" OR secale) NOT "rye$grass"); TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); WOS

Author: RUTTI, R.
Title: Perennial wheat.
Abstract Note: Italian breeders working on the problem of producing perennial wheats suitable for Italy, tested the following material: ( a) the F 4 of Triticum vulgare var. lutescens x Agropyron glaucum[Elymus hispidus], ( b) the F 4 of T. orientale x A. glaucum, ( c) the F 2 of T. vulgare x A. elongatum, and ( d) a first year perennial spring wheat No. 611 The resulting plants showed great differences in tillering, flowering and time of ripening, but all tended to ripen late, which would promote attack by rust. The wild character was expressed by strong tillering and root formation, also by the small grain and the inadequate fertilization capacity. By autumn in the second year all the plants had died and in this year the yields fell sharply. Despite the failure to reproduce under Italian conditions of climate, the results claimed by Russian research workers on perennial wheats, further experiments are being made by Michahelles in crossing the hybrid T. vulgar e x A. glaucum with his wheat varieties Aquila, Impero, Autarchia and Frassinato 405. It is hoped that types of wheat may result, which will ripen earlier and may be suitable for cultivation in the central and southern regions of Italy, in mountainous parts, and in dry areas where the soil is saline. In the actual wheat growing districts, where the soil is deep and yieldsare high, perennial wheats are unnecessary. E.W.
Manual Tags: search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); WOS

Author: Bell, Lindsay W.; Wade, Len J.; Ewing, Mike A.
Title: Perennial wheat: a review of environmental and agronomic prospects for development in Australia
Abstract Note: Perennial wheat could improve grain production systems in Australia by rectifying many environmental problems such as hydrological imbalance, nutrient losses, soil erosion, and declining soil carbon and soil health. There are also potential direct production benefits from reduced external inputs, providing extra grazing for livestock in mixed farming systems, as well as benefits for whole-farm management which may offset lower grain yields. In addition to universal issues of domestication and breeding of perennial wheat, specific challenges for perennial wheat in Australia's dryland systems will include tolerance of water deficit and poor soil environments, and the risks of hosting foliar pathogens over summer. Temperate perennial forage grasses could indicate the potential distribution and traits required in perennial wheat adapted to more arid environments (e.g. summer dormancy). Several Australian native and exotic perennial relatives of wheat could also provide sources of disease resistance, and tolerance of soil acidity, drought, salinity and waterlogging. Still, several farming systems could accommodate perennial wheat with inconsistent persistence in some environments. While developing perennial wheat will be challenging, there is significant opportunity in Australia for perennial wheat to diversify current cropping options. The risks may be minimised by staged investment and interim products with some immediate applications could be produced along the way.
Manual Tags: AGRICOLA; search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); TX (perennial N1 (triticum OR wheat)); WOS
Automatic Tags: arid lands; Australia; carbon; disease resistance; domestication; dormancy; drought; edaphic factors; farming systems; flooded conditions; forage grasses; grain yield; mixed grazing; pathogens; production technology; risk; salinity; soil erosion; soil pH; soil quality; soil water deficit; summer; wheat

Author: Cox, C.M.; Murray, T.D.; Jones, S.S.
Title: Perennial wheat germ plasm lines resistant to eyespot, Cephalosporium stripe, and wheat streak mosaic
Abstract Note: A perennial wheat cropping system on the Palouse Prairie of eastern Washington may provide an alternative to the Federal Conservation Reserve Program and reduce soil erosion while providing a harvestable crop for growers. Twenty-four perennial wheat germ plasm lines resulting from crosses between wheat and wheatgrass were evaluated under controlled environment conditions for resistance to Wheat streak mosaic virus (WSMV), Cephalosporium gramineum, and Tapesia yallundae (anamorph Pseudocercosporella herpotrichoides var. herpotrichoides). Perennial wheat lines SS452, SS103, SS237, MT-2, and PI 550713 were resistant to all three pathogens. Eight lines (33%) were resistant to WSMV at 21°C and 25°C; AT3425 was resistant to WSMV at 21°C but not at 25°C. Thirteen lines (54%) were highly to moderately resistant to C. gramineum. Thirteen lines (54%) were resistant to T. yallundae in each experiment, but the reactions of four lines differed between experiments. The wheatgrasses Thinopyrum intermedium (PI 264770) and Thinopyrum ponticum (PI 206624) are reported as new sources of resistance to T. yallundae. Perennial wheat must have resistance to these diseases in order to be feasible as a crop in the Pacific Northwest.
Manual Tags: AGRICOLA; Scopus; search.wheat; SPV; TITLE-ABS-KEY (perennial W/1 (triticum OR wheat)) AND DOCTYPE (ar); TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); TX (perennial N1 (triticum OR wheat)); WOS
Automatic Tags: cropping systems; disease resistance; fungal diseases of plants; germplasm; Hymenula cerealis; Oculimacula yallundae; perennials; plant genetic resources; Triticum aestivum; Washington; Wheat streak mosaic virus

Title: "Perennial" wheat in the U.S.S.R.
Publication Title: Journal of the American Society of Agronomy

Author: Anonymous
Title: Perennial wheat is on the way.
Abstract Note: Progress made at Davis, Calif., in breeding perennial wheat from crosses between Triticum and Agropyron is briefly reviewed.
Manual Tags: search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); WOS

Author: Tsitsin, Nikolai
Title: Perennial wheat passes tests
Publication Title: U S S R Inform Bull
Abstract Note: Presents a condensation of an article by the Soviet biologist, Nikolai Tsitsin, on new hybrid wheats produced by crossing of different vars. of wheat with couch grass (Agropyron sp.). Perennial wheat no. 34,085 is drought-resistant, grows on saline soils, is immune to fungus diseases, has high gluten content and yields harvests for 2 or 3 yrs. without resowing. The bulletin is published by the U. S. S. R. Embassy, 3031 Gates Road N. W., Washington 8, D. C. Mailed without charge on written request.
Manual Tags: search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); WOS

Author: TSITSIN; CICIN], N.
Title: Perennial wheats.
Abstract Note: A brief report is given of achievements in the Soviet Union in the work of crossing wheat with Agropyron, rye, and Elymus. Mention is made of new varieties of perennial wheat which have now been developed from crosses between wheat and Agropyron, and which are recommended for sowing on a large scale. It is also reported that hybrids of wheat and barley with Elymus have recently been secured. As a result of these crosses, it is considered that the production of varieties bearing 200-300 grams per ear will be possible.
Manual Tags: search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); WOS

Author: WALDRON, L. R.
Title: Perennial wheats. Bi-m.
Publication Title: Bulletin. North Dakota Agricultural Experiment Station
Abstract Note: This brief article discusses the recent development of perennial wheats in the Soviet Union, and points out the possibility of obtaining from the cross wheat x Agropyron a variety of winter wheat hardier than any present variety.
Manual Tags: search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); WOS

Author: Forlani, R.
Title: Perennial wheats from the experimental standpoint.
Abstract Note: It is pointed out that the Triticum x Agropyron hybrids produced so far are of little or no interest for the sake of their grains, but may afford useful breeding material for areas with highly unfavourable growth conditions.
Manual Tags: search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); WOS

Author: Scheinost, P.L.; Lammer, D.L.; Cai, X.; Murray, T.D.; Jones, S.S.
Title: Perennial wheat: The development of a sustainable cropping system for the U.S. Pacific Northwest
Abstract Note: Perennial wheat offers a new solution to the long-standing problems of soil erosion and degradation associated with conventional annual small-grain cropping systems in the Pacific Northwest region. Using classical breeding methods, new types of wheat have been developed that maintain the key characteristics of annual wheat, but continue to grow after harvest. Following dormancy in the winter, growth is initiated from the roots or crowns in the spring, allowing a crop to be harvested every fall. By retaining constant soil cover over multiple years, wind and water erosion would be dramatically reduced. In addition, the costs associated with annual seeding and tillage would be minimized, and unlike many reduced tillage systems, it is expected that standard seeding equipment would be suitable for stand establishment. Other potential benefits of perennial wheat include improved wildlife habitat, more efficient use of available water, provision of a potent carbon sink, and the possibility of integrating straw retrieval into a small grains cropping system. Past attempts in the first half of the last century failed to develop perennial wheat as a viable crop, primarily because of low yields, and the research was ultimately abandoned. Perrennial wheat production may now be viewed as acceptable for highly erodible land or for obtaining carbon sequestration credits. This paper presents an overview of solutions to the obstacles encountered by previous researchers, introduces some of the newly developed perennial wheat lines, and discusses considerations for management practices.
Manual Tags: AGRICOLA; Carbon sequestration; Cereal grains; Conservation reserve program; Crop cover; No-till agriculture; plant breeding; Scopus; search.wheat; soil erosion control; SPV; TITLE-ABS-KEY (perennial W/1 (triticum OR wheat)) AND DOCTYPE (ar); TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); TX (perennial N1 (triticum OR wheat)); WOS

Author: LOZANO, M. J.
Title: Perennial wheat will be most useful.
Publication Title: Revista del Instituto Agricola Catalan de San Isidro

Author: Anonymous
Title: Perenniel rye.
Abstract Note: A small scale sowing of perennial rye in the Donbas region has yielded up to 20 cwt. per acre.

Author: Jian, Wang; ChangQing, Gao; ChunPu, Xie; HongPing, Liu; HuaShu, Liu; ChangBing, Liu; XinSheng, Wang; Ju, Le; HanHua, Tang; ZhongHui, Lin; WeiGang, Wang; Ming, Zheng; YongJun, Li
Title: Performance and high-yielding cultivation techniques of Y Liangyou 2 grown as ratoon rice in Xiaogan, Hubei Province.
Abstract Note: Y Liangyou 2 is a new two-line late-maturing hybrid combination. It was derived from the cross Y58S*Yuanhui No.2. It was examined and approved in 2011 and 2013 by the Crop Variety Appraisal Committee of Hunan Province and the State Crop Variety Appraisal Committee, respectively. Y Liangyou 2 as the first season rice and ratoon rice gave an average yield of 9.64 and 4.15 tons/ha. at Xiaogan, Hubei, China in 2013, respectively. Its total yield as the first season rice and ratoon rice was 5.69 tons/ha higher than one-season rice in this region, and its net income was 6663 PBY/ha. Some key technical measures for Y Liangyou 2 as the ratoon rice are presented and discussed. They include applying fertilizer to promote bud emergence and seedling growth, paying attention to water management, promoting maturity by chemical control, controlling plant diseases and insect pests, and harvesting in good time.
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: Gawali, S. R.; Rao, A. S.
Title: Performance of fodder maize (African tall), sorghum (SSG), hybrid napier (CO-1) and guinea grass (hamil) in farmers' fields.
Abstract Note: Pennisetum purpureum * P. americanum [ P. glaucum] cv. CO-1, Panicum maximum cv. Hamil, maize cv. African tall and sorghum cv. Pioneer/SSG ( Sorghum bicolor * S. sudanense) were grown in farmers' fields in Anekal taluk of Bangalore district. The two grasses were harvested at 55 to 65 days intervals, maize at 60 to 70 days and sorghum at 45 to 50 days. The average green fodder yield per harvest was 27.1, 15.2, 35.4 and 31.4 t/ha; DM yield was 5.01, 3.06, 6.57 and 4.90 t/ha and CP yield was 0.49, 0.25, 0.63 and 0.59 t/ha, respectively, for the four crops. The yield was low in winter. The annual green yield from 6 harvests of P. purpureum * P. americanum was 162.4 t/ha, from 6 harvests of P. maximum 91.8 t/ha, from 4 crops of maize 141.2 t/ha and from 3 crops of sorghum followed by a ratoon of each crop was 159.9 t/ha in the first year. Green yield of P. purpureum * P. americanum and P. maximum from 7 harvests in the 2nd year was 193.4 and 136.0 t/ha, respectively. Irrigation water, electricity for pumping, manure and labour were limiting factors under field conditions. Plant height was the highest for maize (185 cm) and the lowest for P. maximum (93 cm). P. purpureum * P. americanum and maize had longer leaves than P. maximum and sorghum. Cereals had wider leaves than grasses. The leaf/stem ratio of grasses was much higher than that of cereals. P. purpureum * P. americanum showed the lowest cost of production followed by sorghum. The cost of production of P. purpureum * P. americanum was further reduced in the 2nd year.
Manual Tags: search.sorghum; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 sorghum); WOS

Author: BULLER, RODERIC E.; T., RICARDO GARZA
Title: Performance of grass legume associations in the central Mexico milkshed areas
Publication Title: Mexico Sec Agric Y Ganader Estud Esp Foll Tec
Abstract Note: The performance of irrigated grass-legume mixtures for forage were compared to that of alfalfa in 3 areas. In the valley of Mexico alfalfa was the most productive cutting forage. Associations of grass and clover were not productive. Under year round grazing an alfalfa-orchard grass mixture resisted grazing better, its forage production being only slightly better than alfalfa alone. In the Toluca valley red clover-orchard grass outyielded alfalfa. A Ladino clover-grass mixture was more productive than alfalfa during the winter months. Well-adapted grasses were orchard, tall fescue, perennial rye, annual rye and rescue. These were completely dominated by legumes in the mixtures. In the Bajfo alfalfa alone outyielded all mixtures. Alfalfa persists only 2 years under cutting. Ladino clover thrived for longer periods but needed more time for establishment and more irrigation. || ABSTRACT AUTHORS: W. D. Yerkes, Jr
Manual Tags: search.rye; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 ("rye" OR secale) NOT "rye$grass"); WOS

Author: RAO, EVSP; SINGH, M.; RAO, RSG
Title: PERFORMANCE OF INTERCROPPING SYSTEMS BASED ON PALMAROSA (CYMBOPOGON-MARTINII-VAR-MOTIA)
Abstract Note: A field experiment was conducted during 1986-87 and 1987-88 to study the performance intercropping systems based on palmarosa [Cymbopogon martinii (Roxb.) Wats. var motia Burk.] at Bangalore. The intercropping systems were palmarosa + cowpea [Vigna unguiculata (L.) Walp.], palmarosa + blackgram (Phaseolus mungo L.) and palmarosa + greengram (Phaseolus radiatus L.) during 1986-87, and palmarosa + blackgram-blackgram, palmarosa + sorghum grain [Sorghum bicolor (L.) Moench.]-blackgram and palmarosa + sorghum fodder-ratoon during 1987-88. The results showed that the intercropping of blackgram-blackgram or sorghum fodder-ratoon gave additions yields of 660 kg/ha seed and 16.6 tonnes/ha fodder respectively compared with the sole crop of palmarosa. Land-use efficiency in these intercropping systems increased by 24 and 9% respectively.
Manual Tags: search.sorghum; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 sorghum); WOS

Author: Santos, A. B. dos; Cutrim, V. dos A.; Castro, E. da M. de
Title: Performance of lines of irrigated rice as a ratoon crop.
Abstract Note: In field trials of 17 inbred lines selected for irrigated cultivation from advanced trials of a breeding programme, the grain yields of the ratoon crop were 2244-3403 kg/ha, but differences between lines were not significant. Ratoon crop plants of all lines were shorter than directly sown plants and their growth cycle was shorter (64-78 days).
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: D, SANTOS A. B.; A, CUTRIM V. D.; D, CASTRO E. D. M.
Title: PERFORMANCE OF LOWLAND RICE CULTIVARS-LINES IN RATOON CROP
Abstract Note: The grain yield of ratton crop of 17 lowland rice inbred lines selected out of the Advanced Comparative Trials of National Rice and Bean Research Center (CNPAF) Breeding Programs at Goiania, GO, Brazil, were evaluated in a field experiment during the period 1983/84. Grain yield of the ratoon varied from 2,244 to 3,403 kg/ha. All lines compared showed decrease in plant height and circle in ratoon crop.

Title: PERFORMANCE OF LOWLAND RICE CULTIVARS LINES IN RATOON CROP

Author: Maheshwari, S.K.; Sharma, R.K.; Gangrade, S.K.
Title: Performance of palmarosa (Cymbopogon martini var. motia) and pigeonpea (Cajanus cajan) intercropping under different planting geometries
Abstract Note: In an experiment higher mean dry herb yield of palmarosa [Cymbopogon martini (Roxb). Wats. var. motia Burk] along with higher mean oil yield of the crop, besides higher average yield of pigeonpea ([Cajanus cajan (L) Millsp.] were obtained under sole cropping of the respective crops at closer spacing of 45 cm × 15 cm. Additive series of 1 : 1 and 2 : 1 with variable spacings tried in palmarosa-pigeonpea intercrops. The yield of pigeonpea drastically reduced under 2 : 1 palmarosa-pigeonpea intercropping system and as such there was no possibility to grow pigeonpea in the second-season ratoon crop of palmarosa due to no harvest of the intercrop. Maximum monetary returns were realized by growing sole palmarosa at 45 cm × 15 cm spacing.
Manual Tags: Scopus; search.pigeonpea; SPV; TITLE-ABS-KEY (ratoon* W/5 (cajanus OR "pigeon?pea" OR pigeonpea)) AND DOCTYPE (ar)

Author: Kujur, S.; Ahmad, S.; Srivastava, G.P.; Singh, C.S.
Title: Performance of pigeonpea (Cajanus cajan) intercropping as influenced by row ratios and duration of fingermillet (Elusine coracana) cultivars
Abstract Note: Field experiment was conducted during the rainy season of 2005 and 2006 at Ranchi to evaluate the production potential of pigeonpea (Cajanus cajan (L.) Millsp.) in sole and intercropping with different duration (short, medium and long) cultivars of fingermillet (Elusine coracana (L.) Gaertn.) under four row proportions (1:1, 1:2, 1:3 and 1:4). The maximum grain yield (1.05 and 1.13 t/ha in 2005 and 2006) was obtained with pigeonpea sole which was significantly superior to intercropping treatments. Among intercropping systems, grain yield of pigeonpea increased with decrease in plant densities of fingermillet. Pigeonpea + short duration (SD) fingermillet 1:1 recorded maximum grain yield of pigeonpea (0.83 t/ha) that is 76.1% of sole crop. The grain yield of fingermillet cultivars was also higher under sole cropping and decreased in intercropping system in respect of short, medium and long duration cultivars. Intercropping pigeonpea and long duration fingermillet 1:4 row ratio recorded maximum finger millet grain yield (2.33 t/ha). Row arrangement of 1:1 ratio pigeonpea + fingermillet intercropping produced significantly higher pigeonpea equivalent yield (PEY) irrespective of duration of fingermillet. However SD fingermillet + pigeonpea 1:1 row proportion was most remunerative (Rs 15,091/ha) with high land equivalent ratio (1.46) and monetary advantage (6,204 Rs/ha). Nutrient uptake (N, P and K), available soil moisture, available N-P-K content of soil was higher when pigeonpea was grown with fingermillet in 1:1 row ratio. The intercropping of pigeonpea with fingermillet at higher row proportion (1:4) was found loss making system.
Manual Tags: Fingermillet; Intercropping; Land management; Nutrient uptake; Scopus; search.pigeonpea; SPV; TITLE-ABS-KEY ("long duration" W/1 (cajanus OR "pigeon?pea" OR pigeonpea)) AND DOCTYPE (ar); Yield

Author: Bhat, K.; Hosmani, M. M.
Title: Performance of ratoon as influenced by planting pattern, fertilizer levels and intercropping of cowpea in sorghum.
Abstract Note: In field experiment during the rabi [winter] season of 1988 at Dharwad, Karnataka, sorghum cv. SPV-351 was sown in skipped rows of 60 cm or paired rows of 30:90 cm, intercropped with cowpeas or grown alone, and given 50, 75 or 100% of the recommended fertilizer rate of 100:75:37.5 kg N:P 2O 5:K 2O/ha. The plant crop was cut for fodder 69 d after sowing. The ratoon crop did not receive any fertilizers. Green fodder yield of sorghum was highest with the recommended NPK rate (31.87 t/ha), was not affected by the sowing pattern and was greater with intercropping than the sole crop (31.47 vs. 29.25 t). Grain yield of the ratoon crop was not affected by the fertilizer rate or intercropping, but was higher under paired rows than skip rows (2.95 vs. 2.75 t).
Manual Tags: search.sorghum; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 sorghum); WOS

Author: Das, G. R.; Ahmed, T.
Title: Performance of semidwarf rice varieties as ratoon crop after summer harvest.
Abstract Note: In trials of 89 semidwarf varieties, insensitive to photoperiod, C3810 gave the highest yields (main and ratoon crops combined) and CR220-66 had the highest ratooning ability.
