Author: Das, S.K.; Reddy, G.S.; Sharma, K.L.; Vittal, K.P.R.; Venkateswarlu, B.; Reddy, M.N.; Reddy, Y.V.R.
Title: Prediction of nitrogen availability in soil after crop residue incorporation
Abstract Note: Controlled study was conducted with five farm-based organic residues to predict the expected nitrogen availability with time, based on N concentration and C/N ratio of the residues under two moisture availability situations. Two kg of red loamy sand soil representing Alfisol and related soil was incubated with the residues to supply 40 kg N ha-1 at 28 +/- 1 degree C at field capacity (FC) and 50% FC moisture conditions. Results obtained indicated that N content in soil released from residues increased with the time allowed for decomposition reactions at both FC and 50% FC moisture regimes. Relatively higher amount of N release was observed in case of legume residues like mungbean (Vigna radiata). L. leucocephala and perennial pigeonpea (Cajanus cajan), although the rate of N release was more with low N concentration residues. Sorghum stover with C/N ratio of 72.1 resulted in immobilization of N upto 90 days. Nitrogen release was higher at FC than 50% FC. The critical N concentrations of the residues at which N neither released nor immobilized decreased with the length of incubation. At 50% FC the critical concentrations were higher than at FC.

Author: Ng, M. L. S.; Warlow, R. S.; Chrishanthan, N.; Ellis, C.; Walls, R.
Title: Preliminary criteria for the definition of allergic rhinitis: a systematic evaluation of clinical parameters in a disease cohort (I)
Abstract Note: Background The aim of this study is to formulate criteria for the definition of allergic rhinitis. Other studies have sought to develop scoring systems to categorize the severity of allergic rhinitis symptoms but it was never used for the formulation of diagnostic criteria. These other scoring systems were arbitrarily chosen and were not derived by any statistical analysis. To date, a study of this kind has not been performed. Objective The hypothesis of this study is that it is possible to formulate criteria for the definition of allergic rhinitis. This is the first study to systematically examine and evaluate the relative importance of symptoms, signs and investigative tests in allergic rhinitis. We sought to statistically rank, from the most to the least important, the multiplicity of symptoms, signs and test results. Methods Forty-seven allergic rhinitis and 23 normal subjects were evaluated with a detailed questionnaire and history, physical examination, serum total immunoglobulin E, skin prick tests and serum enzyme allergosorbent tests (EAST). Results Statistical ranking of variables indicated rhinitis symptoms (nasal, ocular and oronasal) were the most commonly occurring, followed by a history of allergen provocation, then serum total IgE, positive skin prick tests and positive EAST's to house dust mite, perennial rye and bermuda/couch grass. Throat symptoms ranked even lower whilst EAST's to cat epithelia, plantain and cockroach were the least important. Not all symptoms, signs and tests evaluated proved to be statistically significant when compared to a control group; this included symtoms and signs which had been considered historically to be traditionally associated with allergic rhinitis, e.g. sore throat and bleeding nose. Conclusion In performing statistical analyses, we were able to rank from most to least important, the multiplicity of symptoms signs and test results. The most important symptoms and signs were identified for the first time, even though some of these were not included in our original selection criteria for defining the disease cohort i.e. sniffing, postnasal drip, oedematous nasal mucosa, impaired sense of smell, mouth breathing, itchy nose and many of the specific provocation factors.
Manual Tags: search.rye; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 ("rye" OR secale) NOT "rye$grass"); WOS

Author: Ng; Warlow; Chrishanthan; Ellis; Walls
Title: Preliminary criteria for the definition of allergic rhinitis: A systematic evaluation of clinical parameters in a disease cohort (I)
Abstract Note: Background: The aim of this study is to formulate criteria for the definition of allergic rhinitis. Other studies have sought to develop scoring systems to categorize the severity of allergic rhinitis symptoms but it was never used for the formulation of diagnostic criteria. Author: VOVK, A. M.
Title: Preliminary report on a mosaic in wheat-Agropyron hybrids
Publication Title: Trudy Zonal Inst Zernovovo Khoziaistva Nechernozemnoi Polosy Sssr
Abstract Note: The "cocooning" disease is a virosis which is transmitted by the dark cicada (Delphax striatella). It causes striped leaves and sheaths, delays growth, impedes emergence, and causes twisting and partial or complete sterility of the heads. It occurs on oats, barley and wheat, but Agropyron elongatum and A. glaucum are immune. Wheat-Agropyron hybrids vary greatly in resistance, but the valuable perennial wheat line no. 34085, after exposure to infected insects in the field, yielded only 1.5-4.1% of diseased plants, out of 3552 exposed, while the spring wheat vars., lutescens 062 and caesium 0111, had 25-35% infection under the same conditions. Breeding of wheats resistant to this disease should therefore be possible through the use of wheat-Agropyron hybrid derivatives. || ABSTRACT AUTHORS: G. L. Stebbins, Jr
Manual Tags: search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); WOS

Author: DaYun, Tao; Sripichitt, P.
Title: Preliminary report on transfer traits of vegetative propagation from wild rice species to Oryza sativa via distant hybridization and embryo rescue.
Abstract Note: There are diversified patterns of vegetative propagation in Oryza spp. If Oryza sativa was changed from an annual to perennial type via vegetative propagation, the perennial cultivar would be environmentally sound and economically viable. There would be a great potential to increase rice harvest area via ratoon cropping or stubble cropping and a possibility of increasing yield via fixing heterosis by vegetative propagation. A possible donor of the trait for ratoon or stubble cropping is O. rufipogon. The other species possessing rhizome formation ability for breeding of perennial rice are O. longistaminata, O. officinalis, O. rhizomatis and O. australiensis. In this study, the perennial trait was transferred from wild species O. longistaminata, O. rhizomatis and O. officinalis to cultivated rice ( O. sativa) through distant hybridization. Genotypes of O. sativa and wild species, pollen fertility of male species and environmental factors could contribute to crossability or germination rate of the resulting embryos. The "false" hybrid problem and research on utilization of vegetative propagation in wild rice species are discussed.
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (oryza OR rice)); TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: Petter, H.
Title: Preliminary results on growing sugar beet after sugar beet and after forage plants under conditions of additional sprinkler irrigation.
Publication Title: Archiv fur Acker- und Pflanzenbau und Bodenkunde
Abstract Note: In field trials in 1970-2 on a clay black earth, winter wheat, perennial ryegrass, red clover and Westerwolds ryegrass grown with sprinkler irrigation proved to be of equal value as preceding crops for sugar beet. With sprinkler irrigation yields of sugar beet following 1 crop of sugar beet were as high as those of 1st-grown sugar beet and there were no indications of increased incidence of pests.
Manual Tags: search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); WOS

Author: V, NARASIMHA RAO D.; G, DAMODARAM
Title: PRELIMINARY STUDIES ON RATOONING IN SORGHUM-M VARIETIES AND HYBRIDS
Manual Tags: search.sorghum; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 sorghum); WOS

Author: Rao, D. V. N.; Damodaram, G.
Title: Preliminary studies on ratooning in Sorghum varieties and hybrids.
Abstract Note: In a trial in the summer monsoon season of 1968-9, 16 sorghum cv. were cut so as to leave the stubble (a) 10, (b) 15 or (c) 22.5 cm long. The mean numbers of the shoots produced at 25 days after cutting were 3.9, 4.0 and 4.2 with (a), (b) and (c), respectively. Plant height, leaf number, length of the 4th leaf and days to 50% flowering increased, but length and breadth of panicles and 1000-grain weight decreased in the ratoon crop compared with values for the seed-sown crop.<new para>ADDITIONAL ABSTRACT:<new para>In a trial in the summer monsoon season of 1968-9, 16 sorghum cv. were cut so as to leave the stubble (a) 10, (b) 15 or (c) 22.5 cm tall. The mean numbers of shoots at 25 days after cutting were 3.9, 4.0 and 4.2 with (a), (b) and (c), respectively. Plant height, leaf number, length of 4th leaf and days to 50% flowering increased in the ratoon crop compared with the seed-sown crop.
Manual Tags: search.sorghum; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 sorghum); WOS

Author: Lo, K. C.; Hor, C. C.
Title: Preliminary studies on rice tarsonemid mite, Steneotarsonemus spinki (Acarina: Tarsonemidae).
Abstract Note: Studies were carried out in Taiwan to determine the relationship between infestations of rice by Steneotarsonemus spinki Smiley and grain sterility. There was a positive correlation between mite populations on the leaf sheath and sterility, and a negative correlation between mite populations and grain weight. A positive correlation also existed between mite occurrence in grain and sterility. The mite attacked panicles at all stages, the milky stage being the best for mite development and reproduction. In the field, adult female mites (but not eggs or larvae) were occasionally found in the leaf sheaths of graminaceous weeds, and large numbers of mites in different stages were found infesting rice stubble or ratoon plants. It was thought that early treatment of stubble might aid in preventing mite outbreaks in subsequent crops. The complicated interrelationships among the components (insects, mites and microorganisms) of the community found in the leaf sheath and grain are discussed.<new para>ADDITIONAL ABSTRACT:<new para>Data are presented which show a positive correlation between mite infestation of the leaf sheath and grain sterility, and a negative correlation between infestation and grain weight; a positive correlation occurred between grain infestation and grain sterility.
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: NanMing, Zhouy; MinHuan, Liu; ChangPing, Mo
Title: Premininary study on seed production of a ratooning rice cultivar Peiai 64s.
Publication Title: Journal of Guangxi Agricultural and Biological Science
Abstract Note: In a study in 1997-98 on seed production of ratooning rice cv. Peiai 64s, the crop was sown on 5 December, 5 March, 18 June or 6 August, with the seedlings transplanted into the field, and 12 typical male sterile plants in each batch of the 4 sowing dates were transferred to pots at the beginning of heading and isolated from alien pollen. The plants in the first, second and third sowing dates were ratooned for 3, 2 and 1 times, respectively, so as to make their heading synchronized with that of the 4th sowing date which remained intact. Electron microscopic observations on the pollen showed that the Peiai 64s had its fertility transformation on about 20 October, with a pollen abortion rate c. 50% in all the 3 ratooned batches. The plants in the 4th sowing date had a pollen abortion rate of 96.4% and a fertility of 0.3% while those in the 3 ratooning treatments had pollen abortion rates of 46.4-50.1% and fertility of 22.2-23.4%. It is concluded that ratooning can improve selfing fertility in cv. Peiai 64s which is significant for its seed production.
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: ALI, MA; MIAH, SA
Title: PRESENCE OF RICE TUNGRO VIRUS IN THE 1ST RATOON CROP OF TUNGRO INFECTED MAIN CROP OF RICE
Abstract Note: This study confirmed the presence of Rice Tungro Virus (RTV) in the first ratoon crop developed in the greenhouse from RTV infected main crop of rice grown in the field. Latex agglutination test (LAT,RTV transmission test and visual diagnosis method were employed. The results of two consecutive experiments conducted in Aus and T. Aman season proved the ratoon of susceptible variety to be the best source of RTV for secondary infection compared to the ratoon of intermediate or resistant one.
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: Bottenberg, H.; Litsinger, J.A.; Barrion, A.T.; Kenmore, P.E.
Title: Presence of tungro vectors and their natural enemies in different rice habitats in Malaysia
Abstract Note: Rice Oryza sativa L. habitats were evaluated for their propensity to sustain rice tungro virus during the fallow period. Leafhopper vectors and associated natural enemies were sampled by a D-Vac suction machine from rice crops, nurseries, and fallow fields in Malaysia between December 1983 and May 1984. Leersia hexandra Sw. vegetation in wet, fallow rice fields harbored significantly higher densities of Recilia dorsalis (Motschulsky). Nephotettix virescens (Distant) was relatively abundant in second-stage rice nurseries. Nephotettix nigropictus (Stål) and N. malayanus Ishihara et Kawase were only moderately abundant or absent in the habitats sampled. Nephotettix parvus Ishihara et Kawase, a reported vector, was not caught. Spiders, in particular hunting spiders and orbweb weavers, numerically comprised the major natural enemy guilds in all habitats except in direct-seeded rice and single-stage nurseries, where predatory insects were more abundant. Egg parasitoids were the only parasitoid guild in all habitats except in L. hexandra vegetation where low numbers of nymphal-adult parasitoids were recovered as well. Oryza sativa, Fimbristylis miliacea (L.) Vahl and L. hexandra were the most commonly encountered tungro hosts. All habitats with rice potentially perpetuate tungro, particularly ratoon and volunteer rice which carry tungro and vectors to the next season crop and nurseries which are more susceptible to vectors and tungro infection. Fimbristylis miliacea may act as a tungro reservoir when rice is absent but cannot support vectors. Leersia hexandra harbors high densities of vectors but its role as a tungro host is more limited. Elimination of fallows with rice or tungro hosts is recommended as a preventive practice. However, weedy habitats without tungro hosts are beneficial as they harbor a variety of natural enemies of tungro vectors. Such vegetation should be tolerated where possible. Resistant varieties or selective insecticides should be used to prevent tungro infection in the nursery stage without destroying the diverse natural enemy complex.
Manual Tags: ratoon* W/5 (oryza OR rice); ScienceDirect; Scopus; search.rice; SPV; TITLE-ABS-KEY (ratoon* W/5 (oryza OR rice)) AND DOCTYPE (ar); TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: Tri, Le Quang
Title: Present land use as a basis for land evaluation in the Mekong Delta.
Abstract Note: Land evaluation in the Mekong Delta, Vietnam was carried out to the FAO framework, with data collected from agricultural office records and interviews with farmers. Eighteen major land use types were identified and financially analysed. This led to 11 land use types being selected based on development objectives of the Vietnamese government, present agricultural conditions and results of the analysis. These cropping sequences were: vegetables/vegetables/rice; vegetables/irrigated high yielding rice/rice; irrigated high yielding rice/traditional rice + shrimps; irrigated high yielding rice/drained high yielding rice; irrigated high yielding rice/traditional rice; sugarcane/rice; ratoon cropping of sugarcane; fruit trees + aubergines in the first year; Zingiber officinale + Vigna radiata/traditional rice; cashews + pineapples; and Melaleuca sp. It is concluded that present land use is important in developing future agricultural plans.
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: Ponikiewska, T.
Title: Present state of investigations into the feed value of winter vetch compared with other fodder plants.
Abstract Note: Chemical composition, digestibility, drought resistance and silage, seed, straw and pod production were examined in winter vetch (Vicia villosa) compared with a number of other forage species including lucerne, red clover, winter rape [Brassica napus var. oleifera subvar. biennis], rye, perennial ryegrass and Italian ryegrass. The data presented include values for single species cut at various stages of growth, for forage mixtures and for certain species given various rates of N.

Author: Arbes Jr., Samuel J.; Gergen, Peter J.; Elliott, Leslie; Zeldin, Darryl C.
Title: Prevalences of positive skin test responses to 10 common allergens in the US population: Results from the Third National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey
Publication Title: Journal of Allergy and Clinical Immunology
Abstract Note: Background Allergy skin tests were administered in the second and third National Health and Nutrition Examination Surveys (NHANES II and III) conducted in the United States from 1976 through 1980 and 1988 through 1994, respectively. Objectives This study estimated positive skin test response rates in NHANES III and identified predictors of one or more positive test responses. Comparisons with NHANES II were also made. Methods In NHANES III, 10 allergens and 2 controls were tested in all subjects aged 6 to 19 years and a random half-sample of subjects aged 20 to 59 years. A wheal-based definition of a positive test response was used. Results In NHANES III, 54.3% of the population had positive test responses to 1 or more allergens. Prevalences were 27.5% for dust mite, 26.9% for perennial rye, 26.2% for short ragweed, 26.1% for German cockroach, 18.1% for Bermuda grass, 17.0% for cat, 15.2% for Russian thistle, 13.2% for white oak, 12.9% for Alternaria alternata, and 8.6% for peanut. Among those with positive test responses, the median number of positive responses was 3.0. Adjusted odds of a positive test response were higher for the following variables: age of 20 to 29 years, male sex, minority race, western region, old homes, and lower serum cotinine levels. For the 6 allergens common to NHANES II and III, prevalences were 2.1 to 5.5 times higher in NHANES III. Conclusions The majority of the US population represented in NHANES III was sensitized to 1 or more allergens. Whether the higher prevalences observed in NHANES III reflect true changes in prevalence or methodological differences between the surveys cannot be determined with certainty.
Journal Abbreviation: Journal of Allergy and Clinical Immunology
Manual Tags: allergens; allergic sensitization; allergy skin test; epidemiology; NHANES II; NHANES III; perennial W/1 ("rye" OR secale) AND NOT ("rye?grass" OR "ryegrass"); ScienceDirect; Scopus; search.rye; SPV; survey; TITLE-ABS-KEY (perennial W/1 ("rye" OR secale) AND NOT ("rye?grass" OR ryegrass)) AND DOCTYPE (ar); TS=(perennial NEAR/1 ("rye" OR secale) NOT "rye$grass"); WOS

Author: GLYANTSEV, A. F.
Title: Principal results of the work of the Department of Agriculture during the last 50 years Referat. Zhur., Biol., 1961, No. 3G473. (Translation)
Publication Title: Trudy Ukrain Nauch Issled Inst Rastenievodstva Selektsii I Genet
Abstract Note: From 1912 to 1933 the effect of fertilizers in increasing the yield of various crops was studied. The effectiveness of manure and of mineral fertilizers, as well as the best amounts, methods and sites of their application, were determined. The reaction of plants to permanent sowing was clarified, and the forerunners of vernalized crops, occupied fallow and a series of measures for cultivation of the soil were studied. The best times of sowing were determined, as well as, for some crops (corn, potatoes, sunflowers), the principal methods of sowing and maintenance. Between 1936 and 1941, the methods and optimal quantities for the application of mineral fertilizers, the interrelationship of nutrient substances, the effectiveness of root feeding and various other methods of cultivation were studied in sugar beets. From 1944 to 1958, questions of the grassland system of agriculture were investigated and agrotechnical methods were worked out for the cultivation of perennial grasses for hay and seed. Area and area-cluster sowing and the fertilizer requirements of sugar beets in crop rotation with perennial grasses were studied. Methods for increasing the yield of winter wheat with respect to non-fallow predecessors, the cluster method for the application of fertilizers to corn, and times and methods for sowing groats were studied. Since 1955, work has been begun on a study of a system of soil cultivation in crop rotation.
Manual Tags: search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); WOS

Author: TSITSIN, N. V.
Title: Problema ozimykh i mnogo-letnikh pshenits (Pshenichno-pyremye gibridy). [Winter and perennial wheats (Triticum [CHI] Agropyrum hybrids).]
Publication Title: UNSPECIFIEDPubl. by Sibirskii N.-I. Institut Zernovogo Khoziaistva   [Siberian Sci.-Res. Grain Inst.] Omsk
Abstract Note: The morphological characters of several winter-hardy spp. and vars. of Agropyrum are listed. The author suggests that Agropyrum glaucum, A. trichophorum, A. elongatum and A. junceum should be placed in the genus Triticum. Crosses of Triticum vulgare v. lutescens 062 (as well as other vars. of winter and spring wheats) with A. glaucum, A. elongatum, A. trichophorum, and A. junceum carried out in N. Caucasus and Saratov were highly successful and a considerable number of fertile seed were obtained. No results were obtained from crossing wheat with A. repens, A. tenerum, A. sibiricum, A. intermedium, A. gmelivi, A. cristatum, and A. elymus. The most interesting combination is wheat [CHI] A. elongatum, since the latter is immune to loose smut and rust, has a very strong root system, and grows on alkali soils. The characters of F1, F2, F8 and

Author: Shakhanov, E. Sh; Iskakov, N. K.
Title: Producing new forms of perennial rye by backcrossing.
Abstract Note: Selection within hybrid generations and subsequent polycrossing in the cross between Secale derzhavinii cv. Odesskaya Mnogoletnyaya [Odessa Perennial] and wild S. montanum was successful in producing a synthetic population which exceeded a control variety in green matter and hay yields and protein content.

Author: Blunt, C. G.; Fisher, M. J.
Title: Production and utilization of fodder and grain sorghum as forage for cattle in the Ord River valley, Western Australia.
Publication Title: Australian Journal of Experimental Agriculture and Animal Husbandry
Abstract Note: In a trial at Kimberley Research Station, fodder sorghum cv. Sudax Sx 11a was irrigated at intervals of 1, 2 or 4 weeks and was given 0, 90, 180 or 270 kg N/ha. DM yields increased at all rates of N with 2- and 4-weekly compared with weekly irrigation and were 13.6 t/ha and 14.0 t/ha at 180 kg N and 270 kg N/ha, respectively, with 4-weekly irrigation. In a 2nd trial, fodder sorghum grazed at stocking rates of 6.4 and 4 beasts/ha for 26 weeks gave mean daily liveweight gains of 0.36 and 0.41 kg/beast, respectively. Ratooned grain sorghum grazed at 4 beasts/ha gave daily liveweight gains of 0.35 kg/beast, but was unable to carry 6.4 beasts/ha. Freshly chopped fodder sorghum fed at the pre-flowering and at the soft dough stages gave mean daily liveweight gains of 0.48 and 0.37 kg/beast over a period of 26 weeks.
Manual Tags: search.sorghum; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 sorghum); WOS

Author: CHARLES, A. H.
Title: Production of early grass.
Publication Title: Journal of the Agricultural Society, University College of Wales
Abstract Note: In trials on the early-spring productivity of simple grass/white-clover mixtures, the total early herbage produced over 3 harvest years was highest in the Italian ryegrass strains. The relative total early spring (April) yield was 100, 99, 86, 82 and 67 for S22 Italian, Irish Italian, Hl, the 2 perennial rye-grasses (average) and S55 meadow foxtail, respectively. The importance of strain was noticeable in all the grasses. S50 timothy had an average spring production 38%above that of S48, it also withstood severe frosts better and had a higher protein content. In its second year, S170 tall fescue was the earliest and most productive of all grasses in the trial at Aberystwyth, relative figures for early grass of S22, Hl and S170 being 100, 61 and 351. In comparisons of the ryegrass strains Hl, S22 and Irish Italian, S22 and to a lesser extent Irish Italian were superior to Hl in early spring growth and productivity, particularly in the second and third harvest years and in severe winters. Cutting of the grass early, on 10 March 1952, greatly reduced the yield of the second cut on 4 April. The total production of S22 in the 2 cuts was 791 lb. per ac. and from one cut (April) 1317 lb. per ac., comparable figures for Hl were 629 and 1150 lb. per ac. respectively.-M.P.
Manual Tags: search.rye; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 ("rye" OR secale) NOT "rye$grass"); WOS

Author: Pospelova, L. S.
Title: Production of perennial forms.
Abstract Note: Soviet work on the production of perennial triticale is outlined from 1933, when A. I. Derzhavin produced a hexaploid amphidiploid between semiwinter durum wheat and a perennial wild rye which he called "perennial wheat", to the 1960s and 1970s, when the use of Agropyron glaucum [ Elymus hispidus] in intergeneric crosses, recommended and tested by Derzhavin in the 1940s and 1950s, came to fruition with the production of perennial triticales by directional selection from complex crosses of the type {( Triticum aestivum cv. Alabasskaya X Secale derzhavinii) X [( T. aestivum cv. Leucurum 1364/1 X perennial wild rye) X S. derzhavinii]} X ( T. durum X A. glaucum). Details of meiosis in perennial triticale are given, together with grain set and morphological characters. The best results in producing perennial triticale were obtained by selection for regrowth of winter-type tillers and for a vigorous root system and by hybridizing perennial triticale with perennial wheat-rye- Agropyron hybrids.
Manual Tags: search.rye; search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 ("rye" OR secale) NOT "rye$grass"); TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); WOS

Author: Le Mer, Jean; Roger, Pierre
Title: Production, oxidation, emission and consumption of methane by soils: A review
Abstract Note: Methane emission by soils results from antagonistic but correlated microbial activities. Methane is produced in the anaerobic zones of submerged soils by methanogens and is oxidised into CO2 by methanotrophs in the aerobic zones of wetland soils and in upland soils. Methanogens and methanotrophs are ubiquitous in soils where they remain viable under unfavourable conditions. Methane transfer from the soil to the atmosphere occurs mostly through the aerenchyma of aquatic plants, but also by diffusion and as bubbles escaping from wetland soils. Methane sources are mainly wetlands. However 60 to more than 90 % of CH4 produced in the anaerobic zones of wetlands is reoxidised in their aerobic zones (rhizosphere and oxidised soil-water interface). Methane consumption occurs in most soils and exhibits a broad range of values. Highest consumption rates or potentials are observed in soils where methanogenesis is or has been effective and where CH4 concentration is or has been much higher than in the atmosphere (ricefields, swamps, landfills, etc.). Aerobic soils consume atmospheric CH4 but their activities are very low and the micro-organisms involved are largely unknown. Methane emissions by cultivated or natural wetlands are expressed in mg CH4·m–2·h–1 with a median lower than 10 mg CH4·m–2·h–1. Methanotrophy in wetlands is most often expressed with the same unit. Methane oxidation by aerobic upland soils is rarely higher than 0.1 mg CH4·m–2·h–1. Forest soils are the most active, followed by grasslands and cultivated soils. Factors that favour CH4 emission from cultivated wetlands are mostly submersion and organic matter addition. Intermittent drainage and utilisation of the sulphate forms of N-fertilisers reduce CH4 emission. Methane oxidation potential of upland soils is reduced by cultivation, especially by ammonium N-fertiliser application.
Manual Tags: consumption; emission; Methane; production; ratoon* W/5 (oryza OR rice); review; ScienceDirect; search.rice; soils; SPV

Author: Khistaria, M.K.; Padmani, D.R.; Khokhani, M.G.; Kalaria, K.K.
Title: Production potential and compatibility of arable crops with subabul (Leucaena leucocephala) and perennial pigeonpea (Cajanus cajan) under alley cropping
Abstract Note: An experiment was conducted during 1989-90 to 1993-94 on arable field crops in the alleys of perennial pigeonpea [Cajanus cajan (L.) Millsp.] and subabul (Leucaena leucocephala) on a fixed site. Groundnut (Arachis hypogaea L.) crop may be raised in the alleys of perennial pigeonpea for higher equivalent yield of green fodder (186.08 q/ha) and maximum gross monetary returns (Rs 4,679/ha). Significantly highest green fodder-equivalent yield of subabul (287.63 q/ha) and maximum gross monetary returns (Rs 7,122/ha) were recorded when groundnut was grown in the alley cropping of subabul.
Manual Tags: Alley cropping; Economics; Green fodder; Groundnut; Scopus; search.pigeonpea; SPV; Subabul; TITLE-ABS-KEY (perennial W/1 (cajanus OR "pigeon?pea" OR pigeonpea)) AND DOCTYPE (ar); TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (cajanus OR "pigeon$pea")); WOS

Author: YADAV, ND; YADAV, DS
Title: PRODUCTION POTENTIAL AND ECONOMIC RETURNS OF DIFFERENT PIGEONPEA (CAJANUS-CAJAN)-BASED CROPPING SYSTEMS AS INFLUENCED BY VARIETY AND PLANT-POPULATION
Abstract Note: An experiment was conducted at Faizabad during 1985-86 and 1987-88 to evaluate production potential and economic returns in pigeonpea [Cajanus cajan (L.) Millssp.]-based cropping systems involving different varieties and planting densities. Variety 'T 21' recorded highest biological yield, pigeonpea equivalent, cost of cultivation, net profit and benefit : cost ratio. Lowest plant density of 80,000 plants/ha had highest biological yield, net profit and benefit : cost ratio. Pigeonpea-wheat (Triticum aestivum L. emend. Fiori & Paol.) rotation registered highest biological yield, pigeonpea equivalent, cost of cultivation and net profit. The benefit : cost ratio was higher in pigeonpea-pigeonpea (ratoon) system. The interaction effect indicated highest biological and pigeonpea equivalent yields in pigeonpea-wheat sequence with 'T 21' variety. In this sequence, highest biological yield in 1985-86 and 1987-88 was achieved at 160,000 and 80,000 plants/ha respectively.
Manual Tags: search.pigeonpea; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (cajanus OR "pigeon$pea")); WOS

Author: Ramshe, D. G.; Surve, D. N.; Patil, B. R.
Title: Production potential and economics of multiple cropping systems.
Abstract Note: 8 cropping sequences including cereals, legumes, oilseeds and forage crops in the kharif [monsoon] season and sorghum, chickpeas and wheat in the rabi [winter] season were grown in 1981-83 under irrigation and no constraint of inputs to study the potential and economics of different cropping systems. Sorghum/sorghum ratoon/groundnuts, sorghum/wheat/groundnuts and maize/wheat/groundnuts sequences were the most productive systems, giving 10.6-11.3 t grain and seed/ha annually. Economic return was highest with sorghum/sorghum ratoon/groundnuts followed by sorghum/chickpeas/fodder bajra [ Pennisetum americanum] and sorghum/chickpeas/groundnuts.
Manual Tags: search.sorghum; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 sorghum); WOS

Author: Singh, Man; Singh, Aparbal; Singh, Saudan; Tripathi, R. S.; Patra, D. D.
Title: Production potential and economics of safed musli (Chlorophytum borivilianum) under intercropping system
Publication Title: Archives of Agronomy and Soil Science
Abstract Note: A field experiment was conducted for two years, 2004-5 and 2005-6 during July-March at the research farm of the Central Institute of Medicinal and Aromatic Plants, Lucknow to study the compatibility, productivity and economics of intercropping in safed musli (Chlorophytum borivilianum Santapau & Fernandes). Vegetable crops viz cowpea, okra and bottle gourd, maize for grain, long duration pigeon pea, sweet basil in first year at their full and half population were intercropped with full population of safed musli in additive series. In the second year okra and sweet basil were replaced by lablab bean and sacred basil, respectively. Results of two years' experiments showed that intercropping of pigeon pea and bottle gourd with musli were advantageous in terms of overall yield, land equivalent ratio (LER), monetary advantage and economic return. The most appropriate combinations to realize the maximum advantage from intercropping were half plant population of bottle gourd grown at 100 x 100 cm or 120 x 90 cm spacing and pigeon pea grown at 120 x 20 cm spacing with musli. These combinations gave additional yield of 49.82 t ha(-1) of bottle gourd and 6.51 t ha(-1) grain of pigeon pea (2-year mean) without significantly reducing the root yield of musli.
Manual Tags: search.grain; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 grain); WOS

Author: Singh, G.; Singh, V.P.; Singh, O.P.; Singh, R.K.
Title: Production potential of various cropping systems in flood-prone areas of eastern Uttar Pradesh
Abstract Note: A field experiment was conducted during 1992-93 and 1993-94 to evaluate the production potential of 8 cropping systems in flood-prone areas. Sugarcane (Saccharum officinarum L.) - ratoon system gave significantly the highest net profit (Rs 42,901/ha), profit/day/ha (Rs 117.53) and rice-equivalent yield (20,78 tonnes/ha), followed by banana (Musa paradisciaca) - banana systems. Among the rice-based sequences, rice - wheat (Triticum aestivum L. emend, Fiori and Paol.) - maize (Zea mays L.) + cowpea [Vigna unguiculata (L.) Walp.] (fodder) gave significantly the highest net profit (Rs 21, 493/ha), profit/day/ha (Rs 67.16) and rice-equivalent (11.82 tonnes/ha), followed by rice - lentil (Lens culinaris Medikus) - maize + cowpea (fodder). Oil seed crops, viz sunflower (Helianthus annuus L.) and mustard [Brassica juncea (L.) Czenj. and Cosson] after rice showed poor economic return than cereal and legume crop. Rice - mustard - maize + cowpea (F) was the poorest The labour-employment generation was the highest (552 man-days/ha/year) against sugarcane - ratoon, followed by banana - banana system. Rice - sunflower - maize + cowpea (fodder) resulted higher labour employment generation, among the rice-based cropping sequences. The fodder sequence showed the lowest labour-employment generation.
Manual Tags: Scopus; search.rice; SPV; TITLE-ABS-KEY (ratoon* W/5 (oryza OR rice)) AND DOCTYPE (ar); TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: K, MAMEDOV
Title: PRODUCTIVITY ANALYSES OF SIMULTANEOUS SOWINGS OF ALFALFA AND OTHER FODDER CROPS IN THE PIEDMONT SUBZONE OF KOPET-DAG USSR
Publication Title: Izvestiya Akademii Nauk Turkmenskoi SSR Seriya Biologicheskikh Nauk
Abstract Note: The mixed lucerne and grass crop sowings increased the green part (yield) and improved the fodder quality. The maximum output of the fodder was obtained when lucerne mixed with annual and perennial sorghum were sown (205 centner/ha).
Manual Tags: search.sorghum; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 sorghum); WOS

Author: Timsina, J; Connor, D.J
Title: Productivity and management of rice–wheat cropping systems: issues and challenges
Abstract Note: Rice (Oryza sativa L.) and wheat (Triticum aestivum L.) are now grown in sequence on the same land in the same year over 26 Mha of South and East Asia to meet the food demand of a rapidly expanding human population. This rice–wheat (R–W) system brings together conflicting and complementary practices. Much of the system operates at low yield because of inadequate nutrients and inappropriate water management. The challenge to research is to understand crop responses to the required combination of practices so that management systems can be devised for high and sustainable combined yield. The repeated transitions from anaerobic to aerobic to anaerobic growing conditions affect soil structure, nutrient relations, the growth of the component crops, and their associated pests and diseases. This review establishes realistic yield targets and discusses strategies and tactics to improve complementarity of the two crops by choice of cultivar, sowing time, mechanization, soil and water management, choice and combination of organic and inorganic fertilizers, management of weeds, pests and diseases, and the inclusion of other crops into the system, especially legumes. While research must attend to existing problems and improve resource-use efficiency of existing practices, the review suggests the need to look for new production strategies that might avoid existing constraints in some areas of the R–W region. In particular, soil, water and nutrient management strategies, such as reduced tillage and use of raised beds, that avoid the deleterious effects of puddling on soil structure and fertility, improve water- and nutrient-use efficiencies, and increase crop productivity, may be appropriate.
Manual Tags: Nutrients; Productivity; ratoon* W/5 (oryza OR rice); Rice–wheat; ScienceDirect; search.rice; search.wheat; South Asia; SPV; Water

Author: MACKENZIE, J.; MAYER, R.; BISSET, WJ
Title: PRODUCTIVITY OF 5 SUB-TROPICAL GRASSES ON A BLACK EARTH OF THE EASTERN DARLING DOWNS OF QUEENSLAND
