Author: V, KIDIN V.; N, IKONNIKOV A.
Title: PRODUCTIVITY OF AGRICULTURAL CROPS AS A FUNCTION OF THE TIME OF THE APPLICATION OF AMMONIUM SULFATE AND NITRIFICATION INHIBITORS
Abstract Note: Research has been carried out on soddy-podzolic medium loam soils of the Vologda region. Combined application of ammonia sulphate and nitrification inhibitors.sbd.nitropyrine and ATS-60 has been found to increase yielding capacity of winter rye, oats and perennial grasses and total uptake of fertilizers by plants. Depending on the date of fertilization utilization coefficients of ammonia sulphate nitrogen calculated by differential method have equaled 15,4-88.4%. Inhibitors have contributed to 10-20% higher utilization of nitrogen from fertilizers.
Manual Tags: search.rye; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 ("rye" OR secale) NOT "rye$grass"); WOS

Author: Rao, M.R.; Ong, C.K.; Pathak, P.; Sharma, M.M.
Title: Productivity of annual cropping and agroforestry systems on a shallow Alfisol in semi-arid India
Abstract Note: An experiment was conducted at ICRISAT Center, Patancheru, India from June 1984 to April 1988 on a shallow Alfisol to determine whether the productivity of annual crop systems can be improved by adding perennial species such as Leucaena leucocephala managed as hedgerows. Except in the first year, crop yields were suppressed by Leucaena due to competition for moisture. The severity of competition was high in years of low rainfall and on long-duration crops such as castor and pigeonpea. Based on total biomass, sole Leucaena was most productive; even on the basis of land productivity requiring both Leucaena fodder and annual crops, alley cropping had little or no advantage over block planting of both components. Application of hedge prunings as green manure or mulch on top of 60 kg N and 30 kg P2O5ha-1 to annual crops did not show any benefit during the experimental period, characterized by below average rainfall. Indications are that (i) alley cropping was beneficial in terms of soil and water conservation with less runoff and soil loss with 3 m alleys than with 5.4 m alleys, and (ii) root pruning or deep ploughing might be effective in reducing moisture competition.
Manual Tags: Agroforestry; Alley cropping; castor; Hedgerow intercropping; Leucaena; pearl millet; perennials; Scopus; search.pigeonpea; Semi-arid tropics; SPV; TITLE-ABS-KEY (perennial W/1 (cajanus OR "pigeon?pea" OR pigeonpea)) AND DOCTYPE (ar)

Author: S, SDOBNIKOV S.; P, BABAKOV V.
Title: PRODUCTIVITY OF CULTIVATED DRAINED SODDY-PODZOLIC SOILS FIRST COMMUNICATION SELECTING CROPS AND OPTIMIZING THEIR NUTRITION IN VARIOUS SYSTEMS OF AGRICULTURAL USE OF SODDY-PODZOLIC GLEY SOIL
Abstract Note: Features of the water status of drained soddy-podzolic gley heavy loamy soils were studied, the coefficient of water requirement of crops was determined, and optimal levels of fertilizers under field crops and hay fields were formulated. An agroeconomical evaluation is provided of the cultivation of barley, fodder beets, perennial grass, alfalfa, winter wheat, potatoes and oats on drained soils of the nonchernozem zone of Russia.
Manual Tags: search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); WOS

Author: K-P, HONG; G-M, SHON; J-Y, KIM; K-B, CHOI; Y-S, LEE; Z-R, CHOE
Title: PRODUCTIVITY OF HERBAGE YIELD OF RATOON IN RICE PLANT AT SOUTHERN REGION
Publication Title: Research Reports of the Rural Development Administration (Suweon)
Abstract Note: This study was carried out to investigate the effects of different harvesting times and heights, nitrogen levels and top dressing date, and cultivars on the productivity of ratoon in rice at southern part of Korea. The conditions given to ratoon culture after main crop were four levels of rice harvesting time (30, 35, 40, 45 days after heading date), two levels of harvesting height (5, 15cm above the ground level), two levels of top dressing dates (10 days before harvesting time, harvesting time), and three levels of nitrogen (0, 40, 80kg N ha-1). Root activity, the number of ratoon tillers, ratoon tiller ratio and herbage yield was significantly increased in the plot early harvested. Ratooning ability and herbage yield were significantly increased by nitrogen application up to 40kg N ha-1 Cultivars such as Yeongdeogbyeo, Donghaebyeo, Hwaseongbyeo as Japonica type, and Baegyangbyeo, Namyeongbyeo, Yongmoonbyeo as Tongil type, were proved to be benefit for ratoon in term of the number of ratoon tillers, ratoon tiller ratio, and fresh and dry herbage yield.
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: Singh, Dheer; Tomar, P. K.
Title: Productivity of sugarcane ratoon influenced by weed management practices given in planted cane and ratoon crop grown in mustard and wheat based cropping system and its residual effects on wheat crop grown after ratoon crop.
Abstract Note: A field experiment was conducted during 2001-02 and 2002-03 on a silty clay loam soil in Pantnagar, Uttaranchal, India, consisting of 2 main treatments: (i) rice-mustard-sugarcane-ratoon-wheat and (ii) rice-wheat-sugarcane-ratoon-wheat cropping systems, and 4 subplot treatments given in plant sugarcane: (i) pre-emergence atrazine at 2 kg/ha+paraquat spraying at 0.5 kg/ha, (ii) 4 hoeings given when necessary, (iii) one hoeing after first irrigation+atrazine at 2 kg/ha after second irrigation in moist soil, and (iv) weedy control. At the same layout, the 4 treatments given in ratoon were superimposed on plant cane-treated plots. Wheat crop (cv. UP 2425) was taken after ratoon crop harvesting. Sugarcane cultivars Co Pant90223 during 2001-02 and CoS 767 during 2002-03 were taken as ratoon crop after harvesting plant crop. Wheat crop was sown on 19 December 2002 during 2002-03 and 13 December 2003 during 2003-04. Cane yield of ratoon was influenced by the weed management practices adopted in plant cane as well as in ratoon crop. Losses caused by weeds (due to weedy control in plant cane) were 38.77% during 2001-02 and 26.40% during 2002-03, and 27.24% during 2001-02 and 38.81% during 2002-03 due to weeds in ratoon. Cane yield of ratoon was significantly higher over the weedy control in the cultural treatment during both years. Weed population and dry matter were highest in the weedy control plots. Cane yield of ratoon was affected significantly and found higher in the rice-wheat-sugarcane-ratoon sequence than in the mustard-based cropping system during 2002-03 only. Commercial cane sugar percentage was not affected either directly or indirectly by weed management practices given in plant cane or in ratoon or by cropping sequences. The major weed species in the weedy control plots included Cyperus rotundus, Eleusine indica and Brachiaria ramosa.
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: N, CALENDACION A.
Title: PROFITABLE CROPPING PATTERNS FOR IRRIGATED AND RAINFED LOWLAND RICE ENVIRONMENTS
Abstract Note: Thirty irrigated and 10 rainfed lowland rice-based cropping patterns were compared for yield performance and profitability under the Prosperity Through Rice Project from 1984 to 1986 at the International Rice Research Institute (IRRI) farm. Potato-rice-rice was the most promising pattern tested in 1986 in irrigated lowland rice environment. Potato yielded 16t/ha. The 1984 check pattern IR36-IR36-IR42 yielded 14t/ha but exhibited declining grain yield in successive croppings due to increasing insect infestation and pathogen infection. IR58-IR58 - tomato reached a gross margin 1.7 times higher than that of the IR36 - IR36 - IR42 check. Tomato and stringbean, are highly perishable crops. IR64-ratoon-mungbean was the most practicable pattern tested in rainfed lowland rice environment. Ratooned IR64 from a main crop when straw was cut at 45 cm and without fertilizer yielded 0.9t/ha after 45 days.
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: SUNESON, C. A.
Title: Progress in 25 years of perennial wheat development
Abstract Note: A very diverse and still unstable gene pool from a 25-year new-species development effort with Triticum X Agropyron crosses is described. The evolutionary development method used, some genetic resource components, and a chromosome-substitution program are evaluated. The population seems to have immediate utility in California for feeding game birds in the winter. These has been a recent world-wide distribution of seed to breeders. || ABSTRACT AUTHORS: Authors
Manual Tags: search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); WOS

Author: Cox, T.S.; Van Tassel, D.L.; Cox, C.M.; Dehaan, L.R.
Title: Progress in breeding perennial grains
Abstract Note: Annual cereal, legume and oilseed crops remain staples of the global food supply. Because most annual crops have less extensive, shorter-lived root systems than do perennial species, with a correspondingly lower capacity to manage nutrients and water, annual cropping systems tend to suffer higher levels of soil erosion and generate greater water contamination than do perennial systems. In an effort to reduce soil degradation and water contamination simultaneously something that neither no-till nor organic cropping alone can accomplish - researchers in the United States, Australia and other countries have begun breeding perennial counterparts of annual grain and legume crops. Initial cycles of hybridization, propagation and selection in wheat, wheatgrasses, sorghum, sunflower and Illinois bundleflower have produced perennial progenies with phenotypes intermediate between wild and cultivated species, along with improved grain production. Further breeding cycles will be required to develop agronomically adapted perennial crops with high grain yields.
Manual Tags: AGRICOLA; plant breeding; Scopus; search.grain; search.sorghum; search.wheat; sorghum; SPV; Sunflower; Sustainable agriculture; TITLE-ABS-KEY (perennial W/1 grain) AND DOCTYPE (ar); TS=(perennial NEAR/1 grain); TX (perennial N1 grain); Wheat; WOS
Automatic Tags: cropping systems; Desmanthus illinoensis; food supply; grain crops; grain yield; Helianthus annuus; hybridization; legumes; nutrients; oilseed crops; root systems; soil erosion; soil water; staple foods; United States; water pollution; wheat

Author: Larkin, Philip J.; Newell, Matthew T.; Hayes, Richard C.; Aktar, Jesmin; Norton, Mark R.; Moroni, Sergio J.; Wade, Len J.
Title: Progress in developing perennial wheats for grain and grazing
Abstract Note: Dual-purpose cereals have been important for increasing the flexibility and profitability of mixed farming enterprises in southern Australia, providing winter feed when pasture dry matter production is low, and then recovering to produce grain. A perennial dual-purpose cereal could confer additional economic and environmental benefits. We establish that, at the end of a second growth season, selected perennial cereals were able to achieve up to 10-fold greater below-ground biomass than a resown annual wheat. We review and expand the data on available, diverse, perennial, wheat-derived germplasm, confirming that perenniality is achievable but that further improvements are essential through targeted breeding. Although not yet commercially deployable, the grain yields and dry matter production of the best performing lines approach the benchmarks predicted to achieve profitability. On reviewing the genomic composition of the most promising wheat-derived perennials, we conclude that the best near-term prospect of a productive breeding program for a perennial, wheat-derived cereal will utilise a diploid, perennial donor species, and the most promising one thus far is Thinopyrum elongatum. Furthermore, the breeding should be aimed at complete wheat-Th. elongatum amphiploids, a hybrid synthetic crop analogous to triticale. We advocate the generation of many primary amphiploids involving a diversity of Th. elongatum accessions and a diversity of adapted annual wheat cultivars. Primary perennial amphiploids would be inter-crossed and advanced with heavy, early-generation selection for traits such as semi-dwarf plant height, non-shattering heads, large seed size and good self-fertility, followed by later generation selection for robust perenniality, days to flowering, grain yield, forage yield, stability of grain yield across seasons, and disease resistance.
Manual Tags: search.grain; search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 grain); TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); WOS

Author: XiaoQi, Zhu; QiYun, Deng; ChunGuang, Chen; Wen, Zhuang; Wen, Wu
Title: Progress in research on ratooning rice and ratooning utilization of super hybrid rice.
Abstract Note: Ratooning rice is a type of rice with a special cultivating system. The research progresses on ratooning rice and ratooning utilization of super hybrid rice are reviewed. Super hybrid rice has a great yield potential, however, how to give full play to its yield potential and how to further increase rice yield by means of the ratooning system would be a new topic for the development of super hybrid rice.
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: Anonymous
Title: Progress reported in the development of perennial wheat for Canada.
Abstract Note: A brief report is presented of an interview with L. H. Shebeski on perennial wheat. It is not yet known whether the perennial wheat now being grown experimentally at Saskatoon would be suitable as a forage or as a grain crop. Experimental results have, however, indicated that it might prove useful as a spring wheat; the grain ripens while the straw is still green and if the crop was swathed instead of being harvested with a binder or directly combined, the straw could provide good feed. The perennial wheat is of a bread wheat type, and is reported to have superior disease resistance but is insufficiently hardy. Yield, drought resistance, and milling and baking quality have not yet been tested.
Manual Tags: search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); WOS

Author: Junaedi, A.; Chozin, M.A.; Lontoh, A.P.; Salam, M.A.; Lee, S.B.; Kim, K.H.; Kim, E.H.; Chung, I.M.
Title: Promising allelopathic rice lines derived from the recombinant inbred lines of Nongan/sathi cross
Abstract Note: Rice plants that exhibit allelopathic behavior represent potential options for sustainable weed management. Previous studies have shown that the Sathi rice variety (an indica-type) shows high allelopathic potential (HAP), whereas the Nongan rice variety (a japonica-type) shows low allelopathic potential (LAP). Hence, in this study, we assessed the F6 and F7 generations of 180 recombinant inbred lines (RILs) derived from crossing Nongan/Sathi planted in Seoul, Korea. A laboratory assessment (double pots allelopathy bioassay) and a field assessment (rice ratoon interplanting barnyardgrass seedling) were used to screen the allelopathic potential of the rice cross. Both methods used barnyardgrass (Echinochloa crus-galli Beauv. var. frumentaceae) as a plant (weed) indicator to evaluate how rice suppressed plant growth. The results indicated that some prospective lines have HAP, exhibiting high suppression of barnyardgrass height and shoot dry-weight. Further selection for desired agronomical characteristics was performed for F8 RILs in the field in Korea, with some selected F9 lines exhibiting HAP and LAP during repeated planting in Bogor, Indonesia. The allelopathic potential of the Nongan/Sathi rice cross was confirmed on F10 RILs by evaluating agronomic performance. Through this multi-generation work, some promising lines derived from japonica and indica rice-types exhibiting high and low allelopathic traits, may be used in closely monitored agronomic field trials.
Manual Tags: Allelopathy; Barnyardgrass; Breeding; Echinochloa crusgalli; Low input; Rice; Scopus; Screening; search.rice; SPV; Sustainable weed management; TITLE-ABS-KEY (ratoon* W/5 (oryza OR rice)) AND DOCTYPE (ar); TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: SINSKAJA, E. N.
Title: Promising forage plants and methods of using them.
Abstract Note: Several practical suggestions for more extensive use of wild material in breeding various forage plants are put forward. Cereals for forage. Wild Hordeum spon-taneum, in which the brittle ear may be eliminated by breeding and selection, and several ryes, including a land variety from the Altai territory, an alternative rye Orahoiskaja and several wild perennial rye forms found in the Caucasus, are regarded as promising. Grasses. Some ecotypes of Bromus erectus are referred to as having economic possibilities. Selection of Lasiagrostis bromoides for vigour and tender leaf and tests of Digraphis species as perennial spring forage plants are advocated. Legumes. Medicago glutinosa subsp. polychroa, found in Georgia, is regarded as useful material for breeding lucerne for earliness and resistance to diseases, and M. coerulea, and several species related to it, as useful material for breeding for resistance to drought. An improved hybridization technique by which fertile hybrids from crosses between lucernes with 16 and those with 32 chromosomes can be obtained is referred to. The method involves fertilization of non-emasculated flowers with mixed pollen containing self pollen or pollen of related species and forms. It is expected that, in breeding work with red clover, heterotic hybrids may be produced by hybridization involving highly fertile Armenian alpine strains and northern Pecorskii [Pecora] strains. Trials of vetches, Vicia variabilis at Erevan and V. amoena at Stavropolj, are mentioned. More extensive use of wild species of sainfoin, which cross readily with the cultivated varieties and with each other, is urged. Mention is made of Meshetskii sainfoin, a wild species resistant to drought and scorching by the sun, which has been selected in Georgia. Tests of the Armenian species should include Lathyrus miniatus. Root crops for forage. Trials as green fodder plants of wild Daucus species, remarkable for their moderate soil requirements and resistance to drought, and of wild Pastinaca and wild Algerian and Caucasian Beta species, which are tolerant of soil salinity, are advocated.
Manual Tags: search.rye; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 ("rye" OR secale) NOT "rye$grass"); WOS

Author: Luster, J.; Kalbitz, K.; Lennartz, B.; Rinklebe, J.
Title: Properties, processes and ecological functions of floodplain, peatland, and paddy soils
Publication Title: Properties, processes and ecological functions of floodplain, peatland, and paddy soils
Manual Tags: perennial W/1 (oryza OR rice); ScienceDirect; search.rice; SPV

Author: Muller, M.; Seidel, H.; Schulz, H.
Title: Prophylaxis of grass tetany of cattle with magnesium chloride final liquor. 4. Magnesium-substituting effect of the liquor in fertilization of single crops.
Abstract Note: In field trials in 1974 application of MgCl2 final liquor (a by-product of the potassium industry) to plots of fodder rye, perennial ryegrass and cocksfoot at 1m3/ha (96kg Mg/ha) significantly increased the contents of Mg in the soil and plants. Contents of plant-available Mg in the soil before application of MgCl2 and at 10 and 20 days afterwards were 2, 3.7 and 8 mg/100 g soil, respectively, in rye plots and 2.7, 5.1 and 5.9 mg in ryegrass plots. Contents in soil of control plots were 3, 2 and 2.2 mg in rye and 6.9, 5.8 and 4.4 mg in ryegrass. Mg contents in
Manual Tags: search.rye; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 ("rye" OR secale) NOT "rye$grass"); WOS

Author: Anonymous
Title: Prospect for creation of perennial wheat not bright says Saskatchewan Professor.
Abstract Note: A very brief report is given of an address by J. B. Harrington to the Saskatchewan Agricultural Graduates' Association. Canadian plant breeders, the speaker pointed out, have only had limited success in the development of perennial wheat, and particular mention is made of unsatisfactory yield in seasons of insufficient rainfall, and the difficulties of weed control. Brief reference to current breeding work on winter wheat is also included.
Manual Tags: search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); WOS

Author: Shi, Chunlong; Tian, Chao; Li, Jilin; Zhang, Yanming
Title: Prospect of Perennial Wheat in Agro-ecological System
Publication Title: 2011 2nd International Conference on Challenges in Environmental Science and Computer Engineering (CESCE 2011)
Abstract Note: The development of perennial crops through breeding would help deal with the multiple issues involving environmental conservation and food security in a world of shrinking resources. Perennial wheat offers a new solution to the long-standing problems of soil erosion and degradation associated with conventional annual small-grain cropping systems. This paper presents morphological characteristics and cytogenetics analysis of perennial wheat that from crosses between octoploid trititrigia and Thinopyrum intermedium, introduces the important role of perennial wheat at the development of sustainable agriculture system as well as discusses the significant utilization of perennial wheat in ecological benefits.
Manual Tags: ecological benefits; perennial W/1 (triticum OR wheat); perennial wheat,Thinopyrum; ScienceDirect; search.wheat; soil erosion control; SPV; Sustainable agriculture

Author: Cox, Thomas S.; Glover, Jerry D.; Van Tassel, David L.; Cox, Cindy M.; DeHaan, Lee R.
Title: Prospects for developing perennial-grain crops
Abstract Note: Perennial plants, growing in mixtures, make up most of the world's natural terrestrial biomes. In contrast, monocultures of annual crops are sown on more than two-thirds of global cropland. Grain and oilseed crops are the foundation of the human diet, but to date there are no perennial species that produce adequate grain harvests. Yet perennial plant communities store more carbon, maintain better soil and water quality, and manage nutrients more conservatively than do annual plant communities, and they have greater biomass and resource management capacity. These advantages provide a base from which to begin hybridization and selection for increased resource allocation to developing seeds, a decades-long process that must overcome or circumvent genetic complications. Breeding programs aimed at developing perennial grain crops have been initiated in wheat, sorghum, sunflower, intermediate wheatgrass, and other species.
Manual Tags: search.grain; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 grain); WOS

Author: SKADOVSKII, S. N.; MESSINEVA, M. A.; USPENSKAYA, V. I.; TELITCHENKO, M. M.
Title: Prospects for improving the quality of the water in the North Donets-Donbass Canal by regulating the bio-coenoses of aquatic organisms From: REFERAT ZHUR BIOL, 1964, No. 4D331. (Translation)
Abstract Note: Deterioration of the water is caused by the growth and death of species of Cladophora and Enteromorpha. Because the contamination arises in the canal itself and is not brought in from the North Donets River, stable biocoenoses must be created in the canal. Since the development of these algae is caused by an excess of nitrogenous compounds, competitive species must be introduced, e. g. perennial wild rice, whose decomposition process differs sharply from that of algae and which has the further advantage of being mowable. The acclimatization of unionlds in the canal will make possible a decrease in the turbidity of the water and destruction of detritus and organo-mlneral accumulations around the plants. For the lower reaches of the canal, the installation of the new "bloabsorbers" on whose working surfaces bacteria and algae become attached and develop, will lower the concentration of biogenlc elements and increase that of O2.
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: Ali, M. H.; Hoque, M. S.; Jahiruddin, M.
Title: Prospects of boro ratoon cropping in alleviating rural poverty in haor areas of Bangladesh.
Abstract Note: The haor areas in Bangladesh (low lying basins that stay under water for about 6 months of the year) are mainly located in the greater Sylhet-Mymensingh districts and the areas' economy is highly under-developed because only a single boro (summer) crop can be grown a year. The government has undertaken embankment and sluice-gate projects to protect boro crops from early flash flood water. While the major beneficiaries of these projects will be medium and large farmers who own over 70% of the cultivable land, the landless and small farmers may also benefit from more secured ratoon cultivation. This study, conducted in three haor areas in Sunamganj district, indicates that ratoon cropping is an important source of self-employment for the landless and small farmers and contributes a significant portion of their income. Ratoons are currently grown on only a small proportion of boro land, because of the problem of early flash floods, and lack of interest by medium and large farmers who own the land, for reasons of social prestige. However, the area under ratoon is expected to increase as embankments are completed. Reducing the risk of ratoon cropping through embankments increases the probability that medium and large farms will grow ratoons. The government can protect the interests of the rural poor by enacting rules for a ratoon sharing arrangement.
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: Sarma, Kamal; Ravisankar, N.; Roy, S. D.; Grinson, G.; Srivastava, R. C.
Title: Prospects of fish culture in the broad bed and furrow system in Andaman.
Abstract Note: The BBF system of cultivation is a technique of land manipulation to grow vegetables and fodder right in the midst of rice field. The technology involves making of broad beds and furrows alternatively in rice fields. In the BBF, the raised broad bed areas are used for cultivating seasonal vegetable or fodder crops during monsoon season months. To study the economic feasibilities of fish culture in broad bed and furrow system a study was undertaken in south Andaman. Indian major carps and air breathing fishes were cultured in the furrows along with rice (Taichung -sen-Yu) separately. No supplementary feeding and other management techniques were adopted for fishes. From 6000 m 2 area of furrow fish production of 25 and 45 kg of magur and singhi and 78 and 73 kg of Indian major carps were obtained. Best return was obtained in rice+ratoon+ground nut+fishes (singhi and magur) combination and B:C ratio was 0.94 where fishes alone contributed for 12.5 B:C ratio.
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: Bahar, F. A.; Datta, S. K. De
Title: Prospects of increasing tropical rice production through ratooning.
Abstract Note: In 5 experiments in 1973-5 with 6 rice cv., methods of producing more than one crop, after the dry season crop in irrigated areas and after the wet season crop in rain-fed areas, were studied. The effects of spacing and cutting ht. of the main crops and of N level on ratoon crops were examined in 2 experiments, and the effects of main crop tillage, N rate and cutting ht. and water measurement in ratoon crops were also investigated. Grain yields of ratoon crops were 0-2.6 t/ha and varied among cv., being higher when the main crop was cut at 15 cm rather than at 5 cm. All the cv. grown as ratoon crops were infected with grassy stunt virus disease, but those grown at the same time by transplanting or direct sowing were not infected, indicating the high risk of growing virus-susceptible cv. as ratoon crops.
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: Song, S.; Tao, Y.; Zhang, H.; Wu, Y.
Title: Psathyrostachys huashanica, a potential resource for resistance to Barley yellow dwarf virus-GAV
Abstract Note: Barley/cereal yellow dwarf viruses (B/CYDVs) are recognized as serious pathogens of wheat. It is critical to find diverse sources of resistance to reduce yield losses caused by B/CYDVs. Psathyrostachys huashanica Keng, a perennial wheat-relative species, has been regarded as a potential germplasm resource because of its excellent performance on resistance to drought, salinity, wheat stripe rust and the take-all fungus. In this work, the susceptibility to BYDV-GAV of P. huashanica was evaluated following inoculation using reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) and double antibody sandwich-enzyme linked immunosorbent assay (DAS-ELISA). Additionally, an aphid-transmission test was conducted for further verification of virus infection. The results indicated that BYDV-GAV could infect P. huashanica but accumulated to much lower level in inoculated leaves of P. huashanica than in the leaves of resistant wheat line Zhong 5 and the susceptible wheat line 7182. However, no BYDV-GAV particles could be detected in new leaves of inoculated P. huashanica. In this study, we first demonstrated that P. huashanica is highly resistant to BYDV-GAV and possibly has a negative effect on the movement of the viral particles from inoculated leaves to new leaves.
Manual Tags: AGRICOLA; Barley yellow dwarf virus; Psathyrostachys huashanica; Resistance; Scopus; search.wheat; SPV; Susceptibility; TITLE-ABS-KEY (perennial W/1 (triticum OR wheat)) AND DOCTYPE (ar); TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); TX (perennial N1 (triticum OR wheat)); Wheat-relative species; WOS
Automatic Tags: barley; drought tolerance; fungi; germplasm; leaves; pathogens; Psathyrostachys huashanica; reverse transcriptase polymerase chain reaction; salinity; viruses; wheat

Author: Ermishev, V.Yu.; Naroditsky, B.S.; Khavkin, E.E.
Title: Putative MADS-Box retropseudogenes in rye (Secale L.)
Abstract Note: The fragments of MADS-box genes belonging to the agamous and agamous-like structural classes were isolated by direct amplification of genomic DNA from annual rye (Secale cereale L.) and perennial rye (Secale montanum Guss.). The characterized fragments (deposited in the Genbank as the accession nos. AF332885-AF332887 and AF346894) comprise the complete sequences of exons 1 to 5 and lack corresponding introns. Their nearest homologs are the maize genes zag1 and zag5 (the Genbank accession nos. L18924 and L46398). One more agamous-like fragment isolated from annual rye (AF362364) is similar to the TaMADS12 wheat gene (AB007505). The fragment comprises exons 3-5 and contains a 105-bp insert between the exons 3 and 4; this insert does not resemble any MADS-box introns presently known. We assume that all these fragments of MADS-box genes are retropseudogenes.
Manual Tags: Arabidopsis thaliana; MADS-box genes; Oryza sativa; Pseudogenes; Retrotransposons; Scopus; search.rice; search.rye; search.wheat; Secale cereale; Secale montanum; SPV; TITLE-ABS-KEY (perennial W/1 ("rye" OR secale) AND NOT ("rye?grass" OR ryegrass)) AND DOCTYPE (ar); Triticum aestivum; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 ("rye" OR secale) NOT "rye$grass"); WOS; Zea mays

Author: Demiral, İlknur; Ayan, Emine Aslı
Title: Pyrolysis of grape bagasse: Effect of pyrolysis conditions on the product yields and characterization of the liquid product
Abstract Note: In this study, pyrolysis of grape bagasse was investigated with the aim to study the product distribution and their chemical compositions and to identify optimum process conditions for maximizing the bio-oil yield. Particular investigated process variables were temperature (350–600 °C), heating rate (10–50 °C/min) and nitrogen gas flow rate (50–200 cm3/min). The maximum oil yield of 27.60% was obtained at the final pyrolysis temperature of 550 °C, sweeping gas flow rate of 100 cm3/min and heating rate of 50 °C/min in a fixed-bed reactor. The elemental analysis and heating value of the bio-oils were determined, and then the chemical composition of the bio-oil was investigated using chromatographic and spectroscopic techniques such as column chromatography, 1H NMR and FTIR. The fuel properties of the bio-oil such as flash point, viscosity and density were also determined. The bio-oils obtained from grape bagasse were presented as an environmentally friendly feedstock candidate for bio-fuels.
Manual Tags: Bio-oil; Characterization; Grape bagasse; perennial W/1 (oryza OR rice); Pyrolysis; ScienceDirect; search.rice; SPV

Author: DONG, Chen-fei; CAI, Qing-sheng; WANG, Cai-lin; HARADA, Jiro; NEMOTO, Keisuke; SHEN, Yi-xin
Title: QTL Analysis for Traits Associated with Feeding Value of Straw in Rice (Oryza sativa L.)
Abstract Note: Genetic improvement of the digestibility of rice straw for increasing the utilization of the whole rice plant as feedstuffs is an important way to solve the feedstuffs shortage in southeastern China. To elucidate the genetic basis of the traits affecting the digestibility of rice straw, a rice population of 111 recombinant inbred lines (RILs) derived from a cross of Nekken 2×Gaya was used to map the quantitative traits loci (QTLs) for in vitro dry matter digestion (IVDMD), the percentages of nonstructural carbohydrate (NSC) and acid detergent fiber (exclusive of residual ash, ADFom) in 2005 and 2006. IVDMD was positively correlated with NSC, and negatively correlated with ADFom. A total of 16 QTLs were detected in the two years, and the amounts of variation explained by individual QTLs ranged from 6.9% to 15.5%. Some QTLs for IVDMD and ADFom on chromosome 2 were detected in the two years. On chromosome 2, the interval RM475–RM3515 contained QTLs for IVDMD in the two years and for NSC in 2006 only, while the interval RM3874–RM5305 influenced ADFom in the two years and NSC in 2005 only. At those loci, Gaya contributed favorable alleles to IVDMD and NSC, while Nekken 2 contributed positive alleles to ADFom.
Manual Tags: Acid detergent fiber; feeding value; in vitro dry matter digestion; nonstructural carbohydrate; quantitative trait locus; ratoon* W/5 (oryza OR rice); Rice straw; ScienceDirect; search.rice; SPV

Author: Chuan-hang, Yang; Yu-ping, Wang; Bin, Tu; ZengYu-qing; Shi-gui, Li
Title: QTL Analysis of Cold Resistance and Ratooning Ability by Using indica-japonica RIL Populations in Rice
Abstract Note: A molecular linkage map containing 105 SSR markers was constructed by using a RIL population which was derived from the F-7 descent of a cross between japonica glutinous rice variety Nuo 89-1 and an indica variety Shuhui 527. The cold resistance of bud for both the parents and the RIL was investigated at 5 degrees C low temperature, and their survival and ratooning ability were evaluated under natural temperature conditions in winter. QTL analysis showed that the cold resistance of rice was controlled by QTLs and followed a continuous distribution in RIL population. Two QTL, qCtg3 and qCtg5 controlling cold resistance at bud stage were located on chromosome 3 and 5. explaining 75.57% and 79.04% phenotypic variation, respectively. A major QTL, qCtr5 controlling the survival and ratooning ability in rice was mapped on chromosome 5. Two QTLs(qRa4, qRa5) conferning ratooning capacity were detected on chromosome 4 and 5, explaining 8.17% and 7.09% phenotypic variation, respectively. qCtg5 qCtr5 and qRa5 locus were simultaneously linked to RM153 on chromosome 5, which indicated the relationship of those traits.
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: ChuanHang, Yang; YuPing, Wang; Bin, Tu; Ting, Li; Liang, Hu; ShiGui, Li
Title: QTL analysis of rice ratooning ability and related agronomic traits by using RIL populations.
Abstract Note: A molecular linkage map containing 105 SSR marks were constructed by using a RIL population generated from the F 7 descent of a cross of japonica glutinous rice variety 89-1 and an indica heavy panicle backbone hybrid rice lines SH527. By using this map, we mapped 15 QTLs for seven agronomic traits in the normal season, which was distributed on chromosomes 1, 2, 3, 5, 6, 7, and 10, respectively. The LOD value varied from 2.10 to 7.51, and the contribution rate varied from 3.77% to 25.37%, among which seven QTLs had the contribution rate larger than 10.0%. The number of a single trait QTL varied from 1 to 5. Two QTLs ( qRA4, qRA5) affecting rice ratooning ability were detected on chromosomes 4 and 5, the contribution rate was 8.17% and 7.09%, and the additive effect was 0.32 and -0.39, respectively. Thirty-six QTLs for agronomic traits were detected in two seasons and among which eight were detected repeatablely. According to the results, the ratooning ability was remarkably negatively related to the effective ear of the normal season. In addition, the ratooning ability was tightly positively related to the effective ear in the ratooning season, and was negatively related to the grain number per ear and seed density. The QTLs mapping results revealed that the effective ear of normal season and ratooning season is the main factor that affects rice's ratooning ability.
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: Liang, Chen; Qiao-jun, Lou; Zong-xiu, Sun; Yong-zhong, Xing; Xin-qiao, Yu; Li-jun, Luo
Title: QTL mapping of low temperature germinability in rice
Abstract Note: A double haploid population (DH) with 198 lines, derived from anther culture of F-1 hybrid between indica line Zhenshan 97B and japonica perennial rice line AAV002863 was used to construct a linkage map with 140 SSR markers and to investigate the low temperature germinability (LTG). The germination rates of Zhenshan 97B and AAV002863 were 79.7% and 30.1%, respectively, and those of the DH population ranged from 0% to 100% at 15 degrees C for six days. Quantitative trait loci (QTLs) controlling low temperature germinability were identified on chromosomes 3 and 10. The percentage of observed phenotypic variance attributed to qLTG-3 and qLTG-10 were 12.6% and 12.9%, respectively. Allele from Zhenshan 97B increases the LTG at the region of qLTG-3, while allele from AAV002863 increases the LTG at the region of qLTG-10. One pair of epistatic interaction were detected between loci on chromosomes 3 and 10. The main-effect QTL on chromosome 10 was also involved in epistatic interaction.
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: Soltani, S.M.; Hanafi, M.M.; Karbalaei, M.T.; Khayambashi, B.
Title: Qualitative land suitability evaluation for the growth of rice and off-seasons crops as rice based cropping system on paddy fields of central guilan, Iran
Publication Title: Indian Journal of Science and Technology
Abstract Note: Land suitability evaluation analysis is a necessecary to achieve optimum management and utilization of the available land resources for sustainable agricultural crops production. One of the most serious and urgent constraint in lowland paddy fields of Iran is to improve agricultural land management and cropping patterns either to increase the agricultural production with proper land use resources or to get more income from out of season plant as a second crops. Therefore, the objective of this study was to find the most suitable off-season crops after rice. Qualitative Land Suitability (QLS) classification of fifteen first and second agricultural crops in the paddy fields of the Guilan plain in Iranunder RBCS that covers an area of 40567 ha was carried out. By using the semi-detailed method of soil classification, 24 soil unites at 11 soil series in five different physiographic units were indentified (river alluvial plains (5 series), low lands (2 series), river banks (2 series) and coastal plains and sand dunes (2 series)). Land and climate characteristics of each crop with its requirements were also determined and rated based upon Parametric and simple limitation method proposed by Sys et al. [1]. The obtained indexes indicated that land suitability classes varied from S2 (moderately suitable) to N (Not suitable). The highest land suitability class for crops are: S2 for Rice, Spinach, Beans, Radish, Garlic, Shall cress, Clover, Lettuce, Rape seed, Bean (vulgaris and faba cultivars) and S3 for Wheat, Carrot, Barley, Triticale, and Rice (Ratoon). The most important limiting factors are: climate (low temperature and high rainfall at vegetative and reproductive growth stages), drainage (shallow water table depth), soil (texture) and fertility (low organic carbon content, pH) (alone or in combination) respectively, those influence adversely on the land suitability classes, especially climatic and drainage limitation, because of growing season in autumn and winter Verification of the factors and their relative significance is very important for decision on land suitability.
Manual Tags: Land suitability; Paddy fields; Rice; Scopus; search.rice; Second crops; SPV; TITLE-ABS-KEY (ratoon* W/5 (oryza OR rice)) AND DOCTYPE (ar)

Author: Nagaraja, A.; Mahadevappa, M.
Title: Quality of main and ratoon crop seeds of rice.
Abstract Note: Data are tabulated on germination, vigour and yield-related characters for the ratoon and main crops of 7 varieties. Grain viability deteriorated more quickly in the ratoon than in the main crop, resulting in poor germination, field emergence and vigour. Differences were observed between plants grown from grain collected from the two crops in 1000-grain weight, root and shoot lengths and seedling dry weight.
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: Vasundhara, S.; Mahadevappa, M.
Title: Quality of main and ratoon crop seeds of some rice cultivars.
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: SHIBAEV, P. N.
Title: Quality of the grains of wheat-Agropyron hybrids
Publication Title: Trudy Zonal Inst Zernovovo Khoziaistva Nechernozemnoi Polosy Sssr
Abstract Note: A large number of species of wild grasses of the tribe Hordeae, particularly in the genera Aegilops and Agropvron, have a high gluten content in their grains. The percentage of dry protein in the grains of Agropvron elongatum, A. glaucum,, and A. junceum ranged from 24.-3 1.6, and that in wheat vars. Lutescens 062 and Caesium 0111 from 17.7-17.8. Great diversity in protein and gluten content exists even among different strains of the same species of Agropvron. For 170 different annual lines of wheat-Agropyron hybrids the quality of the grain was determined indirectly by the time taken for falling off of the seed coat during fermentation with yeast at 32[degree]C. Of these, 37 were superior to the wheat var. Lutescens 062, 14 were inferior, and 119 about the same. Direct tests of porosity and volume yield of bread in 10 of these gave higher values than Lutescens 062 for 8 vars. One var., no. 22580, was slightly superior to both Lutescens 062 and Caesium 0111 in these qualities and in protein content at both the Gorki-Leninsk and Nemchinovka exp. stations. Fertilization with 1 metric ton of manure, 259 kg. of N, 252 kg. of P, and 126 kg. of K per acre had a greater effect in increasing protein content and bread quality in hybrid 22850 than in Lutescens 062. Perennial wheats nos. 34085 and 23086 have higher dry protein and gluten content than Lutescens 062, and their bread has a higher volume yield, but the color of the flour and bread is dark. Bread made from perennial wheat of the 1940 harvest had a poor texture due to the insufficient ripeness of the grains. || ABSTRACT AUTHORS: G. L. Stebbins, Jr
Manual Tags: search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); WOS

Author: SH, GARIFULLIN F.; G, ASHIMOV E.
Title: QUANTITATIVE ANALYSIS OF VARIOUS HUMIDITY REGIMENS CONTENT OF NITRATE NITROGEN AND MOBILE PHOSPHORUS IN CHERNOZEMS AND GRAY FOREST SOILS OF THE CIS-URAL BASHKIR-ASSR RUSSIAN-SFSR USSR AS A FUNCTION OF CULTIVATED CROPS
Abstract Note: By comparing selected media and their dispersion, the degree of different parameters was evaluated according to layers of the soil profile. The degree of similarity and difference of soil varieties of 1 field of crop rotation or the same soil under the effect of different cultivated crops was studied. Sweet clover, maize, spring wheat, perennial grass, potato, peas and oats, winter rye, and millet were cultivated.
Manual Tags: search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); WOS

Author: SKOSYREVA, A. N.
Title: Question of the salt resistance of perennial wheat.
Abstract Note: Seeds of Cicin's perennial wheat No. 34085 were sown in pots in sand and watered with Hell-riegel's solution to which varying quantities of NaCl and Na 2S0 4 had been added. The variety Caesium 0111 was used as control. The perennial wheat seedlings developed more vigorously and produced better plants in solutions containing 0.04% NaCl than in those without NaCl. Thus in the normal solutions without salt the yield of grain was 16.43 grm. and in those with 0.04% NaCl it was 18.46; with 0.25% NaCl the yield was still almost normal and the yield of grain in 0.35% NaCl solutions was only reduced to 11.03; even in 1% solutions some grain was formed. The control plants of Caesium 0111 failed to grow at all in 1% NaCl solutions and produced no grain even in 0.35% and 0.25% solutions. In isotonic solutions of NaCl and Na 2SO 4 the perennial wheats gave higher yields with Na 2SO 4. Thus with 0.35% NaCl the yield per pot (three plants) was 11.03 grm. and with 0.5% Na 2SO 4 it was 14.76 grm. ; with 1% NaCl the yield was 3.63 grm. and with 1.5% Na 2SO 4 it was still 10.76 grm. In the early growth phases however the perennial wheat was less tolerant of the sulfates than the chlorides. The straw was found to contain larger quantities of salts than the grain and in fact exuded much of it on to the surface. The plants grown in high salt concentrations bore quite large grains, which had a higher protein content than those grown without salt.
Manual Tags: search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); WOS

Author: cicin, N. V.
Title: Questions of distant hybridization in plants.
Abstract Note: Five generations of hybrids of Triticum x Elymus have now been produced and mutagenic treatments are being applied in an attempt to remove the dominant wheat genes reducing the number of grains per spike. True perennial wheats have been selected from the Triticum x Agropyron hybrids, some of them persisting for two and even three years; a few of them have ears resembling those of bread wheat. Other hybrids produce an aftermath after the grain has been reaped and give several crops of autumn forage; conversely they can be cut for early forage before the grain crop is formed; they have lax ears with vitreous grain of medium size and the ears ripen while the leaves are still green. Among the annual wheats produced from these crosses, five have been approved; one of them, Vostok [East], is completely resistant to loose smut, another, 599, is resistant to bunt and 172 to brown smut [ sic].
Manual Tags: search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); WOS

Title: R-11913 (Herbicide).
Abstract Note: See also Abs. 68. The experimental herbicide R-11913 (3'-hydroxypropionanilide isopropylcarba-mate 80% w.p.) is an off-white solid with a m.p. of about 168degreesC, vapour pressure (25degreesC) 0.001 and solubility in water (20degreesC) 15 ppm (solubilities given for 5 other solvents). The acute oral dose for rats is > 4640mg/kg. R-11913 may be incorporated 1-3 in. deep at 1-4 lb a.i/ac before sowing or it may be applied pre-em. if rainfall or irrigation is sufficient to move it into the soil; it enters weeds through their roots after germination. It may also be applied post-em, to weeds < 2 in. high; again uptake is via roots. Crops tolerating 1-4 pounds per acre include lucerne, barley, sugar-beet, lentils [ Lens culinaris], peas, potatoes, sorghum and wheat and perennial crops tolerating 2-6 pounds per acre include established deciduous fruit trees and grape vines. Susceptible annual grasses include Digitaria spp., Avena fatua and Echinochloa spp. and susceptible broad-leaved weeds include Mollugo verticillata, Polygonum spp., Kochia scoparia, Chenopodhtm album. Amaranthus spp., Portulaca spp. and Ambrosia spp. Established perennials were resistant.-P.K.
Manual Tags: search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); WOS

Author: Janse, A. R. P.
Title: Radar reflections from crops, forest and soil.
Abstract Note: Data are given on the attenuation of X-band radar at 9375 MHz and 45 deg angular incidence by crops of oats, sugar beet, potatoes and wheat in June and the seasonal course of attenuation in sugar beet, field beans, oats, perennial ryegrass, wheat and lucerne. Cereals and grassland behaved as though they consisted of vertical needles of water and exhibited considerable differences in reflection for horizontally and vertically polarized radar. Adequate explanations of the results were not always immediately apparent.
Manual Tags: search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); WOS

Author: O, NELSON S.; M, HECKERT R.; E, STETSON L.; W, WOLF W.
Title: RADIO FREQUENCY ELECTRICAL TREATMENT EFFECTS ON DORMANCY AND LONGEVITY
Abstract Note: Seed lots of 7 small-seeded legume species and winter oats, winter rye, and perennial ryegrass were exposed to 39 MHz electric fields of known field intensities for various time periods and tested for germination response. The radiofrequency (RF) treatments effectively increased germination of alfalfa, red clover and ladino clover through reduction of hard seed percentages. Significant increases in germination for these 3 spp., as a result of electrical treatment, were retained in temperature and humidity controlled storage for 14 yr. Differences between treated and untreated samples held in a seed warehouse without temperature and humidity control tended to disappear after a few years because hard seeds became permeable naturally as the seeds aged. RF treatments overcame postharvest dormancy in winter oats. They did not affect the longevity of winter rye seed held for 6 yr after treatment.
Manual Tags: search.rye; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 ("rye" OR secale) NOT "rye$grass"); WOS

Author: V, RACHINSKII V.; G, KRETOVA L.; A, DEMCHENKO E.; KHANG, TRUONG DIN'
Title: RADIOINDICATOR EVALUATION OF THE PLANT UPTAKE OF 2 4-D FROM THE SOIL
Abstract Note: The work evaluates the scale of uptake of 14C-2,4-D from the soil by plants. Depending on the soil type the plants [wheat, perennial grasses] can absorb from 1% (soddy-podzolic soil) to 0.1% (chernozems) of the applied herbicide. Losses of 2,4-D due to its uptake by plants can be considerable on light sandy soils.
Manual Tags: search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); WOS

Author: A, DERZAVIN
Title: Raising perennial wheats and other crops.
Abstract Note: In many crop plants the perennial surpass the annual forms in greatly increased and earlier yields in its second, third and fourth year as compared with its first year's output. Many perennial spring crops are also highly frost resistant. The author's early work with hybrids between wild and cultivated species is mentioned with more recent work on the production of perennial wheat and the problem of eliminating the F 1 sterility in wheat x perennial rye crosses. After 189, 000 pollinations, hybrid combinations were chosen which on back-crossing gave a set of 0.01-2.00 per cent. Only a very small proportion of the plants raised from such seed showed normal fertility. In a cross between Leucurum 1364/1 and perennial rye apparently back-crossed to perennial rye two large seeds were obtained of the Triticum durum type. One of these seeds produced a normally fertile plant. The hybrid proved to have 42 chromosomes and was therefore an amphidiploid resulting from the union of two unreduced gametes. No back-crossing to the rye had therefore occurred. This plant produced seed in 1933 and twice (summer and winter) in 1934 and 1935, thus indicating a perennial wheat had been obtained. The numerous progenies were resistant to drought and rust, being only slightly attacked by brown rust and not at all by stem or yellow rust; they also showed high yields, e.g. 70 grains per ear with a 1000 grain weight up to 50 grm. The perennial wheat is a vigourous plant which in the second year frequently gives a higher yield and usually ripens 10-15 days earlier than the autumn sowing of the first year. It can also be used for hay, yielding about 1-2 tons per hectare. The second harvest in the year amounts to 50-80 per cent of the first and the 1000 grain weight is 35 grm. The winter-hardiness of the hybrids has been little studied but the winter form survived the 1935-36 winter. In 1937 a few plants without the defect of fragile ears were selected and the type is to be tested in variety trials. A coefficient of multiplication of 11, 339 has been obtained and, in 1938 it is hoped, 30, 000 grains may be obtained from 100 plants from one grain. Spring forms were also found among the hybrids. Similar investigations axe being conducted with perennial hybrids from perennial x annual rye and wild perennial rye plants are also being collected for breeding plants suitable for use as hay. Work has also been done on perennial vetches ( Vicia cracca and Lathyrus species) and sorghum. Forms of L. latifolius with non-splitting pods have been obtained, while perennial sorghum hybrids should prove valuable in view of their normal fertility, great drought resistance, hardiness under poor soil conditions and high coefficient of multiplication.
Manual Tags: search.rye; search.sorghum; search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 ("rye" OR secale) NOT "rye$grass"); TS=(perennial NEAR/1 sorghum); TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); WOS

Author: Mahiboobsa, M.; Dharmaraj, P.S.; Fakruddin, B.; Muniswamy, S.; Yamanura; Sony, T.; Rajkumar; Patil, R.; Bankar, C.
Title: RAPD markers for identification of stable CMS and restorer lines of pigeonpea (Cajanus cajan)
Publication Title: Plant Cell Biotechnology and Molecular Biology
Abstract Note: To achieve success in hybrid seed production, it was essential to develop cytoplasmic genetic male sterility system (CMS) that would be acceptable and feasible to both farmers as well as commercial hybrid seed producer. Identification of pigeonpea CMS lines and restorers using Random amplified polymorphic DNA (RAPD) molecular markers in the early stage of growth is important and economical in the long duration pigeonpea. The CMS lines derived from the wild (Cajanus canifolius-ICPA-2043, ICPA-2078 and Cajnus scarabaeoides - GT-288A) and the cultivated species of Cajanus cajan. The male sterile (A) and restorer lines could be easily differentiated with certain random primers. A total of 54 RAPD primers screened, 12 were found to be polymorphic. The four primers viz., AB-04, N-04, N-12 and 1-10 were exhibited good resolution. However, the primer OPI-23 was successful in differentiating the male sterile and restorer lines. These can be effectively utilized for the development of new CMS-based hybrid pigeonpea technology by identification of RAPD markers linked to male sterile, maintainer and restorer lines at molecular level.
Manual Tags: Cytoplasmic gentic male sterility; Gentic male sterility; Random amplified polymorphic DNA; Scopus; search.pigeonpea; SPV; TITLE-ABS-KEY ("long duration" W/1 (cajanus OR "pigeon?pea" OR pigeonpea)) AND DOCTYPE (ar)

Author: Ge, S.; Oliveira, G. C. X.; Schaal, B. A.; Gao, L. Z.; Hong, D. Y.
Title: RAPD variation within and between natural populations of the wild rice Oryza rufipogon from China and Brazil
Abstract Note: Genetic variation within and between eight natural populations of Oryza rufipogon from China and Brazil was investigated at the DNA level by analysis of RAPD fragments. Out of 60 random primers, which were initially screened against DNA from four individuals, 20 generated highly reproducible RAPD fragments which were then used for further population analysis. With these primers, 95 discernible DNA fragments were produced and 78 (82.1%) were polymorphic, which indicated that high levels of genetic variation existed in these natural populations. In addition, the Chinese populations showed greater polymorphism than those from Brazil at both the population and regional levels. This is noteworthy considering that the Chinese populations are from a relatively restricted area of China. The factors responsible for these findings include the contrasting mating systems in the Brazilian and Chinese populations, and gene flow from annual cultivated rice to perennial natural populations in China. An Analysis of Molecular Variance (AMOVA) was used to apportion the variation between individuals within populations, between populations within regions, and between regions. Results showed that 61.8% of the total genetic diversity resided between the two continents, whereas only 14.9% and 23.3% was attributable to population differences within regions and to individual differences within a population, respectively. The great genetic differentiation between the Chinese and Brazilian populations is in agreement with recent treatment of the American form of O. rufipogon as a separate species, O. glumaepatula.
Manual Tags: AGRICOLA; Genetic variation; Oryza glumaepatula; Oryza rufipogon; RAPDs; Scopus; search.rice; SPV; TITLE-ABS-KEY (perennial W/1 (oryza OR rice)) AND DOCTYPE (ar); TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (oryza OR rice)); TX (perennial N1 (oryza OR rice)); WOS
Automatic Tags: Brazil; China; genetic polymorphism; genetic variation; Oryza rufipogon; random amplified polymorphic DNA technique

Author: Payne, C.E.; Wolfrum, E.J.
Title: Rapid analysis of composition and reactivity in cellulosic biomass feedstocks with near-infrared spectroscopy
Abstract Note: Background: Obtaining accurate chemical composition and reactivity (measures of carbohydrate release and yield) information for biomass feedstocks in a timely manner is necessary for the commercialization of biofuels. Our objective was to use near-infrared (NIR) spectroscopy and partial least squares (PLS) multivariate analysis to develop calibration models to predict the feedstock composition and the release and yield of soluble carbohydrates generated by a bench-scale dilute acid pretreatment and enzymatic hydrolysis assay. Major feedstocks included in the calibration models are corn stover, sorghum, switchgrass, perennial cool season grasses, rice straw, and miscanthus. Results: We present individual model statistics to demonstrate model performance and validation samples to more accurately measure predictive quality of the models. The PLS-2 model for composition predicts glucan, xylan, lignin, and ash (wt%) with uncertainties similar to primary measurement methods. A PLS-2 model was developed to predict glucose and xylose release following pretreatment and enzymatic hydrolysis. An additional PLS-2 model was developed to predict glucan and xylan yield. PLS-1 models were developed to predict the sum of glucose/glucan and xylose/xylan for release and yield (grams per gram). The release and yield models have higher uncertainties than the primary methods used to develop the models. Conclusion: It is possible to build effective multispecies feedstock models for composition, as well as carbohydrate release and yield. The model for composition is useful for predicting glucan, xylan, lignin, and ash with good uncertainties. The release and yield models have higher uncertainties; however, these models are useful for rapidly screening sample populations to identify unusual samples.
Manual Tags: Biofuels; Biomass conversion; Cellulosic biomass; Compositional analysis; Enzymatic hydrolysis; FT-NIR; Herbaceous feedstocks; High-throughput assay; Multivariate analysis; NIR spectroscopy; PLS; Pretreatment; Reactivity; Scopus; search.sorghum; SPV; TITLE-ABS-KEY (perennial W/1 sorghum) AND DOCTYPE (ar); TS=(perennial NEAR/1 sorghum); WOS

Abstract Note: Rare and wild species of cereal genera are listed: (Triticum timopheevi Zhuk., T. macha Dek. et Men., T. aegilopoides Bal. and T. araraticum Jakubz.), barley (Hordeum spontaneum C. Koch. and H. bulbosum L.), annual rye (Secale chaldicum An. Fhed., S. vavilovi Grossh.) and perennial rye (S. kuprijanovi Grossh. and S. montanum) collected by an expedition of the Institute in the mountainous regions of Armenia, Georgia and Azerbaidzhan. || ABSTRACT AUTHORS: Courtesy NSF (PL 83-480) 1963

Author: Tripolskaja, L.; Ignotas, V.
Title: Rates and frequency of pulverized limestone application on dernopodzolic acid sandy loam soils.
Publication Title: Lietuvos Zemdirbystes Instituto Mokslo Darbai, Zemdirbyste
Abstract Note: The effects of application frequency and rates of pulverized limestone on soil acidity and yields of potatoes, barley, rye, perennial grasses and Lupinus grown in various rotations on dernopodzolic acid sandy loam soils were studied during 1972-1993 in a field experiment in Lithuania. The results showed that increasing the application by up to 2-3.5 times at the beginning of every 5 years neutralized soil acidity and had a positive effect on the P, K and Al contents of soil. However, there was no beneficial effect on crop yields and productivity.
Manual Tags: search.rye; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 ("rye" OR secale) NOT "rye$grass"); WOS

Author: Jones, D. B.
Title: Ratoon crop management.
Abstract Note: A series of experiments to assess the efficiency of various rice ratoon cropping techniques are reported briefly. Main crop sowing rates of 50, 100 or 150 kg/ha and row spacing of 15, 20 or 25 cm had no effect on ratoon crop yield. Cutting height (10, 20, 30, 40 and 50 cm) had a significant effect on ratoon crop maturity, height and yield. However, cv. selection had a greater effect on yields. Draining the main crop appeared to be the stimulus for ratoon crop regrowth rather than cutting or reflooding. Greatest response to N (60 kg/ha) occurred when applied 4 weeks after main crop draining, at the panicle initiation stage of the ratoon crop. The occurrence of rice stink bugs ( Oebalus pugnax) in the crop was monitored; numbers increased steadily during the grain filling period of the ratoon crop.
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: Tanesaka, E.
Title: Ratoon crop maturation in an abandoned rice field, Orysa sativa ssp. japonica, that passed the winter in central Japan.
Publication Title: Memoirs of the Faculty of Agriculture of Kinki University
Abstract Note: Ratoon crop maturation and weed flora were observed in an abandoned paddy field of rice, Oryza sativa subsp. japonica, in Nara Prefecture, central Japan. The presence of weed flora, which included perennial species such as Andropogon virginicus and Solidago altissima, supported the fact that two years had passed since any agricultural management had occurred, as confirmed by an interview with a few farmers. This observation showed that Japanese rice is perennial in fields even after the passage of winter.

Author: Wali, M. C.; Mahadevappa, M.; Krishna Murthy, R. A.
Title: Ratoon crop performance of experimental rice hybrids in Karnataka.
Abstract Note: Eight hybrids plus 3 controls were evaluated for ratooning performance during kharif 1992. Highest ratooning ability and increased yields were noted in the hybrid IR-54752A/ARC-11353, followed by hybrids having the same maternal parent IR-54752A. Highest yields were recorded in IR-54752A/IR-54 (67.57 q/ha) followed by IR-54752A/IR-27315 (60.67 q/ha) [1 quintal = 100 kg].

Author: Reddy, T. G.; Mahadevappa, M.; Coffman, W. R.
Title: Ratoon crop performance of some promising rice genotypes.
Abstract Note: Data are tabulated on height, days to maturity, and grain yield per plant and production per day in 45 genotypes and in 25 selected genotypes in the main and ratoon crops in the wet and dry seasons of 1980-81. Inton and Mingolo performed better than the others when ratooned; they flowered late in both crops and thus escaped damage from low temperatures in the ratoon crop.

Author: McCormick, M.E.; Morris, D.R.; Ackerson, B.A.; Blouin, D.C.
Title: Ratoon cropping forage sorghum for silage: Yield, fermentation, and nutrition
Abstract Note: Two field experiments were conducted on Lexington silt loam soil (fine-silty, mixed, thermic Typic Paleudalf) to identify a harvest regime that would improve the nutritive value of ensiled whole-plant sorghum [Sorghum bicolor (L.) Moench] while maintaining silage yield. In a 1-yr preliminary study, first-cut sorghum was harvested at mid-vegetative, late-vegetative, boot, bloom, and hard-dough stages of maturity. Regrowth was harvested in late August. In a 2-yr experiment, yield, ensiling losses, intake, and in vivo apparent digestibility of vegetative sorghum (initial and ratoon cuts wilted 24 h) were compared with direct cut hard-dough-stage sorghum. Forages were stored in 1.8-Mg-capacity (fresh wt.) experimental sites and, upon opening, were fed to lambs (Ovis aries). Results from the preliminary experiment indicated that dry matter (DM) yield of first-cut sorghum was greatest at the hard-dough stage; however, nutritional value was greatest for the mid-vegetative stage. Maximum yield for the combined harvests was obtained when first harvest was made at boot stage, The 2-yr experiment average DM yields were 7.3 Mg ha(-1) for combined initial (mid-vegetative stage) and ratoon crops, compared with 6.7 Mg ha(-1) for the single hard-dough-stage harvest. Ensiling losses did not differ with harvest regime. Vegetative sorghum was more digestible than sorghum harvested at the hard-dough stage (670 vs, 570 g kg(-1)). These studies suggest that sorghum harvested twice per season (with wilting) will produce a higher quality silage than a single hard-dough stage cutting, without yield reduction.
Manual Tags: AGRICOLA; Scopus; search.sorghum; SPV; TITLE-ABS-KEY (ratoon* W/5 sorghum) AND DOCTYPE (ar); TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 sorghum); TX (ratoon* N5 sorghum); WOS
Automatic Tags: crop yield; digestibility; dry matter accumulation; feed intake; forage crops; harvest date; lambs; maturity stage; nutritive value; ratooning; Sorghum bicolor; sorghum silage

Author: Palchamy, A.; Purushothaman, S.; Rajagopal, A.
Title: Ratoon cropping in rice for better water resource management in river command area in Tamil Nadu.
Abstract Note: In a field experiment in 1984-85 at Madurai, Tamil Nadu, rice cv. Bhavani, Ponni and IR 20 were kept flooded to a depth of 5 cm or were flooded to 5 cm depth after the disappearance of ponded water (DPW) and were given 50-125 kg N/ha. The crops were ratooned after the plant crop. Ratoon cropping decreased grain yield by between 45.3 (with Bhavani) and 91.5% (IR 20) compared with the plant crops in 1984/85. Yields were decreased by similar levels the following year. Grain yield was higher where the crop was flooded to 5 cm after the DPW compared with keeping the crop flooded to a depth of 5 cm. The application of 125 kg N gave the highest grain yield.
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: Reddy, T. G.; Mahadevappa, M.; Kulkarni, K. R.
Title: Ratoon cropping of rainfed rice.
Abstract Note: In 1976, rice cv. Intan was ratooned and yielded 2.2 and 1.7 t/ha for the 1st and 2nd crop after 166 and 109 days, resp., with no additional fertilizer. In 1977-8, rice cv. Intan was ratooned in the Chikmagalur district and yielded 2.0-5.5 t/ha in the 1st crop and 2.3-7.7 t/ha in the 2nd crop. The 2nd crop matured in 133 days and grain yield increased with increasing N application from 0 to 50 kg N/ha.
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: Mahadevappa, M.
Title: Ratoon cropping of rice in Karnataka.
Abstract Note: Results of a trial on lowland of the rain-fed tract of Karnataka showed that paddy yields of the ratoon crop of rice cv. Itan were 76-350%, depending on fertilizer rates, of the maincrop yield. The duration of the maincrop and ratoon crop was 185 and 133 days, resp.
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: EVATT, N. S.; BEACHELL, H. M.
Title: Ratoon cropping of short-season rice varieties in Texas.
Abstract Note: In Texas the practice of ratoon cropping, which appears to be a practical means of increasing rice yields, is gradually being extended by using early-maturing varieties (109-132 days from sowing to maturity). Yields of 1500-2000 lb of paddy/ ac have been reported from some ratoon crops. Under favourable growing conditions the new, very early rice varieties (100-105 days) gave yields comparable with those of later varieties. The use of these very early varieties will eliminate much of the risk involved in ratoon cropping by reducing the necessity for early sowing.-E.B.O.

Author: Adigbo, S. O.; Olojede, M. O.; Harris, P. J. C.; Ajayi, O.
Title: Ratooned lowland nerica rice varieties as an option for triple cropping in inland valleys of derived savannah in Nigeria
Abstract Note: Although triple cropping in inland valleys of Nigeria is technically feasible, the third crop between the main crop and dry season non-rice crop has been considered not to be economically viable because of poor crop establishment due to soil inundation. The identification of an appropriate technology with low input, such as ratooning, would allow this niche to be utilized. Field experiments were conducted at the University of Agriculture, Abeokuta, Nigeria in 2007-2008 and 2008-2009 cropping seasons to evaluate the performance of the main and ratooned crops of lowland NERICA (New Rice for Africa) rice (Oryza sativa L.) varieties in a lowland rice-ratooned rice-fluted pumpkin (Telfairia occidentalis Hook F.) sequence. The experiment was laid out in a randomized complete block design with three replicates. The lowland rice varieties used were NERICA-L 19, NERICA-L 20, NERICA-L 22, NERICA-L 24, OFADA, NERICA-L 26, NERICA-L 41, NERICA-L 42, NERICA-L 44 and NERICA-L 47. The grain yield of the main rice crop ranged from 5.0 to 7.3 t ha(-1) in 2007-2008 cropping season and from 4.1 to 9.1 t ha(-1) in 2008-2009. The ratooned rice had a grain yield of 1.0-4.7 t ha(-1) in 2007-2008 and 1.2-3.4 t ha(-1) in 2008-2009. The total grain yield obtained in 2007-2008 from the main and ratooned rice crops in seven months was 6.7-11.6 t ha(-1), while in 2008-2009 it was 5.3-2.6 t ha(-1). The fresh leaf yield of fluted pumpkin ranged from 14.6 to 16.9 t ha(-1) in 2007-2008 and from 18.3 to 19.8 t ha(-1) in 2008-2009, similar to previously reported rainy season unfertilized yields. Thus, a ratooned rice crop appears to be a feasible technology capable of boosting rice production and consequently increasing the overall productivity of the inland valley in a rice-rice-vegetable cropping sequence.
Manual Tags: Scopus; search.rice; SPV; TITLE-ABS-KEY (ratoon* W/5 (oryza OR rice)) AND DOCTYPE (ar); TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: Gorbet, D. W.
Title: Ratoon evaluations of grain sorghum hybrids.
Abstract Note: In a trial of 7 commercial hybrid varieties and another of 9 F 1 testcross populations, sown in April 1984 and harvested first in August and again, as ratoon crops, in November, resistance to anthracnose ( Colletotrichum graminicola) in first and ratoon crops among the hybrid varieties was highest in NK Savanna 5 and DeKalb DK64, but was in general higher among the testcrosses, being highest of all in A-Tx622 X F-A54IS12609 and A-Tx622 X F-NKS3. NK Savanna 5 gave the highest yields of all, both in the first harvest (7060 kg/ha) and the ratoon crop (5050 kg/ha). Among the testcrosses, A-Tx622 X F-A54IS12609 outyielded all others in both harvests.
Manual Tags: search.sorghum; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 sorghum); WOS

Author: Gorbet, D. W.
Title: Ratoon evaluations of grain sorghum testcrosses in north Florida.
Abstract Note: Tabulated data are presented on disease scores for infection by Colletotrichum and on grain yield in both the plant and ratoon crop of
Manual Tags: search.sorghum; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 sorghum); WOS

Author: Pandey, N.; Singh, N. B.
Title: Ratoon feasibility of long-duration pigeonpea hybrids.
Abstract Note: Experiments were conducted in 1995-97 to assess the grain yield performance of ratoon crop in long duration pigeon pea [ Cajanus cajan] hybrids. In the first year 74 entries (71 hybrids and 3 controls) were sown followed by 38 entries (35 hybrids and 3 controls) in the second year. Data were recorded on yield in both main and ratoon crops. The highest grain yield (2314 kg/ha) was recorded in the main crop by the hybrid NDPH 94-20 while in the ratoon crop the highest yield (1413 kg/ha) was recorded by hybrid RAUPH 9001. In the second year trial, the highest yields were recorded by RAUPH 9507 main crop (3981 kg/ha) and RAUPH 9501 ratoon crop (1300 kg/ha). Hybrids RAUPH 9001 and RAUPH 9501 have the same genetic background (MS 3783 * Bahar). Studies of the plant population were also conducted. On the basis of these findings it is concluded that it is not feasible to raise a ratoon crop in long duration pigeon pea hybrids in northern India. Due to high rainfall and excess soil moisture, plants attained 4-5 m height and suffered serious diseases.
Manual Tags: search.grain; search.pigeonpea; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 grain); TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (cajanus OR "pigeon$pea")); WOS

Author: CHAUHAN, JS; LOPEZ, FSS; VERGARA, BS

Author: T, KUPKANCHANAKUL; S, VERGARA B.; K, KUPKANCHANAKUL
