Author: Shivakumaraswamy, P. H.; Mahadevappa, M.
Title: Ratooning ability of 20 F 3 rice crosses.
Abstract Note: Analysis of data from 8 varieties and 20 crosses advanced to the F 3, revealed that ratooning measured 3 weeks after the main harvest varied from 4% in Karikagga to 99% in Mahsuri. The average ratooning ability (RA) of the crosses was 90% vs. 64% for the parents. This is taken to indicate dominant and heterotic expression by genes governing RA. Mutants of parental varieties with good RA generally maintained the trait, but Intan mutants 1, 2 and 3 did not; this is taken to indicate that recessive genes govern RA in this material.
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: T, KUPKANCHANAKUL; S, VERGARA B.; K, KUPKANCHANAKUL
Title: RATOONING ABILITY OF DEEPWATER RICE AND RATOON CROP HERBAGE PRODUCTION
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: Qiu, B. Q.; Jin, Q. S.
Title: Ratooning ability of IR varieties in Hangzhou, China.
Abstract Note: A total of 28 varieties in the IR series (IR5-IR64) were evaluated for ratooning ability (RA) in a screenhouse by cutting mature plants to a height of 15 cm and measuring ratooning 15 days later on a 1-9 scale. IR29, IR30, IR43 and IR64 had relatively high RA (1 on scale) and their ratoon crops yielded c. 50% of main crops. In 13 varieties, RA was intermediate and ratoon crops yielded 20-30% of main crops. Data are tabulated for all 28 varieties.
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: Srinivasan, K.; Purushothaman, S.
Title: Ratooning ability of medium duration rice varieties.
Abstract Note: In field trials at Madurai, in 1986-87, the ratoon crop of cv. Bhavani performed better than Ponni with regard to growth, yield attributes and grain yield. The Bhavani ratoon crop produced 2752 kg/ha grain which was 50.2% of the maincrop yield whereas the ratoon crop of Ponni (1754 kg/ha) was 38% of the maincrop yield. Different spacings (15, 20 or 25 *
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: Roy, B. C.; Hossain, M. A.; Rahman, M. A.
Title: Ratooning ability of photoperiod-sensitive rice varieties transplanted in the boro season.
Abstract Note: A field experiment was conducted at the Bangladesh Rice Research Institute, Charbadna farm, Barisal, from boro 2001 to aman 2002. Seven photoperiod-sensitive rice cultivars (BR22, BR23, BRRI dhan34, BRRI dhan37, BRRI dhan38, BRRI dhan40 and BRRI dhan41), including three fine grain aromatic cultivars (BRRI dhan 34, BRRI dhan37 and BRRI dhan38), were transplanted on 15 and 30 December 2001. After harvest of the boro crop, the ratoons were allowed to grow and in the succeeding aman, a good harvest was obtained from those ratoons. In the boro season, the highest yield was obtained from BRRI dhan41 (7.51 t/ha) followed by BR23 (7.06 t/ha). The yield of aromatic cultivars was ~5 t/ha. The ratoon yields of both aromatic and non-aromatic cultivars in the succeeding aman season were also encouraging and produced ~2 t/ha, which was more than the average yield of local cultivars normally cultivated in the transplanted aman season in that region. The highest yield was obtained by BR23 (2.87 t/ha) followed by BRRI dhan37 (2.63 t/ha). From this experiment, it was revealed that the photoperiod-sensitive rice cultivars could be planted in the early boro season and the ratoons from this crop also produced a good harvest. This might be a low-cost rice cultivation technique in those areas, where crop establishment in the transplanted aman season is somewhat difficult due to the early intrusion of tidal water in the field at the end of boro season.
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: Roy, S. K. B.; Mondal, J.
Title: Ratooning ability of some photoperiod - sensitive rices.
Abstract Note: Ten photoperiod sensitive deepwater and wetland rice cv. grown during 1982 were harvested in May by cutting to 8 or 12 cm. Ratooning ability, scored 15 days after cutting, was not affected by cutting ht. Photoperiod sensitive cv. scored higher than cv. IR36; cv. SR26B showed highest ratooning ability with 97% of hills producing new tillers, followed by NC1263 (94%), Achra 10811 and NC365 (93%) and Tillakachari and Bhasamanik (91%).
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: S, ARUMUGACHAMY; P, VIVEKANANDAN; M, SUBRAMANIAN
Title: RATOONING ABILITY OF SOME RICE CULTIVARS AND HYBRIDS
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: Singh, B. K.; Thakur, R. B.; Singh, R. P.
Title: Ratooning ability of some summer rices on saline-calcareous soil.
Abstract Note: Ratooning ability of 7 rice cv. was determined in field trials carried out on calcareous silt loam in 1979. The C8585 and NC1626 ratoons yielded 32 and 24%, resp., of the main crop yields of 3.5 and 4.1 t/ha. Cv. NC1626 yielded higher overall when the yields of the main and ratoon crops were combined. The ratoon crop was 25% shorter than the main crop. The number of panicle-bearing shoots/hill of the ratoon was positively correlated with the number for the main crop. The ratoon crop had lower grain wt. than the main crop and matured 70 days earlier.
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: H, CHAUDHRY A.; M, PASHA M. A.; U, SAMOO A.
Title: RATOONING ABILITY OF SORGHUM CULTIVARS
Publication Title: Proceedings of the Pakistan Science Conference
Manual Tags: search.sorghum; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 sorghum); WOS

Author: Patil, R. C.; Mali, V. S.; Kadam, D. E.
Title: Ratooning ability of ten sorghum hybrids.
Abstract Note: The hybrids were grown in kharif 1983 and subsequently also harvested as winter (ratoon) crop. The performance of SPH221, SPH225, SPH232, MSH50 and CSH5 showed promise in respect of yields of grain and of fodder in each of the two crops.
Manual Tags: search.sorghum; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 sorghum); WOS

Author: MUKERJI, S. K.; CHATTERJEE, B. N.
Title: Ratooning in Juar (Andropogon sorghum)
Manual Tags: search.sorghum; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 sorghum); WOS

Author: SARAN, A. B.; PRASAD, M.
Title: Ratooning in paddy.
Abstract Note: A trial was laid down at the Rice Experimental Area, Sabour, India, using Aus CH 10 rice, to determine the effect of harvesting at 4 different cutting heights on the yield of the subsequent ratoon crop. The treatments were randomized and replicated 6 times. The best ratoon-crop yield, equal to 31% of the yield of the preceding main crop, was obtained when the main crop was harvested at a cutting height of 14 in.-W.J.B.
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: Chatterjee, B. N.; Bhattacharyya, S.; Debnath, P.
Title: Ratooning of rice.
Abstract Note: Tabulated data are presented on grain yield, number of panicles per hill, number of filled grains per panicle and 1000-grain weight for five varieties in wet and dry season ratoons, after transplanting.
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: GARCIA DURAN, E.
Title: Ratooning of rice.
Abstract Note: In some regions of Colombia ratooning of rice is practised, and 2-3 consecutive crops are obtained. Experiments showed that yields of the first and the second ratoon were 54 and 59% less, respectively, than that of the sown crop. There was more weed growth in ratooned fields and a higher loss of the elements N, P and K. Although production costs per ha of ratooned rice were lower, the cost per kg of rice was higher than that of a sown crop. From Trop. Abstr. 18: k48.-R.B.
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: Thanunathan, K.; Kalyanasundaram, D.; Imayavaramban, V.; Singaravel, R.; Kandasamy, S.
Title: Ratooning of rice: An economically viable agrotechnology for flood prone areas.
Abstract Note: A field experiment was conducted to find out the effect of ratooning of rice and feasibility of growing rice-fallow pulses in the flood prone tail-end areas of Cauvery deltaic zone. Rice cultivars having different duration viz., long duration (Ponmani, White ponni and CO 43), medium duration (ADT 38) and short duration (PY5) were tried in different rice growing seasons viz., 'Samba', late 'Samba', 'Kuruvai', 'Thaladi' and late 'Kuruvai' seasons. Ratooning was practised in short and medium duration varieties with a view to accommodate a pulse crop in rice-fallows. Results of the study showed that short duration rice variety was amenable for ratooning and rice-fallow blackgram could be successfully grown in the correct season (January-March). The cumulative crop yields (main rice crop, ratoon rice and blackgram), cropping intensity, net income and cost: benefit ratio were maximum when short duration rice cv. PY 5 was cultivated in 'Kuruvai' followed by ratooning of the same rice cultivar and growing of blackgram in rice fallows.
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: G, RAMSHE D.; R, BAPAT D.; S, POL P.; S, MANE S.
Title: RATOONING PERFORMANCE OF HYBRID SORGHUM CSH-5
Abstract Note: The ratooning potential of hybrid sorghum (CSH-5) was studied by harvesting the main crop at different times and irrigating the ratoon at different critical stages, keeping different numbers of tillers for ratoon. Harvesting the main crop at physiological maturity (15 days before the normal date), irrigation at all critical stages of plant growth, and free tillering of ratoon yielded maximum grain and fodder yield.
Manual Tags: search.sorghum; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 sorghum); WOS

Author: Sanni, K.A.; Ojo, D.K.; Adebisi, M.A.; Somado, E.A.; Ariyo, O.J.; Sie, M.; Akintayo, I.; Tia, D.D.; Ogunbayo, S.A.; Cissé, B.; Sikirou, M.; Adekoya, M.A.
Title: Ratooning potential of interspecific NERICA rice varieties (Oryza glaberrima×Oryza sativa)
Abstract Note: Field experiment was conducted in Deve (6°48 N, 1°47'E, 72 masl) in the Savannah zone of Benin Republic, to examine the increase in grain yield due to ratooning. Eighteen upland interspecific varieties (NERICA1-18) and their Oryza glaberrima (CG 14) and one of the O. sativa (WAB 56-104) parents were used in a Randomized complete block design with three replications. The first (main) crop was harvested at mass maturity, after which the tillers were hand mowed to stubbles of about 10 cm tall. These were then left without any further input, until the ratooned plants were ready for harvest. The result showed a large variation in the ratoon performance among NERICA, with ratoon ability ranging from 13% (NERICA 2) to 39% (NERICA 14 and 17). Total grain yield (main plus ratoon) was significantly different (p<0.001) from that of the main harvest. The maximum total grain yield was 6.141 ha-1 for NERICA 2 followed by NERICA 15 and 11 (6.02 and 6.01 t ha-1, respectively). The yield increase of more than 1.5 t ha-1 (the average yield of upland rice in Sub-saharan Africa) recorded in NERICA, with no additional input was very encouraging. This will presumably increase with additional input during ratoon. Therefore, NERICA rice is able to fructify twice, hence farmers can harvest more rice and make more profit.
Manual Tags: Grain yield; NERICA; Ratoon; Rice; Scopus; search.rice; Second harvest; SPV; TITLE-ABS-KEY (ratoon* W/5 (oryza OR rice)) AND DOCTYPE (ar)

Title: Ratooning Potential of Interspecific NERICA Rice Varieties (Oryza glaberrimaxOryza sativa)
Abstract Note: Field experiment was conducted in Deve (6 degrees 48 N, 1 degrees 47'E,

Author: GuiLian, Zhang; NaiMei, Tu; ShunTang, Zhang
Title: Ratooning properties of axillary buds in hybrid rice.
Abstract Note: The ratooning characteristics of the 2-line hybrid rice combination, Peiliangyou 500 and a 3-line hybrid rice Shanyou 63 were studied. Compared to Shanyou 63, Peiliangyou 500 had higher ratooning ability of axillary buds and living bud rate, showing significant heterosis in terms of dry matter accumulation and non-structural carbohydrate content at the late stage of the main crop. A significant relationship between living bud rate and dry matter weight of the different stem nodes, soluble carbohydrate content and starch content. Superoxide dismutase and peroxidase activities increased 20 days after full heading of the main crop and reached its highest at the maturity stage.
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: ZhenXie, Yi; NaiMei, Tu; Pu, Wang; PingPing, Chen
Title: Ratooning properties of axillary buds of two-line hybrid rice in vivo and in vitro.
Abstract Note: Two-line hybrid rice combinations Pei' ai 64S/E32 and Peiliangyou 500 were used to investigate the ratooning properties of axillary buds from different nodes in vivo and in vitro. High-stubble and node-cutting experiments were conducted. The length of the middle nodes' axillary buds was longer than that of other nodes during fully heading stage (FHS) in the main crop. The growth rate of all axillary buds was slow from FHS to 20 days after FHS, and accelerated from 20 days after FHS to maturing stage. However, the growth rate of higher nodes' axillary buds was faster than that of lower nodes. Plant height of ratooning rice of the 2nd and 3rd node from the top of Pei'ai 64S/E32 and of the 2nd, 3rd and 4th node from the top of Peiliangyou 500 in vitro were shorter than in vivo. The higher the nodal position the bigger the difference in height. Compared to those in vivo, the panicle length and spikelets per panicle of all ratooning rice nodes in vitro were higher. The lower the node position the bigger the difference, which suggests that the dependence of middle and higher node axillary buds to stubble nutrition was higher than that of lower nodes, and the limitation of nutrient application to lower node axillary buds was higher than that to higher ones in vivo. The difference between ratooning rate of axillary buds from different nodes was bigger in vivo than that in vitro. The correlation between total N content of internodes and ratooning rate of corresponding axillary buds was positive at 0.05 level from FHS to 10 days after FHS, but it was negative or very weak from 20 days after FHS to maturing stage. The higher soluble sugar and starch content in full heading stage did not increase ratooning rate. From 10 days after FHS to maturing stage, negative correlation existed between starch content and ratooning rate, and positive correlation existed between soluble sugar content, soluble sugar and starch in gross and ratooning rate. The results suggests that total N content of internodes is the main deciding factor in determining the ratooning rate of corresponding-node axillary buds in early productive stage.
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: LOMTE, MH; DABHADE, RS
Title: RATOON MANAGEMENT IN GRAIN-SORGHUM (SORGHUM-BICOLOR)
Manual Tags: search.sorghum; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 sorghum); WOS

Author: Molina, A. B.; Cabangbang, R. P.; Quintana, R. V.
Title: Ratoon performance of selected grain sorghum varieties at three levels of plant population and nitrogen fertilization.
Abstract Note: Data are given on number of productive ratoons/ha, grain yield, stover yield, av. panicle length, number of grains/panicle, 100-grain wt., leaf angle, days to flowering and plant ht. for 7 grain sorghum cv. grown with 0, 100 or 200 kg N/ha, 50% applied at sowing and the other 50% side-dressed after 3 wk, and at plant populations of 120 000, 200 000 or 280 000/ha. With increase in plant population, there were decreases in panicle length and number of grains/panicle, and an increase in the number of productive ratoons. It was concluded that 100 kg N/ha was opt. for number of productive ratoons, grains/panicle and panicle length; number of days to flowering was reduced by 10 days with 100 kg N/ha compared with plots without N fertilizer.
Manual Tags: search.sorghum; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 sorghum); WOS

Author: Karunakaran, K.; Jalajakumari, M. B.; Sreedevi, P.
Title: Ratoon performance of some short-duration rice cultures.
Abstract Note: 20 rice cv. were grown at Pattambi during the 1981 kharif season. Seedlings were transplanted at 15 cm * 10 cm spacing and received 70-35-35 kg NPK/ha. The main crop was harvested to leave 15 cm tall stubble and entries were then assessed for ratoon performance. Main crop grain yields varied from 3.2 to 4.9 t/ha while ratoon crop yields varied from 0.1 to 0.5 t/ha.
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: Faria, E. A.; Soares, P. C.
Title: Ratoon production of irrigated rice in Minas Gerais. Present situation and prospects.
Abstract Note: Data are given of ratoon production of irrigated rice in Minas Gerais in 1981-3, av. yield being about 30% of that of the first crop. In other countries a corresponding figure of 50% is obtained. Factors to be taken into consideration for ratoon management include sowing date, cv., cutting height, fertilizers, water management and weed control. Trials to study rice ratoon cropping are being established in various regions of Minas Gerais.
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: Sankaranarayanan, K.; Satheeshkumar, N.; Solaimalai, A.; Sanicaran, N.
Title: Ratoon ratio and ratoon index of multicut fodder sorghum varieties as influenced by intercropping and nitrogen levels
Abstract Note: A field experiment was carried out during rabi 2004 and summer 2005 at Tamil Nadu Agricultural University, Coimbatore to assess the influence of intercropping and nitrogen levels on ratoon ratio and ratoon index of multicut fodder sorghum varieties. Harasona variety registered higher ratoon ratio and index. Sole sorghum gave maximum ratoon ratio and ratoon index. Application of 60 kg N/ha after cutting resulted in higher ratoon ratio and index but it was comparable with that of application of
Manual Tags: search.sorghum; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 sorghum); WOS

Author: Rao, P. K. A.; Shivashankar, G.
Title: Ratoon regeneration in rices and their single-cross hybrids after three cuttings.
Abstract Note: After the third ratooning, stubble of 15 varieties and 16 hybrids among them was either left in situ or transplanted in single rows. Height and tiller number/plant were recorded 35 days later. Both characters varied among genotypes. In general, hybrids had greater ratoon regeneration capacity than varieties, TN1 X Type 3 being the best hybrid. Many varieties produced no tillers in situ. Propagation of single-cross hybrids in this way is considered useful because it allows continuous production of F 2 seed and maximizes the population size of the second segregating generation.
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: Maharudrappa, S. K.
Title: Ratoon rice as influenced by stubble height and nitrogen levels.
Abstract Note: In a field experiment in 1985-86 at Mudigere, Karnataka, plant rice cv. Intar crop was cut to stubble heights of 2.5, 5-7.5 or 7.5-12.5 cm and grown as a ratoon crop and given 0-57 kg N/ha. Grain yield was not affected by stubble height and was highest with 57 kg N (2.32 t/ha).
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: Nayak, R. L.; Das, M.; Mandal, S. S.
Title: Ratoon rice can yield well.
Abstract Note: Tabulated data are given for grain yield and number of days to maturity for nine cultivars grown as a main crop in the wet and dry seasons and as a ratoon crop after the dry season crop. IET3629 yielded highest (2.7 t/ha) in the shortest time (95 days). Its ratoon yield was 12% higher than its main crop yield in wet season. Other cultivars with good ratooning ability were IET4555 (2.1 t/ha) and IET3273 (1.8 t/ha).
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: Islam, Muhammad Shamiul; Hasanuzzaman, Mirza; Rokonuzzaman, Md
Title: Ratoon Rice Response to Different Fertilizer Doses in Irrigated Condition
Abstract Note: The response of different fertilizer doses was studied on the ratoon crop as well as main crop. The different fertilizer doses under the study were F-1 (N=90, P2O5 = 45, K2O=50, S=13, Zn = 4: in kg ha(-1)), F-2 (N=105, P2O5 = 55, K2O=60, S=13, Zn = 4: in kg ha(-1)), F-3 (N=120, P2O5 = 65, K2O=70, S=13, Zn = 4: in kg ha(-1)), F-4(N=135, P2O5=75, K2O=80, S=13, Zn=4: in kg ha(-1)) and F-5 (N=150, P2O5 =85, K2O = 90, S=13, Zn = 4: in kg ha(-1)). In the main crop, the highest grain and biological yields were produced by F-3 dose. The highest straw yield was produced by F-4 dose. The lowest grain yield and the lowest biological yield were produced by F-1 dose and the lowest straw yield was produced by F-2 dose. The highest crop duration was found using F-1 dose and the shortest crop duration was found using F-3 doses. In the ratoon crop, the highest grain yield, straw yield and biological yield was produced by F-5 dose whereas the lowest grain yield, straw yield and biological yield was achieved with F-1 dose. The longest crop duration was observed using F-2 dose and the shortest crop duration was recorded using F-5 dose.
Manual Tags: Crop duration; Fertilizer dose; Ratoon; Rice; Scopus; search.rice; SPV; TITLE-ABS-KEY (ratoon* W/5 (oryza OR rice)) AND DOCTYPE (ar); TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); WOS; Yield

Author: Bond, J.a.; Bollich, P.k.
Title: Ratoon Rice Response to Nitrogen Fertilizer [electronic resource]
Abstract Note: Field research was conducted for 2 years to determine the N fertilizer application rate producing maximum ratoon rice grain yields. The long-grain rice cultivars Cheniere, CL161, Cocodrie, and Cypress were grown using a delayed-flood, drill-seeded production system. Immediately following harvest of the main crop, N fertilizer at rates of 30, 60, 90, or 120 lb/acre was applied as urea. No ratoon rice lodging was observed in any site-year at any N fertilizer application rate. Ratoon days to 50% heading was delayed 1 day when the N fertilizer application rate was increased from 60 to 90 or 120 lb/acre. Ratoon rough rice yield increased significantly from 2390 to 2710 lb/acre as the N fertilizer application rate increased from 30 to 90 lb/acre, but increasing the N fertilizer application rate from 90 to 120 lb/acre did not improve ratoon rough rice yields. No ratoon rice lodging was observed in any site-year at any N fertilizer application rate. In this study, the N fertilizer application rate producing maximum ratoon rice yields in the Gulf Coast area of the United States was 90 lb/acre.
Manual Tags: AGRICOLA; search.rice; SPV; TX (ratoon* N5 (oryza OR rice))
Automatic Tags: crop production; fertilizer application; fertilizer rates; grain yield; lodging; Louisiana; nitrogen fertilizers; Oryza sativa; ratooning; rice; urea

Author: Chakraborty, P. K.; Roy, S. K. B.
Title: Ratoon tillering in short-duration rice varieties.
Abstract Note: After the main harvest (crop sown in November, 1985, transplanted January, 1986) of a set of varieties in the 1985 International Yield Nursery-Early, irrigation water and 20 : 10 : 10 Kg/ha NPK were applied. Ten varieties (listed) showed high ratooning ability. Varieties with a high percentage of regeneration (91-100%) had the highest number of ratoon tillers/hill (5-13).
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: Cox, C.M.; Garrett, K.A.; Cox, T.S.; Bockus, W.W.; Peters, T.
Title: Reactions of perennial grain accessions to four major cereal pathogens of the Great Plains
Abstract Note: Methods of disease management used in annual grain crops, especially cultural practices designed to disrupt the disease cycle of a particular pathogen, will not necessarily be applicable to perennial grain crops. Resistance to multiple pathogens, therefore, will clearly be important in disease management. The objective of this research was to evaluate disease resistance in 10 perennial grain accessions (one to two accessions of each: perennial wheat (Thinopyrum sp. x Triticum aestivum), intermediate wheatgrass (Thinopyrum intermedium), perennial rye (Secale montanum), hexaploid triticale (Triticum turgidum x S. montanum), octoploid triticale (Triticum aestivum x S. montanum), tetraploid perennial rye (Secale cereale x S. montanum), and tall wheatgrass (Thinopyrum ponticum)) to tan spot (caused by Pyrenophora tritici-repentis), take-all (caused by Gaeumannomyces graminis var. tritici), wheat streak mosaic, and barley yellow dwarf, four important diseases of the Great Plains. Several of the grasses were resistant to tan spot, barley yellow dwarf, and wheat streak mosaic. Indeed, the wild grasses and perennial donors T. intermedium (including BFPMC1), T. ponticum, and S. montanum, in addition to Permontra, a tetraploid perennial rye, were highly resistant to all three diseases. Additionally, the remaining grasses tested were also more resistant to tan spot than the susceptible wheat control. However, none of the 10 grass accessions appeared highly resistant to take-all, and substantial losses in biomass were observed, although such effects may be moderated under field conditions due to the potential for take-all decline in perennial plantings.

Author: Bian, Shaomin; Jiang, Yiwei
Title: Reactive oxygen species, antioxidant enzyme activities and gene expression patterns in leaves and roots of Kentucky bluegrass in response to drought stress and recovery
Abstract Note: The objective of this study was to investigate accumulation of reactive oxygen species, antioxidant enzyme activities, and gene expression patterns of antioxidant enzymes of Kentucky bluegrass (Poa pratensis L.) under drought stress and recovery. Grass (c.v. Midnight II) was subjected to soil drying for 5 d and then rewatered for 1 d in growth chambers. Drought stress increased superoxide (O2−) production of leaves and hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) content of the leaves and roots. Recovery enhanced leaf O2− production and root H2O2 content. Lipid peroxidation of the roots increased 4.5-fold and 2.4-fold under drought stress and recovery, respectively. Drought stress increased the leaf activities of ascorbate peroxidase (APX, EC 1.11.1.11), monodehydroascorbate reductase (MDHAR, EC 1.6.5.4), dehydroascorbate reductase (DHAR, EC 1.8.5.1), and the root activities of catalase (CAT, EC 1.11.1.6), glutathione reductase (GR, EC 1.6.4.2) and MDHAR, while reducing the root activities of superoxide dismutase (SOD, EC 1.15.1.1) and DHAR, respectively. The increased leaf activities of APX, MDHAR, DHAR and the root activities of MDHAR and CAT were observed after rewatering, compared to the control. For the leaves, the expressions of iron SOD (FeSOD), cytosolic copper/zinc SOD (Cu/ZnSOD), chloroplastic Cu/ZnSOD, and DHAR were down-regulated by drought stress but recovered to control level after rewatering, while the expressions of GR and MDHAR were up-regulated and remained that levels after recovery. For the roots, the expressions of cytosolic Cu/ZnSOD, manganese SOD (MnSOD), cytosolic APX, GR, and DHAR were down-regulated under drought stress but recovered except for GR and DHAR, while MDHAR expression was up-regulated. No differences in CAT transcript abundance were noted among the treatments. Antioxidant enzymes and their gene expressions may be differentially or cooperatively involved in the defense mechanisms in the leaves and roots of Kentucky bluegrass exposed to drought stress and recovery.
Manual Tags: Antioxidative enzyme; Drought stress; Gene expression; perennial W/1 (oryza OR rice); Poa pratensis L.; Reactive oxygen species; ScienceDirect; search.rice; SPV

Author: Ong, C. K.; Singh, R. P.; Khan, A. A. H.; Osman, M.
Title: Recent advances in measuring water loss through trees.
Abstract Note: A review done in 1986 of the techniques available for measuring transpiration in agroforestry systems [ Black, C.R. Measurement of transpiration in agroforestry systems. Consultant's report. Hyderabad, India; ICRISAT, 114 pp.] concluded that porometry and sap-flow techniques offered the best potential. This paper describes 2 new sap-flow techniques, which have been evaluated over 2 yr. The first is the 'custom heat-pulse system' developed in New Zealand by Edwards, R., and the second the 'heat-balance technique' developed at ICRISAT in conjunction with Campbell, G. of Washington State University, USA. The 2 techniques are described and representative results given from studies at ICRISAT for perennial pigeon pea (Cajanus cajan), Acacia albida and Albizia lebbeck [A. lebbek]. There was good agreement between the methods.
Manual Tags: search.pigeonpea; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (cajanus OR "pigeon$pea")); WOS

Author: Zheng, Huabin; Huang, Huang; Liu, Jianxia; Yao, Lin; He, Hui
Title: Recent progress and prospects in the development of ridge tillage cultivation technology in China
Abstract Note: Abstract The trace of high and low ridge in the Sanyangzhuang village site showed that adopting ridge tillage cultivation technology (RT) in China has a long history of more than 2000 years. In this paper, we reviewed recent advances of the development and application of RT in China. The better yields from crops grown on ridges/furrow compared with those on flat land were attributed mainly to the improvement of soil moisture conditions, better air permeability and effective supply of soil nutrition. However, most studies of RT are mainly concentrated in upland crop. It has not been reported on RT's higher water use efficiency (WUE) and the capacity of drainage & impounding during the rice production process. New systems of ridge tillage & terrace cultivation model (RTT) for irrigated rice are described here. Further research is needed to optimize management strategies and to strengthen basic research for RTT to obtain environmental and economic benefits and to evaluate practicability and effectiveness of RTT in the paddy field.
Manual Tags: Crop yield; Nutrition utilization & balance; perennial W/1 (oryza OR rice); Root; ScienceDirect; search.rice; Soil property; SPV; Water utilization efficient

Author: Arumugachamy, S.; Vivekanandan, P.; Subramanian, M.
Title: Reciprocal differences in a 6 * 6 diallel for ratoon traits in rice.
Abstract Note: Thirty F 1 hybrids and their parents from a 6 * 6 diallel cross were grown to maturity, harvested 20 cm above ground level and then assessed for tiller regeneration and ratoon yield. Marked reciprocal effects were observed, with 6 and 5 crosses showing significant positive and negative reciprocal effects, respectively, for number of regenerated tillers. In general, tiller regeneration was best when IET6709 and IET7552 were used as maternal parents. The latter also had positive reciprocal effects on ratoon yield.
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: Tamborini, Elena; Brandazza, Anna; De Lalla, Claudia; Musco, Giovanna; Siccardi, Antonio G.; Arosio, Paolo; Sidoli, Alessandro
Title: Recombinant allergen Lol p II: Expression, purification and characterization
Abstract Note: Pollen from perennial rye grass (Lolium perenne) is a major cause of type I allergies worldwide. It contains complex mixtures of proteins, among which Lol p II is a major allergen. Previously, we have reported the cloning and sequencing of Lol p II and its expression in fusion with the heavy chain of human ferritin as carrier polypeptide (Sidoli et al. 1993, J. biol. Chem. 268, 21819–21825.). Here, we describe the expression, purification and characterization of a recombinant Lol p II overproduced as a non-fusion protein in the periplasm of E. coli. The recombinant allergen was expressed in high yields and was easily purified in milligram amounts. It competed with the natural Lol p II for binding to specific IgE, and it induced allergic responses in skin prick tests, indicating to be immunologically analogous to the natural protein. Biochemical analyses indicate that recombinant Lol p II is a highly stable and soluble monomeric molecule which behaves like a small globular protein.

Author: Carpenter, A. J.; Khatibu, A. I.
Title: Recovery from blast (Bl) defoliation in rice.
Abstract Note: F 4 and F 5 lines bred for drought resistance and earliness were subjected to selection which involved the digging up of surviving plants from drought-affected, segregating populations and encouraging, under irrigation, new growth from ratoon tillers. This resulted in F 6 lines which at 8 weeks after sowing produced vigorous new growth following Bl [ Pyricularia oryzae] damage of 6-8 as scored by the 1980 Standard Evaluation System for Rice. Many of these lines produced 3-4 t grain/ha. It is concluded that, if it can be confirmed, the existence of genetically controlled differences between varieties in recovery following defoliation should be of interest with respect to breeding for recovery from (1) drought, (2) P. oryzae damage and (3) damage caused by a range of insects which attack rice leaves. Lines showing the best recovery, their parents and country of origin are listed.
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: Kumar, K.; Goh, K. M.
Title: Recovery of N-15-labelled fertilizer applied to winter wheat and perennial ryegrass crops and residual N-15 recovery by succeeding wheat crops under different crop residue management practices
Abstract Note: The recovery of N-15-labelled fertilizer applied to a winter wheat (120 kg N ha(-1)) and also a perennial ryegrass (60 kg N ha(-1)) crop grown for seed for 1 year in the Canterbury region of New Zealand in the 1993/94 season was studied in the field. After harvests, ryegrass and wheat residues were subjected to four different residue management practices (i.e. ploughed, rotary hoed, mulched and burned) and three subsequent wheat crops were grown, the first succeeding wheat crop sown in 1994/95 to examine the effects of different crop residue management practices on the residual N-15 recovery by succeeding wheat crops. Total N-15 recoveries by the winter wheat and ryegrass (seed, roots and tops) were 52% and 41%, respectively. Corresponding losses of N-15 from the crop-soil systems represented by un-recovered N-15 in crop and soil were 12% and 35%, respectively. These losses were attributed to leaching and denitrification. The proportions of N-15 retained in the soil (0-400 mm depth) at the time of harvest of winter wheat and ryegrass were 36% and 24%, respectively. Although the soil functioned as a substantial sink for fertilizer N, the recovery of this residual fertilizer by subsequent three winter wheat crops was low (1-5%) and this was not affected by different crop residue management practices.

Author: SINGH, R. S.; MEHTA, P. R.; SINGH, B.
Title: Red spot diseases of leaves of jowar (Andropogon sorghum Brot.)
Abstract Note: Ascochyta sorghi, hitherto unrecorded from India, has caused considerable damage to A. sorghum, A. sorghum var. sudanensis and A. halepensis. Symptoms of the disease, morphology, physiology, pathological histology and host range are given in detail. The disease is considered to perpetuate through the mycelium and pycnidia in soil or in diseased leaf trash or on perennial grass hosts such as A. halepensis. || ABSTRACT AUTHORS: M. K. Patel
Manual Tags: search.sorghum; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 sorghum); WOS

Author: Adesogan, A.T.; Salawu, M.B.; Williams, S.P.; Fisher, W.J.; Dewhurst, R.J.
Title: Reducing Concentrate Supplementation in Dairy Cow Diets While Maintaining Milk Production with Pea-Wheat Intercrops*
Abstract Note: In the first of 2 experiments, 40 dairy cows were used to evaluate the milk production potential and concentrate-sparing effect of feeding dairy cows a basal diet of pea-wheat intercrop silages instead of perennial rye-grass silage (GS). Dairy cows were offered GS or 2 intercrop silages prepared from wheat and either Magnus peas (MW, a tall-straw variety) or Setchey peas (SW, a short-straw variety) ad libitum. The respective intercrops were supplemented with 4 kg/d of a dairy concentrate (CP = 240 g/kg dry matter; MW4 and SW4), and the GS were supplemented with 4 (GS4) or 8 (GS8) kg/d of the same concentrate. The second experiment measured the forage DM intake, digestibility, rumen function, and microbial protein synthesis from the forages by offering them alone to 3, nonlactating cows (3 × 3 Latin square design with 21-d periods). Forage dry matter intake was greater in cows fed the intercrop silages than those fed GS. Milk production was greater in cows fed SW4 than those fed GS4 or MW4, but similar to cows fed GS8. Dietary treatment did not affect milk fat, protein, or lactose concentrations. The intercrops had greater N retention, and were more digestible than the GS, and these factors probably contributed to the greater forage DM intakes and greater milk production from the intercrop silages compared with the GS. Rumen volatile fatty acid concentrations were similar across forages, but urinary purine derivative excretion was greater in the cows fed the intercrop silages than the GS, suggesting that rumen microbial protein synthesis was enhanced by feeding the intercrops. In conclusion, similar milk yield and milk composition can be obtained by feeding SW and 4 kg of concentrates as that obtained with GS and 8 kg of concentrates. Feeding intercrop silages instead of GS with the same amount of concentrates increased forage intakes, N retention, and microbial protein synthesis.
Manual Tags: bi-crop; cereal-legume; pea-wheat; perennial W/1 ("rye" OR secale) AND NOT ("rye?grass" OR "ryegrass"); rumen function; ScienceDirect; search.rye; search.wheat; SPV

Author: Yan, He; Bin, Wang; Li-geng, Jiang; Cui-li, Meng; Zhao-rong, Ou; Shi-hong, Xu
Title: Refined Climatic Division of Rice Planting Distribution Using GIS in Guangxi, China
Abstract Note: According to the climatic requirements of rice growth and development, four key climatic factors, including length of safe period for rice cropping, active accumulated temperature during the safe period, sunshine hours during the period when daily mean temperature above 10 degrees C and annual mean temperature, were selected as the indices to classify agro-climatic zones for rice cropping in Guangxi. Climatic data during 1961 to 2010 and related geographical information data of 90 weather stations in Guangxi were used to establish spatial calculating models for the classification indices. The spatial calculating models for the safe period for rice cropping (Y=1193.028-9.831 phi -0.086 h -6.680 lambda the active accumulated temperature during the safe period (Y=30166.74-262.656 phi -2.848 h - 165.549 lambda). the sunshine hours during the period when daily mean temperature above 10 degrees C (Y=6665.195-110.344 phi - 0.416 h -23.416 lambda), and the annual mean temperature (Y=73.237 -0.735 phi - 0.005 h - 0.314 lambda) were obtained by using geographic infermation system (GIS) technology and stepwise regression method, and fine-grid calculation and residual error correction were carried out for each classification index. Based on the identified classification rules, four agro-climatic zones, namely late-maturing double-rice cropping zone. middle and late-maturing double-rice cropping zone, early and middle-maturing double-rice cropping zone, and single rice-ratoon rice cropping zone, were classified for rice cropping in Guangxi, and the map of agro-climatic zones for rice cropping in Guangxi was built.
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: Coale, F.J.; Jones, D.B.
Title: Reflood timing for ratoon rice grown on Everglades histosols
Abstract Note: Rice (Oryza sativa L.) ratooning is commonly practiced in the Everglades Agricultural Area of southern Florida, yet optimum length of the drained period between main and ratoon crops has not been determined. Research was conducted to determine the effect of length of drain period at main-crop harvest on ratoon rice productivity on an Everglades Histosol. Our research was conducted in 250-L (0.95 m height, 0.58 m i.d.) custom-made water control lysimeters filled with a Pahokee muck soil (euic, hyperthermic Lithic Medisaprist). Ratoon reflood timing treatments were 0, 5, 15, 25, 35, and 45 d drained beginning at main-crop maturity. Ratoon-crop grain yield exhibited a significant quadratic response to length of drain period with maximum grain yield produced at 28 d drained. Ratoon panicle number was not affected by reflood timing, but quadratic responses to length of drain period were observed for grain number and 1000 grain weight. We propose that the resultant effect of reflood timing on ratoon grain yield was the combined responses to increasing mineral N supply and increasing water stress associated with delayed reflooding. For drained durations < 28 d, the beneficial effects of increased mineral N supply resulting from organic matter oxidation resulted in a net increase in ratoon-crop yield. Conversely, for drained periods > 28 d, the detrimental impact of prolonged water stress dominated the response to reflood timing and ratoon rice yields declined.

Author: Christiansen, J.L.; Jørgensen, J.R.; Jørnsgård, B.; Stölen, O.
Title: Regrowth in barley (Hordeum vulgare L.) and rye (Secale cereale L.)
Publication Title: Acta Agriculturae Scandinavica - Section B Soil and Plant Science
Abstract Note: Regrowth after cutting at four development stages, from heading to grain maturity, was investigated in a pot experiment containing three rye and four barley varieties. Regrowth in the barley varieties decreased strongly from heading to grain maturity. Rye generally showed stronger regrowth than barley after late cutting, but only the perennial variety 'Soperta' regenerated as many tillers at cutting as formed when harvested at the ripe grain stage. In both species, significant differences were found between varieties. The level of soluble carbohydrates reached a maximum between heading and maturity, but differences in regrowth could not be explained by such differences. Total N decreased from heading to maturity, except for perennial rye, where an increase was observed towards ripening. It is, however, uncertain whether this was an effect rather than a cause of the regrowth.

Title: Relation between the variation of IAA content in plant and germination and growth of ratooning buds in hybrid rice.

Author: JingYong, Li; YongQun, Tang
Title: Relationship between change in plant endogenous cytokinin content and germination and growth of ratooning buds of hybrid rice.
Abstract Note: Hybrid rice K You130 was grown in 2000 on a farm of the Chongqing Crop Institute, China. Endogenous cytokinin contents (CCs) in different organs were determined by ELISA. Germination and growth (GG) status of ratooning buds (RBs) in each node was observed at jointing, booting and full heading stages. The RBs grew very slowly or were in dormant state during 5-19 days after full heading when the CCs were relatively low in leaves and leaf sheaths. However, the GG of RB quickened after 19 days of full heading when the CCs increased in leaves and leaf sheaths. The buds in lower nodes were longer than those in higher nodes at the earlier stage (19 days after full heading) when the CC in the stems of lower nodes was higher than that of higher nodes. However, the buds in higher nodes grew faster than those of lower nodes at the late stage (33 days after full heading) when the CCs in buds and stems of higher nodes were higher than those of lower nodes. It is concluded that the GG of RBs was closely correlated with the variation of endogenous CC.
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: Redding, Gregory J.; Singleton, Rosalyn J.; DeMain, Jeffrey; Bulkow, Lisa R.; Martinez, Patricia; Lewis, Toby C.; Zanis, Carolyn; Butler, Jay C.
Title: Relationship between IgE and specific aeroallergen sensitivity in Alaskan native children
Abstract Note: Background: The relationship between atopic disease and serum IgE levels varies among populations and geographic regions. The close association of atopy with IgE may not occur in subarctic populations as it does in developed countries in temperate climates. Objective: To evaluate the relationship between total and specific IgE concentrations and clinical atopy in 5- to 8-year-old Alaskan native children. Methods: Medical record reviews, interviews, physical examinations, serum IgE measurements, and radioallergosorbent testing (RAST) were performed. Results: The IgE geometric mean was 122.1 IU/mL. Fifty-eight percent of patients had IgE levels greater than 70 IU/mL, and 17% had levels greater than 1,000 IU/mL; 14% had RAST values greater than 0.35 kU/L. Both IgE levels greater than 70 IU/mL and greater than 1,000 IU/mL were associated with RAST values greater than 0.35 IU/L (P = .004) and early wheezing (P = .005) but not with current wheezing, asthma, eczema, or a history of allergies. A RAST value greater than 3.51 kU/L was associated with eczema (P = .04) but not with allergies or wheezing. Children with current wheezing were more likely to have allergies (P = .03) but not eczema, an IgE level greater than 70 IU/mL, or a positive RAST value. Children hospitalized with respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) were not more likely than controls to have current wheezing. Conclusions: Elevated serum IgE concentrations, including levels greater than 1,000 IU/mL, are common among Alaskan native children; positive RAST reactions to aeroallergens are not. The IgE levels do not relate to wheezing, eczema, a history of allergies, or past hospitalization for RSV infection but likely reflect infections other than RSV and environmental factors in subarctic indigenous populations.
Manual Tags: search.rye; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 ("rye" OR secale) NOT "rye$grass"); WOS

Author: Manjappa, K.; Prabhakar, A.S.
Title: Relationship between main crop stem carbohydrate to ratoon crop yield
Abstract Note: An experiment was conducted to study the effect of integrated nutrient management practices on performance of main and ratoon crops of hybrid rice (Oryza sativa L.) during rainy (kharif) and winter (rabi) seasons of 1997-98 and 1998-99. In this study, an attempt was made to correlate the carbohydrate concentration in stubbles of main crop at harvest, as influenced by fertilizer-management practices, with ratoon yield. The different fertilizer treatments influenced the sugar and starch content in stubbles significantly during both the years. On an average, the sugar (3.7%) and starch (8.25%) content was maximum in recommended dose of fertilizer (RDF) + sunnhemp treatment. Similarly, the grain yield of main as well as ratoon crops was also maximum with RDF + sunnhemp treatment (7,142 and 2,123 kg/ha). The correlation coefficients between grain yield of ratoon crop and sugar and starch content in stubbles of main crop were also significant and positive.
Manual Tags: Organic manures; Ratoon crop yield; Scopus; search.rice; SPV; Stem carbohydrate and starch; TITLE-ABS-KEY (ratoon* W/5 (oryza OR rice)) AND DOCTYPE (ar); TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: FuXian, Xu; Shong, Hong; Hong, Xiong
Title: Relationship between N applied at bud development and ratooning ability, and its mechanism in hybrid rice.
Abstract Note: Application of N to rice hybrids Shan You 63 and Kei You 3 at 15 days after full heading of the main crop increased the percentage of viable buds at the 4th and 5th nodes from the top of the plant. N applied for bud development increased grain yield of ratooned rice, associated with an increase in stem dry weight.
