Author: FuXian, Xu; Hong, Xiong
Title: Relationship between ratio of grain to leaf area and ratooning ability in middle-season hybrid rice.
Abstract Note: Thirty-three hybrid rice combinations were used to study the relationship between ratio of grain to leaf area and ratooning ability from 1995 to 1998. There were significant negative correlations between the ratio of grain to leaf area and the ratooning ability of the main crop. The ratooning ability of varieties can be changed under the ratio of grain to leaf area. The reason was that there are significant positive correlations between dry weight of maternal stems and the ratooning ability, significant negative correlations between the ratio of grain to leaf area and dry weight of the maternal stems. Significant positive correlations between the number of grains per panicle among varieties and the ratio of grain to leaf area of main crop were observed. There were significant negative correlations between the number of grains per panicle of main crop and the yield of the ratooning rice. The number of grains per panicle of main crop could be used as a distinguishing criterion for ratooning ability.
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: FuXian, Xu; Hong, Xiong; YongChuan, Zhu; GuiXiong, Wang
Title: Relationship between the efficient amount of nitrogen application for bud development and the source-sink structure at full heading stage of main crop.
Publication Title: Southwest China Journal of Agricultural Sciences
Abstract Note: The relationship between the efficient amount of nitrogen application for bud development and the source-sink structure at full heading stage of main crop in main crop and ratooning rice was investigated using II-you 602, a mid-season hybrid rice combination. There were significant negative correlations between the efficient amount of nitrogen application for bud development and SPAD values of the first leaf from top. The source-sink ratio at the full heading stage of the main crop, the efficient amount of nitrogen application for bud development under different SPAD values of the first leaf from top and the different source-sink ratio at full heading stage of main crop were predicted. The diagnosing index of need-not-apply nitrogen for bud development in ratooning rice production practice was that the SPAD values of the first leaf from top were over 47.39 or the wet weight of leaf-grain ratio were over 27.53 mg/grain or the dry weight of leaf-grain ratio was over 1.05 mg/grain at full heading stage of the main crop.
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: Oad, F. C.; Samo, M. A.; Oad, N. L.; Chandio, G. Q.; Sta. Cruz, P.
Title: Relationship of physiological, growth and yield contributing parameters of locklodged rice ratoon crop.
Abstract Note: A field experiment was conducted in the Philippines to assess the relationship of growth and yield components with the final grain yield of locklodged rice ratoon crop (cv. PSBRc8). Rice grain yield was associated with all the agronomical and physiological traits including plant height, leaf dry matter, total dry matter, leaf area index, relative growth rate, crop growth rate, biomass duration, 1000-grain weight, seed length, panicle length, number of panicles per plant, tiller number at harvest and ratoon rating. Growth, yield and physiological parameters were interrelated, except for net assimilation rate.
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: WenBang, Tang; LiYun, Chen; YingHui, Xiao; JianFeng, Liu
Title: Relationships among yield, yield components and some features of ratooning rice.
Abstract Note: The relationships among yield, yield components and ratooning features such as evenness degree of plant height and panicle length were studied using 37 cultivars (hybrid crosses) as materials. The results showed that: (1) yield and yield components of ratooning rice of hybrid rice were better than those of conventional cultivars; (2) the number of panicles per plant, spikelets per panicle and filled grains per panicle were the most important factors that affected the yield of ratooning rice; and (3) evenness degree of plant height and panicle length were significantly negatively correlated with yield.
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: Appuhn, Astrid; Scheller, Edwin; Joergensen, Rainer Georg
Title: Relationships between microbial indices in roots and silt loam soils forming a gradient in soil organic matter
Abstract Note: Perennial rye grass (Lolium perenne) was grown in a greenhouse pot experiment on seven soils to answer the question whether the microbial colonisation of roots is related to existing differences in soil microbial indices. The soils were similar in texture, but differed considerably in soil organic matter, microbial biomass, and microbial community structure. Ergosterol and fungal glucosamine were significantly interrelated in the root material. This ergosterol was also significantly correlated with the average ergosterol content of bulk and rhizosphere soil. In addition, the sum of fungal C and bacterial C in the root material revealed a significant linear relationship with microbial biomass C in soil. The colonisation of roots with microorganisms increased apparently with an increase in soil microbial biomass. In the root material, microbial tissue consisted of 77% fungi and 23% bacteria. In soil, the fungal dominance was slightly, but significantly lower, with 70% fungi and 30% bacteria. Fungal glucosamine in the root material was significantly correlated with that in soil ( r = 0.65 ). This indicates a close relationship between the composition of dead microbial remains in soil and the living fraction in soil and root material for unknown reasons.
Manual Tags: AGRICOLA; Bacteria; ergosterol; Fungi; Glucosamine; Microbial biomass; Muramic acid; perennial W/1 ("rye" OR secale) AND NOT ("rye?grass" OR "ryegrass"); rhizosphere; ScienceDirect; Scopus; search.rye; SPV; TITLE-ABS-KEY (perennial W/1 ("rye" OR secale) AND NOT ("rye?grass" OR ryegrass)) AND DOCTYPE (ar); TX (perennial N1 ("rye" OR secale) NOT "rye#grass")
Automatic Tags: community structure; ergosterol; glucosamine; grasses; Lolium perenne; microbial colonization; rhizosphere; roots; silt loam soils; soil organic matter

Author: Gonzalez-Paleo, Luciana; Ravetta, Damian
Title: Relationships between reproductive output, morpho-physiological traits and life span in Lesquerella (Brassicaceae)
Abstract Note: The development of perennial industrial crops could contribute to increase agriculture sustainability and yield stability in arid environments. Since perennial plants allocate resources preferentially to perpetuation and to structural and functional characters that provide drought tolerance, they tend to have lower reproductive output (yield) than their congeneric annuals. Four species of Lesquerella native to arid regions were evaluated to understand the relationships between reproduction, drought tolerance, and their association with the plant's life span. We assessed the following set of characters (defined as plant strategies): phenology, gas exchange, specific leaf area, leaf area ratio, total biomass and biomass allocation. Annual (Lesquerella gracilis and Lesquerella angustifolia) and perennial (Lesquerella mendocina and Lesquerella pinetorum) species were compared under water limiting conditions. Within this set of species differences in structural and functional characters were observed. The annual, L gracilis showed a plant strategy characterized by high reproductive output, harvest index (HI) and specific leaf area (SLA). L mendocina (perennial), produced more total biomass, but had a low reproductive output, and also showed characters that provide drought tolerance (high allocation to roots-root mass ratio (RMR), and storage-total non structural carbohydrates (TNC) and low SLA). The annual L angustifolia and the perennial L pinetorum had intermediate plant strategies (i.e. intermediate values of traits typically related with annual or perennial life span). In the case of L. pinetorum we found some traits common to L mendocina: long vegetative period, high biomass, CO(2) assimilation rate (A), and water use efficiency (WUE), and low SLA. The high reproductive output in L. pinetorum was a result of both, higher total biomass and longer growing season compared to the annuals, and of higher HI in relation to the other perennial. These differences in plant strategies among perennial Lesquerella show that there are different combinations of traits that could be used as criteria for the selection of a perennial crop in programs of domestication for Patagonia and others arid lands.
Manual Tags: search.grain; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 grain); WOS

Author: Mote, U. N.
Title: Relative damage due to major pests and losses caused by them on kharif, ratoon and rabi sorghum.
Abstract Note: The incidence of insect pests on sorghum in India increased in severity with the introduction of hybrids and high yielding varieties. Atherigona soccata Rond. attacks during the early stage of crop growth and Chilo partellus Swinh. during the middle stage, while Contarinia sorghicola Coq. infests the flowering earheads. Field tests were carried out in Maharashtra in 1979-80 to estimate and compare the losses caused by insects in the rainy-season crop, the ratoon crop and the winter crop. A. soccata was the only abundant pest during the study period; in sorghum fields that had not received protective treatment with carbaryl, the estimated percentage losses of fodder and (in brackets) grain were 33.94 (28.93) in the rainy-season crop, 65.78 (50.59) in the ratoon crop and 27.41 (20.29) in the winter crop.
Manual Tags: search.sorghum; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 sorghum); WOS

Author: JOHANSEN, C.; CHAUHAN, YS; SAXENA, NP; SINGH, H.; TIWARI, AS; CHAUHAN, YS; FARIS, DG
Title: RELATIVE PERFORMANCE OF LONG-DURATION PIGEONPEA (CAJANUS-CAJAN) OF DIFFERENT GROWTH HABITS AS SOLE CROP AND IN INTERCROP
Abstract Note: An experiment was conducted during 1985-86 and 1986-87 to study the relative performance of long-duration pigeonpea [Cajanus cajan (L.) Mill sp.] genotypes of different canopy habits in sole crops and intercrops with pearl millet [Pennisetum glaucum (L.) R. Br. emend. Stuntz]. In both the seasons no interaction between grain yield of pigeonpea genotypes in sole crops and intercrops was observed, suggesting the validity of selecting progeny of long-duration pigeonpea in sole crops for eventual use in intercropping systems. These results are attributed to the long period, after the harvest of the intercropped pearl millet, over which long-duration pigeonpea can compensate for any differential competitive effects at early growth stages. The major factor determining yield appeared to be length of growing period, which was in tum determined by genotype and the environmental conditions following pearl millet harvest.
Manual Tags: search.grain; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 grain); WOS

Author: Pandey, D.K.; Mishra, Neeraj; Singh, Pooja
Title: Relative phytotoxicity of hydroquinone on rice (Oryza sativa L.) and associated aquatic weed green musk chara (Chara zeylanica Willd.)
Abstract Note: Relative toxicity of hydroquinone on rice (Oryza sativa L. var. Kranti) and associated submerged aquatic weed green musk chara (Chara zeylanica Willd.) was investigated for exploring possible use of the phytotoxin as herbicide in management of the weed. The hydroquinone was lethal to rice at and above 5 mM. It was phytotoxic to green musk chara at as low as 0.01 mM and lethal at 0.075–0.10 mM. The toxicity symptoms on the weed were dull green appearance followed by loss of biomass, and bleaching and fragmentation of the plant resulting in death in 3–12 days. The treated plants showed an excessive leakage of cellular constituents reflecting loss of cellular membrane integrity. There was a loss of metabolites like starch, sugars, amino acids, phenolics, protein, phosphorus, potassium, and chlorophyll a, chlorophyll b, total chlorophyll, and carotenoid pigments with the advancement of the treatment and concomitant accumulation of oxidative stress as reflected by initial spurt of activity of some of the enzymes of the oxidative stress. Relatively higher toxicity of hydroquinone, a phytotoxin, to green musk chara than to rice appeared to be due to capability of the latter to withstand excessive accumulation of the chemical in the roots and inability of the chemical to reach the shoots. The phytotoxin appears to have killed the weed by causing massive damage to cellular membrane integrity, loss of metabolic activities and macromolecules, accompanied by associated starvation and accumulation of oxidative stress. Such a differential toxicity of a phytotoxin, which is short lived in the environment, to a crop and associated weed may have potential of weed management under certain circumstances.
Manual Tags: Aquatic weed; Carotenoids; Catalase; Chara zeylanica; Chlorophyll; Enzymes of oxidative stress; Glutathione reductase; Glutathione S-transferase; Green musk chara; Hydroquinone; Metabolites; perennial W/1 (oryza OR rice); Peroxidases; Phytotoxin; ScienceDirect; search.rice; Solute leakage; SPV

Author: Zizin; Cicin], N. V.
Title: Remote hybridization, one of the most important methods in creating new species and forms of plants.
Abstract Note: The advantages of remote hybridization in breeding are described, and also the problems which may be met in attempts to use this technique. Instances are quoted from the author's past work of means adopted to overcome sexual incompatibility between species, genera and even families. Difficulty in transmitting the right combination of required characteristics to the offspring is exemplified by work on Triticum x Elymus hybrids, from which several winter-hardy perennial wheat forms have been bred, including a dual-purpose grain and fodder form. The inheritance of branched spikes in T. aestivum x Agropyron spp. hybrids is described, also the improvement in gluten content of Secale cereale to 18% on crossing with A. glaucum.
Manual Tags: search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); WOS

Author: SKRIPCHINSKII, V. V.
Title: Removal of vernalization changes in the process of vegetative reproduction of plants
Abstract Note: In perennial rye plants, the vernalization changes arising in the meristem may be removed during the formation of vegetative shoots forming from both the apical growing point of an elongated vegetative stem (Anatolian rye, timothy), and from the lateral meristem in axils of upper leaves of a reproductive stem. The removal of vernalization changes helps the plant to form organs which have the ability to undergo hardening, and by this to acquire a great degree of frost resistance. The removal of vernalization changes does not mean rejuvenation, and the plant developing again during this process remains older in age. The process of removal represents 1 of lengthening the graded development of the perennial plant, but not a return to its original state. The phenomenon of removal of vernalization and similar changes is distributed among all living forms of perennial plants[long dash]grasses, shrubs, and trees; because of this, we can hardly be mistaken if we say that it is one of the cardinal physiological processes which determine the ability of these plants to survive the unfavorable period of winter, and in essence determines the possibility of survival of many of them as perennials. || ABSTRACT AUTHORS: Auth. summ
Manual Tags: search.rye; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 ("rye" OR secale) NOT "rye$grass"); WOS

Author: DERJAVIN, A. I.
Title: Report of the Director of the Voroschilovsk Plant Breeding Station
Publication Title: Selektsi I Semenovodstvo [plant Breeding and Seed Growing]
Abstract Note: Recommended for this region are Krasnodarka 622/2, which gives much higher yields than the standard vars.; Ukrainka and Stepniachla, and the American crosses Kanred X Fulcaster 262287 and Illini Chief, the last a rust-resistant one. Produced at the Station is Sary-Bugda, selected by Dudar. The cross of wheat with wild perennial rye, due to the excessive drought of 1938, did not yield as high as expected, but it gave good results in milling and bread-baking tests. Martchenko produced a tuber-bearing cross between the perennial wild sunflower, and the cultivated annual sunflower. The tubers contain more dry matter than Jerusalem artichoke. || ABSTRACT AUTHORS: J. W. Pincus
Manual Tags: search.rye; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 ("rye" OR secale) NOT "rye$grass"); WOS

Author: YANG, S. C.; PAO, T. P.
Title: Report on reclamation of silty-soil at Min-Shiung and result of sugar cane cultivation on that soil
Abstract Note: Experiments on sugarcane yield with various treatments on non-irrigated silty soil were carried out at Min-Shiung in 3 successive crop years, 1957-1960. Soil characteristics are described. Three treatments, applications of filter cake, compost, and mulching with bagasse or cane leaves, were established. Increments of yield due to applications of filter cake and compost were entirely satisfactory. In 1958-1959, the increments reached as high as 15% and 11% respectively, the average being 7% and 6%. Since pH varies lime requirement should be determined in every plot. In this district, lack of irrigation is the main limiting factor for its agricultural development. The rainfall in spring and summer gives the local farmers only a crop of paddy rice or sometimes a crop of paddy rice plus a crop of sweet potato every year. The farmers suffer great loss from low yield as well as uneconomic utilization of the land. The area in cane has increased 5 times as compared with 1952-1953; generally, 2 crops of sugarcane (plant and ratoon) are realized in 3 years, giving a net profit of 41-58% more than with the usual practice of rice planting. || ABSTRACT AUTHORS: From auth. summ
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: JENNINGS, DANA C.
Title: Report on the search for a perennial wheat hybrid
Abstract Note: Research on this problem follows 2 parallel lines[long dash]agronomic and genetic. In breeding wheat x wheat grass crosses, greater resistance to leaf rust and other diseases is sought. Test plots of Triticum x Agropyron seed are being inoculated with bunt and loose smut. Working from the genetic angle, a comparison was made between related awnless and bearded wheat strains, the latter of which proved superior in yield, test wt., and kernel wt., although no difference was observed in the date of first heading and in plant height. Expts. are being made crossing Pawnee with monosomic strains. The F2 of Pawnee x monosomic crosses will be studied this winter. || ABSTRACT AUTHORS: M. Howe
Manual Tags: search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); WOS

Author: BAUR, E.
Title: Report on the state of the most important breeding investigations at the Kaiser-Wilhelm Institute Muncheberg.
Abstract Note: A progress report on the work that is being done with potatoes, cereals, protein fodder plants, oil plants, vines, fruit, vegetables, forest trees and meadows. To combine on the one hand resistance to Phytophthora and to wart disease with good yield and other desirable tuber qualities and on the other hand frost resistance with high quality are the two main objects in the potato breeding experiments. Barley breeding is directed in the winter types towards increasing winter hardiness and resistance to lodging and in the spring types to the production of reliable forms as regards yield and a good naked barley for brewing purposes. The main aim in regard to wheat is the production of types that are winter hardy, of high baking quality and hardy as regards soil conditions. Intergeneric crosses have so far given no outstanding results. Efforts are being made by inducing self-pollination to obtain varied material for selection with a view to developing a short-strawed rye. Perennial rye strains from a Petkus x Anatolian wild rye cross giving a good yield of grain are being tested in large numbers, and may ultimately prove valuable as fodder. A suggestion is put forward that the bitter lupin should be replaced by the sweet lupin and other Leguminosae as a source of plant proteins for fodder purposes. Breeding work is also being directed towards the production of fodder plants of suitable fat content to reduce the high imports of oil cake, etc., into Germany. The primary object of the extensive vine breeding operations in progress is the production of a variety equal in quality to the best German grapes and completely resistant to Peronospora, and also as resistant as possible to Roter Brenner ( Pseudopeziza tracheiphila] and true mildew. Breeding experiments are also being carried out in hopes of developing high quality stocks and good mildew resistant direct producers. From the cross and self-pollination of apple trees 30, 000 seedlings have been raised. It is hoped to obtain Fusicladium resistant types of apples and pears as well as valuable commercial types. Similar work is being done with cherries, plums, peaches and apricots. Earliness is the chief aim in vegetable breeding and in tomato breeding in particular a combination of earliness with good keeping properties is hoped for from certain crosses that are being tried. A mildew resistant, large berried gooseberry will probably soon be ready for distribution to growers and some new forms from gooseberry x currant and raspberry crosses may follow. The main object as regards forest trees is to evolve races of pines that are resistant to leaf cast and one such race has been under test for several years. From crosses with poplars it is hoped rapidly growing and well developed types may be obtained.
Manual Tags: search.rye; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 ("rye" OR secale) NOT "rye$grass"); WOS

Author: Jiang, M.; Way, M.O.; Du, X.; Ji, X.; He, Y.
Title: Reproductive biology of summer/fall populations of rice water weevil, Lissorhoptrus oryzophiius Kuschel, in Southeastern Texas
Abstract Note: The rice water weevil, Lissorhoptrus oryzophilus Kuschel (Coleoptera: Erirhinidae), is one of the most important pests of rice, Oryzae sativa L., in the US, and has emerged as a pest of rice in eastern Asia where it reproduces parthenogenetically. Females were collected from early July to late September 2006 from flooded main crop rice, ratoon crop rice, and a light trap placed in grassy vegetation and fallow fields near Beaumont, TX. Their mating status and ovarian developmental stages were monitored, and their reproductive capacity on rice plants was determined in the laboratory. Sexually reproductive individuals occurred consistently from early July to mid-September, which accounted for more than 50% of the females in most collections. Less than 7% of females seemed to be reproducing parthenogenetically. In the laboratory, 45.1% of females were mated within 9 days after emergence. For females emerging in late July and late August, only 17.4 and 6.1%, respectively, developed to ovipositing and post-ovipositing stages after feeding on rice plants for 4 weeks. These results indicated that in Southeast Texas >80% of summer females entered diapause after emergence, but reproductive females often are abundant later in rice fields. Contributions of summer females to the occurrence and abundance of this insect in subsequent seasons are discussed.
Manual Tags: Scopus; search.rice; SPV; TITLE-ABS-KEY (ratoon* W/5 (oryza OR rice)) AND DOCTYPE (ar); TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: Ch'ang, T.S.
Title: Reproductive disturbances of romney ewe lambs grazed on red clover (trifolium pratense) pastures
Abstract Note: ON March 10, 1958, 111 Romney ewe lambs (group A) which had grazed continuously since weaning (December 12, 1957) on pastures dominant in red clover were joined with an additional 92 Romney ewe lambs (group B) for studies of their breeding season. This latter group had grazed, since weaning (December 11, 1957), on perennial rye-grass-white clover pastures. Vasectomized, ochred rams were run with these lambs from March 17, 1958, all being grazed together on perennial rye-grass-white clover pastures. All lambs were weighed on March 19, group A and group B having the same average live weight (71 lb.). On the same day, that is, within two days of joining with teasers, 29 lambs from group A but none from group B were found to have been marked. This sudden onset of œtrus from one group of lambs was unexpected in view of the previous results1 on the breeding season of Romney ewe lambs. Owing to the relatively early age at first œstrus shown by these lambs, laparotomy was performed within five days of observed œstrus to determine whether ovulation had occurred. Both the left and right ovaries of eight lambs were examined without finding any evidence of the existence of corpora lutea. Graafian follicles of varying sizes, however, were seen on most ovaries.
Manual Tags: Scopus; search.rye; SPV; TITLE-ABS-KEY (perennial W/1 ("rye" OR secale) AND NOT ("rye?grass" OR ryegrass)) AND DOCTYPE (ar)

Author: HUDSON, J. P.
Title: Research at Nottingham University.
Abstract Note: Some of the research work recently done at the Midland Agricultural College, Sutton Bonington, is reported. Pot plant scum. The development and control of scum on the surface of the soil of pot plants was investigated. It was found that the algae could be controlled effectively by reducing the frequency of watering so as to allow the surface soil periodically to dry out. Frequent watering not only encouraged scum, but also depressed growth in young plants. Tomato and lettuce seedlings pricked out in early summer and watered every fourth day for 3 weeks were well ahead of those watered more often. Sowing lettuce. The germination and growth of lettuce seedlings resulting from different methods of sowing varied widely. The depth of sowing may vary from1/16 to 0.25 in. but must be uniform within each box. Of the various methods of watering tried, dipping proved most satisfactory and produced a stronger type of plant. Tomato rogues. Plumpton King is apt to throw rogue plants that cannot be distinguished at the seedling stage by the usual characteristics. The comparison of plant characteristics at the seedling and later stages has led to the development of a technique for recognizing a proportion of the rogues at a very early stage. Orchard cover cropping. Trials with orchard cover crop mixtures emphasize the need for breeding herbage crops especially for this purpose. Timothy grass (S.50) was much more easily cut by the gang mower than Perennial Rye (S.23) even if allowed to get too long. It is probable, however, that Timothy is also too strong growing for the district, which has an annual rainfall of less than 25 inches, especially on light land.
Manual Tags: search.rye; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 ("rye" OR secale) NOT "rye$grass"); WOS

Author: Davidescu, V.; Neata, G.; Toma, I.; Ignat, A.; Campeanu, M.
Title: Researches about the influence of some fertilising system on some fodder plants cultivated on reddish-brown soil from Moara Domneasca.
Publication Title: Lucrari Stiintifice - Universitatea de Stiinte Agronomice Bucuresti.   Seria A, Agronomie
Abstract Note: As fodder plants are used in animal feeding, they represent an important factor for the progress of the Animal Husbandry. This research studied the quality of the fodder plants yield for the fodder plants cultivated on reddish-brown soil at Moara Domneasca, Romania. The mixtures of fodder plants consisted of perennial grains and vegetables, which were fertilized with increasing doses of nitrogen at constant level of potassium. The research was performed in 1994 and 1995, in greenhouse conditions at the U.S.A.M.V. - Bucarest. The experiments were made in four variants and five repetitions. The fertilizer application was made before sowing, with increasing doses of nitrogen (0, 50, 150, 250 kg N/ha) at constant level of potassium (200 kg K/ha). An amount of 0.2 g seed mixture was used for each vegetation pot, correlated with the amount of seeds used for sowing in field. The biological material consisted of Dactylis glomerata, Festuca pratensis and Medicago sativa for the first mixture and Trifolium repens, Dactylis glomerata, Lolium perene and Festuca pratensis for the second mixture. The fodder were harvested three times in 1994 and five times in 1995, at equal time intervals. In the plant samples, the following quantities were measured: the soluble nitrate, phosphorus and potassium content, the total nitrogen, phosphorus and potassium content and the protein content. The yield for each variant was also registered. The two fodder plants mixture reacted differently to used nitrogen fertilizer dose. The accumulation rate of the nitrates in plants was higher in the early growing phases. The nitrates content decreased during the vegetation period as an effect of dilution as well as due to using of the nitrates by plants in metabolic processes. The nitrate content accumulated in the two fodder plants mixtures does not exceed the admitted limits, namely 750 ppm nitrates, for these plants.
Manual Tags: search.grain; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 grain); WOS

Author: Neacsu, M. G.; Neacsu, C.; Vicovan, G. P.; Radu, R.; Vicovan, A.
Title: Researches regarding the exploitation of the temporary pastures which are resistant to draught in the 2nd year of vegetation with sheep.
Publication Title: Bulletin of University of Agricultural Sciences and Veterinary Medicine   Cluj-Napoca. Animal Science and Biotechnologies
Abstract Note: The tests were made on a temporary pasture of perennial grain and vegetable plants with high resistance at draught, founded in 2008 and exploited with sheep of Merinos de Palas breed. There were organized two lots of young female sheep: the 1st lot fed by grazing the A1 mixture and the 2nd lot foddered by grazing the A2 mixture. Both lots received also a supplement of concentrated fodders (barley) of 0.3 kg/animal/day. The production of dry substance obtained in the 2nd year of vegetation reveals the high potential of production of A1 complex mixture, represented by species of perennial grain plants - Lolium perenne 20%, Dactylis glomerata 30%, Festuca pratensis 15%, Festuca arundinacea 20% and perennial vegetable plants - Trifolium repens 10% and Lotus corniculatus 5% from which it was obtained a production of 5 t/ha S.U. (25 t/ha green mass). The consumption of nutritive substances/animal/day presented almost equal values between the 2 lots, a little higher at the 2nd lot where the pasture had a higher value of vegetable plants. The final body weight was of 45.20-46.30 kg, higher with 2.43% at the 1st lot. The daily average increase was of 101 g at the 2nd lot and of 110 g at the 1st lot, being superior at the latter, with 8.91%.
Manual Tags: search.grain; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 grain); WOS

Author: FIRSOVA, M. K.
Title: Research Institutes in struggles for harvests.
Abstract Note: Summaries are presented of the reports for 1947 submitted to the USSR Ministry of Agriculture by the Institute of Grain Husbandry of the Southeastern USSR, the Institute of Grain Husbandry of the Non-Black Earth Bert, the Stavropolj Experimental Field for Perennial Crops, the Subsidiary Base for Distant Hybridization of Wheats of the Timirjazev Agricultural Academy and the Dokucaev Agricultura] Institute of the Central Black Earth Zone. Institute of Grain Husbandry of Southeastern USSR Wheat Work at this Institute included propagation of the recently selected spring wheats Lutescens 53/12 and Albidum 43, and selection of the following new spring varieties: Lutescens 758, Albidum 21, 24 and 210. Besides these, the spring wheats Saratovskaja [Saratov] 27 and 28 and Lutescens 1433 and 1237 have been obtained by complex hybridization methods. The Station has submitted to State Trials the new spring wheat varieties Flora 5, 6 and 7. Flora 5 appears to be more productive than Lutescens 62 under conditions of the Non-Black Earth Belt. A hardy winter wheat Lutescens 319 has been selected. Buckwheat Tetraploids have been produced of 22 local varieties. Oats Hybrid 113 (- Nemcinovsku [Nemcinov] 2) has been obtained from Moskovskii [Moscow] A-3 15 x Orel [Eagle]. The variety is large grained, resistant to lodging and yields 27 c. per ha. more than the standard. Rye A new variety, Volzanka [Volga], has been bred, yielding 24-5 centners per hectare. Barley Breeding for gluten content is in progress. Agropyron hybrids The study of Cicin's Agropyron wheat hybrids was carried on. Optimal quantities of seed for sowing for each hybrid variety were determined. The most promising of the perennial wheats in the districts around Moscow are the varieties 2, 3 and M-164. They can be harvested two years in succession, some plants surviving the third year. These wheats produce grain of good baking properties containing 21-74% crude protein. Some 2000 families of other perennial hybrids are undergoing selection for their perennial habit. The annual Agropyron-wheat hybrids 599 (= Sehurdinovka), 4871, 186 and 64/65 and the square heads 1 and 2 have been submitted to State Tests. An aniphidiploid was obtained in 1947 of the hitherto sterile wheat-rye-Agropyron combination. Legumes Intraspecific hybridization with pea, vetches, lupin, and clover is being carried out. The clover Mos-1 has been released as a standard for Moscow province. Potato In productivity tests seedling 157-3 and Snezinka [Snow Flake] 33 and 35 did well. Sunflower In varietal trials, Saratovskii [Saratov] 188 was the most productive. Some 27 inter-varietal hybrids obtained from natural cross pollination were tested. Other crops The experimental programme includes work with perennial flax, sweet sorghum and millet. The use of vegetative grafting in overcoming incompatibility in hybridization of distant forms has been studied. Yellow Acacia, pea, Cyphomandra and tomato were the experimental plants. Repeated grafting of pea on Acacia stocks has resulted in no changes in the eighth pea seed generation. Stavropolj Experimental Field for Perennial Crops Work has been concerned with the production of distant rye, wheat and sorghum hybrids. The problems of sterility and brittleness of the ears in hybrids have been overcome. Wheat Amphidiploids of Agropyron-wheat hybrids have been produced which are hardier, more productive and with larger grain than their parental forms. Perennial forms have been obtained. Rye Perennial rye has been obtained by crossing winter rye with wild perennial rye. Pending the results of State Tests the rye is being used for forage. Sorghum Perennial sorghum has been obtained from the cross between sweet Sorghum x wild gumai sorghum. Breeding it as a cereal continues. The present form produces up to 16% sugar and does well on sandy soil of semi-deserts of the Stavropolj Territory, where it grows 2-5 to 3 m. above the ground. Other crops Breeding is in progress of perennial vetchling, vetch and Jerusalem artichoke. Lysenko's theory of phasic development is being applied to several horticultural plants. Subsidiary Base for Distant Hybridizaiion of Wheat of the Timirjazev Agriculiural A cademy The report of the work of this Station is presented by A. P. Zebrak. Wheat Over 100 amphidiploids have been obtained by colchicine. The disease resistant Triticum Timopheevi was used as a component in all crosses, as a result of which the hybrid offspring has certain undesirable characters. These could be eliminated through selection. Crosses between the amphidiploids and T. vulgare soft wheats have given a variety of forms. This method is expected to cancel out T. Timopheevi genomes. Crosses are being made between the hard and soft wheats. As a result 70-chromosome amphidiploids have been obtained. The amphidiploids are being studied. The study includes the crosses between the amphidiploids of winter habit and amphidiploids of the spring habit type. Dokucaev Institute of Agriculture for the Central Black Earth Belt Study of open cross pollination is in progress. It has been found that the method does not yield heterotic forms, but that the hybrids become increasingly productive. Wheat Four new winter wheats have been obtained in the above manner, including Stepnaja [Steppe] 135 which at the Mironovskaja Station has outyielded Ukrainka [Ukrainian]. Four spring wheats have been selected and are undergoing tests. Rye Two promising rye varieties have been selected from naturally cross pollinated ryes. The varieties Voronezskaja SHI [Voronez Agricultural Institute] and Mup are being improved.
Manual Tags: search.rye; search.sorghum; search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 ("rye" OR secale) NOT "rye$grass"); TS=(perennial NEAR/1 sorghum); TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); WOS

Author: Davidescu, V.; Toma, I.; Neata, G.
Title: Research on chemical fertilisers and the lead as polluting of fodder plants cultivated on reddish-brown soil at Moara Domneasca.
Publication Title: Lucrari Stiintifice - Universitatea de Stiinte Agronomice Bucuresti.   Seria A, Agronomie
Abstract Note: The use of chemical fertilizers, manure and chemical substances for plant protection can influence the quality of fodder plant and the environment. Chemical fertilizers with nitrogen as nitrate have a high solubility and can be leached by irrigation water or precipitation through soil in phreatic water. Lead can be accumulated in fodder plants and can be absorbed from polluted soil or from polluted environment by industries. This study determined the quantity and quality of fodder plants cultivated in reddish brown soil at Moara Domneasca, Romania. The mixture of fodder plant consisted of perennial grains and vegetables, fertilized with increasing doses of nitrogen at a constant level of potassium. Lead was also applied in 100 and 200 ppm concentration on some variants. The plants evaluated were Dactylis glomerata, Festuca pratensis and Medicago sativa. The experiment was conducted in 1994 and continued in 1995 and 1996 under greenhouse conditions in U.S.A.M.V., Bucharest, Romania. In 1996, the fodder plants were harvested three times and the yield for each variant was also registered. The fodder plants have different reactions to the fertilizer application. The accumulation of nitrates in fodder plants was accelerated in variant where lead was applied. The content of total nitrogen and protein corresponds to their normal contents in fodder plants as 2-3.5% total nitrogen and 8-22% protein. Increasing nitrogen doses and the lead added in soil determined increases in yield and protein content in fodder plants.
Manual Tags: search.grain; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 grain); WOS

Author: Popescu, A.
Title: Research on the efficiency of new, simple and combined types of herbicides for weed control in maize crops.
Publication Title: Analele Institutului de Cercetari pentru Cereale si Plante Tehnice,   Fundulea
Abstract Note: Results obtained in experiments performed during 1993-1994 at 13 Agricultural Research Stations on the application of new, simple (Frontier [dimethenamid], Guardian [flucythrinate], Ring 800 [prosulfuron] and Bromotril SC [bromoxynil]) and combined herbicides (Diburom, Dimezin, Dimesin, Primextra [atrazine + metolachlor] and Sanolt combi) for the control of mono- and dicotyledonous annual weeds in maize are presented. Weed control was similar to that obtained by using standard products. The effects of the selective herbicides Mistral, Titus and Tell for post-emergent application to the monocotyledonous perennial weeds, Sorghum halepense and Elymus repens, were also studied. The selective products resulted in better weed control, and hence in greater maize yields.
Manual Tags: search.sorghum; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 sorghum); WOS

Author: Cox, T. S.; Picone, C.; Jackson, W.
Title: Research priorities in natural systems agriculture.
Abstract Note: Over the course of millennia and most dramatically in recent years, agriculture has eroded natural capital as it has supplied human demands. These tendencies can be offset by infusions of fossil fuels for fertility, pest control and traction, but only partially and not over the long term. This could be called the "problem of agriculture," in contrast to problems in agriculture. Natural ecosystems are unmatched for efficient nutrient recycling, solar energy use, and biodiversity preservation, but they cannot feed dense human populations. An ecological agriculture that is a synthesis of natural and agricultural systems can save soils from erosion and reduce chemical and water use. Reducing chemical pollution of air, water and soils will conserve wildlife habitat, improve water quantity and quality and protect human health. By practicing an agriculture that has conservation as a direct result, farmers can become better stewards of the land. Lower input costs and inherent sustained soil fertility will mean more profit for farmers and communities. Principles of natural systems agriculture (NSA) are applicable to any food- or fibre-production system worldwide. In the central Great Plains of the United States, agriculture should mimic the native prairie, which is a polyculture of herbaceous perennial plants. The Land Institute has spent 25 years studying the structure and function of prairies. Now we and other research organizations are breeding perennial grain crops, including cool- and warm-season grasses, legumes and composites. We are following two parallel strategies: selecting wild perennials for greater seed production and other traits of domestication and hybridizing wild perennials with annual crops to combine desired traits. Although the breeding process will take many years, the effort will be repaid many times over if we achieve our goal: a lasting solution to the 10 000-year-old problem of agriculture.
Manual Tags: search.grain; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 grain); WOS

Author: Xiong, Yao; YongQun, Tang; Ming, Wen; XianWei, Zhang; JingYong, Li
Title: Research progress and developing strategies of ratoon rice in southwest ecotope.
Abstract Note: The current situation and recent development of the ratoon rice in southwest ecotope were reviewed. The present problems were pointed out including insufficient attention, incomplete matching technology, difficult technical extension and decreasing reserved area After discussion on the important research direction of ratoon rice in future, the proposed suggestions included improving the ideological understanding, increasing the funds investment, jointing the academy and institutes, laying a solid foundation, strengthening technology integration, and promoting the mode of high yield.
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: Kumaresan, M.; Rangasamy, A.
Title: Residual effect of green manure and growth regulators on the yield of ratoon rice.
Abstract Note: Sesbania rostrata applied basally at 12.5 t ha -1 for the main rice crop increased the growth parameters, grain yield and straw yield of the ratoon crop. Spraying 2% glucose on the 5th day after harvest of the plant crop (DAHP) plus 2% DAP (diammonium phosphate) at 30 DAHP increased the growth parameters and yield of ratoon rice.

Author: Singh, Y. V.; Mandal, B. K.
Title: Residual effect of organic manures and inorganic fertilizers on succeeding ratoon rice.
Abstract Note: In a field trial in West Bengal, various combinations of Azolla, cyanobacteria, farmyard manure, green manuring with Ipomoea, Pistia or water hyacinth [ Eichhornia crassipes], and different rates of N fertilizer, were applied to rice, and their residual effects on the following ratoon rice crop were determined. The plant crop had been grown at 50 hills/m but only 42-58% of culms regenerated in the ratoon crop. Grain yield of the ratoon crop ranged from 1.32 t/ha in controls given no fertilizers to 2.42 t/ha with the residual effects of Azolla (1 t/ha) applied to standing water 7 days after transplanting the first rice crop. N, P and K contents of grain, straw and soil are tabulated.

Author: Chen, Ming-Yih; Yein, Chi-Fuu
Title: Residual effects of rice hulls applied to sorghum fields in ratoon cultivation
Publication Title: Journal of the Agricultural Association of China
Abstract Note: This investigation was undertaken to explore the residual effects of rice hulls when applied to sorghum fields at a rate of 10 tons and 20 tons per hectare, respectively. Rice hull was spread over a sorghum field before planting and the field was then plowed, manured, puddled and mulched for the 1986 spring cultivation and for the ratoon cultivation of next crop.The experiment had a significant and favorable result. The rice hull plots showed a higher soil organic matter and soluble Si compared to the control. A sorghum plant analysis on leaf blades revealed that silicon uptake at the rice hull plot was higher than that at the check. An increase of 7% in grain yield showed the residual effect of the rice hull plot at a rate of 20 tons per hectare. Therefore, one application of rice hulls had a beneficial effect on more than two crops, due to the slow decomposition character of the hull.
Manual Tags: search.sorghum; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 sorghum); WOS

Author: Pamplona, P. P.; Moody, K.
Title: Residual effects of weed control treatments applied to sorghum on mungbean.
Abstract Note: Sorghum grown in 1977 at 150, 250 or 350 * 10 plants/ha was hand weeded at 17 and 31 days after sowing (DAS), treated pre-em. with 2 kg butachlor or atrazine/ha, or cultivated between the rows at 17 and 31 DAS. Following harvest, sorghum was allowed to ratoon on half of each plot, while Vigna radiata cv. MG50-10Ag was grown on the other half. Part of each V. radiata plot was weeded 14 and 28 DAS and the remainder was left unweeded. Weeds occurring included Digitaria spp., Eleusine indica, Echinochloa colonum, Rottboellia exaltata, Ipomoea triloba, Amaranthus spinosus, Euphorbia hirta, Portulaca oleracea, A. viridis, Sida acuta,Cyperus rotundus and C. iria. Weed weight in V. radiata was unaffected by plant density or weed control treatments applied to the previous sorghum. Atrazine failed to control C. rotundus. Stand and yield of V. radiata were significantly reduced by residual effects of atrazine but were unaffected those of butachlor.
Manual Tags: search.sorghum; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 sorghum); WOS

Author: Jaisal, J. K.; Srivastava, C. P.; Sharma, R. P.
Title: Resistance in long duration pigeon pea against major insect pests.
Abstract Note: The incidence of pod fly ( Melanagromyza obtusa), pod bug and lepidopterous pod borer (LBP) on long-duration pigeon pea genotypes (MA-20, MAL-13, Bahar, MAL-24 and MA-3) grown in Varanasi, Uttar Pradesh, India, was studied during the kharif of 2007-08. The densities of mature and immature stages of the pests were evaluated weekly from 13 January 2008 until the harvesting stage. Pod fly was initially observed on the 2nd standard week (SW) in all genotypes. The peak in pod fly population was observed from the 8th SW to the 12th SW. The mean pod fly population ranged from 1.19 adult per plant on MAL-24 to 1.32 adult per plant on MA-3. Pod damage by pod fly, pod bug and LPB was greatest on MA-20 (50.3%), MAL-24 (31.0%) and MAL-6 (14.1%), respectively. Grain damage by pod fly, pod bug and LPB was greatest on MAL-13 (36.4%), MA-20 (18.2%) and MAL-6 (9.46%), respectively. The grain yield varied from 7.33 quintal/ha for MAL-24 to 11.11 quintal/ha for MA-3. The results indicated that pod fly was the major insect pest on pigeon pea and MA-3 was the most suitable genotype in this zone. [1.0 quintal=100.0 kg].
Manual Tags: search.grain; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 grain); WOS

Author: Prusakova, L. D.; Chizhova, S. I.; Khripach, V. A.
Title: Resistance to lodging and yielding capacity of cereals under effect of brassinosteroids
Abstract Note: The effect of synthetic analogs of brassinosteroids (brassinolid, epibrassinolid, homobrassinolid) on the growth, the stem firmness, and the productivity of the spring barley cultivar Nosovsky 9 and the perennial wheat cultivar Zernokormovaya 169 has been studied in greenhouse and field experiments. The aim of experiments was to develop principally new approaches to the increase of cereals' resistance to the lodging. It has been shown that brassinosteroids possessed a high physiological activity, expressed in the induced activity of alpha-amylase in the barley endosperm, the increase of the grain weight per ear, the 1000-grain weight, and the yield. Under the spraying with synthetic analogs (10-5 mg/l) during the flowering, the barley stem diameter and firmness also increased, which conditioned an improved resistance to the lodging.
Manual Tags: search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); WOS

Author: Solodukhina, O.; Kobylyansky, V.
Title: Resistance to stem rust (Puccinia graminis Pers. f. sp. secalis Erikss. et Henn.) in rye
Abstract Note: Development of stem rust in short-stem diploid rye decreased grain yield by 35%. Breeding of resistant varieties is the most effective way of protection from the disease. Plants resistant to stem rust were selected from populations of diploid winter rye varieties received from the collection of our institute such as: Ilmen, Orlovskii Gibrid, Kharkovskaya 60, Kharkovskaya 55, Kustovka, Kombaininyai, Kazanskaya, Krupnozernaya, Novozybkovskaya 4, Alfa, Derzhavinskaya 29, Chulpan, Rossul and in perennial rye Secale montanum Guss. Genetic control of resistance was determined for Kharkovskaya 55 and Rossul. In both cases one single dominant gene resistance was found; we suppose that their genes for resistance were identical. We suggest a temporary symbol Sr1 for this gene.
Manual Tags: Genetic control; Rye; Scopus; search.rye; SPV; Stem rust resistance; TITLE-ABS-KEY (perennial W/1 ("rye" OR secale) AND NOT ("rye?grass" OR ryegrass)) AND DOCTYPE (ar); TS=(perennial NEAR/1 ("rye" OR secale) NOT "rye$grass"); WOS

Author: Tremblay, C.; Comeau, A.; Cloutier, C.
Title: Resistance to the bird cherry-oat aphid, Rhopalosiphum padi L. (Homoptera: Aphididae), in perennial gramineae and wheat X perennial gramineae hybrids
Abstract Note: The potential for resistance to Rhopalosiphum padi (L.) was evaluated in seedlings of Agropyron elongatum (Host.) Beauv., Agropyron intermedium (Host.) Beauv., Agropyron repens L. Beauv., Elymus angustus Trin., and hybrids obtained from crosses between these perennial Gramineae and cultivated wheat, Triticum aestivum L. Binary choice tests designed to detect antixenosis showed that A. repens and the hybrid wheat x A. repens were less attractive than the two parental wheat varieties used to produce the hybrid (P < 0.05). Parameters of aphid performance, including reproductive rate, duration of prereproductive period, adult fresh weight, and aphid biomass, also allowed the detection of various levels of antibiosis in the four perennial grasses and hybrids tested. Results showed that natural resistance found in Agropyron and Elymus spp. can be successfully transmitted to hybrids produced from their crosses with cultivated wheat.
Short Title: Resistance to the bird cherry-oat aphid, Rhopalosiphum padi L. (Homoptera
Manual Tags: AGRICOLA; search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); TX (perennial N1 (triticum OR wheat)); WOS

Author: Fidalski, J.; Chaves, J. C. D.
Title: Response of Iapar-59 coffee ( Coffea arabica L.) to surface applied organic residues in a Typic Haplorthox.
Abstract Note: The objective of this work was to assess the soil fertility, nutritional status, vegetative growth and yield of coffee cv. Iapar-59, subjected to four exogenous applications (2002-2004): 20 t ha -1 dry matter (grey mucuna, leucaena, pigeon pea, perennial peanut, brizantha grass, forage sorghum, sugarcane bagasse, filter cake-sugarcane, citrus bagasse, sewage sludge, sewage sludge and lime, coffee straw, manure (bovine), chicken litter, chicken manure, sugarcane bagasse and chicken manure, swine manure; 200 m 3 ha -1 liquid swine manure); N (95 kg ha -1 ammonium sulphate). A field experiment was set up in 2002, in a Typic Haplorthox, in Paranavai, northwestern region of Parana state, Brazil. From 2003 to 2005 soil (0-5, 5-10, 10-20 e 20-40 cm) and leaf samples were collected and coffee tree growth and yield were assessed. Grey mucuna increased leaf N, leucaena increased soil K (5-40 cm) and filter cake-sugarcane increased soil Ca (10-40 cm). These alterations were closely related to higher coffee growth rates and yield.
Manual Tags: search.pigeonpea; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (cajanus OR "pigeon$pea")); WOS

Author: Touré, Amadou; Becker, Mathias; Johnson, David E.; Koné, Brahima; Kossou, Dansou K.; Kiepe, Paul
Title: Response of lowland rice to agronomic management under different hydrological regimes in an inland valley of Ivory Coast
Abstract Note: A large proportion of the rice in West Africa is produced in rainfed lowland ecosystems, mainly in inland valleys. The hydrological conditions (duration and intensity of flooding) vary with the toposequence position between the fringe and the centre of the valley. Production methods tend to evolve from the currently predominant unbunded plots without external input use, to input-intensive production in bunded plots. Agronomic management interventions co-evolve and may include varietal choice, herbicide use, and mineral N fertilizer application. The response of rice and the associated weeds to such interventions is likely to vary with the prevailing hydrological regime. A 2-year field experiment was conducted in northern Ivory Coast to determine the impact of water regime (plot position in the valley, presence of bunds) and input use (mineral N fertilizer and herbicide) on the productivity (yield and N use efficiency) of traditional and modern rainfed lowland rice cultivars and the biomass and composition of the associated weeds. Installing field bunds reduced seasonal variations in ponded water depth and resulted in a mean increase in rice grain yield of 30–40% (p < 0.005). This increase was associated with a 25% lower cumulative weed biomass and a several-fold increase in the agronomic use efficiency of applied mineral N in bunded than unbunded plots. Under low input management, traditional varieties tended to out-yield modern varieties in unbunded plots. Improved crop management such as herbicide and fertilizer application, and the construction of field bunds was more effective to increase the yield and N use efficiency in the flooded valley centre than in the drought-prone valley fringes. There is a need for site-specific targeting of modern cultivars, land development and improved production methods in the inland valleys of the West African savanna zone.
Manual Tags: N use efficiency; Oryza sativa; perennial W/1 (oryza OR rice); ScienceDirect; search.rice; SPV; Weeds; West Africa

Author: Dong, Wenjun; Chen, Jin; Zhang, Bin; Tian, Yunlu; Zhang, Weijian
Title: Responses of biomass growth and grain yield of midseason rice to the anticipated warming with FATI facility in East China
Abstract Note: Crop model projections and historical data analyses have shown that global warming may cause serious decrease in crop productivity, however, many uncertainities remain on the impact quantification due to the unclear understanding of actual crop response. Therefore, we performed a three-year field warming experiment with free air temperature increase (FATI) facility to investigate the actual response of midseason rice growth in East China. There were four treatments (AW: all-day warming; DW: daytime warming; NW: nighttime warming; CK: ambient control) with three replicates. This FATI facility presented a good simulation of the local air temperature pattern with an increase in the daily mean temperature of about 1.1–2.0 °C during rice whole growth duration compared to the ambient control. Warming shortened the pre-heading phase respectively by 3.3 d, 1.7 d and 2.0 d in the AW, DW and NW plots, while the post-heading phase stayed almost unchanged. During the three years, warming slightly decreased the aboveground biomass by an average of 9.1%, 10.3% and 3.3%, and the grain yield by an average of 0.9%, 6.4% and 6.1% in the AW, DW and NW plots, respectively. Warming tended to decrease rice photosynthesis rate and stimulate the nighttime respiration rate. It also enlarged the flag leaf area and increased its chlorophyll content. No significant difference and interaction in the actual response of rice growth were found between the warming regimes. The above evidences suggest that the expected warming less than 2.0 °C may not cause significant decrease in rice productivity in East China.
Manual Tags: Biomass production; East China; Free air temperature increase; Global warming; Grain yield; Midseason rice; perennial W/1 (oryza OR rice); ScienceDirect; search.rice; SPV

Author: Zhou, Suping; Abaraha, Abraham
Title: Response to heat stress in warm season and cool season turf grass cultivars
Abstract Note: In this study, we investigated differences between cool-season and warm season grasses when exposed to heat stress. The results show that Kentucky blue seed germination rate was the highest at 25 degrees C (40-50%), decreased significantly at 30 degrees C (23-30%) and dropped to 0 at 40 degrees C. For the Bermuda cultivars, seed germination rate was two fold higher at 30 degrees C then 25 degrees C, and reached the highest at 40 degrees C. The cool season perennial rye and Bent grass seeds germinated well between 25 and 30 degrees C. Their germination rate was significantly lower at 40 degrees C. After exposure to 38 degrees C for 2 d, the chlorophyll content decreased significantly for Bermuda cultivars, remained stable for Bent grass and perennial rye, and increased to the greatest extent for Kentucky blue. Leaf soluble protein contents increased significantly for Kentucky Blue, but remained stable for most of the other cultivars. Western blot with Hsp70 and dehydrin antibodies identified that the Bermuda cultivars had a dynamic changes in the profile of the heat and dehydration stress-related proteins. No similar changes were detected in Kenblue cultivars. High temperature induced dehydrin homolog proteins, but not the Hsp 70 in Perennial rye and Bent grass cultivars. Findings from this research can be used to differentiate cool season and warm season grass cultivars in terms of germination and survival ability under high temperature.
Manual Tags: search.rye; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 ("rye" OR secale) NOT "rye$grass"); WOS

Author: Pospelova, L. S.
Title: Results of a trial of the perennial fodder crop PRPG II42 in comparison with perennial cereals and perennial rye.
Publication Title: Sb. n.-issled. rabot aspirantov i molodykh uchenykh. Stavropol'sk. NII   s. kh.
Abstract Note: In trials in the Stavropol' area of the USSR during 1971-73, PRPG II42 [Triticum-Secale-Agropyron Hybrid II42] yielded up to 157 c/ha of green matter, outyielding A. glaucum (77 c/ha) but not S. X derzhavinii '29 + 2' (347 c/ha). In yield of dry matter (up to 49 c/ha), PRPG II42 equalled 29 + 2 and slightly exceeded A. glaucum, but was inferior in protein content to both forms. The hybrid is resistant to rust species and relatively resistant to powdery mildew.
Manual Tags: search.rye; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 ("rye" OR secale) NOT "rye$grass"); WOS

Author: N, NOVIKOV L.
Title: RESULTS OF EXPERIMENTAL STUDIES CONDUCTED TO DEVELOP A DEVICE FOR RAPID EVALUATION OF FODDER QUALITY
Publication Title: Doklady Vsesoyuznoi Ordena Lenina i Ordena Trudovogo Krasnogo Znameni   Akademii Sel'skokhozyaistvennykh Nauk Imeni V I Lenina
Abstract Note: Experiments were carried out to improve and automate traditional methods for controlling protein concentration in fodder of plant origin. Perennial grass hay and wheat, rye, and barley straws were examined, using IR spectroscopy, as was haylage from sown grasses. The use of the device made it possible to increase work productivity and to automate fodder distribution.

Author: Poletaev, G. M.; Volovik, V. F.; Goncharova, V. M.
Title: Results of the state tests of cultivars and hybrids of maize, sorghum and Sudan grass.
Abstract Note: New maize hybrids included in the Russian Register of breeding achievements are listed. The hybrids include maize Aktsent MV, Bazis, Balans, Bogatyr', Brat, Byaris, Delipot, Del'fin, DK 366, DK 391, Zernogradskii 251 MV, Kavkaz 575 MV, Kaskad 166 ASV, Kvartal, Krasnodarskii 290 MV, Kransodarskii 416 MV, Kransodarskii 632 MV, Kulundinskaya 2, Leksik R 2 N, Mashuk 480 SV, Milenium MV, Nadezhda 3 SV, Neksos, Obskii 140 SV, Pontiak, Samberz 165 MV, Splendis, Furio sumo, Tselest, Chelsea, Shumika MV; grain sorghum Prem'era, Slavyanskoe pole 112, Start; perennial sorghum Karavan and Travinka; sweet sorghum Krepysh, Slavyanskoe pole, Slavyanskoe priusadebnoe; and Sudan grass ( Sorghum sudanense) hybrid Slavyanskoe pole 15 and Turan 2. Descriptions of the hybrids are given.
Manual Tags: search.sorghum; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 sorghum); WOS

Author: Krauss, H. H.
Title: Results of trials with increased application of blast-furnace slags and carbonate lime in the NE German lowland.
Abstract Note: A report on a site amelioration trial started in 1954 on a flat site with medium to poor quality sandy soil 10 km SW of Eberswalde. Following clear felling of a poor-quality Scots pine [ Pinus sylvestris] stand, stump removal and 30-cm deep complete ploughing, treatment of a new Scots pine plantation involved application of granulated blast furnace slags (15, 30, 60, 120 t/ha) and carbonate lime, together with associate plants (rye, perennial lupin, annual yellow lupin). Intermediate reports were made in 1964/65 and 1973. In this paper, the results are presented of soil analyses made in 1992.
Manual Tags: search.rye; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 ("rye" OR secale) NOT "rye$grass"); WOS

Author: Bottrell, Dale G.; Schoenly, Kenneth G.
Title: Resurrecting the ghost of green revolutions past: The brown planthopper as a recurring threat to high-yielding rice production in tropical Asia
Abstract Note: The brown planthopper (BPH), Nilaparvata lugens (Stål), which periodically erupted in tropical Asian rice before the 1960s, became a major threat after farmers adopted green revolution technologies in the 1960s. Management and policy changes in the 1980s and 1990s emphasized non-insecticidal tactics to avert BPH outbreaks. However, insecticides have resurfaced as the primary means for controlling rice insect pests and tropical Asian countries have recently experienced planthopper outbreaks in record numbers. Our review of factors that have contributed to the outbreaks points to insecticides as the most tangible outbreak factor primarily because of their harmful effects on natural enemies. BPH resistance to insecticides and especially imidacloprid has increased the probability of outbreaks as farmers have applied increasing quantities of insecticide in an attempt to combat resistant populations. Similarly, heavy use of nitrogen fertilizer, especially on hybrid rice, has increased the potential for outbreaks. Other factors triggering outbreaks are less documented, but we discuss the possibility that the high outbreak synchrony in geographically separated populations of BPH may suggest a “Moran effect” such as climate that promotes an environment favoring above-average increases in BPH populations. Also, we hypothesize that BPH functions as a metapopulation and, as such, periodic outbreaks could be a natural phenomenon requiring resupply of planthoppers into vacant areas to ensure genetic linkage among subpopulations. We conclude with a series of recommendations for research and policy changes aimed at better understanding the cause of BPH outbreaks and for developing sustainable management practices to prevent future outbreaks.
Manual Tags: Agricultural landscapes; Insect outbreaks; Intra- and inter-population variation; Metapopulation; Moran effect; ratoon* W/5 (oryza OR rice); ScienceDirect; search.rice; SPV; Tropical pest management

Author: Xu, Zijun; Ramakrishna, Wusirika
Title: Retrotransposon insertion polymorphisms in six rice genes and their evolutionary history
Abstract Note: Retrotransposons are abundant in higher plant genomes. Although retrotransposons associated with plant genes have been identified, little is known about their evolutionary conservation at the level of species and subspecies. In the present study, we investigated the phylogenetic distribution of long terminal repeat (LTR) retrotransposon, long interspersed nuclear element (LINE) and short interspersed nuclear element (SINE) insertions in six genes in 95 cultivated and wild rice genotypes. These six genes are likely to be functional based on nonsynonymous (Ka) to synonymous (Ks) substitution ratios which were found to be significantly < 1. Different conservation patterns of these retrotransposons in genes were observed in cultivated and wild rice species. Four out of seven retrotransposon insertions appear to predate the ancestral Oryza AA genome. Two of these insertions in genes 4 and 5 occurred early in the evolutionary history of Oryza. Two retrotransposon insertions in gene 1 arose after the divergence of Asian cultivated rice from its wild ancestor. Furthermore, the retrotransposon insertion in gene 3 appears to have occurred in the ancestral lineage leading to temperate japonicas. Conservation of retrotransposon insertions in genes in specific groups, species, and lineages might be related to their specific function.
Manual Tags: Evolution; Oryza; perennial W/1 (oryza OR rice); Retrotransposons; Rice genome; ScienceDirect; search.rice; SPV

Author: Padmavathiamma, Prabha K.; Li, Loretta Y.
Title: Rhizosphere Influence and Seasonal Impact on Phytostabilisation of Metals—A Field Study [electronic resource]
Abstract Note: Field experiments were conducted to assess the influence of plant growth and amendment addition on phytostabilisation of copper (Cu), lead (Pb), manganese (Mn) and zinc (Zn) along highway soil in southwest British Columbia, Canada. The plant species tested were Lolium perenne L (perennial rye grass), Festuca rubra L. (creeping red fescue) and Poa pratensis L. (Kentucky blue grass) and the amendments, lime and phosphate. The treatment efficiencies were assessed during different seasons as a completely randomized factorial experiment in split plot design. The research tasks involved: (1) quantifying the seasonal extent of metal accumulation in soil and assessing the seasonal impact on metal speciation for different soil amendments and plant species; (2) determining seasonal accumulation differences between sampling periods in plant parts; and (3) assessing the influence of root–soil interactions on metal dynamics. The amendments decreased the exchangeable fraction and plant uptake of all four metals. The lowest mobile fractions (exchangeable and carbonate bound) were found in soils growing Festuca for Cu, Lolium for Mn and a Lolium/Poa/Festuca combination for Pb and Zn. Metal accumulation and metal dynamics in the rhizosphere soil are compared with those of the bulk soil. The final outcome was the development of a remediation strategy for all four metals involving suitable plants and amendments and incorporating seasonal and rhizosphere influences.
Manual Tags: AGRICOLA; search.rye; SPV; TX (perennial N1 ("rye" OR secale) NOT "rye#grass")

Author: Akromah, R.
Title: Rice germplasm resources in Ghana.
Abstract Note: Rice germplasm resources in Ghana consist of 3 wild species (perennial tetraploid Oryza punctata, perennial diploid O. longistaminata and annual diploid O. barthii), and 2 cultivated species (African O. glaberrima and Asian O. sativa). Since the introduction of O. sativa, 3 broad categories of rice have been cultivated: (1) rices associated with O. sativa, having leaning and loose panicles bearing white grains, (2) rices associated with O. glaberrima, having erect and compact panicles and a red testa, and (3) rices with slightly leaning habit and a red testa, believed to derive from hybrids between the African and Asian cultigens. O. sativa has proved to be adaptable to Ghanaian conditions and many local varieties have been developed. Several collections of rice germplasm have been made since 1970.
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: Beuzelin, J.M.; Mészáros, A.; Way, M.O.; Reagan, T.E.
Title: Rice harvest cutting height and ratoon crop effects on late season and overwintering stem borer (Lepidoptera: Crambidae) infestations
Abstract Note: A 2-year field study in Texas compared infestations of the stem borers Eoreuma loftini (Dyar) and Diatraea saccharalis (F.) in rice, Oryza sativa L., as affected by main crop harvest cutting height and the production of a ratoon crop. Substantial infestations (>5.6 stem borers/m2) remained in rice culms regardless of cutting height (20 vs. 40 cm). However, the 20-cm cutting height reduced E. loftini infestations by 70–81% whereas D. saccharalis infestations were not affected. Plant dissections showed that compared to D. saccharalis larvae and pupae, relatively more E. loftini immatures are located high in rice plants (>20 cm from the base of the culm). In October, the ratoon crop was more infested with stem borers than the unmanaged main crop stubble during the first year of the study. The opposite was observed during the second year. Differences in unmanaged main crop stubble phenology between the two years likely caused these differences in infestation levels. During the post-growing season, infestations in main and ratoon crop stubble decreased over the winter. After favorable winter conditions, infestations in main and ratoon crop stubble did not differ, attaining 3.3 E. loftini/m2 and 0.4 D. saccharalis/m2 by March 2008. In March 2009, rice stubble harbored 0.3 E. loftini/m2 and 0.2 D. saccharalis/m2 regardless of whether only a main crop or a main and ratoon crop had been produced. This study showed that a lower rice harvest cutting height can suppress late season E. loftini populations. Furthermore, rice stubble under favorable conditions represents a substantial overwintering habitat, thus warranting evaluation of pest management tactics targeting overwintering populations.
