Author: Qi, Z.; Helmers, M.J.; Kaleita, A.L.
Title: Soil water dynamics under various agricultural land covers on a subsurface drained field in north-central Iowa, USA
Abstract Note: Modification of land cover systems is being studied in subsurface drained Iowa croplands due to their potential benefits in increasing soil water and nitrogen depletion thus reducing drainage and NO3-N loss in the spring period. The objective of this study was to evaluate the impacts of modified land covers on soil water dynamics. In each individual year, modified land covers including winter rye-corn (rC), winter rye-soybean (rS), kura clover as a living mulch for corn (kC), and perennial forage (PF), as well as conventional corn (C) and soybean (S), were grown in subsurface drained plots in north-central Iowa. Results showed that subsurface drainage was not reduced under modified land covers in comparison to conventional corn and soybean. Soil water storage (SWS) was significantly reduced by PF treatments during the whole growing seasons and by kC during May through July when compared to the cropping system with corn or soybean only (p<0.05). Treatments of rC and rS typically maintained higher SWS than C and S, respectively, during the 3 years of this study. In the spring during a 10-15-day period when the rainfall was minimal, SWS in plots with rye, kura clover, and forage decreased at a significantly higher rate than the C and S plots which were bare. Estimated evapotranspiration (ET) during this period was significantly higher in rS, kC, and PF treatments than C and S. The results of this study suggested that significantly higher ET and similar drainage for modified land covers may increase water infiltration, which would be expected to reduce surface runoff thus to decrease stream flow. Because subsurface drainage reduction was not seen in this study, impact of modified land covers on NO3-N loss needs further investigation.
Manual Tags: Kura clover; Perennial forage; Rye cover crop; Scopus; search.rye; Soil water dynamics; SPV; TITLE-ABS-KEY (perennial W/1 ("rye" OR secale) AND NOT ("rye?grass" OR ryegrass)) AND DOCTYPE (ar)

Author: Mandal, A. B.; Pramanik, S. C.
Title: Somaclonal variation in ratooning ability in indica and japonica rice.
Abstract Note: Ratoons from somaclones (SC 2 generation) of indica rice variety Pokkali and japonica rice variety Fuzisaka-3 were evaluated under humid tropical conditions at Port Blair in 1993. They displayed wide variations in ratooning ability, plant height, panicle length, spikelet sterility and grain yield per plant. Overall, the ratooning ability of japonica was better than that of indica, however the percentages of somaclones with high ratooning ability and improvement in average ratooning ability compared to the parent were higher in the indica variety. Ratoons from somaclones were shorter than those of their parents, with the reduction being greater in Pokkali than in Fuzisaka-3. Panicle length of somaclones was slightly increased over that of the parents in both varieties. Ratoon spikelet sterility was higher in somaclones than in parents, although the magnitude was low in Pokkali. A number of somaclones produced no yield due to complete spikelet sterility. Average ratoon yield of somaclones was higher in Pokkali than in Fuzisaka-3. The majority of somaclones in both varieties produced less yield than their parents. However, out-yielders (10-12% of somaclones) were observed and these should provide scope for selecting high yielding ratoons.
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: UNGENFUKHT, V. F.
Title: Some aspects of growing perennial rye in the Volga region.
Publication Title: Nauch. Trudy nauchno-issled. Inst. sel'. Khoz. Yugo-Vostoka.
Abstract Note: Perennial fodder rye, a cross between perennial Secale [? kuprijanovii] and winter rye, grown near Saratov, USSR, gave an annual average yield of 362 hkg green material/ha in 3 yr, 166 hkg/ha more than crested wheatgrass, although the latter yielded more in the 3rd yr. Harvested at the pre-earing stage, perennial fodder rye yielded 56.3 hkg hay/ha/yr, containing 623 kg CP; respective figures for the full earing stage were 73.0 hkg and 647 kg. The content of CP in the DM at these 2 stages was 12-13.6% and 9.6-10.5%, respectively. 3 million seeds/ha was the best sowing rate on bare fallow and 7 million seed/ha after other crops. Tillering and further development of perennial fodder rye was also compared with that of crested wheatgrass.
Manual Tags: search.rye; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 ("rye" OR secale) NOT "rye$grass"); WOS

Author: BLAGOVESCENSKIJ, A. V.; SOKOLOVA, S. M.
Title: Some biochemical characteristics of perennial wheats.
Abstract Note: The thermic coefficient of the catalase proved to be lower in perennial Triticum * Agropyron hybrids than in older wheat cultivars such as Lutescens 329, the enzymatic activity of which is inferior to that of the new forms. No difference between the varieties was observed in peroxidase activity.
Manual Tags: search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); WOS

Author: GARDNER, E. H.; JACKSON, T. L.; WEBSTER, G. W.; TURLEY, R. H.
Title: Some effects of fertilization on the yield, botanical and chemical compostion of irrigated grass and grass-clover pasture swards
Abstract Note: In an irrigated pasture experiment on Vancouver Island, on a soil deficient in available N and K but apparently containing sufficient available P, Ca, and Mn for adequate plant growth, an irrigated Ladino clover-grass mixture greatly outproduced a grass mixture on a forage, protein and mineral nutrient yield basis. In order to attain even a moderate yield with a grass mixture, heavy fertilization with N and K was necessary. N fertilization was not essential to high yields with the Ladino clover-grass mixture. N fertilization tended to decrease the per cent Ladino clover and the protein and Ca content in the clover -grass forage and increased the protein content of the grass herbage. The Ca content of the grass herbage was decreased by N fertilization. The P and Mg contents of the clover-grass and grass herbage were not appreciably altered by N fertilization. Decreasing the time interval between N applications resulted in a more even production of dry matter over the growing season but did not increase the total seasonal yield. K fertilization increased the yield of both mixtures and increased the per cent clover in the grass-clover sward. Multi-annual potassium applications were required for the elimination of plant K deficiency symptoms and the applied K was quickly absorbed by the plants. Grass herbage contained more K, slightly more P and less C, Mg and N than grass-clover herbage. || ABSTRACT AUTHORS: Author
Manual Tags: search.rye; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 ("rye" OR secale) NOT "rye$grass"); WOS

Author: BARTON, LELA V.
Title: Some effects of treatment of non-dormant seeds with certain growth substances
Abstract Note: Seeds of Allium cepa, Antirrhinum majus, Avena sp., Beta vulgaris, Brassica rapa, Daucus carota var. sativa, Delphinium ajacis, Festuca pratensis, Glycine max, Lactuca sativa, Lolium perenne, Lycopersicon esculentum, Matthiola incana, Paeonia suffruticosa, Phytolacca decandra, Pisum sativum, Poa pratensis, Raphanus sativus, Secale cereale, Solanum melongena var. esculentum, Tagetes erecta, T. patula, Triticum sp., Tropaeolum majus, and Zinnia sp. were treated with growth substances applied as vapors, liquids, or dusts, and the effect on germination and further growth of the plants noted. Soaking in solns. of K [alpha]-naphthalene-acetate at conc. of 320, 106.6, 35.5, 11.8, 3.7, and 1.2 mg./l. failed to increase the speed or percentage of germination. Injury was obtained with the higher conc. Powder treatments with Auxan, Rootone, or Merck prepns. (containing indole-butyric acid in conc. of 2, 5, 8, or 12 mg./g.) were also without a stimulating effect. Similar treatments of 6-yr.-old tomato seeds failed to promote germination. Measurements of very young seedlings grown from treated seeds of 9 vars. indicated increased seedling length as a result of certain treatments of eggplant, radish, and stock. These differences were apparent only when the seeds were germinated on moist filter paper and never appeared in soil plantings. Stunting effects were obtained by one or more of the higher conc. treatments of all 9 types of seeds. When tomato plants from treated seeds were grown to maturity, no stimulation of growth was noted, although soine stunting effects persisted. Treated and control lots of seeds of meadow fescue, perennial rye grass, Kentucky Blue grass, oats, spring rye, and wheat produced plants with the same growth rate and time of maturity. A study of the flowering of larkspur, marigold, nasturtium, snapdragon, stock, and zinnia plants from treated seeds revealed no significant differences from the control plants, either in the number of plants producing flowers or in the number of flowers produced. In many of the tap roots of radish plants from seeds treated with the higher conc. a region of constriction was produced after the root started to enlarge and below this constriction a 2d enlargement occurred giving the appearance of a double root. || ABSTRACT AUTHORS: Auth. summ
Manual Tags: search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); WOS

Author: CHERNOV, A. P.
Title: Some elements of root nourishment in the central northern Caucasus Predkavkazskiy Chernozem area in connection with fertilizer application and hay yields from perennial rye
Publication Title: Sbornik Nauch Issled Robot Stud Stavropol Sk Inst
Abstract Note: On the basis of field and laboratory experiments Kravkov's method of investigating soil types makes it possible to clarify the reserves of fundamental nutritive elements and in this way, to some extent, to predetermine the effectiveness of certain variants of field experiments. The joint application of organic and mineral fertilizers is of practical significance for this particular region. || ABSTRACT AUTHORS: Transl. from Referat. Zhur. Biol. 10529, 1958, courtesy OTS-JPRS

Author: Griffiths, Ellis; Siddiqi, M.A.
Title: Some factors affecting occurrence of Fusarium Culmorum in the soil
Publication Title: Transactions of the British Mycological Society
Abstract Note: During a survey of soil fungi in plots of perennial rye-grass, Fusarium culmorum (W. G. Sm.) Sacc. was regularly isolated over a period of 21 months. Frequency of isolation was significantly greater from plots which had been limed and from those receiving nitrogen; there was, however, no evidence of an interaction between lime and nitrogen. There was also a significant seasonal variation in frequency of isolation. This could not be related simply to either soil moisture or temperature considered independently, but there was evidence of interaction in that low frequencies were associated with either (a) low temperature (< 7° C.) and high moisture or (b) high temperature (> 7°) and low moisture; higher frequencies, on the other hand, were associated with high temperature coupled with high moisture. Frequency of recovery of the fungus from soil samples incubated in the laboratory for 28 days, under a wide range of temperature and moisture conditions, followed closely that found in the field. The inhibitory effect of high temperature at low moisture levels was not observed in sterilized soil, and it has been concluded that under these conditions microbial antagonism plays a significant role in determining the activity of F. culmorum. It has been found that, in sterilized soil at low moisture levels, Trichoderma viride suppresses growth of F. culmorum at temperatures above 10°, whereas at lower temperatures F. culmorum suppresses T. viride.
Journal Abbreviation: Transactions of the British Mycological Society
Manual Tags: perennial W/1 ("rye" OR secale) AND NOT ("rye?grass" OR "ryegrass"); ScienceDirect; search.rye; SPV

Author: Prashar, C.R.K.
Title: Some factors governing rice-ratoon yields
Abstract Note: Studies on rice ratooning showed that the height of cutting the main crop affected the maturity period and the yield of the ratoon. The ratoon yield was significantly higher when the main crop was cut at ground level versus cutting at 4,8 and 12 cm high, but the maturity period was lower with a higher cutting. Delaying first watering for 4 to 8 days was superior to watering a day after the harvest of the main crop. The ratoon yield was about 14 per cent higher than the planted crop.

Author: Zhang, J.; Yuan, Z.
Title: Some new sources of resistance in wheat.
Abstract Note: Xinkang 1 (NS2625 X Zhong 3) is immune to 9 races of Puccinia striiformis (22, 23, 26 and 29, L13II, L10II, L10V and Suweon 11II), 4 races of P. recondita (1, 2, 3 and 20) and to Erysiphe graminis. It is a semi-winter variety, 115 cm tall, with red, semi- durum grains; 1000-grain weight is 28 g. Xinkang 2, with the same parents and also a semi-winter variety, is immune to P. striiformis races 28, L13II, L10V and Suweon 11II and highly resistant to races 25, 29 and L13V. Plant height is 110cm. The grains are red, of durum type, and the 1000-grain weight is 45 g. Xinkang 3, another semi-winter variety of the same parentage, is immune to 10 races of P. striiformis (22, 23, 25, 26, 28, 29, L13II, L10II, L10V and Suweon 11I). Plant height is 112 cm. Grains are red, of durum type and good quality; 1000-grain weight is 46 g. Xinkang 4 ((Shuang 1 X 974-1253) X perennial wheat) is an early, winter variety immune or highly resistant to P. striiforis races 28, L13V, L13II and L10V. Plant height is 115 cm and the grain is white and of semi- durum type; 1000-grain weight is 45 g.

Author: HUGHES, C. G.
Title: Some recent developments in the study of ratoon stunting disease
Abstract Note: Ratoon stunting disease may be transmitted to sugarcane by inoculation with extracts of corn and sweet sorghum that had previously been inoculated with juice from diseased sugarcane. The disease may be transmitted through the roots of the cane. || ABSTRACT AUTHORS: L. G. Davidson

Author: FRANTSEV, A. V.
Title: Some ways of influencing life in fresh water reservoirs Referat. Zhur., Biol., 1962, No. 24Zh403. (Translation)
Abstract Note: The article presents some methods of actively controlling life in fresh-water reservoirs. Water quality in canals carrying drinking water deteriorates due to pollution by fouling organisms. In a river, representing another type of flow, there are three factors relating to self-purification of water: sands through which the water filters; shallow stretches of water with aquatic vegetation, in which a segment of biogenic substance is surrendered, quantity of plankton decreases and a coagulation of some substances does occur; also, deep water sedimentation stretches in which suspended matter settles. These natural resources should be subject to intelligent exploitation. The significance of sand in self-purification of water was demonstrated on laboratory models. Discussed are trends in practical exploitation of higher forms of aquatic vegetation, in part with relation to water supply, where cultivation and harvest of plants for farm animal fodder is one of the economically sound means, while exploitation of the antagonism of higher aquatic vegetation and phytoplankton represents a radical means of controlling florescence. It would be proper to limit research at the start to four plants, most promising from the standpoint of fodder, annual and perennial rice, canary grass and sloughgrass; the work should involve crop assimilation and development of farming techniques on a scale of one to two farms. The practice of planting and sowing both species of rice is in effect on the Uchinskoe reservoir.
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: Dunavin, L. S.
Title: Sorghum alone vs. corn and sorghum in double-harvest program for silage.
Publication Title: Proceedings, Soil and Crop Science Society of Florida
Abstract Note: Double cropping with maize or sweet corn followed by sorghum was compared with sorghum followed by its ratoon crop in field trials on fine sandy loam in 1971-4. Average DM yields for sorghum (1st crop), maize and sweet corn, based on 4 cultivars in each case, were 17.19, 12.86 and 7.08 t/ha, respectively. The sorghum ratoon crop gave 6.38 t, sorghum following maize 8.02 t and sorghum following sweet corn 8.65 t/ha. In 1973-4, total grain yields for any crop combination were not significantly different, though total forage yields decreased in the order forage sorghum + ratoon crop > maize/sorghum > sweet corn/sorghum.
Manual Tags: search.sorghum; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 sorghum); WOS

Author: Tapadia, B. B.; Kale, V. C.; Navhat, D. A.; Nagargoje, S. R.
Title: Sorghum based cropping system for irrigated areas of Marathwada region of Maharashtra
Abstract Note: A field trial was conducted during 1984-85 to 1986-87 at Marathwada Agricultural University, Parbhani (India) to evaluate the production potential, economic feasibility and social adoptability of sorghum (Sorghum bicolor (L.) Moench) base cropping sequence in comparison with premonsoon groundnut followed by wheat in rabi. Results indicate that, among the sorghum base sequence, sorghum-bengal gram and sorghum-sunflower proved superior with limited resources of water to maximize the productivity and net returns within the range of Rs. 7.2 to 10.4 th/ha and C.B. ratio ranging from 1:1 80 to 1:2.80.
Manual Tags: search.sorghum; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 sorghum); WOS

Author: Foale, M. A.; Carberry, P.
Title: Sorghum in the farming system: reviewing performance, and identifying opportunities by doing on-farm research.
Abstract Note: Until recently the investigation of crop management on-farm has been a minor part of the broad scientific research effort. Researchers have been content rather to apply skills derived from crop science to solve specific plant problems of adaptation and protection, nutrition, water use and so forth. Any particular farmer best appreciates the specifics of managing his or her own crop and paddock combination, such that interaction with researchers may diminish once the general principles of crop and plant performance are understood. In dryland farming, however, there is a great deal of `slack' in the linkage between principles and practice. This situation has been addressed with the development of soil and crop monitoring tools that provide the specifics of a crop and paddock which can be linked to the principles of system performance using a simulation model. The output generated by a crop simulator enables researchers to contribute usefully to discussions of crop management with farmers. Actual and simulated experience are compared and combined, leading to enhanced appreciation by the farmer of the degree of exposure to risk that he faces in making management decisions. This would be expected to enhance the farmer's ability to make decisions that improve productivity and profit. Sorghum occupies a major niche in many semiarid subtropical farming systems due to its generally low cost of production, and its ability to respond to favourable seasons with high yield. The sorghum crop is flexible, providing vital soil protection both as a standing crop and as postharvest residue, and it is also valuable forage. Even in a situation where the price of cotton can give a gross return 3 times higher than sorghum on a crop-for-crop basis, sorghum holds a strong position because of the lower risk involved in both establishing and protecting the crop. Sorghum has a growing season that is one third shorter than cotton and it consumes proportionally less soil water resources, and also provides substantial protective residue whereas the recommendation for cotton fields is postharvest cultivation to reduce the survival of resistant pests. Sorghum presents the possibility of a ratoon crop which provides prolonged soil protection and takes advantage of spring rainfall, especially in the northern grain belt, where the `gain to rain' ratio is likely to be higher for the ratoon crop than the primary crop. On-farm cropping research enables a systematic assessment of the different levels of risk associated with substitutable crops. The equivalent of many years of farming experience can be accumulated, using advanced tools for monitoring and simulation. This approach contributes to valuable learning when researchers and farmers interpret simulator outputs in a discussion group that pays heed also to their personal experience.
Manual Tags: search.sorghum; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 sorghum); WOS

Author: Foloni, J. S. S.; Tiritan, C. S.; Calonego, J. C.; Dundes, L. R.
Title: Sorghum regrowth under different cutting heights and nitrogen rates.
Abstract Note: Regrowth capacity is one of the greatest advantages of sorghum, allowing other crops without sowing new seeds or plant regrowth for grazing in Crop-Livestock Integration Systems. An experiment was conducted to evaluate regrowth capacity, phytomass production, N level and N accumulation in biomass of sorghum regrowth, as a function of cutting height and N top dress application. The experiment was conducted after the first harvest of sorghum ( Sorghum bicolor cv. Volumax) for silage, at different cutting heights: tall (0.36 m0.08) and short (0.13 m0.03) cuttings, different top dress nitrogen rates (0, 30, 60 and 120 kg/ha) at sorghum regrowth. At 35 days after cutting, the tall cutting gave the highest dry matter production, therefore, if sorghum regrowth is used for grazing, it is recommended to leave tall ratoons and application of

Author: ZhenXie, Yi; NaiMei, Tu; PingPing, Chen
Title: Source-sink characteristics of main crop and ratoon crop of several new hybrid rice combinations.
Abstract Note: Eight hybrid rice combinations (64S/E32 Pei ai 64S/E32, 500 Peiliangyou 500, 64S/B52 Pei ai 64S/B52, Liangyoupeijiu, 2054 Kangliangyou 2054, 18S/53159 Lu 18S/53159, T98A/259 and 316A/180) were used to study the source-sink characteristics and yields of main and ratoon crops. The leaf area (LA) index (LAI) and the LA per culm of the ratoon crop were approximately 1/3 and 1/7-1/3 of those of the main crop, respectively. The total sink volume of the ratoon crop was higher by 1.5- to 2.0-fold than that of the main crop. The ratio of the number of grains to the LA (RGL) in the ratoon crop was higher than that of the main crop by 1.5- to 2.0-fold. The high RGL was beneficial for obtaining high yields in the main crop. The high LAI and weight of stem sheath at maturity, low RGL, and high dry matter distribution to the stem sheath of the main crop were beneficial for obtaining high yields in the ratoon crop. A positive correlation was observed between LAI at the full heading stage and yield of the ratoon crop. In the ratoon crop, a positive correlation was observed between LA per culm at the full heading stage and yield per culm. A negative correlation was evident between RGL and seed set, and between RGL and yield. The source-sink relationship in the ratoon crop, especially the upper-node ratoon rice, was of the source-limited type. The yields of 18S/53159, Kangliangyou 2054, Pei ai 64S/E32 and Peiliangyou 500 ratoon crops were greater than 5200 kg/hm 2. Based on the yield of the ratoon crop and total yields under the climatic conditions of Changsha region, Hunan, China, during 2002, the optimum combination for ratooning was Peiai 64 S/E32, followed by Kangliangyou 2054 and T98A/259.
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: Zhen-xie, Yi; Nai-mei, Tu; Ping-ping, Chen
Title: Source-sink characteristics of main crop and ratooning rice of several new hybrid rice combinations
Abstract Note: Eight hybrid rice combinations were used to study the source-sink characteristics of main crop and ratooning rice in hybrid rice, and the source-sink relationship for yield formation in ratooning rice. The results indicated that: (1) Leaf area index(LAI) of ratooning rice was about one third of that of the main crop, and leaf area per culm of ratooning rice was about from one seventh to one third of that of the main crop. The whole sink volume of the main crop was about 1. 5 times of that of ratooning rice. The ratio of grain number to leaf area in ratooning rice was 1. 5 to 2 times of that in the main crop. (2) High ratio of grain number to leaf area was beneficial to get high yield in the main crop. High LAI at maturity stage. low ratio of grain number to leaf area, high weight of stem-sheath at maturity stage and high export percentage of the matter in stern-sheath in the main crop were helpful to obtain high yield in ratooning rice. (3) There was a positive correlation at the 0. 05 level between LAI at full heading stage and yield of ratooning rice. To upper-node ratooning rice, there were a positive correlation at the 0. 01 level between leaf area per culm at full heading stage and yield per culm. a negative correlation between the ratio of grain number to leaf area and seed setting rate. and a negative correlation at the 0. 01 level between the ratio of grain number to leaf area and yield. The type of source-sink relationship of ratooning rice. especially of upper-node ratooning rice belonged to the source-limited. (4) The yields of ratooning rice of Lu 18S/53159, Kangliangyou 2054. Pei'ai 64S/E32 and Peiliangyou 500 were all above 5200 kg/hm(2). Considering synthetically yield of ratooning rice and the total of the two crops. under the climate conditions of 2002 in Changsha region. the optimal combination for ratooning was Pei'ai 64S/E32. followed by Kangliangyou 2054 and T98A/259.
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: VAVILOV, N. I.
Title: Soviet scientific plant industry during the period of Soviet reconstruction 1930-1933.
Publication Title: Bull. Appl. Bot. Leningrad, Ser. A
Abstract Note: The achievements of the last three years are reviewed, reference being made to the enormous scale on which agricultural research is now carried on in the U.S.S.R. As a result of this it is now possible for every locality to cultivate only those varieties that are adapted to it-the State Variety Testing Service is testing over 2, 000 Soviet and foreign varieties of 125 different crops at 400 different stations. Breeding methods are being fundamentally changed so as to form a complex system involving the co-operation of physiologists, phytopathologists, entomologists, chemists and technologists. The more important achievements in the form of improved new varieties are reviewed. Special mention is made of the use of wild fruit trees in hybridization by Michurin, of the hybrids of wheat by rye of Meister and others, the production by interspecific crossing of wheats of the vulgare type having the hard durum grain, of perennial wheats from crosses with Agropyrum, of fertile amphidiploids between a number of species giving sterile hybrids and of sugar beet x mangold hybrids with increased yield. Special reference is also made to the discovery of new species of wheat and potatoes and the valuable practical results that are already beginning to accrue therefrom; also to the valuable results obtained from artificial curtailment of the length of day in many southern forms of both herbaceous plants and trees. Special new methods, suitable for use by breeders, have been elaborated for determining the cold and drought resistance and other physiological properties of the plant, extensive tests have been carried out with success on vernalization, special attention has been devoted to quality in nearly all crops, and the areas of possible cultivation of a great number of crops, notably cotton, have been extended by the production of improved forms. Collections have been made of the cultivated plants of the whole world, the wild fruit trees having proved to be specially interesting and important, the centre of origin of most European fruit trees having been shewn to be in Transcaucasia and Central Asia, including parts of Persia and Turkey. A thorough study of these areas is being executed. Great numbers of new plants have also been brought into cultivation, including the valuable new rubber plant tau-saghiz, which yields a rubber of the first quality. The application of cytogenetics has led to the production of polyploid forms of certain small bush fruits with increased berry size. Similarly Pangalo's studies on the cucurbits have made known the extent and the interrelationships of this large group for the first time, by classifying the whole world collection and separating out the most valuable types, and by crossing with species themselves not distinguished by high sugar content twofold increases in the sugar content have resulted.

Author: VOROB'EV, S. A.
Title: Spacing of annuals in crop rotations in a nonchernozem zone Referat. Zhur., Biol., 1959, No. 79286. (Translation)
Abstract Note: Experiments over many years on soddy-podzolic soils of the Moscow Oblast' have clearly shown the advantages of cultivation of winter crops on a 1-year perennial grass sod. From crops thus grown the following average yields were obtained over a 4-yr. period on fertilized and unfertilized backgrounds respectively: winter rye, on fertilized background, 25 to 27 metric centners/ha, without fertilization, 16 to 20 metric centners/ha; spring wheat 12 metric centners/ha, and 8 metric centners/ha respectively; potato 196 to 232 metric centners/ha, and 147.5 metric centners/ha respectively. When sown on a 2-year grass sod grown on well cultivated soils, the yields were: winter rye 26 and 17 metric centners/ha with and without fertilized background respectively; spring wheat 27 and 20 metric centners/ha respectively. In these conditions it is profitable to grow spring wheat and other spring crops, or potato. In the 1st year after the plowing in of grass sod the number of water-stable aggregates in the soil increased considerably. The structure of soil is retained for 3 years after the plowing in of grass sod, but then sharply deteriorates especially in nonfertilized soil. When grass is plowed for winter crops in summer, there is a decrease of water-stable aggregates. If the plowed sod is used for potato, these changes are unimportant. The total yield of a 4-yr. link of crop rotation with clover fallow is more productive than the same link with bare fallow. Winter rye yield after occupied fallow and fertilized soil was similar to that after fertilized bare fallow. Corn yield was highest on plowed sod after cereals, while corn sown after potato gave only a low yield. || ABSTRACT AUTHORS: Courtesy NSF (PL 83-480) 1963
Manual Tags: search.rye; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 ("rye" OR secale) NOT "rye$grass"); WOS

Author: XiaoLin, Yang; ZhenWei, Song; Hong, Wang; QuanHong, Shi; Fu, Chen; QingQuan, Chu
Title: Spatio-temporal variations of winter wheat water requirement and climatic causes in Huang-Huai-Hai Farming Region.
Publication Title: Zhongguo Shengtai Nongye Xuebao / Chinese Journal of Eco-Agriculture
Abstract Note: Information on crop water requirement and the changes in this factor in time and space are critical for irrigation schemes, water resources planning and decision-making. Based on observed daily meteorological data in 50 weather stations in 7 sub-zones of Huang-Huai-Hai Farming Region (HFR) in 1960-2009, winter wheat water requirement and irrigation amount were simulated using the modified SIMETAW model. Results showed that winter wheat water requirement decreased from 1960 to 2009, with a significant decrease of 9.21-18.90 mm from 1970 to 1999. Winter wheat perennial average water requirement was 452.4 mm, coupled rainfall degree for winter wheat growing season was only 0.40. Winter wheat irrigation amount varied among different sub-zones, it increased at the rate of 10.02-13.48 mm per decade in western Henan Province and central Shanxi and Shaanxi Provinces. With regard to spatial distribution, water requirement and irrigation amount during winter wheat growing season were higher in the peripheral than in the central regions. Both water requirement and irrigation amount were highest in the west Henan Province with values of 457.32 mm and 335.33 mm. However, winter wheat water requirement and irrigation amount were lowest in the lower Haihe Plain with values of 363.24 and 247.51 mm. While temperature significantly increased, wind speed, humidity and solar radiation significantly decreased and also with an insignificant decrease in precipitation from 1960 to 2009. The negative trend in winter wheat water requirement in HFR was mainly attributed to declining solar radiation, which was in turn driven by some other climatic factors. Correlation analysis showed that temperature, sunshine hour and wind speed were positively correlated with winter wheat water requirement, while relative humidity was negatively correlated with it.
Manual Tags: search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); WOS

Author: CRAWFORD, W. R.
Title: Specialized small seed production on Marlborough Farm.
Abstract Note: Farming is described on a holding in the lower Wairau Valley where the summer is dry with much sunshine. The main crops grown for seed each year are: peas, wheat, perennial ryegrass, white clover, onions and broad beans. The main rotation is: pasture 4 to 5 years/peas/wheat/clover for seed or pasture 4 to 5 years/peas/ryegrass for seed. " The certification of perennial ryegrass and white clover under the Department of Agriculture's seed certification scheme is an important part of the farm programme. No seed of a class lower than Pedigree is sown and Government Stock seed is used when available."-M.H.

Author: BAKHTIN, P. U.; VOLOTSKAYA, V. I.
Title: Specific resistance of grey forest soils during plowing in the Pakhomovo sovhoz, Tul skaya Oblast'
Abstract Note: These are the 1st results of determining the specific resistance of soils of the "Pakhomovo" sovkhoz during plowing: a) of light grey forest podzolized soil beneath 2nd year perennial grasses and on oats stubble; b) of grey forest soil with gleyey subsoil under peas with oats and sunflower for silage; c) of grey forest soil with a double humus layer and with surface gleying under winter wheat for green forage; d) on an area of light grey soil and grey soil with gleyey subsoil after deep plowing following the radical soil alteration method (after Bushinskiy). When the moisture of the soil equals or approaches the optimum moisture, the maximum specific resistance values are obtained on clover area, and against a background of deep plowing, on light grey forest podzolized soils. These values are in category of medium heavy and heavy specific resistance (0.60-0.82 and 0.59-0.76 kg/cm2). On the remaining areas the specific resistances of soils are medium. On light grey forest soils, in connection with their inferior state of cultivation, the specific resistances during normal moisture are higher than on the grey forest soil with gleyey subsoil. The minimum specific resistance indices are recorded on grey forest soils with a double humus horizon (0.43-0.48 kg/cm2). With subsoiling, despite an increase in the total traction effort registered on the tractor bar, the specific resistance of the soil decreased on all areas, as a result of the high state of soil cultivation, decrease in the hardness of the subplowed layer, and its lower bulk density. || ABSTRACT AUTHORS: Authors
Manual Tags: search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); WOS

Author: Stenberg, M.
Title: Spying establishment of perennial ryegrass in winter wheat
Abstract Note: Catch crops, under-sown in spring cereals and kept growing during autumn and winter, have been shown to reduce nitrate leaching in several field experiments. In Sweden, perennial ryegrass (Lolium perenne L.) is often used as a catch crop, both in experiments and by farmers. Autumn-sown crops such as winter wheat and winter rye are not as efficient as ryegrass in reducing soil nitrogen content during autumn and winter. Thus, to meet the Swedish legislation of keeping arable land covered with catch crops during autumn and winter, it may be necessary to establish a catch crop in a growing winter cereal crop. In this study, with the objective of evaluate methods for catch crop establishment in winter cereals, different dates for under-sowing winter wheat with perennial ryegrass in spring were compared. Two held experiments per year were carried out during a four-year period. In 1994, double- and single-mounted tractor wheels were added as treatments and in 1995-97, two types of seed drills were compared. Under-sowing with ryegrass in spring had only minor effects on winter wheat yields. Only very early in weak wheat stands or very late in wheat already at stem elongation did the action of the seed drill significantly reduce yield. It was observed that the choice of drill for under-sowing might influence the wheat yield. In a dense winter wheat crop, fast emergence was important for establishment of a good catch crop. In most cases, the highest number of emerged ryegrass plants was achieved by early under-sowing, since soil water content was generally higher in early spring than in late. On sowing too early, however, soil temperature was too low for acceptable establishment. Ryegrass establishment and growth were lowest at the latest sowing dates.
Manual Tags: search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); WOS

Author: UMRANI, NK; JOSHI, AC; KAREPPA, SM
Title: STABILITY AND ECONOMICS OF CROP SEQUENCES UNDER ASSURED WATER-SUPPLY
Abstract Note: An experiment was conducted during 1981-1986 to study the stability and economics of the multiple-crop sequences under assured water supply. The sequences included cereals, pulses, oilseed and forage crops. Sorghum [Sorghum bicolor (L.) Moench]-wheat (Triticum aestivum L. emend. Fiori & Paol.)-groundnut (Arachis hypogaea L.) was the most stable sequence, giving the maximum net returns. Inclusion of summer groundnut in the sequence increased the net returns. Short-duration pulses and ratooning of sorghum were highly unstable over period of time. Sorghum-gram (Cicer arietinum L.)-pearlmillet [Pennisetum glaucum (L.) R. Br. emend. Stuntz] (for fodder) was also productive and stable crop sequences. Judged from calories productivity sorghum-gram-pearlmillet (fodder) was the best sequence. Based on the protein productivity cowpea (fodder)-sorghum-groundnut was found to be the best sequence.
Manual Tags: search.sorghum; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 sorghum); WOS

Author: Pandey, N.; Singh, N. B.
Title: Stability for seed yield in pigeonpea hybrids.
Abstract Note: Ten hybrid genotypes of long duration pigeonpea ( Cajanus cajan) were evaluated over four years (1992-96) at Muzaffarpur, Bihar, for seed yield. Mean differences between hybrids (H) and years (Y) were highly significant indicating substantial variability among hybrids and years for seed yield. Highly significant variance due to environment + (H * Y) revealed that hybrids interacted considerably with environmental conditions that existed during different years. Significant H * Y interaction was observed for seed yield. Both linear and nonlinear components of H * Y interaction played important roles in the expression of seed yield. However, the linear component was larger in magnitude. It was observed that RAUPH 9117 and RAUPH 9003 were adaptable to all environments, while the hybrid genotypes RAUPH 9122 and RAUPH 9127 were suitable for higher yielding environments.
Manual Tags: search.grain; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 grain); WOS

Author: Sompaew, V.; Datta, S. K. de
Title: Stand establishment techniques and management practices for direct-seeded rice.
Abstract Note: Four field experiments were conducted from March 1978 to February 1979 at the International Rice Research Institute Farm on Maahas clay to determine the effects of planting method, land preparation method, and nitrogen fertilizer management on the stand establishment, plant characters, grain yield, and yield components of direct-seeded rice. For wetland rice, additional studies were conducted to determine the feasibility of ratoon cropping in increasing the productivity of rice. Furthermore, the different seedling ages were used in the experiment with wetland rice to determine the feasibility of reducing field duration. The dibbling method produced higher grain yield than the other methods for dryland seeding, and the drilling method for wetland seeding. The normal tillage operation gave grain yield similar to that obtained with intensive land preparation. During both dry and wet seasons two split applications of nitrogen fertilizer produced the same grain yield as the placement of nitrogen in the reduced soil layer. For the dry season, the optimum seedling age for the early-maturing varieties was 20 to 30 days, and for the medium- and late-maturing varieties was 30 to 40 days. But for the wet season planting, the optimum seedling ages for all varieties were 20 to 30 days. Seedling ages of the main crop had no effect on the grain yield of the rice ratoon crop. Deep placement of nitrogen fertilizer to the main crop gave a higher grain yield in the ratoon crop compared with split application. Higher grain yields were obtained from the rice ratoons from the late-maturing varieties. The grain yield of the rice ratoon crops ranged from 28 to 34% of the main crop. The maturity of the ratoon crops varied from 53 to 68 days after cutting the main crops depending upon the variety.
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: ALEKSEYEV, E. K.
Title: State and perspectives of the application of green manure in the USSR
Abstract Note: Some zones are chosen in which the introduction of legume crops is advisable. Peculiarities of their cultivation are shown. (1) Woodlands of Ukraine, Byelorussia to the latitude of Minsk, adjoining regions of the Lithuanian SSSR, of the Bryansk, Kaliningrad and other neighboring districts (yellow fodder, narrow-eared and perennial lupines, seradella). (2) The zone to the Leningrad-Kostroma line (one-year and perennial lupines, maple pea, melilot). (3) Siberia and the Far East (annual and perennial lupines). (4) Irrigated lands (winter pea, winter vetch, clover). (5) Humid subtropics of the transcaucasus (white and narrow leaved lupines, seradella, lotus, cow pea, soybean, pigeon pea). || ABSTRACT AUTHORS: Transl. from Referat. Zhur. Biol. 24778, 1958, courtesy OTS-JPRS
Manual Tags: search.pigeonpea; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (cajanus OR "pigeon$pea")); WOS

Author: Tsitsin, N. V.
Title: State and prospects of research in the field of distant hybridization.
Abstract Note: Information is presented on the methodology of intergeneric hybridization and on Soviet successes in breeding intergeneric hybrids, especially of cereals, such as Triticum X Agropyron, Triticum X Secale and Triticum X Elymus, Triticum X Agropyron X Elymus and Triticum X Secale X Agropyron. Particular attention is paid to Triticum X Agropyron hybrids, which the author has designated as a new wheat species, T. agropyrotriticum, with two subspecies, subsp. perenne (perennial wheat) and subsp. submittans (forage wheats).
Manual Tags: search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); WOS

Author: Johnson, W.L.
Title: Strategies for improving the nutritional status of small ruminants in tropical ecosystems
Abstract Note: Research on goat and sheep nutrition and feeding systems has been initiated in five tropical or Mediterranean countries, by United States and host-country institutions which are participants in the Small Ruminant Collaborative Research Support Program. The major objective is to increase small ruminant productivity by better utilizing locally available feedstuffs and to more closely meet the nutritional needs of animals during the critical phases of their production cycle. West Java, Indonesia, is a humid tropical site with high rainfall and intensive agriculture, with small ruminants raised in nearly total confinement. Village feed resources include native grasses, tree legumes, and foliage from food crops. Energy may be the most limiting nutrient, due to seasonal feed availability and intake limitation when tropical grasses form a large proportion of the diet. Western Kenya is a wet-dry tropical site with a long and a short rainy season. The feasibility of intensifying dual purpose goat production within mixed crop-livestock systems is under study. Solutions to severe dry season feed limitations are being evaluated. Sweet potato vines and legumes such as pigeon peas have been demonstrated to be excellent in nutritional value, with high intakes by lactating does. Intercropped or ratooned sorghum also has promise. Northeast Brazil is representative of the semiarid tropics with a short, variable rainy season and prolonged dry season during which all production parameters for goats and hair sheep are unsatisfactory. The native “caatinga” brushland is the major feed resource. Dry season confinement of lambs has resulted in adequate growth (90 g/day or more) when fed maized crop residue plus supplements. Weanling kids fed the same ration have lower intake and gains of 20 to 40 g/day. Sorghum hay has been fed to lactating dairy goats. The fourth site, Morocco, has a Mediterranean climate with good rainfall in spring, prolonged drought in summer and fall, and cold limitation in winter (especially at higher elevations). Wheat stubble and other crop residues are under study for their nutritional contribution and supplementation requirements in summer, fall and winter. Also, studies are underway on productivity responses of native sheep in extensive or semi-intensive systems, as well as the prolific D'man breed in total confinement. The fifth site is Peru, where Andean highland areas are limited by cold year-round and extended drought for part of the year. Grazing systems for sheep and alpacas are under study at three Andean locations. At a coastal site, which receives sporadic rain (1 to 3 months, not every year), improved feeding systems for seminomadic herds of dual purpose goats are under study.
Manual Tags: crop residues; Goats; humid tropics; Nutrition; ratoon* W/5 sorghum; ScienceDirect; Scopus; search.sorghum; semiarid tropics; sheep; SPV; TITLE-ABS-KEY (ratoon* W/5 sorghum) AND DOCTYPE (ar)

Author: E, MOLLER; N, WITT; Z, THELLESEN H.
Title: STRAW FOR FODDER VI. ADDITION OF SODIUM HYDROXIDE
Abstract Note: The report presents results from 9 experiments in the years 1981-84 with NaOH-treated straw of barley, winter wheat and perennial ryegrass. The experiments were conducted at The National Agricultural Engineering Institute, Bygholm. The digestibility trials (sheep) with 62 lots of untreated and NaOH-treated straw from the experiments were conducted at The Govenment Research Station, Odum and The Institute of Forage Crops, Foulum. The results from the experiments with addition of NaOH have been corrected for the influence of NaOH-application on the determination of
Manual Tags: search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); WOS

Author: Slykhuis, John T.; Watson, Marion A.
Title: STRIATE MOSAIC OF CEREALS IN EUROPE AND ITS TRANSMISSION BY DELPHACODES PELLUCIDA (FAB.)
Abstract Note: A virus disease that resembles wheat striate mosaic was found affecting up to 5 % of the plants in English wheat fields in 1956. Symptoms on wheat included fine chlorotic striae, followed by stunting, general chlorosis, and death of plants. Other hosts included oats, barley, rye, perennial rye grass and Italian rye grass. The virus was transmitted by Delphacodes pellucida (Fabricius) (Homoptera, Delphacidae). A few of the insects were already infective when caught in the field. The percentage of infective individuals was increased by feeding the insects for 24 hr. or longer on diseased plants, and up to 56 % became infective after feeding on diseased plants for 3 days. Non-infective. e insects were unable to transmit the virus until from 8 to 36 days after they first fed on diseased plants, but they frequently remained infective for the remainder of their lives, up to 10 weeks after feeding on a diseased plant. Infective insects seldom transmitted the virus during test feeds as short as 30 min. When fed for I or more days on each test plant, some insects infected many plants in succession, others seldom infected test plants even if they fed as long as 7 days on each. The virus was transmitted through the eggs to as many as 88% of the progeny of infective females, and to some of the progeny of a few females that had failed to infect wheat test plants.
Manual Tags: search.rye; search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 ("rye" OR secale) NOT "rye$grass"); TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); WOS

Author: Smith, M.a.; Carter, P.r.
Title: Strip intercropping corn and alfafa
Abstract Note: Strip intercropping annual row crops can improve productivity, but the effect of strip cropping grain and perennial forage crops has not been thoroughly investigated. This study was conducted to evaluate the productivity and profitability of strip intercropping corn (Zea mays L.) and alfalfa (Medicago sativa L.). Alternating strips of corn and alfalfa of three widths (10, 20, and 40 ft) were compared in a field trial conducted from 1988 through 1990. Corn silking dates, heights, grain yields, and moisture were determined for each row within strips. Alfalfa yields and forage quality were determined for harvest strips within plots and for whole plots. Land equivalent ratios (LER) and gross returns to both strips and sole crops were calculated. In the drought of 1988, neither corn nor alfalfa yields differed due to strip width or from the sole crop yield. In 1989, corn yields were lowest for the sole crop (146 bu/acre), increased 3% in 40-ft strips, and 10% in 10- and 20-ft strips. In 1990, corn yields were also lowest for the sole crop (123 bu/acre), and increased 6% in 40-, 11% in 20-, and 17% in 10-ft wide strips. Alfalfa yields did not differ due to strip width or from the sole crop yield in 1989. In 1990, alfalfa yields in strips vs. the sole crop were reduced 10% only for the 10-ft wide plots. Land equivalent ratios were lowest in 1988, with values below 1.00 for 10- and 40-ft strips. All strip widths had values above 1.00 in subsequent years. Maximum LERS were 1.02, 1.08, and 1.06 for 20-ft strips in 1988, 1989, and 1990, respectively. In all years, 20-ft wide strips had the greatest economic advantage, returning $6, $29, and $17/acre over sole crops in 1988, 1989, and 1990, respectively. Increases in prices received for crops always increased the advantage of strip intercropping.
Manual Tags: AGRICOLA; search.grain; search.rice; SPV; TX (perennial N1 grain)
Automatic Tags: crop yield; drought; field experimentation; forage; intercropping; light; Medicago sativa; meteorological data; prices; profitability; soil water content; width; Wisconsin; Zea mays

Author: Smith, M.A.; Carter, P.R.
Title: Strip intercropping corn and alfalfa
Abstract Note: Strip intercropping annual row crops can improve productivity, but the effect of strip cropping grain and perennial forage crops has not been thoroughly investigated. This study was conducted to evaluate the productivity and profitability of strip intercropping corn (Zea mays L.) and alfalfa (Medicago sativa L.). Alternating strips of corn and alfalfa of three widths (10, 20, and 40 ft) were compared in a field trial conducted from 1988 through 1990. Alfalfa yields and forage quality were determined for harvest strips within plots and for whole plots. Land equivalent ratios (LER) and gross returns to both strips and sole crops were calculated. In the drought of 1988, neither corn nor alfalfa yields differed due to strip width or from the sole crop yield. In 1989, corn yields were lowest for the sole crop (146 bu/acre), increased 3% in 40-ft strips, and 10% in 10- and 20-ft strips. Alfalfa yields did not differ due to strip width or from the sole crop yield in 1989. In 1990, alfalfa yields in strips vs. the sole crop were reduced 10% only for the 10-ft wide plots. Author: Yamazoe, Sayumi; Hasegawa, Koji; Shigemori, Hideyuki
Title: Structure-activity relationship of acetylenes from galls of Hedera rhombea as plant growth inhibitors
Publication Title: Zeitschrift Fur Naturforschung C-a Journal of Biosciences
Abstract Note: The structure-activity relationship of 12 isolated acetylenes from galls of Hedera rhombea (Araliaceae) induced by Asphondylia sp. (Cecidomyiidae) and their derivatives has been studied for the inhibition of the shoot and root growth of rice, perennial ryegrass, cockscomb, lettuce, and cress. Almost all acetylenes generally showed growth inhibitory activity. The diacetylenes exhibited higher activity than the monoacetylenes, suggesting that a conjugated diyne segment is essential for the activity. On the other hand, the acetylenes with a nonoxidated methylene group at C-8 showed stronger activity comparing with those possessing hydroxy and acetoxy groups at C-8. Furthermore, it has been demonstrated that the acetylenes bearing a terminal olefinic group at C-16,C-17 enhanced the activity. It is thus clarified that important sites for the activity of the acetylenes from galls of H. rhombea are a conjugated diyne and a terminal olefinic group connecting to the aliphatic chain and that less oxidated compounds show more activity.
Manual Tags: Acetylenes; Hedera rhombea; Scopus; search.rice; SPV; Structure-Activity Relationship; TITLE-ABS-KEY (perennial W/1 (oryza OR rice)) AND DOCTYPE (ar); TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: M, MAHADEVAPPA; VISHAKANTHA; K, SARMA N. D. R.; G, GOVINDARAJ K.
Title: STUBBLE PLANTING-PROMISING VEGETATIVE PROPAGATION METHOD FOR HYBRID RICE
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: EVATT, N. S.
Title: Stubble rice production tests.
Abstract Note: The 8- to 9-month growing season of the Texas Gulf Coast Prairie is not quite long enough to permit two successive rice crops to be grown from seed. A preliminary test in 1956 demonstrated that ratooning was possible if an early-maturing variety was used and the crop was combine-harvested to leave at least 17 in. of stubble. This cutting height was necessary even though all tillering came from the base of the plant. In 1957, more than 4000 Ib. grain/ac. were obtained from the first crop and more than 2000 Ib./ac. from the ratoon-crop. Highest yields were obtained by applying N and P to the crop soon after sowing, and again to the ratoon-crop soon after cutting. There was no response to K. The first crop must be harvested before 10 August to obtain a successful ratoon-crop. Varieties which mature even earlier than Century Patna 231 would be an advantage.-J.D.J.
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: E, KAMERLING G.
Title: STUDIES IN SOIL PHYSICS AND AGRO HYDROLOGY ON THE YOUNG COASTAL PLAIN OF SURINAM SOUTH AMERICA
