Author: Gurumurthy, S.; Muthukrishnan, P.; Thirumurugan, V.; Kaliappa, R.
Title: Studies of ratoon in IR 20, Bhavani and Co 42 rice varieties.
Abstract Note: The 3 medium duration cultivars were grown at one wetland site in 1981-82, with NPK fertilization. After harvesting the main crop, 4 levels of N fertilization (100-160 kg/ha) were given either in a single dose 7 days after harvest or with half the dose delayed until 20 days after harvest. Bhavani gave the highest grain yield in the ratoon crop, and IR20 the lowest, although IR20 had given the highest yield in the planted crop.
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: Paterkowski, M.
Title: Studies of soyabeans grown alone or in mixtures. 2. The cultivation of soyabeans in mixtures.
Abstract Note: In field trials in 1965-7 on rendzina soils near Chelm, Poland, soyabeans were grown in mixtures with a number of different crops including Echinochloa frumentacea, perennial ryegrass, Sorghum sudanense, Setaria italica, maize, Sorghum bicolor, Panicum miliaceum and sunflower. The mixtures were sown during 2 periods in the spring, the precise dates depending on the yr. Yields of fresh matter ranged from 24.6 to 95.4 t/ha and from 19.7 to 72.1 t/ha for mixtures sown during the earlier and later periods, resp. The highest yields were obtained from mixtures of soyabeans and sunflowers and soyabeans and maize. Growing soyabeans in mixtures with other spp. tended to improve the chemical composition and enhance the protein content of the mixture compared with spp. grown alone.
Manual Tags: search.sorghum; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 sorghum); WOS

Author: BALERAO, SS; CHOUDHARI, SD
Title: STUDIES ON 2ND CROP AFTER KHARIF SORGHUM UNDER RAINFED CONDITIONS
Manual Tags: search.sorghum; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 sorghum); WOS

Author: Shivaraj, B.; Munirayappa, G.; Gowda, A.
Title: Studies on biological yield and grain to straw ratio as influenced by dates of planting, varieties and dates of cutting in rice.
Publication Title: Current Research - University of Agricultural Sciences (Bangalore)
Abstract Note: Rice DM yield at Bangalore, Karnataka in kharif [monsoon] 1986 was not significantly affected by transplanting date (1 Sep. or 1 Oct.) but was decreased by cutting on 1 or 15 Dec. DM yield averaged 9.37 t/ha in cv. Intan and 6.18 t in cv. Mahsuri.
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: ShiHua, Jiang; Hong, Xiong; Wen, Fang; WenZhi, Luo
Title: Studies on comprehensive cultivation techniques for high yield of ratoon rice in Sichuan Province.
Abstract Note: Management of high-yield ratoon rice was studied in field experiments and demonstration plots in 1991-94 in Sichuan. The optimum temperature, relative humidity and stubble moisture content for the germination of regenerated buds were found to be 25.5-27.0°C, 81-85% and about 70%, respectively. Stubble moisture contents of >70% were negatively associated with germination and elongation of the regenerated buds. The adoption of balanced fertilizer application and other management techniques helped the accumulation of nutrients in the plants, delayed their senescence and improved the sprouting of regenerated buds and their establishment, Fertilizer dressing at the germination and sprout elongation stages increased the number of productive panicles and well-filled grains, thus increasing yield. Application of GA at the initial heading stage helped maintain a stabilized panicle number and increased seed-setting rate, seed-set per panicle and 1000-seed weight. Double cutting of the stubble reduced the negative influence of drought on the germination and elongation of regenerated buds.
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: Y-I, CHU; S-C, HONG; T-W, LAI; Y-S, CHEN
Title: STUDIES ON EGG OVERWINTERING OF THE BROWN PLANTHOPPER NILAPARVATA-LUGENS
Abstract Note: The overwinter of brown planthopper (Nilaparvata lugens) with its egg stage are studied under the outdoor conditions with the materials collecting from the fields. The eggs deposited in the period between the end of Nov. 1983 and the end of Feb. 1984 are incubated under the outdoor conditions. The eggs are capable of hatching during the winter, no diapause are observed. However the incubation period is increased with the progression of winter season, the egg stage prolongs to 60 days in maximum and 50.12 .+-. 4.18 days in average. The low temperature bring mal-influence on the survival and development of eggs. The symptom can be divided into two large groups. One is characterized with eggs which do not show any embryonic development. The other group of eggs show the symptom of deformation during their embryonic development and fail to hatch at the last. The dead eggs in the first group are considered to be caused by mal-influence of low temperature through their mother adult. The latter are presumed to be influenced directly by the cold conditions at the egg stage. In the fallowing paddy field, the egg population on the ratoon paddy increase from December. The population peak is observed in the middle of January. Most of those eggs hatch in the middle of February. Then, the temperature condition is no longer serious to the newly hatched nymphs. Therefore the survival rate of the nymph are surely high. They are recognized to be the first generation of planthopper of the year. The low temperature seems a mechanism regulating the embryonic development of brown planthopper during winter season. As a result, the hatching of overwintering eggs are concentrated in the middle of February. Based on the finding, the monitoring operation on the abundance of the first generation is suggested to focus on the egg density in ratoon paddy in the beginning of February.
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: Muddemmanavar, S. S.; Gumaste, S. K.; Angadi, S. S.; Kubsad, V. S.
Title: Studies on fodder yielding and ratooning abilities of sorghum varieties as influenced by fertilizer levels.
Abstract Note: In a field trial in the summer (irrigated) and kharif [monsoon] (rainfed) seasons of 1981 on clay soil at Dharwad, Karnataka, the effects of 50 kg N + 30 kg P + 20 kg K/ha or double or triple these amounts on main crop and ratoon crop fodder yields of sorghum cv. Rio, Roma, Dale, RM 57-1, Annigeri-1 and J-set-3 were studied. Cv. RM 57-1 gave the highest main crop dry fodder yield of 15.26 t/ha, whereas the highest ratoon crop and total dry fodder yields were obtained from cv. Dale. The main crop and total dry fodder yields increased with up to 100 kg N + 60 kg P + 40 kg K, whereas the ratoon crop dry fodder yield increased with up to the highest NPK rate.
Manual Tags: search.sorghum; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 sorghum); WOS

Author: Aspinall, G.O.; Telfer, R.G.J.
Title: Studies on fructosans. Part VI. The degradation of fructosans in aqueous solution
Abstract Note: It has been shown that the degradation of fructosans in hot aqueous solution involves the formation of small quantities of acidic materials, which cause the fructosans to undergo slow hydrolysis. The oligosaccharides, formed from the partial breakdown of the fructosan from perennial rye-grass, have been examined. The isolation of sucrose provides further evidence that in the grass levans the chains of fructofuranose residues are terminated by a non-reducing glucopyranose unit.
Manual Tags: Scopus; search.rye; SPV; TITLE-ABS-KEY (perennial W/1 ("rye" OR secale) AND NOT ("rye?grass" OR ryegrass)) AND DOCTYPE (ar)

Author: Harwood, V.D.; Laidlaw, R.A.; Telfer, R.G.J.
Title: Studies on fructosans. Part V. Short-chain fructosans from Lolium perenne
Abstract Note: A mixture of short-chain fructosans has been isolated from mid-season perennial rye-grass (Lolium perenne). On fractionation of the methylated material a product was obtained which, on hydrolysis, yielded 1:3:4:6-tetra-(13.2%) and 1:3:4-tri-O-methyl-D-fructose (76.2%) along with 2:3:4:6-tetra-(5.3%) and 2:4:6-tri-O-methylglucose (4.1%). A di-O-methylfructose (1.2%) was also isolated. The findings indicate the presence of short, straight-chain polysaccharides made up of 2:6-linked fructofuranose residues, terminated in some cases by a glucopyranose residue linked as in sucrose.
Manual Tags: Scopus; search.rye; SPV; TITLE-ABS-KEY (perennial W/1 ("rye" OR secale) AND NOT ("rye?grass" OR ryegrass)) AND DOCTYPE (ar)

Author: Mishra, Akhilesh; Prasad, Kedar; Swarnkar, G. B.; Rai, Gita; Khan, Naushad
Title: STUDIES ON GRAIN YIELD AND YIELD COMPONENTS OF LONG DURATION PIGEONPEA (CAJANUS CAJAN L. MILLSP) AS INFLUENCED BY PLANTING METHODS AND PLANT POPULATIONS
Abstract Note: An experiment was laid out in two consecutive kharif seasons during 2003 and 2004 at Chandra Shekhar Azad University of Agriculture and Technology, Kanpur, Uttar Pradesh to study the effect of planting methods and plant densities on yield and yield attributes in late sown pigeonpea. Experiment consisted four plant populations (88888, 66666, 5333 and 44444 plants ha(-1)) and two planting methods (Ridge and Flat bed), with four replications in randomized block design. Results revealed that ridge planting method influnced the seed yield and its components significantly with an increase of 27% in grain yield; significant increase in grain yield was also recorded along with simultaneous increase in plant densities. Therefore, it can be said that ridge sowing with high plant density practice in late sown pigeonpea produces maximum grain yield.
Manual Tags: Harvest index; Planting methods; Plant populations; Ridge; Scopus; search.grain; search.pigeonpea; SPV; TITLE-ABS-KEY ("long duration" W/1 (cajanus OR "pigeon?pea" OR pigeonpea)) AND DOCTYPE (ar); TS=(perennial NEAR/1 grain); WOS

Author: Tunio, S. D.; Korejo, M. N.; Jarwar, A. D.; Waggan, M. R.
Title: Studies on indigenous and exotic weed competition in wheat.
Publication Title: Pakistan Journal of Agriculture, Agricultural Engineering, Veterinary   Sciences
Abstract Note: The experiment was conducted to evaluate the effect of indigenous and exotic weed competition in wheat at Plant Physiology Section, Agriculture Research Institute, Tandojam during rabi 2002-2003. Seven weed competition treatments viz; wheat+broad leaf weeds, wheat+narrow leaf weeds, wheat+sedges, wheat+perennial weeds, wheat+annual weeds (narrow and broad leaf weeds), weedy check were tested. The weeds under weedy check were predominantly present in the experimental area with intensity of 25%. Other treatments, wheat+annual weeds, wheat+narrow leaf weeds, wheat+perennial weeds, wheat+broad leaf weeds and wheat+sedges were present with intensity of 21.61%, 15.38%, 11.95%, 10.53% and 1.36%, respectively. Broad leaf weeds had more competition than narrow leaf weeds. The results showed that the highest grain yield (4043 kg ha -1) was obtained under weed free treatment, which had no competition because weeds were removed and wheat crop had ideal environment for growth and development. Whereas, increase in grain yield was also associated with more number of productive tillers plant -1 under weed free conditions. It is concluded that more grain yield could be obtained under weed free conditions, or keeping weeds at lower intensity to reduce their competition with main crop.
Manual Tags: search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); WOS

Author: YOSHIDA, T.; HOZONO, S.
Title: STUDIES ON LATERAL BUDS GROWTH INTO RATOON TILLERS IN EARLY-SEASON CULTURE OF RICE PLANTS
Abstract Note: The yielding ability and the effect of fertilization on yield were investigated in ratoon crop rice in early-season cultures. The total leaf number of each tiller in the ratoon crop was compared with Katayama's theoretical total number of leaves. The ratoon crop produced about 30% of the grain yield of the parent crop. Fertilization of the ratoon crop increased the panicle number per hill, resulting in an increased yield, Ratoon tillers were separated from the main stem to determine their tillering position on the seem, and to find the effect of fertilization on regrowth of tillers. Yield increase by fertilization was mainly due to the increase in the number of ripened secondary tillers. Tillers had 2 similar to 3 more leaves than the total leaves expected from the theory of synchronous growth of leaves and tillers. The investigation of growth of lateral buds at each growth stage of the parent crop showed that the relation between growth of the main stem and lateral bud growth of ratoon tillers was not synchronized, resulting in the increase of total leaf number over the theoretical one.
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: Sivasupiramaniam, S.; Sitamparanathan, J.; Appadurai, R. R.
Title: Studies on pasture improvement in the hill country dry zone patanas of Sri Lanka.
Abstract Note: Total DM yields of Kikuyu grass sown after pioneer crops of sorghum and ratoon sorghum, or sorghum and sunnhemp, or without a pioneer crop were in the range 21.3-23.1 lb/plot (20 X 20 ft) for all treatments for the 3rd cut. For the 1st and 2nd cuts yields were highest for treatments which included pioneer crops. In a 2nd trial 12 pasture grasses were sown separately after a pioneer crop. The highest yields of fresh herbage in the 1st year were 957 cwt/ac for Setaria sphacelata cv. Kazungula and 926 cwt for Paspalum commersonii, and in the 2nd year 1245 cwt for Kazungula and 1151 cwt for Panicum maximum cv. Green Panic. In a 3rd trial each of the same grasses was sown together with Desmodium uncinatum, Glycine javanica [= G. wightii] and Phaseolus atropurpureus [= Macroptilium atropurpureum]. In the 2nd year the yields of legume were 0-10 lb/plot for all plots and of grasses 102-323 lb/plot. In a 4th trial, one of 6 grasses was sown together with one or all of D. uncinatum, G. wightii and M. atropurpureum, or in a pure stand treated with N. In the 2nd year the highest legume percentage was 14-30% for combination with Digitaria decumbens and the highest total herbage yield for S. sphacelata + N. Finally, data for the DM yield and CP content of
Manual Tags: search.sorghum; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 sorghum); WOS

Author: C-H, CHENG
Title: STUDIES ON POPULATION DYNAMICS AND FORECASTING OF POPULATION ABUNDANCE
Abstract Note: The population changes of brown planthopper, Nilaparvata lugens (Homoptera: Delphacidae) in paddy fields were investigated for the first and second rice crops in Chianan area from 1982 to 1988. The results revealed that the immigration of brown planthopper in the initial stage of the first rice crop in most cases could not be traced due to low immigrant. The first generation adults used to appear during the end of April to the beginning of May, and the hopper took about one month to complete one generation up to the time of harvest of the crop in the end of June. The highest population peak in this crop season ranged from 0.60 to 10.2 with an average of 1.33 per hill, which appeared mostly during 1-2 weeks before harvest of the crop. Analysis of the factors affecting to abundance of the hopper in the first rice crop indicated that the density of over-winter population was the most important (r2 = 0.984). Besides, the number of days with the lowest day-temperature below 10.degree.C during December to Match, and the number of rainy day in April were also the factors affecting the population abundance to a certain extend. On the contrary, the population of the hopper in the second rice crop was high. The immigrant invaded into paddy fields soon after rice planting, and the peak of immigration appeared mostly during 2 to 3 weeks after rice planting. Initial population was varied from year with a range from 0.006 to 0.27 female adults per hill. The population increased from 46.6 to 2071 folds through 2 to 3 generation's multiplication to reach its highest population peak in the range of 0.6 to 450.6 per hill. The population abundance of the hopper in this crop season was highly correlated with the density of immigrant and the rainfall in September. High temperature over 34.degree.C in August was also an important factor in reducing the population abundance in this crop season. Several regression equations has been established for predicting the population abundance of the hopper both in the first and second rice crop in this area. The coefficience of determination of the regressions were higher than 0.986, indicating that they were likely to be used practically. The population characteristics of the hopper in each crop season and on ratoon rice in this area are also discussed in the paper.
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: Lu, X. H.; Liu, Z. Z.; Lin, Y. L.; Lin, D. T.; Ding, S. M.
Title: Studies on protoplast culture of upland rice and plant regeneration.
Abstract Note: In the perennial rice Fang Ye 87-707, callus induction in mature embryos was used as a basis for establishing suspension cultures in AA medium with abundant amino acid. The isolated protoplasts in suspension culture were embedded with agarose in improved KM8P medium. Sustained division occurred, and by alternation of differentiation medium complete plantlets were regenerated and successfully transplanted. Adding abscisic acid to the suspension culture medium improved the survival and division of protoplasts. Use of increased osmotic pressure in the medium for culturing the regenerated cell colony and the callus from protoplasts increased plant regenerative ability.
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: Mane, S. S.; Ramshe, D. G.
Title: Studies on ratooning ability of sorghum entries.
Abstract Note: Tabulated data are presented on the grain and fodder yields from one to three tillers per shoot of the ratoon crop of three hybrids and four varieties. The highest mean grain yields were given by the hybrids; of these, CSH1, with 44.13 q/ha, produced most, producing 37, 46, 49 and 55% more than the varieties 168, Swarna, 370 and CS3541, respectively. The highest mean fodder yield was given by Swarna, followed by CSH5.
Manual Tags: search.sorghum; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 sorghum); WOS

Author: Hou, F. F.
Title: Studies on ratooning and its correlation with TNC content in rice.
Publication Title: Bulletin of Taichung District Agricultural Improvement Station
Abstract Note: In a study of 10 varieties, there was a positive correlation at harvest between ratooning ability and the content of total nonstructural carbohydrates (TNC) in the stem bases (10 cm above ground level). Rooting and bud sprouting ability of the first node above ground level, assessed in the laboratory after harvest, was also positively correlated with ratooning ability in the field, indicating that laboratory culture of the first node could be used in early screening tests for ratooning ability.
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: BALASUBRAMANIAN, B.; MORACHAN, Y. B.; KALIAPPA, R.
Title: Studies on ratooning in rice. 1. Growth attributes and yield.
Abstract Note: In rice cv. IR8, ADT 27, Co 32 and Jeeraga Samba, the planted crop was harvested at 10, 20 or 30 cm above ground level and 40, 80 or 120 kg N/ha was applied to the stubble. In all treatments, ratoon yields were low even at the highest N application. All ratoon crops were shorter and the time taken to reach maturity was less than in the planted crops. Height of cutting the planted crops did not influence grain yield of the ratoons, but strongly influenced straw yields. Ratooning ability was shown to be a varietal characteristic. AGGH.
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: B, BALASUBRAMANIAM; B, MORACHAN Y.; R, KALIAPPAN
Title: STUDIES ON RATOONING IN RICE-M
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: Palchamy, A.; Kolandaiswamy, S.
Title: Studies on ratooning in Vaigai and Bhavani rice varieties.
Abstract Note: Effects of 90-150 kg N/ha and stubble ht. on paddy yields of the ratoon crops of 2 rice cv. were determined. The mid-season cv. Bhavani harvested to a stubble ht. of 20 cm and given 120 kg N/ha yielded 4.85 t paddy/ha.
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: ZhenXie, Yi; NaiMei, Tu; PingPing, Chen
Title: Studies on ratooning properties of a series of hybrid combinations derived from Peiai 64S.
Abstract Note: A field experiment was conducted in 2002 in Changsha, Hunan, China, to study the growth, development and ratooning properties of 4 combinations of rice derived from Peiai 64S. The total grain yield of the first rice crop and ratooning rice was ranked as follows: Peiai 64 * E32 > Liangyoupei 9 > Peiai 64 * B32 > Peiliangyou 500. The order of the contribution of yield components to grain yield for ratooning rice was: effective panicles/plant > spikelets/panicle > seed setting percentage > 1000-grain weight. The yield components of first rice crop had obvious effects on the ratooning rate (RR). Significant positive correlations were recorded between RR and effective panicles/plant, and between RR and 1000-grain weight. Significant negative correlations were noted between RR and grains/panicle, and between RR and seed setting percentage. The source-sink properties of the first rice crop also had obvious effects on RR. Significant positive correlations were observed between RR and maximal leaf area index, and between RR and output rate of dry matter in stem and sheath.
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: Naidu, B. S.; Vasanthakumar, H. L.; Seshadri, V. S.; Nagaraju, M. S.
Title: Studies on ratoon performance of leaf blast-susceptible varieties at ARS, Ponnampet, Karnataka.
Abstract Note: Although all 50 rice varieties screened were susceptible to Pyricularia oryzae (7-9 on a 0-9 scale) and gave virtually no yield, IET9667, IET9668 and IET9670 gave rise to productive ratoon tillers which gave an average yield of 1.6 t/ha and were free from disease. In the ratoon, plant height was reduced by 46.6% and days to 50% flowering by 42.6%.
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: REIMANNP.R; EICHHORN.H
Title: STUDIES ON RELATIONSHIP OF FERTILITY AND MODE OF CHROMOSOME PAIRING IN TETRAPLOID F1-SPECIES HYBRIDS OF RYE (SECALE-CEREALE X SECALE-MONTANUM) HETEROZYGOUS FOR 3 TRANSLOCATED CHROMOSOMES
Manual Tags: search.rye; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 ("rye" OR secale) NOT "rye$grass"); WOS

Author: Cao, W. Y.; Zhao, W. Y.; Zhao, S. M.
Title: Studies on resistance to rosette virus in different forms of wheat.
Abstract Note: Of 1986 forms screened in the field, 34 had a moderately high and 66 a moderate degree of resistance. In artificial inoculation tests, three very resistant forms were identified, of which "perennial wheat" was the most resistant. These three were also very resistant to Puccinia striiformis, P. graminis, P. recondita and Erysiphe graminis.
Manual Tags: search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); WOS

Author: RANGASWAMI, G.; BALASUBRAMANIAN, A.
Title: STUDIES ON RHIZOSPHERE MICROFLORA OF SORGHUM IN RELATION TO HYDROCYANIC ACID CONTENT OF ROOTS
Manual Tags: search.sorghum; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 sorghum); WOS

Author: Ahmed, S. N.; Muthukrishnan, P.; Ravichandran, V. K.; Rajasekaran, S.
Title: Studies on sugarcane based cropping systems with early varieties.
Abstract Note: In a field experiment in 1989-91 at Cuddalore, Tamil Nadu, early maturing (8 months) sugarcane cv. Co 8338 and CoC671 were grown for 2 ratoon crops or 1 ratoon crop followed by groundnuts cv. VRI. 1 and rice cv. IR 20. Returns from a sugarcane cv. CoC 80561 (maturing in 12 months) crop + 1 ratoon crop were compared with the treatments. Net returns were lower with 2 sugarcane ratoon crops than with 1 ratoon crop + groundnuts + rice. The highest net return and income equivalent ratio (1.19) was obtained from ratooning CoC 671 followed by groundnuts and rice. Yield data are tabulated.
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: Kamal, Nazira; Begum, Anwara; Biswas, Vivekananda
Title: Studies on the abundance of spiders in rice ecosystem
Abstract Note: Twentynine species of spiders belonging to 16 genera under 10 families were recorded from rice crops, associated weedy fallow on borders, ratoons and seed-beds in Shikerpur of Jhenidah district in Bangladesh. The common species of spiders in four situations were Eucta javana, Tetragnatha mandibulata, Oxyopes sp., O. shweta and Neoscona theisi.
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: Hao, Tang; LiYun, Chen; YiShan, Yang; JunMing, Li
Title: Studies on the correlation between nutrient content and ratooning ability in rice.
Abstract Note: The correlation between nutrient content of the main crop and its ratooning ability was studied in 30 rice cultivars (hybrid crosses) grown in Changsha, Hunan, China. A slight correlation between ratooning ability and nutrient content at 18 days after full heading was observed. Ratooning ability was positively correlated with nitrogen and phosphorus contents at harvest, but negatively correlated with calcium, magnesium, manganese, copper and boron contents. The results suggest that fertilizer application to promote booting at 12 days before harvest and fertilizer application to protect booting at 5 days after harvest are necessary. Phosphorus fertilizer should be applied as a basal fertilizer, and calcium fertilizer should be applied separately depending on the requirement of the main and ratoon crops. Trace element fertilizers, such as magnesium, manganese, copper, boron and zinc fertilizers, should not be applied at later growth stages of the main crop.
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: HSIEH, C. F.; KAO, S.; CHIANG, C.
Title: Studies on the cultivation of ratooned rice. 3. Effect of ploughing depth and amount of fertilizer on the viability and yield of ratooned rice.
Publication Title: Nung-yeh Yen-chiu = Journal of Taiwan Agricultural Research
Abstract Note: In trials in 1959-61, regrowth of ratooned rice decreased with increase in ploughing depth and with increase in the rate of N applied to the previous crop. Maximum grain yields were obtained from a 25-cm ploughing depth. F.en s. FAS.
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: Schulenburg, S.; Dorffling, K.
Title: Studies on the drought tolerance of perennial ryes.
Abstract Note: Perennial wild rye ( Secale montanum) X S. cereale hybrids show promise for fodder and grain production especially in semiarid regions where their advantages include drought tolerance. In pot experiments in which 6-week-old plants were deprived of water for 18 days, drought injury was markedly lower and survival rate and recovery after restoration of water supply higher in S. montanum and its perennial hybrid Sopertra than in 2 tetraploid and 1 diploid winter rye cultivars. Similarly, loss of leaf turgor and changes in leaf osmotic potentials were lower in hybrids Sopertra and Permontra than in the tetraploid winter rye cv. Teku and Halo. When S. montanum, the same perennial hybrids and several winter and summer rye cultivars were watered every 2 or 4 days, the perennials used less water and accumulated less DM during the first 4 weeks of growth than did the annual rye cultivars, but perennials were less sensitive than annuals to reductions in water supply. Shoot:root ratios were lower in perennials under the dry than under the wet conditions and they used water more efficiently for root growth than did the rye cultivars.
Manual Tags: search.rye; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 ("rye" OR secale) NOT "rye$grass"); WOS

Author: Dutta, D.
Title: Studies on the efficiency of rock phosphate as a source of phosphorus to pigeonpea ( Cajanus cajan) in acid laterite soil of West Bengal.
Abstract Note: A field experiment was conducted during rainy seasons of 2004 and 2005 at the Regional Research Substation, Sekhampur, Birbhun, West Bengal, India to investigate the effect of single application of Mussoorie rock phosphate (RP) and in conjugation with single superphosphate (SSP), or organic manure (farmyard manure, FYM) and biofertilizer (phosphate-solubilizing bacteria, PSB) on the yield of pigeon pea (cv. UPAS 120) and on the uptake and availability of phosphorus (P) in an acid lateritic soil. Fourteen treatments were used: (T1) control; (T2) 100% SSP; (T3) 100% RP; (T4) T3+PSB; (T5) T3+FYM; (T6) T5+PSB; (T7) 75% RP+25% SSP; (T8) T7+PSB; (T9) T7+FYM; (T10) T9+PSB; (T11) 50% RP+50% SSP; (T12) T11+PSB; (T13) T11+FYM; and (T14) T13+PSB. Results revealed that root nodulation, growth and yield parameters were highest in the treatment which received 50% RP + 50% SSP along with FYM and PSB, which was significantly different from the treatment with 100% SSP alone. This treatment produced significantly higher seed yield (28.20 and 8.29%) over the control (no phosphorus) and 100% SSP alone, respectively. The P availability in soil was gradually increased from the initial stage in all RP-treated plots, while a decreasing trend up to harvest stage was found with 100% SSP alone. The highest P uptake in the crop was registered by the treatment with 50% RP+50% SSP in combination with FYM and PSB. This study indicated that the integrated use of the indigenous source of P (RP), SSP, FYM and PSB, besides curtailing the input cost, can effectively be used to improve the yield of the long-duration pigeon pea and to increase P availability in soil.
Manual Tags: search.grain; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 grain); WOS

Author: HSIEH, C.-F.; KAO, S.; CHIANG, C.
Title: Studies on the method of growing rice from ratoons. II. Intervarietal differences in capacity for regrowth and in yield.
Publication Title: Nung-yeh Yen-chiu = Journal of Taiwan Agricultural Research
Abstract Note: The yield of 15 Peng-lai (= Horai) and 2 native varieties grown from ratoons was determined. Yield differences between varieties were marked but were always below that following transplanting.
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: Chen, W. G.; Lin, H.; Guan, W. F.; Tang, F. Q.
Title: Studies on the optimum NPK ratio and application level to low-intermediate yielding paddy fields.
Abstract Note: This paper summarizes the results of 37 trials of N, P and K application to 1st and 2nd rice crops in the low/intermediate-yielding paddy fields in Fujian Province in 1983. Yields of 1st and 2nd cropped rice given NPK were 15.4 to 54.1 and 17.3 to 46.8% higher, resp., than control yields. With N, P and K applied in various combinations, the order of the rice yield increase was NPK > NK > NP > PK > control. Highest yield was obtained at N:P:K ratio of 1:0.5:1, and the most economic results at 1:0.5:1 or 1:0-0.3:0.5 for 1st and 2nd crops, resp. The order of the yield increase for separate application was N > K > P. The effect of N, P and K on rice yield was higher for low-yielding than for high-yielding paddy fields. Opt. rates were 16 jin N, 4- 8 jin P 2O 5 and 8-10 jin K 2O/mu for 1st crop and 16 jin N, 0-4 jin P 2O 5 and 6-11.5 jin K 2O/mu for the 2nd rice crop. [1 jin=0.5 kg ; 1 mu=0.067 ha].
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: H, Cheng C.
Title: Studies on the population dynamics and forecasting population abundance of smaller brown planthopper, Laodelphax striatellus (Fallen) on rice in Taiwan.
Abstract Note: The smaller brown planthopper (Laodelphax striatellus (Fallen) (Homoptera: Delphacidae) is an important insect pest of rice in Taiwan; in addition to causing direct damage by sucking nutrients from vascular tissues of rice plants, it also acts as a vector for transmission of rice stripe virus disease. The present study was conducted to determine the population dynamics of this insect pest, factors affecting the population abundance, and the development of models for forecasting the population based on data collected from monitored fields and traps since 1985 in central Taiwan. Data indicate that the smaller brown planthopper goes through 8 generations a year, with 3 generations for each crop of rice. The population peak, regardless of planting time, appeared mostly during the milky to doughy stages of the rice. In general, macropterous adults of the smaller brown planthopper immigrated successively to paddy fields soon after transplanting. The population of immigrants was significantly higher in paddy fields planted earlier than those planted later. Since the ratio of brachypterous adults in every generation was lower then 35% both in the first and second cropping season, a portion of the newly emerged adults from the earlier planted rice either migrated to the later planted rice or drifted away in the air. In the first cropping season, the highest population of the planthopper in paddy fields was positively correlated with catches by light traps, but was significantly negatively correlated with catches by airborne net traps from May to July. Similar relationships were also observed among field populations and catches by light and airborne net traps from October to December in the second cropping season, but the correlations did not reach statistical significance. Further analysis of the factors affecting the population abundance of the planthopper showed that catches by yellow water-pan traps in ratooning rice during last December and the average temperatures from the previous December to March were the most important factors affecting the population in the first cropping season. However, catches by airborne net traps from July to August or catches by yellow water pan traps within 30 days after transplanting, average temperature and days of rainfall exceeding 10 mm/h in August, and times when a typhoon was present were the important factors affecting the population in the second cropping season. Several models for forecasting the population abundance were developed for the present study to further test their applicability.
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: Totev, T.
Title: Studies on the possibility of improving high montane Nardus stricta grasslands by resowing with perennial rye (Secale montanum) in pure stands and mixtures with other perennial grasses for grazing utilization.
Abstract Note: Natural N. stricta grasslands at 1750 m alt. in the central Balkan range were improved by resowing in 1969 with S. montanum, cocksfoot, timothy, Agrostis alba, Festuca rubra and Lotus corniculatus in different mixtures. Data on herbage and hay yields and botanical and chemical composition of swards in different mixtures and in S. montanum in pure stands during 1970-4 are given.
Manual Tags: search.rye; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 ("rye" OR secale) NOT "rye$grass"); WOS

Author: Yin, Ru-Zhan; Jian, Zhang
Title: Studies on the relation between the ratooning rice and the hibernating larvae of Scirpophaga incertulas (Walker).
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: Singh, R. B.; Singh, R. A.; Sharma, R. C.; Singh, D. C.; Singh, R. P.
Title: Studies on the spider's abundance in off-season rice(ratoon) ecosystem
Abstract Note: The abundance of predatory spiders in ratoon rice (off-season) was studied at ND. University of Agriculture & Technology, Faizabad, Uttar Pradesh with a view to utilize the importance of conservation & augmentation of such important fauna so that their population may flourish at their maximum level in next kharif rice. The observation reveled that population of wolf and crab spiders' were maximum (38.5 & 23.1%) under quadrate method and the population of crab, lynx and long jawed spiders were maximum (33.2, 19.8 & 18.2%) under net-sweeping method in off-season, which were prominent in kharif season. Thus, through this finding we can say that ratoon rice can be utilized as a prominent source of transmigration to the next kharif which can keep the pest population under check
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: M, ICHII
Title: STUDIES ON THE UTILITY OF RATOON TRAITS OF RICE AS THE INDICATOR OF AGRONOMIC CHARACTERS IN BREEDING
Publication Title: Memoirs of Faculty of Agriculture Kagawa University
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: Chaudhry, M. S.; Acikgoz, N.
Title: Study of sowing date in six rice varieties and its effect on ratooning.
Abstract Note: Six varieties were sown at Menemen Izmir at 10-day intervals between 2 April and 1 June in 1980 and 1981. After transplanting, the varieties Krasnodarskii and Maratelli produced ratoon crops (about 20% of the first crop) after the first four sowings only, while the remaining varieties produced no ratoon crops. Observations on 13 characters indicated that the long-duration, high-yielding variety Calrose and the high-quality variety Basmati are suitable for the area when sown up to mid-May.
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: Komarova, E. P.
Title: Study of the biochemical nature of immunity to rust infection in rye.
Abstract Note: Two types of resistance to rusts, termed necrotic and chlorotic, were detected among wild and semiwild strains of rye and in triticale. The wild rye Secale kuprijanovii and the perennial fodder rye S. derzhavinii when infected with Puccinia dispersa [ P. recondita] formed necrotic lesions at the site of entry of the pathogen. When the cultivated rye Khar'skovskaya 60, susceptible to P. dispersa, was infected with P. coronifera [ P. coronata] and P. triticina [ P. recondita] chlorotic spots formed at the penetration site. Triticale AD206 infected with P. dispersa also showed the chlorotic type of resistance.
Manual Tags: search.rye; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 ("rye" OR secale) NOT "rye$grass"); WOS

Author: Lyubimova, V. F.; Poleva, L. V.
Title: Study of the development of new forms in wheat X wheatgrass hybrids involving Elytrigia elongata (Host) Nevski (2 n = 10 x = 70).
Abstract Note: Development of new forms was studied in the progenies of crosses of winter durum, winter bread and perennial [ Elymus X Triticum?] wheats with E. elongata [ Elymus elongatus], in backcrosses following controlled pollination of the F 1s with pollen from perennial wheat and in the F 1s under open pollination. Results are presented of the grain set and germination in the various crosses. Cytological observations revealed some aspects of the developmental process. The best ways of producing useful breeding forms are noted.
Manual Tags: search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); WOS

Author: LIU, Jian-xin; CHEN, Jian-guo; CHEN, Dong-ling; SONG, Zhao-jian; DAI, Bing-cheng; CAI, De-tian
Title: Study on Floral and Pollen Characters of Tetraploid Rice
Abstract Note: Polyploidization is the evolution trend of many crops, and the yield increased obviously after polyploidization. The polyploidization of rice often brings “gigas” of both vegetative organs and seeds. Howevere, in rice breeding, it is required for restoring lines to have not only big anthers but also abundant pollens. People often doubt that the enlargement of the floral organ may just be enlargement of cell size in polyploid rice. So, it is of significance to study characteristics of floral organs and pollens of several tetraploid rice varieties or lines. Floral organ and pollen characteristics of Sg99012 and HN2026 were studied comparatively by stages and different ploidy levels, with the materials 9311, HD9802S, and PA64S as the control. The results showed that chromosome doubling had much more influence on floral characteristics of every lines than seeding by stages, and the tetraploids of every lines displayed “gigas”. In correlation analysis, spikelet length, spikelet width, and anther length had significant correlation; spikelet width and anther width had significant correlation, too. Both seeding by stages and chromosome doubling made the correlations of characters between every floral organ changed to some extent. Seeding by stages had little effect on pollen diameter and fertility of HN2026-4X and Sg99012-4X. But chromosome doubling increased pollen size of every lines remarkably, and also increased the pollen quantity of PMeS (polyploid meiosis stability) restoring line HN2026-4X and gene map restoring line 9311-4X remarkably, whereas only had little effect on that of sterile lines. Moreover, chromosome doubling changed pollen fertility and made the number of fertility pollen of 9311 reduced significantly, but the pollen fertility of HN2026 (PMeS restoring line) and PA64S (sterile line) almost had no change after chromosome doubling. The results showed that tetraploid restoring lines had advantage of abundant and big size pollens, and tetraploid sterile lines had the characters of big size pollens, few change of pollen quantity and stable sterile character. These results provided evidence in reproductive biology for utilizing heterosis of polyploid rice by two-line method.
Manual Tags: correlation analysis; floral organ; pollen; polyploid rice; ratoon* W/5 (oryza OR rice); ScienceDirect; search.rice; significance testing; SPV

Author: JiChao, Yuan; XiaoHui, Sun; YianHua, Tian; Jun, Ma
Title: Study on nitrogen requirement and split application of nitrogen fertilizer in ratoon rice.
Abstract Note: Ratooned rice was given different rates of N fertilizer 15 d after full heading of the main crop (BF; bud fertilizer) and/or 1 d after harvest of the main crop (TF; tiller fertilizer). BF promoted carbohydrate and N metabolism during late growth of the main crop, enhancing bud growth and thus increasing numbers of tillers and effective panicles in the ratoon crop. TF promoted growth of the ratoon crop, increasing the percentage of filled spikelets and numbers of filled grains per panicle. It is suggested that N should be applied at both stages, and that the ratio of
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: Singh, Mahandera; Yadav, Amit; Singh, M. P.
Title: Study on nutrients use pattern and crops yields at farmers fields
Abstract Note: On-farm studies on the performance of main crops grown with farmers' rates of nutrients and recommended rates of nutrients application were carried out at a representative village of Meerut district, western Uttar Pradesh during 2000-2003. The main crops of the area were sugarcane, wheat, rice and fodder sorghum and main cropping systems included sugarcane ratoon-wheat and rice/sorghum fodder-wheat. All farmers were found to use FYM with a rate of 20-40 t/ha, onec in 3-4 years and recommended or nearer to recommended doses of nitrogen. Application of phosphorus was mainly limited to plant crop of sugracane (63 kg P2O5 /ha) and wheat crop (56 kg P2O5 kg/ha) and its application in these crops was nearer to optimum. In other crops, farmers generally did not apply phosphorus. Use of other nutrients, potash, zinc etc was, however, negligible. Crops yields with farmers' parctices were lower than the yields obtained with recommended rates of nutrients with a yield gap of 9-27 per cent in different crops. Study indicates that rates of nutrients did not seem to be mainly responsible for lower yields of crops at farmers levels. The other reasons, i.e., imbalanced use of nutrients, delay in sowing of crops, poor seed management, high infestation of weeds in crops etc. might be influencing the crop yields adversely.
Manual Tags: search.rice; search.sorghum; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 sorghum); WOS

Author: Ling, Q. H.; Su, Z. F.; Hou, K. P.; Guo, H. W.
Title: Study on the growth and panicle differentiation of resting buds in rice and their application.
Abstract Note: Observations on 7 rice cultivars in Yangzhou in 1986-87 showed that panicle differentiation in resting buds was initiated between the pistil and stamen differentiation stage and pollen mother cell differentiation in the main crop panicles. At heading of the main crop, the panicles of resting buds at middle or upper nodes showed spikelet primordia and those on lower nodes were less developed. Between heading and harvesting of the main crop, panicle differentiation in resting buds did not progress further. The cultivars differed in the percentage of buds regenerating from different nodes of the stem. Applying N 7-10 d before harvesting the 1st crop promoted regrowth from resting buds and improved grain number and wt/ear in the ratoon crop.
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: FuXian, Xu; Hong, Xiong; GanLin, Zhao; Song, Hong
Title: Study on the mortality of axillary buds before harvest in hybrid mid-season rice and methods to reduce this.
Abstract Note: Studies in 1995-97 with rice cv. Keiyou 3, Keiyou 5 and Shanyou 63 showed that the mortality of axillary buds was very high before harvest of mid-season rice, especially at the 4th and 5th nodes from top. Among the dead buds, 95% of them were <3.5 cm long. Most of the photosynthates were transported to the panicles after full heading of the main crop, and little was distributed to the axillary buds. Improved light conditions and N application increased axillary bud growth. There were highly significant negative correlations between ratooning ability and the days from the date of N application for bud development (NABD) to full heading of the main crop. The best date for NABD was full heading of the main crop, but the effect of the date of NABD on increasing the grain yield of ratooned rice was related to the dry weight of the main stems. There was little effect when the dry weight of the main stems were very high or low.
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: Su, Z. F.; Zhang, H. C.; Hou, K. P.; Guo, H. W.
Title: Study on the role of panicle differentiation of ratooning rice and its application.
Abstract Note: Observations on 7 rice cultivars showed that 20 days before heading of the main crop, panicle initiation in resting buds was at the stage of differentiation of pistils and stamens or pollen mother cells. After the 1st crop was harvested, buds at the middle internodes of the ratooned plants differentiated earlier and more rapidly than those at the upper and lower position in some cultivars while in others all buds on the ratooned stems differentiated and developed in a downward sequential order of time and rate. It is concluded that when a ratoon crop is required, the cutting height for the 1st crop should be determined in accordance with the cultivar used.
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: MaoLin, Ran; Hong, Xiong; Song, Hong; NaiHong, Zhang; YinPing, Chen; HuaZhong, Liu
Title: Study on the young ear differentiation character and the technology of sprouting for ratooning rice.
Publication Title: Southwest China Journal of Agricultural Sciences
Abstract Note: The factors affecting young ear differentiation, and sprouting technology in ratoon rice were studied. Sprouting of ratoon rice was affected synthetically by many factors such as rice stump nutrition, plant diseases and insect pests, seed characteristics, lodging, and drought. Young ear differentiation of ratoon rice occurred from low to high stems. Rates of differentiation had significantly differed for each stem. The highest differentiation happened at the fourth stage of the main crop. Young ear differentiation of ratoon rice synchronized with the growth of stem and leaf, heading and flowering of the main crop. Under good main crop cultivation conditions, and combined application of NPK with manure and chemical regulators to ratoon rice, balanced sprouting and stable, high yield can be obtained.
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: O'Grady, L.; Doherty, M.L.; Mulligan, F.J.
Title: Subacute ruminal acidosis (SARA) in grazing Irish dairy cows
Abstract Note: Subacute ruminal acidosis (SARA) is a significant production disease of dairy cattle. Previous concerns have been raised over the occurrence of SARA in pasture-fed dairy cattle and the potential consequences of laminitis and lameness. Highly digestible perennial rye grass contains high concentrations of rapidly fermentable carbohydrate and low concentrations of physical effective fibre that may result in SARA. This study conducted a point prevalence survey of rumen health status in grazing Irish dairy cattle fed predominantly perennial rye grass-based pasture. The survey assessed rumen fluid, animal health status, milk production data and pasture composition. A total of 144 cows between 80 and 150 days in milk were sampled on 12 farms. Eleven percent of cows were classified as affected with SARA (pH ≤ 5.5), 42% were marginal (pH 5.6-5.8) and 47% were normal (pH > 5.8). The study showed that low rumen pH is prevalent in grazing Irish dairy cattle consuming perennial rye grass-based pasture and raises concerns regarding effective pasture utilisation and possible consequences for animal health.

Author: Dranitsaris, G.; Ellis, A.K.
Title: Sublingual or subcutaneous immunotherapy for seasonal allergic rhinitis: An indirect analysis of efficacy, safety and cost
Publication Title: Journal of Evaluation in Clinical Practice
Abstract Note: Rationale, aims and objectives The standard of preventive care for poorly controlled seasonal allergic rhinitis (AR) is subcutaneous immunotherapy (SCIT) with allergen extracts, administered in a physician's office. As an alternative to SCIT, sublingual immunotherapy (SLIT) is now an option for patients with seasonal AR. Oralair™, a SLIT tablet containing freeze-dried allergen extracts of five grasses [cocksfoot (Dactylis glomerata), meadow grass (Poa pratensis), rye grass (Lolium perenne), sweet vernal grass (Anthoxanthum odoratum) and timothy grass (Phleum pratense)], and Grazax™, a SLIT tablet containing a standardized extract of grass pollen allergen from timothy grass (P pratenase), are two such agents currently available in many countries. However, head-to-head comparative data are not available. In this study, an indirect comparison on efficacy, safety and cost was undertaken between Oralair™, Grazax™ and SCIT. Methods A systematic review was conducted for double-blind placebo-controlled randomized trials evaluating Oralair™, Grazax™ or SCIT in patients with grass-induced seasonal AR. Using placebo as the common control, an indirect statistical comparison between treatments was performed using meta regression analysis with active drug as the primary independent variable. An economic analysis, which included both direct and indirect costs for the Canadian setting, was also undertaken. Results Overall, 20 placebo-controlled trials met the study inclusion criteria. The indirect analysis suggested improved efficacy with Oralair™ over SCIT [standardized mean difference (SMD) in AR symptom control = -0.21; P = 0.007] and Grazax™ (SMD = -0.18; P = 0.018). In addition, there were no significant differences in the risk of discontinuation due to adverse events between therapies. Oralair™ was associated with cost savings against year-round SCIT ($2471), seasonal SCIT ($948) and Grazax™ ($1168) during the first year of therapy. Conclusions Oralair™ has at least non-inferior efficacy and comparable safety against SCIT and Grazax™ at a lower annual cost.

Author: Gilbert, R.A.; Rainbolt, C.R.; Morris, D.R.; McCray, J.M.
Title: Sugarcane growth and yield responses to a 3-month summer flood
Abstract Note: Sugarcane (Saccharum spp.) in south Florida is often subjected to flooding due to interacting effects of soil subsidence, pumping restrictions, and tropical storms. While there has been considerable research on the response of sugarcane cultivars to high water tables and periodic flooding, there is a lack of information on commercial cultivar yield response to long-term flooding. An experiment was established in Belle Glade, FL to examine the effect of a 3-month summer flood (July–September) on the growth and yield of cultivars CP 80-1743 and CP 72-2086 during the plant cane (2003) and second ratoon (2005) crop. Harvest samples were taken early-, mid-, and late-season. Flooding sugarcane in the summer caused sequentially greater yield reductions throughout the harvest season in plant cane. Sucrose yields for flooded cane, compared with the non-flooded control, were 9.6 t sucrose ha−1 versus 11.7 t sucrose ha−1 early, 9.2 t sucrose ha−1 versus 12.8 t sucrose ha−1 mid-season and 7.8 t sucrose ha−1 versus 12.3 t sucrose ha−1 at late harvest. In the second ratoon crop, flooding reduced sugarcane tonnage and sucrose yield by 54–64% across sampling dates, and preliminary results indicated that flooding reduced leaf nutrient content by 10–78%. Yield reductions due to flooding in both crops were attributed more to reduced tonnage rather than sucrose content. CP 72-2086 yielded 18–28% greater sucrose than CP 80-1743 when harvested late. However the flood × cultivar interaction was not significant as both cultivars recorded similar yield reductions under flooded conditions. Our results identified severe yield losses caused by a 3-month summer flood in these cultivars, particularly in ratoon crops. Strategies to increase summer on-farm water storage in Florida should focus on short-duration periodic flooding rather than long-term flooding.
Manual Tags: Flood; Florida; Growth; Nutrient concentration; ratoon* W/5 (oryza OR rice); ScienceDirect; search.rice; SPV; Sugarcane; Water table; Yield

Author: SEIFERS, DL; HANDLEY, MK; BOWDEN, RL
Title: SUGARCANE MOSAIC-VIRUS STRAIN MAIZE-DWARF MOSAIC VIRUS-B AS A PATHOGEN
Abstract Note: Eastern gamagrass (EGG) (Tripsacum dactyloides) is a high-quality, high-production native forage grass with potential as a high-protein, perennial grain crop. We used enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay to test EGG samples for virus infection. Over a 2-yr period, we found five instances of maize dwarf mosaic virus (MDMV) and a high incidence (12 and 72% in 3-mo-old and 5-yr-old plantings, respectively) of sugarcane mosaic virus strain MDMV-B (SCMV-MDMV-B) in experimental breeding nurseries in Kansas. Incidence of SCMV-MDMV-B was higher in older breeding nurseries. SCMV-MDMV-B, but not MDMV, was found in three of 42 natural EGG stands. EGG plants infected by SCMV-MDMV-B showed no symptoms or a range of symptoms from mild mosaic to extensive chlorotic spots that became necrotic. EGG seedlings grown from two seed sources and inoculated in the greenhouse were infected by four MDMV and five SCMV-MDMV-B isolates. SCMV-MDMV-B apparently overwinters in infected EGG and has the potential to be a serious disease problem for this crop.
Manual Tags: search.grain; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 grain); WOS

Author: Goor, Francois; Dubuisson, Xavier; Jossart, Jean-Marc
Title: Suitability, environmental impact and energy balance of some energy crops in Belgium
Abstract Note: In Europe, due to increasing surpluses of agricultural products, a growing area of farm land may become available for other purposes and more and more farmers are looking for new income sources. As a result, there is a growing interest for the use of energy crops and various biomass sources for energy. A literature study was conducted to itemise the main potential energy crops and to compare their relative suitability and sustainability when cultivated under belgian soil and climate conditions. The characteristics taken into account for crop choice were their relative expansion in Belgium, their hardiness, their adaptability to various soils and climates, their potential use as energy crops, their productivity level, and the development of their use for biomass. Five annual crops (sugar beet, wheat, oilseed rape, Jerusalem artichoke and sweet sorghum), one perennial crop (miscanthus) and one perennial lignocellulosic crop (willow short rotation coppice SRC) were compared (Table 1). We collected information about crop ecophysiology, soil, water and temperature requirements, phytotechnical indicators (rotation, soil preparation, sowing or planting, fertilisation, weeds, pests and parasites, harvest and yields). Food and non-food potentials, together with biomass energy balance were also detailed (Table 2). Sugar beet, winter wheat and oilseed rape show more or less the same characteristics. They hardly cope with acid soils and require temperatures around 20-25degreeC for optimum growth. Their required nitrogen fertilisation is quite high to reach acceptable yields. Their energy efficiency is around 2.5-3, when the by-products, usually metabolisable by livestock, are taken into account, but goes down close to 1 when considering only the main products (bioethanol or biodiesel), because of the high energy consuming transformation cycle required to produce liquid biofuels. To compare various forms of energy, it would be useful to evaluate their relative added-value. In the present case, liquid biofuels have a larger added value than lignocellulose (higher energy content per volume unit, easier substitution to liquid fossil fuels), but this added value is difficult to quantify. Comparing all crops on the basis of the same valorisation path (for example, production of heat and electricity by biomass combustion) is theoretical and unrealistic and does not allow to evaluate an added value for the biofuels. The interest of such crops for biofuels is clearly depending on food crops overproduction and political will. Jerusalem artichoke is an interesting hardy crop, little demanding in terms of soil and water, able to grow under a wide range of weather conditions. The tubers can stand in soil during winter, allowing to harvest when time and workforce are available. Potential yields permit to reach a good energy efficiency, but cropping still encounters some problems, while the lack of experimentation makes yield prospect uncertain. The main problem of sweet sorghum and miscanthus is temperature requirements. The minimum germination temperature is round 10-12degree C (sometimes observed late in the growing season), while the optimum growing temperature is about 25 to 30degree C. These crops are very sensitive to frost and not well adapted to belgian climate. Under appropriate conditions, their energy efficiencies are satisfactory, comparable to Jerusalem artichoke. Willow (cultivated as short rotation coppice) shows many advantages, although it is water demanding. It can be grown on slightly acid soils, is harvested in the winter (when farm operations are reduced, and when all leaves have fallen on the soil, providing nutrients for the following growing seasons, so that fertilisation can be reduced). As a perennial crop, it helps to control erosion and nitrate leaching, while its yields (10 to 12 tons of oven-dry matter) allow to reach a high energy efficiency (20 to 30, depending on the chosen valorisation path). Willow seems to be a promising crop, adapted to various soil and climate conditions, less demanding for fertilisation, and highly efficient from an energy point of view. It can be burned in various heat and/or power plants, alone or combined with existing wood waste.

Author: Szynkiewicz, Anna; Moore, Craig H.; Glamoclija, Mihaela; Pratt, Lisa M.
Title: Sulfur isotope signatures in gypsiferous sediments of the Estancia and Tularosa Basins as indicators of sulfate sources, hydrological processes, and microbial activity
Abstract Note: In order to reconstruct paleo-environmental conditions for the saline playa lakes of the Rio Grande Rift, we investigated sediment sulfate sources using sulfur isotope compositions of dissolved SO 4 2 - ions in modern surface water, groundwater, and SO 4 2 - precipitated in the form of gypsum sediments deposited during the Pleistocene and Holocene in the Tularosa and Estancia Basins. The major sulfate sources are Lower and Middle Permian marine evaporites (δ34S of 10.9–14.4‰), but the diverse physiography of the Tularosa Basin led to a complex drainage system which contributed sulfates from various sources depending on the climate at the time of sedimentation. As inferred from sulfur isotope mass balance constraints, weathering of sulfides of magmatic/hydrothermal and sedimentary origin associated with climate oscillations during Last Glacial Maximum contributed about 35–50% of the sulfates and led to deposition of gypsum with δ34S values of −1.2‰ to 2.2‰ which are substantially lower than Permian evaporates. In the Estancia Basin, microbial sulfate reduction appears to overprint sulfur isotopic signatures that might elucidate past groundwater flows. A Rayleigh distillation model indicates that about 3–18% of sulfates from an inorganic groundwater pool (δ34S of 12.6–13.8‰) have been metabolized by bacteria and preserved as partially to fully reduced sulfur-bearing minerals species (elemental sulfur, monosulfides, disulfides) with distinctly negative δ34S values (−42.3‰ to −20.3‰) compared to co-existing gypsum (−3.8‰ to 22.4‰). For the Tularosa Basin microbial sulfate reduction had negligible effect on δ34S value of the gypsiferous sediments most likely because of higher annual temperatures (15–33 °C) and lower organic carbon content (median 0.09%) in those sediments leading to more efficient oxidation of H2S and/or smaller rates of sulfate reduction compared to the saline playas of the Estancia Basin (5–28 °C; median 0.46% of organic carbon). The White Sands region of the Tularosa Basin is frequently posited as a hydrothermal analogue for Mars. High temperatures of groundwater (33.3 °C) and high δ18O(H2O) values (1.1‰) in White Sands, however, are controlled predominantly by seasonal evaporation rather than the modern influx of hydrothermal fluids. Nevertheless, it is possible that some of the geochemical processes in White Sands, such as sulfide weathering during climate oscillations and upwelling of highly mineralized waters, might be considered as valid terrestrial analogues for the sulfate cycle in places such as Meridiani Planum on Mars.
Manual Tags: perennial W/1 (oryza OR rice); ScienceDirect; search.rice; SPV

Author: Eriksen, J.
Title: Sulphur cycling in Danish agricultural soils: Inorganic sulphate dynamics and plant uptake
Abstract Note: Predicting the S requirements of plants has become increasingly important in European agriculture primarily because of decreasing atmospheric S emissions. I have examined inorganic sulphate fluctuations during the year and its relation to plant uptake and S requirements. In a field study, three soil types (4, 7 and 10% clay) were mixed with carrier-free 35SO4S and combinations of sulphate-S and cellulose in PVC cylinders cropped with perennial rye-grass. Fertilizer S addition increased sulphate concentrations, but in a few months, they decreased again because of plant uptake, leaching and incorporation into organic matter. In the absence of cellulose, total dry matter production in rye-grass roots and tops increased up to twofold by S application, and a significant correlation was observed between soil inorganic sulphate at the start of the experiment and plant S uptake (r = 0.72). The presence of a readily available C source inhibited the uptake of both S and 35S. C addition equivalent to 10 t straw ha−1 caused immobilization and rapidly decreasing amounts of soil inorganic sulphate. Thus, plant yield, S-uptake and leaching losses were lower than in soils without C addition. During the season, the contribution of fertilizer-S to plants decreased from 46 to 26% in material sampled 84–182 d after sowing, irrespective of soil type and C addition. The decrease in the proportion of S in plants originating from fertilizer was caused by plant uptake of unlabelled soil S.

Title: Summary of ratoon rice cultivation in Zhejiang in 1986.
Abstract Note: The grain of a rice crop and its ratoon crop averaged 746.6 kg/mu, 16.9 kg/mu lower than that of double-cropped rice in a series of field experiments in 1986. As panicle number of the ratoon rice crop depends on the effective tillers of the previous crop and on the activity of axillary buds on mother culms, the optimum population is 350 000 effective tillers/mu at most. For a crop which is to be ratooned, it is essential to raise strong seedlings with 2 or more tillers/plant at a sowing rate of 10-20 kg/mu and to transplant the seedlings at the 7- to 8-leaf stage. It is recommended that fertilizer applications to the rice nursery be 20-30% higher than the usual rate. The optimum spacing is 23.1 * 13.2 to 20 * 20 cm with 2-3 seedlings/hill. In transplanted paddy fields, organic manure should be increased by 40%. Field management is very important for high yield of both the rice crop and its ratoon crop in the period from 1 month before to 1 month after harvest. Harvesting should be done at 90% maturity to stimulate growth of the axillary buds. The optimum cutting height is about 20 cm. Application of 5-8 kg urea/mu 5-7 days before harvest increased the yield of both rice crops. (1 mu = 0.067 ha).
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: DERZAVIN, A. I.
Title: Summary of work with perennial wheat in 1937.
Abstract Note: The perennial wheats are proving quite winter-hardy, and are superior to the standard Ukrainka in such qualities as vigour of growth, height and strength of straw, number of spikelets per ear and size of ear (twice that of Ukrainka in the second year of growth) and rust resistance. They were four days later in maturity than Ukrainka. Some individuals shattered rather badly when over-ripe and were therefore discarded; out of 300, 000 plants six were found with ears absolutely free from shattering, thereby removing one of the main defects of the perennial wheats. Many plants gave a second yield of grain later in the season.
Manual Tags: search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); WOS

Author: HANSON, A. A.
Title: Summer annual forage grasses in the United States
Publication Title: U S Dept Agric Agric Handbk
Abstract Note: Summer annual grasses, used for supplementary pastures or emergency forages, are relied on for a dependable supply of high quality forage when perennial forage species are relatively low in quality or yield. Sudangrass and its hybrids, pearl millet, Sorghum almum perennial sweet grass, fortail millet, japanese millet, and browntop millet are described and their yield and forage quality compared. Notes on prussic acid poisoning and seed production are included. || ABSTRACT AUTHORS: D. S. Negi

Author: DER ZAVIN, A. I.
Title: Supplementary information on perennial rye, S ecale Kuprijanovi Grossh. and its agricultural value.
Publication Title: Trudy prikl. Bol. Genet i Selekcii. Ser.
Abstract Note: There is literature to indicate that 5. Kuprijanovi Grossh. segregated by A. A. Grossheim (1928) from S. montanum L. and primarily evaluated agriculturally by I. M. Kuprijanov (1922 to 1926) has long been cultivated in mountainous parts of North Caucasus and from here was evidently introduced into Turkey and Armenia by immigrating natives (1864). It is valued for its relative earliness among other perennial rye forms, and its compact and vigorously tillering bush of prostrate shape. It retains green stems and leaves at full grain maturity, thus being of particular value for forage and pasture. Low drought resistance, prolonged maturation, susceptibility to fungi and fragility of ear lower its quality as a grain crop. Winterhardiness is still to be ascertained. Individual selection has given good results, namely, forms with simultaneous maturation of grain, and spring and highly drought resistant forms. High self-fertility of S. Kuprijanovi makes it easy to split populations into sections. As it crosses readily with other annual and perennial ryes, further improvement of 5. Kuprijanovi is thought to be possible through hybridization. In F 1 generation perenniality is dominant, but this seems to be linked with winterness and fragility of ear.-M.A.O.

Author: Jia'nan, Xie; JianJun, Guo; DaoChao, Jin; QiRong, Liao; TianLei, Liu
Title: Survey on rice planthopper overwintering in southern Guizhou Province.
Abstract Note: To find out present overwintering situation of rice planthoppers in Guizhou Province, a survey research was taken in southern Guizhou Province during 2010-2012 by methods of nets, visual inspection and light trap. The results showed that in nowaday climate background, and in the south part of Guizhou Province, such as Chaoyang and Yongkang, Sogatella furcifera and Laodelphax striatellus succeeded in overwintering on ratooning rice, of which long-wing type was more than short-wing type, females were more than males. Those overwintering rice planthoppers had very little effect on breakout of the initial rice planthoppers in the next spring.
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: Han, Xiao; CunShan, Ying
Title: Survey on the variations of morphological characters within the natural population of Dongxiang wild rice.
Abstract Note: Dongxiang wild rice ( Oryza sativa f. spontanea) regenerates by ratooning from nodes of lodged and buried stems. Comparisons with O. rufipogon have suggested that it is an exclusively perennial type. Information is presented from a principal component analysis of plant characters within a natural population of Dongxiang wild rice. Differences are noted between the subpopulations Linchang and Shuitao Tree.
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: Cadle-Davidson, L.; Bergstrom, G. C.; Cox, T. S.
Title: Susceptibility of perennial small grains to Soilborne wheat mosaic virus and Wheat spindle streak mosaic virus.
Abstract Note: Preliminary experiments were conducted to assess whether 8 of the most promising, yet diverse, perennial wheat and rye breeding lines were susceptible to Soilborne wheat mosaic virus (SBWMV) and Wheat spindle streak mosaic virus (WSSMV), either individually or when co-inoculated. The lines included were: AT3425 (putatively Triticum aestivum * Thinopyrum ponticum [ Elymus elongatus]), BFPMC1 ( Thinopyrum intermedium [ Elymus hispidus]), Permontra ( Secale cereale * S. montanum), PI-368149, PI-368150 ( Triticum turgidum * S. montanum), Spitzer, TA12252 ( S. montanum) and Varimontra (reselection of Permontra). Two seeds were planted into one-inch balls of moistened soil collected from SBWMV- and WSSMV-infested fields or a mixture of both soils (for co-inoculation). Two dozen soil balls per genotype per soil inoculum were planted into microplots of previously non-infested soil confined by fibreglass barriers at Tailby field, Ithaca, New York, USA in October 2001. Plants were inspected for virus-like symptoms in May, September and October 2002. All genotypes, except Spitzer, were considered to be at least moderately susceptible to one or both viruses based on the observation of typical disease symptoms in some inoculated plants. ELISA was used to confirm visual symptoms observed in May 2002. For SBWMV, ELISA confirmed infection of AT3425, PI-368149, TA12252 and Varimontra. For WSSMV, ELISA confirmed infection of AT3425 and Permontra. ELISA also confirmed co-infection of AT3425, BFPMC1, Permontra, PI-368149, PI-368150, TA12252 and Varimontra by SBWMV and WSSMV. None of the singly inoculated plants were co-infected. Strikingly, co-inoculation resulted in increased infection by both viruses. No symptoms were observed during autumn 2002, even though autumn temperatures were similar to those that were conducive for symptom development in the spring. No plants, whether infected by virus or not, survived the following winter for unknown reasons. The results suggest that perennial small grains are at risk for infection by soilborne viruses and that resistant cultivars may be needed for management of these diseases.
Manual Tags: search.grain; search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 grain); TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); WOS

Author: Cadle-Davidson, L.; Cox, T.s.; Bergstrom, G.c.
Title: Susceptibility of Perennial Small Grains to Soilborne wheat mosaic virus and Wheat spindle streak mosaic virus [electronic resource]
Abstract Note: Perennial small grains offer the potential for sustainable production of forage and grain on marginal and erodable lands. The authors' results suggest that perennial small grains are at risk for infection by Soilborne wheat mosaic virus (SBWMV) and Wheat spindle streak mosaic virus (WSSMV) and that resistant cultivars may be needed for management of these diseases. Ideally, breeders should screen perennial small grain lines for resistance to soilborne viruses in the early stages of selection.
Manual Tags: AGRICOLA; search.grain; search.rye; search.wheat; SPV; TX (perennial N1 grain)

Author: Michels Jr., G.J.; Jones, E.N.; Rush, C.M.
Title: Susceptibility of selected perennial small grain cultivars, to greenbug, schizaphis graminum (Rondani) (Hemiptera: Aphididae)
Abstract Note: Twelve perennial small grain cultivars were examined for eight characteristics favorable to management of greenbug, Schizaphis graminum (Rondani). A greenbug-susceptible variety of hard red winter wheat, Triticum aestivum L., and a greenbug-resistant hard red winter wheat variety were used as checks. Eight of the 12 perennial small grain cultivars (including X Triticosecale spp. / Thinopyrum intermedium // X Triticosecale spp., X Triticosecale spp. / Thinopyrum ponticum // X Triticosecale spp., Thinopyrum ponticum / Triticum aestivum var. Eltan, X Agrotriticum spp. (PI550715) / Tripsacum dactyloides var. Spitzer, and Hordeum vulgare var. MT2 / Tripsacum dactyloides var. Spitzer) had at least one favorable greenbug management characteristic. Cultivars that included X Triticosecale spp. and either Thinopyrum intermedium (Host) Barkworth & D.R. Dewey or T. ponticum wheatgrass in their genetic background had the most favorable characteristics.
Manual Tags: Scopus; search.grain; SPV; TITLE-ABS-KEY (perennial W/1 grain) AND DOCTYPE (ar); TS=(perennial NEAR/1 grain); WOS

Author: Fraser, D.M.; Dorling, P.R.
Title: Suspected ergotism in two heifers.
Abstract Note: A syndrome similar to gangrenous ergotism was seen in 2 Friesian heifers grazing meadow hay containing perennial rye grass seed heads parasited by an ergot presumed to be Claviceps purpurea. Clinical signs were bilateral hind limb lameness and gangrene. There was angiographic evidence of vasoconstriction in the lower hind limbs with necrosis of all tissues in the distal region of both hind limbs.
Manual Tags: Scopus; search.rye; SPV; TITLE-ABS-KEY (perennial W/1 ("rye" OR secale) AND NOT ("rye?grass" OR ryegrass)) AND DOCTYPE (ar)

Author: Snapp, S. S.; Rohrbach, D. D.; Simtowe, F.; Freeman, H. A.
Title: Sustainable soil management options for Malawi: can smallholder farmers grow more legumes?
Abstract Note: Sole-cropped, unfertilized maize is the dominant cropping system throughout southern Africa. Yields have become stagnant and legumes are frequently advocated as an affordable option for resource poor farmers, to enhance productivity. Farmer participatory research was employed to test legume intensification as a means to improve maize-based systems in Malawi. A range of,options were evaluated, from grain/legume intercrops of. long-duration pigeonpea (Cajanus cajan) and groundnut (Arachis hypogaea) rotated with maize (Zea mays), to a relay green manure system of maize with Tephrosia vogelii (Fishbean). Two years of on-farm experimentation indicated that under on-farm conditions legume-intensified systems produced residues that contained about 50 kg N/ha per year, two-fold higher than sole-cropped maize residues. Grain yields from legume-intensified systems were comparable to yields from continuous sole maize, even in a dry lakeshore ecology. These preliminary findings were linked to farmer assessment, where farmers participating in the trials expressed strong interest in the technologies. Yet the probability of adoption remains uncertain. Associated surveys outlined constraints and trade-offs underlying technology choice, information that is not usually considered in conjunction with on-farm trials. Although the legumes were highly productive, farmers expressed worries about the marginal loss of maize production. While the trial performance was similar across regions, differences in market condition, farm resources and household composition appears to stimulate different technology choices. Farmers weigh the benefits of weed suppression and potential cash earnings, against the costs of seed, problems of seed access, labor requirements and problems of grain market access and price. Surveyed farmers commonly manage residues by burning. Promotion and experimentation with more efficient use of legume residues may offer higher short-term impacts than efforts to promote adoption of another cash crop. Ultimately, adoption and soil fertility benefits may depend on market returns to legume production. This study documents the value of researchers and farmers partnering in evaluation of technologies, adoption constraints and competing technology choices.
