Author: W, SILVEY M.; R, FERRARIS
Title: SWARD PRODUCTIVITY AND SEASONAL ANIMAL PRODUCTION FROM PERENNIAL FORAGE SORGHUMS GRAZED AT FOUR STOCKING RATES
Publication Title: Australia Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organization   Division of Tropical Crops and Pastures Tropical Agronomy Technical   Memorandum
Abstract Note: Three forage sorghums (cvs. Crooble, Silk and Sucro) were sown in December 1974 and November 1976 as pure stands in a brigalow environment in south east Queensland [Australia]. Sward performance and seasonal animal [Hereford steers] production from the sorghums were assessed at stocking rates of 1.50, 2.50, 3.00 and 3.25 beasts ha-1. The pastures established in 1974 were grazed continuously from January 1975 to April 1976. The pastures sown in 1976 were grazed from January 1977 to June 1977. Swards were then spelled over winter and again grazed from January 1978 to April 1978. The cultivars differed little in annual sward productivity under grazing, though Silk produced more green material and had higher dry matter yields during the cool season. Swards of Crooble and Silk had less weed content during the second season. Total yield, green yield and sorghum yield decreased with increasing stocking rate. The superior growth of Silk in cool weather was reflected in least liveweight loss at this time. At other times of the year, there were no differences between cultivars in animal performance. The thermal regime dominated overall pasture productivity, regardless of species composition of swards, and this productivity was reflected in animal production. Average daily liveweight gain per animal over all cultivars and stocking rates reached 0.83 kg in one 112-day period. For a continuous 336-day period, average liveweight gain per animal was ca. 130 kg, equivalent to ca. 340 kg ha-1. Liveweight gain per animal or per hectare was reduced with increased stocking rate in the cooler months but, in summer, gain per hectare increased with stocking rate.
Manual Tags: search.sorghum; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 sorghum); WOS

Author: ONLEY, J. A.; SILLAR, D. J.
Title: Sweet sorghum for winter - autumn feed
Abstract Note: Departmental trials have shown that it is possible to finish steers at 2 years of age on young sweet sorghum. The mature growth is better utilized by breeders and older bullocks. Thirty 2-year old Poll Hereford steers, starting at an average weight of 758 lbs., gained only 1 lb. between April and May, grazing on mature December-January planted sweet sorghum. Transferred to an autumn planted crop and grazed another 2 months they gained 1.3 lbs./day. In the next 2 months grazing on ratoon sweet sorghum the steers gained 1.8 lbs./day to an average of 949 lbs. and dressed in September at 520 lbs. Although it was very dry during the winter (1.4 in. of rain May through October), the area continued to carry 1 beast to 2 acres. Besides fattening beef animals sweet sorghum may be used for weaned calves. Regrowth feed is of great value for late calving breeders. A large part of the dairy farms are subject to frosts. Sweet sorghum ready for grazing at this time is valuable as a source of energy to replace dry pastures, but protein feeds must be supplemented. Sweet sorghum has a place in preparing cut over lands for permanent pastures. || ABSTRACT AUTHORS: T. L. Bissell
Manual Tags: search.sorghum; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 sorghum); WOS

Author: Ryley, M.J.
Title: Symptom development on two wild, perennial grasses infected by Peronosclerospora species (Family Peronosporaceae: The downy-mildew fungi)
Abstract Note: The reproductive structures of the downy-mildew fungi, Peronosclerospora noblei and Peronosclerospora eriochloae, develop only on chlorotic leaves of tall, vegetative tillers of the perennial grasses Sorghum leiocladum (wild sorghum) and Eriochloa pseudoacrotricha (early spring grass), respectively. They are never found on the leaves of flowering tillers, even when tillers of both types grow from the same tussock. The development of symptoms on infected tillers of both hosts and the morphological and anatomical changes to host tissues on infected tillers are detailed.
Manual Tags: Scopus; search.sorghum; SPV; TITLE-ABS-KEY (perennial W/1 sorghum) AND DOCTYPE (ar); TS=(perennial NEAR/1 sorghum); WOS

Author: Björk, P.; Malm, J.; Hörnfeldt, A.-B.; Gronowitz, S.
Title: Synthesis of various substituted benzo[c]-2,7-naphthyridines and an approach towards the skeleton of meridine. Considerations about the effect of copper (II)oxide
Abstract Note: Derivatives of benzo[c]-2,7-naphthyridines have been prepared in good yields and in one step through the use of the Pd(0)-catalyzed cross couplings of 4-formyl- and 4-acetyl-3-pyridyltrimethylstannanes with ortho-bromoacetanilides. Perlolidine, an alkaloids present in perennial rye grass, was readily prepared in a few steps taking advantage of the cross coupling. An approach towards the pentacyclic ring skeleton of meridine has also been made, leading to several new derivatives of benzo[c]-2,7-naphthyridine. All cross couplings are greatly promoted by the addition of stoichiometric amounts of copper(II) oxide and a comparison with the use of other catalytic systems in the Pd(0)-catalyzed cross couplings is made.
Manual Tags: Scopus; search.rye; SPV; TITLE-ABS-KEY (perennial W/1 ("rye" OR secale) AND NOT ("rye?grass" OR ryegrass)) AND DOCTYPE (ar)

Author: Buddin, W.; Garrett, S. D.
Title: Take-all of cereals in 1943
Abstract Note: Take-all disease caused by Ophiobolus graminis was especially prevalent in Britain in 1943 following a mild and rainy winter. The disease was more prevalent in wheat following wheat or barley than in other rotations. Severe outbreaks of take-all have been traced to infected perennial grasses, especially Agropyron repens, Holcus lanatus, and Agrostis spp. Clean fields and crop rotation are recommended for control. || ABSTRACT AUTHORS: A. R. Trotter
Manual Tags: search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); WOS

Author: Anderson, K. L.
Title: Tame pastures in Kansa
Abstract Note: Practical in-formation, based on station research and experience, is given on the economy of pastures, tame perennial grasses and legumes, pasture mixtures, establishment and manage-ment practices, and the use of cereal grains, Sudan grass, Korean lespedeza, and rape for pasture. || ABSTRACT AUTHORS: Courtesy Exp. Sta. Rec
Manual Tags: search.grain; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 grain); WOS

Author: Washburn, J.D.; Murray, S.C.; Burson, B.L.; Klein, R.R.; Jessup, R.W.
Title: Targeted mapping of quantitative trait locus regions for rhizomatousness in chromosome SBI-01 and analysis of overwintering in a Sorghum bicolor × S. propinquum population
Abstract Note: While rhizome formation is intimately associated with perennialism and the derived benefit of sustainability, the introduction of this trait into temperate-zone adapted Sorghum cultivars requires precise knowledge of the genetics conditioning this trait in order to minimize the risk of weediness (e.g., Johnsongrass, S. halepense) while maximizing the productivity of perennial sorghum. As an incremental step towards dissecting the genetics of perennialism, a segregating F4 heterogeneous inbred family derived from a cross between S. bicolor and S. propinquum was phenotyped in both field and greenhouse environments for traits related to over-wintering and rhizome formation. An unseasonably cold winter in 2011 provided high selection pressure, and hence 74.8 % of the population did not survive. This severe selection pressure for cold tolerance allowed the resolution of two previously unidentified over-wintering quantitative trait locus (QTL) and more powerful correlation models than previously reported. Conflicting with previous reports, a maximum of 33 % of over-wintering variation could be explained by above-ground shoot formation from rhizomes; however, every over-wintering plant exhibited rhizome growth. Thus, while rhizome formation is required for over-wintering, other factors also determine survival in this interspecific population. The fine mapping of a previously reported rhizome QTL on sorghum chromosome SBI-01 was conducted by targeting this genomic region with additional simple sequence repeat markers. Fine mapping reduced the 2-LOD rhizome QTL interval from similar to 59 to similar to 14.5 Mb, which represents a 75 % reduction in physical distance and a 53 % reduction in the number of putative genes in the locus.
Manual Tags: AGRICOLA; Perennialism; Perenniality; Rhizomes; Scopus; search.sorghum; sorghum; Sorghum propinquum; SPV; TITLE-ABS-KEY (perennial W/1 sorghum) AND DOCTYPE (ar); TS=(perennial NEAR/1 sorghum); TX (perennial N1 sorghum); WOS
Automatic Tags: cold; cold tolerance; cultivars; genes; loci; models; overwintering; quantitative trait loci; rhizomes; risk; shoots; Sorghum bicolor; Sorghum halepense; winter

Author: SHARMA, S. D.; SHASTRY, S. V. S.
Title: Taxonomic studies in genus Oryza L. [Gramineae]. II. Some nomenclatural confusions
Abstract Note: Wild rices of Asia have been variously referred to by different workers as Oryza perennis, O. fatua, O. rufipogon, O. sativa var. fatua O. sativa L. f. spontanea, O. balunga, O. formosana etc. The validity of each of these names and their application to the taxa are discussed, and it is concluded that the name O. perennis is to be discarded: the valid name for perennial wild rice of Asia is O. rufipogon; and annual wild rice of Asia lacks a valid name. || ABSTRACT AUTHORS: Authors
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: Cherney, D.J.; Siciliano-Jones, J.; Pell, A.N.
Title: Technical note: forage in vitro dry matter digestibility as influenced by fiber source in the donor cow diet.
Abstract Note: Objectives of this study were to determine the influence of five donor cow diets that differed in source of fiber on true in vitro DM digestibility of eight forages. Test forages included two alfalfa (31.2 and 38.3% NDF), corn silage (50.2% NDF), oat forage (48.2% NDF), perennial rye (62.1% NDF), two reed canarygrasses (55.9 and 68.1% NDF), and timothy (68.2% NDF). Sources of fiber in donor cow diets were alfalfa haylage or alfalfa haylage plus either corn cobs, cottonseed hulls, oat hulls, or soy hulls. In addition, the effect of filtering through sintered glass crucibles or filter paper (two replicates each) was evaluated. There were differences (P < .01) among feeds in in vitro DM digestibility, but there were no interactions (P > .05) between test forages and either source of fiber in donor diets or filtration method. There was an interaction between source of fiber in the donor diet and method of filtration (P < .01). Samples inoculated with ruminal fluid from cows fed diets with oat hulls or soy hulls had lower (P < .01) in vitro DM digestibility when filtered on crucibles than on filter paper. Filtration method did not affect (P > .05) in vitro DM digestibility of samples inoculated with ruminal fluid from other diets. The in vitro DM digestibility of samples inoculated with ruminal fluid from cows fed alfalfa haylage was less than the in vitro DM digestibility when other inocula were used. The source of fiber in the donor cow diet and filtration method can affect in vitro DM digestibility, but relative ranking of forages was unaffected by these variables.
Manual Tags: Scopus; search.rye; SPV; TITLE-ABS-KEY (perennial W/1 ("rye" OR secale) AND NOT ("rye?grass" OR ryegrass)) AND DOCTYPE (ar)

Author: Cherney, D.j.r.; Pell, A.n.; Siciliano-Jones, J.
Title: Technical note: forage in vitro dyr matter digestibility as influenced by fiber source in the donor cow diet
Abstract Note: Objectives of this study were to determine the influence of five donor cow diets that differed in source of fiber on true in vitro DM digestibility of eight forages. Test forages included two alfalfa (31.2 and 38.3% NDF), corn silage (50.2% NDF), oat forage (48.2% NDF), perennial rye (62.1% NDF), two reed canarygrasses (55.9 and 68.1% NDF), and timothy (68.2% NDF). Sources of fiber in donor cow diets were alfalfa haylage or alfalfa haylage plus either corn cobs, cottonseed hulls, oat hulls, or soy hulls. In addition, the effect of filtering through sintered glass crucibles or filter paper (two replicates each) was evaluated. There were differences (P <.01) among feeds in in vitro DM digestibility, but there were no interactions (P > .05) between test forages and either source of fiber in donor diets or filtration method. There was an interaction between source of fiber in the donor diet and method of filtration (P < .01). Samples inoculated with ruminal fluid from cows fed diets with oat hulls or soy hulls had lower (P < .01) in vitro DM digestibility when filtered on crucibles than on filter paper. Filtration method did not affect (P > .05) in vitro DM digestibility of samples inoculated with ruminal fluid from other diets. The in vitro DM digestibility of samples inoculated with ruminal fluid from cows fed alfalfa haylage was less than the in vitro DM digestibility when other inocula were used. The source of fiber in the donor cow diet and filtration method can affect in vitro DM digestibility, but relative ranking of forages was unaffected by these variables.

Author: SHEPHERD, W.
Title: TEMPERATURE EFFECTS IN DETERMINATIONS OF LEAF RELATIVE WATER-CONTENT
Publication Title: Journal of the British Grassland Society

Author: Cysneiros, D.; Thuillier, A.; Villemont, R.; Littlestone, A.; Mahony, T.; O'Flaherty, V.
Title: Temperature effects on the trophic stages of perennial rye grass anaerobic digestion
Abstract Note: Continuous Stirred Tank Reactors (CSTRs), operated in batch mode, were used to evaluate the feasibility of psychrophilic (low temperature) digestion of perennial rye grass in a long term experiment (150 days) for the first time. The reactors were operated in parallel at 3 different temperatures, 10, 15 and 37 °C. Hydrolysis, acidification and methanogenesis were assessed by VS degradation, by soluble chemical oxygen demand (SCOD) and volatile fatty acids (VFA) production, and by methane production, respectively. Hydrolysis was the rate-limiting step at all temperatures and the rates and extent of hydrolysis were considerably lower at 15 and 10 °C, than at 37 °C. The total VS degradation was 53%, 34% and 19% at 37, 15 and 10 °C, respectively. Acidification was not affected by temperature and VFA production and consumption was balanced in all cases, except at 10 °C. Methane yields were 0.215 m 3 CH 4 kg -1 VS -1 added, 0.160 m 3 CH 4 kg -1 VS -1 added and 0.125 m 3 CH 4 kg -1 VS -1 added at 37, 15 and 10 °C, respectively. Methanogenesis was not strongly affected at 15 °C but it became rate-limiting at 10 °C. Overall, the solid degradation and methane production performance under psychrophilic conditions was encouraging and greater than previously reported. Considering the nonacclimated, mesophilic nature of the inoculum, there are grounds to believe that low-temperature anaerobic digestion of grass could be feasible if coupled to efficient hydrolysis of the biomass.
Manual Tags: Anaerobic digestion; Grass; Methane potential; Psychrophilic; Scopus; search.rye; SPV; Temperature effect; TITLE-ABS-KEY (perennial W/1 ("rye" OR secale) AND NOT ("rye?grass" OR ryegrass)) AND DOCTYPE (ar)

Author: OSSENT, H. P.
Title: Ten years of rye-breeding is Mucheberg.
Abstract Note: Different varieties oi rye react differently to prolonged inbreeding; some show only a very slight degree of degeneration. It has also been observed that in individual progenies the expression of the degeneration may vary. Vegetative vigour may be affected in some cases, in others the fertility. By 1937, after continuous inbreeding and selection a whole series of strains resistant to the ill-effects of inbreeding had been produced and a large number of crosses between them were made representing the beginning oi a systematic combination breeding programme. One of the objects is the production of a, rye with good baking quality and another the production of a perennial cultivated rye. Crosses between S. cereals and S. montanum anatolicum have been made and the promising progenies are being studied.
Manual Tags: search.rye; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 ("rye" OR secale) NOT "rye$grass"); WOS

Author: FEDOROV, A. K.
Title: Termination of the stage of vernalization of winter crop plants under natural conditions Referat. Zhur., Biol., 1956, No. 67158. (Translation.)
Abstract Note: This work was carried out from 1951 to 1953 with winter rye, winter wheat, various winter wheats obtained from vernalized wheat, red clover, and meadow fescue. Sowing of the grains was carried out in 8 periods, while the perennial grasses were sown every 10 days from April 21 to Oct. 11. Under Moscow district conditions, the stage of vernalization in winter wheat, rye, and perennial grasses ends at the end of Oct. and the beginning of Nov., depending on external conditions, sowing period, and variety. The winter qualities of plants are conditioned at the general stage of vernalization, but winter hardiness is a combination of processes within the plant organism. Perennial grasses must go through the stage of vernalization every year regardless of whether they blossomed in the previous years. Passage through the stage of vernalization precedes the bearing of all seeds by shoots of perennial grasses. In view of the absence of sufficient stores of organic substances, fescue and clover cannot experience the stage of vernalization in the seed, but go through it in phases 3 to 5 of the leaves.
Manual Tags: search.rye; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 ("rye" OR secale) NOT "rye$grass"); WOS

Title: Thai farmers and their use of fertilizers.
Abstract Note: The role of fertilizers in Thai agriculture is examined in order to understand the benefits which will accrue from the establishment of a fertilizer complex. During 1975-84 the use of chemical fertilizers increased fairly steadily due to government promotion and farmers' readiness to accept new technology. Farmers tend to use fertilizers in irregular quantities and often only on their poorest fields. Irrigation appears to be a major factor leading to increased fertilizer use, and more irrigation will have to be provided if the use of fertilizer is to become more widespread. In most cases the ingredients of fertilizers are imported and mixed locally with a filler. Demand for fertilizer depends largely on its price and producer prices of crops. 52% of total fertilizers consumed during the 1981/82-1983/84 cropping seasons were used for rice, while perennials and vegetables accounted for 14% and 12% respectively. The price of fertilizers in Thailand is higher than in other neighbouring countries. The use of fertilizers largely depends upon either the low price of fertilizer or the high price of agricultural products.
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: TSITSIN; CICIN], N. V.
Title: The 1954 U.S.S.R. agricultural exhibition.
Abstract Note: The director of the exhibition describes its chief features. Among the exhibits are some 2000 crop varieties, of which 354 represent the cereals, including high-yielding wheat-Agropyron hybrids highly resistant to lodging and plots of perennial wheat. A large "Micurin orchard" is also on display.

Author: KEDROV-ZIKHMAN, O. K.; TALANOVA, K. S.
Title: The action of granular superphosphate on the yield of agricultural crops as a function of the method of its application and in connection with the liming of mildly argillaceous Turf-Pest Podzolic Soils
Publication Title: Sbarnik Nauch Trud Inst Sots S Kh Akad Nauk Sssr
Abstract Note: In two field experiments a comparison was made between the effects of powdered and granulated superphosphate on unlimed soil and on soil which had been limed with chalk (1.5 T/hectare). The first experiment was set up on lupine fallow with a K base, the second on an NK base. The superphosphate was applied as follows: the powdered variety was scattered at the rate of 60 kg P2O5/hectare and the granulated placed in the rows at the rate of 10-20 kg P2O5/hectare. The experimental crops were rye and barley followed by perennial grasses. The granulated Pc gave rises in the yield similar to those resulting from powdered Pc. Applying small doses of Pc in the rows raised the rye and barley yields, and their quality, and the yields of the perennial grasses which followed them. On unlimed soil in the majority of cases granulated Pc had no particular advantage over the powdered. Liming gave rise to a significant mobilization of P2O5 in the soil. || ABSTRACT AUTHORS: Transl. from Referat. Zhur. Biol. 1238, 1958, courtesy OTS-JPRS
Manual Tags: search.rye; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 ("rye" OR secale) NOT "rye$grass"); WOS

Author: SOUDNOV, P.
Title: The after-harvest growing of perennial wheat and perennial rye.
Abstract Note: Perennial wheat ( Triticum x Agropyron) and rye sprouted better after the first crop of grain when this was cut high than when cut low.
Manual Tags: search.rye; search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 ("rye" OR secale) NOT "rye$grass"); TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); WOS

Author: HART, J.
Title: The agricultural potential of the Central Queensland Highlands
Abstract Note: The area was opened in 1870 and has been farmed spasmodically but with little success. Farmers from other areas are now slowly moving in and the area has high potential yields when the proper methods are followed. Tractors and modern machinery have made the development possible. The Highlands include 24,000,000 acres on the Tropic of Capricorn and 100 to 300 miles inland. The rainfall averages 26 inches with monsoon rains in summer and dry winters. The mean minimum temperaute is 58[degree]F. and the mean maximum 85[degree]. There are 310 frost-free days. The open downs country which requires practically no clearing is undulating (2[degree] to 5[degree] slopes) and potentially erosive, hence strip cropping is the ideal system. Cultivated crops include grain or sweet sorghum, wheat, linseed and sunflower. Oats are used for a winter grazing crop. Sorghum and wheat yield 60 bu. per acre when properly managed and sorghum is especially valuable because it may ratoon for 4 or 5 years. Stubble mulching on the fallow land is necessary. Land with soil less than two feet deep is risky, three and four feet are better so as to store plenty of water. Also it is necessary to avoid land with stone underlying the surface. The proper size of a living area seems to lie between 1500 and 5000 areas. At present three acres are required per sheep but this can be reduced to one acre by proper handling and 2500 to 3000 sheep afford a reasonable living. || ABSTRACT AUTHORS: T. L. Bissell
Manual Tags: search.sorghum; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 sorghum); WOS

Author: KHASHKHOZHEV, A.; AVDEEV, Yu S.
Title: The agriculture and diseases of Potato.
Abstract Note: a. Common scab [ Streptomyces scabies] developed most severely in plots on which potato was planted after fodder beet and perennial grasses. Wheat was the best preceding crop. Annual inorganic fertilizer decreased tuber infection but organic fertilizer favoured the disease. b. The number of potato plants infected by rugose and streak mosaic, gothic and leaf roll [viruses] decreased to 3.4% after applying NPK with Ca as compared with 7% in single cultivation and 6.4% with crop rotation.
Manual Tags: search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); WOS

Author: IKONNIKOV, V. K.
Title: The agrotechny of perennial grasses in relation to soils contours
Abstract Note: According to the data of the All-Union Scientific Research Institute of Fertilizers and Agricultural Soil Science the cultivation of perennial grasses on areas with disjointed relief in the northwestern part of the Tartar ASSR requires special agricultural engineering, selection of species and the ingredients in grass mixtures. On the higher parts of the contour and on the southern slopes alfalfa either pure or mixed with smooth brome grass give better results. It is recommended that the alfalfa be sown only under the cover of the spring wheat. It is expedient to use clover with timothy grass on the lower parts of the contour and on the northern slopes. A higher rate of seed sowing should be used on the higher places of the contour and on the patches of land filled up with the mud from eroded soils. || ABSTRACT AUTHORS: Transl. from Referat. Zhur. Biol. 91697, 1958, courtesy OTS-JPRS
Manual Tags: search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); WOS

Author: Jeffreys, J.A.D.
Title: The alkaloids of perennial eye-grass (lolium perenne L.). Part I. Perloline
Abstract Note: Perloline is shown to be a normal constituent of perennial rye-grass growing in Britain. Its isolation is described. Perloline is shown to exist in different solvents as an anhydronium base, a pseudo-base, or an ether thereof, as a cation, or as an anion.

Author: Ferguson, G.; Jeffreys, J.A.D.; Sim, G.A.
Title: The alkaloids of perennial rye-grass (Lolium perenne L.) Part II. The crystal structure of the red form of perloline mercurichloride
Publication Title: Journal of the Chemical Society B: Physical Organic
Abstract Note: The structure of the perloline cation C 20H 17N 2O 3 + (=AH +) has been determined by an X-ray study of the hydrated mercurichloride, (AH) 2HgCl 4,2H 2O. The crystals are orthorhombic, a = 12.83 ± 0.03, b = 18.85 ± 0.05, c = 16.63 ± 0.05 Å, space group Pnan, with four formula units (i.e., eight perloline residues) in the unit cell. Phase determination based on the mercury atom with Fourier and least-squares refinement methods established the constitution of the cation. In the final results the discrepancy R over the 2077 reflections used is 11.15%. The bond lengths and angles have average estimated standard deviations of 0.03 Å and 2°.

Author: Jeffreys, J.A.D.
Title: The alkaloids of perennial rye-grass (Lolium perenne L.). Part IV. Isolation of a new base, perlolyrine; the crystal structure of its hydrobromide dihydrate, and the synthesis of the base
Publication Title: Journal of the Chemical Society C: Organic
Abstract Note: A new alkaloid, perlolyrine, 1-(5-hydroxymethyl-2-furyl)-9H-pyrido[3,4-b] indole (6b), has been isolated from Lolium perenne L. (Graminae). The structure of the base was revealed by an X-ray analysis of its hydrobromide dihydrate C16H12N2O2,HBr,2H20 (space group P1, a=7.81, b=10.55, c=10.55 Å, α=79.2 α= 72.9 β, γ= 78.8°), by use of the heavy-atom method, assisted by spectroscopic data. The final value of R over 2360 reflections is 0.129; an attempt to refine the structure in space group P1 failed. The alkaloid has been synthesised from tryptophan and 5-acetoxymethyl-2-formylfuran. The 3,4-dihydro- and 1,2,3,4-tetrahydro-derivatives have also been synthesised, starting from tryptamine. The ways in which perlolyrine and its reduced derivatives break up on electron impact are discussed. Perlolyrine is shown to be present in the dried grass, and is not an artefact of the working-up process.
Manual Tags: Scopus; search.rye; SPV; TITLE-ABS-KEY (perennial W/1 ("rye" OR secale) AND NOT ("rye?grass" OR ryegrass)) AND DOCTYPE (ar)

Author: POTAPOV, A. A.
Title: The anophelogenic significance of water wild rice sprouts in reservoirs
Abstract Note: Observations made in shallow water portions of various reservoirs (Uchinsk, Karpovsk) in 1956 disclosed that thickets of annual rice which have floating leaves at the beginning of development are anophelogenic. During the full vegetative stage the rice darkens large areas of the water, but in many sections it grows as thin thickets where hairweed and Elodea (water thyme) grow and promote the development of the Anopheles mosquitoes. If the rice is not cut annually, when it dies off, conditions are created which favor the development of algae. Calculations showed that the anophelogeni-city of rice does not exceed that of the control plots. It is recommended that agrotechnical measures be taken in order to increase the height and density of the thickets; and also that the rice be harvested as late as possible. No fertilizers should be used because they stimulate hairweed. Perennial rice crops are not favorable for Anopheles larvae, since they form dense thickets which reach a height of 3 to 3-1/2 m; their powerful stems and wide leaves form a dense shade and the perennial rice competes successfully not only with submerged vegetation but also with lineides. Mosquito larvae are very sparse in these thickets. Only harvested sections had anophelogenic importance, but when the rice grew again the anophelogenicity dropped rapidly. The abundance of larvae in these patches is determined by the method of rice harvesting. || ABSTRACT AUTHORS: Transl. from Referat. Zhur. Biol. 91085, 1958, courtesy OTS-JPRS
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: WILLS, J. McGREGOR; BERRILL, F. W.
Title: The banana
Abstract Note: Bananas have been planted in Queensland since 1867 and extend from the southern border northward 1200 miles to Mossman. Plantings in 1952-53 were estimated at 8707 acres. The banana plant consists of a thick pseudostem above the true stem or rhizome. The pseudostem consists of leaf bases which protect new leaves and developing flowers. Sucker buds arise in leaf axils on opposite sides of the stem. Roots are cord-like and fleshy and few go deeper than 30 inches in the soil. Flowers and resultant fruit develop on the terminus of the corm which pushes up through the pseudostem. The flowers are potentially bisexual but differentiate to female, hermapheodite and male; cultivated bananas produce fruit without pollination and make no seed. Flowers may be laid down about 4 mos. after planting but in southern Queensland it is better if initiation comes at the end of cold weather, or about 8 mos. after planting the first of January. If initiated before cold weather the fruit may be stunted and is called "November dump". Fruit initiated in September is thrown or shoots in January or February and is ready to harvest from April to June. The main vars. are Cavendish, Mosn Mari and Williams Hybrid, Lady Finger, Sugar and Anamalu. Lady Finger and Sugar are susceptible to Panama Disease; Cavendish is resistant. Cavendish is 6 ft. tall and sturdy, the others vary from 8 to 16 ft. and either require propping when the fruit is filling or are too tall to make it practical. Mons Mari and Williams Hybrid are mutants of Cavendish adapted to high altitudes. Between 50 and 100 inches of rain, a high temperature with freedom from frost, and protection from wind are required. A perennial legume such as pigeon pea, Cajanus cajan, is used as a cover crop. If the first growth is cut back at 12 months regrowth will suppress weeds and may be left several years. Banana planting material includes butts, the corms with part of the pseudostem from a matured or nearly matured plant, suckers which are offshoots from the parent plant, and most commonly used planting material, and bits which are obtained by splitting the corm of a 6-month old plant so each half has a good bud or eye. Extra buds and the original growing point are gouged out. Planting in southern Queensland about January 1 gives best results. The taller vars. are planted earlier than the dwarf. Banana plants are allowed from 81 to 196 square feet of space. Bananas will make several ratoon crops selecting 2 or 3 sucker or follower plants the first year and one each succeeding year. Desuckering and thrashing or removal of dead leaves is a monthly task. Bunches of fruit maturing during the winter must be covered to prevent blemishes [long dash]open ended cloth or paper sacks are used. The bunch is ready to cut when the fruit is evenly rounded without prominent ribs and flowers readily rub off. Bananas are allowed to sweat 8 hours in the shed and packed in 1-1/4 bu. cases as "singles" or less commonly as hands. The fruit is cut green and artificially ripened with coal gas or other material. To prevent spread of disease bananas are grown under regulation, and diseased and old plants must be eradicated. They are dug out by hand or injected with hormone plant killer in the summer. To clear an acre 5 gallons of 1% solution are required, following up with 0.2% solution in spray form on surviving suckers. || ABSTRACT AUTHORS: T. L. Bissell
Manual Tags: search.pigeonpea; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (cajanus OR "pigeon$pea")); WOS

Author: SCHILBERSZKY, K.
Title: The Barberry shrub and the black rust problem.
Abstract Note: The investigations of various workers on the role of barberries (chiefly Berberis vulgaris and Mahonia [B.] aquifolium) in the transmission of black rust of cereals ( Puccinia graminis) are summarized, and a discussion [accompanied by tables] is given of the author's recent researches (1929-30) on the correlation between environmental and climatic conditions and the occurrence of the disease in Hungary. Under Hungarian conditions the overwintered uredospores of the rust may sometimes be found on winter cereals (rye) and perennial wild grasses, e.g., Dactylis glomerata and Poa pratensis, in the very early spring (23rd and 25th March, 1930). Teleutospores may be formed as early as a fortnight after the first appearance of the uredospores. The teleutospores do not germinate until they have overwintered under natural conditions; those passing the winter on straw in barns or granaries cannot be germinated. As a rule the teleutospores lose their viability in a few months, but when kept in the cold they may retain it for almost a year [cf. R.A.M., ix, p. 365]. During the excessively cold winter of 1928-9 (mini-mum temperature during February in Hungary -32degreesC.) the teleutospores remained viable and infected the barberries in the following spring, resulting in a severe epidemic of black rust on the cereals. In places liable to rigorous winter weather late developing uredospores of P. graminis may in exceptional cases persist until the spring in a viable condition on manure heaps or the like; protection from the frost may further be given by the snow cover. Spring infections may also arise in Hungary through the agency of uredospores which are not of local origin but are borne by the prevailing south, south-east, and south-west winds from southerly regions, e.g., the Balkans and northern Italy [cf. ibid., viii, p. 364]. Although P. graminis is not absolutely dependent on the barberry for its persistence, there can be no doubt, in the writer's opinion, that systematic barberry eradication would have a considerable effect in reducing black rust of cereals.
Manual Tags: search.rye; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 ("rye" OR secale) NOT "rye$grass"); WOS

Author: TANSIOII, V. I.
Title: The basis of agricultural methods of control of the wheat thrips Haplothrips tritici Kurd. (Thysanoptera, Phloeothripidae) in northern Kazakhstan
Abstract Note: The wheat thrips (Haplothrips tritici Kurd.) is widely distributed in northern Kazakhstan where it colonizes all the spring wheat sowings on the newly opened lands and attains large numbers on them. The main sources of colonization of new sowings are the spring wheat fields situated on old plowlands. The other sources from which wheat thrips can migrate are the virgin lands and fallow lands of varying age, mainly those under couch-grass. The start of the flight of the thrips in northern Kazakhstan coincides with stalk formation in spring wheat, and flight coincides with the beginning of spike-formation. The colonization of plants by thrips takes place exactly at the phase of loosening of the sheath, when they have the "opportunity to penetrate into the young spike still hidden under the leaves. The timing of the egg laying to the period between the start of loosening of the sheath and full ripening of the wheat plants causes constant migrations of adult thrips from plant to plant within the field, as well as to other fields outside it. Migration is effected passively by wind. Extended sowing of winter wheat creates favorable conditions for egg-laying by the thrips owing to the longer time the wheat plants are in the selected phase of development. Late sowings usually act as bait crops and there is a concentration of egg-laying females on them. Fecundity is low and amounts to 20-22 eggs/female. The larvae attain their greatest numbers on spring wheat during grain formation. By the start of harvest, the vast majority of them have migrated into the soil for wintering. Survival during overwintering and metamorphosis varies greatly in different fields and largely depends on the modes of soil and crops cultivation, which determine both the moisture-temperature regime in the soil and on its surface, and also the vertical distribution of the larvae in the soil. In northern Kazakhstan the greatest mortality among the larvae (65-75%) in the wintering period was brought about by stubble-harrowing in autumn. A relatively smaller mortality among the larvae (30 to 60%) was produced by autumn plowing. On perennial grass fields, untilled in autumn, the mortality among the larvae did not exceed 25-47%. In the period of metamorphosis in the stubble mortality in fallow fields reached 53%, on spring wheat sowings 39%, and on perennial grasses only 12%. The application of the Mal'tsev system of soil cultivation, the extension of sowings of annual grasses in place of half-cover sowings of perennial grasses and the shortening of the sowing period for spring wheat create the requisite conditions for reducing the numbers of wheat thrips in northern Kazakhstan. || ABSTRACT AUTHORS: Auth. summ
Manual Tags: search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); WOS

Author: TANSKII, V. I.
Title: The basis of cultural methods of control of the wheat thrips, Haplothrips tritici Kurd. (Thysanoptera, Phloeothrjpidae), in northern Kazakhstan.
Abstract Note: Haplothrips tritici Kurd, is a serious pest of spring-sown wheat in the recently cultivated lands of northern Kazakhstan. In 1954-56, when observations were made, the adults appeared in mid-June and the females laid up to 20-22 eggs each on the immature ears. The nymphs hatched at the beginning of July, at the time of grain formation, but left the ears before harvest and hibernated either in the soil, at a depth of about 4 in., or in the stubble near the roots. In May, they came to the upper soil layer for pupation, and nymphs, pupae and adults were all observed in the soil in June. Considerable mortality occurred during metamorphosis, 53.7, 39.7 and 12 per cent. of the thrips dying in fallow, wheat and perennial grass fields, respectively; though temperature and moisture in the last were more favourable for development. Autumn ploughing resulted in 30-60 per cent. mortality of the overwintering nymphs, and breaking up the soil, which exposed them to frost, gave 65-75 per cent. kill. The rotation of wheat with annual grasses instead of with perennial ones is recommended, and further control can be gained by shortening the sowing period, thus reducing the time favourable for oviposition.
Manual Tags: search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); WOS

Author: KHOLODNY, T.
Title: The birth of perennial wheat.
Abstract Note: An account is given of Cicin's investigations on crossing wheat with Agropyron. Reference is made to a meeting between Micurin and Cicin in 1927, at which Micurin made the suggestion of improving wheat by remote hybridization.

Author: GHOSH, C. C.
Title: The Black Beetle ( Alissonotum impressicolle Arr.), a Pest of Sugarcane in Myitkyina District in Northern Burma.
Abstract Note: Alissonotum impressicolle, Arr., is a serious pest of sugar-cane in a district about 300 miles north of Mandalay in northern Burma. Brief notes are given on the characters of soil and climate in the district; the beetle has not so far been abundant where the soil is highly acid. It occurs in association with elephant grasses both in Assam and Burma (where the preponderant species are Saccharum arundinaceum and Imperata arundinacea[Imperata cylindrica], among the roots of which the larvae are common), but has also been found on high, well-drained lands without any elephant grass. It was first recorded as a pest of sugar-cane in Assam in 1919 and in Burma in 1927. S. Takano, in a communication to the author, stated that in Formosa it is a pest of sugar-cane in unirrigated districts in the south and causes most injury in May and June; cane planted from January to April suffers severely but that planted from July to October is little affected. In northern Formosa, cane is an irrigated crop grown in rotation with rice, and most of the larvae die during the rainy season from December to March. Crops are rarely ratooned. Campsomeris (Elis) annulata, F., which also occurs in Burma, destroys about 1.5 per cent, of the larvae. In Burma, eggs are laid in the soil from late September to early December and hatch in about 2-21/2 weeks. Larvae are capable of feeding and developing on humus, but in sugar-cane fields they live among and feed on the roots, and so are not affected by the cultivation of the soil between the rows. They only become a pest when conditions are favourable for breeding in the field, as when ratooning is long continued. Pupation and adult emergence begin in early and mid-March, respectively. The adults are active until late June or early July, gnawing the shoots of cane, and then rest until late September, when oviposition begins. They are dead by December. If drought occurs while the beetles are active, feeding decreases, but is renewed with heavy showers of rain. When in want of food, they migrate in numbers. They are slightly repelled by strong lights. Collections at the beginning of the season showed that the sexes were about equal in number, but later females greatly outnumbered males. Females probably lay about 100 eggs, depositing them a few at a time and often at intervals of several days. Details are given of the extent and nature of the damage caused by this Dynastid. In 1932, it was estimated that 12-75 larvae occurred under each root over large areas of ratoon cane. The variety of sugar-cane chiefly grown up to 1932 shows some slight resistance to attack, but ratoons well, third ratoon being commonly taken and sometimes fourth and fifth, which encourages the infestation. Four other varieties, which are less resistant but which can only be ratooned once, are now recommended. Natural enemies of the larvae, none of which appears to be of much importance, include various birds, the Asilid, Philodicus femoralis, Ric., Campsomeris annulata, a Tachinid parasite, several Carabid predators, and the fungus, Metanhizium anisopliae. An account is given of experiments on control in which various baits for the adults were ineffective, and soil fumigants against the larvae did not give results good enough to justify their use. Flooding the fields with water only killed a small percentage of the larvae. A rotary plough, working down to about 4 ins., destroyed 40 per cent, of the larvae and exposed others to birds. The only measure that has so far given any practical result is the restriction of ratooning and the introduction of a fallow period of at least a year. Infestation is negligible if cane is grown as an annual crop in rotation with non-cereal crops. The possibilities of control by hand collection of the beetles or by introducing natural enemies are discussed.
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: CONRAD, JOHN P.
Title: The carbohydrate composition of corn and sorghum roots
Publication Title: Journal of the American Society of Agronomy
Abstract Note: In preliminary tests under the same cultural conditions in 1927 at maturity total sugars as sucrose in the roots varied in different types and varieties of sorghums from about 15% to over 55% on the basis of dry organic matter, while in corn varieties they varied from much less than 1 to about 4.5%. In more extensive experiments in 1928 under different soil moisture conditions, the sugars in corn (King Philip Hybrid) decreased from amounts varying from about 8.5 to nearly 18% at the blossom stage down to amounts, with one exception, below 2.5% at maturity. This suggests a movement of sugars to the ear during the maturing of the crop. Sugars in sorghum (White Durra) with but few exceptions remained above 16% from bloom to maturity, with many of the samples being over 30% There are indications that sorghums cut back at maturity make new shoot growth at the expense of sugars stored in the roots. In corn plants without seed-bearing ears at maturity in 1930 the sugar percentages were consistently higher in both roots and stalks than in those plants with seed-bearing ears. This was especially true in regard to stalks. These data are consistent with the view that corn is physiologically an annual while sorghums are perennials.
Manual Tags: AGRICOLA; search.sorghum; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 sorghum); TX (perennial N1 sorghum); WOS
Automatic Tags: carbohydrates; chemical constituents of plants; roots; Zea mays

Author: Moore, Andrew D.
Title: The case for and against perennial forages in the Australian sheep-wheat zone: modelling livestock production, business risk and environmental interactions
Abstract Note: Perennial forages have been proposed as a means of ameliorating both the summer-autumn feed gap and the risks posed by soil salinity and erosion in mixed farming areas of southern Australia. Whole-farm simulation analyses using the APSIM and GRAZPLAN models at nine locations across southern Australia have evaluated the likely trade-offs among expected profitability, financial risk, soil erosion risk, deep drainage and soil carbon change as annual pastures are converted to perennial pastures based on a C-3 grass, a C-4 grass or lucerne. Differences between perennial and annual feedbases in total pasture growth (median -11%, range -47% to +20%) and metabolisable energy supply from pasture (median +1%, range -48% to +52%) were diverse across locations and perennial species. At some locations, improvements in the pasture feedbase were counter-balanced by lower livestock intakes from crop stubbles. The modelled farming system with the highest profit included some perennial pasture at seven of the nine locations, but no one pasture species or land-use system predominated across all locations or producer risk attitudes. Local characteristics of the soils and farming systems are as important as broad climatic factors in determining how substituting perennial for annual pastures alters the trade-off between profitability and wind erosion risk. Further expanding permanent pastures into land currently used for crops only unequivocally reduced wind erosion risk at the four locations with Mediterranean climates. Lucerne grown in long rotations provided the best trade-off between mean gross margin and financial risk at Merriwagga and Temora. Permanent C-3 or C-4 perennial grass pastures separated from continuous cropping may simultaneously increase profits and reduce business and erosion risk at low-rainfall locations with Mediterranean climates, as long as they can be managed to persist. Managing pastures for greater nitrogen inputs could be considered as an erosion-abatement strategy.
Manual Tags: search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); WOS

Author: Meyfroidt, Patrick; Lambin, Eric F.
Title: The causes of the reforestation in Vietnam
Abstract Note: We test an emerging theory of the forest transition using the case of Vietnam. In the early 1990s, decollectivisation of agriculture, allocation of forestry land to households, and the development of market networks transformed land use in the mountains of Vietnam, leading to an increase in forest area. We used census and geographic data covering the whole country at a fine level of aggregation to build a spatial lag regression model of reforestation. We separated natural forest regrowth from the increase in plantation forests. The forest transition theory distinguishes between the forest scarcity and economic development paths. Our study suggests that the forest scarcity path was in part at work in Vietnam: new policies allocating forestry land to households, local scarcity of forest products, and development of remote demand for timber contributed to forest cover increases. The evidence regarding the economic development path are more ambiguous, as there was no depopulation or agricultural decline in marginal regions. We propose a third forest transition path that better corresponds to Vietnam's situation: a smallholder agricultural intensification path. In marginal regions, land scarcity associated with population growth, land degradation, and political restrictions led to, on one hand, a decline in cultivation on hillsides followed by reforestation and, on the other hand, an increase in labour inputs on the plots with the highest agro-ecological potential. The development of markets for agricultural inputs and outputs did also contribute to reforestation by raising agricultural productivity in mountain paddies and maize fields. This reinforced the concentration of agriculture on the most suitable land.
Manual Tags: Agricultural intensification; Forestry; Forest transition; Land abandonment; Land allocation; Land use change; perennial W/1 (oryza OR rice); Reforestation; ScienceDirect; search.rice; Spatial lag regression; SPV; Vietnam

Author: Medina, Joaquín; Catalá, Rafael; Salinas, Julio
Title: The CBFs: Three arabidopsis transcription factors to cold acclimate
Publication Title: Plant and Microbe Adaptation to Cold
Abstract Note: Low temperature is one of the adverse environmental factors that most affects plant growth and development. Temperate plants have evolved the capacity to acquire chilling and freezing tolerance after being exposed to low-nonfreezing temperatures. This adaptive response, named cold acclimation, involves many physiological and biochemical changes that mainly rely on reprogramming gene expression. Currently, the best documented genetic pathway leading to gene induction under low temperature conditions is the one mediated by the Arabidopsis C-repeat/dehydration-responsive element binding factors (CBFs), a small family of three transcriptional activators (CBF1-3) that bind to the C-repeat/dehydration-responsive element, which is present in the promoters of many cold-responsive genes, and induce transcription. The CBF genes are themselves induced by cold. Different evidences indicate that the CBF transcriptional network plays a critical role in cold acclimation in Arabidopsis. In this review, recent advances on the regulation and function of CBF factors are provided and discussed.
Manual Tags: Abiotic stress; Arabidopsis; CBF/DREB1; Cold acclimation; Freezing tolerance; perennial W/1 (oryza OR rice); ScienceDirect; search.rice; SPV; Transcriptional regulation

Author: HuiJie, Yang; JingSheng, Zheng; ZhaoWei, Jiang; YiZhen, Li; ChuanYing, Zhuo; ShangShou, Zhang
Title: The characters of sink structure of super high-yielding ratooning rice.
Abstract Note: The sink structure of ratooning rice with different yield potentials was investigated in 2000. The variety used in the study was Xianyouming 86, a super high-yielding rice. Results indicated that yield was most closely related to spikelet number per panicle in the first season, and this yield factor contributed most to yield. In the ratooning season, yield was most closely related to panicle number, which was the main contributor to yield. Super high-yielding ratooning rice had larger sinks [than lower yielding varieties?], not only in the first season but also in the ratooning season. The sink volume made a greater contribution to yield than did seed setting. The contribution of total spikelet number per unit area to yield was higher than that of grain weight. The contribution of spikelet number per panicle to total spikelet number per unit area was higher than panicle number per area in the first season, and in the ratooning season this was the other way round. It is concluded that larger panicles should be fostered in the first season to enlarge the sink volume in order to obtain higher yield, but panicle numbers should be fostered in the ratooning season.
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: ISKENDEROV, S. G.
Title: The chemical composition of perennial hybrid gramineous plants, and of their mixtures with legumes, at various stages of growth.
Publication Title: Sbornik Trudov Aspirantov i Molodykh Nauchnykh Sotrudnihov. Vsesoyuznyi   Nauchno-Issledovaterskii Institut N.I. Vavilova
Abstract Note: Herbage of perennial hybrid wheat ( Secale kuprijanovii * Triticum durum), perennial hybrid rye ( S. kuprijanovii * S. segetale), cocksfoot and lucerne, grown in Azerbaidzhan was analysed for CP and carotene in the 1st and 2nd yr of growth. Wheat and rye hybrids contained 21.4 and 20.5% CP (DM basis), respectively, at full-flowering in the 1st yr and 17.5% (both hybrids) at the same stage in the 2nd yr; cocksfoot contained 13.5 and 12.9% CP in the 1st and 2nd yr, respectively. Mixtures of wheat and rye hybrids with cocksfoot, lucerne, vetches and fodder peas in various combinations were also analysed and recommendations are made for their cultivation for fodder. -A.V.B.
Manual Tags: search.rye; search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 ("rye" OR secale) NOT "rye$grass"); TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); WOS

Author: KangJing, Liang; ShiLiao, Chen; KaiJian, Chen; JuSheng, Wang; WenMo, Fang; YuanXiang, Zhou; GuanHan, Xiao
Title: The comparison and correlation and path analysis of yield and its components between the first and ratooning crop of hybrid rice.

Author: Y-I, CHU; R-F, LIOU
Title: THE COMPARISON OF FEEDING MARKS AND HONEYDEW EXCRETION OF GREEN RICE LEAFHOPPER NEPHOTETTIX-CINCTICEPS ON VARIOUS GRAMINACEOUS PLANTS DELTOCEPHALIDAE HOMOPTERA
Abstract Note: The relationship between the suitability of host plants and feeding amount of green rice leafhopper (N. cincticeps Uhler) was investigated. Feeding amount is evaluated by the number of feeding marks on each tested plant, and the sugar and amino acid content in the honeydew. The following 20 spp. of graminaceous plants were used: bermuda grass (Cynodon dactylon Pers.), torpelo grass (Panicum repens Linn.), goosegrass (Eleusine indica Gaerth), buffalo grass (Paspalum conjugatum Berg.), dillis grass (P. dilatum Poiret.), knot grass (P. distichum Linn.), water bamboo (Zizania aquatica Linn.), sugarcane (Saccharum officinarum Linn., F160), Setaria italica Kth. (Taidong no. 3), wheat (Triticum sativum Lam. var. vulgare. Taichung no. 31), corn (Zea mays Linn., Tainan no. 11), oat (Avena fatua Linn., NTU no. 1), sorghum (Andropogon sorghum Brot., Taihung no. 3), dent foxtail (Alopecurus aequalis Sobolewsky), barnyard grass (Echinochloa crus-galli Beauv.), Leersia hexandra, ratoon paddy (Oryza sativa Linn., Tainong no. 67), and paddy (O. sativa Luin., Tainan no. 5), Brachiaria mutica, Sporobolus fertilis. Then, ten 3rd- to 4th-instar nymphs or 3-5 day-old male and female adult leafhoppers were inoculated on each host plant and exposed for 48 h. The number of feeding marks on a host plant was not consistent with the suitability of the plant to the leafhopper. The occurrence of feeding marks on preferable host plants is arranged in the following order: ratoon paddy > paddy > leersia > grass > barnyard grass > dent foxtail. The combinations of probing stimulant, sucking stimulant, nutrients within the plant juice and the physical characters of the plant cuticles for feeding mark formation may result in this inconsistency. The honeydew from the most favorable host plants, including paddy ratoon paddy, barnyard grass, leersia grass and dent foxtail contains more carbohydrates and amino acids than the others. Estimation of carbohydrates and amino acid content in honeydew provides a simple and rapid bioassay method for the evaluation of suitability of plants to green rice leafhopper.
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: Shahid Masood, M.; Nishikawa, Tomotaro; Fukuoka, Shu-ichi; Njenga, Peter K.; Tsudzuki, Takahiko; Kadowaki, Koh-ichi
Title: The complete nucleotide sequence of wild rice (Oryza nivara) chloroplast genome: first genome wide comparative sequence analysis of wild and cultivated rice
Abstract Note: We determined the complete nucleotide sequence of the chloroplast genome of wild rice, Oryza nivara and compared it with the corresponding published sequence of relative cultivated rice, Oryza sativa. The genome was 134,494 bp long with a large single-copy region of 80,544 bp, a small single-copy region of 12,346 bp and two inverted repeats of 20,802 bp each. The overall A+T content was 61.0%. The O. nivara chloroplast genome encoded identical functional genes to O. sativa in the same order along the genome. On the other hand, detailed analysis revealed 57 insertion, 61 deletion and 159 base substitution events in the entire chloroplast genome of O. nivara. Among substitutions, transversions were much higher than transitions with the former even more frequent than the latter in the coding region. Most of the insertions/deletions were single-base but a few large length mutations were also detected. The frequency of insertion/deletion events was more in the coding region within inverted repeats. In contrast, a very few substitution events were identified in the coding region. Polymorphism was observed among rice cultivars at loci of large insertion/deletion events. This is the first report describing comparative and genome wide chloroplast analysis between a wild and cultivated crop.
Manual Tags: Chloroplast; Comparative genome; Oryza nivara; perennial W/1 (oryza OR rice); ScienceDirect; search.rice; SPV; Wild rice

Author: GARRET, S. D.
Title: The control of take-all under intensive cereal cultivation
Abstract Note: Economic conditions at various times since the earyl nineteen-thirties have been such that it has not been feasible to follow the well tested crop rotations which have proven successful in control of the take-all disease (Ophiobolus graminis) of cereals. Further research work, carried out at the Rothamsted Expt. Station and elsewhere showed that a substantial increase in the current rates of N applications for spring sown wheat and barley, and for the early spring topdressing of winter wheat, would aid materially in reducing losses from this disease. Another method of control, called the Chamberlain system, consisted of sowing trefoil (Medicago bysulina) and Italian rye grass along with the barley. After the barley is harvested, the trefoil utilizes the available nitrogen in the soil and thereby helps starve out the causal organism. Plowing under the straw left by the combine is considered helpful provided additional nitrogen is used at time of sowing the succeeding crop. In conclusion, the author points out the necessity of keeping the land free of perennial grass weeds which may harbor the fungus. || ABSTRACT AUTHORS: T. J. Nugent
Manual Tags: search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); WOS

Author: Boeken, G. B.
Title: The control of wild rice in Senegal.
Publication Title: Bulletin des Recherches Agronomiques de Gembloux
Abstract Note: In trials in Senegal river delta rice paddy fields, dalapon at 15-22.5 kg/ha gave satisfactory control of perennial red rice (Oryza longistaminata) on fallow land, and a rate of 7.5 kg/ha controlled annual red rice (O. barthii). See WA 19, 795 for nomenclature of wild rices.
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: SOKOLOVA, S. M.
Title: The conversion of nitrogenous substances in perennial wheat
Publication Title: Byul Mosk Obshch Ispytat Prirody Otd Biol
Abstract Note: Triticum agropyrotriticum perenne, a hybrid derived from crossing Lutescens 329, a winter wheat, with Agropyron glaucum, was analyzed at various growth phases for total N, amine N, and protein N in leaves and grain. Data obtained by means of microanalysis, precipitation with trichloracetic acid, and paper chro-matography indicate that the hybrid leaves have the highest total N content in early phases and that N content decreases by 75% by the milk ripe stage. Protein N decreases at the same rate, while non-protein N decreases by 50%. A 50% drop in amino-acid N occurs at the time of flowering. In the grain total protein changes from 3.25% of absolute dry weight at the milk ripe stage to 2.94% at the wax ripe stage, to 2.97% at full ripeness; corresponding figures for non-protein N are 0.48%, 0.45%, and 0.32%, and for protein N, 2.77%, 2.49%, and 2.67%. In the process of ripening the amino-acid content changes in quality and quantity; the maximum occurs at the milk ripe stage. Perennial wheat contains more gliadin and glutelin and less globulin than other wheat hybrids. A bibliography of 12 titles is included. || ABSTRACT AUTHORS: M. J. Hall
Manual Tags: search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); WOS

Author: Leiferman, Kristin M.; Gleich, Gerald J.
Title: The cross-reactivity of IgE antibodies with pollen allergens: I. Analyses of various species of grass pollens
Publication Title: Journal of Allergy and Clinical Immunology
Abstract Note: Atopic patients with histories of grass pollen allergy often are sensitive to a variety of species of grasses. Using a serum pool from patients sensitive to June grass, we analyzed the reactivity of IgE antibodies to seven grasses by the radioallergosorbent test. Extracts were analyzed for their inhibitory activities with solid-phase allergens prepared from all of the grass pollens. Also samples of serum were exhaustively absorbed with solid-phase allergens and the supernatants tested to determine the reactivity of the remaining IgE antibodies. Three patterns of reactivity were observed: (1) June, orchard, meadow fescue, and perennial rye grasses displayed similar reactivity in both inhibition and absorption studies; (2) sweet vernal and Bermuda grasses were considerably less reactive with the serum pool, indicating that they lacked antigenic determinants possessed by the other grasses; and (3) timothy grass possessed unique antigenic determinants. Knowledge of these patterns of cross-allergenicity is of importance for diagnosis and treatment of sensitive patients as well as for in vitro standardization of extracts.
Journal Abbreviation: Journal of Allergy and Clinical Immunology
Manual Tags: perennial W/1 ("rye" OR secale) AND NOT ("rye?grass" OR "ryegrass"); ScienceDirect; Scopus; search.rye; SPV; TITLE-ABS-KEY (perennial W/1 ("rye" OR secale) AND NOT ("rye?grass" OR ryegrass)) AND DOCTYPE (ar); TS=(perennial NEAR/1 ("rye" OR secale) NOT "rye$grass"); WOS

Author: Hill, R.D.
Title: The cultivation of perennial rice, an early phase in Southeast Asian agriculture?
Abstract Note: Domesticated rice, Oryza sativa L., though a perennial, is nowadays usually cultivated as an annual. This has led a number of commentators to misinterpret the historical record. The older view that rice was domesticated around the Bay of Bengal and in parts of mainland Southeast Asia has been replaced by competing views of earliest domestication in that region and in the Yangzi valley. Botanical considerations point clearly to the retention of perennial characteristics while archaeological and historical evidences point to cultivation with more than a single harvest from an initial planting – the practice of ratooning. Evidence is reviewed briefly for China and more extensively for Southeast Asia. Modern field evidence is used to support the notion that ratooning was probably more widespread in the past and that this practice may represent an early phase in the history of rice agriculture in Southeast Asia as it does in China.
Manual Tags: Asian prehistory; History of early agriculture; Perennial crops; perennial W/1 (oryza OR rice); ratoon* W/5 (oryza OR rice); Rice cultivation; ScienceDirect; Scopus; search.rice; Southeast Asia; SPV; TITLE-ABS-KEY (perennial W/1 (oryza OR rice)) AND DOCTYPE (ar); TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (oryza OR rice)); WOS
