Author: NengPu, Shi
Title: The development of ratooning rice and its utilization.
Abstract Note: The benefits of ratoon cultivation of rice and the increased use of the technique were considered. In trials in 1992-96 yields of the main crop of early rice were 7.60-9.46 t/ha and the ratoon crop yielded 3.10-6.24 t/ha. Ratoon cultivation of intermediate rice and of hybrid rice were also considered.
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: Anonymous
Title: The divisions of Plant Industry and Breeding and of Plant Protection.
Abstract Note: At a joint meeting of the two divisions of the All-Union Lenin Academy of Agricultural Sciences on 26-27 March, 1970, N. V. Turbin reported that over 11, 000 items had been added to the world collections in the past year; some of the most interesting were listed. The achievements mentioned included the selection of perennial wheat lines; tetraploid carrots with larger roots; useful mutants of a number of crops; and the production of unproved cultivars of wheat, barley, maize, rice, tomato and subtropical fruits and nuts, the best of which are listed. S. I. Ibragimov, reporting on the Cotton Research Institute, mentioned a number of new cultivars produced, which included Surhan, an Egyptian cotton resistant to Fusarium, and several other wilt-resistant cultivars. V. F. Peresypkin, reporting on advances in plant protection, referred to wheats resistant to rust and potatoes to wart and blight, for use in breeding resistant varieties. Wheat cultivars have been shown to be mixed in respect of resistance to Puccinia recondita', race 77 attacks all cultivars but Avrora, Kavkaz and Il'ioevka; no standard Egyptian cotton is resistant to Verticillium and Fusarium wilts, the least affected being 6249V.
Manual Tags: search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); WOS

Author: FEDEROV, A. K.
Title: The duration of the vernalization stage in winter wheat under field conditions [English summ.]
Abstract Note: When wheat was sowed at the optimal time in boxes in the greenhouse, the plants transferred after a certain time interval to open ground and allowed to grow under continuous illumination, it was established that under field conditions normal passage through the vernalization stage begins with the establishment of minimal temperatures of about 5[degree] and below and a mean daily temperature of 10[degree]C; the vernalization stage continues for several days less than with vernalization of the slightly covered seeds at a constant temperature of 0-2[degree]. It is probable that with winter plants in the fall, the vernalization stage takes place at temperatures above 5[degree] and is evidently shorter in green plants than in lightly covered seeds. At temperatures somewhat higher than 0-2[degree], with winter wheat and perennial plants (meadow fescue, red-top, smooth brome, orchard grass) on a short day, the vernalization stage is more quickly concluded than with a natural day, while with continuous illumination it continues for 1-3 months and longer.
Manual Tags: search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); WOS

Author: SKRIPCINSKII, V. V.
Title: The dying-off of vegetative organs of perennial and annual grasses at the time of seed ripening.
Abstract Note: The characteristic difference between annual and perennial plants, which is apparent at the time of seed ripening; is the complete dying-off of the vegetative organs in annuals and the preservation of these organs in perennials. In 1949, preliminary work was begun on the physiology of perishing in the vegetative organs in annual grasses. Two annuals (Hostianum 237 winter wheat, and Tarasanskaja winter rye), and 2 perennials (cultivated rye and wild rye, Secale anatolicum) were grown. The leaf lamina, leaf sheath and internodes were studied in regard to changes in vitality and water content (estimated, visually, by change in colour from green to yellow and by relative turgidity) at different stages of seed ripening, namely, 14 June (beginning of seed setting), 3 July (wax ripeness), 11 July (full ripeness), and 4 August (over-ripeness). For economy of space the data obtained are given (in tables) only for Hostianum 237 and wild rye. The figures are discussed in relation to the transfer of nutrient substances from the vegetative organs to the seeds, with special reference to the fact that the perennials are reproduced by seeds and by vegetative reproduction, whereas the annuals are reproduced by seeds only. Dying-off in perennials is characterized by two phases of perishing in the leaves. The first coincides with the onset of seed setting and takes place in the lowest leaves of the stem, proceeding (as in annuals) from the base upwards; the second coincides with seed filling and ripening, but starts in the upper leaves, and proceeds downwards. It is concluded that this characteristic of the perennials may be useful in selection studies.-M.H.
Manual Tags: search.rye; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 ("rye" OR secale) NOT "rye$grass"); WOS

Author: V, SHLYAKOVA E.
Title: THE ECOLOGICAL BIOLOGICAL SPECTRUM OF FIELD WEEDS OF THE KOSTROMA OBLAST RUSSIAN-SFSR USSR
Abstract Note: A survey was made of the species composittion and ecology of field weeds in the Kostroma Oblast (Russian SFSR, USSR) with examination of 150 fields in 13 collective farms. Of 95 spp. registered in the winter period in wheat, rye and perennial hay fields, 47 spp. were perennials of which 5 spp. were chamaephytes, 37 were hemicryptophytes and 5 were geophytes. Other types present were hemitherophytes (4 spp.), therophytes (40 spp.) and hemicryptophyte-therophytes (4 ssp.). A table is presented of 39 spp. of field weeds (therophytes) present in the winter period. Examples of plasticity characteristic for weeds are provided by the group of species which in the subzones of mixed and broadleaved forests are capable of developing as therophytes in spring and winter cultures and as hemicryptophytes in perennial grasses (Barbarea vulgaris, Melandrium album). This group of weeds is conditionally designated hemicryptophyte-therophytes, and includes all hemicryptophytes capable of manifesting annual forms in the given vegetative zone.
Manual Tags: search.rye; search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 ("rye" OR secale) NOT "rye$grass"); TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); WOS

Author: VYSHINSKII, A. M.
Title: The effectiveness of, and the possibility of replacing superphosphate by, phosphorite meal in Polesia, Ukrainian SSR.
Abstract Note: Phosphorite meal (45 kg/ha P 2O 5) applied in autumn under the plough and followed by super (15 kg/ha P 2O 5) applied at the spring cultivation preceding sowing, increased straw and seed yield of flax as much as did super alone. Fibre quality was also improved. Phosphorite meal was as effective as super in increasing winter rye, winter wheat, barley, perennial herbage and potato yields.
Manual Tags: search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); WOS

Author: A, GAWRONSKA-KULESZA; I, SUWARA
Title: THE EFFECT OF A LAND USE SYSTEM ON THE GRANULAR STRUCTURE OF SOIL
Abstract Note: The authors of this paper discussed the results concerning the influence of cultivation of spring wheat after perennial grasses, winter wheat in 5-year crop rotation, and maize monoculture on soil structure. The soil from plot in which spring wheat was cultivated after perennial grasses was charcterized by the best structure. The stability of crumbs at a given time depended on the plants cultivated. Under maize the stability of aggregates was observed to increase from June to August, but the least stable crumbs were under winter wheat.
Manual Tags: search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); WOS

Author: Gawronska-Kulesza, A.; Suwara, I.
Title: The effect of a land use system on the granular structure of soil.
Abstract Note: The effects of cultivation of spring wheat after perennial grasses, winter wheat in 5-year crop rotation, and maize monoculture on soil structure were studied. The soil in which spring wheat was cultivated after perennial grasses had the best structure. Ped stability at a given time was dependant on the plants cultivated. Under maize the stability of aggregates was observed to increase from June to August, but the least stable peds were under winter wheat.
Manual Tags: search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); WOS

Author: Hofgaard, I.S.; Ergon, Å.; Wanner, L.A.; Tronsmo, A.M.
Title: The effect of chitosan and Bion on resistance to pink snow mould in perennial ryegrass and winter wheat
Abstract Note: The effects of chitosan on resistance to pink snow mould (Microdochium nivale) were studied in young winter wheat (Triticum aestivum L.) and perennial ryegrass (Lolium perenne L.) under controlled environmental conditions. In perennial ryegrass, the putative defence activator Bion was also tested. Resistance was measured as regrowth of plants after inoculation with M. nivale and incubation in darkness at 2°C. In winter wheat, pre-treatment with chitosan at 1000 μg per plant increased resistance to subsequent infection by M. nivale, but this effect was less significant in a replicate experiment. Chitosan-treated winter wheat plants expressed the gene for the pathogenesis-related protein chitinase at higher levels than non-treated plants. Chitinase gene expression was also stimulated by M. nivale infection in winter wheat. Perennial ryegrass pre-treated with Bion or chitosan and inoculated with M. nivale did not display better regrowth after incubation than non-treated, inoculated plants. Rather, regrowth was reduced in some of the Bion-treated plants after incubation. We speculate that the cost or the mechanism of induced resistance makes Bion non-effective in plants that are not actively growing. Bion at concentrations of 10, 100 and 1000 μg active ingredient per ml, and the highest concentration of chitosan used (2000 μg per ml) reduced in vitro growth of the pathogen, suggesting that both defence activators possess antifungal activity.
Manual Tags: Benzo-(1,2,3) thiadiazole-7-carbothioic acid-S-methyl ester; Benzothiadiazole; Induced resistance; Lolium perenne; Scopus; search.wheat; SPV; TITLE-ABS-KEY (perennial W/1 (triticum OR wheat)) AND DOCTYPE (ar); Triticum aestivum; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); WOS

Author: Samson, B. T.; Zandstra, H. G.; Mabbayad, B. B.
Title: The effect of clipping portion of the rice panicles/leaves as a method of inducing ratoonability in rice.
Abstract Note: The sensitivity that ratooning showed to minor changes in harvest dates of the main crop and the response to lower temperatures led us to evaluate the effect of panicle and leaf clipping treatments to modify the source-sink ratio of the plant. In 1979 wet season, clipping experiments at IRRI using a randomized complete block design. Results showed that tillering increased from 10 to 14 per hill where half of each panicle was removed and reduced from 10 to 6 per hill where half of each leaf was removed. These effects were further confirmed in the following dry season trial, which also showed that late clipping of the panicles (at soft dough stage) may lessen the increase in ratooning. Plant analysis of the rice stubble (0 to 15 cm above ground level) and roots of the main crop at harvest showed that the number of ratoon tillers produced to significantly relate to % carbohydrate (anhydroglucose) content. These results indicate that ratooning ability is closely associated with the amount of carbohydrate left in the plant stubble at harvest.
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: TKACHEV, V. V.
Title: The effect of deep loosening on the physical properties of soil and crop yields.
Abstract Note: On clayey southern chernozems in the Rostov region a toothed harrow loosened the top 2-3 cm of soil under winter wheat and the top 0.5-1.5 cm under perennial herbage. A rotary hoe did not disturb the soil crust under perennial herbage and loosened the top 4-6 and 7-8 cm under winter wheat and summer wheat respectively. A soil loosener affected the top 8-12 cm under perennial herbage and the top 10-12 cm under winter and spring crops. Compared with shallow loosening, deep loosening improved soil structure, increased aeration and decreased the compaction and volume-weight of the soil. Deep loosening greatly reduced the formation of cracks on the soil surface. Evaporation was decreased by deep loosening but not by shallow loosening to 1-2 cm. Deep loosening to 8-12 cm improved the moisture regime of the soil compared with shallow loosening. Deep loosening improved the nutrient regime and the water permeability and destroyed the greatest number of weeds. Harrowing destroyed the greatest number of crop plants. Deepening the depth of loosening from 1-2 cm to 4-6 cm and 10-12 cm increased the yield of winter wheat. Deep loosening was most effective for winter wheat and perennial herbage when spring-summer rainfall was insufficient. Shallow loosening was ineffective. Surface cultivation decreased the yield of spring wheat in wet years.
Manual Tags: search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); WOS

Author: PAVLOVSKII, M. A.
Title: The effect of deep plowing on the soil-moisture content.
Abstract Note: In the first year after the deep plowing of a heavy, weakly podzolized, sod podzol, the total and useful content of water to 60 cm depth increased with plowing depth. The yields in NPK and NK plots varied closely with the soil-moisture content. On no-N plots in a wet year, yields fell sharply with deep plowing. Maximum yield occurred only with the simultaneous maximum provision of nutrients: deep plowing can show its greatest effect only under conditions of good husbandry. In the 2nd-3rd year after deep plowing, compaction increased and porosity decreased, but not to the level of the controls ploughed to 20 cm. In a dry summer, the top 50-cm of soil in the deep-plowed plots contained 6-14% more moisture, leading to better survival and recovery of crops. The extra moisture occurred largely in the sod layer at a depth of 20-50 cm. The greater porosity to a greater depth also probably favoured a greater condensation of atmospheric moisture within the soil. As reflected in yields of wheat, clover, perennial grasses and oats, the most favourable conditions occurred with plowing to 40-45 cm, with the sod layer placed at 30-35 cm and mixed with the illuvial horizon (B 1 and A 2B).
Manual Tags: search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); WOS

Author: BABTLETT, S.; HENBY, K. M.; KON, S. K.; OSBOBNE, L. W.; THOMPSON, S. Y.; TINSLEV, J.
Title: The effect of different methods of drying on the biological value and digestibility of the proteins and on the carotene content of grass.
Abstract Note: The grass investigated came from a first class permanent sward, consisting largely of perennial rye grasp and wild white clover. The biological values, determined by Mitchell's balance sheet method with young rats, for the total nitrogen of samples of the same batch of grass dried in different ways were: artificially dried at about 300° F. for 15 to 30 minutes 67, artificially dried at about 170° F. for 50 to 70 minutes 62, made into sun-cured hay 52. The corresponding true digestibilities were: 66, 65 and 64. Statistical examination showed that the only significant differences lay between the biological values of the two samples of artificially dried grass and that of the hay. Carotene was estimated by the method of Ferguson and Bishop (Abst. 3100, Vol. 6) in the fresh grass, in the above dried samples and in two other samples, one dried in a current of hot air at about 135° F. for 22 hours, and the other made into hay indoors at air temperature. With the value for the fresh grass as 100 the following relative values were obtained: artificially dried at high temperature 87, at low temperature 78, in hot air 89, sun-cured hay 25, hay made indoors 32. During the sun-curing of grass it was found that there were losses of 23, 46 and 79 per cent, of the carotene content during 24, 48 and 96 hours, respectively. M. A. B. Fixsen.
Manual Tags: search.rye; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 ("rye" OR secale) NOT "rye$grass"); WOS

Author: Samson, B. T.; Zandstra, H. G.; Mabbayad, B. B.
Title: The effect of different temperature regimes on the ratoonability of two IRRI rice varieties.
Abstract Note: Experimental results in 1978 have shown that exceptionally good ratoon crop yields at the International Rice Research Institute (IRRI) reached 2.0 to 3.2 t/ha in replicated small plot trials using 13 rice varieties tested under three different water regimes. Further trials in 1979 dry season using the same varieties proved disappointing. High temperature (35°C daily maximum) and solar radiation (600 g-cal/cm 2/day) around harvest time appeared to be the cause of high percentage of missing hills (89%) thus, low yields. These trials also showed ratooning (tillers per hill) and ratoon yields to be unstable. To test the effects of temperature we placed two rice varieties inside the IRRI phytotron glasshouse rooms using a randomized complete block design. After the plant crop harvest, pots exposed to low temperature formed twice the number of ratoon tillers than those of normal and high temperature. Ratoon grain yields were very low in the 20/20°C regime because of sterility. These results indicate that ratooning ability may be associated with the amount of carbohydrate left in the stubble and roots of the main crop at harvest Plant analysis of the ratooned hills at harvest should be done to determine the total amount of % carbohydrate (anhydroglucose) content.
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: ATLAVINITE, O. P.; PAYARSKAITE, A. I.
Title: The effect of erosion on earthworms (Lumbricidae) during the growing season [English summ.]
Abstract Note: In 1961 the authors studied the effect of erosion upon earthworms (Lumbricidae) under different crops on a plot (1080 m2) on a hill slope (6-9[degree]). The downflow of water and carrying away of soil together with a certain number of earthworms took place only during strong rains. The amount of eroded soil and the number of earthworms varied in each plot and depended upon the vegetation. The maximum erosion was observed in fallow soil (9633.3 dm3 of water, 859.829 kg of absolutely dry soil, 2665 specimens of earthworms weighing 1.171 kg) and in soil under barley (616.1 dm3 of water, 14.319 kg of absolutely dry soil, 1498 specimens of earthworms, their weight being 0.791 kg). The minimum erosion was observed under natural vegetation (245.3 dm3 of water 9.115 kg of absolutely dry soil, 1550 specimens of earthworms, their weight being 0.840 kg) and under rye with perennial grasses (302.3 liters of water, 11.083 kg of absolutely dry soil, 2993 specimens of earthworms, with a weight of 1.751 kg). || ABSTRACT AUTHORS: Authors

Author: Lisova, R.; Greimas, G.; Tripolskaja, L.
Title: The effect of fertilization systems on the spread of fungal diseases in cereal crops for different crop rotations and preceding crops.
Publication Title: Lietuvos Zemdirbystes Instituto Mokslo Darbai, Zemdirbyste
Abstract Note: Field trials were conducted during 1985-1990 in cereal (winter rye, barley and oat) rotations at the Voke branch of the Lithuanian Institute of Agriculture. Winter rye cv. Kustro was sown in the field crop rotation after perennial grasses and winter rye. Rye after perennial grasses in the field and in the cereal crop rotations was fertilized with nitrogen fertilizers (N 90-120), in the field crop rotation after annual grasses with manure (21 and 42 t/ha) and P 100K 200 together and with mineral fertilizers (N 90P 100-136K 200-297) alone. Author: Lisova, R.; Greimas, G.
Title: The effect of fertilizers on the spread of fungal diseases on winter rye.
Abstract Note: These investigations were conducted during 1991-96 in Lithuania in a field with sandy loam soil using the winter rye cultivar Verasen. Seeds were sown in a field crop rotation after perennial grasses and after annual grasses. After perennial grasses, rye was fertilized with N (N 90-120), after annual grasses it was fertilized with manure (21 and 42 t/ha) and P 100 + K 200 and with mineral fertilizers (N 90 P 100-136 K 200-297). N and mineral fertilizers increased the development of Erysiphe graminis, Puccinia dispersa [ P. recondita], P. graminis, Pseudocercosporella herpotrichoides and common root rot ( Fusarium sp. and Helminthosporium sp.). An increase in N fertilizer from N 90 to N 120 had no significant influence on the diseases. When annual grasses were used as a preceding crop, the fungal diseases increased. Winter rye was most severely affected by Rhynchosporium secalis.
Manual Tags: search.rye; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 ("rye" OR secale) NOT "rye$grass"); WOS

Author: GIRKO, P. A.; KAPLUN, A. L.; KUZHEL', A. I.
Title: The effect of fertilizers on the yield and quality of winter wheat
Publication Title: Nauchn Tr Ukr S Kh Akad
Abstract Note: At the farm of the Ukrainian Academy a comparison was made in 1953-1954 of the yields and quality of winter wheat grain growth on a vetch and oat fallow (VOF) and on a cover of perennial grasses (G) both with and without fertilization. The wheat yield without fertilizer in 1953 totalled on VOF 18.6 and on G[long dash]13.9, while in 1954 it was 16.2 and 16.0 centners/ha. The wheat yield with fertilizer increased on the VOF in 1953 by 3.8 and 5.1, in 1954 by 0.9 and 6.7 and on G in 1953 by 2.1, in 1954 by 1.5 centners/ha. When the wheat was planted on G there was an increased content of P, K and protein in the grains. || ABSTRACT AUTHORS: Transl. from Referat. Zhur. Biol. 24957, 1958, courtesy OTS-JPRS
Manual Tags: search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); WOS

Author: VLASYUK, P. A.; DOBROTVORSKAYA, K. M.
Title: The effect of fertilizers on the yield and quality of winter wheat.
Abstract Note: Fertilizers did not improve yield when wheat followed bare fallow, except on a lighter soil where 10 tons/ha, of dung was the optimal rate. The highest response to fertilizers was obtained when wheat followed perennial herbage. Wheat grown after a fallow carrying a vetch-oats mixture had a low grain protein content unless N fertilizers were applied.
Manual Tags: search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); WOS

Author: Huang, Hsiang-Ching; Tsai, Yi-Fong; Huang, Shen-Ney
Title: The effect of hog manure application on the growth and yield of upland crops
Publication Title: Bulletin of Taichung District Agricultural Improvement Station
Abstract Note: Field trials were carried out at Changhua (slightly alkaline slate alluvial soil) and Taichung (strongly acidic red earth) under the sorghum-ratooned sorghum-corn cropping sequence during 1988-1991. Results showed that the application of hog manure 10 or 20 t/ha increased significantly the plant height, ear weight (or panicle weight), 1000-grain weight and grain yield of the test crops or two sites of experiment. The yield of fall corn response best to the treatment of hog manure 20 t/ha in combination with recommended chemical fertilizers. The spring sorghum and ratooned sorghum had a better grain yield under the application of hog manure 10 t/ha and chemical fertilizers. The hog manure application significantly increased the density of rooting system in the 30 cm depth of surface soil.
Manual Tags: search.sorghum; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 sorghum); WOS

Author: MILTON, W. E. J.
Title: The effect of irrigation on the palatability of certain grass and clover species grown in plots of pure species
Abstract Note: The soil of the exptl. area was an acid podsol derived from a heavy substratum of Silurian shale, and the plants used were 5 grasses (perennial rye, cocksfoot, timothy) bred at the Welsh Plant Breeding Station, a commercial broad red clover, and a wild white clover. 8 replications of each species and strain were sown, and arranged so that 4 occurred on each section. After sowing, eaeh plot received 63/4 cwt. per acre of N. African phosphate. Irrigation water was run on for about a fortnight before each grazing. Grazing was done by sheep 7 times in 1936 and once in 1937. Relative growth was assessed before each grazing and the amt. of grass eaten after each grazing. Irrigation increased the growth and palatability of the herbage throughout, but different spp. responded to different extents, the response of cocksfoot being least. A wet winter and spring did not lessen the effects of irrigation. Generally, there was a distinct tendency for differences in palatability to be minimized by irrigation. Density of herbage was increased, but the spp. and strains reacted differently in respect to numbers of tillers. || ABSTRACT AUTHORS: E. H. Tripp

Author: Shtikans, Yu A.; Kazhotsin'sh, B. E.
Title: The effect of lime and mineral fertilizers on nutrient losses associated with the drainage of dernopodzolic soil.
Abstract Note: A study was carried out from 1982-90 on an experimental drainage installation on a reclaimed dernopodzolic gleyed medium loam in Latvia. Lime (Ca) was applied at rates of 0, 0.5, 1.0 and 2.0 of hydrolytic activity and four levels of fertilizer application, where F 0 = no fertilizer, F 1 = 45 + 30 + 45 N + P + K, F 2 = 2 * F 1, and F 3 = 3 * F 1. Fertilizers were applied annually in the form of ammonium nitrate, simple granulated superphosphate and potassium chloride. The field crop rotation included winter rye, barley, perennial grasses, potatoes and oats. It was concluded that: (1) drainage of excessively wet dernopodzolic soils promotes the leaching of Ca, Mg and other plant nutrients; (2) with an annual drainage runoff of 118 mm and the addition of lime and fertilizer, Ca and Mg were leached at the following rates:

Author: Mobasser, H. R.; Rostaei, K.; Alamdari, M. Q.
Title: The effect of main crop harvesting time on rice-ratoon and berseem clover ( Trifolium alexanderinum L.) yield as intercropping system.
Publication Title: International Journal of Agronomy and Plant Production
Abstract Note: To determine the effect of main crop harvesting time on rice ratoon and berseem clover yield as intercropping system, the experiment was conducted out as split plot in randomized complete block design with three replications in Northern Iran at 2010. Main crop harvesting time of rice has been chosen as main plot at four levels; 19 and 26 August, and 2 and 9 September. The kind of cultivation has been also chosen as sub-plot at three levels; berseem clover cultivation, ratooning, and intercropping berseem clover with rice ratoon. The results showed that the total number of tillers and effective tillers per hill, the total number of spikelet per panicle and percentage of filled spikelet were significantly decreased by delaying harvesting time. The maximum grain yield and harvesting index were attained by earlier harvesting time at
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: Schoene, K; Franz, J.-Th; Masuch, G
Title: The effect of ozone on pollen development in Lolium perenne L.
Abstract Note: Perennial ryegrass plants (Lolium perenne L.) were exposed in “Closed-Top Chambers” to different ozone concentrations and to charcoal filtered ambient air to study the effect of ozone on the development of pollen. Ozone at ambient (65 nl l−1, 8 h) and elevated (110 nl l−1, 4 h) concentrations affected the maturing of pollen by inhibiting starch accumulation in pollen throughout the anther. Affected pollen persisted in the vacuolated state while normal pollen in the same anther were filled with amyloplasts. The percentage of underdeveloped pollen—determined in transversal sections—was significantly higher in exposed plants than in plants grown in filtered air. Results indicate that ozone stress was responsible for the disrupted development of pollen in L. perenne.
Manual Tags: Lolium perenne; Ozone; perennial W/1 (oryza OR rice); Pollen development; ScienceDirect; search.rice; SPV

Author: SEGETA, V.; KODYTEK, K.
Title: The effect of root matter development of winter wheat and some perennial fodder crops on the vertical movement of soil during winter.
Publication Title: Sbornik Ceskoslovenske Akademie Zemedelskych Ved. Rada C. Rostlinna   Vyroba
Abstract Note: In pot and plot experiments the vertical movement of soil under wheat, perennial ryegrass, creeping fescue, red clover and lucerne was determined during 2 winters. Maximum heaving relative to that of bare soil and the total heaving decreased as the root mass at the beginning of winter increased. The relationship was non-linear and there was some variability in the effect of different crops.
Manual Tags: search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); WOS

Author: Meharg, A.A.; Killham, K.
Title: The effect of soil pH on rhizosphere carbon flow of Lolium perenne
Abstract Note: Perennial rye-grass plants were grown at 15°C in microcosms containing soil sampled from field plots that had been maintained at constant pH for the last 30 years. Six soil pH values were tested in the experiment, with pH ranging from 4.3-6.5. After 3 weeks growth in the microcosms, plant shoots were exposed to a pulse of 14C-CO2. The fate of this label was determined by monitoring 14C-CO2 respired by the plant roots/soil and by the shoots. The 14C remaining in plant roots and shoots was determined when the plants were harvested 7 days after receiving the pulse label. The amount of 14C (expressed as a percentage of the total 14C fixed by the plant) lost from the plant roots increased from 12.3 to 30.6% with increasing soil pH from 4.3 to 6. Although a greater percentage of the fixed 14C was respired by the root/soil as soil pH increased, plant biomass was greater with increasing soil pH. Possible reasons for observed changes in the pattern of 14C distribution are discussed and, it is suggested that changes in the soil microbial biomass and in plant nitrogen nutrition may, in particular be key factors which led to increased loss of carbon from plant roots with increasing soil pH.

Author: Smith, J.M.; Cook, S.K.; Mills, A.R.; Bacon, E.T.G.; Clarke, J.H.
Title: The effect of three or five years of set-aside on the husbandry and grain yield of subsequent cereal crops in the UK
Abstract Note: During the period 1993-1997, at six contrasting sites located throughout England, two successive cereal test crops were grown both with and without nitrogen fertiliser after three or five years of set-aside or after continuous arable cropping. Vegetation during set-aside included natural regeneration and perennial rye-grass (Lolium perenne) with or without white clover (Trifolium repens), managed by mowing on one or more occasions per year. Establishment of the successive cereal test crops after destruction of the set-aside was generally not a problem. Fertile tiller numbers were increased by inclusion of clover in the set-aside cover or application of inorganic nitrogen. The presence of couch grass (Elytrigia repens) or volunteer cereals in the set-aside covers provided alternative hosts for take-all (Gaeumanomyces graminis) and eyespot (Pseudocercosporella herpotrichoides) and take-all caused some yield reductions in following cereal crops. Management during the set-aside period significantly affected grain yields of the subsequent cereal crops in the majority of the site-year combinations. However, these effects were not as large as would be expected after traditional break crops and were frequently masked by the application of nitrogen fertiliser. Mean yields increased by 80% due to the application nitrogen at the optimum rate compared to nil nitrogen. Most of the effects of set-aside treatment on grain yield were shown to be attributable to soil mineral nitrogen content, but at some sites, infections by take-all or eyespot also accounted for some of the variation. There were no effects of pests that could be related to treatment. The presence of sown clover during the set-aside period had the most consistent effect across sites, affecting tiller populations, grain yield and grain quality of cereal crops. At some sites, establishing a sown cover during the set-aside period, or cutting the cover more than once a year, improved grain yield and quality, and reduced the incidence of some specific weeds and disease. Abbreviations: SMN - soil mineral nitrogen; N - Nitrogen.
Manual Tags: Cereal; Cereal quality; Cereal yields; Natural regeneration; Nitrogen; Nitrogen uptake; Rye-grass; Scopus; search.rye; Set-aside; SPV; TITLE-ABS-KEY (perennial W/1 ("rye" OR secale) AND NOT ("rye?grass" OR ryegrass)) AND DOCTYPE (ar); White clover

Author: Samson, B. T.; Zandstra, H. G.
Title: The effect of two temperature regimes on the ratoonability of some IRRI cultivars/experimental lines.
Abstract Note: Previous rice ratooning trials conducted at IRRI showed ratooning (tillers per hill) and ratoon yields to be unstable. High temperatures around harvest time appeared to be a possible cause for the high percentage of missing hills in the ratoon crops, thus low yields. In this experiment, we tested the effect of high temperature during flowering and maturation stages on rice ratoon yields. Eight IRRI cultivars and experimental lines were grown in the IRRI Phytotron under two temperature regimes 35/27C and 29/21C (day/night) using a randomized complete block design. While the number of tillers were greater in the high temperature regime, the sterility in the panicles were greater than for plants grown in the low temperature regime. Consequently, grain yields were approximately nine fold greater from plants grown in the cooler temperatures than for plants grown at the high temperatures. Plants were taller and maturity was earlier when grown in the hot room than the plants grown in the cooler room. The rice cultivars and experimental lines tested showed great yield differences to temperature both for the main crop and ratoon crop.
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: Ichii, M.
Title: The effect of water management on ratoon ability of rice plants.
Publication Title: Technical Bulletin of Faculty of Agriculture, Kagawa University
Abstract Note: In pot trials, ratoon production of rice cv. Yaeho cut at 10 days after heading to 5 cm ht. was similar (40-60%) to that of plants cut to ground level without flooding whereas there was little ratoon production in plants cut to ground level and flooded after cutting. In cv. Oseto, the number of ratoon tillers was >80% in plants cut to 5 cm ht. and was only slightly reduced by cutting to ground level without flooding, but was <10% in flooded plants cut to ground level. Ratoon ht. followed a similar trend. In a 2nd trial, ratoon number and ht. of rice cv. Koshihikari cut to 20 cm ht. on the 10th day after heading was not affected by irrigation or flooding treatments.

Author: Huang, H. C.; Tsai, Y. F.; Huang, S. N.
Title: The effects of application of pig manure on the growth and yield of upland crops.
Publication Title: Bulletin of Taichung District Agricultural Improvement Station
Abstract Note: In field trials at Changhua (slightly alkaline slate alluvial soil) and Taichung (strong acidic red earth) in 1988-91, 10 or 20 t pig manure/ha or chemical fertilizers at rates recommended for the individual crops or both pig manure and chemical fertilizer were applied to a sorghum/ratooned sorghum/maize cropping sequence. Pig manure either alone or with chemical fertilizer increased plant height, spike weight, 1000-grain weight and grain yields. In some cases the higher rate of pig manure was more effective than chemical fertilizer alone. Maize gave the best response to 20 t pig manure + chemical fertilizer, while sorghum and ratooned sorghum responded best to 10 t pig manure + chemical fertilizer. Pig manure increased root density of maize at a depth of 30 cm.

Author: Sparrow, A.H.; Schwemmer, Susan S.; Bottino, P.J.
Title: The effects of external gamma radiation from radioactive fallout on plants with special reference to crop production
Abstract Note: This paper describes the major problems involved in attempting to predict for economically useful plants the degree of radiation damage which would arise from exposure to high level radioactive fallout. Since almost no data exist on the deleterious effects inflicted on crops by actual fallout radiation, it is necessary to extrapolate from the existing radiobotanical data concerned with the effects of gamma radiation on survival and yield of plants. A number of factors can modify the effects of the radiation and, hence, influence the accuracy of predictions of postattack injury. The most important variables are (a) species differences in interphase chromosome volume (the larger this value the more sensitive the plant), (b) exposure rate (high rates are more effective than lower rates), (c) stage of development of the plant (a complex and difficult variable to assess), (d) postirradiation time (generally the longer the time the greater the degree of damage), and (e) numerous environmental factors such as moisture, temperature, light, competition, etc., which normally modify plant growth and yield. These factors acting singly or in various combinations can have a considerable effect on the radiation response and thereby make more difficult the prediction of postattack injury. Survival and yield data obtained from irradiation of growing plants are presented for many species. The most useful values in comparing sensitivities are LD10, LD50 and LD90 (exposures required to reduce survival by 10, 50 and 90 per cent), and the YD10, YD50 and YD90 (exposures required to reduce yield by 10, 50 and 90 per cent). A log—log regression of LD10 vs. YD50 for 36-hr FDS (fallout decay simulation) gamma exposures has a slope not significantly different from + 1, indicating that, in general, an exposure which produces an LD10 will reduce yield by 50 per cent. A prediction of other LD10 values may also be made from regressions of interphase chromosome volume on LD10. Predicted YD50 values following FDS exposures are given for 89 crop plants and for 82 woody plants for a 16-hr constant rate exposure. Using these predictions and the available radiobiological data some conclusions may be drawn concerning the vulnerability of crop plants to fallout radiation. The cereals, i.e. wheat, barley, oats and maize, which are probably our most important group of crop plants, would be the most sensitive with YD50 values ranging from about 1 to 4 kR (rice is much more resistant). The legumes, i.e. peas and beans, include both sensitive and resistant species with YD50s ranging from less than 1 to 12 kR. Root crops, i.e. onion, garlic, beet, potato and radish, have a wider range in sensitivity with YD50s between 1 and 16 kR. For pasture and forage crops the YD50 varies from 2 to 20 kR. Of the herbaceous crop species 70 per cent fall in the predicted sensitivity range between 4 and 16 kR. Woody species have a range of predicted LD50s between about 0·4 and 8 kR with the gymnosperms predominating below 2 kR. These predictions are for average conditions only and we still lack a significant amount of radiobiological data to make confident predictions of the expected response of many species to high level fallout gamma exposure. Also, inadequate information about beta radiation injury and its possible interaction with gamma radiation make extrapolation to actual fallout conditions even more difficult (see also Summary pp. 112–114).
Manual Tags: perennial W/1 (oryza OR rice); ScienceDirect; search.rice; SPV

Author: KHAR'KOV, D. V.
Title: The effects of prolonged application of manure and mineral fertilizers on the harvests of rotated crops Referat. Zhur., Biol, 1959, No. 5G276. (Translation)
Abstract Note: In field experiments started in 1931 in soddy podzolic heavy-loam soil the effects on the harvests and the properties of the soil of yearly applications 12 metric tons/ha of manure or of mineral fertilizers containing an equivalent amount of basic nutrient elements were studied. At the end of 25 years the humus content of the fields treated with mineral fertilizers was greater (1.57%) than that of the untreated control fields (1.48%) and less than that of the fields treated with manure (1.82%). The mineral fertilizers increased, and the manure decreased the acidity of the soil. The mineral fertilizers produced higher yields of winter rye than did the manure; and the yields of potatoes in fields treated with mineral fertilizers were somewhat higher than those in fields treated with manure. However, manure produced higher yields of fodder beets than did the mineral fertilizers, this is attributed to the acidifying effect of the mineral fertilizers on the soil. This effect also explains the higher yields of perennial grasses which were obtained by fertilization with manure. When the acidifying effects of the mineral fertilizers were corrected, they were more effective than manure.
Manual Tags: search.rye; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 ("rye" OR secale) NOT "rye$grass"); WOS

Author: Ivanyuk, V. G.; Aleksandrov, O. T.
Title: The efficiency of agrotechnics measures directed against rhizoctoniosis of potato
Abstract Note: The increasing of organic and mineral fertilizer's dose reduce significantly the development of Rh. solani (Rhizoctonia) placed on underground roots of potato. The best potato's predecessors from the phytosanitary are oats, barley, winter rye, winter wheat, maize, perennial grasses, flax, winter rape. To reduce the influence of potato's rhizoctoniose its tubers planting should perform for 6-8 centimetres of depth in the first decade of May (central zone of Belarus). It is worthwhile to increase the depth of planting up to 12-20 cm to receive the seed kinds which are free of photogene's sclerocia. The optimal density of planting is 50 thous. plants per ha using seed potato tubers in 71-90 gr. with poor degree (1 ball) of sclerocia Rh. solani. Herbicides application such as: zenkor, rejser, raundap, targa, topogard does not influence significantly to rhizoctoniose development.
Manual Tags: search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); WOS

Author: Vaughan, Duncan A.; Lu, Bao-Rong; Tomooka, Norihiko
Title: The evolving story of rice evolution
Abstract Note: Recent research related to evolution in the primary gene pool of rice, which consists of Oryza species with the A-genome, provides new perspectives related to current and past eco-genetic setting of rice and its wild relatives and fresh insights into rice domestication. In Asia the traits of the rice domestication syndrome are many but due to the remarkable diversification of rice and introgression with wild rice, few traits are consistently different between wild and domesticated rice. Reduced shattering and reduced dormancy are the principal traits of domestication in rice. Using the principal criteria for distinguishing single and multiple origins of crops, recent key research results do not support a polyphyletic origin of domesticated rice in distinctly different geographic regions. While domestication is a long-term process and continues today, a single event during domestication, the selection of the non-shattering sh4 allele, resulted in rice becoming a species dependent on humans for survival - domesticated. Here the apparent contradictions between a single origin of Asian rice and deep genetic divisions seen in rice germplasm are resolved based on a hypothesis of cycles of introgression, selection and diversification from non-shattering domesticated rice, importantly in the initial stages in its center of origin in the region of the Yangtze river valley, and subsequently beyond, as domesticated rice spread. The evolution of African rice differs from Asian rice mainly in the more restricted gene pool of wild rice from which it was domesticated, ecological diversification rather than eco-geographic diversification, and historic introgression from the Asian rice gene pool. The genetics of post-domestication evolution in Asian rice is well illustrated by changes at the waxy locus. For both Asian and African rice becoming domesticated was a single event, it was the subsequent evolution that led to their genetic complexity.
Manual Tags: Domestication; Genetic resources; Oryza; perennial W/1 (oryza OR rice); ratoon* W/5 (oryza OR rice); ScienceDirect; search.rice; SPV; Waxy gene; Wild rice

Author: Shi, Zuliang; Jing, Qi; Cai, Jian; Jiang, Dong; Cao, Weixing; Dai, Tingbo
Title: The fates of 15N fertilizer in relation to root distributions of winter wheat under different N splits
Abstract Note: To optimize the nitrogen fertilizer management for high yield wheat production, field experiments were conducted to investigate the effects of nitrogen (N) splits on root growth, the fates of 15N fertilizer (recovery, residual, and loss), and grain yield in winter wheat (Triticum aestivum L.) from 2007 to 2009. The experiment site locates in the Middle and Lower Yangtze River Basin with frequent rainfall and higher groundwater table in China. 15N micro-plot experiment was designed with three N ratios of basal to topdressing as 30–70%, 50–50% and 70–30% at rate of 225 kg N ha−1, respectively. The results showed that root weight density increased with increasing share of basal N fertilizer before jointing. After jointing, root weight density in the 0–40 cm soil layer was the highest under an half N as topdressing. The fates of basal and top-dressed N showed significant differences. On average, the recovery and residual for top-dressed N were higher than those for basal N, whereas loss was lower. Moreover, the loss of basal N mainly occurred before jointing and contributed more to total N loss. Two years of data showed that half of N as basal fertilizer and half as top-dressing gave better root growth and increased plant N uptake and soil residual 15N, resulting in reduced loss of fertilizer 15N and hence improved grain yield.
Manual Tags: Grain yield; N loss; N recovery; N uptake; perennial W/1 (oryza OR rice); Residual N; Root density; ScienceDirect; search.rice; SPV

Author: BADULINA, A. V.
Title: The grain-leaf sawfly (Pachynematus clitellatus) in Kazakhstan Referat. Zhur., Biol., 1962, No. 6Zh247. (Translation)
Abstract Note: On virgin lands of Akmolinsk raion the grain sawfly P. clitellatus has become a serious pest of spring wheat. The flight of this sawfly begins early in May. The mature insects hide in leaves. The female deposits one egg at a vein. The larva has a powerful mouth apparatus and a strong, chitinous head. The older larvae are bright green with white longitudinal bands and are 25 mm long. The larvae live free and have 6 stages; they feed 24 hours a day on perennial grains and sedge grain vegetation and for 3-4 weeks[long dash]during the period of tillering, shooting, and spiking[long dash]they feed on spring wheat. The larvae pupate in the soil at depths of 3-7 cm where they weave a thick cocoon in which they pass the diapause until spring of the following year. A part of the larvae remain in the diapause until the second year. This pest develops in 1 generation on spring wheat, but in 2 generations on perennial grains.
Manual Tags: search.grain; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 grain); WOS

Author: MURAV'EV, P. A.
Title: The grain quality of certain annual Triticum Agropyron hybrids of N. V. Tzitzin and of A. I. Derzavin's perennial wheat.
Abstract Note: The grain properties of a number of the annual hybrids are described. Some of them are of good quality, but their bread is not superior to that from the best standard wheat varieties. The perennial hybrid produced bread of inferior quality, though excellent in flavour.

Title: The green-pea tree.

Author: Scholz, V.; Ellerbrock, R.
Title: The growth productivity, and environmental impact of the cultivation of energy crops on sandy soil in Germany
Abstract Note: Energy plants, cultivated on set-aside land, could substitute nearly 3% of the primary energy in Germany and could raise the income of farmers. However, the substitution of fossil fuels by plants requires the selection of plant species with high site suitability, an ecologically benign farming system and high yields. This paper describes results of the cultivation of 10 energy plant species suitable for combustion. Over a period of 6 yr, yield, energy gain, and environmentally relevant substances in the plant and the soil were determined under practical conditions. Fertilization was carried out in four variants each ranging from 0 to 150 kg N ha(-1) and with wood- and straw ashes, as well as basic mineral fertilizer. Plant protection products were entirely dispensed with. The results show that, except for topinambur haulm (Jerusalem artichoke) and short rotation coppice with undersown crops, the mean yield ranges between 8 and 12 t(DM) ha(-1) and that a reduction of nitrogen application from 150 to 75 kg N ha(-1) causes only slight yield losses. Without fertilization, yields diminish by 20-40% after 6 years, except for poplars, which reach similarly a high yield level as with fertilization. The contents of the emission- and combustion-relevant plant nutrients, such as nitrogen, potassium, sulfur and chlorine, are significantly lower in poplars and willows than in grass, rye, triticale and hemp. Heavy metals, such as cadmium, copper, zinc, and lead, are absorbed differently. Hemp, poplars, and winter rye allow high-energy yields to be achieved. Even if nitrogen fertilization is reduced, net energy gains of more than 120 GJ ha(-1) yr(-1) (3.2 kl oil equivalent ha(-1) yr(-1)) are reached.
Manual Tags: search.rye; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 ("rye" OR secale) NOT "rye$grass"); WOS

Author: TlMOFEEVA-TJULINA, M. T.
Title: The hardiness of evergrowing (perennial) wheat.
Abstract Note: The difficulties of training perennial wheats 2 and 3 for hardiness are discussed; they prefer the foreign pollen of wheat or Agropyron to self pollen with the result that they lose the perennial habit or the desirable characters of wheat, respectively.

Author: GEL'TSER, F. YU
Title: The herbaceous structure and the process of soil formation
Abstract Note: Grains (oats, winter rye, corn), perennial grases (timothy, fescue, clover), strawberry, and iris were sown in concrete lysimeters filled with loam. For two years all the plants were fertilized with mineral fertilizers (NPK), and the annual crops were removed. In the control lysimeter, ground parts of these crops was removed. In the control lysimeter, which had no plants in it, diatoms, green algae, and blue-green algae were grown for the three years of the experiment; their density was 71,000/gram, and the increase in humus was 30 grams. Under the annual crops 56 grams of humus accumulated, and 112-154 grams accumulated under the perennial ones. The nitrogen increase in the control lysimeter was insignificant [long dash]0.004%. Even when this amount is deducted, the annual plants accumulated 3.6 grams more than the lysimeter, and the perennial ones [long dash]9.2 to 20.3 grams, i.e. between 3 and 6.7/year. The endomicorise which was abundantly developed in the roots of the iris and the perennial grasses, made it possible for the nitrogen to accumulate in significant quantities. Over the three years the irises accumulated 713-1022 g (dry weight) of roots while the perennial grases accumulated 270-306 g, the strawberry [long dash]136- . 234 g, and the corn [long dash]9 g. The perennial grasses and the irises, both of which have a sharply defined endotropic mycorrhiza, are able to enrich the loam with N and humus to a much greater extent than the annual plants which have weakly developed symbiotropic microorganisms, and this ensures intensive development of the process of soil formation under them. || ABSTRACT AUTHORS: Transl. from Referat. Zhur. Biol. 10452, 1958, courtesy OTS-JPRS
Manual Tags: search.rye; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 ("rye" OR secale) NOT "rye$grass"); WOS

Author: Chauhan, Y. S.; Venkataratnam, N.; Sheldrake, A. R.
Title: The high-yield potential of extra-early pigeonpeas in peninsular India.
Abstract Note: In field studies in 1982 the extra-early pigeonpea cv. ICPL 1, ICPL 81 and ICPL 87 were sown to give populations of 160 000, 260 000, 420 000 and 670 000 plants/ha on 15 June and 23 Aug. at the ICRISAT Center, peninsular India and on 18 June at Hissar, northern India. At the ICRISAT Center these cv. flowered and matured about 1 month earlier than at Hissar. 3 harvests could be taken with June sowing at ICRISAT, with cv. ICPL 4, ICPL 81 and ICPL 87 giving totals of 3060, 3870 and 5220 kg seed/ha, resp. 2 harvests were taken with Aug. sowing, giving totals of 1280, 1582 and 2270 kg/ha, resp. At Hissar only one harvest could be taken, giving 1970, 2350 and 2580 kg/ha, resp. Yields at ICRISAT were better than those usually obtained with medium-maturity cv. Substantial amounts of woody stalks were produced by the early cv., e.g. 4.5 t/ha by June-sown cv. ICPL 87. At Hissar the lower population densities of 160 000 and 260 000 plants/ha gave better yields than the higher ones. At ICRISAT Center, with Aug. sowing, the highest plant density gave the best yields. In the June sowing at ICRISAT, ICPL 4 and ICPL 81 gave more yield at the higher densities and ICPL 87 at the lower densities.
Manual Tags: search.pigeonpea; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (cajanus OR "pigeon$pea")); WOS

Author: ARENS, L. E.
Title: The history of the discovery of perennial rye in the North Caucasus.
Abstract Note: Perennial rye ( Secale kuprijanovii) was first found in the mountains of the Kuban' Province in 1870 and it is thought to be an escape of an ancient cultivation. It is now considered to be a valuable fodder grass and it was used in the USSR for crossing with cultivated rye to obtain perennial forms of the latter.-A.B.
Manual Tags: search.rye; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 ("rye" OR secale) NOT "rye$grass"); WOS

Author: Williams, C.T.; Okhidievbie, O.; Harris, K.M.; Ukwungwu, M.N.
Title: The host range, annual cycle and parasitoids of the African rice gall midge Orseolia oryzivora (Diptera: Cecidomyiidae) in central and southeast Nigeria
Abstract Note: Host range experiments and field sampling in Nigeria produced no evidence that African rice gall midge, Orseolia oryzivora Harris and Gagne, can develop on plants other than Oryza species. Sampling in three outbreak areas during 1994 showed that the insect's annual cycle varied according to the agroecological zone and rice cropping pattern. In the humid forest zone, Orseolia oryzivora persisted through the short dry season on ratoons of cultivated rice Oryza sativa at a rainfed site and on dry season rice crops at an irrigated one. In contrast, at rainfed sites in the moist savannah zone the pest survived the longer dry season on the perennial wild rice O. longistaminata, while ratoons and volunteers of O. sativa provided 'bridges' between the wild host and wet season rice crops. Early in the wet season at rainfed sites, galls of Orseolia oryzivora were not found at high density on wild rice, ratoons or volunteers. The heavy infestations which developed by October resulted primarily from rapid multiplication on rice crops themselves during the wet season. At all 13 sites sampled, the large majority of galls were found on fallow or cropped rice fields, rather than in ditches, bunds or uncultivated wetland, irrespective of the time of year or the hosts involved. From gall dissections, the parasitoids Aprostocetus procerae (Risbec) and Platygaster diplosisae Risbec caused over 30% mortality at some sites by October but generally increased too late to prevent crop damage. Implications of the results for the management of Orseolia oryzivora are discussed.
Manual Tags: Scopus; search.rice; SPV; TITLE-ABS-KEY (perennial W/1 (oryza OR rice)) AND DOCTYPE (ar); TITLE-ABS-KEY (ratoon* W/5 (oryza OR rice)) AND DOCTYPE (ar); TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (oryza OR rice)); TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: BRAITHWAITE, D. P.
Title: The hydrocyanic acid content of perennial Kavirondo sorghum.
Abstract Note: B. determined the hydrocyanic acid content of young, maturing and mature perennial Kavirondo sorghum [a hybrid between Sorghum verticiflorum and S. niloticum] in Kenya, and of the aftermath resulting from cutting at various stages in the season. Mature sorghum was a safe feeding stuff, and young growth from seed, under moist conditions was unlikely to prove harmful. Young aftermath during the dry season, however, had a dangerously high HCN content, and the authors presumed that if young growth from seed were subjected to dry conditions it too might be dangerous, though they did not demonstrate this.-A.S.
Manual Tags: search.sorghum; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 sorghum); WOS

Author: O, OLORODE; R, BAQUAR S.
Title: THE HYPARRHENIA-INVOLUCRATA HYPARRHENIA-SUBPLUMOSA GRAMINEAE COMPLEX IN NIGERIA MORPHOLOGICAL AND CYTOLOGICAL CHARACTERIZATION
Publication Title: Botanical Journal of the Linnean Society
Abstract Note: H. involucrata Stapf is an annual with diploid, aneuploid, tetraploid and hexaploid chromosome races on a base of x = 10, while H. subplumosa Stapf is known to be tetraploid and perennial. The 2 spp. overlap considerably in their vegetative and floral attributes. While the floral characteristics (such as number of awns and sex of imperfect flowers) are fairly constant within H. involucrata, they are quite variable in H. subplumosa: the evolutionary significance of some of these variations is discussed. Some of the observations on size, variability and fertility of pollen grains are interpreted using data from chromosome numbers and meiotic behavior. Preliminary observations on the hybrids between a diploid race of H. involucrata and H. subplumosa indicate that the genomes of the 2 spp. are highly homologous and that perennial habit is a dominant trait controlled by a single gene.
Manual Tags: search.grain; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 grain); WOS

Author: Hendrix, S.G.; Patterson, R.; Zeiss, R.; Suszko, I.M.
Title: The immune response in humans and rabbits to monomeric and polymeric grass allergens
Abstract Note: The antigenicity of polymerized grass (PG) and monomer grass (MG) was studied. As compared with MG, PG produces a similar immunologic response in rabbits as demonstrated by a tanned red blood cell (TRBC) passive hemagglutination assay or by total serum binding of perennial rye grass Group I antigens (RGGI). Six patients with allergic rhinitis sensitive to several grass pollens received an average of 60,000 protein nitrogen units (PNU) of PG. The initial dose was 100 PNU and a maintenance dosage of 8500 PNU was obtained after six injections without systemic reactions in any of the patients. Serum binding of RGGI increased significantly in the PG-treated patients and this increase was quantitatively similar to that measured in a second group of six atopic patients previously treated for 1 year with a total of 100,000 PNU of a standard grass extract mixture. PG, like polymerized ragweed (PRW), has a reduced allerginicity while retaining immunogenicity. These data suggest that PG as compared to standard aqueous grass extract mixtures represents an improved form of immunotherapy for the atopic patient.
Manual Tags: Scopus; search.rye; SPV; TITLE-ABS-KEY (perennial W/1 ("rye" OR secale) AND NOT ("rye?grass" OR ryegrass)) AND DOCTYPE (ar)

Author: SKLJAR, V. N.
Title: The importance of grain colour in perennial rye.
Abstract Note: Yellow, green and brown grains occurred, sometimes all three in the same ear. Tabular data show 1000-grain weight and protein content to be highest in the green grains and lowest in the brown.
Manual Tags: search.rye; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 ("rye" OR secale) NOT "rye$grass"); WOS

Author: BUKHAR, L. E.; KOZLOV, V. M.
Title: The importance of peavine in fodder [English and Moldavian summ.]
Publication Title: Izvest Moldavsk Filiala Akad Nauk Sssr
Abstract Note: Peavine is an important component of green fodder, particularly in June-July when the 1st mowing of perennial grasses loses its freshness, and corn is not yet ready as green fodder; it is valuable in mixed and companion crops with corn, Sudan grass, sorghum, etc. In field crop rotation, peavine should be placed in an occupied fallow field or in a cultivated fallow after summer crops; in fodder rotation it should be placed in a field set aside for annual grasses. Peavine should be sown for seed at the earliest possible dates by solid drill sowing, at 100-120 kg/ha, placing the seeds down to 8 cm in light soils and 4-5 cm in heavy soils. Before sowing, seeds should be treated by hexa-chloranto control the sitona weevil. || ABSTRACT AUTHORS: Courtesy NSF (PL 83-480) 1963
Manual Tags: search.sorghum; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 sorghum); WOS

Author: CICIN, N. V.
Title: The importance of wide crossing in applied botany.
Abstract Note: Attention is called to the value of the wild species of fruit trees that occur on Soviet territory and the use that has been made of them as parents by Micurin and other Soviet breeders, some of the varieties produced in this way being named; these include hybrids of apple x pear, apple x quince, domestic pear x Pyrus ussuriensis, almond x peach, red x black currant and red currant x gooseberry in addition to the many Micurin varieties. Existing species have been resynthesized, for instance the domestic plum, and many new species created. By the use of suitable nutrient media it has been possible to raise mature plants from excised embryos of many cereal hybrids. Most of them give better sets of grain when pollinated with a distant species than with either of their parent species; thus the hybrid Triticum vulgare var. lutescens x Agropyron glaucum[Elymus hispidus] gave only 1.2% set with pollen of either parent but produced a large number of fertile hybrids when pollinated with Secale cereale. It is reported that Elymus giganteus and E. arenarius have now been crossed with wheat, barley and rye [cf. XXIX, 2419]. Some of the perennial Triticum x Agropyron hybrids give 3-4 cuts of hay, with a total yield of up to 100 c. hay per ha., per year, or, alternatively, a yield of grain plus 1-2 cuts of hay. Soft wheats with branched ears have also been produced.
Manual Tags: search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); WOS

Author: DeTemmerman, L.O.; Baeten, H.
Title: The influence of biomass increase, rain and wind on the concentration of airborne fluorides in perennial rye grass
Abstract Note: Perennial rye grass (Lolium perenne) grown in containers equipped with a semi-automatic watering system, was exposed to ambient fluorides for four weeks. The fluorides emitted by the pollution source, a phosphate fertilizer plant, were mainly in gaseous form. After exposure the containers were transported to a low ambient-fluoride level area. In some containers the evolution of the fluoride concentration in the grass was controlled at several time intervals. An exponential decrease in the fluoride concentration as a function of the time was found. The effect of rain was studied by using a rain simulator and the impact of wind by using a fan. The results clearly show the major importance of the studied climatic parameters in the fluoride release process. Washing the samples prior to analysis, indicated that this procedure always removes a part of the accumulated airborne fluorides, even after exposure to large amounts of artificial rain.
Manual Tags: Scopus; search.rye; SPV; TITLE-ABS-KEY (perennial W/1 ("rye" OR secale) AND NOT ("rye?grass" OR ryegrass)) AND DOCTYPE (ar)

Author: Warrington, I. J.; Mitchell, K. J.
Title: The influence of blue- and red-biased light spectra on the growth and development of plants.
Abstract Note: The various lighting systems used for studies of plant growth in controlled environment systems differed markedly in the proportions of blue and red waveband light emitted in the visible spectrum, depending both on the types of lamp chosen and on the proportions of each lamp type used. A series of new high-intensity lamp systems, which provided wide variations in blue:red waveband ratios were used to test, at different irradiance levels, the effects of these different light spectra on the growth of sorghum, soyabean, perennial ryegrass and white clover. The biased spectral treatments used resulted in marked differences in DM accumulation, affected the relative proportions of leaves and stems and influenced tiller and secondary stem development. Final shoot dry weight and plant height were increased approximately 2-fold and leaf area was increased 46% with sorghum under the red-biased compared with blue-biased conditions at the low irradiance level tested. Blue-biased conditions also enhanced the concentrations of amino acids (particularly aspartic and glutamic acids) and protein whereas, in contrast, red-biased sources increased the concentrations of soluble sugars and starch in the leaf tissue. The implications of these results to controlled-environment studies are discussed.
Manual Tags: search.sorghum; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 sorghum); WOS

Author: DUNCAN, RR; MOSS, RB
Title: THE INFLUENCE OF MATURITY ON SORGHUM GRAIN YIELDS WHEN RATOON CROPPING
Publication Title: Georgia Agricultural Experiment Station Research Report
