Author: Gawronska-Kulesza, A.; Suwara, I.
Title: The influence of plants on water resistance of aggregates of various dimensions.
Abstract Note: The effects of different cropping systems on the disintegration of particular aggregate sizes from a black earth topsoil were studied. These systems were: spring wheat following perennial grasses, 5-year crop rotation of winter wheat, and 5 years of maize (monoculture). The effect of sampling time on the disintegration of aggregates of size >10, 10-7, 7-5, 5-3, 3-1 mm was also determined. It was found that aggregate stability changed during crop growth, depending on the cropping system adopted and the time of sampling.
Manual Tags: search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); WOS

Author: Seskas, A.
Title: The influence of preceding crops on winter wheat yield analysis.
Publication Title: Dekoratyviuju ir sodo augalu sortimento, technologiju ir aplinkos   optimizavimas = Optimization of Ornamental and Garden Plant Assortment,   Technologies and Environment
Abstract Note: Aloyzas Seskas, a lecturer at the Kaunas University of Applied science, in 2009-2013 was performing an experiment on the influence off orecrop on winter wheat yield. The experiment was performed on the farm of farmer Antanas Isoda. The location of the farm is in the village of Piliuona, Kaunas region. The experiment is one agent or simple, because only one factor has been investigated, that is the influence of preceding crops on winter wheat harvest. This is a four version experiment with four repetitions which were arranged in a systematic way. The area of the field, where the experiment was performed, is 1 hectare and the area of a protective belt is 2 metres. The scheme of the four - version with the four repetitions is as follows: the 1st version's (test) forecrop is bare fallow; the 2nd version's forecrop is winter barley; the 3rd version's forecrop is perennial grass; the 4th version's forecrop is annual (lasting one year) grass. The experiment has lasted for three years and according to the results of production the conclusion is that the most suitable forecrop on growing winter wheat yield is the forecrop of annual grass, because the grain yield of the plants, which were grown after, was about 1t/ha richer than growing wheat after other forecrops.
Manual Tags: search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); WOS

Author: DUNCAN, RR; GARDNER, WA
Title: THE INFLUENCE OF RATOON CROPPING ON SWEET SORGHUM YIELD, SUGAR PRODUCTION, AND INSECT DAMAGE
Manual Tags: search.sorghum; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 sorghum); WOS

Author: Ennik, G.C.; Kort, J.; Luesink, B.
Title: The influence of soil disinfection with DD, certain components of DD and some other compounds with nematocidal activity on the growth of white clover
Abstract Note: In pots containing soil fumigated with DD before planting the growth of white clover was considerably better than in untreated pots. A similar effect was obtained both with cis- or trans-1,3-dichloropropene. Some other components of DD, including 1,2-dichloropropane, had no influence on clover growth in the concentration at which they occur in DD. Of the compounds not associated with DD, EN 18,133 and sugar showed a favourable effect on clover growth, but X 323 had no influence. In the untreated pots with poorly growing clover many roots had died. On the places where dead lateral roots had been attached many fungi were present in the tissue, especially Rhizoctonia sp. and Fusarium spp. These pots contained also more clover cyst nematodes and more springtails (Collembola). In one of the pot experiments poor growth could probably be attributed to an attack by the clover cyst nematode (Heterodera trifolii Goffart). The nematode level above which damage to the plants occurred was calculated at 1000-3000 eggs (larvae inclusive) per 100 ml of soil. In the other pot experiment, however, poor growth could not be explained by cyst nematodes only. In field experiments clover growth was promoted by soil fumigation with DD, also when only a few cyst nematodes were present. These observations increase the evidence that attack of white clover by pathogens is a complex phenomenon in which nematodes as well as fungi and perhaps insects too are involved. Apart from a small increase in growth at the beginning, soil fumigation with DD did not raise the yield of perennial rye grass.
Manual Tags: Scopus; search.rye; SPV; TITLE-ABS-KEY (perennial W/1 ("rye" OR secale) AND NOT ("rye?grass" OR ryegrass)) AND DOCTYPE (ar)

Author: DAVIDOVSKII, G. M.
Title: The interspecific interrelation of weeds and cultivated plants Referat. Zhur., Biol., 1962, No. 24G510. (Translation)
Publication Title: Izvest Akad Nauk Armyansk Ssr Biol Nauki
Abstract Note: With an increase in the sowing density of spring wheat from 500 to 1000 seeds/m2 with N60P60K60, the number of weeds decreased by 22%, the air-dry weight of the weeds decreased by 35%, and with N150P150K150 the respective figures were 25% and 44%. In a field crop rotation without fallow, there was better extermination of wild oats than in a crop rotation including fallow, perennial grasses, and spring grains. The author describes the interrelation of spring grains with wild cabbage, white charlock, bistort, goosefoot, Chenopodium album, and Italian bugloss, and that of winter crops with field pennycress, shepherd's purse, Conringia, thistle, and wild oats.
Manual Tags: search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); WOS

Author: Su, C. C.
Title: The introduction of ratoon cultivation of rice.
Abstract Note: In trials with ratooned rice, N, PK or NPK fertilizer was applied at the ratoon cut, 20 days later or at the young panicle stage. Grain yields with N were highest with the earliest application date and decreased with delay in application of N. With PK or NPK fertilizer the yields were the same with the 2 earlier application dates and decreased at the latest application date. The effects of herbicide applications were also investigated.
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: Motoriko, M. G.
Title: The Kazakh SSR.
Abstract Note: In the period 1970-71 alone, 48 new crop cultivars were released and over 100 are now undergoing trials. Cultivars receiving special mention include: the spring wheat Kzyl-bas [Red Top], which has contents of 17.4% protein and 40.4% moist gluten and a greater strength than Saratov 29; the lucerne Kokshe, which gives high yields of hay and seed in the north of the republic; the strong spring wheats Pirotriks 28, approved in 1972, Ural'skaya Yubileinaya [Urals Jubilee] and Priishimakaya 100 and the winter wheat Zhana-Zhulduz and Kazakhstan 50; the high-yielding, high-quality sugar beets Kazakhskii poligibrid 24 [Kazakh Polyhybrid 24] and Kazakhskii gibrid [Kazakh Hybrid]; and several cultivars of rice and perennial herbage crops, 30 of apple, pear and strawberry and over ten of vegetables, two of the apples and one pear having won international awards.
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: Abbasi, S.A; Abbasi, Naseema
Title: The likely adverse environmental impacts of renewable energy sources
Abstract Note: The global attention has always been focussed on the adverse environmental impacts of conventional energy sources. In contrast nonconventional energy sources, particularly the renewable ones, have enjoyed a ‘clean’ image vis a vis environmental impacts. The only major exception to this general trend has been large hydropower projects; experience has taught us that they can be disastrous for the environment. The belief now is that minihydel and microhydel projects are harmless alternatives. But are renewable energy sources really as benign as is widely believed? The present essay addresses this question in the background of Lovin's classical paradigm, which had postulated the hard (malignant) and soft (benign) energy concepts in the first place. It critically evaluates the environmental impacts of major renewable energy sources. It then comes up with the broad conclusion that renewable energy sources are not the panacea they are popularly perceived to be; indeed in some cases their adverse environmental impacts can be as strongly negative as the impacts of conventional energy sources. The paper also dwells on the steps we need to take so that we can utilize renewable energy sources without facing environmental backlashes of the type we got from hydropower projects.
Manual Tags: ratoon* W/5 (oryza OR rice); ScienceDirect; search.rice; SPV

Author: Mariano, Marc Jim M.; Giesecke, James A.
Title: The macroeconomic and food security implications of price interventions in the Philippine rice market
Abstract Note: Abstract The Philippine government has a number of policy interventions in the domestic rice market aimed at promoting national food security. This paper examines the economy-wide and food security implications of three of the main policies: a ceiling on prices paid by rice consumers; a floor on prices received by paddy producers; and a subsidy on prices paid for seeds by paddy farmers. These programmes have been subject to domestic criticism on allocative efficiency and distributional grounds. We examine the effects of removing the programmes using an economy-wide model with detailed treatment of agricultural activity, land use, and food security measures. We find that the programmes make a small contribution to food security, for a modest budgetary outlay. The allocative efficiency gains available from ending the programmes are small, and may be outweighed by the potential for adverse short-run macroeconomic consequences.
Manual Tags: Food security; Food subsidies; General equilibrium; Land use; perennial W/1 (oryza OR rice); Philippines; Rice market; ScienceDirect; search.rice; SPV

Author: AGGEEV, V. I.
Title: The main links in cereal rotations on irrigated lands.
Abstract Note: It has been planned by the federal government that the area under irrigation in the Trans-Volga region should be allocated in the following approximate percentages for different crops: 46.0-63.0, 21.2-38.5, up to 6.0, up to 16.8, and 10.8-16.6 per cent for spring wheats, perennial herbage, sugar beet, sunflower, and maize respectively. As a necessary preliminary to introducing a large scale cultivation of the above plants in the collective and State farms of the region, the Bezencuk Experimental Station studied, in field conditions on irrigated lands, the importance of black fallow, the effect of former crops on the yield of winter and spring wheats, and the practicability of growing commercial catch crops. The black fallow was found to be the best means of controlling weeds growing in profusion on old arable lands used for irrigated crops. A deep autumn ploughing (20-22 cm.), repeated in May and followed by 5 cultivations, or ploughing to a depth of 20 cm. with a subsequent deepening of the arable horizon by further 8-10 cm. + 6 cultivations were found to reduce weed infestation to 0.6-1.3 per cent. The black fallow and Vicia-oats mixture for hay were found to be the most suitable predecessors conditioning the highest yield of grain and straw in the case of winter wheat; the average yields of the latter, in a period of three years, 1938-40, were, in centners per ha., 35.0 and 32.6 for the grain, and 53.5 and 56.7 for the straw with Vicia-oats and black fallow as predecessors respectively. Potatoes (early), spring wheat and sunflower, in this descending order, when used as predecessors, resulted in lower yields of winter wheat. For spring wheat, with sugar beet and maize, as predecessors on irrigated lands, higher yields of both grain and straw were obtained than on the fields where potatoes, sunflower or soya beans were previously grown. The Vicia-oats mixture was proved to be the most economical catch-crop for production of hay; maize and, particularly, sunflower gave best results as silages. To shorten the vegetative period and to ensure a higher yield of seeds, vernalization should be used as a routine method for the seeds of the above plants when utilized as catch-crops.-H.F.
Manual Tags: search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); WOS

Author: Emery, Frank
Title: The mechanics of innovation: clover cultivation in Wales before 1750
Abstract Note: Welsh agriculturists were more responsive to the introduction of new crops in the seventeenth and early eighteenth centuries than is generally assumed. In particular, they appreciated the nutritious fodder that could be provided for their livestock by the sown grasses, notably clover, sainfoin and perennial rye grass. These legumes were tried on Welsh estates at least as early as 1668. The initial mechanics of innovation are explored: what were the processes by which knowledge was gained, distributed, tested and used in the decision-making of those who first cultivated the grasses? On the Trevor estates the stages of adoption included the inception of trial plots of sainfoin; observation and enquiry with several English growers; assessment of soils and seeds; parallel experiments at two sites; close reference to the printed word about the crop, in papers of instruction and books. Welsh initiators also followed patterns of imitation, in some cases based on clover cultivation already established in Wales, in others on the classic model of Herefordshire. The scale of adoption is indicated by data from every Welsh county, and for landowners and farmers at different levels of operation. The literature of improved agriculture was directly influential, as were the ties of family kinship, language and religion among adopters. The working of a three-step flow of communication is suggested.
Manual Tags: perennial W/1 ("rye" OR secale) AND NOT ("rye?grass" OR "ryegrass"); ScienceDirect; Scopus; search.rye; SPV; TITLE-ABS-KEY (perennial W/1 ("rye" OR secale) AND NOT ("rye?grass" OR ryegrass)) AND DOCTYPE (ar)

Author: DOBROHVA LOV, V. P.; CICIN, N. V.
Title: The methodological aspect of the hybridization theory.
Publication Title: Nauc. Dokl. vyss. Sk. : Philos. Nauk. (Sci. Rep. high. Sch. : Philos.   Sci.).
Abstract Note: After a discussion of the evolutionary significance of distant hybridization, its practical value is illustrated by Triticum-Agropyron hybrids such as the cultivar Vostok [East], combining earliness, resistance to loose smut, and freedom from lodging, shedding and sprouting with high yield; perennial wheats giving grain and forage yields in the first two years and having a survival of 60% in the third; and wheats that yield 400 c. and more of green matter per ha after the grain has been harvested.
Manual Tags: search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); WOS

Author: Moreno, C.; Hale, C.; Ivanyi, L.
Title: The mitogenic, immunogenic and tolerogenic properties of dextrans and levans. Lack of correlation according to differences of molecular structure and size
Abstract Note: The mitogenicity of dextrans, levans and some of their depolymerized fractions was assayed in vitro using spleen cells from CBA mice and compared with their immunogenic and tolerogenic potency in vitro. Two branched dextrans (B1355 and B1299) induced a greater increase in DNA synthesis than linear dextran B512 which was only feebly mitogenic. The activity of B1355 was greater than that of B1299 and induced a level of stimulation similar to that of polyanions (dextran sulphate and polystyrene sulphonic acid). Dextrans B1355 and B1299 were relatively poor tolerogens for the α1-6 glucosyl epitope whilst the native linear dextran B512 was much more effective. Their immunogenicity for this specificity also decreased in the order B512, B1355, B1299. All depolymerised fractions of B512 induced only minimal mitogenic responses bearing no relevance to their immunogenic and tolerogenic potentials, which declined in parallel with decreasing molecular weight to extinction at 2 X 10 4. Native levan, hydrolyzed fractions of it and perennial rye grass fructosans were all equally potent mitogens irrespective of their molecular weight. In contrast, the controlled hydrolysis of levan can, according to extent, abrogate either both its immunogenicity and tolerogenicity or immunogenicity alone. These results together seem incompatible with the hypothesis that discrimination between immunity and tolerance induced by T-independent antigens depends on the intensity of mitogenic stimulation to which they subject corresponding specific B cells.
Manual Tags: Scopus; search.rye; SPV; TITLE-ABS-KEY (perennial W/1 ("rye" OR secale) AND NOT ("rye?grass" OR ryegrass)) AND DOCTYPE (ar)

Author: KRIVONOSOVA, L. P.
Title: The morphological and physiological characteristics of Johnson grass and of sorghum-Johnson grass hybrids.
Publication Title: Sb. Nauchno-issled. robot molo-dykh uchenykh. Stavropol'sk. n. -i. in-t   s. kh.
Abstract Note: Development of vegetative organs and rhizomes was studied in Sorghum halepense, sorghum x S. halepense hybrids and perennial sorghum. Perennial sorghum had larger leaves and its green-matter yield was 3-4 times higher than that of S. halepense and the hybrids.
Manual Tags: search.sorghum; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 sorghum); WOS

Author: RODE, A. A.
Title: The most important results of ten-year investigations at the Dzhanybek Station, Academy of Sciences, USSR.
Abstract Note: In the north-west Caspian lowland, the flat land between depressions in the relief is occupied by a solonets complex, half of whose area consists of solonchakous solonets. The solonets complex is reclaimed by plantation plowing and snow retention. Plantation plowing to 50 cm transports the gypsum in the 35-50 cm layer into the ploughed layer. Plantation plowing should be preceded by plowing to 20-22 cm and should be followed by harrowing. Good crops of wheat and perennial herbage have been obtained on the reclaimed land. Oak, ornamental trees and shrubs, fruit trees and annual and perennial herbage have grown well on the dark soils occupying large depressions in the relief.
Manual Tags: search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); WOS

Author: FORLANI, R.
Title: The most recent wheat varieties.
Abstract Note: The wheat varieties selected in Italy during the last few years are suitable for the plains and for low hill country. The highest yields in Lombardy are mostly obtained with the variety 0.10. Other high-yielding varieties are Mara, Funo and Fortunato. In a variety trial, which included 0.10, Funo was best with 71.35 q./ha. While 0.10 does well only in particular conditions, S. Pastore is adaptable to different conditions, including cold. Perennial wheat, obtained by crossing Triticum with Agropyron, is considered of no practical value.-E.B.
Manual Tags: search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); WOS

Author: KUPRIJANOV, S. I.; SUDNOV, P. E.
Title: The nature of aftermath formation in perennial wheats of A. I. Derzavin (perennial wheat-rye-hybrids).
Abstract Note: Aftermath growth depended on the number of green internodes left after mowing and the reserve substances in them. A better aftermath was formed in those plants which had a larger number of unvernalized buds. The buds which were vernalized during winter produced fertile tillers and deferred barren shoots. Unvernalized shoots winter much better, fully vernalized tillers perishing during winter. The number of fertile tillers was very small in the second cut and the use of the second cut for seed was hardly expedient; for forage the second cut should be mown at the time of sowing winter crops. Further improvement of hybrids should prevent the formation of fertile shoots in the second cut and vernalization of autumn-formed shoots.-M.A.O.
Manual Tags: search.rye; search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 ("rye" OR secale) NOT "rye$grass"); TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); WOS

Author: KUPRINAOV, S. I.; SUDNOV, i P. E.
Title: The nature of growth of the perennial wheat of A. I. Derjavin, the perennial wheat-rye hybrid
Publication Title: Selektsiia I Semenovodstvo [plant Breeding and Seed Growing]
Abstract Note: Growth of shoots after first harvest depends directly upon the presence of internodes and the amt. of nutrients contained; on the number of buds, particularly basal ones; on proper culture and autumnal fertilization; and on wider spacing of rows and prompt harvest when ripe. Use of second-crop seeds which are poor and late interferes with development of winter shoots. Vernalization results in winter killing. The Lyssenko cultural system increases hardiness and shoot formation, without heading, in the 2d crop, thus insuring grain production for 3-4 yrs. || ABSTRACT AUTHORS: J. W. Pincus
Manual Tags: search.rye; search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 ("rye" OR secale) NOT "rye$grass"); TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); WOS

Author: Glover, J. D.
Title: The necessity and possibility of perennial grain production systems

Author: Nascente, Adriano Stephan; Crusciol, Carlos Alexandre Costa; Cobucci, Tarcísio
Title: The no-tillage system and cover crops—Alternatives to increase upland rice yields
Abstract Note: Upland rice (Oryza sativa L.) cultivation has been increasing in importance in Asia while water availability for irrigation has been decreasing because of rapid growth in industry and urban centers. Therefore, the development of technologies that increase upland rice yields under aerobic conditions, thereby saving water, would be an effective strategy to avoid a decrease in global rice grain production. The use of the no-tillage system (NTS) and cover crops that maintain soil moisture would prove advantageous in the move toward sustainable agriculture. However, upland rice develops better in plowed soil, and it has been reported that this crop does not perform well under the NTS. Therefore, the aim of this study was to investigate the effect of cover crops on upland rice grain yield and yield components sowed in a NTS. A field experiment was conducted during two growing seasons (2008–2009 and 2009–2010), and treatments consisted of growing rice under five cover crops in a NTS and two control treatments under the conventional tillage system (plowing once and disking twice). Treatments were carried out in a randomized block design with three replications. Our findings are as follows: On average, Brachiaria brizantha (12.32 Mg ha−1), Brachiaria ruziziensis (11.08 Mg ha−1) and Panicum maximum (11.62 Mg ha−1) had outstanding biomass production; however, these grasses provided the worst upland rice yields (2.30, 2.04, and 2.67 Mg ha−1, respectively) and are not recommended as cover crops before upland rice. Millet and fallow exhibited the fastest straw degradation (half-lives of 52 and 54 days, respectively), and millet exhibited the fastest nitrogen release (N half-life of 28 days). The use of a NTS was promising when millet was used as a cover crop; this allowed the highest upland rice yield (3.94 Mg ha−1) and did not statistically differ from plowed fallow (3.52 Mg ha−1).
Manual Tags: Cover crops; Crop–livestock integration; perennial W/1 (oryza OR rice); ScienceDirect; search.rice; Soil management; SPV; Sustainable agriculture

Author: YAKOVLEV, G. V.
Title: The number of primary roots in rye.
Publication Title: Sbornik Trudov Aspirantov i Molodykh Nauchnykh Sotrudnihov. Vsesoyuznyi   Nauchno-Issledovaterskii Institut N.I. Vavilova
Abstract Note: The number of primary roots in cultivated and in annual-weed rye varied from 1 to 10 and in species of wild perennial rye ( Secale kupriyanovi, S. anatolicum) from 1 to 6, the majority of grains developing 4-7 and 2-4 primary roots, respectively. Seedlings of wheat and barley were examined for comparison.-A.V.B.
Manual Tags: search.rye; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 ("rye" OR secale) NOT "rye$grass"); WOS

Author: Gabrovska, Dana; Fiedlerova, Vlasta; Holasova, Marie; Maskova, Eva; Smrcinov, Hana; Rysova, Jana; Winterova, Renata; Michalova, Anna; Hutar, Martin
Title: The nutritional evaluation of underutilized cereals and buckwheat
Abstract Note: We evaluated the nutritional factors of underutilized cereals (spelt, emmer, einkorn, millet, foxtail millet, semiperennial rye, naked oat, and naked barley) and buckwheat. The basic food components as well as minor nutrients were determined. The analyses included dry matter, ash, protein, dietary fiber, fat, fatty acids, amino acids, minerals, and lipophilic and hydrophilic vitamins. Rutin was also determined in buckwheat. We hope to offer new recipes for the healthy food production and for special dietary use (diabetes, celiac disease, phenylketonuria diet, etc.). Use of the germinated seeds is also suggested. The examples of some healthy food products in the Czech Republic are mentioned.
Manual Tags: search.rye; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 ("rye" OR secale) NOT "rye$grass"); WOS

Author: Xue-Qing, Zhao; Hui-Mei, Shen; Yan-Qiong, Yin; Xiang-Yong, Li; Jian-Ping, Lu; Ai-Dong, Chen
Title: The occurrence characteristics and population dynamics of Sogatella furcifera (Horvath) in Yunnan Province
Abstract Note: [Objectives] The objective of this study was to investigate the occurrence characteristics and damage caused by Sogatella furcifera (Horvath) in Yunnan Province to provide a basis for the effective control of this pest. [Methods] In 2010-2011, the population occurrence and dynamics of S. fuercifera were systematically studied in the field using light-trap collection in six major rice growing areas in Yunnan, including the west, southwest, south, southeast, east, and northeast. [Results] The results show that the size of the overwintering population was smaller than in other seasons and its distribution was different in six major rice farming areas of Yunnan; mostly concentrated on rice stubble, ratooning rice and rice seedlings in wet paddy fields at latitudes south of N 23 degrees 55'164 '' and altitudes below 1 369 m. Moreover, the overwintering population of S. furcifera in the south and southeast of Yinman was more abundant than that in the west and southwest. Light-trapping indicated that the beginning of the migration period of S. furcifera was from early March to late May in the west, early March in the southwest, and middle to late May in the northeast. The migration period of S. furcifera was progressively later from the west to the southwest, south, southeast, east, and northeast. Adult numbers captured by light-trapping were lower in the southwest than the southeast and the peak immigration dates were mainly in May, June and July. The return migration peak occurred from late September to middle October. Population peaks occurred in the southwest and south from the end of April to June, in the southeast and east from late May to early July, and in the northeast from late June to July. [Conclusion] S. furcifera mostly occurs in the south, southeast and southwest of Yunnan in May, June and July.
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: Spitz, P.; Hemerka, I.
Title: The occurrence of moisture deficits for representatives of main crop sorts in their critical development stages in driest regions of the Czech Republic in years 1961-2000
Publication Title: Acta Universitatis Agriculturae et Silviculturae Mendelianae Brunensis
Abstract Note: The article presents acquired results of moisture deficits for representatives of main crop sorts in their very critical development stages on soil moisture in our driest regions (Žatecko, Litoměřicko, Middle Bohemia, East Bohemia, Southern Moravia, South-East Moravia, Middle Moravia) in the years 1961-2000. The calculations were realized by the specially developed program BIVPROG 1 (the balance moisture program) for PC for perennial wheat (as representative of cereals), perennial rape (technical crops), potatoes (root-crops) and alfalfa (fodder crops), in its first crop year. The results of the calculations are probabilities of over fullfilment of maximum number days successive with moisture below the lower limit of soil moisture θz found out in very critical development stages on moisture for every chosen crop. The probabilities of over fullfilment were determined from quadragenarian line (the years 1961-2000) of calculations made for every technical line of climatological data and pertinent phenological station with phenological data of chosen crop and they were worked into graphs. With regards to the extent of graphical outcome, the results are worked in tables VI. to IX. The fortnightly criterion was derived for comprehensive evaluation of acquired results, the values of comprehensive evaluation are presented in table X. This table reflects that the fortnightly criterion in the years 1961-2000 was exceeded in more then 20 years for all chosen crops, also in the case of perennial wheat and rape which are considered as secondary from the aspect of their irrigation requirements. From the obtained data also follows, that the lack of soil moisture usually starts to show signs before the very critical development stages of the crop, and then often continues. The results were acquired for medium soil, for mild soil the results would be even more unfavourable. The obtained results from our driest regions evoke the concern for irrigation requirements in these regions.
Short Title: Výskyt vláhových deficitů u hlavních druhů plodin v jejich kritických vývojových stadiích v nejsušších oblastech čr vletech 1961-2000
Manual Tags: Climatological data; Critical stage on soil moisture of crop; Crop; Fortnightly criterion; Lower limit of soil moisture; Model calculations on PC; Phenological data; Probability of over fullfilment; Scopus; search.wheat; SPV; TITLE-ABS-KEY (perennial W/1 (triticum OR wheat)) AND DOCTYPE (ar); TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); WOS

Author: Lin, C. Y.
Title: The occurrence of sorghum ergot disease caused by Claviceps sorghi in Taiwan.
Publication Title: Bulletin of Taichung District Agricultural Improvement Station
Abstract Note: During the autumn of 1980, C. sorghi infection of F 1 seed of ratoon sorghum (Taichung No. 5) cultivated at the Chai-yi and Taichung areas of Taiwan was more severe (50%) than that of normal sorghum (19%). Female parents (male sterile) were more susceptible than male parents to the pathogen. C. sorghi produced 3 types of conidia: macroconidia, microconidia and secondary conidia. The fungicides Folicur E.C. [tebuconazole] and TMTD W.P. [thiram] inhibited the germination of conidia by 23 and 80%, respectively, and increased seed germination.

Title: THE ORGANIC ACIDS OF GRASS EXTRACTS

Author: SINSKAJA, E. N.; BORKOVSKAJA, V. A.
Title: The perennial Agropyron-Triticum hybrid of P. J. Bodovskij.
Abstract Note: The hybrid described, alleged to be a cross of A. repens * wheat, is intermediate between these two in habit; it is perennial but has proved winter hardy only in the milder parts of the southern USSR; it is also not tolerant of drought; however, under favourable conditions it gives higher yields of green fodder in the first and second cuts than those obtained from perennial grasses, Secale kuprijanovii or the perennial hybrids of N. V. Cicin. It has remained free from brown rust and almost free from yellow rust. It breeds true and is partially sterile; it has a chromosome number of 2n = 56.
Manual Tags: search.rye; search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 ("rye" OR secale) NOT "rye$grass"); TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); WOS

Author: Pfeifer, Matthias; Martis, Mihaela; Asp, Torben; Mayer, Klaus F. X.; Luebberstedt, Thomas; Byrne, Stephen; Frei, Ursula; Studer, Bruno
Title: The Perennial Ryegrass GenomeZipper: Targeted Use of Genome Resources for Comparative Grass Genomics
Abstract Note: Whole-genome sequences established for model and major crop species constitute a key resource for advanced genomic research. For outbreeding forage and turf grass species like ryegrasses (Lolium spp.), such resources have yet to be developed. Here, we present a model of the perennial ryegrass (Lolium perenne) genome on the basis of conserved synteny to barley (Hordeum vulgare) and the model grass genome Brachypodium (Brachypodium distachyon) as well as rice (Oryza sativa) and sorghum (Sorghum bicolor). A transcriptome-based genetic linkage map of perennial ryegrass served as a scaffold to establish the chromosomal arrangement of syntenic genes from model grass species. This scaffold revealed a high degree of synteny and macrocollinearity and was then utilized to anchor a collection of perennial ryegrass genes in silico to their predicted genome positions. This resulted in the unambiguous assignment of 3,315 out of 8,876 previously unmapped genes to the respective chromosomes. In total, the GenomeZipper incorporates 4,035 conserved grass gene loci, which were used for the first genome-wide sequence divergence analysis between perennial ryegrass, barley, Brachypodium, rice, and sorghum. The perennial ryegrass GenomeZipper is an ordered, information-rich genome scaffold, facilitating map-based cloning and genome assembly in perennial ryegrass and closely related Poaceae species. It also represents a milestone in describing synteny between perennial ryegrass and fully sequenced model grass genomes, thereby increasing our understanding of genome organization and evolution in the most important temperate forage and turf grass species.
Manual Tags: Scopus; search.sorghum; SPV; TITLE-ABS-KEY (perennial W/1 sorghum) AND DOCTYPE (ar); TS=(perennial NEAR/1 sorghum); WOS

Author: RUBENE3, E. Y.
Title: The periods for plowing grassy surface soil in the Latvian Soviet Sociallst Republic
Abstract Note: The experiments were carried out from 1950 to 1954 on an 8-field crop rotation on sandy-clayey, medium podzolic soil. Such soil constitutes about 30% of all the arable land of the Republic. A mixture of perennial grasses (late red clover, timothy and meadow fescue) was sown under cover of winter rye and fertilized with manure and complete mineral fertilizer. Additional fertilization with superphosphate and potassium chloride was carried out in the first year of utilization by grasses. The crops of winter rye were higher when the top layer was plowed earlier (July 15), because better decomposition of the plant residues provided more favorable nutrient conditions. The crop was also higher with a layer of perennial grasses in the first year of utilization than the second year. The largest crop of spring wheat was produced by plowing the top layer Sept. 15. With this timing of the plowing, less decomposition of the plant residues takes place, which keeps the nutrients from being washed out of the soil by the fall rains. The conclusion is reached that on sandy-clayey soils, one-year utilization of grasses is more expedient. Under Latvian conditions winter rye and winter wheat are more productive than spring wheat.
Manual Tags: search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); WOS

Author: Klinkenberg, E; Takken, W; Huibers, F; Touré, Y.T
Title: The phenology of malaria mosquitoes in irrigated rice fields in Mali
Abstract Note: A field study was carried out in the large-scale rice irrigation scheme of the Office du Niger in Mali to investigate the relation between anopheline mosquito larval development and small-scale differences in irrigation practices, such as water level, irrigation application and irrigation frequency. The objective of the study was to find out if water management can be used as a tool for vector control to reduce the malaria transmission risk. Larvae of Anopheles gambiae s.s.,̄ the main malaria vector in the study area, developed mostly in the first 6 weeks after transplanting the rice. During rice development, a succession of anopheline species was observed. This was associated with a marked decrease in light intensity reaching the water surface as plant height increased. Minor differences in water management resulted in noticeable variations in larval densities and species composition. A. gambiae s.s. larvae were most abundant during the early growing stages and almost absent in a closed rice crop. Due to improper drainage after harvest, A. gambiae s.s. breeding was soon re-established in fields where small pools of water were retained. The results suggest that larval mosquito habitats in the Office du Niger can be significantly reduced by water management, simultaneous planting and harvesting and proper drainage of fallow fields.
Manual Tags: Anopheles larvae; Irrigation; Malaria vectors; Mali; Mosquito population dynamics; perennial W/1 (oryza OR rice); ScienceDirect; search.rice; SPV

Author: Coffins, G. N.
Title: The phylogeny of maize.
Publication Title: Bulletin of the Torrey Botanical Club
Abstract Note: The normal haploid chromosome number for Zea is ten, but certain forms are known to have one or two additional chromosomes. Other genera of the group also have ten, Euchlaena pernnis 20, and certain types of Tripsacum dactyloides have 36, whilst others have 18. There seems to be little connection between the chromosome number and phylogeny. So far the only forms with the double number which have been found in Euchlaena and the sorghums are perennials. The possibility of maize having existed as a wild plant is dismissed as improbable. An objection to the idea of an origin by mutation is that crosses of maize and Euchlaena give a series of intermediate forms, whereas characters arising by mutation behave as unit characters. An origin by human selection from Euchlaena is regarded also as improbable, Euchlaena being a highly inappropriate subject. It seems more probable that the two species have been distinct since the origin of the Tripsaceae from some perfect flowered form, except that this would fail to account for their interfertility. The author leans towards the idea of a hybrid origin, with Euchlaena as one of the parents.
Manual Tags: search.sorghum; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 sorghum); WOS

Author: Luo, Ke-chang; Jiang, Tian-fu; Li, Yun-ping
Title: The population dynamic and influence on yield of Pachydiplosis oryzae Wood-Mason on ratooning rice.

Author: GORSKOV, I.; JAKOVLEV, P.
Title: The possibilities revealed by the achievements of I. V. Michurin.
Publication Title: Sotsialisticeskaja Rekonstruktsija Sel'skogo Khozjaistva (Socialist   Reconstruction of Agriculture)
Abstract Note: Reference is made to the immense value to Soviet agriculture and breeding of the wild forms and species of many cultivated plants newly discovered by the Soviet expeditions to the centres of distribution. The provision of forms suitable to more northerly cultivation in particular is likely to be achieved by this means and special reference is made to the perennial wheat produced by hybridizing with rye-grass. The same is now being done for fruit trees. Twenty species of small bush fruits not hitherto used either as fruit or for crossing have been collected at Hibiny. In Siberia all possible kinds of temperate fruits are found and these are not damaged by the frost. Michurin has made use of all these forms, many of them for direct introduction and all of them for hybridization. Whole forests of interesting forms of common fruits, hitherto untouched by the breeder, exist in Transcaucasia and other countries. Many of these are resistant to frost or to drought. Similar forests of walnut, pistachio and other nuts occur in the Central Asiatic republics of the Soviet Union and these, as well as a number of subtropical fruits, are being used by Michurin, whose breeding work has made possible the cultivation in northern regions of all kinds of fruits that would not have been even considered previously. Michurin's method consists of crossing forms of widely different geographical origin-the wild vines, pears, almonds, etc., of the Far East were crossed with the high-quality varieties of Europe and America-or crossing forms of very different genetic constitution, i.e. interspecific and intergeneric hybridization. Species and genera that will not cross are first united vegetatively at as early an age as possible or else crossed by means of an intermediate form. By this means he has produced over two hundred new varieties of fruits and other plants. At present he is evolving frost-resistant peaches for the central area of the U.S.S.R. and the Crimea. In apples he has evolved sorts that not only grow in such regions as Voronesh but come into bearing at the end of 5-6 years and are of superior quality and flavour. In whole areas of central and northern U.S.S.R., Siberia and the Urals, fruit growing has been made possible as a result of this work. Attention is now being devoted also to the production of artificial mutation. In 1934 fifty thousand hybrid seedlings were growing at Michurin's station and 948 combinations were made, involving the pollination during that year of 205, 057 flowers artificially and 463, 942 by means of bees. Mass hybridizations were made at other places too, 150, 000 flowers being cross-pollinated at the Moscow station, 80, 000 at Leningrad, and 600, 000 at others. At present four thousand growers are using Michurin's varieties and sixteen thousand hectares will be under them in the second Five Year Plan.
Manual Tags: search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); WOS

Author: KOLESNIKOVA, P. D.
Title: The possibility of characterizing the water balance of plants by the parameter of the relative degree of saturation of the cells with water (H) Referat. Zhur., Biol., 1963, No. 6G88. (Translation)
Publication Title: Izvest Akad Nauk Tadzhiksk Ssr Otd Sel Skokhoz I Biol Nauk
Abstract Note: The purpose of the work was to confirm whether the index of the relative degree of saturation of the cells with water reflects the water balance of plants, and to establish the possibility of the practical use of the index. Pot and field experiments were carred out with perennial grasses 1 and 2 years old (alfalfa, Italian ryegrass, and orchardgrass) in pure sowings and in grass mixtures with different types of nutrition and water supply near Tashkent. To determine the cell water-saturation (H), the author used the formula suggested by Shardakov where [image] [center dot]100%, in which P is the osmotic pressure and S the suction. H reflects the state of the plant's supply of water and this value can be used in irrigation practice. With perennial grains the application of nitrogen fertilizers and the simultaneous growing of alfalfa improves the supply of water for the cells, as found by increased values of H. With alfalfa, fertilizer has little effect on H. In mixed sowings of grains with alfalfa the value of H is lower than with pure sowings.
Manual Tags: search.grain; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 grain); WOS

Author: SHUBIN, V. F.
Title: The problem of arranging the correct rotations of crops and putting virgin soil and waste land into well-ordered use
Abstract Note: The problem of introducing rational crop rotations into the arid regions of the Southeast is discussed with a view toward supplying food for livestock raising through sowing grass in addition to winter crops, organizing the patches to be used for the yield, as well as arranging early-ripening crops on unused fields. After plowing the lots for one or two years, summer wheat is planted, and then perennial grasses are sown. By combining the methods of cultivating the soil with natural processes of soil restoration, and augmenting the productivity of early-ripening crops on long-unused soil, it becomes possible to significantly reduce the period during which the land lies fallow and to create the desired and most productive form of grass cultivation. || ABSTRACT AUTHORS: Transl. from Referat. Zhur. Biol. 20185, 1958, courtesy OTS-JPRS
Manual Tags: search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); WOS

Author: DNEPROVSKII, I. F.
Title: The problem of perennial cereal crops in the farming system based on grass rotations.
Abstract Note: This article is devoted to discussing the advantages which would accrue to farmers when the fields allocated to the growing of perennials ( Medicago, Phleum, Trifolium, Agropyron cristatum, A. americanum etc., both as fodder crops and for maintaining the structure and increasing the fertility of soil for the subsequent field crops), be sown in addition with perennial wheat and rye. Field and plot trials showed that, when wheat or rye were sown in the autumn and lucerne in the spring, the first cutting of perennial cereals yielded grain, and the second (which was done simultaneously with the first cutting of lucerne) yielded good green feed and hay. On some individual collective farms where such procedure was adopted an additional 75 per cent (3, 000 centners) of grain was harvested; at the same time, since the period during which the perennials remain in the field is doubled or trebled, such a rotation, as instanced by the one given below, would inevitably lead to a considerable increase in the fertility of the soil and in yields. The following is a 12-course rotation used with success in the Kharkov Territory, on a farm with a cultivated area of 1, 800 ha. : (1) fallow; (2) perennial wheat (cover crop) + lucerne; (3) 1st year lucerne + perennial wheat; (4) 2nd year lucerne + perennial wheat; (5) 3rd year lucerne + perennial wheat; (6) annual cereals; (7) potatoes, etc. ; (8) spring cereals; (9) fallow; (10) winter cereals; (11) catch crops (cereals); (12) spring crops. In the above rotation the perennial grass stratum remained undisturbed for 4 instead of the usual 2 years with the consequent rise in yields.-H.F.
Manual Tags: search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); WOS

Author: DEMISEV, K. S.
Title: The problem of perennial graminaceous plants.
Abstract Note: Development of perennial forms of wheat and rye at the Kabarda State Breeding Station by environmental training, without wide hybridization, is reported. Some productive forms of rye of the perennial type were derived from the winter rye Kabardinka [Kabarda] and the hybrid Kabardinka x Stal [Steel]. They have borne normally developed grains with a 1000 kernel weight of 24-32 grm. and transmitted the perennial habit to 81-100% of the sexual progeny. The seed progeny of the perennial rye segregated in respect of many characters, including branched and other abnormal types of ear. Some progeny produced culms with several ears each, and others bore ears resembling panicles. The latter plants did not resemble rye or any other plant of the Hordeeae. The material investigated gave more types with branched ears and culms bearing several ears in the later generations, and is being multiplied in the hope that it will give a productive perennial rye adapted to the climate of the Caucasian foothills. References are made to an instance of conversion of rye into Bromus inermis and to a perennial wheat obtained by environmental training of a productive line of Lutescens 907. The perennial wheat had longer ears, bearing 35-38 large grains, than Lutescens 907. It produced grain two years in succession, but was incapable of surviving for a longer period. The experiments suggest that training wheat for the perennial habit is more arduous than with rye.
Manual Tags: search.rye; search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 ("rye" OR secale) NOT "rye$grass"); TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); WOS

Author: DERZAVIN, A.
Title: The problem of perenniality in agricultural plants.
Abstract Note: Research on breeding perennial forms dates from 1930, when a perennial bulbous barley was found by the author in the Karabah highlands, Transcaucasia. For obtaining perennial wheat of a grain and hay type, wheat was crossed with perennial ryes, including Secale Kuprijanovi from North Caucasus. A perennial F 1 generation was easily obtained with a percentage success of 50 to 70, but the hybrids were sterile. Nevertheless, 2650 FI florets yielded thirty-seven grains in 1932, and in the following year 133 grains were obtained from 186, 824 florets. Five generations of perennial forms are now available. By crossing cultivated rye with the perennial type, a perennial and partially fertile F 1 generation was produced. Four generations of perennial forms of hay and grain type are now available. For hay, perennial rye should be sown with perennial vetch; breeding of perennial cultivated forms of vetch and Lathyrus is also in progress. Crosses of cultivated sorghum with the perennial type yielded 1, 700 grains of perennial forms for grain and hay use. In 1935, by crossing annual sunflowers with the perennial type and the perennial sunflowers with the tuberous type, 135 and ten grains were obtained respectively. The object is to obtain perennial forms producing seeds and tubers.-M.A.O.
Manual Tags: search.grain; search.rye; search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 grain); TS=(perennial NEAR/1 ("rye" OR secale) NOT "rye$grass"); TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); WOS

Author: CICIN, N. V.
Title: The problem of perennial wheat.
Abstract Note: Agropyron caninum, A. tenerum, A. sibiricum and A. cristatum were found to be incompatible with wheat. A. glaucum, A. trichophorum, A. elongatum and A. junceum gave a high percentage of success in crossing with soft and hard wheat. A. repens in early experiments failed to cross with wheat, but later forms were found which cross readily. As the systematics of Agropyron are not yet complete, the forms in question may represent a new Agropyron species. In the F 1 generation, the characters of Agropyron are dominant; all the hybrids are perennial and show an equal tendency to generative and vegetative reproduction. Most of the F 1 plants are self-sterile, only individual groups being self-fertile. B. A. Vakar found that the number of chromosomes of the self-fertile hybrids equals the sum of the haploid number of the parental forms. Reduction division of wheat * A. elongatum is quite normal, twenty-eight bivalents being formed; reduction division in wheat * A. glaucum hybrids is associated with such serious meiotic disturbances that the extent of self-fertility is surprising (Vakar). Some F 1 plants segregate, whereas others remain constant. As the majority of F 1 generation was self-sterile, back crossing to one of the parents was required; the percentage of success did not exceed 3 to 4 per cent. Natural cross-pollination in mixed sowings of hybrids and wheat was more successful. From the F 2 generation onwards, segregation gave rise to various forms, some with characters not found in the parents. The percentage of perennial plants fell somewhat in the F 2 generation, and in subsequent generations varied according to the type of parent; the percentage of perenniality in F 4 plants varied from none to 60 or 70. In F 5 and subsequent generations a number of valuable annual and perennial forms could be selected. Some vigourous forms, for example, wheat * A. elongatum hybrids, with many tillers are of particular forage value; perennial wheats are for grain and forage purposes. The length of the vegetative period in F 1 plants is determined by the type of wheat: Agropyron * spring wheat yielded spring hybrids and Agropyron x winter wheat, winter hybrids. The vegetative period of forms intermediate between wheat and Agropyron varies with the year. In the first year three groups are found, namely, forms with long vegetative period (120 days or more), forms not fully earing in the first year and forms not earing in the first year. In the second year all the forms eared earlier than typical winter wheat.-M.A.O.
Manual Tags: search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); WOS

Author: TZITZIN, N. V.
Title: The problem of perennial wheat.
Abstract Note: The many valuable qualities of Agropyrum that it would be desirable to introduce into wheat are enumerated and the early crossing work with wheat (Cf. "Plant Breeding Abstracts", Vol. IV, Abst. 383, Vol. V, Abst.
Manual Tags: search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); WOS

Author: LAZAREV, S. F.
Title: The problem of the creation of a biologically active arable stratum under the conditions of irrigated cotton cultivation [English, German, and French summ.]
Abstract Note: On the irrigated sero-zems of the Central Ak-Kavaksk Agrotechnlcal Experiment Station (Uzbek SSR), fall plowing with turnover of the stratum to a depth of 27-30 cm sharply increased the productivity of the biologically active layer. Sowing of a mixture of lucerne, orchard grass and perennial rye with subsequent plowing under and application of bacterial and mineral fertilizers had a positive effect on the biological activity in the upper layers of the soil.
Manual Tags: search.rye; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 ("rye" OR secale) NOT "rye$grass"); WOS

Author: HUGHES, C. G.
Title: The production and testing of sugar-cane seedlings
Abstract Note: An account is given of the technic applied to the production and testing of sugar-cane seedlings in Queensland. From the crossing point of view, to insure an excellent arrowing season the crops must have made reasonable growth before the wet season, the wet season should be long and uniform, and autumn and early winter conditions should maintain reasonable growth and allow emergence of arrows. A simple lopping procedure is adopted to delay arrowing. Data on pollen viability, abundance of pollen and arrowing are given for the vars. maintained as parent material and the relation of these features to breeding practice is discussed. The main blood lines in use in Queensland are spontaneums at various stages of nobilization, Saccharum robustum, sorghum hybrids, and nobles. The solution method of holding arrows for crossing, and the associated use of lanterns, are described. Pre-storage drying of seed is usually by an electric dryer. The fuzz is stored in small tins at 32.40[degree]F until required for planting within the ensuing yr. Seed is germinated in sterilized soil in flats in glasshouses and the seedlings thinned out to 400-500 per flat of about 270 sq. in. When 3-4 inches high the seedlings are transplanted to pots outside the glasshouses, and when 9-12 inches high are put into the field. Seedlings are selected from either the plant or the ratoon crop, and selection is carried out in the field, where comparison of certain characters as between seedling plots and standard canes can be readily made. The measure of stooling in the original seedling stool is the number of sticks of millable cane at the time of selection. Brix figures are obtained from hand refractometer readings from extracted juice. Selected seedlings are planted in 40-set plots; further selection is made in the plant crop and is mainly on a visual basis. From 20 to 40 seedlings at each station then go into a "yield-observation" trial for two seasons, and the next lot of selections are incorporated in Latin square or randomized block trials and in disease resistance and district trials before being distributed to farmers or rejected for disease susceptibility or other cause. || ABSTRACT AUTHORS: Auth. summ
Manual Tags: search.sorghum; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 sorghum); WOS

Author: CICIN, N. V.; LJUBIMOVA, V. F.
Title: The production of new forms of perennial wheat.
Abstract Note: The properties of the first perennial wheats such as M34085 and M2, arising from crosses of winter bread-wheat with Agroypron glaucum, are described; being insufficiently hardy, they are grown as annuals, giving a yield of grain and several cuts of hay in the same season. Crossing M2 with other hybrids gave rise to certain selections of the wheat type, which were crossed again with other hybrids, as a result of which several promising hybrids have arisen, three of which had 37.6, 48.6 and 62.0% survival after three years of cropping; in these forms, the tillers formed after the grain ripens remain short and the plants are only 30-35 cm. high at the end of September, when those of M2 are 50-60 cm. ; in the spring they grow to 80-115 cm. and form 40-45 ears, those of M458 being closest to the wheat type; grain size increases in the second and third years, the grain having 22-25% of protein and up to 45% of raw gluten. The new forms, in contrast to M2, are predominantly self pollinated. Their yield diminishes in the fourth and later years.
Manual Tags: search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); WOS

Author: SULE, E. P.
Title: The production of perennial forms of wheat
Publication Title: Trudy Zonal Inst Zernovovo Khoziaistva Nechernozemnoi Polosy Sssr
Abstract Note: F1 hybrids between Triticum vulgare var. lutescens 0.62 and Agropvron glaucum, A. elongatum, A. trichophorum, A. junceum, and A. repens are perennial, vigorous, and survive for 5-6 years in the field under Moscow conditions. Although they were highly sterile, a few seeds were obtained from cross pollination. After repeated backcrossing onto wheat, plants of the F4 generation are only 1% perennial. Better results were obtained by using winter wheat with high regenerative ability, and by crossing F1 hybrids with relatively fertile, perennial plants of later generations. Among the plants of the F2 generation, 30 to 35% are sterile, and with a few exceptions grains of the fertile plants have no commercial value. In the F3 generation, particularly after intercrossing between F2 hybrids, a relatively high proportion of perennial plants with wheat-like grains was obtained. In the F4 generation, only 30% of the plants were perennial, but grain quality was good enough so that agronomically valuable selections could be made. Var. no. 34085, obtained from spring wheat Lutescens 0.62 x A. glaucum backgrossed to winter wheat Koopera-torka, has spikes with a mean length of 9.5 cm., 15-16 spikelets per spike, 3-5 grains per spikelet. Mean absolute wt. of grains is 32g. The milling and baking qualities of the grain resemble wheat vars. Milturum 0321 and Caesium 0111. Yield tests over 3 years in the Kazakh and Kirghiz republics have shown that under optimum conditions the yield for a single harvest is 33-37 centners/hectare (1 cent./hect. = 0.74 bushels/acre) and in 4 harvests over 2 yrs. 55 cent./hect. were obtained. In many expt. stations perennial wheat did not realize its full potentialities because of poor agricultural technique and insufficient watering. Several other new vars. are now being tested. || ABSTRACT AUTHORS: G. L. Stebbins, Jr
Manual Tags: search.grain; search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 grain); TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); WOS

Author: WHYTE, RO
Title: THE PROGRESSIVE DILUTION OF VARIABILITY
Publication Title: Indian Journal of Genetics and Plant Breeding

Author: TIUNOVA, N. A.
Title: The protein complex of wheat grains and changes produced in it by hybridization between wheat and another grass species Referat. Zhur., Biol., 1962, No. 18 G80. (Translation)
Publication Title: Tr Gl Bot Sada Akad Nauk Sssr
Abstract Note: Physical and chemical studies were made of the properties of the proteins of the grain of wheat variety Lutescens 329, quackgrass (Agropyron glaucum) and wheat-quackgrass hybrid M-2 (perennial wheat). The quackgrass grain showed a high (2:1) gliadine to gluteline ratio, as compared with a 1:1 gliadine: gluteline ratio in the wheat grain. The content of non-extractable N in the quackgrass flour was significantly higher than in the flour of grain from the wheat or the hybrid. The physical and chemical properties of the proteins of the wheat and quackgrass grains were quite similar. The only differences observed were in the quantitative relationships between the different fractions in the albumin and globulin preparations. No significant differences were found in the contents of the aromatic amino acids tyrosine and tryptophane or in the albumins, gliadines or glutelines of the wheat and quackgrass grains. In its content of different forms of N and in the properties of its proteins the wheat-quackgrass hybrid M-2 occupied an intermediate position between the parent forms, but more frequently showed a somewhat greater resemblance to wheat in its characteristics.
Manual Tags: search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); WOS

Author: MURAVIEV, P. A.
Title: The quality of the grain on the annual hybrid wheat Agropyrum of N. V. Tzitzin and the perennial wheat hybrid of A. I. Derjavin
Publication Title: Selektzia I Semenovodstvo [plant Breeding and Seed Growing]
Abstract Note: The grain of the Tzitzin annual wheat-Agropyrum hybrids, Nos. 22229, 22850, 23004, 23834, and 23823, is descr., with photographs of loaves and descriptions of the grain, flour, and bread-making quality. All hybrids gave good results, and the quality and volume of bread compared favorably with ordinary wheat bread. The test of the perennial hybrid of Derjavin was less conclusive; the bread was tasty, but of small volume and large pores and was inferior to that of the Ukrainka wheat. || ABSTRACT AUTHORS: J. W. Pincus

Author: SKRIPCHINSKY, VV
Title: THE RELATION BETWEEN THE WORK OF ORGANS OF VEGETATIVE PROPAGATION IN PERENNIAL AND ANNUAL CEREALS, AND THE PROCESS OF SEED FORMATION

Author: Whigham, D.F.; Simpson, R.L.
Title: The relationship between aboveground and belowground biomass of freshwater tidal wetland macrophytes
Abstract Note: Aboveground and belowground biomass relationships of 15 annual and perennial freshwater tidal wetland macrophytes were examined. The data showed that regression equations may be used with confidence to estimate belowground biomass from aboveground biomass for most species. The linear regression model was suitable except for one species which had a large belowground component and for which the exponential model was more appropriate. Belowground: aboveground biomass ratios were significantly different for the 8 annual species examined. At peak biomass, all annuals allocated less than one third of the total net annual production into belowground structures. They exhibited distinct seasonal patterns of biomass allocation with more biomass incorporated into belowground components during the early part of the growing season. Perennial species exhibited 4 patterns of biomass allocation with Peltandra virginica (L.) Kunth having a significantly greater mean belowground: aboveground biomass ratio than other perennials. Factors that may control biomass allocation patterns include depth of rooting and life history strategies.
Manual Tags: perennial W/1 (oryza OR rice); ScienceDirect; search.rice; SPV

Author: Thompson, T. N.; Rister, M. E.; Grant, W. R.; Klosterboer, A. D.; McCauley, G. N.; Stansel, J. W.; Krausz, J. P.; Drees, B. M.; Turner, F. T.; Bollich, C. N.; Marchetti, M. A.; Way, M. O.; Webb, B. D.; Whitney, N. G.; Pinson, S. R. M.; Schubert, C. R.
Title: The relationship between experimental plot research and Texas rice producers' ratoon field results
