Author: Sun, X. H.; Tian, Y. H.; Yang, H. L.; Zhang, Z. L.; Wang, H. X.; Ren, G. Z.; Zhang, M. R.
Title: The relationship between the height of the first cropped rice stubble and 32P utilization and economic characteristics of ratooning rice.
Publication Title: Application of Atomic Energy in Agriculture
Abstract Note: The relationship between the height of the 1st crop rice stubble of early cv. Shufeng No.1 ( Oryza sativa subsp. hsien Ting), the absorption and distribution of 32 P and the grain yield of ratooning rice were studied. Results indicated that as stubble height increased so absorption of 32 P increased yield of ratooning rice. Highest DW and radioactivity of the ratooning rice were obtained on the 3rd node in the treatments where the 1st (uppermost) or 2nd node were kept, while in the treatments where the 3rd or 4th node were kept, the max. value was obtained from the 4th node. Highest values for emergence rate, number of panicles and other characters of economic importance were obtained from the 3rd node in all treatments.
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: HARRISON, R. M.
Title: The relationship of herbage to soil in Romney Marsh
Publication Title: Jour S E Agric Coll Wye Kent
Abstract Note: It being broadly recognized that soil fertility and plant growth have a direct relationship to soil profile, 3 types of pastures in Romney Marsh, on as many different soil types, were studied. Two fattening types of pastures were used, the Finn supporting 12 sheep per acre, the New Romney, 10 per acre, and one breeding or non-fattening type on Hurst soils supporting 4-6 sheep per acre. Five fields each of the fattening types were used and 6 of the breeding; the fields were widely distributed over the marsh. The Percentage Area Method was used, the fields being divided into 10 parts and in each part the grasses in 10 random plots 6 inches square were intensively studied. The percentage of area each kind of grass covered was noted down to those covering .5%, and names of those covering a less area and the character of growth or tillering of the more important ones. The richer the pasture the fewer the kinds of grasses, the more freely they branched and the finer and closer the foliage. The principal grasses were perennial rye, bent, and wild white clover. || ABSTRACT AUTHORS: F. L. Muljord
Manual Tags: search.rye; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 ("rye" OR secale) NOT "rye$grass"); WOS

Author: Hesling, J.J.; Pawelska, K.; Shepherd, A.M.
Title: The response of potato root eelworm, heterodera rostochiensis wollenweber and beet eelworm, h. schachtii schmidt to root diffusates of some grasses, cereals and of tagetes minuta
Abstract Note: Three experiments failed to produce evidence that root diffusates from cereals and grasses stimulate eggs of Heterodera rostochiensis to hatch in vitro. Diffusate from Tagetes minuta, tested in one experiment, neither stimulated nor inhibited hatch. Diffusate from cereals, grasses and Tagetes minuta differed very little in effect from soil water. Diffusate from rye and perennial rye grass did not stimulate cysts of H. schachtii. The experiment emphasized the need to test diffusates over a range of dilutions.
Manual Tags: Scopus; search.rye; SPV; TITLE-ABS-KEY (perennial W/1 ("rye" OR secale) AND NOT ("rye?grass" OR ryegrass)) AND DOCTYPE (ar)

Author: KRUTIHOVSKII, V. K.
Title: The results of trials of Derzavin's perennial rye.
Abstract Note: Trials at the Dmitrovskii State Varietal Field, Moscow province, of a perennial rye bred by A. N. Derzavin suggest that this variety shows little promise north and east of Moscow.
Manual Tags: search.rye; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 ("rye" OR secale) NOT "rye$grass"); WOS

Author: HASHIOKA, Y.
Title: The rice stem nematode Ditylenchus angustus in Thailand.
Abstract Note: Ditylenchus angustus was found in paddy near Phathalung, southern Thailand. It attacked rice more seriously than did either Radopholus oryzae or Meloidogyne spp. and caused crop losses from 20 to 90%. Of the 5 varieties of rice grown in Thailand, Khao Tah Oo was the most resistant and Khao Tah Haeng 17 the most susceptible. The optimum temperature for infection by the nematode was 28 to 30°C., but the range of 27 to 28°C. was also very favourable, indicating that in tropical countries D. angustus finds suitable conditions for infection throughout the year. The soil conditions of rice paddy fields during fallow were ideal for the growth of nematodes but laboratory tests and the ecto-and euparasitic nature of D. angustus showed that soil transmission was impossible but survival of the eggs in the soil cannot be disregarded. The disease is spread mainly by nematodes in irrigation water and control methods should concentrate on eliminating other Oryza spp. which are the alternate hosts of D. angustus. Where Oryza is absent, infection is spread by ratoon rice plants and the remains of diseased plants. It is recommended that the rice be cut low, all stubble buried, crop remains burnt and all ratoon plants eliminated. S.W.A.
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: K-C, LO
Title: THE RICE TARSONEMID MITE STENEOTARSONEMUS-SPINKI
Abstract Note: In the laboratory, the rice tarsonemid mite S. spinki required .ltoreq. 3 and .gtoreq. 20 days to complete its development from egg to adult stage at 30.degree. and 20.degree. C, respectively. Each female laid 59.5 and 20.0 eggs at 30.degree. and 20.degree. C, respectively. S. spinki emerged during early May. Its population increased to a high level between Aug. and Oct., and declined until harvest. In the winter they survived in the stubbles and ratoon rices until late Feb. of the next year. The greater the planting density of rice, the higher the population of rice tarsonemid mite. The varieties of lower infestation were Chianung seen No. 11, Tainung No. 67, Kaohsiung sheuan No. 1 and Taichung sen No. 5; those of higher infestation were Kaohsiung sen No. 2, Taichung sen No. 2 and Tainan No. 5. Rice plants infested with S. spinki showed a significant increase in sterility rate and decrease in panicle neck. Rice tarsonemid mite was the main cause for the occurrence of empty head of rice plants. Predatory mites occurred all year. A protozoa parasitized each instar of the rice tarsonemid mite. The highest percentage of parasitism occurred in Oct. All recommended paddy field pesticides were highly toxic to the natural enemies of S. spinki, and had little effect on the S. spinki. This is probably why the rice tarsonemid mite has increased in recent years.
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: McKenzie, B. A.; Hill, G. D.; Ganeshan, V.; Yamoah, E.
Title: The role of legumes in improving nitrogen availability, soil fertility and growth in the following crop.
Abstract Note: Experiments were conducted on silt loam soils in New Zealand, which examined how inclusion of grain or perennial legumes in crop rotations influence crop yield and soil condition. The legumes were soil incorporated at various rates of dry matter (DM) or with or without harvesting of seed. Results showed that lupins ploughed intact into the soil could add up to 1.5 t of nitrogen (N) ha -1 and give yield of annual ryegrass ( Lolium multiflorum cv. Grasslands Moata), which were greater than those obtained from 200 kg of N ha -1. If seed was harvested, ryegrass yield after lupins was still equal to the yield from plots given 200 kg of N ha -1 (16.3 t ha -1). Incorporation of tagasaste ( Chameaecytisus palmensis) at 15 t DM ha -1 gave a yield of 25.4 t of maize DM ha -1. Under dryland conditions, tagasaste at 10 t ha -1 of DM produced significantly more maize DM than the control or plots, which received 200 kg N ha -1. Soil analyses showed that legume incorporation increased total soil N. Soil bulk density was reduced by tagasaste incorporation but not by grain legume incorporation. The results suggest that the crops were responding to N from the incorporated legume material in the same way as they respond to fertilizer N. However, both types of legumes, after incorporation, showed beneficial effects that were non-N related.
Manual Tags: search.grain; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 grain); WOS
Editor: Andrews, M.; Andrews, M. E.; Humphry, D. R.

Author: Fink-Gremmels, J.
Title: The role of mycotoxins in the health and performance of dairy cows
Abstract Note: In comparison to monogastric species, ruminant animals are generally considered to be less susceptible to the adverse effects caused by contamination of feeds with mycotoxins. This is based on the assumption that the rumen flora degrade and inactivate mycotoxins, thus protecting the animal. A number of mycotoxins, however, resist rumen degradation, causing distinct clinical signs of intoxication. Moreover, due to their complex diet, dairy cows may be exposed to a varying number of mycotoxins, originating from different feed materials such as roughage and concentrates. Exposure to these complex mixtures of mycotoxins may result in unexpected health risks. Due to a pre-existing negative energy balance, cows in the transition period are considered to be particularly sensitive to the exposure to feeds contaminated with moulds, fungal spores and mycotoxins.
Manual Tags: search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); WOS

Author: Sipos, Tamas; Halasz, Erika
Title: The role of perennial rye (Secale cereale x s. montanum) in sustainable agriculture
Manual Tags: search.rye; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 ("rye" OR secale) NOT "rye$grass"); WOS

Author: WIT, F.
Title: The role of polyploids in the improvement of ryegrasses and red clover.
Abstract Note: A preliminary account is given of some comparative trials of diploid and tetraploid red clover, perennial ryegrass and Italian ryegrass. Of the tetraploid red clover plants from which seed was harvested in 1952, 12% gave more than 4 g. of seed per plant, that is, more than the average seed yield of diploid plants. Of 21 families of tetraploid red clover which were compared with the original diploid material from which they were obtained, 7 were superior to the original material in respect of yield of green matter and winter hardiness; of these 7, 6 were from mother plants with a high seed production. In general, tetraploid perennial rye-grasses were less winter hardy and yielded less green matter than diploid plants, but the most productive and the most winter hardy tetraploids equalled the best diploids in these qualities. In a comparison of diploid and tetraploid Italian ryegrass there were more high yielding and fewer low yielding plants among the tetraploid group. Tetraploid Italian ryegrass plants also tended to be more winter hardy than the diploids.-W.J.B.
Manual Tags: search.rye; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 ("rye" OR secale) NOT "rye$grass"); WOS

Author: Pretorius, Z.A.; Bender, C.M.; Visser, B.
Title: The rusts of wild rye in South Africa
Abstract Note: AbstractBackground Secale strictum subsp. africanum, a self-fertile and perennial wild rye species, is endemic to the Roggeveld Mountains of the south-western Karoo, South Africa. Despite historical abundance on the Roggeveld plateau, S. strictum subsp. africanum is currently threatened with extinction. Many reasons have been given for its decline, including susceptibility to rusts. Methods Leaves with stem, leaf and stripe rust pustules were sampled from cultivated and naturally occurring S. strictum subsp. africanum on the farm Kanariesfontein near Sutherland. Identity of the rust pathogens was determined through infection and sequencing studies. Results Inoculation studies showed that stem and leaf rust collected from wild rye were avirulent on bread wheat, but virulent on Secale cereale. The stripe rust specimen was virulent on bread wheat and was identified as Puccinia striiformis race 6E16A−. Using ITS sequencing, the wild rye leaf rust specimen was confirmed as Puccinia recondita, and the stripe rust specimen as P. striiformis. ITS sequences did not distinguish between Puccinia graminis f. sp. tritici and Puccinia graminis f. sp. secalis, respectively the causal organisms of wheat and rye stem rust. Inoculation of wild rye plants with P. graminis f. sp. tritici proved its susceptibility to stem rust races attacking wheat and triticale. Conclusion This study established that S. strictum subsp. africanum is a host for both rye and wheat stem rust, rye leaf rust and wheat stripe rust.
Manual Tags: perennial W/1 ("rye" OR secale) AND NOT ("rye?grass" OR "ryegrass"); Roggeveld; Rust diseases; ScienceDirect; Scopus; search.rye; Secale strictum subsp. africanum; SPV; TITLE-ABS-KEY (perennial W/1 ("rye" OR secale) AND NOT ("rye?grass" OR ryegrass)) AND DOCTYPE (ar); TS=(perennial NEAR/1 ("rye" OR secale) NOT "rye$grass"); WOS

Author: Zabrodina, M. V.; Shadenkov, A. A.; Khavkin, E. E.
Title: The search for isoenzyme and DNA markers of the resistance of perennial rye to fungal diseases.
Abstract Note: The isoenzyme spectra of aspartate aminotransferases and esterases, and also those of the DNA amplification products from polymerase chain reaction, differed substantially in wild material of perennial rye ( Secale montanum) and Immunnaya 1, Immunnaya 2, and Immunnaya 3 selected for their resistance to leaf and stem rust ( Puccinia recondita and P. graminis), and to snow mold ( Tilletia).
Manual Tags: search.rye; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 ("rye" OR secale) NOT "rye$grass"); WOS

Author: Solodukhina, O. V.
Title: The search for sources of resistance to brown rust and powdery mildew in rye.
Publication Title: Sbornik Nauchnykh Trudov po Prikladnoi Botanike, Genetike i Selektsii
Abstract Note: In 1979-83, 247 populations of Soviet and foreign varieties and short-strawed hybrids, each consisting of 500 plants, were grown in Leningrad province and evaluated for field resistance. The highest number of plants exhibiting resistance to Puccinia dispersa [ P. recondita] was found in the fodder varieties Grunschnittroggen (56.4%), Zarechanskaya Zelenoukosnaya (42.5%) and Kustovka Mestnaya (21.6%). Of the perennial fodder varieties, the highest number of resistant plants (14.4%) was found in Derzhavinskaya 29 (with perennial Secale montanum in its parentage). The only plants with resistance to Erysiphe graminis were found in SCW5999 (81%), Halle (12%), Orlovskii Gibrid (0.2%) and Derzhavinskaya 29 (9.8%).
Manual Tags: search.rye; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 ("rye" OR secale) NOT "rye$grass"); WOS

Author: Chou, C.-H.; Chang, S.-J.; Cheng, C.-M.; Wang, Y.-C.; Hsu, F.-H.; Den, W.-H.
Title: The selective allelopathic interaction of a pasture-forest intercropping in Taiwan - II. Interaction between kikuyu grass and three hardwood plants
Abstract Note: An allelopathic interaction of a pasture-forest intercropping system was evaluated by field and greenhouse experiments and by laboratory assays. A study site was situated in the farm of Hoshe Forestry Experiment Station at Nantou County, Taiwan. After deforestation of Chinese fir (Cunninghamia lanceolata), a split plot design of 8 treatments was set up: open ground without planting as control, planted with kikuyu grass, planted with kikuyu grass and Alnus formosana, planted with kikuyu grass and Zelkova formosana, planted with kikuyu grass and Cinnamomum camphora, planted with A. formosana, planted with Z. formosana, and planted with C. camphora. Field measurements showed that weeds grew luxuriantly six months after treatment in plots which had not been planted with kikuyu grass. However, the growth of weeds was significantly retarded but that of woody plants was not affected when the plots were planted with kikuyu grass. As compared with the tap water control, the aqueous leachate of kikuyu grass stimulated the seedling growth of C. camphora and A. formosana, but the extract stimulated the growth of C. camphora and inhibited that of A. formosana. In contrast, the aqueous extracts of three hardwood plants exhibited variable inhibition on the root initiation of kikuyu grass, and the extract of Z. formosana revealed the highest phytotoxic effect. The aforementioned extracts and leachates were bioassayed against seed germination and radicle growth of four test plants, namely annual rye grass, perennial rye gras, tall fescue, and Chinese cabbage and against seedling growth of Miscanthus floridulus. The extract of Z. formosana revealed the highest phytotoxic effect on the test species while that of kikuyu grass showed the least effect. By means of paper chromatography and high performance liquid chromatography, phytotoxic phenolics were identified and the amount of phytotoxins present was highest in the extract of Z. formosana but was lowest in that of kikuyu grass. The degree of phytotoxicity and amount of phytotoxins was in good correlation, indicating that a selective allelopathic effect was involved. The findings suggest that allelopathy may contribute benefits in the intercropping system to reduce the need for herbicides and to lessen the labour cost for weed control.
Manual Tags: Allelopathy; Alnus formosana; Cinnamomum camphora; kikuyu grass; pasture-forest intercropping; Pennisetum clandestinum; phenolics; phytotoxins; Scopus; search.rye; SPV; TITLE-ABS-KEY (perennial W/1 ("rye" OR secale) AND NOT ("rye?grass" OR ryegrass)) AND DOCTYPE (ar); Zelkova formosana

Author: Shiou, D. C.; Wu, H. P.
Title: The sequential distribution of species in weed communities and the competition between ratoon rice and weeds.
Publication Title: Journal of Agricultural Research of China
Abstract Note: In a study of crop-weed competition in a ratoon rice crop, the sequential distribution of weed species was analysed statistically. Diversity indices of <0.6 derived from the Shannon equation suggested that the weed community of an abandoned rice field was still at an unstable stage. Further statistical analyses were preformed to characterize species dominance. Weeds belonging to the Gramineae and Rubiaceae predominated in the ratoon rice field. The 2 families were more competitive towards the ratoon rice and shattered rice populations, resp., as indicated by multiple regression analysis. The greater competitive influence on shattered rice than on ratoon rice is explained in terms of skewness of the distribution and the coeff. of variance.
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: Wisser, Dominik; Frolking, Steve; Douglas, Ellen M.; Fekete, Balazs M.; Schumann, Andreas H.; Vörösmarty, Charles J.
Title: The significance of local water resources captured in small reservoirs for crop production – A global-scale analysis
Abstract Note: Summary Rainwater harvesting, broadly defined as the collection and storage of surface runoff, has a long history in supplying water for agricultural purposes. Despite its significance, rainwater harvesting in small reservoirs has previously been overlooked in large-scale assessments of agricultural water supply and demand. We used a macroscale hydrological model, observed climate data and other physical datasets to explore the potential role of small, localized rainwater harvesting systems in supplying water for irrigated areas. We first estimated the potential contribution of local water harvesting to supply currently irrigated areas. We then explored the potential of supplemental irrigation applied to all cropland areas to increase crop evapotranspiration (or green water flow), using locally stored surface runoff in small reservoirs for different scenarios of installed reservoir capacity. The estimated increase in green water flow varied between 623 and 1122 km3 a−1. We assessed the implications of this increase in green water flows for cereal production by assuming a constant crop water productivity in areas where current levels of crop yield are below global averages. Globally, the supplemental irrigation of existing cropland areas could increase cereal production by ∼35% for a medium variant of reservoir capacity, with large potential increases in Africa and Asia. As small reservoirs can significantly impact the hydrological regime of river basins, we also assessed the impacts of small reservoirs on downstream river flow and quantified evaporation losses from small reservoirs.
Manual Tags: Crop yield; Food security; Global modelling; perennial W/1 (oryza OR rice); ScienceDirect; search.rice; Small reservoirs; SPV

Author: D, MILENA
Title: THE STABILIZATION OF AGRICULTURAL SYSTEMS IN THE DISTRICT OF CESKE BUDEJOVICE
Publication Title: Sbornik Agronomicka Fakulta v Ceskych Budejovicich Zootechnicka Rada
Abstract Note: The valuation of the stability of the farming systems in the district of Ceske Budejovice [Czechoslovakia] became a part of the analysis of the structure of these systems which was carried out in 1974-1980 using the methods of the system analysis according to the academician Kudrna. The differences between the maximum and minimum values and between the maximum and average values of chosen parameters, including yields of staple crops in 1974-1980 and 1981-1987, demonstrate the insufficient stability of the absolute majority of tested enterprises. The differences between the maximum and minimum yields in annual and perennial grasses, grain crops and potatoes are inadmissibly significant and they are higher than 40-50% in many enterprises. The results of analyses have discovered a considerable dependence of the yields of staple crops on the course of weather during separate years. Parameters of the structure of farming systems vary considerably with the unfavourable tendency to decrease the share of carbon source in the structure of crops. The change of the structure of crops leading to the raise of carbon sources, the adjustment of the share of annual and perennial grasses, the intensification of the effectiveness of mineral fertilizers.sbd.these are the preconditions both for the increase of the level of bioenergetical potential of soil and for the stabilization of farming systems.

Author: Esmaili, M.; Mobsser, H.; Abad, H. H. S.; Roshan, N. A.; Eftekhari, A.
Title: The study on the effect of plant residue management methods, Azolla and duck on weed characteristics, yield and harvest index in integrated culture of rice ratoon ( Oryza sativa).
Abstract Note: A study was conducted in Iran to investigate the effects of plant residue management methods (base cutting, common regional harvest and lock-lodging), with and without Azolla and ducks, on weed density as well as on yield and harvest index of rice cv. Tarom ratoon. The lock-lodging and common regional harvest methods had the highest and lowest weed populations, respectively. The number, height and dry weight of weeds were also decreased with Azolla and ducks. The weeds Cyperus rotundus, Echinochloa crus-galli and Typha latifolia caused the highest damage to the ratoon crop. The highest yield and harvest index were obtained from lock-lodging due to increased total number of productive tillers, number of panicles/m 2 and total number of spikelets per spike. The ducks also increased the grain yield of rice due to increases in these parameters and high 1000-grain weight. The highest harvest index was recorded with the integration of the lock-lodging method with Azolla and the ducks.
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: Warrington, I.J.; Mitchell, K.J.
Title: The suitability of three high intensity lamp sources for plant growth and development
Abstract Note: Three lamping systems were devised and evaluated for their suitability in providing energy for plant growth and development. These systems were based on three types of high-pressure vapour-discharge lamps (phosphor-coated mercury vapour, mercury iodide, and metal halide types) operated with red and blue wavelength supplementation. The vegetative growth responses of four plant species (sorghum, soybean, perennial ryegrass, and white clover) were examined. In general, plants grew equally well, and growth form and chemical composition were similar under all lighting systems. However, the metal halide lamp was found to be the most efficient tested and at the same time possessed the most uniform spectral distribution over the visible wavelength range.
Manual Tags: perennial W/1 sorghum; ScienceDirect; Scopus; search.sorghum; SPV; TITLE-ABS-KEY (perennial W/1 sorghum) AND DOCTYPE (ar); TS=(perennial NEAR/1 sorghum); WOS

Author: SZOKOLAY, G.
Title: The Swaziland Irrigation Scheme. 3. Ratooning of rice on the Swaziland Irrigation Scheme.
Abstract Note: An alternative to the ratooning system, which gives 2 rice crops per year, was investigated. In this, 2 good crops were obtained in 2 years from only one land preparation and planting operation. The main crop was planted in November, harvested in March, and the stubble left through the winter without irrigation. In the spring (September) the stubbles were irrigated and the subsequent ratoon crop harvested in January. In small-scale trials, yields from these ' spring ratoons ' were not much less than from their preceding planted crops. -M.P.
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); WOS

Author: Gandilyan, P. A.
Title: The systematics of the genus Secale L. and its diversity in the Armenian SSR. I. Specific differentiation.
Abstract Note: A revised classification, with synonymy, is presented for the genus. The known natural forms are grouped in four species: S. sylvestre, S. vavilovii s. l., S. montanum s. l. and S. cereale. It is further considered that artificially produced perennial cultivated rye of hybrid origin should be assigned to a separate species, S. X derzhavinii.

Author: RUDENKO, G. T.
Title: The system of farming in Altai
Abstract Note: It is stated that today Altai agriculture is confronted with 2 major tasks, viz., the doubling of the total production of cereal grains and a 3- to 4-fold increase in the production of meat, milk and other agricultural products. The achievement of this goal will require the production of 75-100 centners of meat and 16 centners of other agricultural products per hectare of arable land. Experimental data are presented which show that the yield of winter wheat was better in fields which had been planted in corn in the preceding year than in fields which had been planted in perennial grasses. A great deal of data also is cited showing that the productivity of the land in terms of animal fodder can be increased greatly by using the new crop rotation system of successive plantings of legumes, corn and wheat or other cereal grains instead of the old system of grassland farming involving the periodic planting of fields in perennial grasses. The article is concluded with a paragraph emphasizing the necessity of using the most scientific methods of soil cultivation for the control of weed growth. || ABSTRACT AUTHORS: R. E. Asnis
Manual Tags: search.grain; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 grain); WOS

Author: Beresford, N.A.
Title: The transfer of Ag-110m to sheep tissues
Abstract Note: The transfer of Ag-110m from the Chernobyl fallout to sheep tissues is discussed. Ag-110m was only detected in the liver and occasionally the brain of the sheep analysed. The transfer of Ag-110m associated with perennial rye-grass, harvested soon after deposition in 1986, was greater to the liver of both ewes and lambs than that of Cs-137. Transfer coefficients of Ag-110m for lamb liver exceeded those for ewe livers. However, in a 1987 field study there was no difference between transfer coefficients of Ag-110m for ewes and lambs. It is suggested that there is a slow turnover of Ag-110m in the liver of sheep and that unlike radiocaesium, Ag-110m from the Chernobyl fallout did not become more available once incorporated into plant tissues.
Manual Tags: perennial W/1 ("rye" OR secale) AND NOT ("rye?grass" OR "ryegrass"); ScienceDirect; search.rye; SPV

Author: KEVORKOV, A. P.; PCHELKIN, V. U.
Title: The use of farmyard manure-lime composts and mixtures.
Publication Title: Byulleten' Vsesoyuznogo Nauchno-Issledovatel'skogo instituta Udobrenii   agrotekhniki i Agropochvovedeniya
Abstract Note: Addition of lime to a compost heap consisting of cow manure (85%), rye straw (15%) and super (1 quintal per 10 tons manure) at rates of 5% and 10% by weight decreased N losses from 40.5 to 29.4 and 22.6 respectively. This decrease appears to be due to the delaying effect of Ca on urea decomposition. Increasing the proportion of straw from 15 to 30% reduced N loss from 40.5 to 26.3% and supplementary addition of super reduced it to 19.1%. In field experiments with rye and perennial grasses, comparing the manurial value of composts with varying amounts of lime added (2.5, 5 and 10% by weight) the highest yield increases were with 5% lime.
Manual Tags: search.rye; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 ("rye" OR secale) NOT "rye$grass"); WOS

Author: Kashbulgayanov, R.
Title: The use of late summer green manure crops in the complex mechanization of soya cultivation in the conditions of Amurskaya Oblast'.
Abstract Note: Amurskaya Oblast', in Russia's Far East region, has suitable soil and climate conditions (including temperature and rainfall in late summer and autumn) for late summer green manure crops to be included in crop rotations. In designing and introducing crop rotations, preference needs to be given to relatively short rotations, which can be modified if necessary. High soil fertility can be assured through the use of perennial grasses, intermediate green manure crops, stubble residues and straw. For farms with relatively small land areas, three-four field rotations may be used, for example: (1) fallow-soya-early cereal crop; (2) wheat and perennial grasses-soya-early cereal crop; and (3) oats (partly as late summer green manure crop)-soya-wheat-soya. The third crop rotation system has been used for five years at SKhPK Start (Ivanovskii raion, Amurskaya Oblast'), and has ensured good conditions for cultivation of soya crops. This rotation has an advantage in ensuring a positive humus balance and has resulted in stable soya harvests. Field trials carried out between 1999 and 2002 at OOO Amurskaya Niva, in southern Amurskaya Oblast', compared the effectiveness of different green manure crops (soya, rape and oats) and wheat straw for preparation of soils to be used for cultivation of soya of the Sonata variety. The highest soya crop yields (2140kg/ha) were obtained on soils on which oats had been grown as a green manure crop. Optimum conditions for the use of oats as a green manure crop are outlined, including tilling, sowing, rolling, disking and ploughing in processes. Using green manure crops such as oats is an environmentally friendly alternative to fertilizer application, and can be used as part of an organic farming system.
Manual Tags: search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); WOS

Author: Anonymous
Title: THE USES OF SORGHUM SPP.
Abstract Note: THE USES OF SORGHUM SPP. for marginal areas or land difficult to cultivate are advocated by A. F. and E. M. de Ledesma (of Campo La Union, Ceres F.C.C.A., Argentina) who claim that the forage sorghums can replace alfalfa and that the grain sorghums can replace maize. The abundance of sorghums compensates for their pound to pound inferiority to alfalfa or maize. Where an acre of sorghum can produce 10 bushels it will fatten a steer better than the same acre producing 5 bushels of maize. Further, 5 bushels of maize per acre is not an economic crop, but 5 bushels of sorghum is, because it can be pastured, thus avoiding harvest expenses. The central part of Argentina, famous for producing some of the finest beef, comprises barely one quarter of the whole country. The marginal land, shading into desert, is faced with a problem that cannot be solved by alfalfa. Sorghum, like any other plant, has its difficulties, and to meet them special machinery, special rotations and methods have been devised. Furthermore, a perennial sorghum-Columbus grass, S. almum has been developed. This is interesting as a perennial crop has enormous advantages in economy over an annual. Many thousands of acres of this seed have been sown during the last 5 years in these marginal lands, and it is expected to do for them what alfalfa has done for the inside cattle zone. Districts hitherto looked upon as semi-desert are now producing rich milk and fat cattle. It has also been found that where the rainfall is over 30 inches it is possible to sow without ploughing, provided the seed has some cover and defence against animals for the first 2 months of its life. This is useful in uncleared land. The question of altitude may be a limiting factor, though temperature is of primary consideration. In Argentina, sorghum has been sown up to 1500 feet.- The Spectator July 8, 1949.-M.H.
Manual Tags: search.sorghum; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 sorghum); WOS

Author: ZOERB, C.
Title: The virgin land territory: plans, performance, prospects.
Abstract Note: In 1963 Khrushev reported that over 42 million hectares of virgin and idle land had been brought under the plough since 1954. The changes in crop land in the principal geographic regions since 1953 are analysed to provide a measure of the impact of the programme on agricultural potential. The Tselinny Krai (Virgin Land Territory) is selected as the model for a comparative study of the potential of the Soviet drive to solve the perennial grain problem; this area was chosen because of its relative compactness and homogeneity of resources and its reliance on a monolithic crop structure based on spring wheat. The area is compared with Saskatchewan, another virgin territory. It is shown that yield in the Virgin Land territory is much below that of Saskatchewan, and is not likely to catch up in the next decade or two. Unless existing cropping practices are altered it is held that no improvement can be expected and that long term effects will be disastrous. While the Virgin Land programme was politically successful, the grain average over the ten-year period indicates that prime production costs were approximately covered, but that aggregate costs of the programme exceed returns. It is held that in the short run the venture was economically advantageous; that it was in part responsible for the overall rise in agricultural output, and that it spread the risks inherent in Soviet farming. However, since 1959, there has been a sharp regression; yields have persistently declined, dust storms have been frequent and most farms have operated at a loss. It is concluded that to restore the consequences of a decade of monoculture farming will take time, new technology, and a continuous and massive flow of capital into the new lands. A commentary on the paper by K. E. Bush is appended. A. T. S.
Manual Tags: search.grain; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 grain); WOS

Author: MASALOV, V. F.
Title: The water balance of gray forest soils under field rotations.
Abstract Note: During 1959-60 the moisture content of heavy-loam gray forest soils was determined in various fields of rotation of fallow, wheat, perennial grasses, maize, vetch-oat mixtures, potatoes. The most favourable hydrophysical properties were possessed by soil of fallow fields & maize fields. Moisture content of the soils depends on the length of time plants have occupied the field, method of cultivation, initial moisture content of the soil, meteorological conditions & transpiration.
Manual Tags: search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); WOS

Author: BURNACKII, D. P.; SUCALKINA, M. I.
Title: The water regime oi the soil of the Stony Steppe in dry years.
Abstract Note: In the Stony Steppe observations have been made on soil moisture conditions chiefly in connexion with agrotechnical questions and only recently has the water regime of soils been studied in relation to ley farming. . The work here is concerned with the very dry year, 1946, and 1947 when there was deficient moisture during the vegetative period. The water regime of the soil was studied under the following rotation, located in the open steppe and also in an area protected by a shelter-belt: (1) herbage; (2) spring wheat (in perennial herbage); (3) spring wheat (on ploughed soil); (4) sunflower; (5) oats; (6) bare fallow; and (7) winter wheat with undersowing of herbage. With the onset of drought in both years the soil dried and crop yields were lowered but less so in the protected sowings. There is indication, further, that the herbage in the rotation made more efficient use of winter precipitation.-M.H.
Manual Tags: search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); WOS

Author: CHUMAKOV, A. E.
Title: The winterkill of seedlings of winter crops The distribution of pests and diseases of agricultural plants in the USSR in 1960 and a prediction of their occurrence in 1961 Referat. Zhur., Biol., 1962, No. 18G473. (Translation)
Abstract Note: The winterkill of seedlings of winter crops is caused by a combination of a number of biological factors and climate and soil conditions involved in the hibernation of herbaceous plants. Two basic diseases are involved: snow mold and sclerotinosis. These diseases usually are disseminated in the non-chernozem zone. However, sclerotinosis also is found in the Siberian agricultural belt from the Urlas to Kamchatka. The plants which are susceptible to this disease are: winter wheat; rye; perennial grasses; and weeds of the grass family. The last outbreak of snow mold was observed in 1957.

Author: CICIN, N. V.; KRYZANOVSKII, F. D.
Title: The winter Wheat- Agropyron Hybrid 1.
Abstract Note: At the Snigiri research station, the hardiness of Hybrid 1 (cf. PBA, Vol. XXIII, Abst. 2560) and its resistance to snow mould are being improved. Hybrid 1 was obtained from a cross between the perennial wheat 34085/34 and a Swedish winter type referred to as Chef-d'oeuvre, which is noted for its large grain, productive ears and resistance to lodging. The perennial form, which was selected from the progeny of a cross between an unspecified wheat variety and an Agropyron species, is described as winter hardy and immune from fungous diseases.

Author: SUDNOV, P. E.
Title: The work of the breeder A. I. Derzavin at the Exhibition.
Abstract Note: The best selections from the hybrids of wheat with perennial rye are now free from sterility and exceed Ukrainka in yield of good plump grain and produce a quantity of herbage which can be used for feeding stock. Forms free from shattering have now been selected. The hybrids are almost equal to Ukrainka in baking quality and excel it in protein content by 2.5 per cent. Reference is also made to hybrids between perennial rye and perennial sorghum.

Author: MIKHAILOVSKII, V.
Title: The work of the Voroshiiovsk official breeding station.
Abstract Note: The method of producing the seeds of varieties designed for each of the three climatic zones served by the Station in the zone itself, according to the principles of Lysenko, is being applied. The varieties are subjected to intravarietal crossing and rigorous selection under intensive conditions of cultivation. Crosses have also been made between the local wheats and imported American varieties, whereby forms of increased resistance to yellow and brown rust and of improved yield have been obtained. Experiments are also being made on the production of perennial wheats by crossing wheats with perennial rye, and of perennial forms of other crops.

Author: Muldoon, D.K.
Title: The yield, quality and profitability of annual forage, perennial pasture and perennial forage systems under irrigation
Abstract Note: Intensive fodder production systems were compared under irrigation in western New South Wales. The three basic systems studied were: 1. (1) Annual forages (Sorghum bicolor × S. sudanense plus Avena sativa). 2. (2) Perennial pasture (Paspalum dilatatum). 3. (3) Perennial forage (Medicago sativa). The first two systems included nitrogen fertilizer or legume options, while the last had the option of including a perennial sorghum. Dry matter production was highest in the annual forage system (maximum of 30·5 tonnes ha-1 year-1), although annual establishment costs were higher than for perennial systems. The perennial pasture yielded 21·5 tonnes ha-1 year-1 but, like the annual forage system, 250 kg N ha-1 year-1 was required to obtain this yield. The perennial forage yielded 19·8 tonnes ha-1 year-1 without nitrogen fertilizer. Furthermore, it yielded more digestible dry matter and nitrogen than any other system. Although the annual forage system was the most profitable when based upon a set price for hay, the best system for grazing was difficult to determine; factors relating to grazing management are discussed.

Author: Escalada, R. G.
Title: Tillering and ratoon cropping of grain sorghum (Sorghum bicolor (Linn.) Moench).
Abstract Note: In trials in which 10 grain sorghum hybrids were ratooned several times by cutting to 3, 8 or 13 cm and were given 0, 100, 200 or 250 kg N/ha, plant height decreased with increasing plant density. The most uniform tiller production was given by cutting to 8 cm. Cutting to 3 cm gave the greatest number of basal tillers but disease organisms entered the short stubble easily. Cutting to 13 cm gave uneven tillering and adventitious roots did not always reach ground level. Grain yields increased with increased rate of applied N and during winter the highest yields were given by cutting to 13 cm and applying 200-250 kg N/ha, while in summer yields were highest with cutting to 3 or 8 cm with the same rates of N. The best cutting height was 8 cm in all plots given N. In trials with 6 hybrids grown at 8 plant densities, the highest grain and stover yields were given by 200 000 plants/ha. In trials with shading and in growth chambers, tillering was decreased by high temperatures, short days and low light intensity, and low light intensity decreased yields.
Manual Tags: search.sorghum; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 sorghum); WOS

Author: DETISTOVA, R. N.
Title: Timetables and methods for sowing rice in the northern part of Volga-Akhtubinskiy Bottom Land under conditions of periodical irrigation
Publication Title: Sbornik Nauchn Rabot Stud Stalingr S Kh Inst
Abstract Note: The work was conducted by the Experimental Improvement Station of Stalingrad. On clean, well-cultivated soils, the highest yield was obtained by uniform sowing. Weed-choked ground required wide row single strips. Early dates for sowing rice are recommended solely in cultivations over perennial grasses and on virgin soil. Generally, the best date for sowing appears to be about May 20. || ABSTRACT AUTHORS: Transl. from Referat. Zhur. Biol. 34669, 1958, courtesy OTS-JPRS

Author: Johnson, D.E; Wopereis, M.C.S; Mbodj, D; Diallo, S; Powers, S; Haefele, S.M
Title: Timing of weed management and yield losses due to weeds in irrigated rice in the Sahel
Abstract Note: The effects of differing periods of weed management were studied in experiments in five farmers’ direct-seeded, irrigated rice (Oryza sativa L.) fields during the 1999 wet season (1999WS) and seven fields during the 2000 dry season (2000DS) in the Senegal River delta. Ten weed management treatments were used to identify critical periods of competition and to enable the development of more precise management recommendations. Rice yields in 1999WS ranged from 3.2 t ha−1 with no weed control to 6.3 t ha−1 in weed-free plots; a yield loss of 49%. Major weed species encountered in 1999WS were Bolboschoenus maritimus, Oryza longistaminata, Cyperus difformis and Echinochloa colona. In 2000DS, C. difformis dominated the weed flora, and rice yields ranged from 3.7 t ha−1 with no weed control to 7.9 t ha−1 in weed-free plots; a yield loss of 47%. To assess the effects of weed biomass on the rice crop over time a linear mixed model was used. This highlighted the importance of E. colona and C. difformis in the wet and dry seasons, respectively, and of O. longistaminata in both seasons. The presence of E. colona early in the crop seemed related to greater levels of rice biomass in 1999WS, while O. longistaminata always had a negative effect on crop growth even at relatively low levels of infestation. Gompertz and logistic equations were fitted to data representing increasing periods of weed-free growth and weed interference, respectively. Critical periods for weed control, obtaining 95% of a weed-free yield, were estimated as between 29 to 32 days after sowing (DAS) in the WS and 4 to 83 DAS in the DS. The lower temperatures in the early DS resulted in slower growth of rice and weeds, delaying the effects of competition. Weed competition either before or after these critical periods had negligible effects on crop yield.
Manual Tags: Critical period; Lowland; perennial W/1 (oryza OR rice); ScienceDirect; search.rice; SPV; Weed competition; Yield loss

Author: Ong, C. K.; Daniel, J. N.
Title: Traditional crop sparks new interest as a multipurpose tree.
Abstract Note: An account of the use of perennial pigeon pea ( Cajanus cajan) as a multipurpose tree, suitable as a component of agroforestry systems in the tropics and subtropics. Notes are given on the characteristics and uses (as food, fodder, green manure, fuelwood, thatching and baskets) of the species, its contribution to soil improvement, studies on phenology and yield potential, spacing and fertilizer requirements, crop combinations and management, weed and pest control, harvesting and research.
Manual Tags: search.pigeonpea; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (cajanus OR "pigeon$pea")); WOS

Author: Meyfroidt, Patrick; Vu, Tan Phuong; Hoang, Viet Anh
Title: Trajectories of deforestation, coffee expansion and displacement of shifting cultivation in the Central Highlands of Vietnam
Abstract Note: Abstract Production of commodities for global markets is an increasingly important factor of tropical deforestation, taking over smallholders subsistence farming. Measures to reduce deforestation and convert shifting cultivation systems towards permanent crops have recently been strengthened in several countries. But these changes have variable environmental and social impacts, including on ethnic minorities. In Vietnam, although a forest transition – i.e. shift from shrinking to expanding forest cover – occurred at the national scale, deforestation fronts and agricultural colonization for commodity crops – a.o. coffee – still dominated the Central Highlands plateaus. Previous studies suggested that the dominant land use changes in that region were on the one hand the acquisition and conversion of agricultural lands to perennial crops for external markets by capital-endowed Kinh households – the majority ethnic group in Vietnam – and on the other hand the corresponding displacement of poor households of ethnic minorities relying on shifting cultivation towards the forest margins. This study tested this hypothesis by using remote sensing to analyze land use and cover changes and deforestation trajectories in the coffee-growing area in Dak Lak and Dak Nong provinces over 2000–2010. Land use changes were linked with socioeconomic dynamics using secondary statistics and spatial modelling. Net deforestation reached −0.31% y−1 of the total area between 2000 and 2010. Deforestation was indeed mainly directly caused by shifting cultivation for annual crops, but this was partly driven indirectly by expansion of coffee and other perennial crops over agricultural lands. Displacement of shifting cultivation into the forest margins, pushed by market crops expansion, was the spatial manifestation of the marginalization of local ethnic minorities and poor migrants, pushed by capital-endowed migrants. This marginalization is a long-standing process rooted in the colonization and development strategy for the highlands followed since colonial times. Over the late 2000s, rapid deforestation was strongly reducing the benefits of national-scale forest recovery, and might shift the country back to net losses of natural forest. Implications for policies that may affect deforestation are discussed.
Manual Tags: Agricultural commodity booms; Ethnic marginalization; Land use policies; perennial W/1 (oryza OR rice); REDD+; Remote sensing; ScienceDirect; search.rice; SPV

Author: Hensgens, L.a.m.; Kooman-Gersmann, M.; Veen, S. van der.; Schilperoort, R.a.; Hart, L.; Maas, H.M. van der.; Os-Ruygrok, E.P. van.; Bakker, E.P.H.M. de.; Mark, F. van de.; Rueb, S.
Title: Transcient and stable expression of gusA fusions with rice genes in rice, barley and perennial ryegrass
Abstract Note: Transcriptional and translational fusions were made between the reading frame coding for  beta-D-glucuronidase and sequences of either a constitutively expressed rice gene (GOS2) involved  in initiation of translation or a light-inducible rice gene (GOS5). The transient expression of  the fusions was studied via particle bombardment of seedling tissues of rice, perennial ryegrass  and barley. Furthermore, the results of transient and stable expression were compared for cell  suspensions of four rice varieties, one barley variety and one perennial ryegrass variety. The  GOS2-gusA fusions were active in all three monocots studied. Best results were obtained for a  construct having both a transcriptional and a translational fusion as well as intron and exon  sequences (PORCEHyg). The level of GUS activity was in the range of activities as obtained by the  35S CaMV promoter transcriptionally fused to gusA. The gusA fusion with the light-inducible gene  (GOS5) was active in green seedling tissues of all monocots studied. Also a weak expression  compared to the GOS2 constructs was found in stably transformed rice callus. The gusA fusions with  the mannopine synthase promoters 1' and 2' of the T(R)-DNA were transiently expressed at lower  levels in cell suspensions than PORCEHyg. For stably transformed rice callus the expression of  the GOS2-gusA fusion often decreased during prolonged subculture. This decrease in GUS activity  and the various GUS-staining phenotypes of transgenic calli are explained by the presence of  different cell types in the suspensions used and in the calli. It is presumed that the nature of  the cells and their relative contribution in the calli change drastically upon further subculture.
Manual Tags: AGRICOLA; search.rice; SPV; TX (perennial N1 (oryza OR rice))
Automatic Tags: beta-glucuronidase; callus; gene expression; genetic transformation; Hordeum vulgare; introns; Lolium perenne; Oryza sativa; plant proteins; promoter regions; recombinant DNA; reporter genes; transgenic plants

Author: SOKOLOVA, S. M.
Title: Transformation of the nitrogenous substances of perennial wheat ( Tri-ticum agropyrotriticum perenne).
Publication Title: Bjull. Moskov. Obscest. Ispyt. Prirody Otdel. Biol. (Bull. Moscow Soc.   Naturalists, Biol. Div.).
Abstract Note: Nitrogenous substances in leaves and grain of a perennial wheat (Lutescens 329 x Agropyron glaucum[Elymus hispidus] hybrid) were estimated at different stages of plant development. The water-soluble protein fractions decreased and the salt- and alkali-soluble protein fractions increased as the leaves aged.-J.P.

Author: Bhuiyan, M.A.R.; Narimah, M.K.; Rahim, H. Abdul; Abdullah, M.Z.; Wickneswari, R.
Title: Transgressive variants for red pericarp grain with high yield potential derived from Oryza rufipogon × Oryza sativa: Field evaluation, screening for blast disease, QTL validation and background marker analysis for agronomic traits
Abstract Note: Five transgressive variants (advanced breeding lines from BC2F5 and BC2F6 generation) were derived from a cross between the wild relative, O. rufipogon Griff. and O. sativa L. subsp. indica cv. MR219, a popular high yielding Malaysian rice cultivar. The aim of the study was to evaluate the pericarp colour of the grains along with yield potential and to validate quantitative trait loci (QTLs) for agronomic traits. The variants were screened against blast disease. Background marker analysis was also done for the promising variants. The field trials were carried out at a single location (due to containment purposes) over two seasons using randomized complete block design (RCBD) with three replications. A trait-based marker analysis was used to identify QTLs for validation in BC2F5 generation. Analysis of variance (ANOVA) showed that the seasonal factors influenced different agronomic traits. Variant G33 produced significantly (p < 0.05) higher yield (5.20 t/ha) than the control, MR219 (4.53 t/ha). Eighteen QTLs for different agronomic traits were identified in BC2F2 population in a previous study. Among them 14 QTLs were found in BC2F5 population of the present study. The yield of variant G33 was influenced by several QTLs viz. qGPL-1, qSPL-1-2, qSPL-8 and qYLD-4, which were introgressed from the donor parent revealed by background marker analysis using BC2F7 generation. Percentage (99%) of red pericarp grain of G33 and G34 in BC2F5 and BC2F6 generations indicated the stability of pericarp colour which was transferred from the wild relative. Variant G33 showed resistance against two pathotype of blast disease (Magnaporthe oryzae). Among the evaluated variants, G33 could be considered for inclusion in the cultivar development program for red rice with high yield potential and resistance to blast disease. This study demonstrated that the alleles from wild relative could improve the yield and yield related traits through allelic interaction, even though the phenotypic traits were inferior to the recurrent parent.
Manual Tags: Background marker analysis; Oryza rufipogon; Oryza sativa; perennial W/1 (oryza OR rice); Quantitative trait loci; ratoon* W/5 (oryza OR rice); Red pericarp; ScienceDirect; search.rice; SPV; Trait-based marker analysis; Transgressive variants

Title: Transient and stable expression of gusA fusions with rice genes in rice, barley and perennial ryegrass
Abstract Note: Transcriptional and translational fusions were made between the reading frame coding for beta-D-glucuronidase and sequences of either a constitutively expressed rice gene (GOS2) involved in initiation of translation or a light-inducible rice gene (GOS5). The transient expression of the fusions was studied via particle bombardment of seedling tissues of rice, perennial ryegrass and barley. Furthermore, the results of transient and stable expression were compared for cell suspensions of four rice varieties, one barley variety and one perennial ryegrass variety. The GOS2-gusA fusions were active in all three monocots studied. Best results were obtained for a construct having both a transcriptional and a translational fusion as well as intron and exon sequences (PORCEHyg). The level of GUS activity was in the range of activities as obtained by the 35S CaMV promoter transcriptionally fused to gusA. The gusA fusion with the light-inducible gene (GOS5) was active in green seedling tissues of all monocots studied. Also a weak expression compared to the GOS2 constructs was found in stably transformed rice callus. The gusA fusions with the mannopine synthase promoters 1' and 2' of the TR-DNA were transiently expressed at lower levels in cell suspensions than PORCEHyg. For stably transformed rice callus the expression of the GOS2-gusA fusion often decreased during prolonged subculture. This decrease in GUS activity and the various GUS-staining phenotypes of transgenic calli are explained by the presence of different cell types in the suspensions used and in the calli. It is presumed that the nature of the cells and their relative contribution in the calli change drastically upon further subculture.

Author: Bozzini, A.; Gallo, M. del
Title: Two strategic objectives for the development of sustainable food production: crops with a perennial habit and with N 2 fixation.
Abstract Note: This paper provides an overview of current cropping practices in terms of input utilization and environmental impact, and describes the potential of cultivating perennial crops and harnessing biological N fixation as more efficient strategies to sustainable food production. Progress in the development of perennial cereals, grain legumes and oilseed plants through breeding, and advances in research on N fixation by endogenous bacteria and other bacteria associated with perennial crops are briefly discussed.

Author: Sánchez, E.; Espinoza, A.M.
Title: Ultrastructure of Oryza glumaepatula, a wild rice species endemic of tropical America
Abstract Note: Oryza glumaepatula is a perennial wild rice species, endemic to tropical America, previously known as the Latin American race of Oryza rufipogon. In Costa Rica, it is found in the northern region of the country, mainly in the wetland of the Medio Queso River, Los Chiles, Alajuela. It is diploid, of AA type genome and because of its genetic relatedness to cultivated rice it is included in the O. sativa complex. We describe the ultrastructure of leaf blade, spikelet, ligule and auricles. Special emphasis is given to those traits of major taxonomic value for O. glumaepatula and to those characters that distinguish this species from O. rufipogon and O. sativa. O. glumaepatula has a leaf blade covered with tombstone-shaped, oblong and spheroid epicuticular wax papillae. It has diamond-shaped stomata surrounded by spherical papillae, rows of zipper-like silica cells, bulky prickle trichomes of ca. 40 μm in length and small hirsute trichomes of ca. 32 μm in length. The central vein is covered with large, globular papillae of ca. 146 μm in length, a characteristic that distinguishes this species from O. rufipogon and O. sativa. The border of the leaf blade exhibits a row of even-sized bulky prickle trichomes of ca. 42.5 μm in length. Auricles have attenuated trichomes of ca. 5.5 mm in length on the edges and small bicellular trichomes of 120 μm in length on the surface. The ligule has a large number of short attenuated trichomes on its surface of 100 μm in length. These latter two traits have important taxonomic value since they were found in O. glumaepatula but not found in O. sativa or in O. rufipogon. The spikelet has the typical morphology of the Oryza genus. Fertile lemmas have abundant spines, a trait shared with O. rufipogon but not with O. sativa. The sterile lemmas are wing-shaped with serrated borders, a characteristic that distinguishes this species from O. rufipogon and O. sativa. All the ultrastructure characters observed in O. glumaepatula from Costa Rica are also common to the specimens from Brazil.
Manual Tags: Anatomy; Morphology; Oryza; Oryza glumaepatula; Oryzeae; Poaceae; Rice; Scopus; search.rice; SPV; TITLE-ABS-KEY (perennial W/1 (oryza OR rice)) AND DOCTYPE (ar); TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (oryza OR rice)); Ultrastructure; WOS

Author: Buddenhagen, I.
Title: Understanding strain diversity in Fusarium oxysporum f. sp. cubense and history of introduction of 'tropical race 4' to better manage banana production.
Abstract Note: Fusarium wilt of banana is caused by 35 different strains or genotypes of Fusarium oxysporum f. sp. cubense. VCG 01213, so-called 'tropical race 4', is just one of six distinct strains that can attack Cavendish, but it is much more aggressive on Cavendish than strains known earlier in Australia and South Africa. New plantations established in the 1990s in peninsula Malaysia and Sumatra soon succumbed. VCG 01213 was later found to be common in village banana plants in those areas. It is only one of eight strains present in the villages. It is not a new mutant strain but is only newly recognised as unique. The combination of many strains and many different cultivars in mixed plantings allows sufficient banana production for home use. Yet attempts to grow Cavendish in plantation fail within a few years of establishment. Commercial Cavendish production in Taiwan, where strain VCG 01213 is present, is possible only by planting partially resistant Cavendish mutants in rotation with paddy rice and ratooning only twice. Even so, losses continue and costs are high. Permanent commercial plantations are no longer economic in areas where VCG 01213 is found. However, surveys indicate this pathogen is not ubiquitous. VCG 01213 was recently introduced into the Northern Territory of Australia, where eradication was attempted. This involved investigation of source, elimination of entire banana fields, isolation of sites, no replanting and tight quarantine. The situation here is not confounded by 'village banana plants' and is simplified by isolation and distance from the country's main banana-growing areas. In the Philippines and China, the disease now occurs in plantations situated within large areas of commercial banana production. The threat was at first not taken seriously and strain identification was delayed. Spread has occurred very rapidly in South China and less so in the Philippines. The VCG 01213 pathosystem is virtually unstudied, and its biology and epidemiology unknown. The results of experimental studies in Sumatra on incidence, treatment with endophytes and antagonists, cassava rotation, timing of infection, root invasion and breeding for resistance are reported. Rotation with cassava appears promising.
Manual Tags: search.rice; SPV; TS=(ratoon* NEAR/5 (oryza OR rice)); WOS
Editor: Jones, D.; van der Bergh, I.

Author: RAMIREZ, D. A.; DUMLAO, R. C.
Title: Uniformity in maturity of two rice varieties grown as transplanted ratoon
Abstract Note: Transplanted basal tillers of Peta and Tjere mas were as uniform in maturity as the seedling crop. The basal tillers matured 14 to 20 days earlier than the seedling crops. The transplanted runners were less uniform in maturity but were also earlier-maturing than the "dapog"-raised seedling crop by 12 to 17 days. With Tjere mas, both the transplanted basal tillers and runners gave higher yields than the seedling crops. With Peta, comparison of relative yields was duplicated by the differential effects of lodging at different stages of maturity. The asexually propagated plants were generally shorter than the seedling plants. || ABSTRACT AUTHORS: Authors

Title: Untersuchungen uber Futterwert und Nahrstoffbedarf von Huhnerweiden

Station) of extensive investigations, including a review of literature, on the nutritive value of poultry ranges and their need of fertilization. The investigations comprised a study of the growth and egg production of chickens on different types of pasture, under several conditions of management and fertilization, as compared with chickens under strict confinement. Author: Arraudeau, M.A.
Title: Upland rice: Challenges and opportunities in a less favorable ecosystem
Abstract Note: IRRI's upland rice research has made progress in solving some of the dilemmas in the upland rice ecosystem, although many challenges remain. IRRI researchers are gaining a better understanding of the ecosystem's constraints, opportunities, and research approaches. Cultivar improvement, use of farmer participatory methods to reduce erosion, and weed management are areas where research advances are being made. Developing perennial upland rice and managing weeds using less herbicide are exciting new projects being pursued. Enhancing rice productivity is seen as an entry point to alleviating the interrelated problems of declining productivity, lack of sustainability, and poverty in the uplands. Delay can irreparably damage the uplands and gravely affect the people who depend on them for survival.

Author: Pillay, A. R.
Title: Upland rice in interrows of ratoon sugarcane in Mauritius.
Abstract Note: Of four varieties (grown in two groups of three at two sites with and without irrigation, respectively) planted as interrows between sugar cane, Kwang Loo and Red Plum Zao, because of their short growing period, matured before the cane canopy had covered the interrows; of the two, Red Plum Zao showed most promise for mixed cultivation with sugar cane under both irrigated and rainfed conditions.

Author: Thornton, B.; Robinson, D.
Title: Uptake and assimilation of nitrogen from solutions containing multiple N sources
Abstract Note: We assessed the extent to which plants can acquire amino acids when supplied as single N-sources or when plants have access to a mixture of amino- and inorganic N sources. Because the uptake of different N-sources is temperature-dependent, the effects of temperature on amino-N uptake were also tested. Lolium perenne (perennial rye-grass) was grown hydroponically at 11°C or 21°C. Uptake of N was determined using 15N tracers at the growth temperature from solutions containing either nitrate, ammonium or glycine as single N sources and from a mixture containing all three N-forms. Estimates of the relative importance of amino acids such as glycine to the total N budget of plants will have been underestimated in studies where uptake was determined in single source solutions compared with those from solutions containing a mixture of N-forms. The proportion of total N acquired from the mixed N source as ammonium increased as temperature was reduced. Regarding the uptake and initial metabolism of glycine, uptake was probably the rate limiting step at 11°C whilst it was the metabolism of glycine to serine at 21°C. Although 15N incorporation into the plant amino-N pool was generally in proportion to the abundance of individual amino acids, its incorporation into the glycine pool was sometimes significantly less than predicted.

Author: Vavilov, P. P.; Makarova, N. A.
Title: Uptake of the chief mineral nutrients by the potato plant in relation to the previous crop and origin of the seed potatoes.
Abstract Note: In 1966-68, early potatoes in a ley rotation, a field-crop rotation, a row-crop rotation and a rotation of grain and row crops on a derno-podzolic soil were respectively preceded by spring wheat following perennial herbage, peas, sugar beet and winter rye following fallow. The potatoes were grown from locally produced seed or from special seed of the same variety (Epron). The N and P contents of the dry matter of the young leaves were higher, and the K content of the dry matter of the stems was lower, in plants from local seed than in those from special seed. N uptake by the plants from special seed was 1.3-1.8 times higher than by those from local seed, P uptake was 1.4-2.2 times higher, and K uptake was 1.6-2.1 times higher. The percentage of N in the total N+P+K in the plants was lower in the plants from special seed, but the K content was higher. Nutrient consumption per ton of tubers was greater by the plants from special seed. The preceding crop did not affect nutrient uptake.[349.1:221.03:282].
Manual Tags: search.wheat; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 (triticum OR wheat)); WOS

Author: DeHaan, Lee R.; Van Tassel, David L.
Title: USEFUL INSIGHTS FROM EVOLUTIONARY BIOLOGY FOR DEVELOPING PERENNIAL GRAIN CROPS
Abstract Note: Annual grain crops dominate agricultural landscapes and provide the majority of calories consumed by humanity. Perennial grain crops could potentially ameliorate the land degradation and off-site impacts associated with annual grain cropping. However, herbaceous perennial plants with constitutively high allocation to harvestable seeds are rare to absent in nature. Recent trade-off theory models suggest that rugged fitness landscapes may explain the absence of this form better than sink competition models. Artificial selection for both grain production and multiyear lifespan can lead to more rapid progress in the face of fitness and genetic trade-offs than natural selection but is likely to result in plant types that differ substantially from all current domestic crops. Perennial grain domestication is also likely to require the development of selection strategies that differ from published crop breeding methods, despite their success in improving long-domesticated crops; for this purpose, we have reviewed literature in the areas of population and evolutionary genetics, domestication, and molecular biology. Rapid domestication will likely require genes with large effect that are expected to exhibit strong pleiotropy and epistasis. Cryptic genetic variation will need to be deliberately exposed both to purge mildly deleterious alleles and to generate novel agronomic phenotypes. We predict that perennial grain domestication programs will benefit from population subdivision followed by selection for simple traits in each subpopulation, the evaluation of very large populations, high selection intensity, rapid cycling through generations, and heterosis. The latter may be particularly beneficial in the development of varieties with stable yield and tolerance to crowding.
Manual Tags: Bottleneck; Domestication; Epigenetics; Epistasis; Evolvability; Genetic assimilation; Genetic load; Perennial grain; Pleiotropy; Scopus; search.grain; SPV; TITLE-ABS-KEY (perennial W/1 grain) AND DOCTYPE (ar); Trade-off; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 grain); WOS

Author: EIDEMANIS, R. I.
Title: Use of a layer of perennial grasses Referat. Zhur., Biol., 1957, No. 17969. (Translation.)
Abstract Note: The conclusion is reached that cultivation in the summer of the layer of mixed grasses before the winter crops does not reduce the harvest of the subsequent crops in comparison with fall plowing of the layer. The layer of mixed grasses the first year of use assures larger harvests of winter rye and spring wheat, than the layer of mixed grasses the second or third year of use. The use of grass mixtures for one year, as compared with their use for two years, does not have a negative effect on the productivity of the following crops in the crop rotation. By the introduction of clover fallows and one-year use of grass mixture it is possible to increase considerably the amount of organic matter accumulating in the soil.

Author: Varga, P.; Majer, J.; Nemeth, C.; Gyorffy-Jahnke, G.; Szoke, B.; Sardi, K.; Salamon, B.
Title: Use of different tillage systems in the vineyard disposed to erosion.
Abstract Note: Grapevine production technology has considerably changed in the past decades. Recently, environmentally sound grapevine tillage approaches are gaining importance and one of their main subjects is the reduction of unfavourable environmental impacts. In the grapevine plantations around the Balaton Region, introduction of tillage systems based on the new concept are especially actual for maintaining the biological balance and water quality of the Lake. In order to study the effects of different tillage systems, an experiment was set up in the year of 2000 at the Research Institute of Viticulture and Oenology in Badacsony, Hungary. The experiment was started at a plot of 'Szurkebarat' variety with the permanent cover cropping of grass, mulching with reed residues, and a conventional mechanical cultivation as a control. A further experiment was set up in 2006 with 'Pinot noir' grapevine variety. Besides of the conventional mechanical cultivation (as a control), influences of permanent mulching of cover crops with low water consumption (a mixture of Festuca ovina and Lolium perenne), mulching with Carex-Phragmites-Solidago, a seasonal cover of rye ( Secale cereale) with triticale and the natural seasonal cover of Stellaria media were compared. In 2007, a plot cropped with perennial rye ( Secale cerale) was involved in the experiment. The main subject of our study was to evaluate the effects of different tillage systems on the available nutrient content and moisture conditions of soil as well as on the main quantity parameters of yield compared to the effects of equivalent nitrogen fertilizer rate (i.e. 55 kg N active agent ha -1 annually). Biggest differences between the effects of treatments could be observed in the NO 3+NO 2-nitrogen content of soil. Highest values were obtained in the plot with conventional mechanical cultivation; verifying the results of literature data. On the other hand, considering soil moisture conditions, significant differences could be observed in plots mulched with crop residues if compared to the other ones. Moisture conservation has become especially important under the extremely dry weather conditions during the last summers in Hungary. When evaluating harvest results, it was established that highest yield levels obtained in the plots of cover-crop mulching with Carex-Phragmites-Solidago might be explained by the favourable moisture content of the soil. Yield results were similar in the plot of mechanical cultivation which was also resulted from the more favourable soil moisture conditions and the high contents of NO 3+NO 2-nitrogen. For the verification of the beneficial effects of treatments applied in our 3 year experiment, further studies are needed and results should be analysed and evaluated.
Manual Tags: search.rye; SPV; TS=(perennial NEAR/1 ("rye" OR secale) NOT "rye$grass"); WOS

Author: Crafts, A.S.
Title: Use of labeled compounds in herbicide research
Publication Title: The International Journal of Applied Radiation and Isotopes
Journal Abbreviation: The International Journal of Applied Radiation and Isotopes
